    
Bleak
House
Charles
Dickens
  
1852
-
-1853
  
Information
about
the
source
     
Chapter
1
.
<EOS>
In
Chancery
 
London
.
 
<EOS>
Michaelmas
term
lately
over
,
and
the
Lord
Chancellor
sitting
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
Hall
.
 
<EOS>
Implacable
November
weather
.
 
<EOS>
As
much
mud
in
the
streets
as
if
the
waters
had
but
newly
retired
from
the
face
of
the
earth
,
and
it
would
not
be
wonderful
to
meet
a
Megalosaurus
,
forty
feet
long
or
so
,
waddling
like
an
elephantine
lizard
up
Holborn
Hill
.
 
<EOS>
Smoke
lowering
down
from
chimney
-
pots
,
making
a
soft
black
drizzle
,
with
flakes
of
soot
in
it
as
big
as
full
-
grown
snowflakes
<EOS>
---
gone
into
mourning
,
one
might
imagine
,
for
the
death
of
the
sun
.
 
<EOS>
Dogs
,
undistinguishable
in
mire
.
 
<EOS>
Horses
,
scarcely
better
;
splashed
to
their
very
blinkers
.
 
<EOS>
Foot
passengers
,
jostling
one
another
's
umbrellas
in
a
general
infection
of
ill
temper
,
and
losing
their
foot
-
hold
at
street
-
corners
,
where
tens
of
thousands
of
other
foot
passengers
have
been
slipping
and
sliding
since
the
day
broke
(
if
this
day
ever
broke
)
,
adding
new
deposits
to
the
crust
upon
crust
of
mud
,
sticking
at
those
points
tenaciously
to
the
pavement
,
and
accumulating
at
compound
interest
.
   
<EOS>
Fog
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
Fog
up
the
river
,
where
it
flows
among
green
aits
and
meadows
;
fog
down
the
river
,
where
it
rolls
deified
among
the
tiers
of
shipping
and
the
waterside
pollutions
of
a
great
(
and
dirty
)
city
.
 
<EOS>
Fog
on
the
Essex
marshes
,
fog
on
the
Kentish
heights
.
<EOS>
Fog
creeping
into
the
cabooses
of
collier
-
brigs
;
fog
lying
out
on
the
yards
and
hovering
in
the
rigging
of
great
ships
;
fog
drooping
on
the
gunwales
of
barges
and
small
boats
.
 
<EOS>
Fog
in
the
eyes
and
throats
of
ancient
Greenwich
pensioners
,
wheezing
by
the
firesides
of
their
wards
;
fog
in
the
stem
and
bowl
of
the
afternoon
pipe
of
the
wrathful
skipper
,
down
in
his
close
cabin
;
fog
cruelly
pinching
the
toes
and
fingers
of
his
shivering
little
'
prentice
boy
on
deck
.
<EOS>
Chance
people
on
the
bridges
peeping
over
the
parapets
into
a
nether
sky
of
fog
,
with
fog
<EOS>
all
round
them
,
as
if
they
were
up
in
a
balloon
and
hanging
in
the
misty
clouds
.
   
<EOS>
Gas
looming
through
the
fog
in
divers
places
in
the
streets
,
much
as
the
sun
may
,
from
the
spongey
fields
,
be
seen
to
loom
by
husbandman
and
ploughboy
.
 
<EOS>
Most
of
the
shops
lighted
two
hours
before
their
time
---
as
the
gas
seems
to
know
,
for
it
has
a
haggard
and
unwilling
look
.
   
<EOS>
The
raw
afternoon
is
rawest
,
and
the
dense
fog
is
densest
,
and
the
muddy
streets
are
muddiest
near
that
leaden
-
headed
old
obstruction
,
appropriate
ornament
for
the
threshold
of
a
leaden
-
headed
old
corporation
,
Temple
Bar
.
 
<EOS>
And
hard
by
Temple
Bar
,
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
Hall
,
at
the
very
heart
of
the
fog
,
sits
the
Lord
High
Chancellor
in
his
High
Court
of
Chancery
.
   
<EOS>
Never
can
there
come
fog
too
thick
,
never
can
there
come
mud
and
mire
too
deep
,
to
assort
with
the
groping
and
floundering
condition
which
this
High
Court
of
Chancery
,
most
pestilent
of
hoary
sinners
,
holds
this
day
in
the
sight
of
heaven
and
earth
.
   
<EOS>
On
such
an
afternoon
,
if
ever
,
the
Lord
High
Chancellor
ought
to
be
sitting
her
---
as
here
he
is
---
with
a
foggy
glory
round
his
head
,
softly
fenced
in
with
crimson
cloth
and
curtains
,
addressed
by
a
large
advocate
with
great
whiskers
,
a
little
voice
,
and
an
interminable
brief
,
and
outwardly
directing
his
contemplation
to
the
lantern
in
the
roof
,
where
he
can
see
nothing
but
fog
.
 
<EOS>
On
such
an
afternoon
some
score
of
members
of
the
High
Court
of
Chancery
bar
ought
to
be
---
as
here
they
are
---
mistily
engaged
in
one
of
the
ten
thousand
stages
of
an
endless
cause
,
tripping
one
another
up
on
slippery
precedents
,
groping
knee
-
deep
in
technicalities
,
running
their
goat
-
hair
and
horsehair
warded
heads
against
walls
of
words
and
making
a
pretence
of
equity
with
serious
faces
,
as
players
might
.
 
<EOS>
On
such
an
afternoon
the
various
solicitors
in
the
cause
,
some
two
or
three
of
whom
have
inherited
it
from
their
fathers
,
who
made
a
fortune
by
it
,
ought
to
be
---
as
are
they
not
?
<EOS>
---
ranged
in
a
line
,
in
a
long
matted
well
<EOS>
(
but
you
might
look
in
vain
for
truth
at
the
bottom
of
it
)
between
the
registrar
's
red
table
and
the
silk
gowns
,
with
bills
,
cross
-
bills
,
answers
,
rejoinders
,
injunctions
,
affidavits
,
issues
,
references
to
masters
,
masters
'
reports
,
mountains
of
costly
nonsense
,
piled
before
them
.
 
<EOS>
Well
may
the
court
be
dim
,
with
wasting
candles
here
and
there
;
well
may
the
fog
hang
heavy
in
it
,
as
if
it
would
never
get
out
;
well
may
the
stained
-
glass
windows
lose
their
colour
and
admit
no
light
of
day
into
the
place
;
well
may
the
uninitiated
from
the
streets
,
who
peep
in
through
the
glass
panes
in
the
door
<EOS>
,
be
deterred
from
entrance
by
its
owlish
aspect
and
by
the
drawl
,
languidly
echoing
to
the
roof
from
the
padded
dais
where
the
Lord
High
Chancellor
looks
into
the
lantern
that
has
no
light
in
it
and
where
the
attendant
wigs
are
all
stuck
in
a
fog
-
bank
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
Court
of
Chancery
,
which
has
its
decaying
houses
and
its
blighted
lands
in
every
shire
,
which
has
its
worn
-
out
lunatic
in
every
madhouse
and
its
dead
in
every
churchyard
,
which
has
its
ruined
suitor
with
his
slipshod
heels
and
threadbare
dress
borrowing
and
begging
through
the
round
of
every
man
's
acquaintance
,
which
gives
to
monied
<EOS>
might
the
means
abundantly
of
wearying
out
the
right
,
which
so
exhausts
finances
,
patience
,
courage
,
hope
,
so
overthrows
the
brain
and
breaks
the
heart
,
that
there
is
not
an
honourable
man
among
its
practitioners
who
would
not
give
---
who
does
not
often
give
---
the
warning
,
"
<EOS>
Suffer
any
wrong
that
can
be
done
you
rather
than
come
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
Who
happen
to
be
in
the
Lord
Chancellor
's
court
this
murky
afternoon
besides
the
Lord
Chancellor
,
the
counsel
in
the
cause
,
two
or
three
counsel
who
are
never
in
any
cause
,
and
the
well
of
solicitors
before
mentioned
?
 
<EOS>
There
is
the
registrar
below
the
judge
,
in
wig
and
gown
;
and
there
are
two
or
three
maces
,
or
petty
-
bags
,
or
privy
purses
,
or
whatever
they
may
be
,
in
legal
court
suits
.
 
<EOS>
These
are
all
yawning
,
for
no
crumb
of
amusement
<EOS>
ever
falls
from
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
(
the
cause
in
hand
)
,
which
was
squeezed
dry
years
upon
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
The
short
-
hand
writers
,
the
reporters
of
the
court
,
and
the
reporters
of
the
newspapers
invariably
decamp
with
the
rest
of
the
regulars
when
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
comes
on
.
<EOS>
Their
places
are
a
blank
.
 
<EOS>
Standing
on
a
seat
at
the
side
of
the
hall
,
the
better
to
peer
into
the
curtained
sanctuary
,
is
a
little
mad
old
woman
in
a
squeezed
bonnet
who
is
always
in
court
,
from
its
sitting
to
its
rising
,
and
always
expecting
some
incomprehensible
judgment
to
be
given
in
her
favour
.
 
<EOS>
Some
say
she
really
is
,
or
was
,
a
party
to
a
suit
,
but
no
one
knows
for
certain
because
no
one
cares
.
 
<EOS>
She
carries
some
small
litter
in
a
reticule
which
she
calls
her
documents
,
principally
consisting
of
paper
matches
and
dry
lavender
.
 
<EOS>
A
sallow
prisoner
has
come
up
,
in
custody
,
for
the
half
-
dozenth
time
to
make
a
personal
application
"
to
purge
himself
of
his
contempt
,
"
which
,
being
a
solitary
surviving
executor
who
has
fallen
into
a
state
of
conglomeration
about
accounts
of
which
it
is
not
pretended
that
he
had
ever
any
knowledge
,
he
is
not
at
all
likely
ever
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
his
prospects
in
life
are
ended
.
 
<EOS>
Another
ruined
suitor
,
who
periodically
appears
from
Shropshire
and
breaks
out
into
efforts
to
address
the
Chancellor
at
the
close
of
the
day
's
business
and
who
can
by
no
means
be
made
to
understand
that
the
Chancellor
is
legally
ignorant
of
his
existence
after
making
it
desolate
for
a
quarter
of
a
century
,
plants
himself
in
a
good
place
and
keeps
an
eye
on
the
judge
,
ready
to
call
out
"
My
Lord
!
"
<EOS>
in
a
voice
of
sonorous
complaint
on
the
instant
of
his
rising
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
lawyers
'
clerks
and
others
who
know
this
suitor
by
sight
linger
on
the
chance
of
his
furnishing
some
fun
and
enlivening
the
dismal
weather
a
little
.
   
<EOS>
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
drones
on
.
 
<EOS>
This
scarecrow
of
a
suit
has
,
in
course
of
time
,
become
so
complicated
that
no
man
alive
knows
what
it
means
.
 
<EOS>
The
parties
to
it
understand
it
least
,
but
it
has
been
observed
that
no
two
Chancery
lawyers
can
talk
about
it
for
five
minutes
without
coming
to
a
total
disagreement
as
to
all
the
premises
.
 
<EOS>
Innumerable
children
have
been
born
into
the
cause
;
innumerable
young
people
have
married
into
it
;
innumerable
old
people
have
died
out
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Scores
of
persons
have
deliriously
found
themselves
made
parties
in
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
without
knowing
how
or
why
;
whole
families
have
inherited
legendary
hatreds
with
the
suit
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
plaintiff
or
defendant
who
was
promised
a
new
rocking
-
horse
when
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
should
be
settled
has
grown
up
,
possessed
himself
of
a
real
horse
,
and
trotted
away
into
the
other
world
.
 
<EOS>
Fair
wards
of
court
have
faded
into
mothers
and
grandmothers
;
a
long
procession
of
Chancellors
has
come
in
and
gone
out
;
the
legion
of
bills
in
the
suit
have
been
transformed
into
mere
bills
of
mortality
;
there
are
not
three
Jarndyces
left
upon
the
earth
perhaps
since
old
Tom
Jarndyce
in
despair
blew
his
brains
out
at
a
coffee
-
house
in
Chancery
Lane
;
but
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
still
drags
its
dreary
length
before
the
court
,
perennially
hopeless
.
   
<EOS>
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
has
passed
into
a
joke
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
the
only
good
that
has
ever
come
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
death
to
many
,
but
it
is
a
joke
in
the
profession
.
 
<EOS>
Every
master
in
Chancery
has
had
a
reference
out
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Every
Chancellor
was
"
in
it
,
"
for
somebody
or
other
,
when
he
was
counsel
at
the
bar
.
 
<EOS>
Good
things
have
been
said
about
it
by
blue
-
nosed
,
bulbous
-
shoed
old
benchers
in
select
port
-
wine
committee
after
dinner
in
hall
.
 
<EOS>
Articled
clerks
have
been
in
the
habit
of
fleshing
their
legal
wit
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
last
Lord
Chancellor
handled
it
neatly
,
when
,
correcting
Mr
Blowers
,
the
eminent
silk
gown
who
said
that
such
a
thing
might
happen
when
the
sky
rained
potatoes
,
he
observed
,
"
or
when
we
get
through
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
,
Mr
Blowers
"
---
a
pleasantry
that
particularly
tickled
the
maces
,
bags
,
and
purses
.
   
<EOS>
How
many
people
out
of
the
suit
<EOS>
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
has
stretched
forth
its
unwholesome
hand
to
spoil
and
corrupt
would
be
a
very
wide
question
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
master
upon
whose
impaling
files
reams
of
dusty
warrants
in
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
have
grimly
writhed
into
many
shapes
,
down
to
the
copying
-
clerk
in
the
Six
Clerks
'
Office
who
has
copied
his
tens
of
thousands
of
Chancery
folio
-
pages
under
that
eternal
heading
,
no
man
's
nature
has
been
made
better
by
it
.
<EOS>
In
trickery
,
evasion
,
procrastination
,
spoliation
,
botheration
,
under
false
pretences
of
all
sorts
,
there
are
influences
that
can
never
come
to
good
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
solicitors
'
boys
who
have
kept
the
wretched
suitors
at
bay
,
by
protesting
time
out
of
mind
that
Mr
Chizzle
,
Mizzle
,
or
otherwise
was
particularly
engaged
and
had
appointments
until
dinner
,
may
have
got
an
extra
moral
twist
and
shuffle
into
themselves
out
of
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
The
receiver
in
the
cause
has
acquired
a
goodly
sum
of
money
by
it
but
has
acquired
too
a
distrust
of
his
own
mother
and
a
contempt
for
his
own
kind
.
 
<EOS>
Chizzle
,
Mizzle
,
and
otherwise
have
lapsed
into
a
habit
of
vaguely
promising
themselves
that
they
will
look
into
that
outstanding
little
matter
and
see
what
can
be
done
for
Drizzle
---
who
was
not
well
used
---
when
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
shall
be
got
out
of
the
office
.
 
<EOS>
Shirking
and
sharking
in
all
their
many
varieties
have
been
sown
broadcast
by
the
ill
-
fated
cause
;
and
even
those
who
have
contemplated
its
history
from
the
outermost
circle
of
such
evil
have
been
insensibly
tempted
into
a
loose
way
of
letting
bad
things
alone
to
take
their
own
bad
course
,
and
a
loose
belief
that
if
the
world
go
wrong
it
was
in
some
off
-
hand
manner
never
meant
to
go
right
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
,
in
the
midst
of
the
mud
and
at
the
heart
of
the
fog
,
sits
the
Lord
High
Chancellor
in
his
High
Court
of
Chancery
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tangle
,
"
says
the
Lord
High
Chancellor
,
latterly
something
restless
under
the
eloquence
of
that
learned
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mlud
,
"
says
Mr
Tangle
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tangle
knows
more
of
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
than
anybody
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
famous
for
it
---
supposed
never
to
have
read
anything
else
since
he
left
school
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
nearly
concluded
your
argument
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mlud
,
no
---
variety
of
points
---
feel
it
my
duty
tsubmit
---
ludship
,
"
is
the
reply
that
slides
out
of
Mr
Tangle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Several
members
of
the
bar
are
still
to
be
heard
,
I
believe
?
"
says
the
Chancellor
with
a
slight
smile
.
   
<EOS>
Eighteen
of
Mr
Tangle
's
learned
friends
,
each
armed
with
a
little
summary
of
eighteen
hundred
sheets
,
bob
up
like
eighteen
hammers
in
a
pianoforte
,
make
eighteen
bows
,
and
drop
into
their
eighteen
places
of
obscurity
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
will
proceed
with
the
hearing
on
Wednesday
fortnight
,
"
says
the
Chancellor
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
question
at
issue
is
only
a
question
of
costs
,
a
mere
bud
on
the
forest
tree
of
the
parent
suit
,
and
really
will
come
to
a
settlement
one
of
these
days
.
   
<EOS>
The
Chancellor
rises
;
the
bar
rises
;
the
prisoner
is
brought
forward
in
a
hurry
;
the
man
from
Shropshire
cries
,
"
My
lord
!
"
<EOS>
Maces
,
bags
,
and
purses
indignantly
proclaim
silence
and
frown
at
the
man
from
Shropshire
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
reference
,
"
proceeds
the
Chancellor
,
still
on
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
,
"
to
the
young
girl
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Begludship
's
pardon
---
boy
,
"
says
Mr
Tangle
prematurely
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
reference
,
"
proceeds
the
Chancellor
with
extra
distinctness
,
"
to
the
young
girl
and
boy
,
the
two
young
people
"
---
<EOS>
Mr
Tangle
crushed
---
 
"
whom
I
directed
to
be
in
attendance
to
-
day
and
who
are
now
in
my
private
room
,
I
will
see
them
and
satisfy
myself
as
to
the
expediency
of
making
the
order
for
their
residing
with
their
uncle
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tangle
on
his
legs
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Begludship
's
pardon
---
dead
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
their
"
---
Chancellor
looking
through
his
double
eyeglass
at
the
papers
on
his
desk
---
"
grandfather
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Begludship
's
pardon
---
victim
of
rash
action
---
brains
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Suddenly
a
very
little
counsel
with
a
terrific
bass
voice
arises
,
fully
inflated
,
in
the
back
settlements
of
the
fog
,
and
says
,
"
Will
your
lordship
allow
me
?
 
<EOS>
I
appear
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
cousin
,
several
times
removed
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
at
the
moment
prepared
to
inform
the
court
in
what
exact
remove
he
is
a
cousin
,
but
he
IS
a
cousin
.
   
<EOS>
Leaving
this
address
(
delivered
like
a
sepulchral
message
)
ringing
in
the
rafters
of
the
roof
,
the
very
little
counsel
drops
,
and
the
fog
knows
him
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
looks
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
can
see
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
speak
with
both
the
young
people
,
"
says
the
Chancellor
anew
,
"
and
satisfy
myself
on
the
subject
of
their
residing
with
their
cousin
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
mention
the
matter
to
-
morrow
morning
when
I
take
my
seat
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Chancellor
is
about
to
bow
to
the
bar
when
the
prisoner
is
presented
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
can
possibly
come
of
the
prisoner
's
conglomeration
but
his
being
sent
back
to
prison
,
which
is
soon
done
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
from
Shropshire
ventures
another
remonstrative
"
My
lord
!
"
<EOS>
but
the
Chancellor
,
being
aware
of
him
,
has
dexterously
vanished
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
else
quickly
vanishes
too
.
 
<EOS>
A
battery
of
blue
bags
is
loaded
with
heavy
charges
of
papers
and
carried
off
by
clerks
;
the
little
mad
old
woman
marches
off
with
her
documents
;
the
empty
court
is
locked
up
.
 
<EOS>
If
all
the
injustice
it
has
committed
and
all
the
misery
it
has
caused
could
only
be
locked
up
with
it
,
and
the
whole
burnt
away
in
a
great
funeral
pyre
---
why
so
much
the
better
for
other
parties
than
the
parties
in
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
!
    
Chapter
2
.
<EOS>
In
Fashion
 
It
is
but
a
glimpse
of
the
world
of
fashion
that
we
want
on
this
same
miry
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
so
unlike
the
Court
of
Chancery
but
<EOS>
that
we
may
pass
from
the
one
scene
to
the
other
,
as
the
crow
flies
.
 
<EOS>
Both
the
world
of
fashion
and
the
Court
of
Chancery
are
things
of
precedent
and
usage
:
oversleeping
Rip
Van
Winkles
who
have
played
at
strange
games
through
a
deal
of
thundery
weather
;
sleeping
beauties
whom
the
knight
will
wake
one
day
,
when
all
the
stopped
spits
in
the
kitchen
shall
begin
to
turn
prodigiously
!
   
<EOS>
It
is
not
a
large
world
.
 
<EOS>
Relatively
even
to
this
world
of
ours
,
which
has
its
limits
too
(
as
your
Highness
shall
find
when
you
have
made
the
tour
of
it
and
are
come
to
the
brink
of
the
void
beyond
)
,
it
is
a
very
little
speck
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
much
good
in
it
;
there
are
many
good
and
true
people
in
it
;
it
has
its
appointed
place
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
evil
of
it
is
that
it
is
a
world
wrapped
up
in
too
much
jeweller
's
cotton
and
fine
wool
,
and
can
not
hear
the
rushing
of
the
larger
worlds
,
and
can
not
see
them
as
they
circle
round
the
sun
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
deadened
world
,
and
its
growth
is
sometimes
unhealthy
for
want
of
air
.
   
<EOS>
My
Lady
Dedlock
has
returned
to
her
house
in
town
for
a
few
days
previous
to
her
departure
for
Paris
,
where
her
ladyship
intends
to
stay
some
weeks
,
after
which
her
movements
are
uncertain
.
 
<EOS>
The
fashionable
intelligence
says
so
for
the
comfort
of
the
Parisians
,
and
it
knows
all
fashionable
things
.
 
<EOS>
To
know
things
otherwise
were
to
be
unfashionable
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
Dedlock
has
been
down
at
what
she
calls
,
in
familiar
conversation
,
her
"
place
"
in
Lincolnshire
.
 
<EOS>
The
waters
are
out
in
Lincolnshire
.
 
<EOS>
An
arch
of
the
bridge
in
the
park
has
been
sapped
and
sopped
away
.
 
<EOS>
The
adjacent
low
-
lying
ground
for
half
a
mile
in
breadth
is
a
stagnant
river
with
melancholy
trees
for
islands
in
it
and
a
surface
punctured
all
over
,
all
day
long
,
with
falling
rain
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
Dedlock
's
place
has
been
extremely
dreary
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
for
many
a
day
and
night
has
been
so
wet
that
the
trees
seem
wet
through
,
and
the
soft
loppings
and
prunings
of
the
woodman
's
axe
can
make
no
crash
or
crackle
as
they
fall
.
 
<EOS>
The
deer
,
looking
soaked
,
leave
quagmires
where
they
pass
.
 
<EOS>
The
shot
of
a
rifle
loses
its
sharpness
in
the
moist
air
,
and
its
smoke
moves
in
a
tardy
little
cloud
towards
the
green
rise
,
coppice
-
topped
,
that
makes
a
background
for
the
falling
rain
.
 
<EOS>
The
view
from
my
Lady
Dedlock
's
own
windows
is
alternately
a
lead
-
coloured
view
and
a
view
in
Indian
ink
.
 
<EOS>
The
vases
on
the
stone
terrace
in
the
foreground
catch
the
rain
all
day
;
and
the
heavy
drops
fall
---
drip
,
drip
,
drip
---
upon
the
broad
flagged
pavement
,
called
from
old
time
the
Ghost
's
Walk
,
all
night
.
 
<EOS>
On
Sundays
the
little
church
in
the
park
is
mouldy
;
the
oaken
pulpit
breaks
out
into
a
cold
sweat
;
and
there
is
a
general
smell
and
taste
as
of
the
ancient
Dedlocks
in
their
graves
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
Dedlock
(
who
is
childless
)
,
looking
out
in
the
early
twilight
from
her
boudoir
at
a
keeper
's
lodge
and
seeing
the
light
of
a
fire
upon
the
latticed
panes
,
and
smoke
rising
from
the
chimney
,
and
a
child
,
chased
by
a
woman
,
running
out
into
the
rain
to
meet
the
shining
figure
of
a
wrapped
-
up
man
coming
through
the
gate
,
has
been
put
quite
out
of
temper
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
Dedlock
says
she
has
been
"
bored
to
death
.
"
   
<EOS>
Therefore
my
Lady
Dedlock
has
come
away
from
the
place
in
Lincolnshire
and
has
left
it
to
the
rain
,
and
the
crows
,
and
the
rabbits
,
and
the
deer
,
and
the
partridges
and
pheasants
.
 
<EOS>
The
pictures
of
the
Dedlocks
past
and
gone
have
seemed
to
vanish
into
the
damp
walls
in
mere
lowness
of
spirits
,
as
the
housekeeper
has
passed
along
the
old
rooms
shutting
up
the
shutters
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
they
will
next
come
forth
again
,
the
fashionable
intelligence
---
which
,
like
the
fiend
,
is
omniscient
of
the
past
and
present
,
but
not
the
future
---
can
not
yet
undertake
to
say
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
is
only
a
baronet
,
but
there
is
no
mightier
baronet
than
he
.
 
<EOS>
His
family
is
as
old
as
the
hills
,
and
infinitely
more
respectable
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
general
opinion
that
the
world
might
get
on
without
hills
but
would
be
done
up
without
Dedlocks
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
on
the
whole
admit
nature
to
be
a
good
idea
(
a
little
low
,
perhaps
,
when
not
enclosed
with
a
park
-
fence
)
,
but
an
idea
dependent
for
its
execution
on
your
great
county
families
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
gentleman
of
strict
conscience
,
disdainful
of
all
littleness
and
meanness
and
ready
on
the
shortest
notice
to
die
any
death
you
may
please
to
mention
rather
than
give
occasion
for
the
least
impeachment
of
his
integrity
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
an
honourable
,
obstinate
,
truthful
,
high
-
spirited
,
intensely
prejudiced
,
perfectly
unreasonable
man
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
is
twenty
years
,
full
measure
,
older
than
my
Lady
.
<EOS>
He
will
never
see
sixty
-
five
again
,
nor
perhaps
sixty
-
six
,
nor
yet
sixty
-
seven
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
twist
of
the
gout
now
and
then
and
walks
a
little
stiffly
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
of
a
worthy
presence
,
with
his
light
-
grey
hair
and
whiskers
,
his
fine
shirt
-
frill
,
his
pure
-
white
waistcoat
,
and
his
blue
coat
with
bright
buttons
always
buttoned
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
ceremonious
,
stately
,
most
polite
on
every
occasion
to
my
Lady
,
and
holds
her
personal
attractions
in
the
highest
estimation
.
 
<EOS>
His
gallantry
to
my
Lady
,
which
has
never
changed
since
he
courted
her
,
is
the
one
little
touch
of
romantic
fancy
in
him
.
   
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
married
her
for
love
.
 
<EOS>
A
whisper
still
goes
about
that
she
had
not
even
family
;
howbeit
,
Sir
Leicester
had
so
much
family
that
perhaps
he
had
enough
and
could
dispense
with
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
had
beauty
,
pride
,
ambition
,
insolent
resolve
,
and
sense
enough
to
portion
out
a
legion
of
fine
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
Wealth
and
station
,
added
to
these
,
soon
floated
her
upward
,
and
for
years
now
my
Lady
Dedlock
has
been
at
the
centre
of
the
fashionable
intelligence
and
at
the
top
of
the
fashionable
tree
.
   
<EOS>
How
Alexander
wept
when
he
had
no
more
worlds
to
conquer
,
everybody
knows
---
or
has
some
reason
to
know
by
this
time
,
the
matter
having
been
rather
frequently
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
Dedlock
,
having
conquered
HER
world
,
fell
not
into
the
melting
,
but
rather
into
the
freezing
,
mood
.
 
<EOS>
An
exhausted
composure
,
a
worn
-
out
placidity
,
an
equanimity
of
fatigue
not
to
be
ruffled
by
interest
or
satisfaction
,
are
the
trophies
of
her
victory
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
perfectly
well
-
bred
.
<EOS>
If
she
could
be
translated
to
heaven
to
-
morrow
,
she
might
be
expected
to
ascend
without
any
rapture
.
   
<EOS>
She
has
beauty
still
,
and
if
it
be
not
in
its
heyday
,
it
is
not
yet
in
its
autumn
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
a
fine
face
---
originally
of
a
character
that
would
be
rather
called
very
pretty
than
handsome
,
but
improved
into
classicality
by
the
acquired
expression
of
her
fashionable
state
.
<EOS>
Her
figure
is
elegant
and
has
the
effect
of
being
tall
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
she
is
so
,
but
that
"
the
most
is
made
,
"
as
the
Honourable
Bob
Stables
has
frequently
asserted
upon
oath
,
"
of
all
her
points
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
same
authority
observes
that
she
is
perfectly
got
up
and
remarks
in
commendation
of
her
hair
especially
that
she
is
the
best
-
groomed
woman
in
the
whole
stud
.
   
<EOS>
With
all
her
perfections
on
her
head
,
my
Lady
Dedlock
has
come
up
from
her
place
in
Lincolnshire
(
hotly
pursued
by
the
fashionable
intelligence
)
to
pass
a
few
days
at
her
house
in
town
previous
to
her
departure
for
Paris
,
where
her
ladyship
intends
to
stay
some
weeks
,
after
which
her
movements
are
uncertain
.
 
<EOS>
And
at
her
house
in
town
,
upon
this
muddy
,
murky
afternoon
,
presents
himself
an
old
-
fashioned
old
gentleman
,
attorney
-
at
-
law
and
eke
solicitor
of
the
High
Court
of
Chancery
,
who
has
the
honour
of
acting
as
legal
adviser
of
the
Dedlocks
and
has
as
many
cast
-
iron
boxes
in
his
office
with
that
name
outside
as
if
the
present
baronet
were
the
coin
of
the
conjuror
's
trick
and
were
constantly
being
juggled
through
the
whole
set
.
 
<EOS>
Across
the
hall
,
and
up
the
stairs
,
and
along
the
passages
,
and
through
the
rooms
,
which
are
very
brilliant
in
the
season
and
very
dismal
out
of
it
---
fairy
-
land
to
visit
,
but
a
desert
to
live
in
---
the
old
gentleman
is
conducted
by
a
Mercury
in
powder
to
my
Lady
's
presence
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
is
rusty
to
look
at
,
but
is
reputed
to
have
made
good
thrift
out
of
aristocratic
marriage
settlements
and
aristocratic
wills
,
and
to
be
very
rich
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
surrounded
by
a
mysterious
halo
of
family
confidences
,
of
which
he
is
known
to
be
the
silent
depository
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
noble
mausoleums
rooted
for
centuries
in
retired
glades
of
parks
among
the
growing
timber
and
the
fern
,
which
perhaps
hold
fewer
noble
secrets
than
walk
abroad
among
men
,
shut
up
in
the
breast
of
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
of
what
is
called
the
old
school
---
a
phrase
generally
meaning
any
school
that
seems
never
to
have
been
young
---
and
wears
knee
-
breeches
tied
with
ribbons
,
and
gaiters
or
stockings
.
 
<EOS>
One
peculiarity
of
his
black
clothes
and
of
his
black
stockings
,
be
they
silk
or
worsted
,
is
that
they
never
shine
.
 
<EOS>
Mute
,
close
,
irresponsive
to
any
glancing
light
,
his
dress
is
like
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
converses
when
not
professionally
consulted
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
found
sometimes
,
speechless
but
quite
at
home
,
at
corners
of
dinner
-
tables
in
great
country
houses
and
near
doors
of
drawing
-
rooms
,
concerning
which
the
fashionable
intelligence
is
eloquent
,
where
everybody
knows
him
and
where
half
the
Peerage
stops
to
say
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
receives
these
salutations
with
gravity
and
buries
them
along
with
the
rest
of
his
knowledge
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
is
with
my
Lady
and
is
happy
to
see
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
an
air
of
prescription
about
him
which
is
always
agreeable
to
Sir
Leicester
;
he
receives
it
as
a
kind
of
tribute
.
 
<EOS>
He
likes
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
dress
;
there
is
a
kind
of
tribute
in
that
too
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
eminently
respectable
,
and
likewise
,
in
a
general
way
,
retainer
-
like
.
 
<EOS>
It
expresses
,
as
it
were
,
the
steward
of
the
legal
mysteries
,
the
butler
of
the
legal
cellar
,
of
the
Dedlocks
.
   
<EOS>
Has
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
any
idea
of
this
himself
?
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
so
,
or
it
may
not
,
but
there
is
this
remarkable
circumstance
to
be
noted
in
everything
associated
with
my
Lady
Dedlock
as
one
of
a
class
---
as
one
of
the
leaders
and
representatives
of
her
little
world
.
 
<EOS>
She
supposes
herself
to
be
an
inscrutable
Being
,
quite
out
of
the
reach
and
ken
of
ordinary
mortals
---
seeing
herself
in
her
glass
,
where
indeed
she
looks
so
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
every
dim
little
star
revolving
about
her
,
from
her
maid
to
the
manager
of
the
Italian
Opera
,
knows
her
weaknesses
,
prejudices
,
follies
,
haughtinesses
,
and
caprices
and
lives
upon
as
accurate
a
calculation
and
as
nice
a
measure
of
her
moral
nature
as
her
dressmaker
takes
of
her
physical
proportions
.
<EOS>
Is
a
new
dress
,
a
new
custom
,
a
new
singer
,
a
new
dancer
,
a
new
form
of
jewellery
,
a
new
dwarf
or
giant
,
a
new
chapel
,
a
new
anything
,
to
be
set
up
?
 
<EOS>
There
are
deferential
people
in
a
dozen
callings
whom
my
Lady
Dedlock
suspects
of
nothing
but
prostration
before
her
,
who
can
tell
you
how
to
manage
her
as
if
she
were
a
baby
,
who
do
nothing
but
nurse
her
all
their
lives
,
who
,
humbly
affecting
to
follow
with
profound
subservience
,
lead
her
and
her
whole
troop
after
them
;
who
,
in
hooking
one
,
hook
all
and
bear
them
off
as
Lemuel
Gulliver
bore
away
the
stately
fleet
of
the
majestic
Lilliput
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
want
to
address
our
people
,
sir
,
"
say
Blaze
and
Sparkle
,
the
jewellers
---
<EOS>
meaning
by
our
people
Lady
Dedlock
and
the
rest
---
"
you
must
remember
that
you
are
not
dealing
with
the
general
public
;
you
must
hit
our
people
in
their
weakest
place
,
and
their
weakest
place
is
such
a
place
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
To
make
this
article
go
down
,
gentlemen
,
"
say
Sheen
and
Gloss
,
the
mercers
,
to
their
friends
the
manufacturers
,
"
you
must
come
to
us
,
because
we
know
where
to
have
the
fashionable
people
,
and
we
can
make
it
fashionable
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
want
to
get
this
print
upon
the
tables
of
my
high
connexion
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
Sladdery
,
the
librarian
,
"
or
if
you
want
to
get
this
dwarf
or
giant
into
the
houses
of
my
high
connexion
,
sir
,
or
if
you
want
to
secure
to
this
entertainment
the
patronage
of
my
high
connexion
,
sir
,
you
must
leave
it
,
if
you
please
,
to
me
,
for
I
have
been
accustomed
to
study
the
leaders
of
my
high
connexion
,
sir
,
and
I
may
tell
you
without
vanity
that
I
can
turn
them
round
my
finger
"
---
 
in
which
Mr
Sladdery
,
who
is
an
honest
man
,
does
not
exaggerate
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
Therefore
,
while
Mr
Tulkinghorn
may
not
know
what
is
passing
in
the
Dedlock
mind
at
present
,
it
is
very
possible
that
he
may
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
Lady
's
cause
has
been
again
before
the
Chancellor
,
has
it
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
?
"
says
Sir
Leicester
,
giving
him
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
on
again
to
-
day
,
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
replies
,
making
one
of
his
quiet
bows
to
my
Lady
,
who
is
on
a
sofa
near
the
fire
,
shading
her
face
with
a
hand
-
screen
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
useless
to
ask
,
"
says
my
Lady
with
the
dreariness
of
the
place
in
Lincolnshire
still
upon
her
,
"
whether
anything
has
been
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
that
YOU
would
call
anything
has
been
done
to
-
day
,
"
replies
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nor
ever
will
be
,
"
says
my
Lady
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
has
no
objection
to
an
interminable
Chancery
suit
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
slow
,
expensive
,
British
,
constitutional
kind
of
thing
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
he
has
not
a
vital
interest
in
the
suit
in
question
,
her
part
in
which
was
the
only
property
my
Lady
brought
him
;
and
he
has
a
shadowy
impression
that
for
his
name
---
the
name
of
Dedlock
---
to
be
in
a
cause
,
and
not
in
the
title
of
that
cause
,
is
a
most
ridiculous
accident
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
regards
the
Court
of
Chancery
,
even
if
it
should
involve
an
occasional
delay
of
justice
and
a
trifling
amount
of
confusion
,
as
a
something
devised
in
conjunction
with
a
variety
of
other
somethings
by
the
perfection
of
human
wisdom
for
the
eternal
settlement
(
humanly
speaking
)
of
everything
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
is
upon
the
whole
of
a
fixed
opinion
that
to
give
the
sanction
of
his
countenance
to
any
complaints
respecting
it
would
be
to
encourage
some
person
in
the
lower
classes
to
rise
up
somewhere
---
like
Wat
Tyler
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
a
few
fresh
affidavits
have
been
put
upon
the
file
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
"
and
as
they
are
short
,
and
<EOS>
as
I
proceed
upon
the
troublesome
principle
of
begging
leave
to
possess
my
clients
with
any
new
proceedings
in
a
cause
"
---
cautious
man
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
taking
no
more
responsibility
than
necessary
---
"
and
further
,
as
I
see
you
are
going
to
Paris
,
I
have
brought
them
in
my
pocket
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
(
Sir
Leicester
was
going
to
Paris
too
,
by
the
by
,
but
the
delight
of
the
fashionable
intelligence
was
in
his
Lady
.
)
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
takes
out
his
papers
,
asks
permission
to
place
them
on
a
golden
talisman
of
a
table
at
my
Lady
's
elbow
,
puts
on
his
spectacles
,
and
begins
to
read
by
the
light
of
a
shaded
lamp
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
In
Chancery
.
 
<EOS>
Between
John
Jarndyce
---
"
"
   
My
Lady
interrupts
,
requesting
him
to
miss
as
many
of
the
formal
horrors
as
he
can
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
glances
over
his
spectacles
and
begins
again
lower
down
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
carelessly
and
scornfully
abstracts
her
attention
.
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
in
a
great
chair
looks
at
the
file
and
appears
to
have
a
stately
liking
for
the
legal
repetitions
and
prolixities
as
ranging
among
the
national
bulwarks
.
 
<EOS>
It
happens
that
the
fire
is
hot
where
my
Lady
sits
and
that
the
hand
-
screen
is
more
beautiful
than
useful
,
being
priceless
but
small
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
,
changing
her
position
,
sees
the
papers
on
the
table
---
looks
at
them
nearer
---
looks
at
them
nearer
still
---
asks
impulsively
,
"
Who
copied
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
stops
short
,
surprised
by
my
Lady
's
animation
and
her
unusual
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
what
you
people
call
law
-
hand
?
"
<EOS>
she
asks
,
looking
full
at
him
in
her
careless
way
again
and
toying
with
her
screen
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
.
 
<EOS>
Probably
"
---
Mr
Tulkinghorn
examines
it
as
he
speaks
---
 
"
the
legal
character
which
it
has
was
acquired
after
the
original
hand
was
formed
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
ask
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Anything
to
vary
this
detestable
monotony
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
go
on
,
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
reads
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
heat
is
greater
;
my
Lady
screens
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
dozes
,
starts
up
suddenly
,
and
cries
,
"
Eh
?
<EOS>
What
do
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
I
am
afraid
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
who
had
risen
hastily
,
"
that
Lady
Dedlock
is
ill
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Faint
,
"
my
Lady
murmurs
with
white
lips
,
"
only
that
;
but
it
is
like
the
faintness
of
death
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
speak
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Ring
,
and
take
me
to
my
room
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
retires
into
another
chamber
;
bells
ring
,
feet
shuffle
and
patter
,
silence
ensues
.
 
<EOS>
Mercury
at
last
begs
Mr
Tulkinghorn
to
return
.
   
<EOS>
"
Better
now
,
"
quoth
Sir
Leicester
,
motioning
the
lawyer
to
sit
down
and
read
to
him
alone
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
quite
alarmed
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
knew
my
Lady
swoon
before
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
weather
is
extremely
trying
,
and
she
really
has
been
bored
to
death
down
at
our
place
in
Lincolnshire
.
"
    
Chapter
3
.
<EOS>
A
Progress
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
great
deal
of
difficulty
in
beginning
to
write
my
portion
of
these
pages
,
for
I
know
I
am
not
clever
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
knew
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
remember
,
when
I
was
a
very
little
girl
indeed
,
I
used
to
say
to
my
doll
when
we
were
alone
together
,
"
Now
,
Dolly
,
I
am
not
clever
,
you
know
very
well
,
and
you
must
be
patient
with
me
,
like
a
dear
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
so
she
used
to
sit
propped
up
in
a
great
arm
-
chair
,
with
her
beautiful
complexion
and
rosy
lips
,
staring
at
me
---
or
not
so
much
at
me
,
I
think
,
as
at
nothing
---
while
I
busily
stitched
away
and
told
her
every
one
of
my
secrets
.
   
<EOS>
My
dear
old
doll
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
such
a
shy
little
thing
that
I
seldom
dared
to
open
my
lips
,
and
never
dared
to
open
my
heart
,
to
anybody
else
.
 
<EOS>
It
almost
makes
me
cry
to
think
what
a
relief
it
used
to
be
to
me
when
I
came
home
from
school
of
a
day
to
run
upstairs
to
my
room
and
say
,
"
Oh
,
you
dear
faithful
Dolly
,
I
knew
you
would
be
expecting
me
!
"
<EOS>
and
then
to
sit
down
on
the
floor
,
leaning
on
the
elbow
of
her
great
chair
,
and
tell
her
all
I
had
noticed
since
we
parted
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
always
rather
a
noticing
way
---
not
a
quick
way
,
<EOS>
oh
,
no
!
---
a
silent
way
of
noticing
what
passed
before
me
and
thinking
I
should
like
to
understand
it
better
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
by
any
means
a
quick
understanding
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
love
a
person
very
tenderly
indeed
,
it
seems
to
brighten
.
 
<EOS>
But
even
that
may
be
my
vanity
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
brought
up
,
from
my
earliest
remembrance
---
like
some
of
the
princesses
in
the
fairy
stories
,
only
I
was
not
charming
---
by
my
godmother
.
 
<EOS>
At
least
,
I
only
knew
her
as
such
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
good
,
good
woman
!
 
<EOS>
She
went
to
church
three
times
every
Sunday
,
and
to
morning
prayers
on
Wednesdays
and
Fridays
,
and
to
lectures
whenever
there
were
lectures
;
and
never
missed
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
handsome
;
and
if
she
had
ever
smiled
,
would
have
been
<EOS>
(
I
used
to
think
)
like
an
angel
---
but
she
never
smiled
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
always
grave
and
strict
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
very
good
herself
<EOS>
,
I
thought
,
that
the
badness
of
other
people
made
her
frown
all
her
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
so
different
from
her
,
even
making
every
allowance
for
the
differences
between
a
child
and
a
woman
;
I
felt
so
poor
,
so
trifling
,
and
so
far
off
that
I
never
could
be
unrestrained
with
her
---
<EOS>
no
,
could
never
even
love
her
as
I
wished
.
 
<EOS>
It
made
me
very
sorry
to
consider
how
good
she
was
and
how
unworthy
of
her
<EOS>
I
was
,
and
I
used
ardently
to
hope
that
I
might
have
a
better
heart
;
and
I
talked
it
over
very
often
with
the
dear
old
doll
,
but
I
never
loved
my
godmother
as
I
ought
to
have
loved
her
<EOS>
and
as
I
felt
I
must
have
loved
her
if
I
had
been
a
better
girl
.
   
<EOS>
This
made
me
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
more
timid
and
retiring
than
I
naturally
was
and
cast
me
upon
Dolly
as
the
only
friend
with
whom
I
felt
at
ease
.
 
<EOS>
But
something
happened
when
I
was
still
quite
a
little
thing
that
helped
it
very
much
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
never
heard
my
mama
spoken
of
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
heard
of
my
papa
either
,
but
I
felt
more
interested
about
my
mama
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
worn
a
black
frock
,
that
I
could
recollect
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
been
shown
my
mama
's
grave
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
been
told
where
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
I
had
never
been
taught
to
pray
for
any
relation
but
my
godmother
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
more
than
once
approached
this
subject
of
my
thoughts
with
Mrs
Rachael
,
our
only
servant
,
who
took
my
light
away
when
I
was
in
bed
(
another
very
good
woman
,
<EOS>
but
austere
to
me
)
,
<EOS>
and
she
had
only
said
,
"
Esther
,
good
night
!
"
and
gone
away
and
left
me
.
   
<EOS>
Although
there
were
seven
girls
at
the
neighbouring
school
where
I
was
a
day
boarder
,
and
although
they
called
me
little
Esther
Summerson
,
I
knew
none
of
them
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
All
of
them
were
older
than
I
,
to
be
sure
(
I
was
the
youngest
there
by
a
good
deal
)
,
but
there
seemed
to
be
some
other
separation
between
us
besides
that
,
and
besides
their
being
far
more
clever
than
I
was
and
knowing
much
more
than
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
them
in
the
first
week
of
my
going
to
the
school
<EOS>
(
I
remember
it
very
well
)
invited
me
home
to
a
little
party
,
to
my
great
joy
.
 
<EOS>
But
my
godmother
wrote
a
stiff
letter
declining
for
me
,
and
I
never
went
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
went
out
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
my
birthday
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
holidays
at
school
on
other
birthdays
---
none
on
mine
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
rejoicings
at
home
on
other
birthdays
,
as
I
knew
from
what
I
heard
the
girls
relate
to
one
another
---
there
were
none
on
mine
.
 
<EOS>
My
birthday
was
the
most
melancholy
day
at
home
in
the
whole
year
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
mentioned
that
unless
my
vanity
should
deceive
me
(
as
I
know
it
may
,
for
I
may
be
very
vain
without
suspecting
it
,
though
indeed
I
do
n't
)
,
my
comprehension
is
quickened
when
my
affection
is
.
 
<EOS>
My
disposition
is
very
affectionate
,
and
perhaps
I
might
still
feel
such
a
wound
if
such
a
wound
could
be
received
more
than
once
with
the
quickness
of
that
birthday
.
   
<EOS>
Dinner
was
over
,
and
my
godmother
and
I
were
sitting
at
the
table
before
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
The
clock
ticked
,
the
fire
clicked
;
not
another
sound
had
been
heard
in
the
room
or
in
the
house
for
I
do
n't
know
how
long
.
 
<EOS>
I
happened
to
look
timidly
up
from
my
stitching
,
across
the
table
at
my
godmother
,
and
I
saw
in
her
face
,
looking
gloomily
at
me
,
"
It
would
have
been
far
better
,
little
Esther
,
that
you
had
had
no
birthday
,
that
you
had
never
been
born
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
broke
out
crying
and
sobbing
,
and
I
said
,
"
Oh
,
dear
godmother
,
tell
me
,
pray
<EOS>
do
tell
me
,
did
Mama
die
on
my
birthday
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ask
me
no
more
,
child
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
pray
tell
me
something
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
Do
now
,
at
last
,
dear
godmother
,
if
you
please
!
 
<EOS>
What
did
I
do
to
her
?
 
<EOS>
How
did
I
lose
her
?
 
<EOS>
Why
am
I
so
different
from
other
children
,
and
why
is
it
my
fault
,
dear
godmother
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
,
do
n't
go
away
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
speak
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
in
a
kind
of
fright
beyond
my
grief
,
and
I
caught
hold
of
her
dress
and
was
kneeling
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
saying
all
the
while
,
"
Let
me
go
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
now
she
stood
still
.
   
<EOS>
Her
darkened
face
had
such
power
over
me
that
it
stopped
me
in
the
midst
of
my
vehemence
.
 
<EOS>
I
put
up
my
trembling
little
hand
to
clasp
hers
or
to
beg
her
pardon
with
what
earnestness
I
might
,
but
withdrew
it
as
she
looked
at
me
,
and
laid
it
on
my
fluttering
heart
.
 
<EOS>
She
raised
me
,
sat
in
her
chair
,
and
standing
me
before
her
,
said
slowly
in
a
cold
,
low
voice
---
I
see
her
knitted
brow
and
pointed
finger
---
"
Your
mother
,
Esther
,
is
your
disgrace
,
and
you
were
hers
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
will
come
---
and
soon
enough
---
when
you
will
understand
this
better
and
will
feel
it
too
,
as
no
one
save
a
woman
can
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
forgiven
her
"
---
but
her
face
did
not
relent
---
"
the
wrong
she
did
to
me
,
and
<EOS>
I
say
no
more
of
it
,
though
it
was
greater
than
you
will
ever
know
---
than
any
one
will
ever
know
<EOS>
but
I
,
the
sufferer
.
 
<EOS>
For
yourself
,
unfortunate
girl
,
orphaned
and
degraded
from
the
first
of
these
evil
anniversaries
,
pray
daily
that
the
sins
of
others
be
not
visited
upon
your
head
,
according
to
what
is
written
.
 
<EOS>
Forget
your
mother
and
leave
all
other
people
to
forget
her
who
will
do
her
unhappy
child
that
greatest
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
go
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
checked
me
,
however
,
as
I
was
about
to
depart
from
her
---
so
frozen
as
I
was
!
---
and
added
this
,
"
Submission
,
self
-
denial
,
diligent
work
,
are
the
preparations
for
a
life
begun
with
such
a
shadow
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
different
from
other
children
,
Esther
,
because
you
were
not
born
,
like
them
,
in
common
sinfulness
and
wrath
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
set
apart
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
went
up
to
my
room
,
and
crept
to
bed
,
and
laid
my
doll
's
cheek
against
mine
wet
with
tears
,
and
holding
that
solitary
friend
upon
my
bosom
,
cried
myself
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
Imperfect
<EOS>
as
my
understanding
of
my
sorrow
was
,
I
knew
that
I
had
brought
no
joy
at
any
time
to
anybody
's
heart
and
that
I
was
to
no
one
upon
earth
what
Dolly
was
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
Dear
,
dear
,
to
think
how
much
time
we
passed
alone
together
afterwards
,
and
how
often
I
repeated
to
the
doll
the
story
of
my
birthday
and
confided
to
her
that
I
would
try
as
hard
as
ever
<EOS>
I
could
to
repair
the
fault
I
had
been
born
with
(
of
which
I
confessedly
felt
guilty
and
yet
innocent
)
and
would
strive
as
I
grew
up
to
be
industrious
,
contented
,
and
kind

hearted
and
to
do
some
good
to
some
one
,
and
win
some
love
to
myself
if
I
could
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
it
is
not
self
-
indulgent
to
shed
these
tears
as
I
think
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
very
thankful
,
I
am
very
cheerful
,
but
I
can
not
quite
help
their
coming
to
my
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
I
have
wiped
them
away
now
and
can
go
on
again
properly
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
the
distance
between
my
godmother
and
myself
so
much
more
after
the
birthday
,
and
felt
so
sensible
of
filling
a
place
in
her
house
which
ought
to
have
been
empty
,
that
I
found
her
more
difficult
of
approach
,
though
I
was
fervently
grateful
to
her
in
my
heart
,
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
in
the
same
way
towards
my
school
companions
;
I
felt
in
the
same
way
towards
Mrs
Rachael
,
who
was
a
widow
;
and
oh
,
towards
her
daughter
,
of
whom
she
was
proud
,
who
came
to
see
her
once
a
fortnight
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
retired
and
quiet
,
and
tried
to
be
very
diligent
.
   
<EOS>
One
sunny
afternoon
when
I
had
come
home
from
school
with
my
books
and
portfolio
,
watching
my
long
shadow
at
my
side
,
and
as
I
was
gliding
upstairs
to
my
room
as
usual
,
my
godmother
looked
out
of
the
parlour
-
door
and
called
me
back
.
 
<EOS>
Sitting
with
her
,
I
found
---
 
which
was
very
unusual
indeed
---
a
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
A
portly
,
important
-
looking
gentleman
,
dressed
all
in
black
,
with
a
white
cravat
,
large
gold

seals
,
a
pair
of
gold
eye

glasses
,
and
a
large
seal
-
ring
upon
his
little
finger
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
my
godmother
in
an
undertone
,
"
is
the
child
.
"
 
<EOS>
Then
she
said
in
her
naturally
stern
way
of
speaking
,
"
This
is
Esther
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
put
up
his
eye
-
glasses
to
look
at
me
and
said
,
"
Come
here
,
my
dear
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
shook
hands
with
me
and
asked
me
to
take
off
my
bonnet
,
looking
at
me
all
the
while
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
complied
,
he
said
,
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
and
afterwards
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
then
,
taking
off
his
eye
-
glasses
and
folding
them
in
a
red
case
,
and
leaning
back
in
his
arm
-
chair
,
turning
the
case
about
in
his
two
hands
,
he
gave
my
godmother
a
nod
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
that
,
my
godmother
said
,
"
You
may
go
upstairs
,
Esther
!
"
<EOS>
And
I
made
him
my
curtsy
and
left
him
.
   
<EOS>
It
must
have
been
two
years
afterwards
,
and
I
was
almost
fourteen
,
when
one
dreadful
night
my
godmother
<EOS>
and
I
sat
at
the
fireside
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
reading
aloud
,
and
she
was
listening
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
come
down
at
nine
o'clock
as
I
always
did
to
read
the
Bible
to
her
,
and
was
reading
from
St
John
how
our
Saviour
stooped
down
,
writing
with
his
finger
in
the
dust
,
when
they
brought
the
sinful
woman
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
So
when
they
continued
asking
him
,
he
lifted
up
himself
and
said
unto
them
,
He
that
is
without
sin
among
you
,
let
him
first
cast
a
stone
at
her
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
I
was
stopped
by
my
godmother
's
rising
,
putting
her
hand
to
her
head
,
and
crying
out
in
an
awful
voice
from
quite
another
part
of
the
book
,
<EOS>
"
"
Watch
ye
,
therefore
,
lest
coming
suddenly
he
find
you
sleeping
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
I
say
unto
you
,
I
say
unto
all
,
Watch
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
In
an
instant
,
while
she
stood
before
me
repeating
these
words
,
she
fell
down
on
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
need
to
cry
out
;
her
voice
had
sounded
through
the
house
and
been
heard
in
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
laid
upon
her
bed
.
 
<EOS>
For
more
than
a
week
she
lay
there
,
little
altered
outwardly
,
with
her
old
handsome
resolute
frown
that
I
so
well
knew
carved
upon
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
Many
and
many
a
time
,
in
the
day
and
in
the
night
,
with
my
head
upon
the
pillow
by
her
that
my
whispers
might
be
plainer
to
her
,
I
kissed
her
,
thanked
her
,
prayed
for
her
,
asked
her
for
her
blessing
and
forgiveness
,
entreated
her
to
give
me
the
least
sign
that
she
knew
or
heard
me
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
.
<EOS>
Her
face
was
immovable
.
 
<EOS>
To
the
very
last
,
and
even
afterwards
,
her
frown
remained
unsoftened
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
day
after
my
poor
good
godmother
was
buried
,
the
gentleman
in
black
with
the
white
neckcloth
reappeared
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
sent
for
by
Mrs
Rachael
,
and
found
him
in
the
same
place
,
as
if
he
had
never
gone
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Kenge
,
"
he
said
;
"
you
may
remember
it
,
my
child
;
Kenge
and
Carboy
,
Lincoln
's
Inn
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
replied
that
I
remembered
to
have
seen
him
once
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
be
seated
---
here
near
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
distress
yourself
;
it
's
of
no
use
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Rachael
,
I
need
n't
inform
you
who
were
acquainted
with
the
late
Miss
Barbary
's
affairs
,
that
her
means
die
with
her
and
that
this
young
lady
,
now
her
aunt
is
dead
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
My
aunt
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
really
of
no
use
carrying
on
a
deception
when
no
object

"

"
Aunt

.
 
<EOS>
Do

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs

,

---

---

---
 
Jarndyce

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Not

"
Not

<EOS>

<EOS>
the

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

---

---
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
But

!
"
   
<EOS>
What

.
 
<EOS>
What

.
 
<EOS>
What

.
   
<EOS>
This

at
Windsor
,
where
I

(
as

)
<EOS>
my

.
 
<EOS>
On
that

week
,
amply

,
I

,

,

Reading
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Rachael
was
too
good
to

any

,
but
I
was
not

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
When

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
No

Esther
!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
It

"
   
<EOS>
The

---

<EOS>

<EOS>
As

.
 
<EOS>
My

Mrs
Rachael
all

;

to

<EOS>

<EOS>
---

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
It

,
"
What
the
de
-
vil

?
"
   
<EOS>
I

"
Me

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

But

<EOS>
"

"

"
There

<EOS>
Now

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well

<EOS>
Look

"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Confound

Rachael
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
her

in

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
began
to

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
thought

he
had

,

he

in

Mrs
Rachael
names
.
   
<EOS>
After

opened

,
which

large

to

,

<EOS>
"
Now
,

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
In

,
"

"

<EOS>
Here

(
a

this

,

)
,

.
 
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
Livers

.
 
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
Now

wo

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
must

I

.
 
<EOS>
We
left

a

.
 
<EOS>
I
often

,
and
never

thinking

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
did
;
and
<EOS>
so
,
as
time
went
on
,
he
passed
out
of
my
mind
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
coach
stopped
,
a
very
neat
lady
looked
up
at
the
window
and
said
,
"
Miss
Donny
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
ma'am
,
Esther
Summerson
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
quite
right
,
"
said
the
lady
,
"
Miss
Donny
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
now
understood
that
she
introduced
herself
by
that
name
,
and
begged
Miss
Donny
's
pardon
for
my
mistake
,
and
pointed
out
my
boxes
at
her
request
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
direction
of
a
very
neat
maid
,
they
were
put
outside
a
very
small
green
carriage
;
and
then
Miss
Donny
,
the
maid
,
and
I
got
inside
and
were
driven

.
   
<EOS>
"
Everything
is
ready
for
you
,
Esther
,
"
said
Miss
Donny
,
"
and
the
scheme
of
your

has
been
arranged
in
exact

with
the
wishes
of
your
guardian
,
Mr
Jarndyce
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
---
did
you
say
,
ma'am
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
your
guardian
,
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
said
Miss
Donny
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
so
bewildered
that
Miss
Donny
thought
the
cold
had
been
too
severe
for
me
and
lent
me
her
smelling
-
bottle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
my
---
guardian
,
Mr
Jarndyce
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
after
a
good
deal
of

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
personally
,
Esther
,
"
said
Miss
Donny
;
"
merely
through
his
solicitors
,
Messrs.
Kenge
and
Carboy
,
of
London
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
superior
gentleman
,
Mr
Kenge
.
 
<EOS>
Truly
eloquent
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
his
periods
quite
majestic
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
this
to
be
very
true
but
was
too
confused
to
attend
to
it
.
<EOS>
Our
speedy
arrival
at
our
destination
,
before
I
had
time
to
recover
myself
,
increased
my
confusion
,
and
I
never
shall
forget
the
uncertain
and
the
unreal
air
of
everything
at
Greenleaf
<EOS>
(
Miss
Donny
's
house
)
<EOS>
that
afternoon
!
   
<EOS>
But
I
soon
became
used
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
adapted
to
the
routine
of
Greenleaf
before
long
<EOS>
that
I
seemed
to
have
been
there
a
great
while
and
almost
to
have
dreamed
rather
than
really
lived
my
old
life
at
my
godmother
's
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
more
precise
,
exact
,
and
orderly
than
Greenleaf
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
time
for
everything
all
round
the
dial
of
the
clock
,
and
everything
was
done
at
its
appointed
moment
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
twelve
boarders
,
and
there
were
two
Miss
Donnys
,
twins
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
understood
that
I
would
have
to
depend
,
by
and
by
,
on
my
qualifications
as
a
governess
,
and
I
was
not
only
instructed
in
everything
that
was
taught
at
Greenleaf
,
but
was
very
soon
engaged
in
helping
to
instruct
others
.
 
<EOS>
Although
I
was
treated
in
every
other
respect
like
the
rest
of
the
school
,
this
single
difference
was
made
in
my
case
from
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
began
to
know
more
,
I
taught
more
,
and
so
in
course
of
time
I
had
plenty
to
do
,
which
I
was
very
fond
of
doing
because
it
made
the
dear
girls
fond
of
me
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
whenever
a
new
pupil
came
who
was
a
little
downcast
and
unhappy
,
she
was
so
sure
---
<EOS>
indeed
I
do
n't
know
why
---
to
make
a
friend
of
me
that
all
new
-
comers
were
confided
to
my
care
.
 
<EOS>
They
said
I
was
so
gentle
,
but
I
am
sure
THEY
were
!
 
<EOS>
I
often
thought
of
the
resolution
I
had
made
on
my
birthday
to
try
to
be
industrious
,
contented
,
and
true
-
hearted
and
to
do
some
good
to
some
one
and
win
some
love
if
I
could
;
and
indeed
,
indeed
,
I
felt
almost
ashamed
to
have
done
so
little
and
have
won
so
much
.
   
<EOS>
I
passed
at
Greenleaf
six
happy
,
quiet
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
in
any
face
there
,
thank
heaven
,
on
my
birthday
,
that
it
would
have
been
better
if
I
had
never
been
born
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
day
came
round
,
it
brought
me
so
many
tokens
of
affectionate
remembrance
that
my
room
was
beautiful
with
them
from
New
Year
's
Day
to
Christmas
.
   
<EOS>
In
those
six
years
I
had
never
been
away
except
on
visits
at

in
the

.
 
<EOS>
After
the
first
six
months
or
so
I
had
taken
Miss
Donny
's
advice
in
reference
to
the
propriety
of
writing
to
Mr
Kenge
to
say
that
I
was
happy
and

,
and
with
her

I
had
written
such
a
letter
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
received
a
formal
answer
acknowledging
its
receipt
and
saying
,
"
We
note
the
contents
thereof
,
which
shall
be
duly
communicated
to
our
client
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
After
that
I
sometimes
heard
<EOS>
Miss
Donny
and
her
sister
mention
how
regular
my
accounts
were
paid
,
and
about
twice
a
year
I
ventured
to
write

similar
letter
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
received
by
return
of
post
exactly

in
the
same

,
with
the

of
Kenge
and
Carboy
in
another

,
which
I
supposed

Mr

's
.
   
<EOS>
It
seems
so
curious

me

to

all
this
about

!
 
<EOS>
As

were
the

of
MY
life
!
 
<EOS>
But
my
little
body
will
soon
fall
into

.
   
<EOS>
Six
quiet
years
<EOS>
(
I
find
I
am

for
the
second

)
<EOS>
I
had
passed
at
Greenleaf
,
seeing
in
those
around

,
as

in
a
looking

glass

every

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
Old
Square
,
Lincoln
's
Inn
   
Madam
,
   
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
   
<EOS>
Our
clt

abt

Ct

.
   
<EOS>
We

<EOS>
We

,

Servts
,
   
Kenge

Carboy
   
Miss
Esther
Summerson
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
never
,
never
,
never

this

!
 
<EOS>
It

them
to

much

me
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
Not

less
sorry
<EOS>
---
I

;
but
the

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

"
<EOS>

"

,

Esther

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

been

---

!
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
what
a
heart
<EOS>
I

!
   
<EOS>
And
could
I
help
it
if
with
all

,

,

,

(

,

"

.

May

!
"
<EOS>
---

"
<EOS>
Oh
,
I

,
I

so

!
"
<EOS>
many

!
   
<EOS>
But

that
I

.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,

,
I
made

,
"
Esther
,
now

really
must
!
 
<EOS>
This
WILL
NOT
do
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
cheered
myself
up
pretty
well

last
,
though
I
am
afraid

was
longer
about

,

watch

.
   
<EOS>
I
was
quite

that
we
were
there
when

ten

,
and
when
we
really

there
,
that
we

.
<EOS>
However
,
when

,
and

seemed

,

every

,
I

to
believe
that
we
really
were
approaching
the

.
 
<EOS>
Very

stopped
.
   
<EOS>
A

who
had
inked

,
"
I

Kenge

,

,

Lincoln
's

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If

,

,
"

<EOS>
I.
   
He
was
very

,
and
as

into

after

the

,
I

there

?
 
<EOS>
For

were
so
full
of
dense

that
scarcely
anything

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
no
,
miss
,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
London
particular
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
never
heard

such

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
fog
,
miss
,
"
said
the
young

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
!
"
said
I.
   
We
drove
slowly
through
the
dirtiest
and
darkest
streets
that
ever
were
seen
in
the
world
(
I

)

I

the

,
until
we
passed
into

under
an
old

and
drove
on
through
a

square
until
we
came
to
an
odd

in

,
where
there

an
entrance
up
a

,
broad

,
like

a

.
 
<EOS>
And
there
really

a

outside
under
some
cloisters
,
<EOS>
for
I
saw
the
gravestones
from

window
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
Kenge
and
Carboy
's
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
showed
me
through
an
outer
office
into
Mr
Kenge
's
room
---
there
was
no
one
in
it
---
and
politely

an
arm
-

for
me
by

.
 
<EOS>
He
then
called
my
attention
to
a
little
looking
-
glass

one

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
In

,

,

,
as

're

.
 
<EOS>
Not

's
requisite
,
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Going

the
Chancellor
?
<EOS>
"
I

,
startled

.
   
<EOS>
"
Only
a

,
miss
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Kenge

in

.
 
<EOS>
He
left

,

some

"
<EOS>
---

---
"
and
look

the
paper
,
"
which

.
 
<EOS>
He
then

the
fire
and

.
   
<EOS>
Everything
was
so

---
the
stranger
from
its
being
night
in
the
day
-

,
the

,
and
looking
raw
and
cold
---
<EOS>
that
I
read
the
words
in
the
newspaper
without
knowing
what
they
meant
and
found
myself
reading
the
same
words
repeatedly
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
of
no
use
going
on
in
that
way
,
I
put
the
paper
down
,
took
a
peep
at
my
bonnet
in
the
glass
to
see
if
it
was
neat
,
and
looked
at
the
room
,
which
was
not
half
lighted
,
and
at
the
shabby
,

tables
,
and
at
the
piles
of
writings
,
and
at
a
bookcase
full
of
the
most
inexpressive
-
looking
books
that
ever
had
anything
to
say
for
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
went
on
,
thinking
,
thinking
,
thinking
;
and
the
fire
went
on
,
burning
,
burning
,
burning
;
and
the
candles
went
on
flickering
and
guttering
,
and
there
were
no
snuffers
---
until
the
young
gentleman
by
and
by
brought
a
very
dirty
pair
---
for
two
hours
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
Mr
Kenge
came
.
 
<EOS>
HE
was
not
altered
,
but
he
was
surprised
to
see
how
altered

was
and
appeared

.
 
<EOS>
"
As

in
the
Chancellor

,
Miss
Summerson
,
"
he

,
"
we

.
 
<EOS>
You
will
not

by
the
Lord
Chancellor
<EOS>
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"
I

,
"
I
do

think
I
shall
,
"
really
not
seeing
on

why
I

be
.
   
<EOS>
So
Mr
Kenge
gave
me
his
arm
<EOS>
and
we
went
round
the
corner
,
under
a

,
and
in
at
a

.
 
<EOS>
And
so
we
came
,
along
a
passage
,
into
a
comfortable
sort
of
room
where
a
young
lady
and
a
young

,

.
 
<EOS>
A
screen
was
interposed
between

and
it
,
and
they
were

on

screen
,

.
   
<EOS>
They
both
looked
up
when
I
came
in
,
and
I
saw
in
the
young
lady
,
with
the
fire

upon
her
,
such
a
beautiful
girl
!
 
<EOS>
With
such

,
such

,
and

,

,

!
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Ada
,
"
said

Kenge
,
"
this
is
Miss
Summerson
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
came
to

a

and
her

,
but
seemed
to
change

in

and

.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
she
had
such
a
natural
,

,
winning

that
in

we
were

in

,
with

of

fire
upon
us
,
talking
together
as

as
could

.
   
<EOS>
What
a
load
off
my
mind
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
so

to
know
that
she
could
confide
in
me
and
like
me
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
so
good
of
her
,
and
so
encouraging
to
me
!
   
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
was
her
distant
cousin
,
she

me
,
and
his
name
Richard
Carstone
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
handsome

with
an
ingenuous

and
a
most
engaging

;
and
after

up
to

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

very

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

and
(

)

.
 
<EOS>

,

;

.

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
4
.
<EOS>
Telescopic
Philanthropy
 
<EOS>
We
were
to
pass
the
night
,
Mr
Kenge
told
us
when
we
arrived
in
his
room
,
at
Mrs
Jellyby
's
;
and
then
he
turned
to
me
and
said
he

<EOS>

)

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

;

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

I

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
And

,

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

,
which

(

<EOS>
,
"

;

<EOS>
The
African

at

.
 
<EOS>
It

in

with

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
We

next

Borrioboola
-
Gha
,

Niger
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Ada

,

,
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

;

,

;

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

---
    
"
The

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,

?
"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
With

,
"

<EOS>

You

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Just

.

<EOS>
I

"
No

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

I

.
   
<EOS>
"
---

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Where

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
"
Presents

,

---
"
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
And

,
"
"

,

"
"

"
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
No
,
Peepy
!
 
<EOS>
Not

!
"
   
<EOS>
Peepy
(
so
self
-
named
)
was
the
unfortunate
child
who
had
fallen
downstairs
,
who
now
interrupted
the
correspondence
by
presenting
himself
,
with
a
strip
of
plaster
on
his
forehead
,
to
exhibit
his
wounded
knees
,
in
which
Ada
and
I
did
not
know
which
to
pity
most
---
 
the
bruises
or
the
dirt
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Jellyby
merely
added
,
with
the
serene
composure
with
which
she
said
everything
,
"
Go
along
,
you
naughty
Peepy
!
"
and
fixed
her
fine
eyes
on
Africa
again
.
   
<EOS>
However
,
as
she
at
once
proceeded
with
her
dictation
,
and
as
I
interrupted
nothing
by
doing
it
,
I
ventured
quietly
to
stop
poor
Peepy
as
he
was
going
out
and
to
take
him
up
to
nurse
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
very
much
astonished
at
it
and
at
Ada
's
kissing
him
,
but
soon
fell
fast
asleep
in
my
arms
,
sobbing
at
longer
and
longer
intervals
,
until
he
was
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
so
occupied
with
Peepy
that
I
lost
the
letter
in
detail
,
<EOS>
though
I
derived
such
a
general
impression
from
it
of
the
momentous
importance
of
Africa
,
and
the
utter
insignificance
of
all
other
places
and
things
,
that
I
felt
quite
ashamed
to
have
thought
so
little
about
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Six
o'clock
!
"
said
Mrs
Jellyby
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
our
dinner
hour
is
nominally
(
for
we
dine
at
all
hours
)
five
!
 
<EOS>
Caddy
,
show
Miss
Clare
and
Miss
Summerson
their
rooms
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
like
to
make
some
change
,
perhaps
?
 
<EOS>
You
will
excuse
me
,
I
know
,
being
so
much
occupied
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
that
very
bad
child
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
put
him
down
,
Miss
Summerson
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
begged
permission
to
retain
him
,
truly
saying
that
he
was
not
at
all
troublesome
,
and
carried
him
upstairs
and
laid
him
on
my
bed
.
<EOS>
Ada
and
I
had
two
upper
rooms
with
a
door
of
communication
between
.
<EOS>
They
were
excessively
bare
and
disorderly
,
and
the
curtain
to
my
window
was
fastened
up
with
a
fork
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
like
some
hot
water
,
would
n't
you
?
"
said
Miss
Jellyby
,
looking
round
for
a
jug
with
a
handle
to
it
,
but
looking
in
vain
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
is
not
being
troublesome
,
"
said
we
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
it
's
not
the
trouble
,
"
returned
Miss
Jellyby
;
"
the
question
is
,
if
there
IS
any
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
evening
was
so
very
cold
and
the
rooms
had
such
a
marshy
smell
that
I
must
confess
it
was
a
little
miserable
,
and
Ada
was
half
crying
.
 
<EOS>
We
soon
laughed
,
however
,
and
were
busily
unpacking
when
Miss
Jellyby
came
back
to
say
that
she
was
sorry
there
was
no
hot
water
,
but
they
could
n't
find
the
kettle
,
and
the
boiler
was
out
of
order
.
   
<EOS>
We
begged
her
not
to
mention
it
and
made
all
the
haste
we
could
to
get
down
to
the
fire
again
.
 
<EOS>
But
all
the
little
children
had
come
up
to
the
landing
outside
to
look
at
the
phenomenon
of
Peepy
lying
on
my
bed
,
and
our
attention
was
distracted
by
the
constant
apparition
of
noses
and
fingers
in
situations
of
danger
between
the
hinges
of
the
doors
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
shut
the
door
of
either
room
,
for
my
lock
,
with
no
knob
to
it
<EOS>
,
looked
as
if
it
wanted
to
be
wound
up
;
and
though
the
handle
of
Ada
's
went
round
and
round
with
the
greatest
smoothness
,
it
was
attended
with
no
effect
<EOS>
whatever
on
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
proposed
to
the
children
that
they
should
come
in
and
be
very
good
at
my
table
,
and
I
would
tell
them
the
story
of
Little
Red
Riding
Hood
while
I
dressed
;
which
they
did
,
and
were
as
quiet
as
mice
,
including
Peepy
,
who
awoke
opportunely
before
the
appearance
of
the
wolf
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
went
downstairs
we
found
a
mug
with
"
A
Present
from
Tunbridge
Wells
"
on
it
lighted
up
in
the
staircase
window
with
a
floating
wick
,
and
a
young
woman
,
with
a
swelled
face
bound
up
in
a
flannel
bandage
blowing
the
fire
of
the
drawing
-
room
(
now
connected
by
an
open
door
with
Mrs
Jellyby
's
room
)
and
choking
dreadfully
.
<EOS>
It
smoked
to
that
degree
,
in
short
,
that
we
all
sat
coughing
and
crying
with
the
windows
open
for
half
an
hour
,
during
which
Mrs
Jellyby
,
with
the
same
sweetness
of
temper
,
directed
letters
about
Africa
.
 
<EOS>
Her
being
so
employed
was
,
I
must
say
,
a
great
relief
to
me
,
for
Richard
told
us
that
he
had
washed
his
hands
in
a
pie
-
dish
and
that
they
had
found
the
kettle
on
his
dressing
-
table
,
and
he
made
Ada
laugh
so
that
they
made
me
laugh
in
the
most
ridiculous
manner
.
   
<EOS>
Soon
after
seven
o'clock
we
went
down
to
dinner
,
carefully
,
by
Mrs
Jellyby
's
advice
,
for
the
stair
-
carpets
,
besides
being
very
deficient
in
stair
-
wires
,
were
so
torn
as
to
be
absolute
traps
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
a
fine
cod
-
fish
,
a
piece
of
roast
beef
,
a
dish
of
cutlets
,
and
a
pudding
;
an
excellent
dinner
,
if
it
had
had
any
cooking
to
speak
of
,
but
it
was
almost
raw
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
woman
with
the
flannel
bandage
waited
,
and
dropped
everything
on
the
table
wherever
it
happened
to
go
,
and
never
moved
it
again
until
she
put
it
on
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
person
I
had
seen
in
pattens
,
who
I
suppose
to
have
been
the
cook
,
frequently
came
and
skirmished
with
her
at
the
door
,
and
there
appeared
to
be
ill
will
between
them
.
   
<EOS>
All
through
dinner
---
which
was
long
,
in
consequence
of
such
accidents
as
the
dish
of
potatoes
being
mislaid
in
the
coal
skuttle
and
the
handle
of
the
corkscrew
coming
off
and
striking
the
young
woman
in
the
chin
---
Mrs
Jellyby
preserved
the
evenness
of
her
disposition
.
 
<EOS>
She
told
us
a
great
deal
that
was
interesting
about
Borrioboola
-
Gha
and
the
natives
,
and
received
so
many
letters
that
Richard
,
who
sat
by
her
,
saw
four
envelopes
in
the
gravy
at
once
.
<EOS>
Some
of
the
letters
were
proceedings
of
ladies
'
committees
or
resolutions
of
ladies
'
meetings
,
which
she
read
to
us
;
others
were
applications
from
people
excited
in
various
ways
about
the
cultivation
of
coffee
,
and
natives
;
others
required
answers
,
and
these
she
sent
her
eldest
daughter
from
the
table
three
or
four
times
to
write
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
full
of
business
and
undoubtedly
was
,
as
she
had
told
us
,
devoted
to
the
cause
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
a
little
curious
to
know
who
a
mild
bald
gentleman
in
spectacles
was
,
who
dropped
into
a
vacant
chair
<EOS>
(
there
was
no
top
or
bottom
in
particular
)
<EOS>
after
the
fish
was
taken
away
and
seemed
passively
to
submit
himself
to
Borriohoola
-
Gha
but
not
to
be
actively
interested
in
that
settlement
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
never
spoke
a
word
,
he
might
have
been
a
native
but
for
his
complexion
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
we
left
the
table
and
he
remained
alone
with
Richard
that
the
possibility
of
his
being
Mr
Jellyby
ever
entered
my

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
WAS
Mr
Jellyby
;
and
a
loquacious
young
man
called
Mr
Quale
,
with
large
shining
knobs
for
temples
and
his
hair
all
brushed
to
the
back
of
his
head
,
who
came
in
the

,
and
told
Ada
he
was
a

,
<EOS>
also
informed
her
that
he
called
the
matrimonial

of
Mrs
Jellyby
with
Mr
Jellyby
the
union
of
mind
and
matter
.
   
<EOS>
This
young
man
,
besides
having
a
great
deal
to
say
for
himself
about
Africa
and
a
project
of
his
for
teaching

to
teach

to
turn

-

and
establish

,
delighted
in

Mrs
Jellyby
out
by

,
"
I

,
Mrs
Jellyby
,

have

as

as

Africa
in

,

not
?
"
<EOS>
or
,
"
If
my

,
Mrs

,
you
once
mentioned
that
you
had

?
"
<EOS>
---
always

Mrs
Jellyby
's

to

like

.
 
<EOS>
During
the
whole
evening
,
Mr
Jellyby
sat
in
a
corner
with
his
head
against
the
wall
as
if
he
were

.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
that
he
had
several
times
opened
his
mouth
when
alone
with
Richard
after

,
as
if
he
had
something
on

,
but
had
always
shut

again
,
to
Richard
's
extreme
confusion
,
without
saying
anything
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Jellyby
,
sitting
in
quite
a
nest
of
waste
paper
,
drank
coffee
all
the
evening
and
dictated
at
intervals
to
her
eldest
daughter
.
<EOS>
She
also
held
a
discussion
with
Mr
Quale
,
of
which
the
subject
seemed
to
be
---
if
I
understood
it
---
the
brotherhood
of
humanity
,
and
gave
utterance
to
some
beautiful

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
so
attentive
an
auditor
as
I
might
have
wished
to
be
,
however
,
for
Peepy
and
the
other
children
<EOS>
came
flocking
about
Ada
and
me
in
a
corner
of
the

-
room
to
ask

another

;
so
we
sat
down
among

and
told

in
whispers
"
Puss
in
Boots
"
<EOS>
and
I
do
n't
know
what
else
until
Mrs
Jellyby
,
accidentally
remembering
them
,
sent
them
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
As
Peepy
cried
for
me
to
take
him
to
bed
,
I
carried
him
upstairs
,
where
the
young
woman
with
the
flannel
bandage
charged
into
the
midst
of
the
little
family
like
a
dragon
and
overturned
them
into
cribs
.
   
<EOS>
After
that
I
occupied
myself
in
making
our
room
a
little

and
in
coaxing
a
very
cross
fire
that
had
been
lighted
to
burn
,
which
at
last
it
did
,
quite

.
 
<EOS>
On

downstairs
,
I
felt
that
Mrs
Jellyby
looked
down
upon
me
rather
for
being
so

,
and
I
was
sorry
for
it
,
though
at
the
same

I

that
I

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
nearly

before
we
found
an
opportunity
of
going
to
bed
,
and
even

left
Mrs
Jellyby
among
her

drinking

and
Miss
Jellyby
biting
the

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
strange
house
!
"
said
Ada
when
we
got

.
 
<EOS>
"
How
curious
of
my
cousin
Jarndyce
to
send

here
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
"
said
I
,
"
it
quite

.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
understand
it
,
and
I
ca
n't

it
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
asked
Ada
with
her
pretty

.
   
<EOS>
"
All
this
,
my
dear
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
It
MUST

very
good
of
Mrs
Jellyby
to
take
such
pains
about
a
scheme
for
the
benefit
of
natives
---
and
<EOS>
yet
---
Peepy
and
the
housekeeping
!
"
   
<EOS>
Ada
laughed
and
put
her
arm
about
my
neck
as
I
stood
looking
at
the
fire
,
and
told
me
I
was
a
quiet
,
dear
,
good
creature
and
had
won
her
heart
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
so
thoughtful
,
Esther
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
yet
so
cheerful
!
 
<EOS>
And
you
do
so
much
,
so
unpretendingly
!
 
<EOS>
You
would
make
a
home
out
of
even
this
house
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
simple
darling
!
 
<EOS>
She
was
quite
unconscious
that
she
only
praised
herself
and
that
it
was
in
the
goodness
of
her
own
heart
that
she
made
so
much
of
me
!
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
you
a
question
?
"
<EOS>
said
I
when
we
had
sat
before
the
fire
a
little

.
   
<EOS>
"
Five
hundred
,
"
said
Ada
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
cousin
,
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
I
owe
so
much
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Would
you
mind
describing
him
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
Shaking
her
golden
hair
,
Ada
turned
her
eyes
upon
me
with
such
laughing
wonder
that
I
was
full
of
wonder
too
,
partly
at
her
beauty
,
partly
at
her
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
Esther
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
want
a
description
of
my
cousin
Jarndyce
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
I
never
saw
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
never
saw
him
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Ada
.
   
<EOS>
Well
,
to
be
sure
!
   
<EOS>
No
,
she
had
never
seen
him
.
 
<EOS>
Young
<EOS>
as
she
was
when
her
mama
died
,
she
remembered
how
the
tears
would
come
into
her
eyes
when
she
spoke
of
him
and
of
the
noble
generosity
of
his
character
,
which
she
had
said
was
to
be
trusted
above
all
earthly
things
;
and
Ada
trusted
it
.
 
<EOS>
Her
cousin
Jarndyce
had
written
to
her
a
few
months
ago
---
"
a
plain
,
honest
letter
,
"
Ada
said
---
proposing

we
were
now
to
enter

and

that
"
in
time
it
might
heal
some
of
the
wounds
made
by
the
miserable
Chancery
suit
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
had
replied
,
gratefully

his

.
 
<EOS>
Richard
had
received
a
similar
letter
and
had
made
a
similar
response
.
 
<EOS>
He
HAD
seen
Mr
Jarndyce
once
,
but
only
once
,
five
years
ago
,
at
Winchester
school
.
<EOS>
He
had
told
Ada
,
when
they
were
leaning
on
the
screen
before
the
fire
where
I
found
them
,
that
he
recollected
him
as
"
a
bluff
,
rosy
fellow
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
was
the
utmost
description
Ada
could
give
me
.
   
<EOS>
It
set
me
thinking
so
that
when
Ada
was
asleep
,
I
still
remained
before
the
fire
,
wondering
and
wondering
about
Bleak
House
,
and
wondering
and
wondering
that
yesterday
morning
should
seem
so
long
ago
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
where
my
thoughts
had
wandered
when
they
were
recalled
by
a
tap
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
I
opened
it
softly
and
found
Miss
Jellyby
shivering
there
with
a
broken
candle
in
a
broken
candlestick
in
one
hand
and
an
egg
-
cup
in
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
very
sulkily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
come
in
?
<EOS>
"
she
shortly
and
unexpectedly
asked
me
in
the
same
sulky
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
I.
 
"
Do
n't
wake
Miss
Clare
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
would
not
sit
down
,
but
stood
by
the
fire
dipping
her
inky
middle
finger
in
the
egg
-
cup
,
which
contained
vinegar
,
and
smearing
it
over
the
ink
stains
on
her
face
,
frowning
the
whole
time
and
looking
very
gloomy
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
Africa
was
dead
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
on
a
sudden
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
going
to
remonstrate
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
"
Do
n't
talk
to
me
,
Miss
Summerson
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
it
and
detest
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
beast
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
told
her
she
was
tired
,
and
I
was
sorry
.
 
<EOS>
I
put
my
hand
upon
her
head
,
and
touched
her
forehead
,
and
said
it
was
hot
now
but
would
be
cool
tomorrow
.
 
<EOS>
She
still
stood
pouting
and
frowning
at
me
,
but
presently
put
down
her
egg
-
cup
and
turned
softly
towards
the
bed
where
Ada
lay
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
pretty
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
with
the
same
knitted
brow
and
in
the
same
uncivil
manner
.
   
<EOS>
I
assented
with
a
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
An
orphan
.
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
knows
a
quantity
,
I
suppose
?
 
<EOS>
Can
dance
,
and
play
music
,
and
sing
?
 
<EOS>
She
can
talk
French
,
I
suppose
,
and
do
geography
,
and
globes
,
and
needlework
,
and
everything
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
,
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
do
anything
hardly
,
except
write
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
always
writing
for
Ma
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
you
two
were
not
ashamed
of
yourselves
to
come
in
this
afternoon
and
see
me
able
to
do
nothing
else
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
like
your
ill
nature
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
you
think
yourselves
very
fine
,
I
dare
say
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
see
that
the
poor
girl
was
near
crying
,
and
I
resumed
my
chair
without
speaking
and
looked
at
her
(
I
hope
)
as
mildly
as
I
felt
towards
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
disgraceful
,
"
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
house
is
disgraceful
.
 
<EOS>
The
children
are
disgraceful
.
 
<EOS>
I'M
disgraceful
.
 
<EOS>
Pa
's
miserable
,
and
no
wonder
!
 
<EOS>
Priscilla
drinks
<EOS>
---
she
's
always
drinking
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
great
shame
and
a
great
story
of
you
if
you
say
you
did
n't
smell
her
today
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
bad
as
a
public
-
house
,
waiting
at
dinner
;
you
know
it
was
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
I
do
n't
know
it
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
,
"
she
said
very

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
sha
n't
say
you
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
dear
!
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
wo
n't
let
me
speak
---
"
   
"
You
're
speaking
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
you
are
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
tell
stories
,
Miss
Summerson
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
said
I
,
"
as
long
as
you
wo
n't
hear
me
out
---
"
   
"
I
do
n't
want
to
hear
you
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
I
think
you
do
,
"
said
I
,
"
because
that
would
be
so
very
unreasonable
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
know
what
you
tell
me
because
the
servant
did
not
come
near
me
at
dinner
;
but
I
do
n't
doubt
what
you
tell
me
,
and
I
am
sorry
to
