.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
make
a
merit
of
that
,
"
said
she
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
That
would
be
very
foolish
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
still
standing
by
the
bed
,
and
now
stooped
down
(
but
still
with
the
same
discontented
face
)
and
kissed
Ada
.
 
<EOS>
That
done
,
she
came
softly
back
and
stood
by
the
side
of
my
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Her
bosom
was
heaving
in
a
distressful
manner
that
I
greatly
pitied
,
but
I
thought
it
better
not
to
speak
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
was
dead
!
"
<EOS>
she
broke
out
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
we
were
all
dead
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
great
deal
better
for
us
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
moment
afterwards
,
she
knelt
on
the
ground
at
my
side
,
hid
her
face
in
my
dress
,
passionately
begged
my
pardon
,
and
wept
.
 
<EOS>
I
comforted
her
and
would
have
raised
her
,
but
she
cried
no
,
no
<EOS>
;
she
wanted
to
stay
there
!
   
<EOS>
"
You
used
to
teach
girls
,
"
she
said
,
"
If
you
could
only
have
taught
me
,
I
could
have
learnt
from
you
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
so
very
miserable
,
and
I
like
you
so
much
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
persuade
her
to
sit
by
me
or
to
do
anything
but
move
a
ragged
stool
to
where
she
was
kneeling
,
and
take
that
,
and
still
hold
my
dress
in
the
same
manner
.
 
<EOS>
By
degrees
the
poor
tired
girl
fell
asleep
,
and
then
I
contrived
to
raise
her
head
so
that
it
should
rest
on
my
lap
,
and
to
cover
us
both
with
shawls
.
 
<EOS>
The
fire
went
out
,
and
all
night
long
she
slumbered
thus
before
the
ashy
grate
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
I
was
painfully
awake
and
vainly
tried
to
lose
myself
,
with
my
eyes
closed
,
among
the
scenes
of
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
by
slow
degrees
,
they
became
indistinct
and
mingled
.
 
<EOS>
I
began
to
lose
the
identity
of
the
sleeper
resting
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
Now
it
was
Ada
,
now
one
of
my
old
Reading
friends
from
whom
I
could
not
believe
I
had
so
recently
parted
.
 
<EOS>
Now
it
was
the
little
mad
woman
worn
out
with
curtsying
and
smiling
,
now
some
one
in
authority
at
Bleak
House
.
 
<EOS>
Lastly
,
it
was
no
one
,
and
I
was
no
one
.
   
<EOS>
The
purblind
day
was
feebly
struggling
with
the
fog
when
I
opened
my
eyes
to
encounter
those
of
a
dirty
-
faced
little
spectre
fixed
upon
me
.
 
<EOS>
Peepy
had
scaled
his
crib
,
and
crept
down
in
his
bed
-
gown
and
cap
,
and
was
so
cold
that
his
teeth
were
chattering
as
if
he
had
cut
them
all
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
5
.
<EOS>
A
Morning
Adventure
 
<EOS>
Although
the
morning
was
raw
,
and
although
the
fog
still
seemed
heavy
---
I
say
seemed
,
for
the
windows
were
so
encrusted
with
dirt
that
they
would
have
made
midsummer
sunshine
dim
---
I
was
sufficiently
forewarned
of
the
discomfort
within
doors
at
that
early
hour
and
sufficiently
curious
about
London
to
think
it
a
good
idea
on
the
part
of
Miss
Jellyby
when
she
proposed
that
we
should
go
out
for
a
walk
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ma
wo
n't
be
down
for
ever
so
long
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
then
it
's
a
chance
if
breakfast
's
ready
for
an
hour
afterwards
<EOS>
,
they
dawdle
so
.
<EOS>
As
to
Pa
,
he
gets
what
he
can
and
goes
to
the
office
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
has
what
you
would
call
a
regular
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
Priscilla
leaves
him
out
the
loaf
and
some
milk
,
when
there
is
any
,
overnight
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
there
is
n't
any
milk
,
and
sometimes
the
cat
drinks
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'm
afraid
you
must
be
tired
,
Miss
Summerson
,
and
perhaps
you
would
rather
go
to
bed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
at
all
tired
,
my
dear
,
"
said
I
,
"
and
would
much
prefer
to
go
out
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
're
sure
you
would
,
"
returned
Miss
Jellyby
,
"
I
'll
get
my
things
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ada
said
she
would
go
too
,
and
was
soon
astir
.
 
<EOS>
I
made
a
proposal
to
Peepy
,
in
default
of
being
able
to
do
anything
better
for
him
,
that
he
should
let
me
wash
him
and
afterwards
lay
him
down
on
my
bed
again
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
he
submitted
with
the
best
grace
possible
,
staring
at
me
during
the
whole
operation
as
if
he
never
had
been
,
and
never
could
again
be
,
so
astonished
in
his
life
---
looking
very
miserable
also
,
certainly
,
but
making
no
complaint
,
and
going
snugly
to
sleep
as
soon
as
it
was
over
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
I
was
in
two
minds
about
taking
such
a
liberty
,
but
I
soon
reflected
that
nobody
in
the
house
was
likely
to
notice
it
.
   
<EOS>
What
with
the
bustle
of
dispatching
Peepy
and
the
bustle
of
getting
myself
ready
and
helping
Ada
,
I
was
soon
quite
in
a
glow
.
 
<EOS>
We
found
Miss
Jellyby
trying
to
warm
herself
at
the
fire
in
the
writing
-
room
,
which
Priscilla
was
then
lighting
with
a
smutty
parlour
candlestick
,
throwing
the
candle
in
to
make
it
burn
better
.
<EOS>
Everything
was
just
as
we
had
left
it
last
night
and
was
evidently
intended
to
remain
so
.
 
<EOS>
Below
-
stairs
the
dinner
-
cloth
had
not
been
taken
away
,
but
had
been
left
ready
for
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
Crumbs
,
dust
,
and
waste
-
paper
were
all
over
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Some
pewter
pots
and
a
milk
-
can
hung
on
the
area
railings
;
the
door
stood
open
;
and
we
met
the
cook
round
the
corner
coming
out
of
a
public
-
house
,
wiping
her
mouth
.
 
<EOS>
She
mentioned
,
as
she
passed
us
,
that
she
had
been
to
see
what
o'clock
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
But
before
we
met
the
cook
,
we
met
Richard
,
who
was
dancing
up
and
down
Thavies
Inn
to
warm
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
agreeably
surprised
to
see
us
stirring
so
soon
and
said
he
would
gladly
share
our
walk
.
<EOS>
So
he
took
care
of
Ada
,
and
Miss
Jellyby
<EOS>
and
I
went
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
mention
that
Miss
Jellyby
had
relapsed
into
her
sulky
manner
and
that
I
really
should
not
have
thought
she
liked
me
much
unless
she
had
told
me
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
would
you
wish
to
go
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Anywhere
,
my
dear
,
"
I
replied
.
   
<EOS>
"
Anywhere
's
nowhere
,
"
said
Miss
Jellyby
,
stopping
perversely
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
us
go
somewhere
at
any
rate
,
"
said
<EOS>
I.
   
She
then
walked
me
on
very
fast
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
are
my
witness
,
Miss
Summerson
<EOS>
,
I
say
I
do
n't
care
-
<EOS>
but
if
he
was
to
come
to
our
house
with
his
great
,
shining
,
lumpy
forehead
night
after
night
till
he
was
as
old
as
Methuselah
,
I
would
n't
have
anything
to
say
to
him
.
<EOS>
Such
ASSES
as
he
and
Ma
make
of
themselves
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
!
<EOS>
"
I
remonstrated
,
in
allusion
to
the
epithet
and
the
vigorous
emphasis
Miss
Jellyby
set
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
duty
as
a
child
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
talk
of
duty
as
a
child
,
Miss
Summerson
;
where
's
Ma
's
duty
as
a
parent
?
 
<EOS>
All
made
over
to
the
public
and
Africa
,
I
suppose
!
 
<EOS>
Then
let
the
public
and
Africa
show
duty
as
a
child
;
it
's
much
more
their
affair
than
mine
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
shocked
,
I
dare
say
!
<EOS>
Very
well
,
so
am
I
shocked
too
;
so
we
are
both
shocked
,
and
there
's
an
end
of
it
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She
walked
me
on
faster
yet
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
for
all
that
,
I
say
again
,
he
may
come
,
and
come
,
and
come
,
and
I
wo
n't
have
anything
to
say
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
's
any
stuff
in
the
world
that
I
hate
and
detest
,
it
's
the
stuff
he
and
Ma
talk
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
the
very
paving
-
stones
opposite

can

as
all

,

Ma

!
"
   
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Thus

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
We

never

Chancery
!
 
<EOS>
We

of

,

---

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Ve

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ye

!
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Before

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

's

<EOS>

Ha

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Pray

LADIES

<EOS>
Everything

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

"

they
---

<EOS>
Here

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
And

ca

(
<EOS>
or

my

think
,
<EOS>
but

THEY

?
)

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

ill

Chancery
.
 
<EOS>
I
do

.
 
<EOS>
I

brother
pretty
well
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

presentiment
that
he
WILL
mention

the

"
   
<EOS>
She

that

which
her

,

M.
 
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
only
other
lodger
,
"

in

"
a

.
 
<EOS>
The

the

here
say
he

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Hush
!
"
   
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>
Passing

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
Richard

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
It

<EOS>
"
J.
"

"
What

?
"

I

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

It

,

"

<EOS>
"

---

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
Strange

!
 
<EOS>
All

.
 
<EOS>
To

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Miss

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
In

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

,

,

(

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

were
perfect

;

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

to

;

,
I

,
was

<EOS>
(

<EOS>
Chapter
6
.
<EOS>
Quite
at
Home
 
<EOS>
The

had
brightened

much
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
By
and

began
to
leave

city
and
to
proceed
through
suburbs
which
,
of

,
would
have
made
a
pretty

in

;
and

got
into

again
,
with

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

before

and
the
immense

behind
;
and
when
a

with

,

and

,

<EOS>
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
The

-

Whittington
,
"

,
"

the

.
 
<EOS>
Halloa
!
<EOS>
What
's

?
"
   
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
Its

,

,

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Good

,

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,

's

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

,
Ada
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
all

in

.
 
<EOS>
Tucked

---

,

,

.
<EOS>
These

.
 
<EOS>

Master
,

;

(

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is

Jarndyce
's

?
"
said

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Going
to
London
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
opened
the
notes
.
 
<EOS>
Each
was
a
counterpart
of
the
other
and
contained
these
words
in
a
solid
,
plain
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
look
forward
,
my
dear
,
to
our

easily
and
without

on

.
 
<EOS>
I
therefore
have
to
propose
that
we
meet
as
old
friends
and

for

.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be

relief
to
you
possibly
,
and
to
me
certainly
,
and
<EOS>
so
my
love

.
   
<EOS>
John
Jarndyce
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
perhaps
less
reason
to
be
surprised
than
either
of
my
companions
,
having
never
yet
enjoyed
an
opportunity
of
thanking
one
who
had
been
my
benefactor
and
sole
earthly
dependence
through
so
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
considered
how
I
could
thank
him
,
my
gratitude
lying
too
deep
in
my
heart
for
that
;
but
I
now
began
to
consider
how
I
could
meet
him
without
thanking
him
,
and
felt
it
would
be
very
difficult
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
The
notes
revived
in
Richard
and
Ada
a
general
impression
that
they
both
had
,
without
quite
knowing
how
they
came
by
it
,
that
their
cousin
Jarndyce
could
never
bear
acknowledgments
for
any
kindness
he
performed
and
that
sooner
than
receive
any
he
would
resort
to
the
most
singular
expedients
and
evasions
or
would
even
run
away
.
<EOS>
Ada
dimly
remembered
to
have
heard
her
mother
tell
,
<EOS>
when
she
was
a
very
little
child
,
that
he
had
once
done
her
an
act
of
uncommon
generosity
and
that
on
her
going
to
his
house
to
thank
him
,
he
happened
to
see
her
through
a
window
coming
to
the
door
,
and
immediately
escaped
by
the
back
gate
,
and
was
not
heard
of
for
three
months
.
 
<EOS>
This
discourse
led
to
a
great
deal
more
on
the
same
theme
,
and
indeed
it
lasted
us
all
day
,
and
we
talked
of
scarcely
anything
else
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
did
by
any
chance
diverge
into
another
subject
,
we
soon
returned
to
this
,
and
wondered
what
the
house
would
be
like
,
and
when
we
should
get
there
,
and
whether
we
should
see
Mr
Jarndyce
as
soon
as
we
arrived
or
after
a
delay
,
and
what
he
would
say
to
us
,
and
what
we
should
say
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
All
of
which
we
wondered
about
,
over
and
over
again
.
   
<EOS>
The
roads
were
very
heavy
for
the
horses
,
but
the
pathway
was
generally
good
,
so
we
alighted
and
walked
up
all
the
hills
,
and
liked
it
so
well
that
we
prolonged
our
walk
on
the
level
ground
when
we
got
to
the
top
.
 
<EOS>
At
Barnet
there
were
other
horses
waiting
for
us
,
but
as
they
had
only
just
been
fed
,
we
had
to
wait
for
them
too
,
and
got
a
long
fresh
walk
over
a
common
and
an
old
battle
-
field
before
the
carriage
came
up
.
 
<EOS>
These
delays
so
protracted
the
journey
that
the
short
day
was
spent
and
the
long
night
had
closed
in
before
we
came
to
St
Albans
,
near
to
which
town
Bleak
House
was
,
we
knew
.
   
<EOS>
By
that

were
so

and

that
even
Richard
confessed
,

the

old
street
,
to
feeling
an

to

.
 
<EOS>
As

Ada

,

he

,
the

sharp

,

from

.
 
<EOS>
When

of
the

,
round

,
and

that
the
post

,

had
for

,
was

Richard

Ada

and

and
the

for

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
light

on

a

,
and
the

,

"
That

!
"
put

,

,
that

sent

.
<EOS>
Presently

lost

,
presently

,
presently

,
presently

it
,
and
turned

.
 
<EOS>
It

what

with

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

<EOS>
"
Ada
,

,
Esther
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Rick

!
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
Warm

"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

(

passage
,
to
the
plain
room
where
Mr
Jarndyce
slept
,
all
the
year
round
,
with
his
window
open
,
his
bedstead
without
any
furniture
standing
in
the
middle
of
the
floor
for
more
air
,
and
his
cold
bath
gaping
for
him
in
a
smaller
room
adjoining
.
 
<EOS>
Out
of
<EOS>
that
you
came
into
another
passage
,
where
there
were
back
-
stairs
and
where
you
could
hear
the
horses
being
rubbed
down
outside
the
stable
and
being
told
to
"
Hold
up
"
and
"
Get
over
,
"
as
they
slipped
about
very
much
on
the
uneven
stones
.
 
<EOS>
Or
you
might
,
if
you
came
out
at
another
door
(
every
room
had
at
least
two
doors
)
,
go
straight
down
to
the
hall
again
by
half
-
a
-
dozen
steps
and
a
low
archway
,
wondering
how
you
got
back
there
or
had
ever
got
out
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
furniture
,
old
-
fashioned
rather
than
old
,
like
the
house
,
was
as
pleasantly
irregular
.
 
<EOS>
Ada
's
sleeping
-
room
was
all
flowers
---
in
chintz
and
paper
,
in
velvet
,
in
needlework
,
in
the
brocade
of
two
stiff
courtly
chairs
which
stood
,
each
attended
by
a
little
page
of
a
stool
for
greater
state
,
on
either
side
of
the
fire
-
place
.
 
<EOS>
Our
sitting
-
room
was
green
and
had
framed
and
glazed
upon
the
walls
numbers
of
surprising
and
surprised
birds
,
staring
out
of
pictures
at
a
real
trout
in
a
case
,
as
brown
and
shining
as
if
it
had
been
served
with
gravy
;
at
the
death
of
Captain
Cook
;
and
at
the
whole
process
of
preparing
tea
in
China
,
as
depicted
by
Chinese
artists
.
<EOS>
In
my
room
there
were
oval
engravings
of
the
months
---
ladies
haymaking
in
short
waists
and
large
hats
tied
under
the
chin
,
for
June
;
smooth
-
legged
noblemen
pointing
with
cocked
-
hats
to
village
steeples
,
for
October
.
 
<EOS>
Half
-
length
portraits
in
crayons
abounded
all
through
the
house
,
but
were
so
dispersed
that
I
found
the
brother
of
a
youthful
officer
of
mine
in
the
china
-
closet
and
the
grey
old
age
of
my
pretty
young
bride
,
with
a
flower
in
her
bodice
,
in
the
breakfast
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
As
substitutes
,
I
had
four
angels
,
of
Queen
Anne
's
reign
,
taking
a
complacent
gentleman
to
heaven
,
in
festoons
,
with
some
difficulty
;
and
a
composition
in
needlework
representing
fruit
,
a
kettle
,
and
an
alphabet
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
movables
,
from
the
wardrobes
to
the
chairs
and
tables
,
hangings
,
glasses
,
even
to
the
pincushions
and
scent
-
bottles
on
the
dressing
-
tables
,
displayed
the
same
quaint
variety
.
 
<EOS>
They
agreed
in
nothing
but
their
perfect
neatness
,
their
display
of
the
whitest
linen
,
and
their
storing
-
up
,
wheresoever
the
existence
of
a
drawer
,
small
or
large
,
rendered
it
possible
,
of
quantities
of
rose
-
leaves
and
sweet
lavender
.
 
<EOS>
Such
,
with
its
illuminated
windows
,
softened
here
and
there
by
shadows
of
curtains
,
shining
out
upon
the
starlight
night
;
with
its
light
,
and
warmth
,
and
comfort
;
with
its
hospitable
jingle
,
at
a
distance
,
of
preparations
for
dinner
;
with
the
face
of
its
generous
master
brightening
everything
we
saw
;
and
just
wind
enough
without
to
sound
a
low
accompaniment
to
everything
we
heard
,
were
our
first
impressions
of
Bleak
House
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
like
it
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
when
he
had
brought
us
round
again
to
Ada
's
sitting
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
makes
no
pretensions
,
but
it
is
a
comfortable
little
place
,
I
hope
,
and
will
be
more
so
with
such
bright
young
looks
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
barely
half
an
hour
before
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
one
here
but
the
finest
creature
upon
earth
---
a
child
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
More
children
,
Esther
!
"
said
Ada
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
literally
a
child
,
"
pursued
Mr
Jarndyce
;
"
not
a
child
in
years
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
grown
up
<EOS>
---
he
is
at
least
as
old
as
I
am
---
but
in
simplicity
,
and
freshness
,
and
enthusiasm
,
and
a
fine
guileless

for
all
worldly
affairs
,
he
is
a
perfect
child
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
felt
that
he
must
be
very
interesting
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
knows
Mrs
Jellyby
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
musical
man
,
an
amateur
,
but
might
have
been
a
professional
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
an
artist
too
,
an
amateur
,
but
might
have
been
a
professional
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
man
of
attainments
and
of
captivating
manners
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
unfortunate
in
his
affairs
,
and
unfortunate
in
his
pursuits
,
and
unfortunate
in
his
family
;
but
he
do
n't
care
---
he
's
a
child
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
imply
that
he
has
children
of
his
own
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Rick
!
 
<EOS>
Half
-
a
-
dozen
.
 
<EOS>
More
!
 
<EOS>
Nearer
a
dozen
,
I
should
think
.
<EOS>
But
he
has
never
looked
after
them
.
 
<EOS>
How
could
he
?
 
<EOS>
He
wanted
somebody
to
look
after
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
child
,
you
know
!
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
have
the
children
looked
after
themselves
at
all
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
just
as
you
may
suppose
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
said
that
the
children
of
the
very
poor
are
not
brought
up
,
but
dragged
up
.
 
<EOS>
Harold
Skimpole
's
children
have
tumbled
up
somehow
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
The
wind
's
getting
round
again
,
I
am
afraid
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
it
rather
!
"
   
<EOS>
Richard
observed
that
the
situation
was
exposed
on
a
sharp
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
IS
exposed
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
that
's
the
cause
.
<EOS>
Bleak
House
has
an
exposed
sound
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
are
coming
my
way
.
 
<EOS>
Come
along
!
"
   
<EOS>
Our
luggage
having
arrived
and
being
all
at
hand
,
I
was
dressed
in
a
few
minutes
and
engaged
in
putting
my
worldly
goods
away
when
a
maid
(
not
the
one
in
attendance
upon
Ada
,
but
another
,
whom
I
had
not
seen
)
brought
a
basket
into
my
room
with
two
bunches
of
keys
in
it
,
all
labelled
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
you
,
miss
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
she
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
me
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
The
housekeeping
keys
,
miss
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
showed
my
surprise
,
for
she
added
with
some
little
surprise
on
her
own
part
,
"
I
was
told
to
bring
them
as
soon
as
you
was
alone
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Summerson
,
if
I
do
n't
deceive
myself
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
my
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
large
bunch
is
the
housekeeping
,
and
the
little
bunch
is
the
cellars
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
Any
time
you
was
pleased
to
appoint
tomorrow
morning
,
I
was
to
show
you
the
presses
and
things
they
belong
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
I
would
be
ready
at
half
-
past
six
,
and
after
she
was
gone
,
stood
looking
at
the
basket
,
quite
lost
in
the
magnitude
of
my
trust
.
 
<EOS>
Ada
found
me
thus
and
had
such
a
delightful
confidence
in
me
when
I
showed
her
the
keys
and
told
her
about
them
that
it
would
have
been
insensibility
and
ingratitude
not
to
feel
encouraged
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
,
to
be
sure
,
that
it
was
the
dear
girl
's
kindness
,
but
I
liked
to
be
so
pleasantly
cheated
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
went
downstairs
,
we
were
presented
to
Mr
Skimpole
,
who
was
standing
before
the
fire
telling
Richard
how
fond
he
used
to
be
,
in
his
school
-
time
,
of
football
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
little
bright
creature
with
a
rather
large
head
,
but
a
delicate
face
and
a
sweet
voice
,
and
there
was
a
perfect
charm
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
All
he
said
was
so
free
from
effort
and
spontaneous
and
was
said
with
such
a
captivating
gaiety
that
it
was
fascinating
to
hear
him
talk
.
 
<EOS>
Being
of
a
more
slender
figure
than
Mr
Jarndyce
and
having
a
richer
complexion
,
with
browner
hair
,
he
looked
younger
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
had
more
the
appearance
in
all
respects
of
a
damaged
young
man
than
a
well
-
preserved
elderly
one
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
easy
negligence
in
his
manner
and
even
in
his
dress
(
his
hair
carelessly
disposed
,
and
his
neckkerchief
loose
and
flowing
,
as
I
have
seen
artists
paint
their
own
portraits
)
<EOS>
which
I
could
not
separate
from
the
idea
of
a
romantic
youth
who
had
undergone
some
unique
process
of
depreciation
.
 
<EOS>
It
struck
me
as
being
not
at
all
like
the
manner
or
appearance
of
a
man
who
had
advanced
in
life
by
the
usual
road
of
years
,
cares
,
and
experiences
.
   
<EOS>
I
gathered
from
the
conversation
that
Mr
Skimpole
had
been
educated
for
the
medical
profession
and
had
once
lived
,
in
his
professional
capacity
,
in
the
household
of
a
German
prince
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
us
,
however
,
that
as
he
had
always
been
a
mere
child
in
point
of
weights
and
measures
and
had
never
known
anything
about
them
(
except
that
they
disgusted
him
)
,
he
had
never
been
able
to
prescribe
with
the
requisite
accuracy
of
detail
.
 
<EOS>
In
fact
,
he
said
,
he
had
no
head
for
detail
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
told
us
,
with
great
humour
,
that
when
he
was
wanted
to
bleed
the
prince
or
physic
any
of
his
people
,
he
was
generally
found
lying
on
his
back
in
bed
,
reading
the
newspapers
or
making
fancy
-
sketches
in
pencil
,
and
could
n't
come
.
<EOS>
The
prince
,
at
last
,
objecting
to
this
,
"
in
which
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
in
the
frankest
manner
,
"
he
was
perfectly
right
,
"
the
engagement
terminated
,
and
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
having
(
as
he
added
with
delightful
gaiety
)
"
<EOS>
nothing
to
live
upon
but
love
,
fell
in
love
,
and
married
,
and
surrounded
himself
with
rosy
cheeks
.
"
 
<EOS>
His
good
friend
Jarndyce
and
some
other
of
his
good
friends
then
helped
him
,
in
quicker
or
slower
succession
,
to
several
openings
in
life
,
but
to
no
purpose
,
for
he
must
confess
to
two
of
the
oldest
infirmities
in
the
world
:
one
was
that
he
had
no
idea
of
time
,
the
other
that
he
had
no
idea
of
money
.
 
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
which
he
never
kept
an
appointment
,
never
could
transact
any
business
,
and
never
knew
the
value
of
anything
!
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
So
he
had
got
on
in
life
,
and
here
he
was
!
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
fond
of
reading
the
papers
,
very
fond
of
making
fancy
-
sketches
with
a
pencil
,
very
fond
of
nature
,
very
fond
of
art
.
 
<EOS>
All
he
asked
of
society
was
to
let
him
live
.
 
<EOS>
THAT
was
n't
much
.
 
<EOS>
His
wants
were
few
.
 
<EOS>
Give
him
the
papers
,
conversation
,
music
,
mutton
,
coffee
,
landscape
,
fruit
in
the
season
,
a
few
sheets
of
Bristol
-
board
,
and
a
little
claret
,
and
he
asked
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
mere
child
in
the
world
,
but
he
did
n't
cry
for
the
moon
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
to
the
world
,
"
Go
your
several
ways
in
peace
!
 
<EOS>
Wear
red
coats
,
blue
coats
,
lawn
sleeves
;
put
pens
behind
your
ears
,
wear
aprons
;
go
after
glory
,
holiness
,
commerce
,
trade
,
any
object
you
prefer
;
only
---
let
Harold
Skimpole
live
!
"
   
<EOS>
All
this
and
a
great
deal
<EOS>
more
he
told
us
,
not
only
with
the
utmost
brilliancy
and
enjoyment
,
but
with
a
certain
vivacious
candour
---
 
speaking
of
himself
as
if
he
were
not
at
all
his
own
affair
,
as
if
Skimpole
were
a
third
person
,
as
if
he
knew
that
Skimpole
had
his
singularities
but
still
had
his
claims
too
,
which
were
the
general
business
of
the
community
and
must
not
be
slighted
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
quite
enchanting
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
felt
at
all
confused
at
that
early
time
in
endeavouring
to
reconcile
anything
he
said
with
anything
I
had
thought
about
the
duties
and
accountabilities
of
life
(
which
I
am
far
from
sure
of
)
,
I
was
confused
by
not
exactly
understanding
why
he
was
free
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
WAS
free
of
them
,
I
scarcely
doubted
;
he
was
so
very
clear
about
it
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
covet
nothing
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
in
the
same
light
way
.
<EOS>
"
Possession
is
nothing
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
my
friend
Jarndyce
's
excellent
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
obliged
to
him
for
possessing
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
sketch
it
and
alter
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
set
it
to
music
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
am
here
,
I
have
sufficient
possession
of
it
and
have
neither
trouble
,
cost
,
nor
responsibility
.
 
<EOS>
My
steward
's
name
,
in
short
,
is
Jarndyce
,
and
he
ca
n't
cheat
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
been
mentioning
Mrs
Jellyby
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
bright
-
eyed
woman
,
of
a
strong
will
and
immense
power
of
business
detail
,
who
throws
herself
into
objects
with
surprising
ardour
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
regret
that
I
have
not
a
strong
will
and
an
immense
power
of
business
detail
to
throw
myself
into
objects
with
surprising
ardour
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
admire
her
without
envy
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
sympathize
with
the
objects
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
dream
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
lie
down
on
the
grass
---
in
fine
weather
---
and
float
along
an
African
river
,
embracing
all
the
natives
I
meet
,
as
sensible
of
the
deep
silence
and
sketching
the
dense
overhanging
tropical
growth
as
accurately
as
if
I
were
there
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
that
it
's
of
any
direct
use
my
doing
so
,
but
it
's
all
I
can
do
,
and
I
do
it
thoroughly
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
for
heaven
's
sake
,
having
Harold
Skimpole
,
a
confiding
child
,
petitioning
you
,
the
world
,
an
agglomeration
of
practical
people
of
business
habits
,
to
let
him
live
and
admire
the
human
family
,
do
it
somehow
or
other
,
like
good
souls
,
and
suffer
him
to
ride
his
rocking
-
horse
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
plain
enough
that
Mr
Jarndyce
had
not
been
neglectful
of
the
adjuration
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
's
general
position
there
would
have
rendered
it
so
without
the
addition
of
what
he
presently
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
only
you
,
the
generous
creatures
,
whom
I
envy
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
addressing
us
,
his
new
friends
,
in
an
impersonal
manner
.
<EOS>
"
I
envy
you
your
power
of
doing
what
you
do
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
what
I
should
revel
in
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
feel
any
vulgar
gratitude
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
almost
feel
as
if
YOU
ought
to
be
grateful
to
ME
for
giving
you
the
opportunity
of
enjoying
the
luxury
of
generosity
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
you
like
it
.
 
<EOS>
For
anything
I
can
tell
,
I
may
have
come
into
the
world
expressly
for
the
purpose
of
increasing
your
stock
of
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
have
been
born
to
be
a
benefactor
to
you
by
sometimes
giving
you
an
opportunity
of
assisting
me
in
my
little
perplexities
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
I
regret
my
incapacity
for
details
and
worldly
affairs
when
it
leads
to
such
pleasant
consequences
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
regret
it
therefore
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Of
all
his
playful
speeches
(
playful
,
yet
always
fully
meaning
what
they
expressed
)
none
seemed
to
be
more
to
the
taste
of
Mr
Jarndyce
than
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
often
new
temptations
,
afterwards
,
to
wonder
whether
it
was
really
singular
,
or
only
singular
to
me
,
that
he
,
who
was
probably
the
most
grateful
of
mankind
upon
the
least
occasion
,
should
so
desire
to
escape
the
gratitude
of
others
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
all
enchanted
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
it
a
merited
tribute
to
the
engaging
qualities
of
Ada
and
Richard
that
Mr
Skimpole
,
seeing
them
for
the
first
time
,
should
he
so
unreserved
and
should
lay
himself
out
to
be
so
exquisitely
agreeable
.
 
<EOS>
They
(
and
especially
Richard
)
were
naturally
pleased
;
for
similar
reasons
,
and
considered
it
no
common
privilege
to
be
so
freely
confided
in
by
such
an
attractive
man
.
<EOS>
The
more
we
listened
,
the
more
gaily
Mr
Skimpole
talked
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
with
his
fine
hilarious
manner
and
his
engaging
candour
and
his
genial
way
of
lightly
tossing
his
own
weaknesses
about
,
as
if
he
had
said
,
"
I
am
a
child
,
you
know
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
designing
people
compared
with
me
"
(
he
really
made
me
consider
myself
in
that
light
)
"
<EOS>
but
I
am
gay
and
innocent
;
forget
your
worldly
arts
and
play
with
me
!
"
<EOS>
the
effect
was
absolutely
dazzling
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
so
full
of
feeling
too
and
had
such
a
delicate
sentiment
for
what
was
beautiful
or
tender
that
he
could
have
won
a
heart
by

.
 
<EOS>
In
the

,
when
I
was

and
Ada
was
touching
the
piano
in
the

room
and
softly

a
tune
to
her
cousin
Richard
,
which
they
had
happened
to
mention
,
he
came
and
sat
down
on
the
sofa
near
me
and
so
spoke
of
Ada
that
I
almost
loved
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
like
the
morning
,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
With
that
golden
hair
,
those
blue

,
and
that
fresh

on
her

,
she
is
like

.
 
<EOS>
The
birds
here
will
mistake
her
for

.
 
<EOS>
We
will
not
call
such
a
lovely
young
creature
as
that
,
who
is
a
joy
to
all

,
an

.
 
<EOS>
She
is
the
child

the
universe
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
,
I
found
,
was
standing
near
us
with
his
hands
behind
him
and
an
attentive
smile
upon

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
universe
,
"
he
observed
,
"
makes
rather
an
indifferent
parent
,
I
am
afraid
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
!
"
cried
Mr
Skimpole
buoyantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
do
know
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
cried
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
the
world
(
which
in
your
sense
is
the
universe
)
,
and
I
know
nothing
of
it
,
so
you
shall
have
your
way
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
I
had
mine
,
"
glancing
at
the
cousins
,
"
there
should
be
no
brambles
of
sordid
realities
in
such
a

as

.
<EOS>
It
should
be
strewn
with
roses
;
it
should
lie
through
bowers
,
where
there
was
no
spring
,
autumn
,
nor

,
but
perpetual
summer
.
 
<EOS>
Age
or
change
should
never
wither

.
 
<EOS>
The
base
word
money
should
never
be
breathed
near
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
patted
him
on
the
head
with
a
smile
,
as
if
he
had
been
really

child
,
and
passing
a
step

two
on
,
and
stopping
a

,
glanced
at
the
young
cousins
.
 
<EOS>
His
look
was
thoughtful
,
but
had
a
benignant
expression
in
it
which
I
often
(
how
often
!
)
<EOS>
saw
again
,
which
has
long
been
engraven
on
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
they
were
,
communicating
with
that
in
which
he
stood
,
was
only
lighted
by
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Ada
sat
at
the
piano
;
Richard
stood
beside
her
,
bending
down
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
the
wall
,
their
shadows
blended
together
,
surrounded
by
strange
forms
,
not
without
a
ghostly
motion
caught
from
the
unsteady
fire
,
though
reflecting
from
motionless
objects
.
<EOS>
Ada
touched
the
notes
so
softly
and
sang
so
low
that
the
wind
,
sighing
away
to
the
distant
hills
,
was
as

as
the
music
.
<EOS>
The
mystery
of
the
future
and
the
little
clue
afforded
to
it
by
the
voice
of
the
present
seemed
expressed
in
the
whole
picture
.
   
<EOS>
But
it
is
not
to
recall
this
fancy
,
well
as
I
remember

,
that
I
recall

.
 
<EOS>
First
,
I
was
not
quite
unconscious
of
the
contrast
in
respect
of
meaning
and

between
the
silent
look
directed
that
way
and
the
flow
of

that
had

.
<EOS>
Secondly
,
though
Mr
Jarndyce
's
glance
as
he
withdrew

rested
for
but

on
me
,
I
felt
as
if
in
that

he
confided

---
 
and

and
that
I

confidence
 
---
his
hope
that
Ada
and
Richard
might
one

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
could
play
on
the

and

,
and
he
was
a

---
<EOS>
had

,
but
got

---
and
played
what
he
composed
with

.
 
<EOS>
After

had
quite

,
in

Richard
---
who
was

Ada
's

that

---
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
After

I
missed
first
Mr

and

,
and

thinking

Richard

,

,

"
If

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
When

with

,

,

,
"
Oh
,

,
miss
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Took
?
"

<EOS>
"
Took
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
Sudden
,
"
said
the
maid
.
   
<EOS>
I

that
his

might
be
of

,
<EOS>
but

and

,
as

,
sufficiently

to

.
 
<EOS>
She
threw

a
door
<EOS>
and
I
went
into
a

,
where
,

,

,

standing
before

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Summerson
,
"

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
Our

Mr
Skimpole
---
do

!
<EOS>
---
is

for

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
really
,
my

Miss
Summerson
,
"
said
Mr

with

,
"
I

that

who

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Are

,

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,

,
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
Some

,

,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

,

,
"
observed

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
wot

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

---
<EOS>
somehow

,
"
said

,
"
like

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The

man
said
nothing
but

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
such
a

one
that
it

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
said
Richard
to

,
"
has

to

because

has

---
I

,

,
I

that

had

---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Though

.
 
<EOS>
Jarndyce
would

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
"
said

,
aside
.
   
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Jail
,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Or

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
May

,

,

---
"
   
"
Coavinses
?
"
said

man
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
'
ouse
.
"
   
<EOS>
Richard
and
I
looked
at
one
another
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
most
singular
thing
that
the
arrest
was
our

and
not
Mr
Skimpole
's
.
<EOS>
He
observed
us
with
a

,
but
there

,
if
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
had

washed
his

of
the

,
and
it
had

ours
.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
he

,
as

,
"

in
a

(
as

)

,
Mr
Richard
or

cousin
,
or

,
could

,
or

,

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
I
do

,

I
suppose
there
is
some
instrument
within
their
power
that
would
settle
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
on
it
,
"
said
the
strange
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Really
?
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
seems
odd
,
now
,
to
one
who
is
no
judge
of
these
things
!
"
   
"
Odd
or
even
,
"
said
the
stranger
gruffly
,
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
not
a
bit
on
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
your
temper
,
my
good
fellow
,
keep
your
temper
!
"
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
gently
reasoned
with
him
as
he
made
a
little
drawing
of
his
head
on
the
fly
-
leaf
of
a
book
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
ruffled
by
your
occupation
.
 
<EOS>
We
can
separate
you
from
your
office
;
we
can
separate
the
individual
from
the
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
not
so
prejudiced
as
to
suppose
that
in
private
life
you
are
otherwise
than
a
very
estimable
man
,
with
a
great
deal
of
poetry
in
your
nature
,
of
which
you
may
not
be
conscious
.
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
only
answered
with
another
violent
snort
,
whether
in
acceptance
of
the
poetry
-
tribute
or
in
disdainful
rejection
of
it
,
he
did
not
express
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dear
Miss
Summerson
,
and
my
dear
Mr
Richard
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
gaily
,
innocently
,
and
confidingly
as
he
looked
at
his
drawing
with
his
head
on
one
side
,
"
<EOS>
here
you
see
me
utterly
incapable
of
helping
myself
,
and
entirely
in
your
hands
!
 
<EOS>
I
only
ask
to
be
free
.
 
<EOS>
The
butterflies
are
free
.
 
<EOS>
Mankind
will
surely
not
deny
to
Harold
Skimpole
what
it
concedes
to
the
butterflies
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Miss
Summerson
,
"
said
Richard
in
a
whisper
,
"
I
have
ten
pounds
that
I
received
from
Mr
Kenge
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
try
what
that
will
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
possessed
fifteen
pounds
,
odd
shillings
,
which
I
had
saved
from
my
quarterly
allowance
during
several
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
always
thought
that
some
accident
might
happen
which
would
throw
me
suddenly
,
without
any
relation
or
any
property
,
on
the
world
and
had
always
tried
to
keep
some
little
money
by
me
that
I
might
not
be
quite
penniless
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
Richard
of
my
having
this
little
store
and
having
no
present
need
of
it
,
and
I
asked
him
delicately
to
inform
Mr
Skimpole
,
while
I
should
be
gone
to
fetch
it
,
that
we
would
have
the
pleasure
of
paying
his
debt
.
   
<EOS>
When
I
came
back
,
Mr
Skimpole
kissed
my
hand
and
seemed
quite
touched
.
 
<EOS>
Not
on
his
own
account
(
I
was
again
aware
of
that
perplexing
and
extraordinary
contradiction
)
,
but
on
ours
,
as
if
personal
considerations
were
impossible
with
him
and
the
contemplation
of
our
happiness
alone
affected
him
.
 
<EOS>
Richard
,
begging
me
,
for
the
greater
grace
of
the
transaction
,
as
he
said
,
to
settle
with
Coavinses
(
as
Mr
Skimpole
now
jocularly
called
him
)
,
I
counted
out
the
money
and
received
the
necessary
acknowledgment
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
too
,
delighted
Mr
Skimpole
.
   
<EOS>
His
compliments
were
so
delicately
administered
that
I
blushed
less
than
I
might
have
done
and
settled
with
the
stranger
in
the
white
coat
without
making
any
mistakes
.
 
<EOS>
He
put
the
money
in
his
pocket
and
shortly
said
,
"
Well
,
then
,
I
'll
wish
you
a
good

,
miss
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
friend
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
standing
with
his
back
to
the
fire
after
giving
up
the
sketch
when
it
was
half

,
"
I
should
like
to
ask
you
something
,
without
offence
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
think
the
reply
was
,
"
Cut
away
,
then
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
know
this
morning
,
now
,
that
you
were
coming

on
this
errand
?
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
.
   
<EOS>
"
Know'd
it
yes'day
aft'noon
at
tea
-
time
,
"
said
Coavinses
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
did
n't
affect
your
appetite
?
 
<EOS>
Did
n't
make
you
at
all
uneasy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
hit
,
"
said
Coavinses
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know'd
if
you
wos
missed
to
-
day
,
you
would
n't
be
missed
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
A
day
makes
no
such
odds
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
when
you
came
down
here
,
"
proceeded
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
it
was
a
fine
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
was
shining
,
the
wind
was
blowing
,
the
lights
and
shadows
were
passing
across
the

,
the

were

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
said
they
warn't
,
in
MY

,
"
returned
Coavinses
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
observed
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
what
did
you
think
upon
the
road
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wot
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
growled
Coavinses
with
an
appearance
of
strong
resentment
.
 
<EOS>
"
Think
!
 
<EOS>
I
've
got
enough
to
do
,
and
little
enough
to
get
for
it
without
thinking
.
 
<EOS>
Thinking
!
"
<EOS>
(
with
profound

)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
did
n't
think
,
at
all
events
,
"
proceeded
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
to
this
effect
:
"
Harold
Skimpole
loves
to
see
the
sun
shine
,
loves
to
hear
the
wind
blow
,
loves
to
watch
the
changing
lights
and
shadows
,
loves
to
hear
the
birds
,
those
choristers
in
Nature
's
great
cathedral
.
 
<EOS>
And
does
it
seem
to
me
that
I
am
about
to
deprive
Harold
Skimpole
of
his
share
in
such
possessions
,
which
are
his
only
birthright
!
"
 
<EOS>
You
thought
nothing
to
that
effect
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
certainly
---
did
---
NOT
,
"
said
Coavinses
,
whose
doggedness
in
utterly
renouncing
the
idea
was
of
that
intense
kind
that
he
could
only
give
adequate
expression
to

by
putting

long

between
each
word
,
and
accompanying
the

with
a

that
might
have
dislocated

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
odd
and
very
curious
,
the
mental
process
is
,
in
you
men

business
!
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
thoughtfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
my
friend
.
<EOS>
Good
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
our
absence
had
been
long
enough
already
to
seem
strange
downstairs
,
I
returned
at
once
and
found
Ada
sitting
at
work
by
the
fireside
talking
to
her
cousin
John
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
presently
appeared
,
and
Richard
shortly
after
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
sufficiently
engaged
during
the
remainder
of
the
evening
in
taking
my
first
lesson
in
backgammon
from
Mr
Jarndyce
,
who
was
very
fond
of
the
game
and
from
whom
I
wished
of
course
to
learn
it
as
quickly
as
I
could
in
order
that
I
might
be
of
the
very
small
use
of
being
able
to
play
when
he
had
no
better
adversary
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
thought
,
occasionally
,
when
Mr
Skimpole
played
some
fragments
of
his
own
compositions
or
when
,
both
at
the
piano
and
the
violoncello
,
and
at
our
table
,
he
preserved
with
an
absence
of
all
effort
his
delightful
spirits
and
his
easy
flow
of

,
that
Richard
and
I
seemed
to
retain
the
transferred
impression
of
having
been
arrested
since
dinner
and
that
it
was
very
curious
altogether
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
late
before
we
separated
,
for
when
Ada
was
going
at
eleven
o'clock
,
Mr
Skimpole
went
to
the
piano
and
rattled
hilariously
that
the
best
of
all
ways
to
lengthen
our
days
was
to
steal
a
few
hours
from
night
,
<EOS>
my
dear
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
past
twelve
before
he
took
his
candle
and
his
radiant
face
out
of
the
room
,
and
I
think
he
might
have
kept
us
there
,
if
he
had
seen
fit
,
until
daybreak
.
 
<EOS>
Ada
and
Richard
were
lingering
for
a
few

by
the
fire
,
wondering
whether
Mrs
Jellyby
had
yet
finished
her

for
the
day
,
when
Mr
Jarndyce
,
who
had

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
me
,
what
's
this
,
what
's
this
!
"
<EOS>
he

,
rubbing
his

and

about
with
his

-

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
this
they
tell
me
?
 
<EOS>
Rick
,
my
boy
,
Esther
,
my

,
what

?
 
<EOS>
Why
did
you
do
it
?
 
<EOS>
How
could
you
do
it
?
 
<EOS>
How
much
apiece
was
it
?
 
<EOS>
The
wind
's
round
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
it
all
over
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
neither
of
us
quite
knew
what
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Rick
,
come
!
 
<EOS>
I
must
settle
this
before
I
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
How
much

out
of
pocket
?
 
<EOS>
You
two
made
the
money
up
,
you

!
 
<EOS>
Why
did
you
?
 
<EOS>
How
could
you
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Lord
,
yes
,
it
's
due
east
---
must

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,

,
"
said
Richard
,
"
I
do
n't

it
would

honourable
in

to

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
relied
upon

---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Lord

,
my
dear
boy
!
 
<EOS>
He
relies

!
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
giving

a

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Everybody
!
 
<EOS>
And
he
'll
be
in
the
same
scrape
again
next

!
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
walking
again
at
a

,
with
a

in

hand
that
had

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
always
in
the
same
scrape
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
born
in
the
same
scrape
.
 
<EOS>
I
verily
believe
that
the
announcement
in
the
newspapers
when
his
mother
was
confined
was
"
<EOS>
On
Tuesday
last
,
at
her

in
Botheration
Buildings
,
Mrs
Skimpole
of
a
son
in
difficulties
.
"
"
   
Richard
laughed
heartily
but
added
,
"
Still
,
sir
,
I
do
n't
want
to
shake
his
confidence
or
to
break
his
confidence
,
and
if
I
submit
to
your
better
knowledge
again
,
that
I
ought
to
keep
his
secret
,
I
hope
you
will
consider
before

any

.
 
<EOS>
Of

,
if
you
do
press
me
,
sir
,
I
shall
know
I
am
wrong
and
will
tell
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
cried
Mr
Jarndyce
,
stopping
again
,
and
making
several
absent

to
put

in

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
---
here
!
<EOS>
Take
it
away
,
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
I
am
about
with

;
it
's
all
the
wind
---
invariably

---
I
wo
n't

you
,
Rick
;

.
 
<EOS>
But

---
to

you

---

young
Saint
Michael
's

!
 
<EOS>
It
'll
blow
a
gale
in
the

the
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
now
alternately
putting
his
hands
into
his
pockets
as
if
he
were
going
to
keep
them
there
a
long

,
and
taking
them
out
again
and
vehemently
rubbing

all

.
   
<EOS>
I
ventured
to
take
this

of
hinting
that
Mr
Skimpole
,
being
in
all
such
matters
quite
a
child
---
    
"
Eh
,
my
dear
?
"
said
Mr

,
catching

.
   
<EOS>
Being
quite
a
child
,
sir
,
"
said

,
"
and
so

other

---
"
   
"
You

!
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
woman
's

hits

mark
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a

---
an

.
 
<EOS>
I

he
was
a
child
,
you

,
when
I
first

.
"
   
<EOS>
Certainly
!
<EOS>
Certainly
!
<EOS>
we
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
he
IS
a
child
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
is
n't
he
?
"
asked
Mr
Jarndyce
,
brightening
more
and
more
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
indeed
,
we
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
you
come
to
think

it
,
it
's
the
height

in

---
<EOS>
I
mean
me
---
"
said
Mr
Jarodyce
,
"
to
regard
him
for
a

as
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
make
HIM
responsible
.
 
<EOS>
The
idea
of
Harold
Skimpole
with
designs
or
plans
,
or
knowledge
of
consequences
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
so
delicious
to
see
the
clouds
about
his
bright
face
clearing
,
and
to
see
him
so
heartily
pleased
,
and
to
know
,
as
it
was
impossible
not
to
know
,
that
the
source
of
his
pleasure
was
the
goodness
which
was
tortured
by
condemning
,
or
mistrusting
,
or
secretly
accusing
any
one
,
that
I
saw
the
tears
in
Ada
's
eyes
,
while
she
echoed
his
laugh
,
and
felt
them
in
my
own
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
a
cod
's
head
and
shoulders
I
am
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
to
require
reminding
of
it
!
 
<EOS>
The
whole
business
shows
the
child
from
beginning
to
end
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
but
a
child
would
have
thought
of
singling
YOU
two
out
for
parties
in
the

!
 
<EOS>
Nobody
but
a
child
would
have
thought
of
YOUR
having
the
money
!
 
<EOS>
If
it
had
been
a
thousand
pounds
,
it
would
have
been
just
the
same
!
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
with
his
whole
face
in
a
glow
.
   
<EOS>
We
all
confirmed
it

our
night
's
experience
.
   
<EOS>
"
To

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
However

<EOS>
No

<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

Richard

"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Good

,

.
 
<EOS>
God

!
"
   
<EOS>
He

,

"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

about

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
in

south
!
"
<EOS>
And

.
   
<EOS>
Ada
and
<EOS>
I
agreed
,
as

little

,
that
this

that
he
used
the

.
 
<EOS>
We

very
characteristic
of

)
<EOS>
the

of

.
   
<EOS>
Indeed
,

my

I

.
 
<EOS>
Any

in
Mr

Mrs
Jellyby
<EOS>

<EOS>
My

.
 
<EOS>
It

's

,

as

<EOS>

of

,

<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
So

"
<EOS>
Esther
,
Esther
,
Esther
!
<EOS>
Duty
,

!
"
and

.
    
Chapter
7
.
<EOS>
The
Ghost
's
Walk
 
While
Esther
sleeps
,
and
while
Esther
wakes
,
it
is
still
wet
weather
down
at
the
place
in
Lincolnshire
.
 
<EOS>
The
rain
is
ever
falling
---
drip
,
drip
,
drip
---
by
day
and
night
upon
the
broad
flagged
terrace
-
pavement
,
the
Ghost
's
Walk
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
is
so
very
bad
down
in
Lincolnshire
that
the
liveliest
imagination
can
scarcely
apprehend
its
ever
being
fine
again
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
there
is
any
superabundant
life
of
imagination
on
the
spot
,
for
Sir
Leicester
is
not
here
(
and
,
truly
,
even
if
he
were
,
would
not
do
much
for
it
in
that
particular
)
,
but
is
in
Paris
with
my
Lady
;
and
solitude
,
with
dusky
wings
,
sits
brooding
upon
Chesney
Wold
.
   
<EOS>
There
may
be
some
motions
of
fancy
among
the
lower
animals
at
Chesney
Wold
.
 
<EOS>
The
horses
in
the
stables
---
the
long
stables
in
a
barren
,
red
-
brick
court
-
yard
,
where
there
is
a
great
bell
in
a
turret
,
and
a
clock
with
a
large
face
,
which
the
pigeons
who
live
near
it
and
who
love
to
perch
upon
its
shoulders
seem
to
be
always
consulting
<EOS>
---
THEY
may
contemplate
some
mental
pictures
of
fine
weather
on
occasions
,
and
may
be
better
artists
at
them
than
the
grooms
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
roan
,
so
famous
for
cross
-
country
work
,
turning
his
large

to
the
grated
window
near
his
rack
,
may
remember
the
fresh

that
glisten
there
at
other
times
and
the
scents
that
stream
in
,
and
may
have
a
fine
run
with
the
hounds
,
while
the
human
helper
,
clearing
out
the
next
stall
,
never
stirs
beyond
his
pitchfork
and

-

.
 
<EOS>
The
grey
,
whose
place
is
opposite
the
door
and
who
with
an
impatient
rattle
of
his
halter
pricks
his
ears
and
turns
his
head
so
wistfully
when
it
is
opened
,
and
to
whom

,
"
Woa
grey
,
then
,
steady
!
 
<EOS>
Noabody
wants
you
to
-
day
!
"
may
know
it
quite
as
well
as
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
seemingly
monotonous
and
uncompanionable
half
-
dozen
,
stabled
together
,
may
pass
the
long
wet
hours
when
the
door

shut
in
livelier

than
is
held
in
the
servants
'

or

the
Dedlock

,
or
may

time
by
improving
(
perhaps

)
<EOS>
the
pony
in
the
loose

in
the
corner
.
   
<EOS>
So
the

,

in
the
court
-

his

may

when

of

,

<EOS>
So

<EOS>

"
Rain

<EOS>
Nothing

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
as

<EOS>
So

<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
So

those

sweet

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
always

a
class
-

(
probably
Christmas
)
,
may

that
summer

him
when
he

.
 
<EOS>
The
discontented

,

the
old

,
twenty

,
may

,
a
waddling

for
weather
when
the

.
   
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
may
,
there
is
not
much
fancy
otherwise
stirring
at
Chesney
Wold
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
be
a
little
at
any
odd
moment
,
it
goes
,
like
a
little
noise
in
that
old
echoing
place
,
a
long
way
and
usually
leads
off
to
ghosts
and
mystery
.
   
<EOS>
It
has
rained
so
hard
and
rained
so
long
down
in
Lincolnshire
that
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
the
old
housekeeper
at
Chesney
Wold
,
has
several
times
taken
off
her
spectacles
and
cleaned
them
to
make
certain
that
the
drops
were
not
upon
the
glasses
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Rouncewell
might
have
been
sufficiently
assured
by
hearing
the
rain
,
but
that
she
is
rather
deaf
,
which
nothing
will
induce
her
to
believe
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
a
fine
old
lady
,
handsome
,
stately
,
wonderfully
neat
,
and
has
such
a
back
and
such
a
stomacher
that
if
her
stays
should
turn
out
when
she
dies
to
have
been
a
broad
old
-
fashioned
family
fire
-
grate
,
nobody
who
knows
her
would
have
cause
to
be
surprised
.
 
<EOS>
Weather
affects
Mrs
Rouncewell
little
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
is
there
in
all
weathers
,
and
the
house
,
as
she
expresses
it
,
"
is
what
she
looks
at
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
sits
in
her
room
<EOS>
(
in
a
side
passage
on
the
ground
floor
,
with
an
arched
window
commanding
a
smooth
quadrangle
,
adorned
at
regular

with
smooth
round
trees
and
smooth
round
blocks
of
stone
,
as
if

trees
were
going
to
play
at
bowls
with
the
stones
)
,
and
the
whole
house
reposes
on
her
mind
.
 
<EOS>
She
can
open
it
on
occasion
and
be
busy
and
fluttered
,
but
it
is
shut
up
now
and
lies
on
the
breadth
of
Mrs
Rouncewell
's
iron
-
bound
bosom
in
a

sleep
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
the
next
difficult
thing
to
an
impossibility
to
imagine
Chesney
Wold
without
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
but
she
has
only
been
here
fifty

.
 
<EOS>
Ask

how
long
,
this
rainy

,
and
she
shall
answer
"
fifty
year
,
three
months
,
and
a
fortnight
,
by
the

,
if
I
live
till
Tuesday
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Rouncewell
died
some
time
before
the
decease
of
the
pretty
fashion
of
pig
-
tails
,
and
modestly
hid
his
own
(
if
he
took
it
with
him
)
in
a
corner
of
the
churchyard
in
the
park
near
the

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
born
in
the
market
-
town
,
and
so
was
his
young
widow
.
 
<EOS>
Her
progress
in
the
family
began
in
the
time
of
the
last
Sir
Leicester
and
originated
in
the
still
-
room
.
   
<EOS>
The
present
representative
of
the
Dedlocks
is
an
excellent
master
.
<EOS>
He
supposes
all
his
dependents
to
be
utterly
bereft
of
individual
characters
,
intentions
,
or
opinions
,
and
is
persuaded
that
he
was
born
to
supersede
the
necessity
of
their
having
any
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
were
to
make
a
discovery
to
the
contrary
,
he
would
be
simply
stunned
---
would
never
recover
himself
,
most
likely
,
except
to
gasp
and
die
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
is
an
excellent
master
still
,
holding
it
a
part
of
his
state
to
be
so
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
great
liking
for
Mrs
Rouncewell
;
he
says
she
is
a
most
respectable
,
creditable
woman
.
 
<EOS>
He
always
shakes
hands
with
her
when
he
comes
down
to
Chesney
Wold
and
when
he
goes
away
;
and
if
he
were
very
ill
,
or

he

down
by

,
or

,
or
placed

any

of
a
Dedlock

,
he
would
say
if
he

,
"
Leave

,
and
send
Mrs
Rouncewell
here
!
"
<EOS>
feeling
his
dignity
,
at
such
a
pass
,
safer
with
her
than
with
anybody
else
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Rouncewell
has
known
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
had
two
sons
,
of
whom
the
younger
ran
wild
,
and
went
for
a
soldier
,
and
never
came
back
.
<EOS>
Even
to
this
hour
,
Mrs
Rouncewell
's
calm
hands
lose
their
composure
when
she
speaks
of
him
,
and
unfolding

from
her

,
hover

her
in

as
she

what
a
likely

,
what
a
fine
lad
,
what
a
gay
,

-

,

lad
he

!
 
<EOS>
Her
second
son
would
have
been
provided
for
at
Chesney
Wold
and
would
have
been
made
steward
in
due
season
,
but
he
took
,
when
he
was
a
schoolboy
,
to
constructing
steam
-

out
of
saucepans
and
setting
birds
to
draw
their
own
water
with
the
least
possible
amount
of
labour
,
so
assisting
them
with
artful
contrivance
of
hydraulic
pressure
that
a
thirsty

had
only
,
in
a
literal
sense
,
to
put
his
shoulder
to
the
wheel
and
the
job
was
done
.
 
<EOS>
This
propensity
gave
Mrs
Rouncewell
great
uneasiness
.
<EOS>
She
felt
it
with
a
mother
's
anguish
to
be
a
move
in
the
Wat
Tyler
direction
,
well
knowing
that
Sir
Leicester
had
that
general
impression
of
an
aptitude
for
any
art
to
which
smoke
and
a
tall
chimney
might
be
considered
essential
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
doomed
young

(
otherwise

,
and

)
,

,

<EOS>
,
she
was

,
with

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
"

,
"
I

never

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

;

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
farther

is
,

,

these

.
"
<EOS>
Farther

,
and
farther

;
and
if
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock

<EOS>
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
Mrs

's

has
,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
You

<EOS>
Ah

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

's

.
<EOS>
Her

that
Rosa

---
 
and

.
 
<EOS>
Thus

pass

from

,

for

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

do
with
a
picture
;
the
housekeeper
can
guarantee
that
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
is
obliged
to
her
for
the
information
and
is
,
moreover
,
generally
obliged
.
 
<EOS>
He
retires
with
his
friend
,
guided
down
another
staircase
by
the
young
gardener
,
and
presently
is
heard
to
drive
away
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
dusk
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Rouncewell
can
trust
to
the
discretion
of
her
two
young
hearers
and
may
tell
THEM
how
the
terrace
came
to
have
that
ghostly
name
.
   
<EOS>
She
seats
herself
in
a
large
chair
by
the
fast
-
darkening
window
and
tells
them
:
"
In
the
wicked
days
,
my
dears
,
of
King
Charles
the
First
---
I
mean
,
of
course
,
in
the
wicked
days
of
the
rebels
who
leagued
themselves
against
that
excellent
king
---
Sir
Morbury
Dedlock
was
the
owner
of
Chesney
Wold
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
there
was
any
account
of
a
ghost
in
the
family
before
those
days
,
I
ca
n't
say
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
think
it
very
likely
indeed
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Rouncewell
holds
this
opinion
because
she
considers
that
a
family
of
such
antiquity
and
importance
has
a
right
to
a
ghost
.
<EOS>
She
regards
a
ghost
as
one
of
the
privileges
of
the
upper
classes
,
a
genteel
distinction
to
which
the
common
people
have
no
claim
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
Morbury
Dedlock
,
"
says
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
"
was
,
<EOS>
I
have
no
occasion
to
say
,
on
the
side
of
the
blessed
martyr
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
IS
supposed
that
his
Lady
,
who
had
none
of
the
family
blood
in
her
veins
,
favoured
the
bad
cause
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
said
that
she
had
relations
among
King
Charles
's
enemies
,
that
she
was
in
correspondence
with
them
,
and
that
she
gave
them
information
.
 
<EOS>
When
any
of
the
country
gentlemen
who
followed
his
Majesty
's
cause
met
here
,
it
is
said
that
my
Lady
was
always
nearer
to
the
door
of
their
council
-
room
than
they
supposed
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
a
sound
like
a
footstep
passing
along
the
terrace
,
Watt
?
"
   
<EOS>
Rosa
draws
nearer
to
the
housekeeper
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hear
the
rain
-
drip
on
the
stones
,
"
replies
the
young
man
,
"
and
I
hear
a
curious
echo
<EOS>
---
I
suppose
an
echo
---
which
is
very
like
a
halting
step
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
housekeeper
gravely
nods
and
continues
:
"
Partly
on
account
of
this
division
between
them
,
and
partly
on
other
accounts
,
Sir
Morbury
and
his
Lady
led
a
troubled
life
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
lady
of
a
haughty
temper
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
well
suited
to
each
other
in
age
or
character
,
and
they
had
no
children
to
moderate
between
them
.
<EOS>
After
her
favourite
brother
,
a
young
gentleman
,
was
killed
in
the
civil
wars
(
by
Sir
Morbury
's
near
kinsman
)
,
her
feeling
was
so
violent
that
she
hated
the
race
into
which
she
had
married
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
Dedlocks
were
about
to
ride
out
from
Chesney
Wold
in
the
king
's
cause
,
she
is
supposed
to
have
more
than
once
stolen
down
into
the
stables
in
the
dead
of
night
and
lamed
their
horses
;
and
the
story
is
that
once
at
such
an
hour
,
her
husband
saw
her
gliding
down
the
stairs
and
followed
her
into
the
stall
where
his
own
favourite
horse
stood
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
seized
her
by
the
wrist
,
and
in
a
struggle
or
in
a
fall
or
through
the
horse
being
frightened
and
lashing
out
,
she
was
lamed
in
the
hip
and
from
that
hour
began
to
pine
away
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
housekeeper
has
dropped
her
voice
to
a
little
more
than
a
whisper
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
had
been
a
lady
of
a
handsome
figure
and
a
noble
carriage
.
<EOS>
She
never
complained
of
the
change
;
she
never
spoke
to
any
one
of
being
crippled
or
of
being
in
pain
,
but
day
by
day
she
tried
to
walk
upon
the
terrace
,
and
with
the
help
of
the
stone
balustrade
,
went
up
and
down
,
up
and
down
,
up
and
down
,
in
sun
and
shadow
,
with
greater
difficulty
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
one
afternoon
her
husband
<EOS>
(
to
whom
she
had
never
,
on
any
persuasion
,
opened
her
lips
since
that
night
)
,
standing
at
the
great
south
window
,
saw
her
drop
upon
the
pavement
.
 
<EOS>
He
hastened
down
to
raise
her
,
but
she
repulsed
him
as
he
bent
over
her
,
and
looking
at
him
fixedly
and
coldly
,
said
,
"
I
will
die
here
where
I
have
walked
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
will
walk
here
,
though
I
am
in
my
grave
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
walk
here
until
the
pride
of
this
house
is
humbled
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
calamity
or
when
disgrace
is
coming
to
it
,
let
the
Dedlocks
listen
for
my
step
!
"
<EOS>
"
  
Watt
looks
at
Rosa
.
 
<EOS>
Rosa
in
the
deepening
gloom
looks
down
upon
the
ground
,
half
frightened
and
half
shy
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
and
then
she
died
.
 
<EOS>
And
from
those
days
,
"
says
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
"
the
name
has
come
down
---
the
Ghost
's
Walk
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
tread
is
an
echo
,
it
is
an
echo
that
is
only
heard
after
dark
,
and
is
often
unheard
for
a
long
while
together
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
comes
back
from
time
to
time
;
and
so
sure
as
there
is
sickness
or
death
in
the
family
,
it
will
be
heard
then
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
And
disgrace
,
grandmother
---
"
says
Watt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Disgrace
never
comes
to
Chesney
Wold
,
"
returns
the
housekeeper
.
   
<EOS>
Her
grandson
apologizes
with
"
True
.
 
<EOS>
True
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
the
story
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
the
sound
is
,
it
is
a
worrying
sound
,
"
says
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
getting
up
from
her
chair
;
"
and
what
is
to
be
noticed
in
it
is
that
it
MUST
BE
HEARD
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
,
who
is
afraid
of
nothing
,
admits
that
when
it
is
there
,
it
must
be
heard
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
shut
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
Watt
,
there
is
a
tall
French
clock
behind
you
(
placed
there
,
'
a
purpose
)
that
has
a
loud
beat
when
it
is
in
motion
and
can
play
music
.
 
<EOS>
You
understand
how
those
things
are
managed
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
grandmother
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Set
it
a
-
going
.
"
   
<EOS>
Watt
sets
it
a
-
going
---
music
and
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
come
hither
,
"
says
the
housekeeper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hither
,
child
,
towards
my
Lady
's
pillow
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
sure
that
it
is
dark
enough
yet
,
but
listen
!
 
<EOS>
Can
you
hear
the
sound
upon
the
terrace
,
through
the
music
,
and
the
beat
,
and
everything
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
can
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
my
Lady
says
.
<EOS>
"
    
Chapter
8
.
<EOS>
Covering
a
Multitude
of
Sins
 
<EOS>
It
was
interesting
when
I
dressed
before
daylight
to
peep
out
of
window
,
where
my
candles
were
reflected
in
the
black
panes
like
two
beacons
,
and
finding
all
beyond
still
enshrouded
in
the
indistinctness
of
last
night
,
to
watch
how
it
turned
out
when
the
day
came
on
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
prospect
gradually
revealed
itself
and
disclosed
the
scene
over
which
the
wind
had
wandered
in
the
dark
,
like
my
memory
over
my
life
,
I
had
a
pleasure
in
discovering
the
unknown
objects
that
had
been
around
me
in
my
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
they
were
faintly
discernible
in
the
mist
,
and
above
them
the
later
stars
still
glimmered
.
 
<EOS>
That
pale
interval
over
,
the
picture
began
to
enlarge
and
fill
up
so
fast
that
at
every
new
peep
I
could
have
found
enough
to
look
at
for
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Imperceptibly
my
candles
became
the
only
incongruous
part
of
the
morning
,
the
dark
places
in
my
room
all
melted
away
,
and
the
day
shone
bright
upon
a
cheerful
landscape
,
prominent
in
which
<EOS>
the
old
Abbey
Church
,
with
its
massive
tower
,
threw
a
softer
train
of
shadow
on
the
view
than
seemed
compatible
with
its
rugged
character
.
 
<EOS>
But
so
from
rough
outsides
<EOS>
(
I
hope
I
have
learnt
)
,
serene
and
gentle
influences
often
proceed
.
   
<EOS>
Every
part
of
the
house
was
in
such
order
,
and
every
one
was
so
attentive
to
me
,
that
I
had
no
trouble
with
my
two
bunches
of
keys
,
though
what
with
trying
to
remember
the
contents
of
each
little
store
-
room
drawer
and
cupboard
;
and
what
with
making
notes
on
a
slate
about
jams
,
and
pickles
,
and
preserves
,
and
bottles
,
and
glass
,
and
china
,
and
a
great
many
other
things
;
and
what
with
being
generally
a
methodical
,
old
-
maidish
sort
of
foolish
little
person
,
I
was
so
busy
that
I
could
not
believe
it
was
breakfast
-
time
when
I
heard
the
bell
ring
.
 
<EOS>
Away
I
ran
,
however
,
and
made
tea
,
as
I
had
already
been
installed
into
the
responsibility
of
the
tea
-
pot
;
and
then
,
as
they
were
all
rather
late
and
nobody
was
down
yet
,
I
thought
I
would
take
a
peep
at
the
garden
and
get
some
knowledge
of
that
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
it
quite
a
delightful
place
<EOS>
---
in
front
,
the
pretty
avenue
and
drive
by
which
we
had
approached
(
and
where
,
by
the
by
,
we
had
cut
up
the
gravel
so
terribly
with
our
wheels
that
I
asked
the
gardener
to
roll
it
)
;
at
the
back
,
the
flower
-
garden
,
with
my
darling
at
her
window
up
there
,
throwing
it
open
to
smile
out
at
me
,
as
if
she
would
have
kissed
me
from
that
distance
.
 
<EOS>
Beyond
the
flower
-
garden
was
a
kitchen
-
garden
,
and
then
a
paddock
,
and
then
a
snug
little
rick
-
yard
,
and
then
a
dear
little
farm
-
yard
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
house
itself
,
with
its
three
peaks
in
the
roof
;
its
various
-
shaped
windows
,
some
so
large
,
some
so
small
,
and
all
so
pretty
;
its
trellis
-
work
,
against
the
southfront
for
roses
and
honey
-
suckle
,
and
its
homely
,
comfortable
,
welcoming
look
---
it
was
,
as
Ada
said
when
she
came
out
to
meet
me
with
her
arm
through
that
of
its
master
,
worthy
of
her
cousin
John
,
a
bold
thing
to
say
,
though
he
only
pinched
her
dear
cheek
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
was
as
agreeable
at
breakfast
as
he
had
been
overnight
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
honey
on
the
table
,
and
it
led
him
into
a
discourse
about
bees
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
objection
to
honey
<EOS>
,
he
said
(
and
I
should
think
he
had
not
,
for
he
seemed
to
like
it
)
,
but
he
protested
against
the
overweening
assumptions
of
bees
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't
at
all
see
why
the
busy
bee
should
be
proposed
as
a
model
to
him
;
he
supposed
the
bee
liked
to
make
honey
,
or
he
would
n't
do
it
---
 
<EOS>
nobody
asked
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
necessary
for
the
bee
to
make
such
a
merit
of
his
tastes
.
 
<EOS>
If
every
confectioner
went
buzzing
about
the
world
banging
against
everything
that
came
in
his
way
and
egotistically
calling
upon
everybody
to
take
notice
that
he
was
going
to
his
work
and
must
not
be
interrupted
,
the
world
would
be
quite
an
unsupportable
place
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
after
all
,
it
was
a
ridiculous
position
to
be
smoked
out
of
your
fortune
with
brimstone
as
soon
as
you
had
made
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
have
a
very
mean
opinion
of
a
Manchester
man
if
he
spun
cotton
for
no
other
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
He
must
say
he
thought
a
drone
the
embodiment
of
a
pleasanter
and
wiser
idea
.
<EOS>
The
drone
said
unaffectedly
,
"
You
will
excuse
me
;
I
really
can
not
attend
to
the
shop
!
 
<EOS>
I
find
myself
in
a
world
in
which
there
is
so
much
to
see
and
so
short
a
time
to
see
it
in
that
I
must
take
the
liberty
of
looking
about
me
and
begging
to
be
provided
for
by
somebody
who
does
n't
want
to
look
about
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
appeared
to
Mr
Skimpole
to
be
the
drone
philosophy
,
and
he
thought
it
a
very
good
philosophy
,
always
supposing
the
drone
to
be
willing
to
be
on
good
terms
with
the
bee
,
which
,
so
far
as
he
knew
,
the
easy
fellow
always
was
,
if
the
consequential
creature
would
only
let
him
,
and
not
be
so
conceited
about
his
honey
!
   
<EOS>
He
pursued
this
fancy
with
the
lightest
foot
over
a
variety
of
ground
and
made
us
all
merry
,
<EOS>
though
again
he
seemed
to
have
as
serious
a
meaning
in
what
he
said
as
he
was
capable
of
having
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
them
still
listening
to
him
when
I
withdrew
to
attend
to
my
new
duties
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
occupied
me
for
some
time
,
and
I
was
passing
through
the
passages
on
my
return
with
my
basket
of
keys
on
my
arm
when
Mr
Jarndyce
called
me
into
a
small
room
next
his
bed
-
chamber
,
which
I
found
to
be
in
part
a
little
library
of
books
and
papers
and
in
part
quite
a
little
museum
of
his
boots
and
shoes
and
hat
-
boxes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
,
you
must
know
,
is
the
growlery
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
am
out
of
humour
,
I
come
and
growl
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
here
very
seldom
,
sir
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
do
n't
know
me
!
"
<EOS>
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
I
am
deceived
or
disappointed
in
---
the
wind
,
and
it
's
easterly
,
I
take
refuge
here
.
<EOS>
The
growlery
is
the
best
-
used
room
in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
aware
of
half
my
humours
yet
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
,
how
you
are
trembling
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
it
;
I
tried
very
hard
,
but
being
alone
with
that
benevolent
presence
,
and
meeting
his
kind
eyes
,
and
feeling
so
happy
and
so
honoured
there
,
and
my
heart
so
full
---
    
<EOS>
I
kissed
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
I
said
,
or
even
that
I
spoke
.
<EOS>
He
was
disconcerted
and
walked
to
the
window
;
I
almost
believed
with
an
intention
of
jumping
out
,
until
he
turned
and
I
was
reassured
by
seeing
in
his
eyes
what
he
had
gone
there
to
hide
.
 
<EOS>
He
gently
patted
me
on
the
head
,
and
I
sat
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
 
<EOS>
There
!
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
over
.
 
<EOS>
Pooh
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
foolish
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
shall
not
happen
again
,
sir
,
"
I
returned
,
"
but
at
first
it
is
difficult
---
"
   
"
Nonsense
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
easy
,
easy
.
 
<EOS>
Why
not
?
 
<EOS>
I
hear
of
a
good
little
orphan
girl
without
a
protector
,
and
I
take
it
into
my
head
to
be
that
protector
.
 
<EOS>
She
grows
up
,
and
more
than
justifies
my
good
opinion
,
and
I
remain
her
guardian
and
her
friend
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
there
in
all
this
?
 
<EOS>
So
,
so
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
we
have
cleared
off
old
scores
,
and
I
have
before
me
thy
pleasant
,
trusting
<EOS>
,
trusty
face
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
to

,
"
Esther
,
my
dear
,
you
surprise

!
 
<EOS>
This
really
is
not
what
I
expected
of
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
it
had
such
a
good
effect
that
I
folded
my

upon
my
basket
and
quite
recovered
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
,
expressing
his
approval
in
his
face
,
began
to
talk
to
me
as
confidentially
as
if
I
had
been
in
the

of
conversing
with

every

for
I
do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I
almost
felt
as
if
I
had
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
Esther
,
"
he

,
"
you
do
n't
understand
this
Chancery
business
?
"
   
<EOS>
And
of
course
I
shook
my
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
who
does
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
lawyers
have
twisted
it
into
such
a
state
of
bedevilment
that
the
original
merits
of
the
case
have
long
disappeared
from
the

of

earth
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
about
a
will
and
the
trusts
under
a
will
---
or
it
was
once
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
about
nothing
but
costs
now
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
always
appearing
,
and
disappearing
,
and
swearing
,
and
interrogating
,
and
filing
,
and
cross
-
filing
,
and
arguing
,
and
sealing
,
and
motioning
,
and
referring
,
and
reporting
,
and
revolving
about
the
Lord
Chancellor
and
all
his
satellites
,
and
equitably
waltzing
ourselves
off
to
dusty
death
,
about
costs
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
great
question
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
rest
,
by
some

means
,
has
melted
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
was
,
sir
,
"
said
I
,
to
bring
him
back
,
for
he
began

rub

,
"
about
a
will
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
,
it
was
about
a
will
when

was
about
anything
,
"
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
certain
Jarndyce
,
in
an
evil
hour
,
made
a
great

,
and
made
a
great
will
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
question
how
the
trusts
under
that
will
are
to
be
administered
,
the
fortune
left
by
the
will
is
squandered
away
;
the
legatees
under

will
are

to

that
they
would
be
sufficiently

if

committed
an
enormous
crime
in
having
money
left
them
,
and
the
will
itself
is
made
a
dead

.
 
<EOS>
All
through
the
deplorable
cause
,
everything
that
everybody
in
it
,
except
one
man
,
knows
already
is
referred
to
that
only
one
man
who
do
n't

to
find
out
---
all
through
the
deplorable
cause
,
everybody
must
have
copies
,
over
and
over
again
,
of
everything
that
has
accumulated
about
it
in
the
way
of
cartloads
of

(
or
must
pay
for

without
having

,
which
is
the
usual

,
for
nobody
wants

)
and
must
go
down
the
middle
and
up
again
through
such

infernal

-
dance
of

and

and
nonsense
and
corruption
as
was
never
dreamed
of
in
the
wildest
visions
of
a
witch
's
Sabbath
.
 
<EOS>
Equity
sends
questions
to
law
,
law
sends
questions
back
to
equity
;
law
finds
it
ca
n't
do
this
,
equity
finds
it
ca
n't
do
that
;
neither
can
so
much
as
say
it
ca
n't
do
anything
,
without
this

instructing
and
this
counsel
appearing
for
A
,
and
that

instructing
and
that

for
B
;
and
so
on
through
the
whole

,
like
the
history
of
the

.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
,
through

and

,
and

and
lives
,
everything
goes
on
,
constantly

over
and
over

,
and
nothing

ends
.
 
<EOS>
And
we
ca
n't
get
out

the
suit
on
any
terms
,
for
we
are
made
parties
to
it
,
and
MUST
BE
parties
to
it
,
whether

.
 
<EOS>
But
it
wo
n't
do
to
think

it
!
 
<EOS>
When
my

,
poor
Tom
Jarndyce
,

it
,
it
was

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
Mr
Jarndyce
,
sir
,
whose
story
I
have
heard
?
"
   
<EOS>
He

gravely
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
his
heir
,
and
this
was
his
house
,
Esther
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
came
here
,
it
was
bleak

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
left
the
signs
of
his
misery
upon

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
changed
it
must
be
now
!
<EOS>
"
I
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
had
been
called
,
before
his
time
,
the
Peaks
.
 
<EOS>
He
gave
it
its
present
name
and
lived
here
<EOS>
shut
up
,
day
and
night
poring
over
the
wicked

of
papers
in
the
suit
and
hoping
against
hope
to
disentangle
it
from

and
bring

to

.
 
<EOS>
In
the

,
the
place
became
dilapidated
,
the
wind

through
the
cracked

,
the
rain
fell
through

broken

,
the

passage
to
the

.
 
<EOS>
When
I
brought
what
remained
of
him
home
here
,
the
brains
seemed
to
me
to
have
been
blown
out
of
the
house
too
<EOS>
,
it
was
so
shattered

.
"
   
<EOS>
He
walked
a

to

after

with

,
and
then
looked
at
me
,
and

,
and
came

down
again
with
his
hands
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
told

this
was
the
growlery
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Where
was
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
reminded
him
,
at
the
hopeful
change
he
had
made
in
Bleak
House
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bleak
House
;
true
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
,
in
that
city
of
London
there
,
some
property
of
ours
which
is
much
at
this
day
what
Bleak
House
was
then
;
I
say
property
of
ours
,
meaning
of
the
suit
's
,
but
I
ought
to
call
it
the
property
of
costs
,
for
costs
is
the
only
power
on
earth
that
will
ever
get
anything
out
of
it
now
or
will
ever
know
it
for
anything
but
an

and

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
street
of
perishing
blind
houses
,
with
their
eyes
stoned
out
,
without
a
pane

glass
,
without
so

-

,
with

and

,

in

,

in
,
the
stone

to
every

(
and

might

death
's
door
)
turning

,
the
very

on
which
the

are
propped
decaying
.
 
<EOS>
Although
Bleak
House
was
not
in
Chancery
,
its
master
was
,
and
it
was
stamped

.
 
<EOS>
These
are
the
Great
Seal
's

,
my

,
all

England
---
the
children
know

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How

is
!
"
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,

it

,
"
he

;
"
and

to

the

picture
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
The
idea
of
my
wisdom
!
)
 
<EOS>
"
These
are
things
I
never
talk
about
or

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

to
mention

to
Rick

Ada
,
"
looking

,
"
you

.
 
<EOS>
I
leave

to
your

,
Esther
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,

---
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
had
better
call

guardian
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
that
I
was
choking
again
---
I
taxed
myself
with
it
,
"
Esther
,
now
,
you
know
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
---
when
he
feigned
to
say
this
slightly
,
as

were
a

instead
of
a

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
gave
the
housekeeping
keys
the
least
shake
in
the
world
as
a
reminder
to
myself
,
and
folding
my
hands
in
a
still
more
determined

on

,
looked
at

quietly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
guardian
,
"
said
I
,
"
that
you
may
not
trust
too
much
to
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
may
not
mistake
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
it
will
be
a
disappointment
to
you
to
know
that
I
am
not
clever
,
but
it
really
is
the
truth
,
and
you
would
soon
find
it
out
if
I
had
not
the

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
He
did
not
seem

all

;
quite

.
 
<EOS>
He
told
me
,
with
a
smile
all

face
,
that
he
knew
me
very
well

and
that
I
was
quite
clever
enough
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
may
turn

so
,
"
said
I
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
am
much
afraid
of
it
,
guardian
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
clever
enough
to
be
the
good
little
woman
of
our
lives
here
,
my
dear
,
"
he
returned
playfully
;
"
the
little
old
woman
of
the
child
's
(
I
do
n't
mean
Skimpole
's
)
rhyme
:
     
"
Little
old
woman
,
and
whither
so
high
?
"
     
<EOS>
"
To
sweep
the
cobwebs
out
of
the
sky
.
"
   
<EOS>
You
will
sweep
them
so
neatly
out
of
OUR
sky
in
the
course

your
housekeeping
,
Esther
,
that
one

these
days
we
shall
have
to
abandon

growlery
and
nail

.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
beginning
of
my
being
called
Old
Woman
,
and
Little

Woman
,
and
Cobweb
,

Mrs

,

Mother

,

,
and
so

that

that
my
own
name
soon

.
   
<EOS>
"
However
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
to

.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
Rick
,
a
fine
young
fellow
full

.
 
<EOS>
What
's
to

done
with
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
goodness
,
the
idea
of

my
advice
on
such

!
   
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
,
Esther
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
comfortably

his
hands
into

and

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
must
have
a

;
he
must

.
 
<EOS>
There
will
be
a
world
more
wiglomeration
about

,
I

,
but
it
must

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
More
what
,
guardian
?
"
said

<EOS>
"
More
wiglomeration
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
only
name
I
know
for
the
thing
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
ward
in
Chancery
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Kenge
and
Carboy
will
have
something
to
say
about
it
;
Master
Somebody
---
a
sort
of
ridiculous
sexton
,
digging
graves
for
the
merits
of
causes
in
a
back
room
at
the
end
of
Quality
Court
,
Chancery
Lane
---
will
have
something
to
say
about
it
;
counsel
will
have
something
to
say
about
it
;
the
Chancellor
will
have
something
to
say
about
it
;
the
satellites
will
have
something
to
say
about
it
;
they
will
all
have
to
be
handsomely
feed
,
all
round
,
about
it
;
the
whole
thing
will
be
vastly
ceremonious
,
wordy
,
unsatisfactory
,
and
expensive
,
and
I
call
it
,
in
general
,
wiglomeration
.
 
<EOS>
How
mankind
ever
came
to
be
afflicted
with
wiglomeration
,
or
for
whose
sins
these
young
people
ever
fell
into
a
pit
of
it
,
I
do
n't
know
;
so
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
began
to
rub
his
head
again
and
to
hint
that
he
felt
the
wind
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
a
delightful
instance
of
his
kindness
towards
me
that
whether
he
rubbed
his
head
,
or
walked
about
,
or
did
both
,
his
face
was
sure
to
recover
its
benignant
expression
as
it
looked
at
mine
;
and
he
was
sure
to
turn
comfortable
again
and
put
his
hands
in
his

and
stretch
out

.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
would
be
best
,
first
of
all
,
"
said
I
,
"
to
ask
Mr
Richard
what
he
inclines
to
himself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
so
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
I
mean
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
,
just
accustom
yourself
to
talk
it
over
,
with
your

and
in

quiet

,
with
him
and
Ada
,
and
see

.
 
<EOS>
We
are
sure
to
come
at
the
heart
of
the
matter
by
your
means
,
little
woman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
really
was
frightened
at
the
thought
of
the
importance
I
was
attaining
and
the
number
of
things
that
were
being
confided
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
had
not
meant
this
at
all
;
I
had
meant
that
he
should
speak
to
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
But
of
course
I
said
nothing
in

except
that
I
would
do
my
best
,
though
I
feared
(
I
realty
felt
it
necessary
to

)
that
he
thought
me
much

than
I
was
.
 
<EOS>
At
which
my
guardian
only
laughed
the
pleasantest

I
ever
heard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
rising
and
pushing

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
we
may
have
done
with
the
growlery
for
one
day
!
 
<EOS>
Only
a

word
.
 
<EOS>
Esther
,
my
dear
,
do
you
wish
to
ask
me
anything
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
so
attentively
at
me
that
I
looked
attentively
at
him
and
felt
sure
I
understood
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
About
myself
,
sir
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
"
Guardian
,
"
said
I
,
venturing
to
put
my

,
which
was
suddenly
colder
than
I
could
have
wished
,
in
his
,
"
nothing
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
quite
sure
that
if
there

I

know
,

.
 
<EOS>
If

and

were
not

you
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
to

,
nothing
in

world
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
drew
my
hand
through

arm
and
we
went
away
to
look
for
Ada
.
<EOS>
From
that
hour
I
felt
quite
easy
with
him
,
quite
unreserved
,
quite
content
to
know
no

,
quite
happy
.
   
<EOS>
We
lived
,
at
first
,
<EOS>
rather
a
busy
life
at
Bleak
House
,
for
we
had
to
become
acquainted
with
many
residents
in
and
out

the
neighbourhood
who
knew
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
Ada
and
me
that
everybody
knew
him
who
wanted
to
do
anything
with
anybody
else
's
money
.
 
<EOS>
It
amazed
us
when
we
began
to
sort
his
letters
and
to
answer
some
of
them
for
him
in
the
growlery
of
a
morning
to
find
how
the
great
object
of
the
lives
of
nearly
all

correspondents
appeared
to
be
to
form

into

for
getting
in
and

.
 
<EOS>
The
ladies
were
as

as
the
gentlemen
;
indeed
,

.
 
<EOS>
They
threw
themselves
into
committees
in
the
most
impassioned
manner
and
collected
subscriptions
with
a

quite

.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
us
that
some
of
them
must
pass
their
whole
lives
in
dealing
out
subscription
-
cards
to
the
whole
post
-
office
directory
---
 
<EOS>
shilling
cards
,
half
-
crown
cards
,
half
-
sovereign

,
penny

.
 
<EOS>
They
wanted
everything
.
 
<EOS>
They
wanted
wearing
apparel
,
they
wanted
linen
rags
,
they
wanted
money
,
they
wanted
coals
,
they
wanted
soup
,
they
wanted
interest
,
they
wanted
autographs
,
they
wanted

,
they
wanted
whatever
Mr
Jarndyce
had
---
or
had

.
<EOS>
Their
objects
were
as
various
as
their

.
 
<EOS>
They
were
going
to
raise
new
buildings
,
they
were
going
to
pay

on
old

,
they
were
going
to
establish
in
a

(
engraving
of
proposed
west
elevation
attached
)
the
Sisterhood
of
Mediaeval
Marys
,

Mrs
Jellyby
,

's

to

mother
-

law
,
<EOS>
whose
deep
devotion
to
him
was
well

,
they

going

get
up
everything
<EOS>
,
I
really
believe
,
from

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
They

the
Women
of
England
,
the
Daughters

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

always

about

.
 
<EOS>
They
seemed
to
our
poor

,
and
according

their

,
to
be
constantly
polling
people
by

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

to

,
on

,
what

must

.
   
<EOS>
Among

for

(
if
I
may
use
the

)

a
Mrs
Pardiggle
,

,

Mr

,

Mrs

.
<EOS>
We
observed
that
the
wind
always
changed
when
Mrs
Pardiggle
became

subject

and
that
it
invariably
interrupted
Mr

and

going
any

,
when

;

;
the

,

a

.
 
<EOS>
We
were
therefore

Mrs
Pardiggle
,
suspecting

to
be
a
type
of
the
former

,
and
were

called
one

with

five

sons
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
a
formidable
style
of
lady
with

,
a
prominent
nose
,
and
a
loud
voice
,
who
had
the
effect
of

.
 
<EOS>
And
she
really

,
for
she
knocked
down
little

with
her
skirts
<EOS>
that
were
quite

.
 
<EOS>
As

Ada

,

,
for

to

like

and
to
make
the
little
Pardiggles
blue

.
   
<EOS>
"
These
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Egbert
,

(

)

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
At

the

,

supposed

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
I

except
,

,
the

,

<EOS>
"

,

"

,
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
We

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

(

)
<EOS>
that

ill

,
these

.
 
<EOS>
He

but

.
   
<EOS>
"
They

(
very

)
at

<EOS>
all

,

"

Pardiggle

"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

;

---
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
But

;
and

they
acquire

,

---
which
will

a

and

.
 
<EOS>
My
young
family
are
not

;
they

the
entire

their

in
subscriptions
,
under
my

;
and
they

<EOS>
Alfred
(

)
,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Alfred

,

,

.

"

,

"

,

,

O*A
Pardiggle
,
F*R*S
,
one

.
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
We
usually

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

enrol

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pardiggle
is

to
throw

his
limited
donation
,
under

;
and
thus
things
are
made
not

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Suppose
Mr

,

?
 
<EOS>
I
was

to
find
myself

this
,
but

came
into

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very

here
!
"
said
Mrs
Pardiggle
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
glad
to
change
the
subject
,
and
going
to
the

,

out
the
beauties
of
the
prospect
,
on

the

appeared
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
Mr
Gusher
?
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
We
were
obliged
to
say
that
we
had
not
the

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
The
loss

,

,
"
said
Mrs
Pardiggle
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
very
fervid
,

speaker
-
full

fire
!
 
<EOS>
Stationed
in
a

on
this

,
now
,
which
,
from
the

the

,
is

a

,
he

!
 
<EOS>
By
this

,
young

"

,

,

,
a

,
"
by
this

have
found

,
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
This

that
Ada

.
 
<EOS>
As

my

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Found

,
I

,
"

Pardiggle
,
"
the

my

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

that
it
is
so

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
I
know
.
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
freely

,
I
am
a

.
 
<EOS>
I
love

;
I
enjoy

.
 
<EOS>
The

does
me

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
so

hard

that
I
do

fatigue

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
We

that

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

;

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

(

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
If

dark

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

"
 
<EOS>
It

!
 
<EOS>
Miss

,

,

Clare
's

"
   
<EOS>
At

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
For

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Ada

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
As

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Felix
,

<EOS>
And

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs

,

<EOS>
(

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs

her
spectacles
with
a
forcible
composure
,
calculated
<EOS>
,
I
could
not
help
thinking
,
to
increase

,

good
book
as

a

's
staff

.
 
<EOS>
I
mean

,

;

carrying

.
   
<EOS>
Ada

I
were
very

.
 
<EOS>
We
both

intrusive
and
out

,
and

both

that
Mrs
Pardiggle

have

.
 
<EOS>
The

;
