us
<EOS>
whatever
,

.
 
<EOS>
We

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs

the
pipe

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

Jenny
!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

"
    
Chapter
9
.
<EOS>
Signs
and
Tokens
 
I
do
n't
know
how
it
is
I
seem
to
be
always
writing
about
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
all
the
time
to
write
about
other
people
,
and
I
try
to
think
about
myself
as
little
as
possible
,
and
I
am
sure
,
when
I
find
myself
coming
into
the
story
again
,
I
am
really
vexed
and
say
,
"
Dear
,
dear
,
you
tiresome
little
creature
,
I
wish
you
would
n't
!
"
<EOS>
but
it
is
all
of
no
use
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
any
one
who
may
read
what
I
write
will
understand
that
if
these
pages
contain
a
great
deal
about
me
,
I
can
only
suppose
it
must
be
because
I
have
really
something
to
do
with
them
and
ca
n't
be
kept
out
.
   
<EOS>
My
darling
and
<EOS>
I
read
together
,
and
worked
,
and
practised
,
and
found
so
much
employment
for
our
time
that
the
winter
days
flew
by
us
like
bright
-
winged
birds
.
 
<EOS>
Generally
in
the
afternoons
,
and
always
in
the
evenings
,
Richard
gave
us
his
company
.
 
<EOS>
Although
he
was
one
of
the
most
restless
creatures
in
the
world
,
he
certainly
was
very
fond
of
our
society
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
very
,
very
,
very
fond
of
Ada
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
it
,
and
<EOS>
I
had
better
say
it
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
seen
any
young
people
falling
in
love
before
,
but
I
found
them
out
quite
soon
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
say
so
,
of
course
,
or
show
that
I
knew
anything
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
I
was
so
demure
and
used
to
seem
so
unconscious
that
sometimes
I
considered
within
myself
while
I
was
sitting
at
work
whether
I
was
not
growing
quite
deceitful
.
   
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
help
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
All
I
had
to
do
was
to
be
quiet
,
and
I
was
as
quiet
as
a
mouse
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
as
quiet
as
mice
too
,
so
far
as
any
words
were
concerned
,
but
the
innocent
manner
in
which
they
relied
more
and
more
upon
me
as
they
took
more
and
more
to
one
another
was
so
charming
that
I
had
great
difficulty
in
not
showing
how
it
interested
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
dear
little
old
woman
is
such
a
capital
old
woman
,
"
Richard
would
say
,
coming
up
to
meet
me
in
the
garden
early
,
with
his
pleasant
laugh
and
perhaps
the
least
tinge
of
a
blush
,
"
that
I
ca
n't
get
on
without
her
.
 
<EOS>
Before
I
begin
my
harum
-
scarum
day
---
 
grinding
away
at
those
books
and
instruments
and
then
galloping
up
hill
and
down
dale
,
all
the
country
round
,
like
a
highwayman
<EOS>
---
it
does
me
so
much
good
to
come
and
have
a
steady
walk
with
our
comfortable
friend
,
that
here
I
am
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
Dame
Durden
,
dear
,
"
Ada
would
say
at
night
,
with
her
head
upon
my
shoulder
and
the
firelight
shining
in
her
thoughtful
eyes
,
"
I
do
n't
want
to
talk
when
we
come
upstairs
here
.
 
<EOS>
Only
to
sit
a
little
while
thinking
,
with
your
dear
face
for
company
,
and
to
hear
the
wind
and
remember
the
poor
sailors
at
sea
---
<EOS>
"
   
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
Richard
was
going
to
be
a
sailor
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
talked
it
over
very
often
now
,
and
there
was
some
talk
of
gratifying
the
inclination
of
his
childhood
for
the
sea
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
had
written
to
a
relation
of
the
family
,
a
great
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
for
his
interest
in
Richard
's
favour
,
generally
;
and
Sir
Leicester
had
replied
in
a
gracious
manner
that
he
would
be
happy
to
advance
the
prospects
of
the
young
gentleman
if
it
should
ever
prove
to
be
within
his
power
,
which
was
not
at
all
probable
,
and
that
my
Lady
sent
her
compliments
to
the
young
gentleman
(
to
whom
she
perfectly
remembered
that
she
was
allied
by
remote
consanguinity
)
and
trusted
that
he
would
ever
do
his
duty
in
any
honourable
profession
to
which
he
might
devote
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
apprehend
it
's
pretty
clear
,
"
said
Richard
to
me
,
"
that
I
shall
have
to
work
my
own
way
.
 
<EOS>
Never
mind
!
 
<EOS>
Plenty
of
people
have
had
to
do
that
before
now
,
and
have
done
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
wish
I
had
the
command
of
a
clipping
privateer
to
begin
with
and
could
carry
off
the
Chancellor
and
keep
him
on
short
allowance
until
he
gave
judgment
in
our
cause
.
 
<EOS>
He
'd
find
himself
growing
thin
,
if
he
did
n't
look
sharp
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
a
buoyancy
and
hopefulness
and
a
gaiety
that
hardly
ever
flagged
,
Richard
had
a
carelessness
in
his
character
that
quite
perplexed
me
,
principally
because
he
mistook
it
,
in
such
a
very
odd
way
,
for
prudence
.
 
<EOS>
It
entered
into
all
his
calculations
about
money
in
a
singular
manner
which
I
do
n't
think
I
can
better
explain
than
by
reverting
for
a
moment
to
our
loan
to
Mr
Skimpole
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
had
ascertained
the
amount
,
either
from
Mr
Skimpole
himself
or
from
Coavinses
,
and
had
placed
the
money
in
my
hands
with
instructions
to
me
to
retain
my
own
part
of
it
and
hand
the
rest
to
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
The
number
of
little
acts
of
thoughtless
expenditure
which
Richard
justified
by
the
recovery
of
his
ten
pounds
,
and
the
number
of
times
he
talked
to
me
as
if
he
had
saved
or
realized
that
amount
,
would
form
a
sum
in
simple
addition
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
prudent
Mother
Hubbard
,
why
not
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
said
to
me
when
he
wanted
,
without
the
least
consideration
,
to
bestow
five
pounds
on
the
brickmaker
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
made
ten
pounds
,
clear
,
out
of
Coavinses
'
business
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
was
that
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
got
rid
of
ten
pounds
which
I
was
quite
content
to
get
rid
of
and
never
expected
to
see
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
deny
that
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
!
 
<EOS>
Then
I
came
into
possession
of
ten
pounds
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
The
same
ten
pounds
,
"
I
hinted
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
has
nothing
to
do
with
it
!
"
returned
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
ten
pounds
more
than
I
expected
to
have
,
and
consequently
I
can
afford
to
spend
it
without
being
particular
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
In
exactly
the
same
way
,
when
he
was
persuaded
out
of
the
sacrifice
of
these
five
pounds
by
being
convinced
that
it
would
do
no
good
,
he
carried
that
sum
to
his
credit
and
drew
upon
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
!
"
he
would
say
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
saved
five
pounds
out
of
the
brickmaker
's
affair
,
so
if
I
have
a
good
rattle
to
London
and
back
in
a
post
-
chaise
and
put
that
down
at
four
pounds
,
I
shall
have
saved
one
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
's
a
very
good
thing
to
save
one
,
let
me
tell
you
:
a
penny
saved
is
a
penny
got
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
believe
Richard
's
was
as
frank
and
generous
a
nature
as
there
possibly
can
be
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
ardent
and
brave
,
and
in
the
midst
of
all
his
wild
restlessness
,
was
so
gentle
that
I
knew
him
like
a
brother
in
a
few
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
His
gentleness
was
natural
to
him
and
would
have
shown
itself
abundantly
even
without
Ada
's
influence
;
but
with
it
,
he
became
one
of
the
most
winning
of
companions
,
always
so
ready
to
be
interested
and
always
so
happy
,
sanguine
,
and
light
-
hearted
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
that
I
,
sitting
with
them
,
and
walking
with
them
,
and
talking
with
them
,
and
noticing
from
day
to
day
how
they
went
on
,
falling
deeper
and
deeper
in
love
,
and
saying
nothing
about
it
,
and
each
shyly
thinking
that
this
love
was
the
greatest
of
secrets
,
perhaps
not
yet
suspected
even
by
the
other
---
I
am
sure
that
I
was
scarcely
less
enchanted
than
they
were
and
scarcely
less
pleased
with
the
pretty
dream
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
going
on
in
this
way
,
when
one
morning
at
breakfast
Mr
Jarndyce
received
a
letter
,
and
looking
at
the
superscription
,
said
,
"
From
Boythorn
?
 
<EOS>
Aye
,
aye
!
"
and
opened
and
read
it
with
evident
pleasure
,
announcing
to
us
in
a
parenthesis
when
he
was
about
half
-
way
through
,
that
Boythorn
was
"
coming
down
"
on
a
visit
.
<EOS>
Now
who
was
Boythorn
,
we
all
thought
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
dare
say
we
all
thought
too
---
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
did
,
for
one
---
would
Boythorn
at
all
interfere
with
what
was
going
forward
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
went
to
school
with
this
fellow
,
Lawrence
Boythorn
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
tapping
the
letter
as
he
laid
it
on
the
table
,
"
more
than
five
and
forty
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
then
the
most
impetuous
boy
in
the
world
,
and
he
is
now
the
most
impetuous
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
then
the
loudest
boy
in
the
world
,
and
he
is
now
the
loudest
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
then
the
heartiest
and
sturdiest
boy
in
the
world
,
and
he
is
now
the
heartiest
and
sturdiest
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
tremendous
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
stature
,
sir
?
"
asked
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
Rick
,
in
that
respect
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
;
"
being
some
ten
years
older
than
I
and
a
couple
of
inches
taller
,
with
his
head
thrown
back
like
an
old
soldier
,
his
stalwart
chest
squared
,
his
hands
like
a
clean
blacksmith
's
,
and
his
lungs
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
simile
for
his
lungs
.
 
<EOS>
Talking
,
laughing
,
or
snoring
,
they
make
the
beams
of
the
house
shake
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Jarndyce
sat
enjoying
the
image
of
his
friend
Boythorn
<EOS>
,
we
observed
the
favourable
omen
that
there
was
not
the
least
indication
of
any
change
in
the
wind
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
's
the
inside
of
the
man
,
the
warm
heart
of
the
man
,
the
passion
of
the
man
,
the
fresh
blood
of
the
man
,
Rick
---
and
Ada
,
and
little
Cobweb
too
,
for
you
are
all
interested
in
a
visitor
---
that
I
speak
of
,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
His
language
is
as
sounding
as
his
voice
.
<EOS>
He
is
always
in
extremes
,
perpetually
in
the
superlative
degree
.
<EOS>
In
his
condemnation
he
is
all
ferocity
.
 
<EOS>
You
might
suppose
him
to
be
an
ogre
from
what
he
says
,
and
I
believe
he
has
the
reputation
of
one
with
some
people
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
no
more
of
him
beforehand
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
not
be
surprised
to
see
him
take
me
under
his
protection
,
<EOS>
for
he
has
never
forgotten
that
I
was
a
low
boy
at
school
and
that
our
friendship
began
in
his
knocking
two
of
my
head
tyrant
's
teeth
out
(
he
says
six
)
before
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
Boythorn
and
his
man
,
"
to
me
,
"
will
be
here
this
afternoon
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
took
care
that
the
necessary
preparations
were
made
for
Mr
Boythorn
's
reception
,
and
we
looked
forward
to
his
arrival
with
some
curiosity
.
 
<EOS>
The
afternoon
wore
away
,
however
,
and
he
did
not
appear
.
 
<EOS>
The
dinner
-
hour
arrived
,
and
still
he
did
not
appear
.
 
<EOS>
The
dinner
was
put
back
an
hour
,
and
we
were
sitting
round
the
fire
with
no
light
but
the
blaze
when
the
hall
-
door
suddenly
burst
open
and
the
hall
resounded
with
these
words
,
uttered
with
the
greatest
vehemence
and
in
a
stentorian
tone
:
"
We
have
been
misdirected
,
Jarndyce
,
by
a
most
abandoned
ruffian
,
who
told
us
to
take
the
turning
to
the
right
instead
of
to
the
left
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
the
most
intolerable
scoundrel
on
the
face
of
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
His
father
must
have
been
a
most
consummate
villain
,
ever
to
have
such
a
son
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
had
that
fellow
shot
without
the
least
remorse
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
he
do
it
on
purpose
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
the
slightest
doubt
that
the
scoundrel
has
passed
his
whole
existence
in
misdirecting
travellers
!
"
returned
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
my
soul
,
I
thought
him
the
worst
-
looking
dog
<EOS>
I
had
ever
beheld
when
he
was
telling
me
to
take
the
turning
to
the
right
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
I
stood
before
that
fellow
face
to
face
and
did
n't
knock
his
brains
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Teeth
,
you
mean
?
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
laughed
Mr
Lawrence
Boythorn
,
really
making
the
whole
house
vibrate
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
,
you
have
not
forgotten
it
yet
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
And
that
was
another
most
consummate
vagabond
!
 
<EOS>
By
my
soul
,
the
countenance
of
that
fellow
when
he
was
a
boy
was
the
blackest
image
of
perfidy
,
cowardice
,
and
cruelty
ever
set
up
as
a
scarecrow
in
a
field
of
scoundrels
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
were
to
meet
that
most
unparalleled
despot
in
the
streets
to
-
morrow
,
I
would
fell
him
like
a
rotten
tree
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
of
it
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
will
you
come
upstairs
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
my
soul
,
Jarndyce
,
"
returned
his
guest
,
who
seemed
to
refer
to
his
watch
,
"
if
you
had
been
married
,
I
would
have
turned
back
at
the
garden
-
gate
and
gone
away
to
the
remotest
summits
of
the
Himalaya
Mountains
sooner
than
I
would
have
presented
myself
at
this
unseasonable
hour
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
so
far
,
I
hope
?
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
my
life
and
honour
,
yes
!
"
cried
the
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
n't
be
guilty
of
the
audacious
insolence
of
keeping
a
lady
of
the
house
waiting
all
this
time
for
any
earthly
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
infinitely
rather
destroy
myself
---
infinitely
rather
!
"
   
<EOS>
Talking
thus
,
they
went
upstairs
,
and
presently
we
heard
him
in
his
bedroom
thundering
"
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
and
again
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
until
the
flattest
echo
in
the
neighbourhood
seemed
to
catch
the
contagion
and
to
laugh
as
enjoyingly
as
he
did
or
as
we
did
when
we
heard
him
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
We
all
conceived
a
prepossession
in
his
favour
,
for
there
was
a
sterling
quality
in
this
laugh
,
and
in
his
vigorous
,
healthy
voice
,
and
in
the
roundness
and
fullness
with
which
he
uttered
every
word
he
spoke
,
and
in
the
very
fury
of
his
superlatives
,
which
seemed
to
go
off
like
blank
cannons
and
hurt
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
were
hardly
prepared
to
have
it
so
confirmed
by
his
appearance
when
Mr
Jarndyce
presented
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
only
a
very
handsome
old
gentleman
---
upright
and
stalwart
as
he
had
been
described
to
us
---
 
with
a
massive
grey
head
,
a
fine
composure
of
face
when
silent
,
a
figure
that
might
have
become
corpulent
but
for
his
being
so
continually
in
earnest
that
he
gave
it
no
rest
,
and
a
chin
that
might
have
subsided
into
a
double
chin
but
for
the
vehement
emphasis
in
which
it
was
constantly
required
to
assist
;
but
he
was
such
a
true
gentleman
in
his
manner
,
so
chivalrously
polite
,
his
face
was
lighted
by
a
smile
of
so
much
sweetness
and
tenderness
,
and
it
seemed
so
plain
that
he
had
nothing
to
hide
,
but
showed
himself
exactly
as
he
was
---
incapable
,
as
Richard
said
,
of
anything
on
a
limited
scale
,
and
firing
away
with
those
blank
great
guns
because
he
carried
no
small
arms
<EOS>
whatever
---
that
really
I
could
not
help
looking
at
him
with
equal
pleasure
as
he
sat
at
dinner
,
whether
he
smilingly
conversed
with
Ada
and
me
,
or
was
led
by
Mr
Jarndyce
into
some
great
volley
of
superlatives
,
or
threw
up
his
head
like
a
bloodhound
and
gave
out
that
tremendous
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
   
"
You
have
brought
your
bird
with
you
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
heaven
,
he
is
the
most
astonishing
bird
in
Europe
!
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
IS
the
most
wonderful
creature
!
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
take
ten
thousand
guineas
for
that
bird
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
left
an
annuity
for
his
sole
support
in
case
he
should
outlive
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
,
in
sense
and
attachment
,
a
phenomenon
.
 
<EOS>
And
his
father
before
him
was
one
of
the
most
astonishing
birds
that
ever
lived
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
subject
of
this
laudation
was
a
very
little
canary
,
who
was
so
tame
that
he
was
brought
down
by
Mr
Boythorn
's
man
,
on
his
forefinger
,
and
after
taking
a
gentle
flight
round
the
room
,
alighted
on
his
master
's
head
.
 
<EOS>
To
hear
Mr
Boythorn
presently
expressing
the
most
implacable
and
passionate
sentiments
,
with
this
fragile
mite
of
a
creature
quietly
perched
on
his
forehead
,
was
to
have
a
good
illustration
of
his
character
,
I
thought
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
my
soul
,
Jarndyce
,
"
he
said
,
very
gently
holding
up
a
bit
of
bread
to
the
canary
to
peck
at
,
"
if
I
were
in
your
place
<EOS>
I
would
seize
every
master
in
Chancery
by
the
throat
tomorrow
morning
and
shake
him
until
his
money
rolled
out
of
his
pockets
and
his
bones
rattled
in
his
skin
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
a
settlement
out
of
somebody
,
by
fair
means
or
by
foul
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
would
empower
me
to
do
it
,
I
would
do
it
for
you
with
the
greatest
satisfaction
!
"
 
<EOS>
(
All
this
time
the
very
small
canary
was
eating
out
of
his
hand
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
,
Lawrence
,
but
the
suit
is
hardly
at
such
a
point
at
present
,
"
returned
Mr
Jarndyce
,
laughing
,
"
that
it
would
be
greatly
advanced
even
by
the
legal
process
of
shaking
the
bench
and
the
whole
bar
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
never
was
such
an
infernal
cauldron
as
that
Chancery
on
the
face
of
the
earth
!
"
said
Mr
Boythorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
but
a
mine
below
it
on
a
busy
day
in
term
time
,
with
all
its
records
,
rules
,
and
precedents
collected
in
it
and
every
functionary
belonging
to
it
also
,
high
and
low
,
upward
and
downward
,
from
its
son
the
Accountant
-
General
to
its
father
the
Devil
,
and
the
whole
blown
to
atoms
with
ten
thousand
hundredweight
of
gunpowder
,
would
reform
it
in
the
least
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
not
to
laugh
at
the
energetic
gravity
with
which
he
recommended
this
strong
measure
of
reform
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
laughed
,
he
threw
up
his
head
and
shook
his
broad
chest
,
and
again
the
whole
country
seemed
to
echo
to
his
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
 
<EOS>
It
had
not
the
least
effect
in
disturbing
the
bird
,
whose
sense
of
security
was
complete
and
who
hopped
about
the
table
with
its
quick
head
now
on
this
side
and
now
on
that
,
turning
its
bright
sudden
eye
on
its
master
as
if
he
were
no
more
than
another
bird
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
how
do
you
and
your
neighbour
get
on
about
the
disputed
right
of
way
?
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
free
from
the
toils
of
the
law
yourself
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
fellow
has
brought
actions
against
ME
for
trespass
,
and
I
have
brought
actions
against
HIM
for
trespass
,
"
returned
Mr
Boythorn
.
<EOS>
"
By
heaven
,
he
is
the
proudest
fellow
breathing
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
morally
impossible
that
his
name
can
be
Sir
Leicester
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
be
Sir
Lucifer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Complimentary
to
our
distant
relation
!
"
said
my
guardian
laughingly
to
Ada
and
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
beg
Miss
Clare
's
pardon
and
Mr
Carstone
's
pardon
,
"
resumed
our
visitor
,
"
if
I
were
not
reassured
by
seeing
in
the
fair
face
of
the
lady
and
the
smile
of
the
gentleman
that
it
is
quite
unnecessary
and
that
they
keep
their
distant
relation
at
a
comfortable
distance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Or
he
keeps
us
,
"
suggested
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
my
soul
,
"
exclaimed
Mr
Boythorn
,
suddenly
firing
another
volley
,
"
that
fellow
is
,
and
his
father
was
,
and
his
grandfather
was
,
the
most
stiff
-
necked
,
arrogant
imbecile
,
pig
-
headed
numskull
,
ever
,
by
some
inexplicable
mistake
of
Nature
,
<EOS>
born
in
any
station
of
life
but
a
walking
-
stick
's
!
 
<EOS>
The
whole
of
that
family
are
the
most
solemnly
conceited
and
consummate
blockheads
!
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
no
matter
;
he
should
not
shut
up
my
path
if
he
were
fifty
baronets
melted
into
one
and
living
in
a
hundred
Chesney
Wolds
,
one
within
another
,
like
the
ivory
balls
in
a
Chinese
carving
.
 
<EOS>
The
fellow
,
by
his
agent
,
or
secretary
,
or
somebody
,
writes
to
me
"
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
Baronet
,
presents
his
compliments
to
Mr
Lawrence
Boythorn
,
and
has
to
call
his
attention
to
the
fact
that
the
green
pathway
by
the
old
parsonage
-
house
,
now
the
property
of
Mr
Lawrence
Boythorn
,
is
Sir
Leicester
's
right
of
way
,
being
in
fact
a
portion
of
the
park
of
chesney
Wold
,
and
that
Sir
Leicester
finds
it
convenient
to
close
up
the
same
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
write
to
the
fellow
,
"
Mr
Lawrence
Boythorn
presents
his
compliments
to
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
Baronet
,
and
has
to
call
HIS
attention
to
the
fact
that
he
totally
denies
the
whole
of
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
's
positions
on
every
possible
subject
and
has
to
add
,
in
reference
to
closing
up
the
pathway
,
that
he
will
be
glad
to
see
the
man
who
may
undertake
to
do
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
fellow
sends
a
most
abandoned
villain
with
one
eye
to
construct
a
gateway
.
 
<EOS>
I
play
upon
that
execrable
scoundrel
with
a
fire
-
engine
until
the
breath
is
nearly
driven
out
of
his
body
.
<EOS>
The
fellow
erects
a
gate
in
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
chop
it
down
and
burn
it
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
He
sends
his
myrmidons
to
come
over
the
fence
and
pass
and
repass
.
 
<EOS>
I
catch
them
in
humane
man
traps
,
fire
split
peas
at
their
legs
,
play
upon
them
with
the
engine
---
<EOS>
resolve
to
free
mankind
from
the
insupportable
burden
of
the
existence
of
those
lurking
ruffians
.
 
<EOS>
He
brings
actions
for
trespass
;
I
bring
actions
for
trespass
.
 
<EOS>
He
brings
actions
for
assault
and
battery
;
I
defend
them
and
continue
to
assault
and
batter
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
To
hear
him
say
all
this
with
unimaginable
energy
,
one
might
have
thought
him
the
angriest
of
mankind
.
 
<EOS>
To
see
him
at
the
very
same
time
,
looking
at
the
bird
now
perched
upon
his
thumb
and
softly
smoothing
its
feathers
with
his
forefinger
,
one
might
have
thought
him
the
gentlest
.
 
<EOS>
To
hear
him
laugh
and
see
the
broad
good
nature
of
his
face
then
,
one
might
have
supposed
that
he
had
not
a
care
in
the
world
,
or
a
dispute
,
or
a
dislike
,
but
that
his
whole
existence
was
a
summer
joke
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
"
he
said
,
"
no
closing
up
of
my
paths
by
any
Dedlock
!
<EOS>
Though
I
willingly
confess
,
"
here
he
softened
in
a
moment
,
"
that
Lady
Dedlock
is
the
most
accomplished
lady
in
the
world
,
to
whom
I
would
do
any
homage
that
a
plain
gentleman
,
and
no
baronet
with
a
head
seven
hundred
years
thick
,
may
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
who
joined
his
regiment
at
twenty
and
within
a
week
challenged
the
most
imperious
and
presumptuous
coxcomb
of
a
commanding
officer
that
ever
drew
the
breath
of
life
through
a
tight
waist
---
and
got
broke
for
it
---
is
not
the
man
to
be
walked
over
by
all
the
Sir
Lucifers
,
dead
or
alive
,
locked
or
unlocked
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
   
"
Nor
the
man
to
allow
his
junior
to
be
walked
over
either
?
"
said
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Most
assuredly
not
!
"
said
Mr
Boythorn
,
clapping
him
on
the
shoulder
with
an
air
of
protection
that
had
something
serious
in
it
,
though
he
laughed
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
will
stand
by
the
low
boy
,
always
.
<EOS>
Jarndyce
,
you
may
rely
upon
him
!
 
<EOS>
But
speaking
of
this
trespass
---
 
with
apologies
to
Miss
Clare
and
Miss
Summerson
for
the
length
at
which
I
have
pursued
so
dry
a

---
is
there
nothing
for
me
from
your

Kenge
and
Carboy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
,
Esther
?
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
guardian
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Much
obliged
!
"
said
Mr
Boythorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
Had
no
need
to
ask
,
after
even
my
slight
experience
of
Miss
Summerson
's
forethought
for
every
one
about
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
(
They
all
encouraged
me
;
they
were
determined
to
do
it
.
)
 
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
because
,
coming
from
Lincolnshire
,
I
of
course
have
not
yet
been
in
town
,
and
I
thought
some
letters
might
have
been
sent
down
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
they
will
report
progress
to
-
morrow
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
saw
him
so
often
in
the
course
of
the
evening
,
which
passed
very
pleasantly
,
contemplate
Richard
and
Ada
with
an
interest
and
a
satisfaction
that
made
his
fine
face
remarkably
agreeable
as
he
sat
at
a
little
distance
from
the
piano
listening
to
the
music
---
and
he
had
small
occasion
to
tell
us
that
he
was
passionately
fond
of
music
,
for
his
face
showed
it
<EOS>
---
that
I
asked
my
guardian
as
we
sat
at
the
backgammon
board
whether
Mr
Boythorn
had
ever
been
married
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
he
meant
to
be
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
How
did
you
find
out
that
?
"
<EOS>
he
returned
with
a
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
guardian
,
"
I
explained
,
not
without
reddening
a
little
at
hazarding
what
was
in
my
thoughts
,
"
there
is
something
so
tender
in
his
manner
,
after
all
,
and
he
is
so
very
courtly
and
gentle
to
us
,
and
 
---
"
   
Mr
Jarndyce
directed
his
eyes
to
where
he
was
sitting
as
I
have
just
described
him
.
   
<EOS>
I
said
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
little
woman
,
"
he
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
all
but
married
once
.
 
<EOS>
Long
ago
.
 
<EOS>
And
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
the
lady
die
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
---
but
she
died
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
That
time
has
had
its
influence
on
all
his
later
life
.
 
<EOS>
Would
you
suppose
him
to
have
a
head
and
a
heart
full
of
romance
yet
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
guardian
,
I
might
have
supposed
so
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
easy
to
say
that
when
you
have
told
me
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
never
since
been
what
he
might
have
been
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
and
now
you
see
him
in
his
age
with
no
one
near
him
<EOS>
but
his
servant
and
his
little
yellow
friend
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
your
throw
,
my
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
,
from
my
guardian
's
manner
,
that
beyond
this
point
I
could
not
pursue
the
subject
without
changing
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
I
therefore
forbore
to
ask
any
further
questions
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
interested
,
but
not
curious
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
a
little
while
about
this
old
love
story
in
the
night
,
when
I
was
awakened
by
Mr
Boythorn
's
lusty
snoring
;
and
I
tried
to
do
that
very
difficult
thing
,
imagine
old
people
young
again
and
invested
with
the
graces
of
youth
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
fell
asleep
before
I
had
succeeded
,
and
dreamed
of
the
days
when
I
lived
in
my
godmother
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
sufficiently
acquainted
with
such
subjects
to
know
whether
it
is
at
all
remarkable
that
I
almost
always
dreamed
of
that
period
of
my
life
.
   
<EOS>
With
the
morning
there
came
a
letter
from
Messrs.
Kenge
and
Carboy
to
Mr
Boythorn
informing
him
that
one
of
their
clerks
would
wait
upon
him
at
noon
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
the
day
of
the
week
on
which
I
paid
the
bills
,
and
added
up
my
books
,
and
made
all
the
household
affairs
as
compact
as
possible
,
I
remained
at
home
while
Mr
Jarndyce
,
Ada
,
and
Richard
took
advantage
of
a
very
fine
day
to
make
a
little
excursion
,
Mr
Boythorn
was
to
wait
for
Kenge
and
Carboy
's
clerk
and
then
was
to
go
on
foot
to
meet
them
on
their
return
.
   
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
full
of
business
,
examining
tradesmen
's
books
,
adding
up
columns
,
paying
money
,
filing
receipts
,
and
I
dare
say
making
a
great
bustle
about
it
when
Mr
Guppy
was
announced
and
shown
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
had
some
idea
that
the
clerk
who
was
to
be
sent
down
might
be
the
young
gentleman
who
had
met
me
at
the

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Then

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
10
.
<EOS>
The

Writer
 
<EOS>
On

<EOS>
In

<EOS>

<EOS>
Here

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Here
,

,
when

<EOS>
Here

.
 
<EOS>
An

of

school
whom

.
   
<EOS>
Like

is
to

,

.
 
<EOS>
Rusty
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Heavy

;

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.

<EOS>
Now
tbe

,
now
the
black
bit
.
<EOS>
That
's
not
it
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
must
gather
them
all
up
and
begin
again
.
   
<EOS>
Here
,
beneath
the
painted
ceiling
,
with
foreshortened
Allegory
staring
down
at
his
intrusion
as
if
it
meant
to
swoop
upon
him
,
and
he
cutting
it
dead
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
has
at
once
his
house
and
office
.
 
<EOS>
He
keeps
no
staff
,
only
one
middle
-
aged
man
,
usually
a
little
out
at
elbows
,
who
sits
in
a
high
pew
in
the
hall
and
is
rarely
overburdened
with
business
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
is
not
in
a
common
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
wants
no
clerks
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
great
reservoir
of
confidences
,
not
to
be
so
tapped
.
 
<EOS>
His
clients
want
HIM
;
he
is
all
in
all
.
 
<EOS>
Drafts
that
he
requires
to
be
drawn
are
drawn
by
special
-
pleaders
in
the
temple
on
mysterious
instructions
;
fair
copies
that
he
requires
to
be
made
are
made
at
the
stationers
'
,
expense
being
no
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
The
middle
-
aged
man
in
the
pew
knows
scarcely
more
of
the
affairs
of
the
peerage
than
any
crossing
-
sweeper
in
Holborn
.
   
<EOS>
The
red
bit
,
the
black
bit
,
the
inkstand
top
,
the
other
inkstand
top
,
the
little
sand
-
box
.
 
<EOS>
So
!
 
<EOS>
You
to
the
middle
,
you
<EOS>
to
the
right
,
you
to

left
.
 
<EOS>
This
train
of
indecision
must
surely
be
worked
out
now
or
never
.
 
<EOS>
Now
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
gets

,

,

,

"
I

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Very

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

,
as

---

,

---

,

.
 
<EOS>
To
Snagsby

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

's

.
 
<EOS>
The

early

:

-

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby

crow

out

.
   
<EOS>
"
Master
at

?
"
   
<EOS>
Guster

,

'

;
<EOS>
consequently
,

<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
Jostling
against

's

,

,

of

,
and

the

,
in
whose
way
the
forensic
wisdom
of
ages
has
interposed
a
million
of
obstacles
to
the
transaction
of
the
commonest
business
of
life
;
diving
through
law
and
equity
,
and
through
that
kindred
mystery
,
the
street
mud
,
which
is
made
of
nobody
knows
what
and
collects
about
us
nobody
knows
whence
or
how
---
 
we
only
knowing
in
general
that
when
there

too
much
of
it
we
find

away
---
the

and
the

-

come
to

,

,

,

,

,

Krook
.

This

,

,

.

.

,

.

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

man
narrowly
.
 
<EOS>
Knows
him
by
sight
.
 
<EOS>
Has
an
indistinct
impression
of
his
aristocratic
repute
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
wish
to
see
him
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
what
I
seldom
do
myself
,
"
says
Mr
Krook
with
a
grin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
call
him
down
?
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
a
weak
chance
if
he
'd
come
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
up
to
him
,
then
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
   
<EOS>
"
Second
floor
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Take
the
candle
.
 
<EOS>
Up
there
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Krook
,
with
his
cat
beside
him
,
stands
at
the
bottom
of
the
staircase
,
looking
after
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hi
-
hi
!
"
<EOS>
he
says
when
Mr
Tulkinghorn
has
nearly
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
The
lawyer
looks
down
over
the
hand
-
rail
.
 
<EOS>
The
cat
expands
her
wicked
mouth
and
snarls
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Order
,
Lady
Jane
!
 
<EOS>
Behave
yourself
to
visitors
,
my
lady
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
they
say
of
my
lodger
?
"
<EOS>
whispers
Krook
,
going
up
a
step
or
two
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
they
say
of
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
say
he
has
sold
himself
to
the
enemy
,
but
you
and
I
know
better
---
he
do
n't
buy
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
though
;
my
lodger
is
so
black
-
humoured
and
gloomy
<EOS>
that
I
believe
he
'd
as
soon
make
that
bargain
as
any
other
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
put
him
out
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
my
advice
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
with
a
nod
goes
on
his
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
comes
to
the
dark
door
on
the
second
floor
.
 
<EOS>
He
knocks
,
receives
no
answer
,
opens
it
,
and
accidentally
extinguishes
his
candle
in
doing
so
.
   
<EOS>
The
air
of
the
room
is
almost
bad
enough
to
have
extinguished
it
if
he
had
not
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
small
room
,
nearly
black
with
soot
,
and
grease
,
and
dirt
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
rusty
skeleton
of
a
grate
,
pinched
at
the
middle
as
if
poverty
had
gripped
it
,
a
red
coke
fire
burns
low
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
corner
by
the
chimney
stand
a
deal
table
and
a
broken
desk
,
a
wilderness
marked
with
a
rain
of
ink
.
 
<EOS>
In
another
corner
a
ragged
old
portmanteau
on
one
of
the
two
chairs
serves
for
cabinet
or
wardrobe
;
no
larger
one
is
needed
,
for
it
collapses
like
the
cheeks
of
a
starved
man
.
 
<EOS>
The
floor
is
bare
,
except
that
one
old
mat
,
trodden
to
shreds
of
rope
-
yarn
,
lies
perishing
upon
the
hearth
.
 
<EOS>
No
curtain
veils
the
darkness
of
the
night
,
but
the
discoloured
shutters
are
drawn
together
,
and
through
the
two
gaunt
holes
pierced
in
them
,
famine
might
be
staring
in
---
the
banshee
of
the
man
upon
the
bed
.
   
<EOS>
For
,
on
a
low
bed
opposite
the
fire
,
a
confusion
of
dirty
patchwork
,
lean
-
ribbed
ticking
,
and
coarse
sacking
,
the
lawyer
,
hesitating
just
within
the
doorway
,
sees
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
lies
there
,
dressed
in
shirt
and
trousers
,
with
bare
feet
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
yellow
look
in
the
spectral
darkness
of
a
candle
that
has
guttered
down
until
the
whole
length
of
its
wick
(
still
burning
)
has
doubled
over
and
left
a
tower
of
winding
-
sheet
above
it
.
 
<EOS>
His
hair
is
ragged
,
mingling
with
his
whiskers
and
his
beard
---
the
latter
,
ragged
too
,
and
grown
,
like
the
scum
and
mist
around
him
,
in
neglect
.
 
<EOS>
Foul
and
filthy
as
the
room
is
,
foul
and
filthy
as
the
air
is
,
it
is
not
easy
to
perceive
what
fumes
those
are
which
most
oppress
the
senses
in
it
;
but
through
the
general
sickliness
and
faintness
,
and
the
odour
of
stale
tobacco
,
there
comes
into
the
lawyer
's
mouth
the
bitter
,
vapid
taste
of
opium
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hallo
,
my
friend
!
"
<EOS>
he
cries
,
and
strikes
his
iron
candlestick
against
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
He
thinks
he
has
awakened
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
He
lies
a
little
turned
away
,
but
his
eyes
are
surely
open
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hallo
,
my
friend
!
"
<EOS>
he
cries
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
 
<EOS>
Hallo
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
rattles
on
the
door
,
the
candle
which
has
drooped
so
long
goes
out
and
leaves
him
in
the
dark
,
with
the
gaunt
eyes
in
the
shutters
staring
down
upon
the
bed
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
11
.
<EOS>
Our
Dear
Brother
 
<EOS>
A
touch
on
the
lawyer
's
wrinkled
hand
as
he
stands
in
the
dark
room
,
irresolute
,
makes
him
start
and
say
,
"
What
's
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
me
,
"
returns
the
old
man
of
the
house
,
whose
breath
is
in
his
ear
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
you
wake
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
done
with
your
candle
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
gone
out
.
 
<EOS>
Here
it
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
Krook
takes
it
,
goes
to
the
fire
,
stoops
over
the
red
embers
,
and
tries
to
get
a
light
.
 
<EOS>
The
dying
ashes
have
no
light
to
spare
,
and
his
endeavours
are
vain
.
 
<EOS>
Muttering
,
after
an
ineffectual
call
to
his
lodger
,
that
he
will
go
downstairs
and
bring
a
lighted
candle
from
the
shop
,
the
old
man
departs
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
for
some
new
reason
that
he
has
,
does
not
await
his
return
in
the
room
,
but
on
the
stairs
outside
.
   
<EOS>
The
welcome
light
soon
shines
upon
the
wall
,
as
Krook
comes
slowly
up
with
his
green
-
eyed
cat
following
at
his
heels
.
 
<EOS>
"
Does
the
man
generally
sleep
like
this
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
the
lawyer
in
a
low
voice
.
"
<EOS>
Hi
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
,
"
says
Krook
,
shaking
his
head
and
lifting
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
next
to
nothing
of
his
habits
except
that
he
keeps
himself
very
close
.
"
   
<EOS>
Thus
whispering
,
they
both
go
in
together
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
light
goes
in
,
the
great
eyes
in
the
shutters
,
darkening
,
seem
to
close
.
 
<EOS>
Not
so
the
eyes
upon
the
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
God
save
us
!
"
<EOS>
exclaims
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
dead
!
"
 
<EOS>
Krook
drops
the
heavy
hand
he
has
taken
up
so
suddenly
that
the
arm
swings
over
the
bedside
.
   
<EOS>
They
look
at
one
another
for

.
   
<EOS>
"
Send
for
some
doctor
!
 
<EOS>
Call
for
Miss
Flite
up

stairs
,

.
<EOS>
Here
's
poison
by
the
bed
!
 
<EOS>
Call
out
for
Flite
,
will
you
?
"
says
Krook
,
with
his
lean

spread
out
above
the

like

's

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
hurries
to

and
calls
,
"
Miss
Flite
!
<EOS>
Flite
!
 
<EOS>
Make
haste
,
here
,
whoever

are
!
 
<EOS>
Flite
!
"
 
<EOS>
Krook
follows
him
with

,
and
while

is

,
finds

to

to
the
old

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Run
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
The

doctor
!
 
<EOS>
Run
!
"
 
<EOS>
So
Mr
Krook
addresses
a
crazy
little
woman
who
is
his
female
lodger
,
who
appears
and
vanishes
in
a
breath
,
who
soon
returns
accompanied
by
a
testy
medical
man
brought
from
his
dinner
,
with
a
broad
,
snuffy
upper

and
a
broad
Scotch

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ey
!
 
<EOS>
Bless
the
hearts
o
'
ye
,
"
says
the
medical
man
,
looking
up
at
them
after
a
moment
's
examination
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
just
as
dead
as
Phairy
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
(
standing
by
the
old
portmanteau
)
inquires
if
he
has
been
dead
any

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Any
time
,
sir
?
"
says

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
probable
<EOS>
he
wull
have
been
dead
aboot
three
hours
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
About
that
time
,
I
should
say
,
"
observes
a

man
on

.
   
<EOS>
"
Air
you
in
the
maydickle
prayfession
yourself
,
sir
?
"
inquires
the
first
.
   
<EOS>
The
dark
young
man
says

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
'll
just
tak
'
my
depairture
,
"
replies
the
other
,
"
for
I
'm
nae
gude
here
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
which
remark
he
finishes
his
brief
attendance
and
returns
to
finish
his
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
The
dark
young
surgeon
passes
the
candle
across
and
across
the
face
and
carefully
examines
the
law
-
writer
,
who
has
established
his
pretensions
to
his
name
by
becoming
indeed
No
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
knew
this
person
by
sight
very
well
,
"
says
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
purchased
opium
of
me
for
the
last
year
and
a
half
.
 
<EOS>
Was
anybody
present
related
to
him
?
"
<EOS>
glancing
round
upon
the
three
bystanders
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
his
landlord
,
"
grimly
answers
Krook
,
taking
the
candle
from
the
surgeon
's
outstretched
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
told
me
once
I
was
the
nearest
relation
he
had
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
died
,
"
says
the
surgeon
,
"
of
an
over
-
dose
of
opium
,
there
is
no
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
is
strongly
flavoured
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
enough
here
now
,
"
taking
an
old
teapot
from
Mr
Krook
,
"
to
kill
a
dozen
people
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
he
did
it
on
purpose
?
"
asks
Krook
.
   
<EOS>
"
Took
the
over
-
dose
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
 
<EOS>
Krook
almost
smacks
his
lips
with
the
unction
of
a
horrible
interest
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
say
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
think
it
unlikely
,
as
he
has
been
in
the
habit
of
taking
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
But
nobody
can
tell
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
poor
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
His
room
---
do
n't
look
rich
,
"
says
Krook
,
who
might
have
changed
eyes
with
his
cat
,
as
he
casts
his
sharp
glance
around
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
never
been
in
it
since
he
had
it
,
and
he
was
too
close
to
name
his
circumstances
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
he
owe
you
any
rent
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Six
weeks
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
will
never
pay
it
!
"
says
the
young
man
,
resuming
his
examination
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
beyond
a
doubt
that
he
is
indeed
as
dead
as
Pharaoh
;
and
to
judge
from
his
appearance
and
condition
,
I
should
think
it
a
happy
release
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
he
must
have
been
a
good
figure
when
a
youth
,
and
<EOS>
I
dare
say
,
good
-
looking
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
says
this
,
not
unfeelingly
,
while
sitting
on
the
bedstead
's
edge
with
his
face
towards
that
other
face
and
his
hand
upon
the
region
of
the
heart
.
<EOS>
"
I
recollect
once
thinking
there
was
something
in
his
manner
,
uncouth
as
it
was
,
that
denoted
a
fall
in
life
.
 
<EOS>
Was
that
so
?
"
<EOS>
he
continues
,
looking
round
.
   
<EOS>
Krook
replies
,
"
You
might
as
well
ask
me
to
describe
the
ladies
whose
heads
of
hair
I
have
got
in
sacks
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Than
that
he
was
my
lodger
for
a
year
and
a
half
and
lived
---
or
did
n't
live
---
by
law
-
writing
<EOS>
,
I
know
no
more
of
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
During
this
dialogue
Mr
Tulkinghorn
has
stood
aloof
by
the
old
portmanteau
,
with
his
hands
behind
him
,
equally
removed
,
to
all
appearance
,
from
all
three
kinds
of
interest
exhibited
near
the
bed
---
from
the
young
surgeon
's
professional
interest
in
death
,
noticeable
as
being
quite
apart
from
his
remarks
on
the
deceased
as
an
individual
;
from
the
old
man
's
unction
;
and
the
little
crazy
woman
's
awe
.
 
<EOS>
His
imperturbable
face
has
been
as
inexpressive
as
his
rusty
clothes
.
 
<EOS>
One
could
not
even
say
he
has
been
thinking
all
this
while
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
shown
neither
patience
nor
impatience
,
nor
attention
nor
abstraction
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
shown
nothing
but
his
shell
.
 
<EOS>
As
easily
might
the
tone
of
a
delicate
musical
instrument
be
inferred
from
its
case
,
as
the
tone
of
Mr
Tulkinghorn
from
his
case
.
   
<EOS>
He
now
interposes
,
addressing
the
young
surgeon
in
his
unmoved
,
professional
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
looked
in
here
,
"
he
observes
,
"
just
before
you
,
with
the
intention
of
giving
this
deceased
man
,
whom
I
never
saw
alive
,
some
employment
at
his
trade
of
copying
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
heard
of
him
from
my
stationer
---
Snagsby
of
Cook
's
Court
.
 
<EOS>
Since
no
one
here
knows
anything
about
him
,
it
might
be
as
well
to
send
for
Snagsby
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
to
the
little
crazy
woman
,
who
has
often
seen
him
in
court
,
and
whom
he
has
often
seen
,
and
who
proposes
,
in
frightened
dumb
-
show
,
to
go
for
the
law
-
stationer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Suppose
you
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
While
she
is
gone
,
the
surgeon
abandons
his
hopeless
investigation
and
covers
its
subject
with
the
patchwork
counterpane
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Krook
and
<EOS>
he
interchange
a

or

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
says
nothing
,
but
stands
,
ever
,
near

old

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
arrives

in

and

.
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
dear

,
"

;
"
and
it

this
,

!
<EOS>
Bless

!
"
   
<EOS>
"

house

about
this

,
Snagsby
?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
in

rent

.
 
<EOS>
And
he
must

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,

,
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

---
"
   
"
<EOS>
No

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Where

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
A
pause
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
looking
at
the
law
-
stationer
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Krook
,
with
his
mouth
open
,

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to

,

"

,
"

,

,
"
I

,

<EOS>
About

---

,

---
"
   
"
That

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
About

"

"

(

)

,
"

"
hard

<EOS>

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
My

has
n't

good

for
names
,
"

,
"
and
she
considered
Nemo
equally
the

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
All

---
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Snagsby
,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Being

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.

<EOS>
"
In

,

,

,
"

Snagsby
.
   
<EOS>
Ah
,
to
be
sure
,
so
there
is
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
does
not
appear
to
have
seen
it
before
,
though
he
is
standing
so
close
to
it
,
and
though
there
is
very
little
else
,
heaven
knows
.
   
<EOS>
The
marine
-
store
merchant
holds
the
light
,
and
the
law
-
stationer
conducts
the
search
.
 
<EOS>
The
surgeon
leans
against
the
corner
of
the
chimney
-
piece
;
Miss
Flite
peeps
and
trembles
just
within
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
apt
old
scholar
of
the
old
school
,
with
his
dull
black
breeches
tied
with
ribbons
at
the
knees
,
his
large
black

,
his
long
-

black
coat
,
and
his
wisp
of
limp
white
neckerchief
tied
in
the
bow
the
peerage
knows
so
well
,
stands
in
exactly
the
same
place
and
attitude
.
   
<EOS>
There
are
some
worthless
articles
of
clothing
in
the
old
portmanteau
;
there
is
a
bundle
of
pawnbrokers
'
duplicates
,
those
turnpike
tickets
on
the
road
of
poverty
;
there
is
a
crumpled
paper
,
smelling
of
opium
,
on
which
are
scrawled
rough
memoranda
---
<EOS>
as
,
took
,
such
a
day
,
so
many
grains
;
took
,
such
another
day
,
so
many
more
---
 
<EOS>
begun
some
time
ago
,
as
if
with
the
intention
of
being
regularly
continued
,
but
soon
left

.
 
<EOS>
There
are
a
few
dirty

of

,
all

to
coroners
'

;
there

.
 
<EOS>
They
search
the
cupboard
and
the

of
the
ink

.
 
<EOS>
There
is
not
a

of
an
old

or

in

.
 
<EOS>
The
young
surgeon
examines
the
dress
on
the
law
-
writer
.
 
<EOS>
A

and
some
odd

are
all
he
finds
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
's
suggestion
is
the
practical
suggestion
after
all
,
and
the
beadle
must
be
called
in
.
   
<EOS>
So
the
little
crazy
lodger
goes
for
the
beadle
,
and
the
rest
come
out

room
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
leave
the
cat
there
!
"
<EOS>
says
the
surgeon
;
"
that
wo
n't
do
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Krook
therefore
drives
her
out
before
him
,
and
she
goes
furtively
downstairs
,
winding

lithe

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
and
goes
home
to
Allegory
and
meditation
.
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
news
has
got
into
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
Groups
of
its
inhabitants
assemble
to
discuss
the
thing
,
and
the
outposts
of
the
army
of
observation
(
principally
boys
)
are
pushed
forward
to
Mr
Krook
's
window
,
which
they
closely
invest
.
 
<EOS>
A
policeman
has
already
walked
up
to
the
room
,
and
walked
down
again
to
the
door
,
where
he
stands
like
a
tower
,
only
condescending
to
see
the
boys
at
his
base
occasionally
;
but
whenever
he
does
see
them
,
they
quail
and
fall
back
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Perkins
,
who
has
not
been
for
some
weeks
on
speaking
terms
with
Mrs
Piper
in

for
an
unpleasantness
originating
in
young
Perkins
'
having
"
fetched
"
young

"
a

,
"
renews
her
friendly

on
this
auspicious

.
<EOS>
The
potboy
at
the
corner
,
who
is
a
privileged
amateur
,
as
possessing
official
knowledge
of
life
and
having
to
deal
with
drunken
men
occasionally
,
exchanges
confidential
communications
with
the
policeman
and
has
the
appearance
of
an
impregnable
youth
,
unassailable
by
truncheons
and
unconfinable
in
station
-
houses
.
<EOS>
People
talk
across
the
court
out
of
window
,
and
bare
-
headed
scouts
come
hurrying
in
from
Chancery
Lane
to
know
what
's
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
The
general
feeling
seems
to
be
that
it
's
a
blessing
<EOS>
Mr
Krook
warn't
made
away
with
first
,
mingled
with
a
little
natural
disappointment
that
he
was
not
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
this
sensation
,
the
beadle
arrives
.
   
<EOS>
The
beadle
,
though
generally
understood
in
the
neighbourhood
to
be
a
ridiculous
institution
,
is
not
without
a
certain
popularity
for
the
moment
,
if
it
were
only
as
a
man
who
is
going
to
see
the
body
.
 
<EOS>
The
policeman
considers
him
an
imbecile
civilian
,
a
remnant
of
the
barbarous
watchmen
times
,
but
gives
him
admission
as
something
that
must
be
borne
with
until
government
shall
abolish
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
sensation
is
heightened
as
the
tidings
spread
from
mouth
to
mouth
that
the
beadle
is
on
the
ground
and
has
gone
in
.
   
<EOS>
By
and
by
the
beadle
comes
out
,
once
more
intensifying
the
sensation
,
which
has
rather
languished
in
the
interval
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
understood
to
be
in
want
of
witnesses
for
the
inquest
to
-
morrow
who
can
tell
the
coroner
and
jury
anything
whatever
respecting
the
deceased
.
 
<EOS>
Is
immediately
referred
to
innumerable
people
who
can
tell
nothing
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
Is
made
more
imbecile
by
being
constantly
informed
that
Mrs
Green
's
son
"
was
a
law
-
writer
his
-
self
and
knowed
him
better
than
anybody
,
"
which
son
of
Mrs
Green
's
appears
,
on
inquiry
,
to
be
at
the
present
time
aboard
a
vessel
bound
for
China
,
three
months
out
,
but
considered
accessible
by
telegraph
on
application
to
the
Lords
of
the
Admiralty
.
 
<EOS>
Beadle
goes
into
various
shops
and
parlours
,
examining
the
inhabitants
,
always
shutting
the
door
first
,
and
by
exclusion
,
delay
,
and
general
idiotcy
exasperating
the
public
.
 
<EOS>
Policeman
seen
to
smile
to
potboy
.
 
<EOS>
Public
loses
interest
and
undergoes
reaction
.
 
<EOS>
Taunts
the
beadle
in
shrill
youthful
voices
with
having
boiled
a
boy
,
choruses
fragments
of
a
popular
song
to
that
effect
and
importing
that
the
boy
was
made
into
soup
for
the
workhouse
.
 
<EOS>
Policeman
at
last
finds
it
necessary
to
support
the
law
and
seize
a
vocalist
,
who
is
released
upon
the
flight
of
the
rest
on
condition
of
his
getting
out
of
this
then
,
come
,
and
cutting
it
---
a
condition
he
immediately
observes
.
 
<EOS>
So
the
sensation
dies
off
for
the
time
;
and
the
unmoved
policeman
(
to
whom
a
little
opium
,
more
or
less
,
is
nothing
)
,
with
his
shining
hat
,
stiff
stock
,
inflexible
great
-
coat
,
stout
belt
and
bracelet
,
and
all
things
fitting
,
pursues
his
lounging
way
with
a
heavy
tread
,
beating
the
palms
of
his
white
gloves
one
against
the
other
and
stopping
now
and
then
at
a
street
-
corner
to
look
casually
about
for
anything
between
a
lost
child
and
a
murder
.
   
<EOS>
Under
cover
of
the
night
,
the
feeble
-
minded
beadle
comes
flitting
about
Chancery
Lane
with
his
summonses
,
in
which
every
juror
's
name
is
wrongly
spelt
,
and
nothing
rightly
spelt
but
the
beadle
's
own
name
,
which
nobody
can
read
or
wants
to
know
.
 
<EOS>
The
summonses
served
and
his
witnesses
forewarned
,
the
beadle
goes
to
Mr
Krook
's
to
keep
a
small
appointment
he
has
made
with
certain
paupers
,
who
,
presently
arriving
,
are
conducted
upstairs
,
where
they
leave
the
great
eyes
in
the
shutter
something
new
to
stare
at
,
in
that
last
shape
which
earthly
lodgings
take
for
No
one
---
and
for
Every
one
.
   
<EOS>
And
all
that
night
the
coffin
stands
ready
by
the
old
portmanteau
;
and
the
lonely
figure
on
the
bed
,
whose
path
in
life
has
lain
through
five
and
forty
years
,
lies
there
with
no
more
track
behind
him
that
any
one
can
trace
than
a
deserted
infant
.
   
<EOS>
Next
day
the
court
is
all
alive
---
is
like
a
fair
,
as
Mrs
Perkins
,
more

to
Mrs
Piper
,
says

that

woman
.
 
<EOS>
The
coroner
is
to
sit
in
the
first
-
floor
room
at
the
Sol
's
Arms
,
where
the
Harmonic

take

twice

and
where

by
a

,

by
Little
Swills
,
the

,
who
hopes
(

the
bill
in
the
window
)
that
his

will

and

first
-

.
 
<EOS>
The
Sol
's
Arms
does
a

of
business
all
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Even
children
so
require

under
the

that
a

who
has

for
the

at
the

his

-
balls

.
 
<EOS>
What
time
the
beadle
,

of
Mr

's

the

Sol
's

,

.
   
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
coroner
frequents

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Call

!

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
 
<EOS>

-

would
fill
a
cart
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
,

Sol
's

and
then

strong

.
 
<EOS>
The

hour
arriving
,
the

,
is
faced
(
red

)

;

.
 
<EOS>
In

"

.
<EOS>
"
 
Is

;

;

)
tippy

,

lo

,

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
On

Watch
 
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

full

,
for

Leicester

.
 
<EOS>
The

out

.
 
<EOS>
It

ELITE

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

,

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

Lady
,
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Through

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

the
carriage
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
carriage
is
stopped
,
the
affectionate
man
alights
from
the
rumble
,
opens
the
door
,
and
lets
down
the
steps
,
obedient
to
an
impatient
motion
of
my
Lady
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
alights
so
quickly
and
walks
away
so

that
Sir
Leicester
,
for
all
his
scrupulous

,
is

to

,
and
is

behind
.
 
<EOS>
A
space
of
a
minute
or
two
has
elapsed
before
he
comes
up
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
smiles
,
looks
very
handsome
,
takes
his
arm
,
lounges
with
him
for
a
quarter
of
a
mile
,
is
very
much

,
and
resumes
her
seat
in
the
carriage
.
   
<EOS>
The
rattle
and
clatter
continue
through
the
greater
part
of
three
days
,
with
more
or
less
of
bell
-
jingling
and
whip
-

,
and
more
or
less
plunging
of
centaurs
and
bare
-
backed

.
 
<EOS>
Their
courtly
politeness
to
each
other
at
the
hotels
where
they
tarry
is
the
theme
of
general
admiration
.
 
<EOS>
Though
my
Lord
IS
a
little
aged
for
my
Lady
,
says
Madame
,
the
hostess
of
the
Golden
Ape
,
and
though
he
might
be
her
amiable
father
,
one
can
see
at
a

that
they
love
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
One
observes
my
Lord
with
his
white
hair
,
standing
,
hat
in
hand
,
to
help
my
Lady
to
and
from
the
carriage
.
 
<EOS>
One
observes
my
Lady
,
how
recognisant
of
my
Lord
's
politeness
,
with
an
inclination
of
her
gracious
head
and
the
concession
of
her
so
-
genteel
fingers
!
<EOS>
It
is
ravishing
!
   
<EOS>
The
sea
has
no
appreciation
of
great
men
,
but
knocks
them
about
like
the
small
fry
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
habitually
hard
upon
Sir
Leicester
,
whose
countenance
it
greenly
mottles
in
the
manner
of
sage
-

and
in
whose
aristocratic
system
it
effects
a
dismal

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
Radical
of
Nature
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
his
dignity
gets
over
it
after
stopping
to
refit
,
and
he
goes
on
with
my
Lady
for
Chesney

,
lying
only
one
night
in
London
on
the
way
to
Lincolnshire
.
   
<EOS>
Through
the
same
cold
sunlight
,
colder
as

declines
,
and
through
the
same
sharp

,
sharper
as

separate

,
and

Ghost
's

,

the

,

to

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

in

,

,

wo

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
where

,

<EOS>
But

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

?
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
My

looking

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
My

,
without

of
words
<EOS>
,
that
she
is

.
   
<EOS>
But

is
in

,

;

,

"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Rosa
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

!
"
 
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
Rosa
,

,

,

,

!
"

do

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nineteen
,
"

<EOS>
"
Take

<EOS>
they

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
My

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

.
   
<EOS>
That

,

's

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

,

,

;
has

that

!
 
<EOS>
Mrs

confirms

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
Heaven

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
'
Tis

,

"

"

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Might

,

?
"

,
who
has

,

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Forgive

!
 
<EOS>
Only

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

's

is

.
   
<EOS>
My

's
maid
is
a

of

,

the
southern
country
about

,
a

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

her

,
and
she
has
a
watchful
way
of
looking

without

which
could
be

,

and

.
 
<EOS>
Through

of
her

,

so

that

she
-

.
 
<EOS>
Besides

in

her

,

is
almost

in

;

,

in

to

for
having

Lady
's

,

<EOS>
Ha

!
 
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
Ha

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>
It

BEST

.
   
<EOS>
In

ca

;

,

<EOS>
an

,

,

,

,
which

of

is

Lady
's

.
   
<EOS>
All

in
the

are
brought

,
many

after

.
 
<EOS>
They
reflect
handsome
faces
,
simpering

,

,
faces
of
threescore
and
ten
that
will
not
submit

;
the
entire
collection
of
faces
that
have
come
to
pass

January
week
or
two
at
Chesney
Wold
,
and
which
the
fashionable
intelligence
,
a
mighty
hunter
before

Lord
,
hunts
with
a

,
from
their
breaking

at
the
Court
of
St
James
's
to
their
being
run
down
to
death
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
in
Lincolnshire
is
all
alive
.
 
<EOS>
By
day
guns
and
voices
are
heard
ringing
in
the
woods
,
horsemen
and
carriages
enliven
the
park
roads
,
servants
and

-
on
pervade
the
village
and
the
Dedlock
Arms
.
 
<EOS>
Seen
by
night
from
distant
openings
in
the
trees
,
the
row
of
windows
in
the
long
drawing
-
room
,
where
my
Lady
's
picture
hangs
over
the
great

-

,
is
like
a
row
of

set
in
a
black
frame
.
 
<EOS>
On
Sunday
the
chill
little
church
is
almost
warmed
by
so
much
gallant
company
,
and
the
general
flavour
of
the
Dedlock
dust
is
quenched
in
delicate

.
   
<EOS>
The
brilliant
and
distinguished
circle
comprehends
within
it
no
contracted
amount
of
education
,
sense
,
courage
,
honour
,
beauty
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Yet
there
is
something
a
little
wrong
about
it
in
despite
of
its
immense
advantages
.
 
<EOS>
What
can
it
be
?
   
<EOS>
Dandyism
?
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
King
George
the
Fourth
now
(
more
the
pity
)
to
set
the
dandy
fashion
;
there
are
no
clear
-
starched
jack
-
towel
neckcloths
,
no
short
-
waisted
coats
,
no
false

,
no
stays
.
<EOS>
There
are
no
caricatures
,
now
,
of
<EOS>
effeminate
exquisites
so
arrayed
,
swooning
in
opera
boxes
with
excess
of
delight
and
being
revived
by
other
dainty
creatures
poking
long
-
necked
scent
-
bottles
at
their
noses
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
beau
whom
it
takes
four
men
at
once
to
shake
into
his
buckskins
,
or
who
goes
to
see
all
the
executions
,
or
who
is
troubled
with
the
self
-
reproach
of
having
once
consumed
a
pea
.
 
<EOS>
But
is
there
dandyism
in
the
brilliant
and
distinguished
circle
notwithstanding
,
dandyism
of
a
more
mischievous
sort
,
that
has
got
below
the
surface
and
is
doing
less
harmless
things
than
jack
-
towelling
itself
and
stopping
its
own
digestion
,
to
which
no
rational
person
need
particularly
object
?
   
<EOS>
Why
,
yes
.
 
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
disguised
.
 
<EOS>
There
ARE
at
Chesney
Wold
this
January
week
some
ladies
and
gentlemen
of
the
newest
fashion
,
who
have
set
up
a
dandyism
---
in
religion
,
for
instance
.
 
<EOS>
Who
in
mere
lackadaisical
want
of
an
emotion
have
agreed
upon
a
little
dandy
talk
about
the
vulgar
wanting
faith
in
things
in
general
,
meaning
in
the
things
that
have
been
tried
and
found
wanting
,
as
though
a
low
fellow
should
unaccountably
lose
faith
in
a
bad
shilling
after
finding
it
out
!
 
<EOS>
Who
would
make
the
vulgar
very
picturesque
and
faithful
by
putting
back
the
hands
upon
the
clock
of
time
and
cancelling
a
few
hundred
years
of
history
.
   
<EOS>
There
are
also
ladies
and
gentlemen
of
another
fashion
,
not
so
new
,
but
very
elegant
,
who
have
agreed
to
put
a
smooth
glaze
on
the
world
and
to
keep
down
all
its
realities
.
 
<EOS>
For
whom
everything
must
be
languid
and
pretty
.
 
<EOS>
Who
have
found
out
the
perpetual
stoppage
.
 
<EOS>
Who
are
to
rejoice
at
nothing
and
be
sorry
for
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Who
are
not
to
be
disturbed
by
ideas
.
 
<EOS>
On
whom
even
the
fine
arts
,
attending
in
powder
and
walking
backward
like
the
Lord
Chamberlain
,
must
array
themselves
in
the
milliners
'
and
tailors
'
patterns
of
past
generations
and
be
particularly
careful
not
to
be
in
earnest
or
to
receive
any
impress
from
the
moving
age
.
   
<EOS>
Then
there
is
my
Lord
Boodle
,
of
considerable
reputation
with
his
party
,
who
has
known
what
office
is
and
who
tells
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
with
much
gravity
,
after
dinner
,
that
he
really
does
not
see
to
what
the
present
age
is
tending
.
 
<EOS>
A
debate
is
not
what
a
debate
used
to
be
;
the
House
is
not
what
the
House
used
to
be
;
even
a
Cabinet
is
not
what
it
formerly
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
perceives
with
astonishment
that
supposing
the
present
government
to
be
overthrown
,
the
limited
choice
of
the
Crown
,
in
the
formation
of
a
new
ministry
,
would
lie
between
Lord
Coodle
and
Sir
Thomas
Doodle
---
supposing
it
to
be
impossible
for
the
Duke
of
Foodle
to
act
with
Goodle
,
which
may
be
assumed
to
be
the
case
in

of
the
breach

out
of
that
affair
with
Hoodle
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
giving
the
Home
Department
and
the

of
the
House
of
Commons
to
Joodle
,
the
Exchequer
to
Koodle
,
the
Colonies
to
Loodle
,
and
the
Foreign
Office
to
Moodle
,
what
are
you
to
do
with
Noodle
?
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
offer
him
the
Presidency
of
the
Council
;
that
is
reserved
for
Poodle
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
put
him
in
the
Woods
and
Forests
;
that
is
hardly
good
enough
for
Quoodle
.
 
<EOS>
What
follows
?
 
<EOS>
That
the
country
is
shipwrecked
,
lost
,
and
gone
to
pieces
(
as
is
made

to
the
patriotism
of
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
)
because
you
ca
n't
provide
for
Noodle
!
   
<EOS>
On
the
other
hand
,
the
Right
Honourable
William
Buffy
,
MP
,
contends
across
the
table
with
some
one
else
that
the
shipwreck
of
the
country
---
about
which
there
is
no
doubt
;
it
is
only
the
manner
of
it
that
is

---
is

.
 
<EOS>
If
you
had
done
with
Cuffy
what
you
ought

have
done
when
he
first
came
into

,
and
had
prevented

from
going

to
Duffy
<EOS>
,
you
would
have
got

into

Fuffy
,
you

with

the
weight
attaching
as
a
smart

to
Guffy
<EOS>
,
you
would
have
brought

upon

the

Huffy
,

in
for

Juffy
,
Kuffy
,
and

,
and
you
would

by

of

.
 
<EOS>
All
this
,
instead
of
being
as
you
now

,
dependent

mere

of
Puffy
!
   
<EOS>
As
to
this

,
and
as
to
some

,
there
are
differences
of
opinion
;
but
it
is
perfectly

to
the
brilliant

distinguished

,
all

,
that
nobody
is
in
question
but
Boodle
and
his

,
and
Buffy
and
HIS

.
 
<EOS>
These
are
the
great
actors
for
whom
the
stage
is
reserved
.
 
<EOS>
A
People
there
are
,
no
doubt
---
a
certain
large
number
of
supernumeraries
,
who
are
to
be
occasionally
addressed
,
and
relied
upon
for
shouts
and

,
as
on
the
theatrical
stage
;
but
Boodle
and
Buffy
,
their

and

,

,

,

,
and
assigns
,
are
the
born
first
-
actors
,
managers
,
and
leaders
,
and
no
others
can
appear
upon
the
scene
for
ever
and
ever
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
,
too
,
there
is
perhaps
more
dandyism
at
Chesney
Wold
than
the
brilliant
and
distinguished
circle
will
find
good
for
itself
in
the
long
run
.
 
<EOS>
For
it
is
,
even
with
the
stillest
and
politest
circles
,
as
with
the
circle
the
necromancer
draws
around
him
---
very
strange
appearances
may
be
seen
in
active
motion
outside
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
difference
,
that
being
realities
and
not
phantoms
,
there
is
the
greater
danger
of
their
breaking
in
.
   
<EOS>
Chesney
Wold
is
quite
full
anyhow
,
so
full
that
a
burning
sense
of
injury
arises
in
the
breasts
of
ill
-
lodged
ladies'-maids
,
and
is
not
to
he
extinguished
.
 
<EOS>
Only
one
room
is
empty
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
turret
chamber
of
the
third
order
of
merit
,
plainly
but
comfortably
furnished
and
having
an
old
-
fashioned
business
air
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
room
,
and
is
never
bestowed
on
anybody
else
,
for
he
may
come
at
any
time
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
come
yet
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
his
quiet
habit
to
walk
across
the
park
from
the
village
in
fine
weather
,
to
drop
into
this
room
as
if
he
had
never
been
out
of
it
since
he
was
last
seen
there
,
to
request
a
servant
to
inform
Sir
Leicester
that
he
is
arrived
in
case
he
should
be
wanted
,
and
to
appear
ten
minutes
before
dinner
in
the
shadow
of
the
library
-
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
sleeps
in
his
turret
with
a
complaining
flag
-
staff
over
his
head
,
and
has
some
leads
outside
on
which
,
any
fine
morning
when
he
is
down
here
,
his
black
figure
may
be
seen
walking
before
breakfast
like
a
larger
species
of
rook
.
   
<EOS>
Every
day
before
dinner
,
my
Lady
looks
for
him
in
the
dusk
of
the
library
,
but
he
is
not
there
.
 
<EOS>
Every
day
at
dinner
,
my
Lady
glances
down
the
table
for
the
vacant
place
that
would
be
waiting
to
receive
him
if
he
had
just
arrived
,
but
there
is
no
vacant
place
.
 
<EOS>
Every
night
my
Lady
casually
asks
her
maid
,
"
Is
Mr
Tulkinghorn
come
?
"
   
<EOS>
Every
night
the
answer
is
,
"
No
,
my
Lady
,
not
yet
.
"
   
<EOS>
One
night
,
while
having
her
hair
undressed
,
my
Lady
loses
herself
in
deep
thought
after
this
reply
until
she
sees
her
own
brooding
face
in
the
opposite
glass
,
and
a
pair
of
black

curiously
observing
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Be
so
good
as
to
attend
,
"
says

Lady
then
,

of

,
"
to

.
 
<EOS>
You
can

at

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
your
Ladyship
's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
says

Lady
,
"
you
need
n't
contemplate
at
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
length
,
one

a
little

,
when

of

which
have
for
the

's
Walk

and

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
comes
towards
them
at
his
usual
methodical

,
which
is
never

,
never

.
 
<EOS>
He
wears
his
usual
expressionless
mask
---
if
it
be
a
mask
 
---
and
carries
family
secrets
in
every

of
his

and
every

of
his
dress
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
his

is
devoted
to

great
or

nothing
beyond
the
services
he
sells
is
his

secret
.
 
<EOS>
He
keeps
it
,
as
he
keeps
the
secrets
of
his
clients
;
he
is
his
own
client
in
that
matter
,
and
will

.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do

,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
?
"

Sir

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
is
quite
well
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
is
quite
well
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
is
quite
well
.
 
<EOS>
All
highly
satisfactory
.
 
<EOS>
The
lawyer
,
with

behind

,
walks
at
Sir
Leicester
's

along
the
terrace
.
<EOS>
My
Lady
walks
upon

.
   
<EOS>
"
We

before
,
"

Sir

.
 
<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>
As
much

to

,
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
we

.
<EOS>
We

,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

and
says
he
is
much

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"

that
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
An

.
 
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr

,
"

,
"
there

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
Mr

"
   
"
It

,
Mr

,
"
<EOS>

,
"
TO

.
 
<EOS>
An

ill
-
conditioned
,
levelling

.
 
<EOS>
A
person
who
,
fifty

,

for

,

---

,
"

,
"

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Sir

appears

in

,
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
night
is

,
"
says

,
"
and
my
Lady
will
take

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
As

hall

,
Lady
Dedlock

Mr
Tulkinghorn
for
the
first

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
sent

a

respecting

person
whose

I

.
 
<EOS>
It
was

you
to

;
I

.
 
<EOS>
Your

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't

what

I

with

hand

,

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
some
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
repeats
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
!
"
returns
my
Lady
carelessly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think

must
have
had

.
 
<EOS>
And
did

to
find

the
writer

that
actual
thing
<EOS>
---
what
is

!
<EOS>
---
affidavit
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
very
odd
!
"
   
<EOS>
They
pass
into
a
sombre
breakfast
-
room
on
the
ground

,
lighted
in
the
day
by

windows
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
now
twilight
.
 
<EOS>
The
fire
glows
brightly
on
the
panelled
wall
and
palely
on
the
window
-
glass
,
<EOS>
where
,
through
the
cold
reflection
of
the
blaze
,
the
colder
landscape
shudders
in
the
wind
and
a
grey
mist
creeps
along
,
the
only
traveller
besides
the
waste
of
clouds
.
   
<EOS>
My
Lady
lounges
in
a
great
chair
in
the
chimney
-
corner
,
and
Sir
Leicester
takes
another
great
chair
opposite
.
 
<EOS>
The
lawyer
stands
before
the
fire
with
his
hand
out
at
arm
's
length
,
shading
his
face
.
<EOS>
He
looks
across
his
arm
at
my
Lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he
says
,
"
I
inquired
about
the
man
,
and
found
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
what
is
very
strange
<EOS>
,
I
found
him
---
"
   
"
Not
to
be
any
out
-
of
-
the
-
way
person
,
I
am
afraid
!
"
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
languidly

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
found
him
dead
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
me
!
"
remonstrated

Leicester
.
 
<EOS>
Not

much

by

.
   
<EOS>
"

was
directed
to

---
a

,
poverty

---
and
I

him
dead
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will

,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
the
less
said
---
"
   
"

,

,

out
"
<EOS>
(
it

)
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
quite
a
story
for

.
 
<EOS>
How

!
<EOS>
Dead
?
<EOS>
"
   
Mr
,
Tulkinghorn
re
-
asserts

by
another

.
<EOS>
"
Whether

---
"

Upon

"

<EOS>
"
Really
!
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Whatever

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

---
"
   
"
No
,

!
 
<EOS>
Go

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
's

concedes

point
,
though
he
still

that
to

sort

---
really
---
    
"

"

"

that

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
The

's

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

,
"

"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
difficult
to

,
"
returns

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
had
lived
so

and
was
so

,

his

,

I

considered

.
 
<EOS>
The
surgeon
had
a
notion
that
he
had

something

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
They

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

had

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
In

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Without

?
"
   
"
Without

;

,
"

,
"
an
old

,
but
---
  
<EOS>
No
,
there
were
no
papers
.
"
   
<EOS>
During
the
utterance
of
every
word
of
this
short

,
Lady
Dedlock
and
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
without
any
other
alteration
in
their
customary
deportment
,
have
looked
very
steadily
at
one
another
---
as
was
natural
,
perhaps
,
in
the
discussion
of
so
unusual
a
subject
.
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
has
looked
at
the
fire
,
with
the
general
expression
of
the
Dedlock
on
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
The
story
being
told
,
he
renews
his
stately
protest
,
saying
that
as
it
is
quite
clear
that
no
association
in
my
Lady
's
mind
can
possibly
be
traceable
to
this
poor
wretch
(
unless
he
was
a
begging

letter
writer
)
,
he
trusts
to
hear
no
more
about
a
subject
so
far
removed
from
my
Lady
's
station
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
a
collection
of
horrors
,
"
says
my
Lady
,
gathering
up
her
mantles
and
furs
,
"
but
they
interest
one
for
the
moment
!
 
<EOS>
Have
the
kindness
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
to
open
the
door
for
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
does
so
with
deference
and
holds
it
open
while
she
passes
out
.
 
<EOS>
She
passes
close
to
him
,
with
her
usual
fatigued
manner
and
insolent
grace
.
 
<EOS>
They
meet
again
at
dinner
---
again
,
next
day
---
 
again
,
for
many
days
in
succession
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
is
always
the
same
exhausted
deity
,
surrounded
by
worshippers
,
and
terribly
liable
to
be
bored
to
death
,
even
while
presiding
at
her
own
shrine
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
is
always
the
same
speechless
repository
of
noble
confidences
,
so
oddly
but
of
place
and
yet
so
perfectly
at
home
.
<EOS>
They
appear
to
take
as
little
note
of
one
another
as
any
two
people
enclosed
within
the
same
walls
could
.
 
<EOS>
But
whether
each
evermore
watches
and
suspects
the
other
,
evermore
mistrustful
of
some
great
reservation
;
whether
each
is
evermore
prepared
at
all
points
for
the
other
,
and
never
to
be
taken
unawares
;
what
each
would
give
to
know
how
much
the
other
knows
---
all
this
is
hidden
,
for
the
time
,
in
their
own
hearts
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
13
.
<EOS>
Esther
's
Narrative
 
<EOS>
We
held
many
consultations
about
what
Richard
was
to
be
,
first
without
Mr
Jarndyce
,
as
he
had
requested
,
and
afterwards
with
him
,
but
it
was
a
long
time
before
we
seemed
to
make
progress
.
 
<EOS>
Richard
said
he
was
ready
for
anything
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Jarndyce
doubted
whether
he
might
not
already
be
too
old
to
enter
the
Navy
,
Richard
said
he
had
thought
of
that
,
and
perhaps
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Jarndyce
asked
him
what
he
thought
of
the
Army
,
Richard
said
he
had
thought
of
that
,
too
,
and
it
was
n't
a
bad
idea
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Jarndyce
advised
him
to
try
and
decide
within
himself
whether
his
old
preference
for
the
sea
was
an
ordinary
boyish
inclination
or
a
strong
impulse
,
Richard
answered
,
Well
he
really
HAD
tried
very
often
,
and
he
could
n't
make
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
much
of
this
indecision
of
character
,
"
Mr
Jarndyce
said
to
me
,
"
is
chargeable
on
that
incomprehensible
heap
of
uncertainty
and
procrastination
on
which
he
has
been
thrown
from
his
birth
,
I
do
n't
pretend
to
say
;
but
that
Chancery
,
among
its
other
sins
,
is
responsible
for
some
of
it
,
I
can
plainly
see
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
engendered
or
confirmed
in
him
a
habit
of
putting
off
---
and
trusting
to
this
,
that
,
and
the
other
chance
,
without
knowing
what
chance
---
and
dismissing
everything
as
unsettled
,
uncertain
,
and
confused
.
 
<EOS>
The
character
of
much
older
and
steadier
people
may
be
even
changed
by
the
circumstances
surrounding
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
too
much
to
expect
that
a
boy
's
,
in
its
formation
,
should
be
the
subject
of
such
influences
and
escape
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
this
to
be
true
;
though
if
I
may
venture
to
mention
what
I
thought
besides
,
I
thought
it
much
to
be
regretted
that
Richard
's
education
had
not
counteracted
those
influences
or
directed
his
character
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
eight
years
at
a
public
school
and
had
learnt
,
I
understood
,
to
make
Latin
verses
of
several
sorts
in
the
most
admirable
manner
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
heard
that
it
had
been
anybody
's
business
to
find
out
what
his
natural
bent
was
,
or
where
his
failings
lay
,
or
to
adapt
any
kind
of
knowledge
to
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
HE
had
been
adapted
to
the
verses
and
had
learnt
the
art
of
making
them
to
such
perfection
that
if
he
had
remained
at
school
until
he
was
of
age
,
I
suppose
he
could
only
have
gone
on
making
them
over
and
over
again
unless
he
had
enlarged
his
education
by
forgetting
how
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
Still
,
although
I
had
no
doubt
that
they
were
very
beautiful
,
and
very
improving
,
and
very
sufficient
for
a
great
many
purposes
of
life
,
and
always
remembered
all
through
life
,
I
did
doubt
whether
Richard
would
not
have
profited
by
some
one
studying
him
a
little
,
instead
of
his
studying
them
quite
so
much
.
   
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
I
knew
nothing
of
the
subject
and
do
not
even
now
know
whether
the
young
gentlemen
of
classic
Rome
or
Greece
made
verses
to
the
same
extent
---
or
whether
the
young
gentlemen
of
any
country
ever
did
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
the
least
idea
,
"
said
Richard
,
musing
,
"
what
I
had
better
be
.
 
<EOS>
Except
that
I
am
quite
sure
I
do
n't
want
to
go
into
the
Church
<EOS>
,
it
's
a
toss
-
up
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
inclination
in
Mr
Kenge
's
way
?
"
suggested
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
,
sir
!
"
replied
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
fond
of
boating
.
<EOS>
Articled
clerks
go
a
good
deal
on
the
water
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
capital
profession
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surgeon
---
"
suggested
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
thing
,
sir
!
"
cried
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
I
doubt
if
he
had
ever
once
thought
of
it
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
thing
,
sir
,
"
repeated
Richard
with
the
greatest
enthusiasm
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
got
it
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
M*R*C*S
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
not
to
be
laughed
out
of
it
,
though
he
laughed
at
it
heartily
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
he
had
chosen
his
profession
,
and
the
more
he
thought
of
it
,
<EOS>
the
more
he
felt
that
his
destiny
was
clear
;
the
art
of
healing
was
the
art
of
all
others
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mistrusting
that
he
only
came
to
this
conclusion
because
,
having
never
had
much
chance
of
finding
out
for
himself
what
he
was
fitted
for
and
having
never
been
guided
to
the
discovery
,
he
was
taken
by
the
newest
idea
and
was
glad
to
get
rid
of
the
trouble
of
consideration
<EOS>
,
I
wondered
whether
the
Latin
verses
often
ended
in
this
or
whether
Richard
's
was
a
solitary
case
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
took
great
pains
to
talk
with
him
seriously
and
to
put
it
to
his
good
sense
not
to
deceive
himself
in
so
important
a
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Richard
was
a
little
grave
after
these
interviews
,
but
invariably
told
Ada
and
me
that
it
was
all
right
,
and
then
began
to
talk
about
something
else
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
heaven
!
"
cried
Mr
Boythorn
,
who
interested
himself
strongly
in
the
subject
---
though
I
need
not
say
that
,
for
he
could
do
nothing
weakly
;
"
I
rejoice
to
find
a
young
gentleman
of
spirit
and
gallantry
devoting
himself
to
that
noble
profession
!
 
<EOS>
The
more
spirit
there
is
in
it
,
the
better
for
mankind
and
the
worse
for
those
mercenary
task
-
masters
and
low
tricksters
who
delight
in
putting
that
illustrious
art
at
a
disadvantage
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
By
all
that
is
base
and
despicable
,
"
cried
Mr
Boythorn
,
"
the
treatment
of
surgeons
aboard
ship
is
such
that
I
would
submit
the
legs
---
both
legs
---
of
every
member
of
the
Admiralty
Board
to
a
compound
fracture
and
render
it
a
transportable
offence
in
any
qualified
practitioner
to
set
them
if
the
system
were
not
wholly
changed
in
eight
and
forty
hours
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
n't
you
give
them
a
week
?
"
asked
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
cried
Mr
Boythorn
firmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
on
any
consideration
!
 
<EOS>
Eight
and
forty
hours
!
 
<EOS>
As
to
corporations
,
parishes
,
vestry
-
boards
,
and
similar
gatherings
of
jolter
-
headed
clods
who
assemble
to
exchange
such
speeches
that
,
by
heaven
,
they
ought
to
be
worked
in
quicksilver
mines
for
the
short
remainder
of
their
miserable
existence
,
if
it
were
only
to
prevent
their
detestable
English
from
contaminating
a
language
spoken
in
the
presence
of
the
sun
---
as
to
those
fellows
,
who
meanly
take
advantage
of
the
ardour
of
gentlemen
in
the
pursuit
of
knowledge
to
recompense
the
inestimable
services
of
the
best
years
of
their
lives
,
their
long
study
,
and
their
expensive
education
with
pittances
too
small
for
the
acceptance
of
clerks
,
I
would
have
the
necks
of
every
one
of
them
wrung
and
their
skulls
arranged
in
Surgeons
'
Hall
for
the
contemplation
of
the
whole
profession
in
order
that
its
younger
members
might
understand
from
actual
measurement
,
in
early
life
,
HOW
thick
skulls
may
become
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
wound
up
this
vehement
declaration
by
looking
round
upon
us
with
a
most
agreeable
smile
and
suddenly
thundering
,
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
<EOS>
over
and
over
again
,
until
anybody
else
might
have
been
expected
to
be
quite
subdued
by
the

.
   
<EOS>
As
Richard
still
continued
to
say
that
he
was
fixed
in
his
choice
after
repeated
periods
for
consideration
had
been
recommended
by
Mr
Jarndyce
and
had
expired
,
and
he
still
continued
to
assure
Ada

in
the
same

manner
that
it
was
"
all
right
,
"
it

to
take
Mr
Kenge
into

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Kenge
,
therefore
,
came
down
to

one

,
and
leaned

chair
,
and
turned
his
eye
-

over
and

,
and
spoke
in

,
and
did

I

seen

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
A

,
Mr
Jarndyce
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

"

<EOS>
"

.
"
   
"
But

"

"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

---
<EOS>

---

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

!
"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

;
"
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>
We

,

---
 
<EOS>
known
,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
We

---

,
"
going

"
---

.
 
<EOS>
It
is

,
"
said

Kenge
with

,
"
one

which
may

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
He
might

by

and

.
 
<EOS>
I
can

as

for
you
,
but
he
MIGHT
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
this
was
an
opening
in
the
prospect
,
it
was
arranged
that
Mr
Kenge
should
see
his
cousin
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
Mr
Jarndyce
had
before
proposed
to
take
us
to
London
for
a
few
weeks
,
it
was
settled
next
day
that
we
should
make
our
visit
at
once
and
combine
Richard
's
business
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Boythorn
leaving
us
within
a
week
,
we
took
up
our
abode
at
a
cheerful
lodging
near
Oxford
Street
over
an
upholsterer
's
shop
.
<EOS>
London
was
a
great
wonder
to
us
,
and
we
were
out
for
hours
and
hours
at
a
time
,
seeing
the
sights
,
which
appeared
to
be
less
capable
of
exhaustion
than
we
were
.
 
<EOS>
We
made
the
round
of
the
principal
theatres
,
too
,
with
great
delight
,
and
saw
all
the
plays
that
were
worth
seeing
.
 
<EOS>
I
mention
this
because
it
was
at
the
theatre
that
I
began
to
be
made
uncomfortable
again
by
Mr
Guppy
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
sitting
in
front
of
the
box
one
night
with
Ada
,
and
Richard
was
in
the
place
he
liked
best
,
behind
Ada
's
chair
,
<EOS>
when
,
happening
to
look
down
into
the
pit
,
I
saw
Mr
Guppy
,
with
his
hair
flattened
down
upon
his
head
and
woe
depicted
in
his
face
,
looking
up
at
me
.
<EOS>
I
felt
all
through
the
performance
that
he
never
looked
at
the
actors
but
constantly
looked
at
me
,
and
always
with
a
carefully
prepared
expression
of
the
deepest
misery
and
the
profoundest
dejection
.
   
<EOS>
It
quite
spoiled
my
pleasure
for
that
night
because
it
was
so
very
embarrassing
and
so
very
ridiculous
.
 
<EOS>
But
from
that
time
forth
,
we
never
went
to
the
play
without
my
seeing
Mr
Guppy
in
the
pit
,
always
with
his
hair
straight
and
flat
,
his
shirt
-
collar
turned
down
,
and
a
general
feebleness
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
were
not
there
when
we
went
in
,
and
I
began
to
hope
he
would
not
come
and
yielded
myself
for
a
little
while
to
the
interest
of
the
scene
,
I
was
certain
to
encounter
his
languishing
eyes
when
I
least
expected
it
and
,
from
that
time
,
to
be
quite
sure
that
they
were
fixed
upon
me
all
the
evening
.
   
<EOS>
I
really
can
not
express
how
uneasy
this
made
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
would
only
have
brushed
up
his
hair
or
turned
up
his
collar
,
it
would
have
been
bad
enough
;
but
to
know
that
that
absurd
figure
was
always
gazing
at
me
,
and
always
in
that
demonstrative
state
of
despondency
,
put
such
a
constraint
upon
me
that
I
did
not
like
to
laugh
at
the
play
,
or
to
cry
at
it
,
or
to
move
,
or
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
I
seemed
able
to
do
nothing
naturally
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
escaping
Mr
Guppy
by
going
to
the
back
of
the
box
,
I
could
not
bear
to
do
that
because
I
knew
Richard
and
Ada
relied
on
having
me
next
them
and
that
they
could
never
have
talked
together
so
happily
if
anybody
else
had
been
in
my
place
.
 
<EOS>
So
there
I
sat
,
not
knowing
where
to
look
---
for
wherever
I
looked
<EOS>
,
I
knew
Mr
Guppy
's
eyes
were
following
me
---
and
thinking
of
the
dreadful
expense
to
which
this
young
man
was
putting
himself
on
my

.
   
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
thought
of
telling
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
feared
that
the
young
man
would
lose
his

and
that
I
might
ruin
him
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
thought
of
confiding
in
Richard
,
but
was

the
possibility
of
his
fighting
Mr
Guppy
and

.
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
thought
,
should

.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
felt
I
could
not

.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes

considered

I

write

,
but

that

would
he
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
always
came
to
the

,

,
that
I
could
do
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
's
perseverance
<EOS>
,
all
this
time
,
not
only
produced
him
regularly
at
any

to
which
we

,
but
caused

to
appear
in
the

as

,
and
even

get

fly
---
 
where
I
am
sure
I
saw
him
,
two
or
three
times
,
struggling
among
the
most
dreadful
spikes
.
 
<EOS>
After
we
got
home
,
he
haunted
a
post
opposite
our
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
upholsterer
's
where
we
lodged
being
at
the
corner
of
two
streets
,
and
my
bedroom
window
being
opposite
the
post
,
I
was
afraid
to
go
near
the
window
when
I
went

,
lest
I
should
see
him
(
as
I
did
one

night
)
leaning
against
the
post
and
evidently
catching
cold
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Guppy
had
not
been
,
fortunately
for
me
,
engaged
in
the
daytime
,
I
really
should
have
had
no
rest
from
him
.
   
<EOS>
While
we
were
making
this
round
of
gaieties
,
in
which
Mr
Guppy
so
extraordinarily
participated
,
the
business
which
had
helped
to
bring
us
to
town
was
not
neglected
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Kenge
's
cousin
was
a
Mr
Bayham
Badger
,
who
had
a
good
practice
at
Chelsea
and
attended
a
large
public
institution
besides
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
quite
willing
to
receive
Richard
into
his
house
and
to
superintend
his
studies
,
and
as
it
seemed
that
those
could
be
pursued
advantageously
under
Mr
Badger
's
roof
,
and
Mr
Badger
liked
Richard
,
and
as
Richard
said
he
liked
Mr
Badger
"
well
enough
,
"
an
agreement
was
made
,
the
Lord
Chancellor
's
consent
was
obtained
,
and
it
was
all
settled
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
day
when
matters
were
concluded
between
Richard
and
Mr
Badger
,
we
were
all
under
engagement
to
dine
at
Mr
Badger
's

.
<EOS>
We
were
to
be
"
merely
a
family
