,
"
Mrs
Badger
's
note
said
;
and
we
found
no
lady
there
<EOS>
but
Mrs
Badger
herself
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
surrounded
in
the
drawing
-
room
by
various
objects
,
indicative
of
her
painting
a
little
,
playing
the
piano
a
little
,
playing
the
guitar
a
little
,
playing
the
harp
a
little
,
singing
a
little
,
working
a
little
,
reading
a
little
,
writing
poetry
a
little
,
and
botanizing
a
little
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
lady
of
about
fifty
,
I
should
think
,
youthfully
dressed
,
and
of
a
very
fine
complexion
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
add
to
the
little
list
of
her
accomplishments
that
she
rouged
a
little
,
I
do
not
mean
that
there
was
any
harm
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bayham
Badger
himself
was
a
pink
,
fresh
-
faced
,
crisp
-
looking
gentleman
with
a
weak
voice
,
white
teeth
,
light
hair
,
and
surprised
eyes
,
<EOS>
some
years
younger
,
I
should
say
,
than
Mrs
Bayham
Badger
.
 
<EOS>
He
admired
her
exceedingly
,
but
principally
,
and
to
begin
with
,
on
the
curious
ground
(
as
it
seemed
to
us
)
of
her
having
had
three
husbands
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
barely
taken
our
seats
when
he
said
to
Mr
Jarndyce
quite
triumphantly
,
"
You
would
hardly
suppose
that
I
am
Mrs
Bayham
Badger
's
third
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
?
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
Her
third
!
"
said
Mr
Badger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Bayham
Badger
has
not
the
appearance
,
Miss
Summerson
,
of
a
lady
who
has
had
two
former
husbands
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
"
Not
at
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
most
remarkable
men
!
"
said
Mr
Badger
in
a
tone
of
confidence
.
"
<EOS>
Captain
Swosser
of
the
Royal
Navy
,
who
was
Mrs
Badger
's
first
husband
,
was
a
very
distinguished
officer
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
The
name
of
Professor
Dingo
,
my
immediate
predecessor
,
is
one
of
European
reputation
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Badger
overheard
him
and
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
my
dear
!
"
<EOS>
Mr
Badger
replied
to
the
smile
,
"
I
was
observing
to
Mr
Jarndyce
and
Miss
Summerson
that
you
had
had
two
former
husbands
---
both
very
distinguished
men
.
 
<EOS>
And
they
found
it
,
as
people
generally
do
,
difficult
to
believe
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
barely
twenty
,
"
said
Mrs
Badger
,
"
when
I
married
Captain
Swosser
of
the
Royal
Navy
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
in
the
Mediterranean
with
him
;
I
am
quite
a
sailor
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
twelfth
anniversary
of
my
wedding
-
day
,
I
became
the
wife
of
Professor
Dingo
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
European
reputation
,
"
added
Mr
Badger
in
an
undertone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
Mr
Badger
and
myself
were
married
,
"
pursued
Mrs
Badger
,
"
we
were
married
on
the
same
day
of
the
year
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
become
attached
to
the
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
So
that
Mrs
Badger
has
been
married
to
three
husbands
---
two
of
them
highly
distinguished
men
,
"
said
Mr
Badger
,
summing
up
the
facts
,
"
and
each
time
upon
the
twenty
-
first
of
March
at
eleven
in
the
forenoon
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
all
expressed
our
admiration
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
for
Mr
Badger
's
modesty
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
I
would
take
leave
to
correct
him
and
say
three
distinguished
men
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Mr
Jarndyce
!
 
<EOS>
What
I
always
tell
him
!
"
<EOS>
observed
Mrs
Badger
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Badger
,
"
what
do
I
always
tell
you
?
 
<EOS>
That
without
any
affectation
of
disparaging
such
professional
distinction
as
I
may
have
attained
(
which
our
friend
Mr
Carstone
will
have
many
opportunities
of
estimating
)
,
I
am
not
so
weak
---
no
,
really
,
"
said
Mr
Badger
to
us
generally
,
"
so
unreasonable
---
as
to
put
my
reputation
on
the
same
footing
with
such
first
-
rate
men
as
Captain
Swosser
and
Professor
Dingo
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
may
be
interested
,
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
continued
Mr
Bayham
Badger
,
leading
the
way
into
the
next
drawing
-
room
,
"
in
this
portrait
of
Captain
Swosser
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
taken
on
his
return
home
from
the
African
station
,
where
he
had
suffered
from
the
fever
of
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Badger
considers
it
too
yellow
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
a
very
fine
head
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
fine
head
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
all
echoed
,
"
A
very
fine
head
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
when
I
look
at
it
,
"
said
Mr
Badger
,
"
"
<EOS>
That
's
a
man
I
should
like
to
have
seen
!
"
 
<EOS>
It
strikingly
bespeaks
the
first
-
class
man
that
Captain
Swosser
pre
-
eminently
was
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
other
side
,
Professor
Dingo
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
him
well
---
attended
him
in
his
last
illness
---
a
speaking
likeness
!
 
<EOS>
Over
the
piano
,
Mrs
Bayham
Badger
when
Mrs
Swosser
.
 
<EOS>
Over
the
sofa
,
Mrs
Bayham
Badger
when
Mrs
Dingo
.
 
<EOS>
Of
Mrs
Bayham
Badger
IN
ESSE
,
I
possess
the
original
and
have
no
copy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Dinner
was
now
announced
,
and
we
went
downstairs
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
genteel
entertainment
,
very
handsomely
served
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
captain
and
the
professor
still
ran
in
Mr
Badger
's
head
,
and
<EOS>
as
Ada
<EOS>
and
I
had
the
honour
of
being
under
his
particular
care
,
we
had
the
full

of
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Water
,
Miss
Summerson
?
 
Allow
me
!
 
<EOS>
Not
in
that
tumbler
,
pray
.
<EOS>
Bring
me
the
professor
's
goblet
,
James
!
"
   
<EOS>
Ada
very
much
admired
some
artificial
flowers
under
a
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Astonishing
how
they
keep
!
"
said
Mr
Badger
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
were
presented
to
Mrs
Bayham
Badger
when
she
was
in
the
Mediterranean
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
invited
Mr
Jarndyce
to
take
a
glass
of
claret
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
that
claret
!
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
an
occasion
,
and
ON
an
occasion
I
produce
some
very
special
claret
I
happen
to
have
.
<EOS>
(
James
,
Captain
Swosser
's
wine
!
)
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
,
this
is
a
wine
that
was
imported
by
the
captain
,
we
will
not
say
how
many
years
ago
.
<EOS>
You
will
find
it
very
curious
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
,
I
shall
he
happy
to
take
some
of
this
wine
with

.
 
<EOS>
(
Captain
Swosser
's
claret
to
your
mistress
,
James
!
)
 
<EOS>
My
love
,
your
health
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
dinner
,
when
we
ladies
retired
,
we
took
Mrs
Badger
's
first
and
second
husband
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Badger
gave
us
in
the
drawing
-
room
a
biographical
sketch
of
the
life
and
services
of
Captain
Swosser
before
his
marriage
and
a
more
minute
account
of
him
dating
from
the
time
when
he
fell
in
love
with
her
at
a
ball
on
board
the
Crippler
,
given
to
the
officers
of
that
ship
when
she
lay
in
Plymouth
Harbour
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
dear
old
Crippler
!
"
said
Mrs
Badger
,
shaking
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
was
a
noble
vessel
.
 
<EOS>
Trim
,
ship
-
shape
,
all
a
taunto
,
as
Captain
Swosser
used
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
excuse
me
<EOS>
if
I
occasionally
introduce
a
nautical
expression
;
I
was
quite
a
sailor
once
.
 
<EOS>
Captain
Swosser
loved
that
craft
for
my
sake
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
was
no
longer
in
commission
,
he
frequently
said
that
if
he
were
rich
enough
to
buy
her
old
hulk
,
he
would
have
an
inscription
let
into
the
timbers
of
the
quarter
-
deck
where
we
stood
as
partners
in
the
dance
to
mark
the
spot
where
he
fell
---
raked
fore
and
aft
<EOS>
(
Captain
Swosser
used
to
say
)
by
the
fire
from
my
tops
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
his
naval
way
of
mentioning
my
eyes
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Badger
shook
her
head
,
sighed
,
and
looked
in
the
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
great
change
from
Captain
Swosser
to
Professor
Dingo
,
"
she
resumed
with
a
plaintive
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
felt
it
a
good
deal
at
first
.
<EOS>
Such
an
entire
revolution
in
my
mode
of
life
!
 
<EOS>
But
custom
,
combined
with
science
---
particularly
science
---
inured
me
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Being
the
professor
's
sole
companion
in
his
botanical
excursions
,
I
almost
forgot
that
I
had
ever
been
afloat
,
and
became
quite
learned
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
singular
that
the
professor
was
the
antipodes
of
Captain
Swosser
and
that
Mr
Badger
is
not
in
the
least
like
either
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
then
passed
into
a
narrative
of
the
deaths
of
Captain
Swosser
and
Professor
Dingo
,
both
of
whom
seem
to
have
had
very
bad
complaints
.
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
it
,
Mrs
Badger
signified
to
us
that
she
had
never
madly
loved
but
once
and
that
the
object
of
that
wild
affection
,
never
to
be
recalled
in
its
fresh
enthusiasm
,
was
Captain
Swosser
.
<EOS>
The
professor
was
yet
dying
by
inches
in
the
most
dismal
manner
,
and
Mrs
Badger
was
giving
us
imitations
of
his
way
of
saying
,
with
great
difficulty
,
"
Where
is
Laura
?
 
<EOS>
Let
Laura
give
me
my
toast
and
water
!
"
<EOS>
when
the
entrance
of
the
gentlemen
consigned
him
to
the
tomb
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
I
observed
that
evening
,
as
I
had
observed
for
some
days
past
,
that
Ada
and
Richard
were
more
than
ever
attached
to
each
other
's
society
,
which
was
but
natural
,
seeing
that
they
were
going
to
be
separated
so
soon
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
therefore
not
very
much
surprised
when
we
got
home
,
and
Ada
and
<EOS>
I
retired
upstairs
,
to
find
Ada
more
silent
than
usual
,
though
I
was
not
quite
prepared
for
her
coming
into
my
arms
and
beginning
to
speak
to
me
,
with
her
face
hidden
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
darling
Esther
!
"
murmured
Ada
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
great
secret
to
tell
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
mighty
secret
,
my
pretty
one
,
no
doubt
!
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
,
Ada
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Esther
,
you
would
never
guess
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
try
to
guess
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
!
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Ada
,
very
much
startled
by
the
idea
of
my
doing
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
I
wonder
who
it
can
be
about
?
"
said
I
,
pretending
to
consider
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
about
---
"
said
Ada
in
a
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
about
---
my
cousin
Richard
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
own
!
<EOS>
"
said
I
,
kissing
her
bright
hair
,
which
was
all
I
could
see
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
about
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Esther
,
you
would
never
guess
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
so
pretty
to
have
her
clinging
to
me
in
that
way
,
hiding
her
face
,
and
to
know
that
she
was
not
crying
in
sorrow
but
in
a
little
glow
of
joy
,
and
pride
,
and
hope
,
that
I
would
not
help
her
just
yet
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
says
---
I
know
it
's
very
foolish
,
we
are
both
so
young
---
but
he
says
,
"
with
a
burst
of
tears
,
"
that
he
loves
me
dearly
,
Esther
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
he
indeed
?
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
heard
of
such
a
thing
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
my
pet
of
pets
,
I
could
have
told
you
that
weeks
and
weeks
ago
!
"
   
<EOS>
To
see
Ada
lift
up
her
flushed
face
in
joyful
surprise
,
and
hold
me
round
the
neck
,
and
laugh
,
and
cry
,
and
blush
,
was
so
pleasant
!
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
darling
,
"
said
I
,
"
what
a
goose
you
must
take
me
for
!
 
<EOS>
Your
cousin
Richard
has
been
loving
you
as
plainly
as
he
could
for
I
do
n't
know
how
long
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
you
never
said
a
word
about
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Ada
,
kissing
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
love
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
waited
to
be
told
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
now
I
have
told
you
,
you
do
n't
think
it
wrong
of
me
,
do
you
?
"
returned
Ada
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
have
coaxed
me
to
say
no
if
I
had
been
the
hardest
-
hearted
duenna
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
Not
being
that
yet
,
I
said
no
very
freely
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
know
the
worst
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
that
's
not
quite
the
worst
of
it
,
Esther
dear
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Ada
,
holding
me
tighter
and
laying
down
her
face
again
upon
my
breast
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
even
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
even
that
!
"
said
Ada
,
shaking
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
never
mean
to
say
---
"
I
was
beginning
in
joke
.
   
<EOS>
But
Ada
,
looking
up
and
smiling
through
her
tear
's
,
cried
,
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
do
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
,
you
know
I
do
!
"
<EOS>
And
then
sobbed
out
,
"
With
all
my
heart
I
do
!
 
<EOS>
With
all
my
whole
heart
,
Esther
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
told
her
,
laughing
,
why
I
had
known
that
,
too
,
just
as
well
as
I
had
known
the
other
!
 
<EOS>
And
we
sat
before
the
fire
,
and
<EOS>
I
had
all
the
talking
to
myself
for
a
little
while
(
though
there
was
not
much
of
it
)
;
and
Ada
was
soon
quiet
and
happy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
my
cousin
John
knows
,
dear
Dame
Durden
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Unless
my
cousin
John
is
blind
,
my
pet
,
"
said
I
,
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
my
cousin
John
knows
pretty
well
as
much
as
we
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
want
to
speak
to
him
before
Richard
goes
,
"
said
Ada
timidly
,
"
and
we
wanted
you
to
advise
us
,
and
to
tell
him
so
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
would
n't
mind
Richard
's
coming
in
,
Dame
Durden
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Richard
is
outside
,
is
he
,
my
dear
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
quite
certain
,
"
returned
Ada
with
a
bashful
simplicity
that
would
have
won
my
heart
if
she
had
not
won
it
long
before
,
"
but
I
think
he
's
waiting
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
he
was
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
They
brought
a
chair
on
either
side
of
me
,
and
put
me
between
them
,
and
really
seemed
to
have
fallen
in
love
with
me
instead
of
one
another
,
they
were
so
confiding
,
and
so
trustful
,
and
so
fond
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
They
went
on
in
their
own
wild
way
for
a
little
while
<EOS>
---
I
never
stopped
them
;
I
enjoyed
it
too
much
myself
---
 
<EOS>
and
then
we
gradually
fell
to
considering
how
young
they
were
,
and
how
there
must
be
a
lapse
of
several
years
before
this
early
love
could
come
to
anything
,
and
how
it
could
come
to
happiness
only
if
it
were
real
and
lasting
and
inspired
them
with
a
steady
resolution
to
do
their
duty
to
each
other
,
with
constancy
,
fortitude
,
and
perseverance
,
each
always
for
the
other
's
sake
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Richard
said
that
he
would
work
his
fingers
to
the
bone
for
Ada
,
and
Ada
said
that
she
would
work
her
fingers
to
the
bone
for
Richard
,
and
they
called
me
all
sorts
of
endearing
and
sensible
names
,
and
we
sat
there
,
advising
and
talking
,
half
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
,
before
we
parted
,
I
gave
them
my
promise
to
speak
to
their
cousin
John
to
-
morrow
.
   
<EOS>
So
,
when
to
-
morrow
came
,
I
went
to
my
guardian
after
breakfast
,
in
the
room
that
was
our
town
-
substitute
for
the
growlery
,
and
told
him
that
I
had
it
in
trust
to
tell
him
something
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
little
woman
,
"
said
he
,
shutting
up
his
book
,
"
if
you
have
accepted
the
trust
,
there
can
be
no
harm
in
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
guardian
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
guarantee
that
there
is
no
secrecy
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
For
it
only
happened
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
?
 
<EOS>
And
what
is
it
,
Esther
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Guardian
,
"
said
I
,
"
you
remember
the
happy
night
when
first
we
came
down
to
Bleak
House
?
 
<EOS>
When
Ada
was
singing
in
the
dark
room
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
wished
to
call
to
his
remembrance
the
look
he
had
given
me
then
.
<EOS>
Unless
I
am
much
mistaken
,
I
saw
that
I
did
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
---
"
said
I
with
a
little
hesitation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
my
dear
!
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
hurry
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
said
I
,
"
Ada
and
Richard
have
fallen
in
love
.
 
<EOS>
And
have
told
each
other
so
.
"
   
"
<EOS>
Already
!
"
cried
my
guardian
,
quite

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
said
I.
 
"
And
to
tell
you
the
truth
,
guardian
,
I
rather
expected
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
deuce
you
did
!
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
He
sat
considering
for
a
minute
or
two
,
with
his
smile
,
at
once
so
handsome
and
so
kind
,
upon
his
changing
face
,
and
then
requested
me
to
let
them
know
that
he
wished
to
see

.
 
<EOS>
When
they
came
,
he
encircled
Ada
with
one
arm
in
his
fatherly
way
and
addressed
himself
to
Richard
with
a

gravity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Rick
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
I
am
glad
to
have
won
your
confidence
.
<EOS>
I
hope
to
preserve
it
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
contemplated
these
relations
between
us
four
which
have
so
brightened
my
life
and
so
invested
it
with
new
interests
and
pleasures
,
I
certainly
did
contemplate
,
afar
off
,
the
possibility
of
you
and
your
pretty
cousin
here
(
do
n't
be
shy
,
Ada
,
do
n't
be
shy
,
my
dear
!
)
<EOS>
being
in
a
mind
to
go
through
life
together
.
<EOS>
I
saw
,
and
do
see
,
many
reasons
to
make
it
desirable
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
was
afar
off
,
Rick
,
afar
off
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
look
afar
off
,
sir
,
"
returned
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
rational
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
hear
me
,
my
dears
!
 
<EOS>
I
might
tell
you
that
you
do
n't
know
your
own

yet
,
that
a
thousand
things
may
happen
to

from
one

,
that
it

well

you

is

,
or

.
 
<EOS>
But
I

.
 
<EOS>
Such
wisdom
will
come
soon
enough
,
I
dare
say
,
if
it
is
to
come

all
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
assume
that
a
few
years
hence
you
will
be
in
your
hearts
to
one
another
what
you
are
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
All
I
say
before
speaking
to
you
according
to
that
assumption
is
,
if
you
DO
change
---
 
if
you
DO
come
to
find
that
you
are
more
commonplace
cousins
to
each
other
as
man
and
woman
than
you

as
boy
and
girl
<EOS>
(
your

,
Rick
!
)
---
do

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

no

over
you
<EOS>
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
wish
and

if
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very

,

,
"

,
"
that
I

Ada

you

strongest

over
us
both
<EOS>
---
rooted

,

---

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear

,
"
said
Ada
,
on

,
"
my
father
's

.
 
<EOS>
All

love
and
duty
I
could

have

to

is

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
for
our
assumption
.
 
<EOS>
Now
we
lift
our

up
and
look
hopefully
at
the
distance
!
 
<EOS>
Rick
,
the
world
is
before
you
;
and
it
is
most
probable
that
as
you
enter
it
,
so
it
will
receive

.
 
<EOS>
Trust
in
nothing
but
in
Providence
and
your
own

.
 
<EOS>
Never
separate
the
two
,
like
the
heathen
waggoner
.
<EOS>
Constancy
in
love
is
a
good
thing
,
but
it
means
nothing
,
and

nothing
,
without
constancy
in
every

.
 
<EOS>
If
you
had
the
abilities
of
all
the
great
men
,
past
and
present
,
you
could
do
nothing
well
without
sincerely
meaning
it
and
setting
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
entertain
the
supposition
that
any
real
success
,
in
great
things
or
in
small
,
ever
was
or
could

,
ever

or

,
wrested
from
Fortune
by
fits

,
leave
that

or

Ada

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will

,

,
"

Richard

,
"
if
I
brought

here
just
now
<EOS>
(
but
I

I
did

)
,
and
will

to

Ada

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Right
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
If

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

---
<EOS>
no
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well

!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
That

well

!
 
<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>
Love

,
Rick
,
in

,
no

,

.
<EOS>
Otherwise
,

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
I

Ada
had

.
"
   
<EOS>
Ada
tenderly

him
,
and
Richard
heartily

with

,
and
then
the
cousins
went
out

the
room
,
looking
back
again
directly
,
though
,
to
say
that
they
would
wait
for
me
.
   
<EOS>
The
door
stood
open
,
and
we
both
followed
them
with
our
eyes
as
they
passed
down
the
adjoining
room
,
on
which
the
sun
was
shining
,
and
out
at
its
farther
end
.
 
<EOS>
Richard
with
his
head
bent
,
and
her
hand
drawn
through
his
arm
,
was
talking
to
her
very
earnestly
;
and
she
looked
up
in
his
face
,
listening
,
and
seemed
to
see
nothing
else
.
 
<EOS>
So
young
,
so
beautiful
,
so
full
of
hope
and

,
they
went
on
lightly
through
the
sunlight
as
their
own
happy
thoughts
might
then
be
traversing
the
years
to
come
and
making
them
all
years
of
brightness
.
 
<EOS>
So
they
passed
away
into
the
shadow
and
were
gone
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
only
a
burst
of
light
that
had
been
so
radiant
.
 
<EOS>
The
room
darkened
as
they
went
out
,
and
the
sun
was
clouded
over
.
   
<EOS>
"
Am
I
right
,
Esther
?
"
said
my
guardian
when
they
were
gone
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
so
good
and
wise
to
ask
ME
whether
he
was
right
!
   
<EOS>
"
Rick
may
gain
,
out
of
this
,
the
quality
he
wants
.
 
<EOS>
Wants
,
at
the
core
of
so
much
that
is
good
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
shaking

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
nothing
to
Ada
,
Esther
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
her
friend
and
counsellor
always
near
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
laid
his

.
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
showing
that
I
was
a
little

,
though
I
did
all
I
could

.
   
<EOS>
"
Tut
tut
!
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
we
must
take
care
,
too
,
that
our

woman
's

is
not
all

in

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Care
?
 
<EOS>
My

,
I

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
some

may

what
Esther
never

---
that
the
little
woman
is
to

!
"
   
<EOS>
I
have
omitted
to
mention
in
its

that
there
was
some

else
at

.
 
<EOS>
It

not

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
It

---

.
 
<EOS>
He

rather
reserved
,
but
I
thought

very

and

.
 
<EOS>
At
least
,
Ada
asked
me
if
I
did
not
,
and
I
said
yes
.
    
Chapter
14
.
<EOS>
Deportment
 
<EOS>
Richard
left
us
on
the
very
next
evening
to
begin
his
new
career
,
and
committed
Ada
to
my
charge
with
great
love
for
her
and
great
trust
in
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
touched
me
then
to
reflect
,
and
it
touches
me
now
,
more
nearly
,
to
remember
(
having
what
I
have
to
tell
)
how
they
both
thought
of
me
,
even
at
that
engrossing
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
a
part
of
all
their
plans
,
for
the
present
and
the
future
,
I
was
to
write
Richard
once
a
week
,
making
my
faithful
report
of
Ada
,
who
was
to
write
to
him
every
alternate
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
be
informed
,
under
his
own
hand
,
of
all
his
labours
and
successes
;
I
was
to
observe
how
resolute
and
persevering
he
would
be
;
I
was
to
be
Ada
's
bridesmaid
when
they
were
married
;
I
was
to
live
with
them
afterwards
;
I
was
to
keep
all
the
keys
of
their
house
;
I
was
to
be
made
happy
for
ever
and
a
day
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
the
suit
SHOULD
make
us
rich
,
Esther
---
which
it
may
,
you
know
!
"
said
Richard
to
crown
all
.
   
<EOS>
A
shade
crossed
Ada
's
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
Ada
,
"
asked
Richard
,
"
why
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
had
better
declare
us
poor
at
once
,
"
said
Ada
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know

that
,
"
returned
Richard
,
"
but
at
all
events
,
it
wo
n't
declare
anything
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
n't
declared
anything
in
heaven
knows
how
many

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Too
true
,
"

Ada
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
but
,
"
urged
Richard
,

what
her

rather

,
"
the
longer
it
goes
on
,
dcar
cousin
,
the
nearer
it
must
be
to
a
settlement
one
way
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
is
not
that
reasonable
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
best
,
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
afraid
<EOS>
if
we
trust
to
it
,
it
will
make
us
unhappy
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
Ada
,
we
are
not
going
to
trust
to
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Richard
gaily
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
know
it
better
than
to
trust
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
only
say
that
if
it
SHOULD
make
us
rich
,
we
have
no
constitutional
objection
to
being
rich
.
 
<EOS>
The
court
is
,
by
solemn
settlement
of
law
,
our
grim
old
guardian
,
and
we
are
to
suppose
that
what
it
gives
us
(
when
it
gives
us
anything
)
is
our
right
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
necessary
to
quarrel
with
our
right
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
Said
Ada
,
"
but
it
may
be
better
to
forget
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
cried
Richard
,
"
then
we
will
forget
all
about
it
!
 
<EOS>
We
consign
the
whole
thing
to
oblivion
.
 
<EOS>
Dame
Durden
puts
on
her
approving
face
,
and
it
's
done
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dame
Durden
's
approving
face
,
"
said
I
,
looking
out
of
the
box
in
which
I
was
packing
his
books
,
"
was
not
very
visible
when
you
called
it
by
that
name
;
but
it
does
approve
,
and
she
thinks
you
ca
n't
do
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
,
Richard
said
there
was
an
end
of
it
,
and
immediately
began
,
on
no
other
foundation
,
to
build
as
many
castles
in
the
air
as
would
man
the
Great
Wall
of
China
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
away
in
high
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
Ada
and
I
,
prepared
to
miss
him
very
much
,
commenced
our
quieter
career
.
   
<EOS>
On
our
arrival
in
London
,
we
had
called
with
Mr
Jarndyce
at
Mrs
Jellyby
's
but
had
not
been
so
fortunate
as
to
find
her
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
that
she
had
gone
somewhere
to
a
tea
-
drinking
and
had
taken
Miss
Jellyby
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
the
tea
-
drinking
,
there
was
to
be
some

-

and
letter

the

,

.
 
<EOS>
All

,
no

,
sufficient

of

her

's

.
   
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
his
wife
know
of
it
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Old
Mr
Turveydrop
's
wife
,
Miss
Clare
?
"
returned
Miss
Jellyby
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
no

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a

.
"
   
<EOS>
We
were
here
interrupted
by
Peepy
,
whose

undergone
so
much
on

of
his

's
unconsciously

like

rope
whenever

was
emphatic
that
the

child
now

with

.
 
<EOS>
As

,
and
as

,

.
 
<EOS>
Miss

proceeded
,
after

that

had
n't
meant
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
If

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

married

,

then
I

Pa

.
 
<EOS>
It
wo

Ma
<EOS>
;
I

only
pen

HER
.
<EOS>
One

comfort

,
"

"

of
Africa

.
 
<EOS>
Young
Mr
Turveydrop

Mr
Turveydrop

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

"

<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

is

.
"
   
<EOS>
Caddy
went

to

that

one

more
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

Flite
,

that

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Young

's

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Old

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
In

<EOS>

,

,
MR

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

up

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Miss

informed

that

had
been
lent
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
We

upstairs
---
it
had

fine
house
once
,
when
it
was
anybody
's

,

---

Turveydrop
's

,
which
was

out

and

.
 
<EOS>
It

bare
,

room
smelling
of

,

along

,

ornamented

-

,
which
seemed
to

-
fashioned

as

.
 
<EOS>
Several

,

of

,

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Miss
Summerson
,
Mr
Prince
Turveydrop
!
"
   
<EOS>
I

to
a

<EOS>
He

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
His

were
particularly

,
and

little

,

which
not

in

,

upon

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

Miss
Jellyby
's

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

fear
,
"
with

,
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Prince
Turveydrop

,

<EOS>
Just

old

Turveydrop
,

.
   
<EOS>
He

a
fat
old
gentleman

a
false

,
false

,
false

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
fur

,
and
he
had
a
padded
breast
to
his
coat
,
which
only
wanted
a
star
or
a
broad
blue

to

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
pinched
in
,
and
swelled
out
,
and
got
up
,
and
strapped
down
,
as
much
as
he
could
possibly
bear
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
such
a
neckcloth
on
(
puffing
his
very
eyes
out
of
their
natural
shape
)
,
and
his
chin
and
even
his
ears
so
sunk
into

,
that
it
seemed
as
though
be
must
inevitably

up
if

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
under
his
arm
a
hat
of
great

and

,
shelving
downward
from
the

,
and
in

with

as

on

in

high

,
round

state
of

not
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
cane
,
he

an
eye
-

,

,
he

rings
,

,

everything

any

;

,

,

was

.
   
<EOS>
"
Father
!
 
<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Jellyby
's

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Distinguished
,
"

Turveydrop
,
"
by

's

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,
aside

"

.
 
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
Go

"

Turveydrop
,

<EOS>
"
Go

!
"
   
<EOS>
At

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Prince
Turveydrop
sometimes
played
the
kit
,

;
sometimes

the

,
standing
;
sometimes

with
what

could

,
while
he
set
a
pupil
right
;
always
conscientiously

with
the
least
proficient
through
every

and
every

of
the
figure
;
and
never

for

.
 
<EOS>
His
distinguished
father
did
nothing
<EOS>
whatever
<EOS>
but
stand
before
the
fire
,
a
model
of
deportment
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
he
never
does
anything
else
,
"
said
the
old
lady
of

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yet
would
you
believe
that
it
's
HIS
name
on
the
door
-
plate
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
His
son
's
name
is
the
same
,
you
know
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
He
would
n't
let
his
son
have
any
name
if
he
could
take
it
from
him
,
"
returned
the
old

.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
the
son
's
dress
!
"
 
<EOS>
It
certainly
was
plain
---
threadbare
---
almost
shabby
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yet
the
father
must
be
garnished
and

out
,
"
said
the
old

,
"
because
of
his

.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
deport
him
!
 
<EOS>
Transport
him
would
be
better
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
curious
to
know
more
concerning
this
person
.
 
<EOS>
I
asked
,
"
Does
he
give
lessons
in
deportment
now
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Now
!
"
returned
the
old

.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
did
.
"
   
<EOS>
After
a

's
consideration
,
I
suggested
that
perhaps
fencing
had
been
his
accomplishment
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
he
can
fence
at
all
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
old
lady
.
   
<EOS>
I
looked
surprised
and
inquisitive
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
lady
,
becoming
more
and
more
incensed
against
the
master
of
deportment
as
she
dwelt
upon
the
subject
,
gave
me
some
particulars
of
his
career
,
with
strong
assurances
that
they
were
mildly
stated
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
married
a
meek
little
dancing
-
mistress
,
with
a
tolerable
connexion
(
having
never
in
his
life
before
done
anything
but
deport
himself
)
,
and
had
worked
her
to
death
,
or
had
,
at
the
best
,
suffered
her
to
work
herself
to
death
,
to
maintain
him
in
those
expenses
which
were
indispensable
to
his
position
.
 
<EOS>
At
once
to
exhibit
his
deportment
to
the
best
models
and
to
keep
the
best
models
constantly
before
himself
,
he
had
found
it
necessary
to
frequent
all
public
places
of
fashionable
and
lounging
resort
,
to
be
seen
at
Brighton
and
elsewhere
at
fashionable
times
,
and
to
lead
an
idle
life
in
the
very
best
clothes
.
 
<EOS>
To
enable
him
to
do
this
,
the
affectionate
little
dancing
-
mistress
had
toiled
and
laboured
and
would
have
toiled
and
laboured
to
that
hour
if
her
strength
had
lasted
so
long
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
mainspring
of
the
story
was
that
in
spite
of
the
man
's
absorbing
selfishness
,
his
wife
(
overpowered
by
his
deportment
)
had
,
to
the
last
,
believed
in
him
and
had
,
on
her
death
-
bed
,
in
the
most
moving
terms
,
confided
him
to
their
son
as
one
who
had
an
inextinguishable
claim
upon
him
and
whom
he
could
never
regard
with
too
much
pride
and
deference
.
 
<EOS>
The
son
,
inheriting
his
mother
's
belief
,
and
having
the
deportment
always
before
him
,
had
lived
and
grown
in
the
same
faith
,
and
now
,
at
thirty
years
of
age
,
worked
for
his
father
twelve
hours
a
day
and
looked
up
to
him
with
veneration
on
the
old
imaginary
pinnacle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
airs
the
fellow
gives
himself
!
"
<EOS>
said
my
informant
,
shaking
her
head
at
old
Mr
Turveydrop
with
speechless
indignation
as
he
drew
on
his
tight
gloves
,
of
course
unconscious
of
the
homage
she
was
rendering
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
fully
believes
he
is
one
of
the
aristocracy
!
 
<EOS>
And
he
is
so
condescending
to
the
son
he
so
egregiously
deludes
that
you
might
suppose
him
the
most
virtuous
of
parents
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
said
the
old
lady
,
apostrophizing
him
with
infinite
vehemence
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
bite
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
being
amused
,
though
I
heard
the
old
lady
out
with

real
concern
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
difficult
to
doubt
her
with
the
father
and
son
before
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
might
have
thought
of
them
without
the
old
lady
's

,
or
what
I
might
have
thought
of
the
old

's
account
without
them
,
I
can
not
say
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
fitness
of
things
in
the
whole
that
carried
conviction
with
it
.
   
<EOS>
My
eyes
were
yet
wandering
,
from
young
Mr
Turveydrop
working
so
hard
,
to
old
Mr
Turveydrop
deporting
himself
so
beautifully
,
when
the
latter
came

to

and
entered

.
   
<EOS>
He
asked
me
,
first

all
,
whether
I
conferred
a
charm
and
a

on
London
by

in

?
 
<EOS>
I
did
not

necessary
to
reply
that
I

perfectly
aware
I
should
not
do

,
in
any

,
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
A

,
"
he

,

,
"
will
look

on
the

here
.
 
<EOS>
We
do
our
best
to
polish
---
 
polish
---
polish
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
sat
down

,
taking
some

to
sit
on

form
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
,
in
imitation
of
the
print
of
his
illustrious

on
the
sofa
.
 
<EOS>
And
really
he
did
look
very
like

.
   
<EOS>
"
To
polish
---
polish
---
polish
!
"
<EOS>
he
repeated
,
taking
a
pinch
of
snuff
and
gently

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
we
are
not
,
if
I
may

to
one
formed
to
be
graceful
both
by
Nature
and
Art
---
"
with
the
high
-

,
which
it
seemed

to

lifting

and

"
<EOS>
---
we

not
what

in
point
of

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
we
not
,

?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
degenerated
,
"
he

,

his

,
which
he
could
do
to
a

in

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
levelling
age
is
not
favourable
to

.
 
<EOS>
It
develops
vulgarity
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
speak
with
some
little

.
 
<EOS>
It
may
not
be
for
me
to

that
I
have
been
called
,
for
some

,
Gentleman
Turveydrop
,

Regent

on

the

at
Brighton
(
that

)
,
<EOS>
"
Who

?
 
<EOS>
Who
the

?
<EOS>
Why
do

?
 
<EOS>
Why
has

thirty

?
"
 
<EOS>
But
these

little

---
the
general
property
,
ma'am
---
 
still
repeated
occasionally
among
the

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Indeed
?
"
said
<EOS>
I.
   
He

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
England
---
alas

!
---
has

.
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
One

,
"

<EOS>
"
You

very
good
.
"
 
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

---

!
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Heaven

---

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

"

<EOS>
"
Understand

.
 
<EOS>
All

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

---
"
 
<EOS>

"
This

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

,

Miss

's

,
now

with

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Your

,
"

<EOS>
"
It

my
reward
,
"
said
Mr
Turveydrop
,
"
to

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
he
treads
in

of

.
<EOS>
She
was

.
 
<EOS>
But
wooman
,

,
"
said
Mr
Turveydrop
with

,
"
what

!
"
   
<EOS>
I

Miss
Jellyby
,
who
was
by

.
 
<EOS>
The
time

to
a
lesson
having
fully

,

of

.
 
<EOS>
When
Miss
Jellyby
and

Prince
found

to

betrothed
<EOS>
I
do

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

Turveydrop

,
"
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
"
 
<EOS>
The

had
no

.
 
<EOS>
The

a

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Recollect

at

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
"

Turveydrop
,

,
"
that

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

You

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Good

"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Bless

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Turveydrop
said
this
in
quite
a
pious

,
and
it
seemed
to
do
his
son
good
,
who
,
in

from

,
was
so

,
so

to
him
,
and
so

that
I

as

were
an
unkindness
to
the
younger
man
not
to
be
able
to
believe
implicitly
in
the
elder
.
 
<EOS>
The
few
moments
that
were
occupied
by
Prince
in
taking
leave
of
us
(
and
particularly

one
of
us
,
as
I
saw
,
being
in
the
secret
)
,
enhanced
my
favourable
impression
of
his
almost

.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
a
liking
for
him
and
a

for
him
as

his
little

in

---
and
with

his

to
stay

little

with

---
and
went
away
good
-
humouredly
to
his
cold
mutton
and
his

at
Kensington
,
that
made
me

less

with
his
father
than
the
censorious

.
   
<EOS>
The
father
opened
the
room

for
us
and
bowed

in
a

,
I
must
acknowledge
,
worthy
of

.
 
<EOS>
In
the
same
style
he
presently
passed
us
on
the
other

the
street
,
on
his

to
the

part
of
the

,
where
he
was
going
to
show

among
the
few
other

left
.
 
<EOS>
For
some

,
I
was
so
lost
in
reconsidering
what
I
had
heard
and
seen
in
Newman
Street
that
I
was
quite
unable
to
talk

Caddy
or

on
what
she
said
to

,

I

inquire
in

whether

,
or

,

,
not

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

so

and
suggested
the
possibility
of
so
many
Mr
Turveydrops
that
I
said
,
"
Esther
,
you
must
make

to

and

Caddy
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
accordingly
did
so
,
and
we
chatted
all
the
rest
of
the
way
to
Lincoln
's
Inn
.
   
<EOS>
Caddy
told
me
that
her
lover
's
education
had
been
so
neglected
that
it
was
not
always
easy
to
read
his
notes
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
if
he
were
not
so
anxious
about
his
spelling
and
took
less
pains
to
make
it
clear
,
he
would
do
better
;
but
he
put
so
many
unnecessary
letters
into
short
words
that
they
sometimes
quite
lost
their
English
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
does
it
with
the
best

,
"
observed
Caddy
,
"
but
<EOS>
it
has
n't
the
effect
he
means
,
poor
fellow
!
"
 
<EOS>
Caddy
then
went
on
to
reason
,
how
could
he
be
expected
to
be
a
scholar
when
he
had
passed
his
whole

in
the
dancing
-
school
and
had
done
nothing
but
teach
and
fag
,
fag
and
teach
,
morning
,
noon
,
and
night
!
 
<EOS>
And
what
did
it
matter
?
 
<EOS>
She
could
write
letters
enough
for
both
,
as
she
knew
to
her
cost
,
and
it
was
far

for

to

than

.
 
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
it
's
not
as
if
I

an

girl
who
had
any

to
give
herself
airs
,
"
said
Caddy
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
little
enough
,
I
am
sure
,
thanks

Ma
!
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
another
thing
I
want

,

,
"
continued
Caddy
,
"
which
I

liked
to
mention
unless
you

Prince
,
Miss
Summerson
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
a
house
ours
is
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
of
no
use
<EOS>
my
trying
to
learn
anything
that
it
would

for
Prince
's
wife
to
know
in
OUR

.
 
<EOS>
We
live
in
such
a
state
of
muddle
that
it
's

,
and
I
have
only
been
more

.
 
<EOS>
So
I
get
a
little
practice
with
---
who
do
you
think
?
 
<EOS>
Poor
Miss
Flite
!
 
<EOS>
Early
in

morning
I
help

to

her

and
clean
her
birds
,
and
I
make
her
cup
of
coffee
for
her
(
of
course
she
taught

)
,
and
I
have
learnt
to
make

so

that
Prince
says
it
's
the
very

coffee
he

,
and
would

old
Mr
Turveydrop
,
who
is
very

about
his

.
 
<EOS>
I
can
make
little

too
;
and
I
know
how
to
buy
neck
of
mutton
,
and

,
and

,
and

,
and
a

many

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not

at
my

,

,
"
said
Caddy
,

the
repairs
on
Peepy
's

,
"
<EOS>
but
perhaps
I
shall
improve
,
and

I
have
been

to
Prince
and
have

doing

,
I
have

subject
which
he
could
not
make
up
his
mind
to
approach
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
imagine
a
countenance
and
manner
more
singularly
expressive
of
caution
and
indecision
,
and
a
perpetual
impulse
to
do
something
he
could
not
resolve
to
venture
on
,
than
Mr
Krook
's
was
that
day
.
 
<EOS>
His
watchfulness
of
my
guardian
was
incessant
.
 
<EOS>
He
rarely
removed
his
eyes
from
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
went
on
beside
him
,
he
observed
him
with
the
slyness
of
an
old
white
fox
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
went
before
,
he
looked
back
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
stood
still
,
he
got
opposite
to
him
,
and
drawing
his
hand
across
and
across
his
open
mouth
with
a
curious
expression
of
a
sense
of
power
,
and
turning
up
his
eyes
,
and
lowering
his
grey
eyebrows
until
they
appeared
to
be
shut
,
seemed
to
scan
every
lineament
of
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
,
having
been
(
always
attended
by
the
cat
)
all
over
the
house
and
having
seen
the
whole
stock
of
miscellaneous
lumber
,
which
was
certainly
curious
,
we
came
into
the
back
part
of
the
shop
.
 
<EOS>
Here
on
the
head
of
an
empty
barrel
stood
on
end
were
an
ink
-
bottle
,
some
old
stumps
of
pens
,
and
some
dirty
playbills
;
and
against
the
wall
were
pasted
several
large
printed
alphabets
in
several
plain
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
doing
here
?
"
asked
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Trying
to
learn
myself
to
read
and
write
,
"
said
Krook
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
do
you
get
on
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Slow
.
 
<EOS>
Bad
,
"
returned
the
old
man
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
hard
at
my
time
of
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
easier
to
be
taught
by
some
one
,
"
said
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Aye
,
but
they
might
teach
me
wrong
!
"
<EOS>
returned
the
old
man
with
a
wonderfully
suspicious
flash
of
his
eye
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
I
may
have
lost
by
not
being
learned
afore
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
like
to
lose
anything
by
being
learned
wrong
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wrong
?
<EOS>
"
said
my
guardian
with
his
good
-
humoured
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
do
you
suppose
would
teach
you
wrong
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
Mr
Jarndyce
of
Bleak
House
!
"
replied
the
old
man
,
turning
up
his
spectacles
on
his
forehead
and
rubbing
his
hands
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suppose
as
anybody
would
,
but
I
'd
rather
trust
my
own
self
than
another
!
"
   
<EOS>
These
answers
and
his
manner
were
strange
enough
to
cause
my
guardian
to
inquire
of
Mr
Woodcourt
,
as
we
all
walked
across
Lincoln
's
Inn
together
,
whether
Mr
Krook
were
really
,
as
his
lodger
represented
him
,
deranged
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
surgeon
replied
,
no
,
he
had
seen
no
reason
to
think
so
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
exceedingly
distrustful
,
as
ignorance
usually
was
,
and
he
was
always
more
or
less
under
the
influence
of
raw
gin
,
of
which
he
drank
great
quantities
and
of
which
he
and
his
back
-
shop
,
as
we
might
have
observed
,
smelt
strongly
;
but
he
did
not
think
him
mad
as
yet
.
   
<EOS>
On
our
way
home
,
I
so
conciliated
Peepy
's
affections
by
buying
him
a
windmill
and
two
flour
-
sacks
that
he
would
suffer
nobody
else
to
take
off
his
hat
and
gloves
and
would
sit
nowhere
at
dinner
but
at
my
side
.
 
<EOS>
Caddy
sat
upon
the
other
side
of
me
,
next
to
Ada
,
to
whom
we
imparted
the
whole
history
of
the
engagement
as
soon
as
we
got
back
.
 
<EOS>
We
made
much
of
Caddy
,
and
Peepy
too
;
and
Caddy
brightened
exceedingly
;
and
my
guardian
was
as
merry
as
we
were
;
and
we
were
all
very
happy
indeed
until
Caddy
went
home
at
night
in
a
hackney
-
coach
,
with
Peepy
fast
asleep
,
but
holding
tight
to
the
windmill
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
forgotten
to
mention
<EOS>
---
at
least
I
have
not
mentioned
---
that
Mr
Woodcourt
was
the
same
dark
young
surgeon
whom
we
had
met
at
Mr
Badger
's
.
 
<EOS>
Or
that
Mr
Jarndyce
invited
him
to
dinner
that
day
.
<EOS>
Or
that
he
came
.
 
<EOS>
Or
that
when
they
were
all
gone
and
I
said
to
Ada
,
"
Now
,
my
darling
,
let
us
have
a
little
talk
about
Richard
!
<EOS>
"
Ada
laughed
and
said
---
    
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
think
it
matters
what
my
darling
said
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
always
merry
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
15
.
<EOS>
Bell
Yard
 
<EOS>
While
we
were
in
London
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
was
constantly
beset
by
the
crowd
of
excitable
ladies
and
gentlemen
whose
proceedings
had
so
much
astonished
us
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Quale
,
who
presented
himself
soon
after
our
arrival
,
was
in
all
such
excitements
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
project
those
two
shining
knobs
of
temples
of
his
into
everything
that
went
on
and
to
brush
his
hair
farther
and
farther
back
,
until
the
very
roots
were
almost
ready
to
fly
out
of
his
head
in
inappeasable
philanthropy
.
 
<EOS>
All
objects
were
alike
to
him
,
but
he
was
always
particularly
ready
for
anything
in
the
way
of
a
testimonial
to
any
one
.
 
<EOS>
His
great
power
seemed
to
be
his
power
of
indiscriminate
admiration
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
sit
for
any
length
of
time
,
with
the
utmost
enjoyment
,
bathing
his
temples
in
the
light
of
any
order
of
luminary
.
 
<EOS>
Having
first
seen
him
perfectly
swallowed
up
in
admiration
of
Mrs
Jellyby
,
I
had
supposed
her
to
be
the
absorbing
object
of
his
devotion
.
 
<EOS>
I
soon
discovered
my
mistake
and
found
him
to
be
train
-
bearer
and
organ
-
blower
to
a
whole
procession
of
people
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Pardiggle
came
one
day
for
a
subscription
to
something
,
and
with
her
,
Mr
Quale
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
Mrs
Pardiggle
said
,
Mr
Quale
repeated
to
us
;
and
just
as
he
had
drawn
Mrs
Jellyby
out
,
he
drew
Mrs
Pardiggle
out
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Pardiggle
wrote
a
letter
of
introduction
to
my
guardian
in
behalf
of
her
eloquent
friend
Mr
Gusher
.
 
<EOS>
With
Mr
Gusher
appeared
Mr
Quale
again
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gusher
,
being
a
flabby
gentleman
with
a
moist
surface
and
eyes
so
much
too
small
for
his
moon
of
a
face
that
they
seemed
to
have
been
originally
made
for
somebody
else
,
was
not
at
first
sight
prepossessing
;
yet
he
was
scarcely
seated
before
Mr
Quale
asked
Ada
and
me
,
not
inaudibly
,
whether
he
was
not
a
great
creature
---
which
he
certainly
was
,
flabbily
speaking
,
though
Mr
Quale
meant
in
intellectual
beauty
---
 
and
whether
we
were
not
struck
by
his
massive
configuration
of
brow
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
we
heard
of
a
great
many
missions
of
various
sorts
among
this
set
of
people
,
but
nothing
respecting
them
was
half
so
clear
to
us
as
that
it
was
Mr
Quale
's
mission
to
be
in
ecstasies
with
everybody
else
's
mission
and
that
it
was
the
most
popular
mission
of
all
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
had
fallen
into
this
company
in
the
tenderness
of
his
heart
and
his
earnest
desire
to
do
all
the
good
in
his
power
;
but
that
he
felt
it
to
be
too
often
an
unsatisfactory
company
,
where
benevolence
took
spasmodic
forms
,
where
charity
was
assumed
as
a
regular
uniform
by
loud
professors
and
speculators
in
cheap
notoriety
,
vehement
in
profession
,
restless
and
vain
in
action
,
servile
in
the
last
degree
of
meanness
to
the
great
,
adulatory
of
one
another
,
and
intolerable
to
those
who
were
anxious
quietly
to
help
the
weak
from
failing
rather
than
with
a
great
deal
of
bluster
and
self
-
laudation
to
raise
them
up
a
little
way
when
they
were
down
,
he
plainly
told
us
.
 
<EOS>
When
a
testimonial
was
originated
to
Mr
Quale
by
Mr
Gusher
(
who
had
already
got
one
,
originated
by
Mr
Quale
)
,
and
when
Mr
Gusher
spoke
for
an
hour
and
a
half
on
the
subject
to
a
meeting
,
including
two
charity
schools
of
small
boys
and
girls
,
who
were
specially
reminded
of
the
widow
's
mite
,
and
requested
to
come
forward
with
halfpence
and
be
acceptable
sacrifices
,
I
think
the
wind
was
in
the
east
for
three
whole
weeks
.
   
<EOS>
I
mention
this
because
I
am
coming
to
Mr
Skimpole
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
me
that
his
off
-
hand
professions
of
childishness
and
carelessness
were
a
great
relief
to
my
guardian
,
by
contrast
with
such
things
,
and
were
the
more
readily
believed
in
since
to
find
one
perfectly
undesigning
and
candid
man
among
many
opposites
could
not
fail
to
give
him
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
be
sorry
to
imply
that
Mr
Skimpole
divined
this
and
was
politic
;
I
really
never
understood
him
well
enough
to
know
.
 
<EOS>
What
he
was
to
my
guardian
,
he
certainly
was
to
the
rest
of
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
very
well
;
and
thus
,
though
he
lived
in
London
,
we
had
seen
nothing
of
him
until
now
.
 
<EOS>
He
appeared
one
morning
in
his
usual
agreeable
way
and
as
full
of
pleasant
spirits
as
ever
.
   
<EOS>
Well
,
he
said
,
here
he
was
!
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
bilious
,
but
rich
men
were
often
bilious
,
and
therefore
he
had
been
persuading
himself
that
he
was
a
man
of
property
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
was
,
in
a
certain
point
of
view
---
in
his
expansive
intentions
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
enriching
his
medical
attendant
in
the
most
lavish
manner
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
always
doubled
,
and
sometimes
quadrupled
,
his
fees
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
said
to
the
doctor
,
"
Now
,
my
dear
doctor
,
it
is
quite
a
delusion
on
your
part
to
suppose
that
you
attend
me
for
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
overwhelming
you
with
money
---
in
my
expansive
intentions
<EOS>
---
if
you
only
knew
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
really
(
he
said
)
<EOS>
he
meant
it
to
that
degree
that
he
thought
it
much
the
same
as
doing
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
had
those
bits
of
metal
or
thin
paper
to
which
mankind
attached
so
much
importance
to
put
in
the
doctor
's
hand
,
he
would
have
put
them
in
the
doctor
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Not
having
them
,
he
substituted
the
will
for
the
deed
.
 
<EOS>
Very
well
!
 
<EOS>
If
he
really
meant
it
---
if
his
will
were
genuine
and
real
,
which
it
was
---
it
appeared
to
him
that
it
was
the
same
as
coin
,
and
cancelled
the
obligation
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
,
partly
,
because
I
know
nothing
of
the
value
of
money
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
but
I
often
feel
this
.
 
<EOS>
It
seems
so
reasonable
!
<EOS>
My
butcher
says
to
me
he
wants
that
little
bill
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
part
of
the
pleasant
unconscious

of
the
man
's
nature
that
he
always
calls
it

"
little
"
bill
---
to
make

payment
appear

to

.
 
<EOS>
I
reply
to
the
butcher
,
"
My
good
friend
,
if
you
knew

,
you
are
paid
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
n't
had
the
trouble
of
coming
to

for
the
little

.
 
<EOS>
You
are
paid
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
it
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
But
,
suppose
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
laughing
,
"
he
had
meant
the
meat
in
the

,
instead
of
providing

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Jarndyce
,
"
he

,
"
you
surprise
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
take
the
butcher
's
position
.
 
<EOS>
A
butcher
I
once
dealt
with
occupied
that
very
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Says
he
,
"
Sir
,
why
did
you
eat
spring
lamb
at
eighteen
pence
a
pound
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Why
did
I
eat
spring
lamb
at
eighteen
-
pence
a
pound
,
my
honest
friend
?
"
<EOS>
said
I
,
naturally
amazed
by
the
question
.
<EOS>
"
I
like
spring
lamb
!
"
 
<EOS>
This
was
so
far
convincing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
says
he
,
"
I
wish
I
had
meant
the
lamb
as
you
mean
the
money
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
good
fellow
,
"
said
I
,
"
pray
let
us
reason
like
intellectual
beings
.
<EOS>
How
could
that
be
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
.
 
<EOS>
You
HAD
got
the
lamb
,
and
I
have
NOT
got
the
money
.
 
<EOS>
You
could
n't
really
mean
the
lamb
without
sending
it
in
,
whereas
I
can
,
and
do
,
really
mean
the
money
without
paying
it
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
end
of
the
subject
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
he
take
no
legal
proceedings
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
he
took
legal
proceedings
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
in
that
he
was
influenced
by
passion
,
not
by
reason
.
 
<EOS>
Passion
reminds
me
of
Boythorn
.
 
<EOS>
He
writes
me
that
you
and
the
ladies
have
promised
him
a
short
visit
at
his
bachelor
-
house
in
Lincolnshire
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
great
favourite
with
my
girls
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
and
I
have
promised
for
them
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nature
forgot
to
shade
him
off
<EOS>
,
I
think
,
"
observed
Mr
Skimpole
to
Ada
and
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
little
too
boisterous
---
like
the
sea
.
 
<EOS>
A
little
too
vehement
---
like
a
bull
who
has
made
up
his
mind
to
consider
every
colour
scarlet
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
grant
a
sledge
-
hammering
sort
of
merit
in
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
should
have
been
surprised
if
those
two
could
have
thought
very
highly
of
one
another
,
Mr
Boythorn
attaching
so
much
importance
to
many
things
and
Mr
Skimpole
caring
so
little
for
anything
.
<EOS>
Besides
which
,
I
had
noticed
Mr
Boythorn
more
than
once
on
the
point
of
breaking
out
into
some
strong
opinion
when
Mr
Skimpole
was
referred
to
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
I
merely
joined
Ada
in
saying
that
we
had
been
greatly
pleased
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
invited
me
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
;
"
and
if
a
child
may
trust
himself
in
such
hands
---
which
the
present
child
is
encouraged
to
do
,
with
the
united
tenderness
of
two
angels
to
guard
him
---
I
shall
go
.
<EOS>
He
proposes
to
frank
me
down
and
back
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
will
cost
money
?
 
<EOS>
Shillings
perhaps
?
 
<EOS>
Or
pounds
?
 
<EOS>
Or
something
of
that
sort
?
 
<EOS>
By
the
by
,
Coavinses
.
 
<EOS>
You
remember
our
friend
Coavinses
,
Miss
Summerson
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
asked
me
as
the
subject
arose
in
his
mind
,
in
his
graceful
,
light
-
hearted
manner
and
without
the
least
embarrassment
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Coavinses
has
been
arrested
by
the
Great
Bailiff
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
will
never
do
violence
to
the
sunshine
any
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
quite
shocked
me
to
hear
it
,
for
I
had
already
recalled
with
anything
but
a
serious
association
the
image
of
the
man
sitting
on
the
sofa
that
night
wiping
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
His
successor
informed
me
of
it
yesterday
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
successor
is
in
my
house
now
---
in
possession
,
I
think
he
calls
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
yesterday
,
on
my
blue
-
eyed
daughter
's
birthday
.
 
<EOS>
I
put
it
to
him
,
"
<EOS>
This
is
unreasonable
and
inconvenient
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
had
a
blue
-
eyed
daughter
you
would
n't
like
ME
to
come
,
uninvited
,
on
HER
birthday
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
But
he
stayed
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
laughed
at
the
pleasant
absurdity
and
lightly
touched
the
piano
by
which
he
was
seated
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
he
told
me
,
"
he
said
,
playing
little
chords
where
I
shall
put
full
stops
,
"
The
Coavinses
had
left
.
 
<EOS>
Three
children
.
 
<EOS>
No
mother
.
<EOS>
And
that
Coavinses
'
profession
.
 
<EOS>
Being
unpopular
.
 
<EOS>
The
rising
Coavinses
.
 
<EOS>
Were
at
a
considerable
disadvantage
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
got
up
,
rubbing
his
head
,
and
began
to
walk
about
.
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
played
the
melody
of
one
of
Ada
's
favourite
songs
.
<EOS>
Ada
and
I
both
looked
at
Mr
Jarndyce
,
thinking
that
we
knew
what
was
passing
in
his
mind
.
   
<EOS>
After
walking
and
stopping
,
and
several
times
leaving
off
rubbing
his
head
,
and
beginning
again
,
my
guardian
put
his
hand
upon
the
keys
and
stopped
Mr
Skimpole
's
playing
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
this
,
Skimpole
,
"
he
said
thoughtfully
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
,
who
had
quite
forgotten
the
subject
,
looked
up
surprised
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
man
was
necessary
,
"
pursued
my
guardian
,
walking
backward
and
forward
in
the
very
short
space
between
the
piano
and
the
end
of
the
room
and
rubbing
his
hair
up
from
the
back
of
his
head
as
if
a
high
east
wind
had
blown
it
into
that
form
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
we
make
such
men
necessary
by
our
faults
and
follies
,
or
by
our
want
of
worldly
knowledge
,
or
by
our
misfortunes
,
we
must
not
revenge
ourselves
upon
them
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
harm
in
his
trade
.
 
<EOS>
He
maintained
his
children
.
 
<EOS>
One
would
like
to
know
more
about
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Coavinses
?
"
cried
Mr
Skimpole
,
at
length
perceiving
what
he
meant
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
easier
.
 
<EOS>
A
walk
to
Coavinses
'
headquarters
,
and
you
can
know
what
you
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
nodded
to
us
,
who
were
only
waiting
for
the
signal
.
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
We
will
walk
that
way
,
my
dears
.
 
<EOS>
Why
not
that
way
as
soon
as
another
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
We
were
quickly
ready
and
went
out
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
went
with
us
and
quite
enjoyed
the
expedition
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
so
new
and
<EOS>
so
refreshing
,
he
said
,
for
him
to
want
Coavinses
instead
of
Coavinses
wanting
him
!
   
<EOS>
He
took
us
,
first
,
to
Cursitor
Street
,
Chancery
Lane
,
where
there
was
a
house
with
barred
windows
,
which
he
called
Coavinses
'
Castle
.
<EOS>
On
our
going
into
the
entry
and
ringing
a
bell
,
a
very
hideous
boy
came
out
of
a
sort
of
office
and
looked
at
us
over
a
spiked
wicket
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
did
you
want
?
"
said
the
boy
,
fitting
two
of
the
spikes
into
his
chin
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
follower
,
or
an
officer
,
or
something
,
here
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
who
is
dead
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
?
"
said
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
his
name
,
if
you
please
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Name
of
Neckett
,
"
said
the
boy
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
his
address
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bell
Yard
,
"
said
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Chandler
's
shop
,
left
hand
side
,
name
of
Blinder
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
he
---
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
to
shape
the
question
---
<EOS>
"
murmured
my
guardian
,
"
industrious
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
Neckett
?
"
said
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
wery
much
so
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
never
tired
of
watching
.
 
<EOS>
He
'd
set
upon
a
post
at
a
street
corner
eight
or
ten
hours
at
a
stretch
if
he
undertook
to
do
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
might
have
done
worse
,
"
I
heard
my
guardian
soliloquize
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
might
have
undertaken
to
do
it
and
not
done
it
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
I
want
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
left
the
boy
,
with
his
head
on
one
side
and
his
arms
on
the
gate
,
fondling
and
sucking
the
spikes
,
and
went
back
to
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
where
Mr
Skimpole
,
who
had
not
cared
to
remain
nearer
Coavinses
,
awaited
us
.
 
<EOS>
Then
we
all
went
to
Bell
Yard
,
a
narrow
alley
at
a
very
short
distance
.
 
<EOS>
We
soon
found
the
chandler
's
shop
.
<EOS>
In
it
was
a
good
-
natured
-
looking
old
woman
with
a
dropsy
,
or
an
asthma
,
or
perhaps
both
.
   
<EOS>
"
Neckett
's
children
?
"
said
she
in
reply
to
my
inquiry
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Surely
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
Three
pair
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
Door
right
opposite
the
stairs
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
she
handed
me
the
key
across
the
counter
.
   
<EOS>
I
glanced
at
the
key
and
glanced
at
her
,
but
she
took
it
for
granted
that
I
knew
what
to
do
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
could
only
be
intended
for
the
children
's
door
,
I
came
out
without
askmg
any
more
questions
and
led
the
way
up
the
dark
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
as
quietly
as
we
could
,
but
four
of
us
made
some
noise
on
the
aged
boards
,
and
when
we
came
to
the
second
story
we
found
we
had
disturbed
a
man
who
was
standing
there
looking
out
of
his
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
Gridley
that
's
wanted
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
fixing
his
eyes
on
me
with
an
angry
stare
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
said
I
;
"
I
am
going
higher
up
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
at
Ada
,
and
at
Mr
Jarndyce
,
and
at
Mr
Skimpole
,
fixing
the
same
angry
stare
on
each
in
succession
as
they
passed
and
followed
me
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
gave
him
good
day
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
day
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
said
abruptly
and
fiercely
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
tall
,
sallow
man
with
a
careworn
head
on
which
<EOS>
but
little
hair
remained
,
a
deeply
lined
face
,
and
prominent
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
combative
look
and
a
chafing
,
irritable
manner
which
,
associated
with
his
figure
---
still
large
and
powerful
,
though
evidently
in
its
decline
---
rather
alarmed
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
pen
in
his
hand
,
and
in
the
glimpse
I
caught
of
his
room
in
passing
,
I
saw
that
it
was
covered
with
a
litter
of
papers
.
   
<EOS>
Leaving
him
standing
there
,
we
went
up
to
the
top
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
tapped
at
the
door
,
and
a
little
shrill
voice
inside
said
,
"
We
are
locked
in
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Blinder
's
got
the
key
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
applied
the
key
on
hearing
this
and
opened
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
poor
room
with
a
sloping
ceiling
and
containing
very
little
furniture
was
a
mite
of
a
boy
,
some
five
or
six
years
old
,
nursing
and
hushing
a
heavy
child
of
eighteen
months
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
fire
,
though
the
weather
was
cold
;
both
children
were
wrapped
in
some
poor
shawls
and
tippets
as
a
substitute
.
 
<EOS>
Their
clothing
was
not
so
warm
,
however
,
but
that
their
noses
looked
red
and
pinched
and
their
small
figures
shrunken
as
the
boy
walked
up
and
down
nursing
and
hushing
the
child
with
its
head
on
his
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
has
locked
you
up
here
alone
?
<EOS>
"
we
naturally
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charley
,
"
said
the
boy
,
standing
still
to
gaze
at
us
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Charley
your
brother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
my
sister
,
Charlotte
.
 
<EOS>
Father
called
her
Charley
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
there
any
more
of
you
besides
Charley
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Me
,
"
said
the
boy
,
"
and
Emma
,
"
patting
the
limp
bonnet
of
the
child
he
was
nursing
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
Charley
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Charley
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Out
a
-
washing
,
"
said
the
boy
,
beginning
to
walk
up
and
down
again
and
taking
the
nankeen
bonnet
much
too
near
the
bedstead
by
trying
to
gaze
at
us
at
the
same
time
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
looking
at
one
another
and
at
these
two
children
when
there
came
into
the
room
a
very
little
girl
,
childish
in
figure
but
shrewd
and
older
-
looking
in
the
face
---
pretty
-
faced
too
---
wearing
a
womanly
sort
of
bonnet
much
too
large
for
her
and
drying
her
bare
arms
on
a
womanly
sort
of
apron
.
 
<EOS>
Her
fingers
were
white
and
wrinkled
with
washing
,
and
the
soap
-
suds
were
yet
smoking
which
she
wiped
off
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
But
for
this
,
she
might
have
been
a
child
playing
at
washing
and
imitating
a
poor
working
-
woman
with
a
quick
observation
of
the
truth
.
   
<EOS>
She
had
come
running
from
some
place
in
the
neighbourhood
and
had
made
all
the
haste
she
could
.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
,
though
she
was
very
light
,
she
was
out
of
breath
and
could
not
speak
at
first
,
as
she
stood
panting
,
and
wiping
her
arms
,
and
looking
quietly
at
us
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
here
's
Charley
!
"
said
the
boy
.
   
<EOS>
The
child
he
was
nursing
stretched
forth
its
arms
and
cried
out
to
be
taken
by
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
girl
took
it
,
in
a
womanly
sort
of
manner
belonging
to
the
apron
and
the
bonnet
,
and
stood
looking
at
us
over
the
burden
that
clung
to
her
most
affectionately
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
possible
,
"
whispered
my
guardian
as
we
put
a
chair
for
the
little
creature
and
got
her
to
sit
down
with
her
load
,
the
boy
keeping
close
to
her
,
holding
to
her
apron
,
"
that
this
child
works
for
the
rest
?
 
<EOS>
Look
at
this
!
 
<EOS>
For
God
's
sake
,
look
at
this
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
thing
to
look
at
.
 
<EOS>
The
three
children
close
together
,
and
two
of
them
relying
solely
on
the
third
,
and
the
third
so
young
and
yet
with
an
air
of
age
and
steadiness
that
sat
so
strangely
on
the
childish
figure
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charley
,
Charley
!
"
said
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
old
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Over
thirteen
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
child
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
What
a
great
age
,
"
said
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
great
age
,
Charley
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
can
not
describe
the
tenderness
with
which
he
spoke
to
her
,
half
playfully
yet
all
the
more
compassionately
and
mournfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
do
you
live
alone
here
with
these
babies
,
Charley
?
<EOS>
"
said
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
child
,
looking
up
into
his
face
with
perfect
confidence
,
"
since
father
died
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
how
do
you
live
,
Charley
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
Charley
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
turning
his
face
away
for
a
moment
,
"
how
do
you
live
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Since
father
died
,
sir
,
I
've
gone
out
to
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
out
washing
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
God
help
you
,
Charley
!
"
said
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
tall
enough
to
reach
the
tub
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
pattens
I
am
,
sir
,
"
she
said
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
got
a
high
pair
as
belonged
to
mother
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
when
did
mother
die
?
 
<EOS>
Poor
mother
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
died
just
after
Emma
was
born
,
"
said
the
child
,
glancing
at
the
face
upon
her
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
father
said
I
was
to
be
as
good
a
mother
to
her
as
I
could
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
I
tried
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
I
worked
at
home
and
did
cleaning
and
nursing
and
washing
for
a
long
time
before
I
began
to
go
out
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
's
how
I
know
how
;
do
n't
you
see
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
do
you
often
go
out
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
often
as
I
can
,
"
said
Charley
,
opening

and

,
"
because
of
earning
sixpences
and
shillings
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
do
you
always
lock
the
babies
up
when
you
go
out
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
keep
'em
safe
,
sir
,
do
n't
you
see
?
"
said
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Blinder
comes
up
now
and
then
,
and
Mr
Gridley
comes
up
sometimes
,
and
perhaps
I
can
run
in
sometimes
,
and
they
can
play
you
know
,
and
Tom
an't
afraid
of
being
locked
up
,
are
you
,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
-
o
!
"
said
Tom
stoutly
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
it
comes
on
dark
,
the
lamps
are
lighted
down
in
the
court
,
and
they
show
up
here
quite
bright
---
almost
quite
bright
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
they
,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Charley
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
almost
quite
bright
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
he
's
as
good
as
gold
,
"
said
the
little
creature
---
<EOS>
Oh
,
in
such
a
motherly
,
womanly
way
!
 
<EOS>
"
And
when
Emma
's
tired
,
he
puts
her
to

.
 
<EOS>
And
when
he
's
tired
he
goes
to
bed

.
 
<EOS>
And
when
I
come
home
and
light
the
candle
and
has
a
bit

supper
,
he
sits
up
again
and
has
it
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
Charley
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
I
do
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
either
in
this
glimpse
of
the
great
pleasure
of
his
life
or
in
gratitude
and
love
for
Charley
,
who
was
all
in
all
to
him
,
he
laid
his
face
among
the
scanty
folds
of
her
frock
and
passed
from
laughing
into
crying
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
time
since
our
entry
that
a
tear
had
been
shed
among
these
children
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
orphan
girl
had
spoken
of
their
father
and
their
mother
as
if
all
that
sorrow
were
subdued
by
the
necessity
of
taking
courage
,
and
by
her
childish
importance
in
being
able
to
work
,
and
by
her
bustling
busy
way
.
 
<EOS>
But
now
,
when
Tom
cried
,
although
she
sat
quite
tranquil
,
looking
quietly
at
us
,
and
did
not
by
any
movement
disturb
a
hair
of
the
head
of
either
of
her
little
charges
,
I
saw
two
silent
tears
fall
down
her
face
.
   
<EOS>
I
stood
at
the
window
with
Ada
,
pretending
to
look
at
the
housetops
,
and
the
blackened
stack
of
chimneys
,
and
the
poor

,
and
the
birds
in
little
cages
belonging
to
the
neighbours
,
when
I
found
that
Mrs
Blinder
,
from

shop
below
,
had
come
in
(
perhaps
it
had
taken
her
all
this

to
get

)
and
was
talking
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
much
to
forgive
'em
the
rent
,
sir
,
"
she
said
;
"
who
could
take
it
from
them
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
said
my
guardian
to
us
two
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
enough
that
the
time
will
come
when
this
good
woman
will
find
that
it
WAS
much
,
and
that
forasmuch
as
she
did
it
unto
the
least

---
This
child
,
"
he
added
after

,
"
could
she
possibly

this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
sir
,
I
think
she
might
,
"
said
Mrs
Blinder
,
getting
her
heavy

by

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
as
handy
as
it
's
possible
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
,
sir
,
<EOS>
the
way
she
tended
them
two
children
after
the
mother
died
was
the
talk
of
the
yard
!
 
<EOS>
And
it
was
a
wonder
to
see
her
with
him
after
he
was
took
ill
,
it
really
was
!
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Blinder
,
"
he
said
to
me
the
very
last
<EOS>
he
spoke
---
he
was
lying
there
 
---
"
Mrs
Blinder
,
whatever
my
calling
may
have
been
,
I
see
a
angel
sitting
in
this
room
last
night
along
with
my
child
,
and
I
trust
her
to
Our
Father
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
He
had
no
other
calling
?
"
said
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mrs
Blinder
,
"
he
was
nothing
but
a
follerers
.
<EOS>
When
he
first
came
to
lodge
here
,
I
did
n't
know
what
he
was
,
and
I
confess
that
when
I
found

I
gave
him
notice
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
n't
liked
in
the
yard
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
n't
approved
by
the
other
lodgers
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
NOT
a
genteel
calling
,
"
said
Mrs
Blinder
,
"
and
most
people
do

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gridley
objected
to
it
very
strong
,
and
he
is
a
good
lodger
,
though
his
temper
has
been
hard
tried
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
you
gave
him

?
"
said
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
gave
him
notice
,
"
said
Mrs
Blinder
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
really
when
the
time
came
,
and
I
knew
no
other
ill
of
him
,
I
was
in

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
punctual
and

;
he
did
what

,

,
"
said
Mrs
Blinder
,
unconsciously

Mr
Skimpole
with

,
"
and
it
's
something
in
this
world
even

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So

kept

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
said
that
if
he
could
arrange
with
Mr
Gridley
,
I
could
arrange
it
with
the
other
lodgers
and
should
not
so
much
mind
its
being
liked
or

in
the

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gridley
gave
his
consent
gruff
---
but
gave
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
gruff
with
him
,
but
he
has
been
kind
to
the
children
since
.
 
<EOS>
A
person
is
never
known
till
a
person
is
proved
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have
many
people
been
kind
to
the
children
?
"
asked
Mr
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
the
whole
,
not
so
bad
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Blinder
;
"
but
certainly
not
so
many
as
would
have
been
if
their
father
's
calling
had
been
different
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Coavins
gave
a
guinea
,
and
the
follerers
made
up
a
little
purse
.
 
<EOS>
Some
neighbours
in
the
yard
that
had
always
joked
and
tapped
their
shoulders
when
he
went
by
came
forward
with
a
little
subscription
,
and
---
in
general
---
not
so
bad
.
<EOS>
Similarly
with
Charlotte
.
 
<EOS>
Some
people
wo
n't
employ
her
because
she
was
a
follerer
's
child
;
some
people
that
do
employ
her
cast
it
at
her
;
some
make
a
merit
of
having
her
to
work
for
them
,
with
that
and
all
her
draw
-
backs
upon
her
,
and
perhaps
pay
her
less
and
put
upon
her
more
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
's
patienter
than
others
would
be
,
and
is
clever
too
,
and
always
willing
,
up
to
the
full
mark
of
her
strength
and
over
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
should
say
,
in
general
,
not
so
bad
,
sir
,
but
might
be
better
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Blinder
sat
down
to
give
herself
a
more
favourable
opportunity
of
recovering
her
breath
,
exhausted
anew
by
so
much
talking
before
it
was
fully
restored
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
was
turning
to
speak
to
us
when
his
attention
was
attracted
by
the
abrupt
entrance
into
the
room
of
the
Mr
Gridley
who
had
been
mentioned
and
whom
we
had
seen
on
our

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
you
may
be
doing
here
,
ladies
and
gentlemen
,
"
he
said
,
as
if
he
resented
our
presence
,
"
<EOS>
but
you
'll
excuse
my
coming
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
come
in
to
stare
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
Charley
!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
Tom
!
<EOS>
Well
,
little
one
!
 
<EOS>
How
is
it
with
us
all
to
-
day
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
bent
over
the
group
in
a
caressing
way
and
clearly
was
regarded
as
a
friend
by
the
children
,
though
his
face
retained
its
stern
character
and
his
manner
to
us
was
as
rude
as
it
could
be
.
 
<EOS>
My
guardian
noticed
it
and
respected
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
one
,
surely
,
would
come
here
to
stare
about
him
,
"
he
said
mildly
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
be
so
,
sir
,
may
be
so
,
"
returned
the
other
,
taking
Tom
upon
his
knee
and
waving
him
off
impatiently
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
argue
with
ladies
and
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
enough
of
arguing
to
last
one
man
his
life
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
sufficient
reason
,
I
dare
say
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
for
being
chafed
and
irritated
---
<EOS>
"
   
"
There
again
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
man
,
becoming
violently
angry
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
of
a
quarrelsome
temper
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
irascible
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
polite
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
very
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Gridley
,
putting
down
the
child
and
going
up
to
him
as
if
he
meant
to
strike
him
,
"
do
you
know
anything
of
Courts
of
Equity
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
do
,
to
my
sorrow
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
your
sorrow
?
"
said
the
man
,
pausing
in
his
wrath
.
 
<EOS>
"
if
so
,
I
beg
your
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
polite
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
!
<EOS>
Sir
,
"
with
renewed
violence
,
"
I
have
been
dragged
for
five
and
twenty
years
over
burning
iron
,
and
I
have
lost
the
habit
of
treading
upon
velvet
.
 
<EOS>
Go
into
the
Court
of
Chancery
yonder
and
ask
what
is
one
of
the
standing
jokes
that
brighten
up
their
business
sometimes
,
and
they
will
tell
you
that
the
best
joke
they
have
is
the
man
from
Shropshire
.
 
<EOS>
I
,
"
he
said
,
beating
one
hand
on
the
other
passionately
,
"
am
the
man
from
Shropshire
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
I
and
my
family
have
also
had
the
honour
of
furnishing
some
entertainment
in
the
same
grave
place
,
"
said
my
guardian
composedly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
have
heard
my
name
---
Jarndyce
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
said
Gridley
with
a
rough
sort
of
salutation
,
"
you
bear
your
wrongs
more
quietly
than
I
can
bear
mine
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
that
,
I
tell
you
---
and
I
tell
this
gentleman
,
and
these
young
ladies
,
if
they
are
friends
of
yours
---
that
if
I
took
my
wrongs
in
any
other
way
,
I
should
be
driven
mad
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
only
by
resenting
them
,
and
by
revenging
them
in
my
mind
,
and
by
angrily
demanding
the
justice
I
never
get
,
that
I
am
able
to
keep
my
wits
together
.
<EOS>
It
is
only
that
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
speaking
in
a
homely
,
rustic
way
and
with
great
vehemence
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
tell
me
that
I
over
-
excite
myself
.
<EOS>
I
answer
that
it
's
in
my
nature
to
do
it
,
under
wrong
,
and
I
must
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
between
doing
it
,
and
sinking
into
the
smiling
state
of
the
poor
little
mad
woman
that
haunts
the
court
.
<EOS>
If
I
was
once
to
sit
down
under
it
,
I
should
become
imbecile
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
passion
and
heat
in
which
he
was
,
and
the
manner
in
which
his
face
worked
,
and
the
violent
gestures
with
which
he
accompanied
what
he
said
,
were
most
painful
to
see
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
he
said
,
"
consider
my
case
.
 
<EOS>
As
true
as
there
is
a
heaven
above
us
,
this
is
my
case
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
one
of
two
brothers
.
 
<EOS>
My
father
(
a
farmer
)
made
a
will
and
left
his
farm
and
stock
and
so
forth
to
my
mother
for
her
life
.
 
<EOS>
After
my
mother
's

,
all

to
come

me
except
a

of
three

pounds
that
I
was

.
 
<EOS>
My
mother
died
.
 
<EOS>
My
brother
some

afterwards
claimed

.
 
<EOS>
I
and

.
 
<EOS>
Now
mind
!
 
<EOS>
That

,

.
<EOS>
No

;

<EOS>

my

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Seventeen

!
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

(
may

!
)
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
---

<EOS>

<EOS>
My

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
Here

,

There

<EOS>

Chapter

<EOS>
Tom

<EOS>
My

<EOS>

It

<EOS>

;

.
   
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
Outside
,
the

,

,

<EOS>
Inside
,
his
forefathers
,
looking
on
him
from
the
walls
,
say
,
"
Each
of
us
was
a
passing
reality
here
and
left
this
coloured

of
himself
and

into

as
dreamy
as

of
the
rooks
now

you
to
rest
,
"
and
hear

too
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
is
very
great
this
day
.
 
<EOS>
And
woe
to
Boythorn
or
other
daring
wight
who
shall
presumptuously
contest
an
inch
with
him
!
   
<EOS>
My
Lady
is
at
present
represented
,
near
Sir
Leicester
,
by
her
portrait
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
flitted
away
to
town
,
with
no
intention
of
remaining
there
,
and
will
soon
flit
hither
again
,
to
the
confusion
of
the
fashionable
intelligence
.
 
<EOS>
The
house
in
town
is
not
prepared
for
her
reception
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
muffled
and
dreary
.
 
<EOS>
Only
one
Mercury
in
powder
gapes
disconsolate
at
the
hall
-
window
;
and
he
mentioned
last
night
to
another
Mercury
of
his

,
also
accustomed
to
good
society
,
that
if
that

thing
was
to
last
---
which
it
could
n't
,
for
a
man
of
his
spirits
could
n't

,
and
a

his
figure
could
n't

expected

---
there
would
be
no
resource
for
him
,
upon
his
honour
,
but
to
cut
his

!
   
<EOS>
What

the

in

,

,

,

of
Jo
the

,
who

?
 
<EOS>
What

between

of
this

who
from
opposite

of
great

have
,

,

!
   
<EOS>
Jo
sweeps
his
crossing
all
day
long
,
unconscious
of
the
link
,
if
any
link
there
be
.
 
<EOS>
He
sums
up
his
mental
condition
when
asked
a
question
by
replying
that
he
"
do
n't
know
nothink
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
knows
that
it
's
hard
to
keep
the
mud
off
the
crossing
in
dirty
weather
,
and
harder
still
to
live
by

.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
taught
him
even
that
much
;
he
found
it
out
.
   
<EOS>
Jo
lives
---
that
is
to
say
<EOS>
,
Jo
has
not
yet
died
---
in
a
ruinous
place
known
to
the
like
of
him
by
the
name
of
Tom
-
all
-
Alone
's
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
black
,
dilapidated
street
,
avoided
by
all
decent
people
,
where
the
crazy
houses
were
seized
upon
,
when
their
decay
was
far
advanced
,
by
some
bold
vagrants
who
after
establishing
their
own

took
to

out
in

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
these
tumbling
tenements
contain
,
by
night
,
a
swarm
of
misery
.
 
<EOS>
As
on
the
ruined
human
wretch
vermin
parasites
appear
,
so
these
ruined
shelters
have
bred
a
crowd
of
foul
existence
that
crawls
in
and
out
of
gaps
in
walls
and
boards
;
and
coils
itself
to
sleep
,
in
maggot

,
where
the
rain
drips
in
;
and
comes
and

,
fetching
and

fever
and
sowing
more
evil
in

than
Lord
Coodle
,
and
Sir
Thomas
Doodle
,
and

,

,
down

,

set

---
though
born

.
   
<EOS>
Twice

,
like

mine
,
in
Tom
-
all
-
Alone
's
;
and

.
 
<EOS>
These

have
made

and
have

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
As

,
the

in
Tom
-
all
-
Alone
's
may

expected

.
   
<EOS>
This
desirable
property
is
in
Chancery
,

.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
an
insult
to
the

of
any
man

.
 
<EOS>
Whether
"
Tom
"

Jarndyce

Jarndyce
,

.
<EOS>
Certainly
Jo
do

.
   
<EOS>
"
For
I
do
n't
,
"

Jo
,
"
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
must
be
a
strange
state
to
be
like
Jo
!
 
<EOS>
To
shuffle
through
the

,
unfamiliar

the
shapes
,
and
in
utter
darkness
as
to
the
meaning
,
of
those

,
so

over

,
and

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
To
see

,
and
to

,

letters
,
and
not

least

of
all
that

---
to
be
,
to
every

it
,
stone

!
<EOS>
It
must

very

to

the
good
company
going
to
the

on
Sundays
,
with
their

in

,
and
to

(
for

Jo
DOES
think

)
what

all

,
and
if
it

anything

,
how

?
 
<EOS>
To
be
hustled
,
and

,
and
moved
on
;
and
really
to
feel
that
it
would

,

,

I
AM
here
somehow
,

,
and
everybody
overlooked

!
 
<EOS>
It
must

,
not

I

(
as

!
 
<EOS>
To

,

,

<EOS>
Jo
's

,

,

<EOS>

,

!
 
<EOS>
His

is

;
his

,
the

.
   
<EOS>
Jo
comes

of
Tom
-
all
-

's
,

in

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
His

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
admires

of
the

and

what

's
all
about
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
no
idea
,
poor
wretch
,

the

of
a

in
the
Pacific
or

to

.
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
The
town
awakes
<EOS>
;

tee
-

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Jo
and
the
other
lower

get
on
in
the
unintelligible

as

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
market
-

.
 
<EOS>
The
blinded
oxen
,
over
-

,
over
-

,
never

,

and
are

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Very
like
Jo
and
his

;
very
,

like
!
   
<EOS>
A

of
music
comes

plays
.
 
<EOS>
Jo
listens
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
So
does
a
dog
 
---
a
drover
's
dog
,
waiting
for
his
master
outside
a
butcher
's
shop
,
and
evidently
thinking
about
those
sheep
he
has
had
upon

for
some
hours
and
is
happily
rid

.
 
<EOS>
He
seems
perplexed
respecting
three
or
four
,
ca
n't
remember
where
he
left

,
looks
up
and
down

street
as
half

to
see

astray
,
suddenly
pricks
up

ears
and
remembers
all
about

.
 
<EOS>
A
thoroughly
vagabond
dog
,
accustomed
to
low
company
and
public
-
houses
;
a
terrific
dog
to
sheep
,
ready
at

scamper
over

backs
and

of
their

;
but
an
educated
,

,
developed
dog
who
has

and
knows

.
 
<EOS>
He
and
Jo
listen

the

,
probably
with
much

same
amount
of
animal
satisfaction
;
likewise
as
to
awakened

,

,
or

,

to
things
beyond

,

upon

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
otherwise
,
how
far
above

human
listener
is
the

!
   
<EOS>
Turn
that
dog
's
descendants
wild
,
like
Jo
,
and
in

very
few
years
they
will
so
degenerate
that
they
will

---
but

.
   
<EOS>
The
day
changes
as

.
 
<EOS>
Jo
fights

among

,
the

,

,

,

unsavoury

Tom
-

-
Alone
's
.
 
<EOS>
Twilight

;

;
the

,
with

,

.
 
<EOS>
A
wretched
evening
is
beginning
to
close
in
.
   
<EOS>
In
his
chambers
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
sits
meditating
an

to
the
nearest

to
-
morrow
morning
for

.
 
<EOS>
Gridley
,
a
disappointed
suitor
,
has
been
here
to
-
day
and
has

alarming
.
<EOS>
We
are
not

in

,
and
that
ill

conditioned

shall

.
 
<EOS>
From

,

,

one

Roman
upside

,

of
Samson
(

,

an

)

.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
for
such
no

,
look

of

?
 
<EOS>
Is
the
hand
not
always
pointing
there
?
 
<EOS>
So
he
does
not
look
out
of
window
.
   
<EOS>
And
if
he
did
,
what
would
it
be
to
see
a
woman
going

?
 
<EOS>
There
are
women
enough
in
the
world
<EOS>
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn

---
<EOS>
too

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

to
see
a
woman
going

,

?
 
<EOS>
They
are
all
secret
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
knows

.
   
<EOS>
But
they
are
not
all
like
the
woman
who
now
leaves
him

his
house
behind
,
between
whose
plain

.
 
<EOS>
She
should
be
an
upper
servant
by
her
attire
,
yet
in
her
air
and
step
,
though
both
are
hurried
and
assumed
---
as
far
as
she
can
assume
in
the
muddy

,
which
she
treads
with
an
unaccustomed

---
she
is
a
lady
.
<EOS>
Her
face
is
veiled
,
and
still
she
sufficiently
betrays
herself
to
make
more
than
one
of
those
who
pass
her
look
round

.
   
<EOS>
She
never
turns
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
or
servant
,
she
has
a
purpose
in
her
and
can
follow

.
 
<EOS>
She
never

head
until
she

to
the
crossing
where
Jo
plies

.
 
<EOS>
He
crosses
with

.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
she

until

.
 
<EOS>
Then

,
"
Come
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
Jo

.
   
<EOS>
"
Are

the
boy
I
've

of
in
the

?
"
<EOS>
she

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

,

,
"
nothink

.
 
<EOS>
I

nothink

nothink

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

---
<EOS>
where

<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
   
"

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
At

.

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
The

-

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

;

.

"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
17
.
<EOS>
Esther
's
Narrative
 
Richard
very
often
came
to
see
us
while
we
remained
in
London
(
though
he
soon
failed
in
his
letter
-
writing
)
,
and
with
his
quick
abilities
,
his
good
spirits
,
his
good
temper
,
his
gaiety
and
freshness
,
was
always
delightful
.
 
<EOS>
But
though
I
liked
him
more
and
more
the
better
I
knew
him
,
I
still
felt
more
and
more
how
much
it
was
to
be
regretted
that
he
had
been
educated
in
no
habits
of
application
and
concentration
.
 
<EOS>
The
system
which
had
addressed
him
in
exactly
the
same
manner
as
it
had
addressed
hundreds
of
other
boys
,
all
varying
in
character
and
capacity
,
had
enabled
him
to
dash
through
his
tasks
,
always
with
fair
credit
and
often
with
distinction
,
but
in
a
fitful
,
dazzling
way
that
had
confirmed
his
reliance
on
those
very
qualities
in
himself
which
it
had
been
most
desirable
to
direct
and
train
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
good
qualities
,
without
which
no
high
place
can
be
meritoriously
won
,
but
like
fire
and
water
,
though
excellent
servants
,
they
were
very
bad
masters
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
had
been
under
Richard
's
direction
,
they
would
have
been
his
friends
;
but
Richard
being
under
their
direction
,
they
became
his
enemies
.
   
<EOS>
I
write
down
these
opinions
not
because
I
believe
that
this
or
any
other
thing
was
so
because
I
thought
so
,
but
only
because
I
did
think
so
<EOS>
and
I
want
to
be
quite
candid
about
all
I
thought
and
did
.
<EOS>
These
were
my
thoughts
about
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
often
observed
besides
how
right
my
guardian
was
in
what
he
had
said
,
and
that
the
uncertainties
and
delays
of
the
Chancery
suit
had
imparted
to
his
nature
something
of
the
careless
spirit
of
a
gamester
who
felt
that
he
was
part
of
a
great
gaming
system
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
and
Mrs
Bayham
Badger
coming
one
afternoon
when
my
guardian
was
not
at
home
,
in
the
course
of
conversation
I
naturally
inquired
after
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Mr
Carstone
,
"
said
Mrs
Badger
,
"
is
very
well
and
is
,
I
assure
you
,
a
great
acquisition
to
our

.
 
<EOS>
Captain
Swosser
used
to
say
of

that
I
was
always
better
than
land
a
-
head
and
a

<EOS>
a
-
starn
to

's
mess
when
the
purser
's
junk
had
become
as

fore
-
topsel
weather

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
his
naval
way
of
mentioning
generally
that
I
was
an

any

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
But

---

wo

mention

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
Ada

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

,

,
"
---
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Because

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

still

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dears
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

on

dear

,

.
 
<EOS>
After

,

,

under

's

.
 
<EOS>
YOU
never
heard

called
the
young

,
my
dears
,
and
<EOS>
probably
wonld
not
