to
their

their
weekly

,
but

otherwise

,
for
blue
water
has
been

to
me
,
and
I
have

.
 
<EOS>
Again
,
with
Professor
Dingo
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
man
of
European
reputation
,
"
murmured

Badger
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
lost

dear
first
and

the
wife
of

dear
second
,
"
said

Badger
,
speaking

her

as

,
"
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

---

<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>

)

<EOS>

<EOS>
Richard

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
I

he

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nine

,

,
"
he
said

,
"
have
passed
since

,

that

.
 
<EOS>
It
was

me
(
as

)
,

to

mine
to

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,
in

such

.
 
<EOS>
It

that
the

bred
her
in

from
her

,
had

all

,

that

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

to

,

,

what

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
early

,

,

<EOS>
I

the
little
creature
,
in
her
darkened
life
,
and
replied
to
the
letter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
took
his
hand
and
kissed
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
laid
the
injunction
on
me
that
I
should
never
propose
to
see
the
writer
,
who
had
long
been
estranged
from
all
intercourse
with
the
world
,
but
who
would
see
a
confidential
agent
if
I
would
appoint
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
accredited
Mr
Kenge
.
 
<EOS>
The
lady
said
,
of
her
own
accord
and
not
of
his
seeking
,
that
her
name
was
an
assumed
one
.
<EOS>
That
she
was
,
if
there
were
any
ties
of
blood
in
such
a
case
,
the
child
's
aunt
.
 
<EOS>
That
more
than
this
<EOS>
she
would
never
<EOS>
(
and
he
was
well
persuaded
of
the
steadfastness
of
her
resolution
)
for
any
human
consideration
disclose
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
,
I
have
told
you
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
held
his
hand
for
a
little
while
in
mine
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
saw
my
ward
oftener
than
she
saw
me
,
"
he
added
,
cheerily
making
light
of
it
,
"
and
I
always
knew
she
was
beloved
,
useful
,
and
happy
.
<EOS>
She
repays
me
twenty
-
thousandfold
,
and
twenty
more
to
that
,
every
hour
in
every
day
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
oftener
still
,
"
said
I
,
"
she
blesses
the
guardian
who
is
a
father
to
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
the
word
father
,
I
saw
his
former
trouble
come
into
his
face
.
<EOS>
He
subdued
it
as
before
,
and
it
was
gone
in
an
instant
;
but
it
had
been
there
<EOS>
and
it
had
come
so
swiftly
upon
my
words
that
I
felt
as
if
they
had
given
him
a
shock
.
 
<EOS>
I
again
inwardly
repeated
,
wondering
,
"
That
I
could
readily
understand
.
 
<EOS>
None
that
I
could
readily
understand
!
"
 
<EOS>
No
,
it
was
true
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
understand
it
.
<EOS>
Not
for
many
and
many
a
day
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
a
fatherly
good
night
,
my
dear
,
"
said
he
,
kissing
me
on
the
forehead
,
"
and
so
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
These
are
late
hours
for
working
and
thinking
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
that
for
all
of
us
,
all
day
long
,
little
housekeeper
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
neither
worked
nor
thought
any
more
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
opened
my
grateful
heart
to
heaven
in
thankfulness
for
its
providence
to
me
and
its
care
of
me
,
and
fell
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
a
visitor
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Allan
Woodcourt
came
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
to
take
leave
of
us
;
he
had
settled
to
do
so
beforehand
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
going
to
China
and
to
India
as
a
surgeon
on
board
ship
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
to
be
away
a
long
,
long
time
.
   
<EOS>
I
believe
---
<EOS>
at
least
I
know
---
that
he
was
not
rich
.
 
<EOS>
All
his
widowed
mother
could
spare
had
been
spent
in
qualifying
him
for
his
profession
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
lucrative
to
a
young
practitioner
,
with
very
little
influence
in
London
;
and
although
he
was
,
night
and
day
,
at
the
service
of
numbers
of
poor
people
and
did
wonders
of
gentleness
and
skill
for
them
,
he
gained
very
little
by
it
in
money
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
seven
years
older
than
I.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
I
need
mention
it
,
for
it
hardly
seems
to
belong
to
anything
.
   
<EOS>
I
think
---
<EOS>
I
mean
,
he
told
us
---
that
he
had
been
in
practice
three
or
four
years
and
that
if
he
could
have
hoped
to
contend
through
three
or
four
more
,
he
would
not
have
made
the
voyage
on
which
he
was
bound
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
no
fortune
or
private
means
,
and
so
he
was
going
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
to
see
us
several
times
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
We
thought
it
a
pity
he
should
go
away
.
 
<EOS>
Because
he
was
distinguished
in
his
art
among
those
who
knew
it
best
,
and
some
of
the
greatest
men
belonging
to
it
had
a
high
opinion
of
him
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
came
to
bid
us
good
-
bye
,
he
brought
his
mother
with
him
for
the
first
time
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
pretty
old
lady
,
with
bright
black
eyes
,
but
she
seemed
proud
.
 
<EOS>
She
came
from
Wales
and
had
had
,
a
long
time
ago
,
an
eminent
person
for
an
ancestor
,
of
the
name
of
Morgan
ap
-
Kerrig
---
of
some
place
that
sounded
like
Gimlet
---
who
was
the
most
illustrious
person
that
ever
was
known
and
all
of
whose
relations
were
a
sort
of
royal
family
.
 
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
have
passed
his
life
in
always
getting
up
into
mountains
and
fighting
somebody
;
and
a
bard
whose
name
sounded
like
Crumlinwallinwer
had
sung
his
praises
in
a
piece
which
was
called
,
as
nearly
as
I
could
catch
it
,
Mewlinnwillinwodd
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Woodcourt
,
after
expatiating
to
us
on
the
fame
of
her
great
kinsman
,
said
that
no
doubt
wherever
her
son
Allan
went
he
would
remember
his
pedigree
and
would
on
no
account
form
an
alliance
below
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
told
him
that
there
were
many
handsome
English
ladies
in
India
who
went
out
on
speculation
,
and
that
there
were
some
to
be
picked
up
with
property
,
but
that
neither
charms
nor
wealth
would
suffice
for
the
descendant
from
such
a
line
without
birth
,
which
must
ever
be
the
first
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
She
talked
so
much
about
birth
that
for
a
moment
<EOS>
I
half
fancied
,
and
with
pain
---
 
<EOS>
But
what
an
idle
fancy
to
suppose
that
she
could
think
or
care
what
MINE
was
!
   
<EOS>
Mr
Woodcourt
seemed
a
little
distressed
by
her
prolixity
,
but
he
was
too
considerate
to
let
her
see
it
and
contrived
delicately
to
bring
the
conversation
round
to
making
his
acknowledgments
to
my
guardian
for
his

and
for
the
very
happy
hours
---
he
called
them
the
very
happy
hours
---
he
had
passed
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
The
recollection
of
them
,
he
said
,
would
go
with
him
wherever
he
went
and
would
be
always
treasured
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
we
gave
him
our
hands
,
one
after
another
---
at
least
,
they
did
---
<EOS>
and
I
did
;
and
so
he
put
his
lips
to
Ada
's
hand
---
and
to
mine
;
and
<EOS>
so
he
went
away
upon
his
long
,
long

!
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
busy
indeed
all
day
and
wrote
directions
home
to
the
servants
,
and
wrote
notes
for
my
guardian
,
and
dusted
his
books
and
papers
,
and
jingled
my
housekeeping
keys
a
good
deal
,
one
way
and
another
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
still
busy
between
the
lights
,
singing
and
working
by
the
window
,
when
who
should
come
in
<EOS>
but
Caddy
,
whom

had
no

of

!
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Caddy
,
my
dear
,
"
said
I
,
"
what
beautiful
flowers
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
such
an
exquisite
little
nosegay
in
her

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
think
so
,
Esther
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
the

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Prince
,
my
dear
?
"
said
I
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
answered
Caddy
,

and

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
Prince
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
Caddy
!
"
said

<EOS>
"
You
must
have
two
lovers
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
 
<EOS>
Do
they
look
like
that
sort

thing
?
"
said
Caddy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
they
look
like
that
sort
of
thing
?
<EOS>
"
I
repeated
,
pinching
her
cheek
.
   
<EOS>
Caddy
only
laughed
in
return
,
and
telling
me
that
she
had
come
for
half
an
hour
,
at
the

of
which
time
Prince
would
be
waiting

her
at

,
sat

with
me
and
Ada
in

,
every

and
then
handing

the
flowers
again
or
trying
how
they
looked
against
my

.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
when
she
was
going
,
she
took
me
into
my
room
and
put
them
in
my
dress
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
me
?
"
said
I
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
you
,
"
said
Caddy
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
They
were
left
behind
by
somebody
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Left
behind
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
poor
Miss
Flite
's
,
"
said
Caddy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Somebody
who
has
been
very
good
to
her
was
hurrying
away
an
hour
ago
to
join
a
ship
and
left
these
flowers
behind
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
take
them
out
.
 
<EOS>
Let
the
pretty
little
things
lie
here
,
"
said
Caddy
,
adjusting

with
a

,
"
because
I
was
present
myself
,
and
I
should
n't
wonder
if
somebody
left

on

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
they
look
like
that
sort
of
thing
?
"
<EOS>
said
Ada
,
coming

behind

and
clasping

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
indeed
they
do
,
Dame
Durden
!
 
<EOS>
They
look
very
,
very
like
that
sort
of
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
very
like
it
indeed
,
my
dear
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
18
.
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
so
easy
as
it
had
appeared
at
first
to
arrange
for
Richard
's
making
a
trial
of
Mr
Kenge
's
office
.
 
<EOS>
Richard
himself
was
the
chief
impediment
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
had
it
in
his
power
to
leave
Mr
Badger
at
any
moment
,
he
began
to
doubt
whether
he
wanted
to
leave
him
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't
know
,
he
said
,
really
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
n't
a
bad
profession
;
he
could
n't
assert
that
he
disliked
it
;
perhaps
he
liked
it
as
well
as
he
liked
any
other
---
suppose
he
gave
it
one
more
chance
!
 
<EOS>
Upon
that
,
he
shut
himself
up
for
a
few
weeks
with
some
books
and
some
bones
and
seemed
to
acquire
a
considerable
fund
of
information
with
great
rapidity
.
 
<EOS>
His
fervour
,
after
lasting
about
a
month
,
began
to
cool
,
and
when
it
was
quite
cooled
,
began
to
grow
warm
again
.
 
<EOS>
His
vacillations
between
law
and
medicine
lasted
so
long
that
midsummer
arrived
before
he
finally
separated
from
Mr
Badger
and
entered
on
an
experimental
course
of
Messrs.
Kenge
and
Carboy
.
 
<EOS>
For
all
his
waywardness
,
he
took
great
credit
to
himself
as
being
determined
to
be
in
earnest
"
this
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
was
so
good
-
natured
throughout
,
and
in
such
high
spirits
,
and
so
fond
of
Ada
,
that
it
was
very
difficult
indeed
to
be
otherwise
than
pleased
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
who
,
I
may
mention
,
found
the
wind
much
given
,
during
this
period
,
to
stick
in
the
east
;
"
As
to
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
Richard
would
say
to
me
,
"
he
is
the
finest
fellow
in
the
world
,
Esther
!
 
<EOS>
I
must
be
particularly
careful
,
if
it
were
only
for
his
satisfaction
,
to
take
myself
well
to
task
and
have
a
regular
wind
-
up
of
this
business
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
idea
of
his
taking
himself
well
to
task
,
with
that
laughing
face
and
heedless
manner
and
with
a
fancy
that
everything
could
catch
and
nothing
could
hold
,
was
ludicrously
anomalous
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
he
told
us
between
-
whiles
that
he
was
doing
it
to
such
an
extent
that
he
wondered
his
hair
did
n't
turn
grey
.
 
<EOS>
His
regular
wind
-
up
of
the
business
was
(
as
I
have
said
)
that
he
went
to
Mr
Kenge
's
about
midsummer
to
try
how
he
liked
it
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
he
was
,
in
money
affairs
,
what
I
have
described
him
in
a
former
illustration
---
generous
,
profuse
,
wildly
careless
,
but
fully
persuaded
that
he
was
rather
calculating
and
prudent
.
 
<EOS>
I
happened
to
say
to
Ada
,
in
his
presence
,
half
jestingly
,
half
seriously
,
about
the
time
of
his
going
to
Mr
Kenge
's
,
that
he
needed
to
have
Fortunatus
'
purse
,
he
made
so
light
of
money
,
which
he
answered
in
this
way
,
"
My
jewel
of
a
dear
cousin
,
you
hear
this
old
woman
!
 
<EOS>
Why
does
she
say
that
?
 
<EOS>
Because
I
gave
eight
pounds
odd
(
or
whatever
it
was
)
for
a
certain
neat
waistcoat
and
buttons
a
few
days
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
if
I
had
stayed
at
Badger
's
I
should
have
been
obliged
to
spend
twelve
pounds
at
a
blow
for
some
heart
-
breaking
lecture
-
fees
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
make
four
pounds
---
in
a
lump
---
by
the
transaction
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
question
much
discussed
between
him
and
my
guardian
what
arrangements
should
be
made
for
his
living
in
London
while
he
experimented
on
the
law
,
for
we
had
long
since
gone
back
to
Bleak
House
,
and
it
was
too
far
off
to
admit
of
his
coming
there
oftener
than
once
a
week
.
 
<EOS>
My
guardian
told
me
that
if
Richard
were
to
settle
down
at
Mr
Kenge
's
he
would
take
some
apartments
or
chambers
where
we
too
could
occasionally
stay
for
a
few
days
at
a
time
;
"
but
,
little
woman
,
"
he
added
,
rubbing
his
head
very
significantly
,
"
he
has
n't
settled
down
there
yet
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
discussions
ended
in
our
hiring
for
him
,
by
the
month
,
a
neat
little
furnished
lodging
in
a
quiet
old
house
near
Queen
Square
.
 
<EOS>
He
immediately
began
to
spend
all
the
money
he
had
in
buying
the
oddest
little
ornaments
and
luxuries
for
this
lodging
;
and
so
often
as
Ada
and
I
dissuaded
him
from
making
any
purchase
that
he
had
in
contemplation
which
was
particularly
unnecessary
and
expensive
,
he
took
credit
for
what
it
would
have
cost
and
made
out
that
to
spend
anything
less
on
something
else
was
to
save
the
difference
.
   
<EOS>
While
these
affairs
were
in
abeyance
,
our
visit
to
Mr
Boythorn
's
was
postponed
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
Richard
having
taken
possession
of
his
lodging
,
there
was
nothing
to
prevent
our
departure
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
have
gone
with
us
at
that
time
of
the
year
very
well
,
but
he
was
in
the
full
novelty
of
his
new
position
and
was
making
most
energetic
attempts
to
unravel
the
mysteries
of
the
fatal
suit
.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
we
went
without
him
,
and
my
darling
was
delighted
to
praise
him
for
being
so
busy
.
   
<EOS>
We
made
a
pleasant
journey
down
into
Lincolnshire
by
the
coach
and
had
an
entertaining
companion
in
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
His
furniture
had
been
all
cleared
off
,
it
appeared
,
by
the
person
who
took
possession
of
it
on
his
blue
-
eyed
daughter
's
birthday
,
but
he
seemed
quite
relieved
to
think
that
it
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Chairs
and
table
,
he
said
,
were
wearisome
objects
;
they
were
monotonous
ideas
,
they
had
no
variety
of
expression
,
they
looked
you
out
of
countenance
,
and
you
looked
them
out
of
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
How
pleasant
,
then
,
to
be
bound
to
no
particular
chairs
and
tables
,
but
to
sport
like
a
butterfly
among
all
the
furniture
on
hire
,
and
to
flit
from
rosewood
to
mahogany
,
and
from
mahogany
to
walnut
,
and
from
this
shape
to
that
,
as
the
humour
took
one
!
   
<EOS>
"
The
oddity
of
the
thing
is
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
with
a
quickened
sense
of
the
ludicrous
,
"
that
my
chairs
and
tables
were
not
paid
for
,
and
yet
my
landlord
walks
off
with
them
as
composedly
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
that
seems
droll
!
 
<EOS>
There
is
something
grotesque
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
chair
and
table
merchant
never
engaged
to
pay
my
landlord
my
rent
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
my
landlord
quarrel
with
HIM
?
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
a
pimple
on
my
nose
which
is
disagreeable
to
my
landlord
's
peculiar
ideas
of
beauty
,
my
landlord
has
no
business
to
scratch
my
chair
and
table
merchant
's
nose
,
which
has
no
pimple
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
His
reasoning
seems
defective
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
my
guardian
good
-
humouredly
,
"
it
's
pretty
clear
that
whoever
became
security
for
those
chairs
and
tables
will
have
to
pay
for
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Exactly
!
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
crowning
point
of
unreason
in
the
business
!
 
<EOS>
I
said
to
my
landlord
,
"
My
good
man
,
you
are
not
aware
that
my
excellent
friend
Jarndyce
will
have
to
pay
for
those
things
that
you
are
sweeping
off
in
that
indelicate
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
no
consideration
for
HIS
property
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
had
n't
the
least
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
refused
all
proposals
,
"
said
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Refused
all
proposals
,
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
made
him
business
proposals
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
him
into
my
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
You
are
a
man
of
business
,
I
believe
?
"
 
<EOS>
He
replied
,
"
I
am
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
said
I
,
"
now
let
us
be
business
-
like
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
an
inkstand
,
here
are
pens
and
paper
,
here
are
wafers
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
want
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
occupied
your
house
for
a
considerable
period
,
I
believe
to
our
mutual
satisfaction
until
this
unpleasant
misunderstanding
arose
;
let
us
be
at
once
friendly
and
business
-
like
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
reply
to
this
,
he
made
use
of
the
figurative
expression
---
which
has
something
Eastern
about
it
---
that
he
had
never
seen
the
colour
of
my
money
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
amiable
friend
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
never
have
any
money
.
<EOS>
I
never
know
anything
about
money
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
said
he
,
"
what
do
you
offer
if
I
give
you
time
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
My
good
fellow
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
have
no
idea
of
time
;
but
you
say
you
are
a
man
of
business
,
and
whatever
you
can
suggest
to
be
done
in
a
business
-
like
way
with
pen
,
and
ink
,
and
paper
---
and
wafers
<EOS>
---
I
am
ready
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
pay
yourself
at
another
man
's
expense
(
which
is
foolish
)
,
but
be
business
-
like
!
"
 
<EOS>
However
,
he
would
n't
be
,
and
there
was
an
end
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
these
were
some
of
the
inconveniences
of
Mr
Skimpole
's
childhood
,
it
assuredly
possessed
its
advantages
too
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
journey
he
had
a
very
good
appetite
for
such
refreshment
as
came
in
our
way
(
including
a
basket
of
choice
hothouse
peaches
)
,
but
never
thought
of
paying
for
anything
.
 
<EOS>
So
when
the
coachman
came
round
for
his
fee
,
he
pleasantly
asked
him
what
he
considered
a
very
good
fee
indeed
,
now
---
a
liberal
one
---
and
on
his
replying
half
a
crown
for
a
single
passenger
,
said
it
was
little
enough
too
,
all
things
considered
,
and
left
Mr
Jarndyce
to
give
it
him
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
delightful
weather
.
 
<EOS>
The
green
corn
waved
<EOS>
so
beautifully
,
the
larks
sang
so
joyfully
,
the
hedges
were
so
full
of
wild
flowers
,
the
trees
were
so
thickly
out
in
leaf
,
the
bean
-
fields
,
with
a
light
wind
blowing
over
them
,
filled
the
air
with
such
a
delicious
fragrance
!
 
<EOS>
Late
in
the
afternoon
we
came
to
the
market
-
town
where
we
were
to
alight
from
the
coach
---
a
dull
little
town
with
a
church
-
spire
,
and
a
marketplace
,
and
a
market
-
cross
,
and
one
intensely
sunny
street
,
and
a
pond
with
an
old
horse
cooling
his
legs
in
it
,
and
a
very
few
men
sleepily
lying
and
standing
about
in
narrow
little
bits
of
shade
.
 
<EOS>
After
the
rustling
of
the
leaves
and
the
waving
of
the
corn
all
along
the
road
,
it
looked
as
still
,
as
hot
,
as
motionless
a
little
town
as
England
could
produce
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
inn
we
found
Mr
Boythorn
on
horseback
,
waiting
with
an
open
carriage
to
take
us
to
his
house
,
which
was
a
few
miles
off
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
over
-
joyed
to
see
us
and
dismounted
with
great
alacrity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
heaven
!
"
said
he
after
giving
us
a
courteous
greeting
.
 
<EOS>
This
a
most
infamous
coach
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
most
flagrant
example
of
an
abominable
public
vehicle
that
ever
encumbered
the
face
of
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
twenty
-
five
minutes
after
its
time
this
afternoon
.
<EOS>
The
coachman
ought
to
be
put
to
death
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
IS
he
after
his
time
?
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
to
whom
he
happened
to
address
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
my
infirmity
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Twenty
-
five
minutes
!
 
<EOS>
Twenty
-
six
minutes
!
<EOS>
"
replied
Mr
Boythorn
,
referring
to
his
watch
.
 
<EOS>
"
With
two
ladies
in
the
coach
,
this
scoundrel
has
deliberately
delayed
his
arrival
six
and
twenty
minutes
.
 
<EOS>
Deliberately
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
that
it
can
be
accidental
!
 
<EOS>
But
his
father
---
and
his
uncle
---
were
the
most
profligate
coachmen
that
ever
sat
upon
a
box
.
"
   
<EOS>
While
he
said
this
in
tones
of
the
greatest
indignation
,
he
handed
us
into
the
little
phaeton
with
the
utmost
gentleness
and
was
all
smiles
and
pleasure
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
,
ladies
,
"
he
said
,
standing
bare
-
headed
at
the
carriage
-
door
when
all
was
ready
,
"
that
I
am
obliged
to
conduct
you
nearly
two
miles
out
of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
But
our
direct
road
lies
through
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
's
park
,
and
in
that
fellow
's
property
I
have
sworn
never
to
set
foot
of
mine
,
or
horse
's
foot
of
mine
,
pending
the
present
relations
between
us
,
while
I
breathe
the
breath
of
life
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
here
,
catching
my
guardian
's
eye
,
he
broke
into
one
of
his
tremendous
laughs
,
which
seemed
to
shake
even
the
motionless
little
market
-
town
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
the
Dedlocks
down
here
,
Lawrence
?
"
said
my
guardian
as
we
drove
along
and
Mr
Boythorn
trotted
on
the
green
turf
by
the
roadside
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
Arrogant
Numskull
is
here
,
"
replied
Mr
Boythorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
<EOS>
Sir
Arrogant
is
here
,
and
I
am
glad
to
say
,
has
been
laid
by
the
heels
here
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
,
"
in
naming
whom
he
always
made
a
courtly
gesture
as
if
particularly
to
exclude
her
from
any
part
in
the
quarrel
,
"
is
expected
,
I
believe
,
daily
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
in
the
least
surprised
that
she
postpones
her
appearance
as
long
as
possible
.
<EOS>
Whatever
can
have
induced
that
transcendent
woman
to
marry
that
effigy
and
figure
-
head
of
a
baronet
is
one
of
the
most
impenetrable
mysteries
that
ever
baffled
human
inquiry
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
ha
!
"
   
"
I
suppose
,
said
my
guardian
,
laughing
,
"
WE
may
set
foot
in
the
park
while
we
are
here
?
 
<EOS>
The
prohibition
does
not
extend
to
us
,
does
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
lay
no
prohibition
on
my
guests
,
"
he
said
,
bending
his
head
to
Ada
and
me
with
the
smiling
politeness
which
sat
so
gracefully
upon
him
,
"
except
in
the
matter
of
their
departure
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
only
sorry
that
I
can
not
have
the
happiness
of
being
their
escort
about
Chesney
Wold
,
which
is
a
very
fine
place
!
 
<EOS>
But
by
the
light
of
this
summer
day
,
Jarndyce
,
if
you
call
upon
the
owner
while
you
stay
with
me
,
you
are
likely
to
have
but
a
cool
reception
.
 
<EOS>
He
carries
himself
like
an
eight
-
day
clock
at
all
times
,
like
one
of
a
race
of
eight
-
day
clocks
in
gorgeous
cases
that
never
go
and
never
went
---
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
!
<EOS>
---
but
he
will
have
some
extra
stiffness
,
I
can
promise
you
,
for
the
friends
of
his
friend
and
neighbour
Boythorn
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
put
him
to
the
proof
,
"
said
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
as
indifferent
to
the
honour
of
knowing
me
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
as
I
am
to
the
honour
of
knowing
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
air
of
the
grounds
and
perhaps
such
a
view
of
the
house
as
any
other
sightseer
might
get
are
quite
enough
for
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Boythorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
it
on
the
whole
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
in
better
keeping
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
looked
upon
about
here
as
a
second
Ajax
defying
the
lightning
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
When
I
go
into
our
little
church
on
a
Sunday
,
a
considerable
part
of
the
inconsiderable
congregation
expect
to
see
me
drop
,
scorched
and
withered
,
on
the
pavement
under
the
Dedlock
displeasure
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
he
is
surprised
that
I
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
For
he
is
,
by
heaven
,
the
most
self
-
satisfied
,
and
the
shallowest
,
and
the
most
coxcombical
and
utterly
brainless
ass
!
"
   
<EOS>
Our
coming
to
the
ridge
of
a
hill
we
had
been
ascending
enabled
our
friend
to
point
out
Chesney
Wold
itself
to
us
and
diverted
his
attention
from
its
master
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
picturesque
old
house
in
a
fine
park
richly
wooded
.
 
<EOS>
Among
the
trees
and
not
far
from
the
residence
he
pointed
out
the
spire
of
the
little
church
of
which
he
had
spoken
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
the
solemn
woods
over
which
the
light
and
shadow
travelled
swiftly
,
as
if
heavenly
wings
were
sweeping
on
benignant
errands
through
the
summer
air
;
the
smooth
green
slopes
,
the
glittering
water
,
the
garden
where
the
flowers
were
so
symmetrically
arranged
in
clusters
of
the
richest
colours
,
how
beautiful
they
looked
!
 
<EOS>
The
house
,
with
gable
and
chimney
,
and
tower
,
and
turret
,
and
dark
doorway
,
and
broad
terrace
-
walk
,
twining
among
the
balustrades
of
which
,
and
lying
heaped
upon
the
vases
<EOS>
,
there
was
one
great
flush
of
roses
,
seemed
scarcely
real
in
its
light
solidity
and
in
the
serene
and
peaceful
hush
that
rested
on
all
around
it
.
 
<EOS>
To
Ada
and
to
me
,
that
above
all
appeared
the
pervading
influence
.
 
<EOS>
On
everything
,
house
,
garden
,
terrace
,
green
slopes
,
water
,
old
oaks
,
fern
,
moss
,
woods
again
,
and
far
away
across
the
openings
in
the
prospect
to
the
distance
lying
wide
before
us
with
a
purple
bloom
upon
it
,
there
seemed
to
be
such
undisturbed
repose
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
came
into
the
little
village
and
passed
a
small
inn
with
the
sign
of
the
Dedlock
Arms
swinging
over
the
road
in
front
,
Mr
Boythorn
interchanged
greetings
with
a
young
gentleman
sitting
on
a
bench
outside
the
inn
-
door
who
had
some
fishing
-
tackle
lying
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
housekeeper
's
grandson
,
Mr
Rouncewell
by
name
,
"
said
,
he
,
"
and
he
is
in
love
with
a
pretty
girl
up
at
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
has
taken
a
fancy
to
the
pretty
girl
and
is
going
to
keep
her
about
her
own
fair
person
---
an
honour
which
my
young
friend
himself
does
not
at
all
appreciate
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
he
ca
n't
marry
just
yet
,
even
if
his
Rosebud
were
willing
;
so
he
is
fain
to
make
the
best
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meanwhile
,
he
comes
here
pretty
often
for
a
day
or
two
at
a
time
to
---
fish
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
ha
!
"
   
"
Are
he
and
the
pretty
girl
engaged
,
Mr
Boythorn
?
"
asked
Ada
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
Miss
Clare
,
"
he
returned
,
"
I
think
they
may
perhaps
understand
each
other
;
but
you
will
see
them
soon
,
I
dare
say
,
and
I
must
learn
from
you
on
such
a
point
---
not
you
from
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ada
blushed
,
and
Mr
Boythorn
,
trotting
forward
on
his
comely
grey
horse
,
dismounted
at
his
own
door
and
stood
ready
with
extended
arm
and
uncovered
head
to
welcome
us
when
we
arrived
.
   
<EOS>
He
lived
in
a
pretty
house
,
formerly
the
parsonage
house
,
with
a
lawn
in
front
,
a
bright
flower
-
garden
at
the
side
,
and
a
well
-
stocked
orchard
and
kitchen
-
garden
in
the
rear
,
enclosed
with
a
venerable
wall
that
had
of
itself
a
ripened
ruddy
look
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
indeed
,
everything
about
the
place
wore
an
aspect
of
maturity
and
abundance
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
lime
-
tree
walk
was
like
green
cloisters
,
the
very
shadows
of
the
cherry
-
trees
and
apple
-
trees
were
heavy
with
fruit
,
the
gooseberry
-
bushes
were
so
laden
that
their
branches
arched
and
rested
on
the
earth
,
the
strawberries
and
raspberries
grew
in
like
profusion
,
and
the
peaches
basked
by
the
hundred
on
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
Tumbled
about
among
the
spread
nets
and
the
glass
frames
sparkling
and
winking
in
the
sun
there
were
such
heaps
of
drooping
pods
,
and
marrows
,
and
cucumbers
,
that
every
foot
of
ground
appeared
a
vegetable
treasury
,
while
the
smell
of
sweet
herbs
and
all
kinds
of
wholesome
growth
(
to
say
nothing
of
the
neighbouring
meadows
where
the
hay
was
carrying
)
made
the
whole
air
a
great
nosegay
.
 
<EOS>
Such
stillness
and
composure
reigned
within
the
orderly
precincts
of
the
old
red
wall
that
even
the
feathers
hung
in
garlands
to
scare
the
birds
hardly
stirred
;
and
the
wall
had
such
a
ripening
influence
that
where
,
here
and
there
high
up
,
a
disused
nail
and
scrap
of
list
still
clung
to
it
,
it
was
easy
to
fancy
that
they
had
mellowed
with
the
changing
seasons
and
that
they
had
rusted
and
decayed
according
to
the
common
fate
.
   
<EOS>
The
house
,
though
a
little
disorderly
in
comparison
with
the
garden
,
was
a
real
old
house
with
settles
in
the
chimney
of
the
brick
-
floored
kitchen
and
great
beams
across
the
ceilings
.
 
<EOS>
On
one
side
of
it
was
the
terrible
piece
of
ground
in
dispute
,
where
Mr
Boythorn
maintained
a
sentry
in
a
smock
-
frock
day
and
night
,
whose
duty
was
supposed
to
be
,
in
cases
of
aggression
,
immediately
to
ring
a
large
bell
hung
up
there
for
the
purpose
,
to
unchain
a
great
bull
-
dog
established
in
a
kennel
as
his
ally
,
and
generally
to
deal
destruction
on
the
enemy
.
 
<EOS>
Not
content
with
these
precautions
,
Mr
Boythorn
had
himself
composed
and
posted
there
,
on
painted
boards
to
which
his
name
was
attached
in
large
letters
,
the
following
solemn
warnings
:
"
Beware
of
the
bull
-
dog
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
most
ferocious
.
<EOS>
Lawrence
Boythorn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
blunderbus
is
loaded
with
slugs
.
<EOS>
Lawrence
Boythorn
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Man
-
traps
and
spring
-
guns
are
set
here
at
all
times
of
the
day
and
night
.
 
<EOS>
Lawrence
Boythorn
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Take
notice
.
<EOS>
That
any
person
or
persons
audaciously
presuming
to
trespass
on
this
property
will
be
punished
with
the
utmost
severity
of
private
chastisement
and
prosecuted
with
the
utmost
rigour
of
the
law
.
<EOS>
Lawrence
Boythorn
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
These
he
showed
us
from
the
drawing
-
room
window
,
while
his
bird
was
hopping
about
his
head
,
and
he
laughed
,
"
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
ha
!
"
to
that
extent
as
he
pointed
them
out
that
I
really
thought
he
would
have
hurt

.
   
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
taking
a
good
deal
of

,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
in
his
light

,
"
when
you
are
not
in

all
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
in
earnest
!
"
returned
Mr
Boythorn
with
unspeakable
warmth
.
<EOS>
"
Not
in
earnest
!
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
have
hoped
to
train
him
,
I
would
have
bought
a
lion
instead
of
that
dog
and
would
have
turned
him
loose
upon
the
first
intolerable
robber
who
should

to
make
an

on
my

.
 
<EOS>
Let
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
consent
to
come
out
and
decide

question
by

,
and
I
will

with
any

known

mankind
in
any
age
or
country
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
that
much
in
earnest
.
 
<EOS>
Not
more
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
arrived
at
his
house
on
a
Saturday
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
Sunday
morning
we
all
set
forth
to
walk
to
the
little
church
in
the
park
.
 
<EOS>
Entering
the
park
,
almost
immediately
by
the
disputed
ground
,
we
pursued
a
pleasant
footpath
winding
among
the
verdant
turf
and
the
beautiful
trees
until
it
brought
us
to
the
church
-
porch
.
   
<EOS>
The
congregation
was
extremely
small
and
quite
a
rustic
one
with
the
exception
of
a
large
muster
of
servants
from
the
house
,
some
of
whom
were
already
in
their
seats
,
while
others
were
yet
dropping
in
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
some
stately
footmen
,
and
there
was
a
perfect
picture
of
an
old
coachman
,
who
looked
as
if
he
were
the
official
representative
of
all
the
pomps
and
vanities
that
had
ever
been
put
into
his
coach
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
very
pretty
show
of
young
women
,
and
above
them
,
the
handsome
old
face
and
fine
responsible
portly
figure
of
the
housekeeper
towered
pre
-
eminent
.
 
<EOS>
The
pretty
girl
of
whom
Mr
Boythorn
had
told
us
was
close
by
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
very
pretty
that
I
might
have
known
her
by
her
beauty
even
if
I
had
not
seen
how
blushingly
conscious
she
was
of
the
eyes
of
the
young
fisherman
,
whom
I
discovered
not
far
off
.
 
<EOS>
One
face
,
and
not
an
agreeable
one
,
though
it
was
handsome
,
seemed
maliciously
watchful
of
this
pretty
girl
,
and
indeed
of
every
one
and
everything
there
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
Frenchwoman
's
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
bell
was
yet
ringing
and
the
great
people
were
not
yet
come
,
I
had
leisure
to
glance
over
the
church
,
which
smelt
as
earthy
as
a
grave
,
and
to
think
what
a
shady
,
ancient
,
solemn
little
church
<EOS>
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
The
windows
,
heavily
shaded
by
trees
,
admitted
a
subdued
light
that
made
the
faces
around
me
pale
,
and
darkened
the
old
brasses
in
the
pavement
and
the
time
and
damp
-
worn

,
and
rendered
the
sunshine
in
the
little
porch
,
where
a
monotonous
ringer
was
working
at
the
bell
,
inestimably
bright
.
 
<EOS>
But
a
stir
in
that
direction
,
a
gathering
of
reverential
awe
in
the
rustic
faces
,
and
a
blandly
ferocious
assumption
on
the
part
of
Mr
Boythorn
of
being
resolutely
unconscious
of
somebody
's
existence
forewarned
me
that
the
great
people
were
come
and
that
the
service
was
going
to
begin
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Enter
not
into
judgment
with
thy
servant
,
O
Lord
,
for
in
thy
sight
---
"
"
   
Shall
I
ever
forget
the
rapid
beating
at
my
heart
,
occasioned
by
the
look
I
met
as
I
stood
up
!
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
ever
forget
the
manner
in
which
those
handsome
proud
eyes
seemed
to
spring
out
of
their
languor
and
to
hold
mine
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
only
a
moment
before
I
cast
mine
down
---
released
again
,
if
I
may
say
so
---
on
my
book
;
but
I
knew
the
beautiful
face
quite
well
in
that
short
space
of
time
.
   
<EOS>
And
,
very
strangely
,
there
was
something
quickened
within
me
,
associated
with
the
lonely
days
at
my
godmother
's
;
<EOS>
yes
,
away
even
to
the
days
when
I
had
stood
on
tiptoe
to
dress
myself
at
my
little
glass
after
dressing
my
doll
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
,
although
I
had
never
seen
this
lady
's
face
before
in
all
my
life
---
I
was
quite
sure
of
it
---
 
<EOS>
absolutely
certain
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
easy
to
know
that
the
ceremonious
,
gouty
,
grey
-
haired
gentleman
,
the
only
other
occupant
of
the
great
pew
,
was
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
and
that
the
lady
was
Lady
Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
But
why
her
face
should
be
,
in
a
confused

,
like
a
broken
glass
to
me
,
in

I
saw
scraps
of
old

,
and
why

be
so
fluttered
and

(
for
I
was
still
)
by
having
casually
met
her
eyes
,
I
could
not
think
.
   
<EOS>
I
felt
it
to
be
an
unmeaning
weakness
in
me
and
tried
to
overcome
it
by
attending
to
the
words
I
heard
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
very
strangely
,
I
seemed
to
hear
them
,
not
in
the
reader
's
voice
,
but
in
the
well
-
remembered
voice
of
my
godmother
.
 
<EOS>
This
made
me
think
,
did
Lady
Dedlock
's
face
accidentally
resemble
my
godmother
's
?
 
<EOS>
It
might
be
that
it
did
,
a
little
;
but
the
expression
was
so
different
,
and
the
stern
decision
which
had
worn
into
my
godmother
's
face
,
like
weather
into
rocks
,
was
so
completely
wanting
in
the
face
before
me
that
it
could
not
be
that
resemblance
which
had
struck
me
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
<EOS>
did
I
know
the
loftiness
and
haughtiness
of
Lady
Dedlock
's
face
,
at
all
,
in
any
one
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
I
---
I
,
little
Esther
Summerson
,
the
child
who
lived
a
life
apart
and
on
whose
birthday
there
was
no
rejoicing
---
seemed
to
arise
before
my
own

,
evoked
out
of
the
past
by
some
power
in
this
fashionable
lady
,
whom
I
not
only
entertained
no
fancy
that
I
had
ever
seen
,
but
whom
I
perfectly
well
knew
I
had
never
seen
until
that
hour
.
   
<EOS>
It
made
me
tremble
so
to
be
thrown
into
this
unaccountable
agitation
that
I
was
conscious
of
being
distressed
even
by
the
observation
of
the
French
maid
,
though
I
knew
she
had
been
looking
watchfully
here
,
and
there
,
and
everywhere
,
from
the

.
 
<EOS>
By

,
though
very

,
I
at
last

my
strange

.
 
<EOS>
After
a
long

,
I
looked
towards
Lady
Dedlock
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
while
they
were
preparing
to
sing
,
before
the
sermon
.
 
<EOS>
She
took
no
heed
of
me
,
and
the
beating
at
my
heart
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
did
it
revive
for
more
than
a
few
moments
when
she
once
or

afterwards
glanced
at
Ada
or
at
me
through
her

.
   
<EOS>
The
service
being
concluded
,
Sir
Leicester
gave
his
arm
with
much
taste
and
gallantry
to
Lady
Dedlock
---
though
he
was
obliged
to
walk
by
the
help
of
a
thick
stick
---
and
escorted
her
out
of
church
to
the
pony
carriage
in
which
they
had
come
.
 
<EOS>
The
servants
then
dispersed
,
and
so
did
the
congregation
,
whom
Sir
Leicester
had
contemplated
all
along
<EOS>
(
Mr
Skimpole
said
to
Mr
Boythorn
's
infinite
delight
)
as
if
he
were
a
considerable
landed
proprietor
in
heaven
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
believes
he
is
!
"
said
Mr
Boythorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
firmly
believes
it
.
<EOS>
So
did
his
father
,
and
his
grandfather
,
and
his
great
-
grandfather
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
"
pursued
Mr
Skimpole
very
unexpectedly
to
Mr
Boythorn
,
"
it
's
agreeable
to
me
to
see
a
man
of
that
sort
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
IS
it
!
"
said
Mr
Boytborn
.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
that
he
wants
to
patronize
me
,
"
pursued
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
well
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
object
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
said
Mr
Boythorn
with
great
vigour
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
really
?
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
in
his
easy
light
vein
.
<EOS>
"
But
that
's
taking
trouble
,
surely
.
 
<EOS>
And
why
should
you
take
trouble
?
 
<EOS>
Here
am
I
,
content
to
receive
things
childishly
as
they
fall
out
,
and
I
never
take
trouble
!
 
<EOS>
I
come
down
here
,
for
instance
,
and
I
find
a
mighty
potentate
exacting
homage
.
 
<EOS>
Very
well
!
 
<EOS>
I
say
"
Mighty
potentate
,
here
IS
my
homage
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
easier
to
give
it
than
to
withhold
it
.
 
<EOS>
Here
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
have
anything
of
an
agreeable
nature
to
show
me
,
I
shall
be
happy
to
see
it
;
if
you
have
anything
of
an
agreeable
nature
to
give
me
,
I
shall
be
happy
to
accept

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mighty
potentate
replies
in
effect
,
"
This
is
a
sensible
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
I
find
him
accord
with
my

and
my

.
 
<EOS>
He
does
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I
expand
,
I
open
<EOS>
,

outward

's

,
and
it

.
"
 
<EOS>
That
's
my
view
of
such

,
speaking
as

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

-

,
"

,
"
where

.
 
<EOS>
How

?
"
   
"
How

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Just

!
 
<EOS>
I

,
"
My

"
---
to

<EOS>
---
"
my

,

?
 
<EOS>
Very

.
 
<EOS>
So

I

I

.
 
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
Therefore

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

,
let

!
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
But

might

"

,

,
"
I

---
"
   
"
I

"

<EOS>
"
Very

.
"
   
"
---

WILL

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
   
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

excellent

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

,

all

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,
who
always

,

,

,
he

was

.
   
<EOS>
"
Enterprise

effort
<EOS>
,
"
he

say
to
us
(
on

)
,
are

.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
I

the
deepest

with

.
 
<EOS>
I
lie

North

<EOS>
Mercenary

"

's

?
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
ca

;
<EOS>

,

he

---

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

hard

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
The

had
gone
round
to
the
Saturday
following
that
beating

my
heart
in
the
church
;
and

had

so

that
to
ramble

,
and

down

,

and

,
had

most

.
 
<EOS>
We
had
one

,
deep
in

and
last
year
's

,
where

some

.
 
<EOS>
Seated

,

,
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
Upon

,
Mr
Jarndyce
,
Ada
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

had
been
all

,
but

---

,

---

the

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

,

-

-

,

.
 
<EOS>
We
had
often

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

was

within
,
now

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

Esther

"

<EOS>
Ada

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Again
,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Lady

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!
"
   
<EOS>

regard
Ada
and
me
as
little
more
than
children
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
as
she
slightly
laughed
and
afterwards
sat
looking
at
the
rain
,
she
was
as
self
-
possessed
and
as
free
to
occupy
herself
with
her
own
thoughts
as
if
she
had
been
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
knew
my
sister
when
we
were
abroad
together
better
than
you
know
me
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
looking
at
him
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
we
happened
to
meet
oftener
,
"
he
returned
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
went
our
several
ways
,
"
said
Lady
Dedlock
,
"
and
had
little
in
common
even
before
we
agreed
to
differ
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
to
be
regretted
,
I
suppose
,
but
it
could
not
be
helped
.
"
   
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
again
sat
looking
at
the
rain
.
 
<EOS>
The
storm
soon
began
to
pass
upon
its
way
.
 
<EOS>
The
shower
greatly
abated
,
the
lightning
ceased
,
the
thunder
rolled
among
the
distant
hills
,
and
the
sun
began
to
glisten
on
the
wet
leaves
and
the
falling
rain
.
 
<EOS>
As
we
sat
there
,
silently
,
we
saw
a
little
pony
phaeton
coming
towards
us
at
a
merry
pace
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
messenger
is
coming
back
,
my
Lady
,
"
said
the
keeper
,
"
with
the
carriage
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
it
drove
up
,
we
saw
that
there
were
two
people
inside
.
 
<EOS>
There
alighted
from
it
,
with
some
cloaks
and
wrappers
,
first
the
Frenchwoman
whom
I
had
seen
in
church
,
and
secondly
the
pretty
girl
,
the
Frenchwoman
with
a
defiant
confidence
,
the
pretty
girl
confused
and
hesitating
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
now
?
"
said
Lady
Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
your
maid
,
my
Lady
,
at
the
present
,
"
said
the
Frenchwoman
.
<EOS>
"
The
message
was
for
the
attendant
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
afraid
you
might
mean
me
,
my
Lady
,
"
said
the
pretty
girl
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
mean
you
,
child
,
"
replied
her
mistress
calmly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
that
shawl
on
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
slightly
stooped
her
shoulders
to
receive
it
,
and
the
pretty
girl
lightly
dropped
it
in
its
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
Frenchwoman
stood
unnoticed
,
looking
on
with
her
lips
very
tightly
set
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
,
"
said
Lady
Dedlock
to
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
that
we
are
not
likely
to
renew
our
former
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
allow
me
to
send
the
carriage
back
for
your
two
wards
.
 
<EOS>
It
shall
be
here
directly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
But
as
he
would
on
no
account
accept
this
offer
,
she
took
a
graceful
leave
of
Ada
---
none
of
me
---
and
put
her
hand
upon
his
proffered
arm
,
and
got
into
the
carriage
,
which
was
a
little
,
low
,
park
carriage
with
a
hood
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
child
,
"
she
said
to
the
pretty
girl
;
"
I
shall
want
you
.
<EOS>
Go
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
carriage
rolled
away
,
and
the
Frenchwoman
,
with
the
wrappers
she
had
brought
hanging
over
her
arm
,
remained
standing
where
she
had
alighted
.
   
<EOS>
I
suppose
there
is
nothing
pride
can
so
little
bear
with
as
pride
itself
,
and
that
she
was
punished
for
her
imperious
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Her
retaliation
was
the
most
singular
I
could
have
imagined
.
 
<EOS>
She
remained
perfectly
still
until
the
carriage
had
turned
into
the
drive
,
and
then
,
without
the
least
discomposure
of
countenance
,
slipped
off
her
shoes
,
left
them
on
the
ground
,
and
walked
deliberately
in
the
same
direction
through
the
wettest
of
the
wet
grass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
young
woman
mad
?
"
said
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
sir
!
"
said
the
keeper
,
who
,
with
his
wife
,
was
looking
after
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hortense
is
not
one
of
that
sort
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
as
good
a
head
-
piece
as
the
best
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
's
mortal
high
and
passionate
---
 
powerful
high
and
passionate
;
and
what
with
having
notice
to
leave
,
and
having
others
put
above
her
,
she
do
n't
take
kindly
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
why
should
she
walk
shoeless
through
all
that
water
?
"
said
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
indeed
,
sir
,
unless
it
is
to
cool
her
down
!
"
said
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Or
unless
she
fancies
it
's
blood
,
"
said
the
woman
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
'd
as
soon
walk
through
that
as
anything
else
,
I
think
,
when
her
own
's
up
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
passed
not
far
from
the
house
a
few
minutes
afterwards
.
<EOS>
Peaceful
as
it
had
looked
when
we
first
saw
it
,
it
looked
even
more
so
now
,
with
a
diamond
spray
glittering
all
about
it
,
a
light
wind
blowing
,
the
birds
no
longer
hushed
but
singing
strongly
,
everything
refreshed
by
the
late
rain
,
and
the
little
carriage
shining
at
the
doorway
like
a
fairy
carriage
made
of
silver
.
<EOS>
Still
,
very
steadfastly
and
quietly
walking
towards
it
,
a
peaceful
figure
too
in
the
landscape
,
went
Mademoiselle
Hortense
,
shoeless
,
through
the
wet
grass
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
19
.
<EOS>
Moving
On
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
long
vacation
in
the
regions
of
Chancery
Lane
.
 
<EOS>
The
good
ships
Law
and
Equity
,
<EOS>
those
teak
-
built
,
copper
-
bottomed
,
iron
-
fastened
,
brazen
-
faced
,
and
not
by
any
means
fast
-
sailing
clippers
are
laid
up
in
ordinary
.
 
<EOS>
The
Flying
Dutchman
,
with
a
crew
of
ghostly
clients
imploring
all
whom
they
may
encounter
to
peruse
their
papers
,
has
drifted
,
for
the
time
being
,
heaven
knows
where
.
<EOS>
The
courts
are
all
shut
up
;
the
public
offices
lie
in
a
hot
sleep
.
<EOS>
Westminster
Hall
itself
is
a
shady
solitude
where
nightingales
might
sing
,
and
a
tenderer
class
of
suitors
than
is
usually
found
there
,
walk
.
   
<EOS>
The
Temple
,
Chancery
Lane
,
Serjeants
'
Inn
,
and
Lincoln
's
Inn
even
unto
the
Fields
are
like
tidal
harbours
at
low
water
,
where
stranded
proceedings
,
offices
at
anchor
,
idle
clerks
lounging
on
lop
-
sided
stools
that
will
not
recover
their
perpendicular
until
the
current
of
Term
sets
in
,
lie
high
and
dry
upon
the
ooze
of
the
long
vacation
.
 
<EOS>
Outer
doors
of
chambers
are
shut
up
by
the
score
,
messages
and
parcels
are
to
be
left
at
the
Porter
's
Lodge
by
the
bushel
.
 
<EOS>
A
crop
of
grass
would
grow
in
the
chinks
of
the
stone
pavement
outside
Lincoln
's
Inn
Hall
,
but
that
the
ticket
-
porters
,
who
have
nothing
to
do
beyond
sitting
in
the
shade
there
,
with
their
white
aprons
over
their
heads
to
keep
the
flies
off
,
grub
it
up
and
eat
it
thoughtfully
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
only
one
judge
in
town
.
 
<EOS>
Even
he
only
comes
twice
a
week
to
sit
in
chambers
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
country
folks
of
those
assize
towns
on
his
circuit
could
see
him
now
!
 
<EOS>
No
full
-
bottomed
wig
,
no
red
petticoats
,
no
fur
,
no
javelin
-
men
,
no
white
wands
.
 
<EOS>
Merely
a
close
-
shaved
gentleman
in
white
trousers
and
a
white
hat
,
with
sea
-
bronze
on
the
judicial
countenance
,
and
a
strip
of
bark
peeled
by
the
solar
rays
from
the
judicial
nose
,
who
calls
in
at
the
shell
-
fish
shop
as
he
comes
along
and
drinks
iced
ginger
-
beer
!
   
<EOS>
The
bar
of
England
is
scattered
over
the
face
of
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
How
England
can
get
on
through
four
long
summer
months
without
its
bar
 
---
which
is
its
acknowledged
refuge
in
adversity
and
its
only
legitimate
triumph
in
prosperity
---
is
beside
the
question
;
assuredly
that
shield
and
buckler
of
Britannia
are
not
in
present
wear
.
 
<EOS>
The
learned
gentleman
who
is
always
so
tremendously
indignant
at
the
unprecedented
outrage
committed
on
the
feelings
of
his
client
by
the
opposite
party
that
he
never
seems
likely
to
recover
it
is
doing
infinitely
better
than
might
be
expected
in
Switzerland
.
 
<EOS>
The
learned
gentleman
who
does
the
withering
business
and
who
blights
all
opponents
with
his
gloomy
sarcasm
is
as
merry
as
a
grig
at
a
French
watering
-
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
learned
gentleman
who
weeps
by
the
pint
on
the
smallest
provocation
has
not
shed
a
tear
these
six
weeks
.
<EOS>
The
very
learned
gentleman
who
has
cooled
the
natural
heat
of
his
gingery
complexion
in
pools
and
fountains
of
law
until
he
has
become
great
in
knotty
arguments
for
term
-
time
,
when
he
poses
the
drowsy
bench
with
legal
"
chaff
,
"
inexplicable
to
the
uninitiated
and
to
most
of
the
initiated
too
,
is
roaming
,
with
a
characteristic
delight
in
aridity
and
dust
,
about
Constantinople
.
 
<EOS>
Other
dispersed
fragments
of
the
same
great
palladium
are
to
be
found
on
the
canals
of
Venice
,
at
the
second
cataract
of
the
Nile
,
in
the
baths
of
Germany
,
and
sprinkled
on
the
sea
-
sand
all
over
the
English
coast
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
one
is
to
be
encountered
in
the
deserted
region
of
Chancery
Lane
.
 
<EOS>
If
such
a
lonely
member
of
the
bar
do
flit
across
the
waste
and
come
upon
a
prowling
suitor
who
is
unable
to
leave
off
haunting
the
scenes
of
his
anxiety
,
they
frighten
one
another
and
retreat
into
opposite
shades
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
the
hottest
long
vacation
known
for
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
young
clerks
are
madly
in
love
,
and
according
to
their
various
degrees
,
pine
for
bliss
with
the
beloved
object
,
at
Margate
,
Ramsgate
,
or
Gravesend
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
middle
-
aged
clerks
think
their
families
too
large
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
unowned
dogs
who
stray
into
the
Inns
of
Court
and
pant
about
staircases
and
other
dry
places
seeking
water
give
short
howls
of
aggravation
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
blind
men
's
dogs
in
the
streets
draw
their
masters
against
pumps
or
trip
them
over
buckets
.
 
<EOS>
A
shop
with
a
sun
-
blind
,
and
a
watered
pavement
,
and
a
bowl
of
gold
and
silver
fish
in
the
window
,
is
a
sanctuary
.
 
<EOS>
Temple
Bar
gets
so
hot
that
it
is
,
to
the
adjacent
Strand
and
Fleet
Street
,
what
a
heater
is
in
an
urn
,
and
keeps
them
simmering
all
night
.
   
<EOS>
There
are
offices
about
the
Inns
of
Court
in
which
a
man
might
be
cool
,
if
any
coolness
were
worth
purchasing
at
such
a
price
in
dullness
;
but
the
little
thoroughfares
immediately
outside
those
retirements
seem
to
blaze
.
 
<EOS>
In
Mr
Krook
's
court
,
it
is
so
hot
that
the
people
turn
their
houses
inside
out
and
sit
in
chairs
upon
the
pavement
---
<EOS>
Mr
Krook
included
,
who
there
pursues
his
studies
,
with
his
cat
(
who
never
is
too
hot
)
by
his
side
.
 
<EOS>
The
Sol
's
Arms
has
discontinued
the
Harmonic
Meetings
for
the
season
,
and
Little
Swills
is
engaged
at
the
Pastoral
Gardens
down
the
river
,
where
he
comes
out
in
quite
an
innocent
manner
and
sings
comic
ditties
of
a
juvenile
complexion
calculated
(
as
the
bill
says
)
not
to
wound
the
feelings
of
the
most
fastidious
mind
.
   
<EOS>
Over
all
the
legal
neighbourhood
there
hangs
,
like
some
great
veil
of
rust
or
gigantic
cobweb
,
the
idleness
and
pensiveness
of
the
long
vacation
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
,
law
-
stationer
of
Cook
's
Court
,
Cursitor
Street
,
is
sensible
of
the
influence
not
only
in
his
mind
as
a
sympathetic
and
contemplative
man
,
but
also
in
his
business
as
a
law
-
stationer
aforesaid
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
more
leisure
for
musing
in
Staple
Inn
and
in
the
Rolls
Yard
during
the
long
vacation
than
at
other
seasons
,
and
he
says
to
the
two
'
prentices
,
what
a
thing
it
is
in
such
hot
weather
to
think
that
you
live
in
an
island
with
the
sea
a
-
rolling
and
a
-
bowling
<EOS>
right
round
you
.
   
<EOS>
Guster
is
busy
in
the
little
drawing
-
room
on
this
present
afternoon
in
the
long
vacation
,
when
Mr
and
Mrs
Snagsby
have
it
in
contemplation
to
receive
company
.
 
<EOS>
The
expected
guests
are
rather
select
than
numerous
,
being
Mr
and
Mrs
Chadband
and
no
more
.
<EOS>
From
Mr
Chadband
's
being
much
given
to
describe
himself
,
both
verbally
and
in
writing
,
as
a
vessel
,
he
is
occasionally
mistaken
by
strangers
for
a
gentleman
connected
with
navigation
,
but
he
is
,
as
he
expresses
it
,
"
in
the
ministry
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chadband
is
attached
to
no
particular
denomination
and
is
considered
by
his
persecutors
to
have
nothing
so
very
remarkable
to
say
on
the
greatest
of
subjects
as
to
render
his
volunteering
,
on
his
own
account
,
at
all
incumbent
on
his
conscience
;
but
he
has
his
followers
,
and
Mrs
Snagsby
is
of
the
number
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
has
but
recently
taken
a
passage
upward
by
the
vessel
,
Chadband
;
and
her
attention
was
attracted
to
that
Bark
A
1
when
she
was
something
flushed
by
the
hot
weather
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
little
woman
,
"
says
Mr
Snagsby
to
the
sparrows
in
Staple
Inn
,
"
likes
to
have
her
religion
rather
sharp
,
you
see
!
"
   
<EOS>
So
Guster
,
much
impressed
by
regarding
herself
for
the
time
as
the
handmaid
of
Chadband
,
whom
she
knows
to
be
endowed
with
the
gift
of
holding
forth
for
four
hours
at
a
stretch
,
prepares
the
little
drawing
-
room
for
tea
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
furniture
is
shaken
and
dusted
,
the
portraits
of
Mr
and
Mrs
Snagsby
are
touched
up
with
a
wet
cloth
,
the
best
tea
-
service
is
set
forth
,
and
there
is
excellent
provision
made
of
dainty
new
bread
,
crusty
twists
,
cool
fresh
butter
,
thin
slices
of
ham
,
tongue
,
and
German
sausage
,
and
delicate
little
rows
of
anchovies
nestling
in
parsley
,
not
to
mention
new
-
laid
eggs
,
to
be
brought
up
warm
in
a
napkin
,
and
hot
buttered
toast
.
 
<EOS>
For
Chadband
is
rather
a
consuming
vessel
---
the
persecutors
say
a
gorging
vessel
---
and
can
wield
such
weapons
of
the
flesh
as
a
knife
and
fork
remarkably
well
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
in
his
best
coat
,
looking
at
all
the
preparations
when
they
are
completed
and
coughing
his
cough
of
deference
behind

,
says
to
Mrs
Snagsby
,
"
At
what
time
did
you
expect
Mr
and
Mrs
Chadband
,
my
love
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
six
,
"
says
Mrs
Snagsby
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
observes
in
a

casual

that
"
it
's
gone
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
'd
like

begin
without

,
"

Mrs
Snagsby
's

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

"
No
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
time
,
"
says
Mrs
Snagsby
,
"
to
eternity
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
true
,
my

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Only

---

---

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To

!
"
<EOS>
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
"
Up

!
<EOS>
As

Chadband

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,

,
"

Snagsby
.
   
<EOS>
Here
,
Guster
,
who
had

,
comes

,
and

,

that
Mr

have

.
 
<EOS>
The
bell
at
the
inner

in
the
passage
immediately
thereafter

,
she
is

by
Mrs
Snagsby
,
on
pain
of
instant

to
her
patron
saint
,
not
to

of

.
 
<EOS>
Much

in
her

(
which
were

in

)
by

,

"
Mr

Cheeseming
,
least

,
Imeantersay
,
whatsername
!
"
and

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chadband
is
a
large
yellow
man
with
a
fat
smile
and
a
general
appearance
of
having
a
good

of
train
oil
in
his
system
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Chadband
is
a
stern
,
severe
-
looking
,
silent
woman
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chadband
moves
softly
and
cumbrously
,
not
unlike
a
bear
who
has
been
taught
to
walk
upright
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
very
much
embarrassed
about
the
arms
,
as
if
they
were
inconvenient
to
him
and
he
wanted
to
grovel
,
is
very
much
in
a

about
the
head
,
and
never
speaks
without
first

up
his
great
hand
,
as

to

that
he
is

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
friends
,
"
says
Mr
Chadband
,
"
peace

on
this
house
!
 
<EOS>
On

master
thereof
,

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
My

,

?
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
Is

?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,

,

,
upon

.
"
   
<EOS>
In

Snagsby

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,

"

"

"
   
Guster

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

,

,

"

"
one

seven

.
"
 
<EOS>

"
Go

"
   
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"
one

.

<EOS>
Mr

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Which

.

<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Rachael
,

!

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
It

---

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

,

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
O

,

!
 
<EOS>
O

!
"
   
<EOS>
With

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

,
"

?
 
<EOS>
Refreshment
.
 
<EOS>
Do

,

?
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
Why

,

?

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
,

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

,

?
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
What

<EOS>
Our

<EOS>

,
"

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

's

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

that

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
The

of

of
any

into
oil
of
the

already
mentioned
appears
to
be
a

so

that
in

,

may

as

a
kind
of

oil
mills

.
 
<EOS>
On

present

of

,
in
Cook
's

,

,

that
the

to

quite
full
when

.
   
<EOS>
At

,
Guster
,

,

's

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
"

,
"

.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

!
 
<EOS>

!
"

,

.

!

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
thus
apostrophized
,
gives
a
slouch
backward
,
and
another
slouch
forward
,
and
another
slouch
to
each
side
,
and
confronts
the
eloquent
Chadband
with
evident
doubts
of
his
intentions
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
young
friend
,
"
says
Chadband
,
"
you
are
to
us
a
pearl
,
you
are
to
us
a
diamond
,
you
are
to
us
a
gem
,
you
are
to
us
a
jewel
.
 
<EOS>
And
why
,
my
young
friend
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replies
Jo
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
nothink
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
young
friend
,
"
says
Chadband
,
"
it
is
because
you
know
nothing
that
you
are
to
us
a
gem
and
jewel
.
 
<EOS>
For
what
are
you
,
my
young
friend
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
a
beast
of
the
field
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
A
bird
of
the
air
?
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
A
fish
of
the
sea
or
river
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
human
boy
,
my
young
friend
.
 
<EOS>
A
human
boy
.
 
<EOS>
O
glorious
to
be
a
human
boy
!
 
<EOS>
And
why
glorious
,
<EOS>
my
young
friend
?
 
<EOS>
Because
you
are
capable
of
receiving
the
lessons
of
wisdom
,
because
you
are
capable
of
profiting
by
this
discourse
which
I
now
deliver
for
your
good
,
because
you
are
not
a
stick
,
or
a
staff
,
or
a
stock
,
or
a
stone
,
or
a
post
,
or
a
pillar
.
     
<EOS>
O
running
stream
of
sparkling
joy
     
<EOS>
To
be
a
soaring
human
boy
!
   
<EOS>
And
do
you
cool
yourself
in
that
stream
now
,
my
young
friend
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Why
do
you
not
cool
yourself
in
that
stream
now
?
 
<EOS>
Because
you
are
in
a
state
of
darkness
,
because
you
are
in
a
state
of
obscurity
,
because
you
are
in
a
state
of
sinfulness
,
because
you
are
in
a
state
of
bondage
.
 
<EOS>
My
young
friend
,
what
is
bondage
?
 
<EOS>
Let
us
,
in
a
spirit
of
love
,
inquire
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
threatening
stage
of
the
discourse
,
Jo
,
who
seems
to
have
been
gradually
going
out
of
his
mind
,
smears
his
right
arm
over
his
face
and
gives
a
terrible
yawn
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
indignantly
expresses
her
belief
that
he
is
a
limb
of
the
arch
-
fiend
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
friends
,
"
says
Mr
Chadband
with
his
persecuted
chin
folding
itself
into
its
fat
smile
again
as
he
looks
round
,
"
it
is
right
that
I
should
be
humbled
,
it
is
right
that
I
should
be
tried
,
it
is
right
that
I
should
be
mortified
,
it
is
right
that
I
should
be
corrected
.
 
<EOS>
I
stumbled
,
on
Sabbath
last
,
when
I
thought
with
pride
of
my
three
hours
'
improving
.
 
<EOS>
The
account
is
now
favourably
balanced
:
my
creditor
has
accepted
a
composition
.
 
<EOS>
O
let
us
be
joyful
,
joyful
!
 
<EOS>
O
let
us
be
joyful
!
"
   
<EOS>
Great
sensation
on
the
part
of
Mrs
Snagsby
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
friends
,
"
says
Chadband
,
looking
round
him
in
conclusion
,
"
I
will
not
proceed
with
my
young
friend
now
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
come
to
-
morrow
,
my
young
friend
,
and
inquire
of
this
good
lady
where
I
am
to
be
found
to
deliver
a
discourse
unto
you
,
and
will
you
come
like
the
thirsty
swallow
upon
the
next
day
,
and
upon
the
day
after
that
,
and
upon
the
day
after
that
,
and
upon
many
pleasant
days
,
to
hear
discourses
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
This
with
a
cow
-
like
lightness
.
)
   
<EOS>
Jo
,
whose
immediate
object
seems
to
be
to
get
away
on
any
terms
,
gives
a
shuffling
nod
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
then
throws
him
a
penny
,
and
Mrs
Snagsby
calls
to
Guster
to
see
him
safely
out
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
But
before
he
goes
downstairs
,
Mr
Snagsby
loads
him
with
some
broken
meats
from
the
table
,
which
he
carries
away
,
hugging
in
his
arms
.
   
<EOS>
So
,
Mr
Chadband
---
of
whom
the
persecutors
say
that
it
is
no
wonder
he
should
go
on
for
any
length
of
time
uttering
such
abominable
nonsense
,
but
that
the
wonder
rather
is
that
he
should
ever
leave
off
,
having
once
the
audacity
to
begin
---
retires
into
private
life
until
he
invests
a
little
capital
of
supper
in
the
oil
-
trade
.
 
<EOS>
Jo
moves
on
,
through
the
long
vacation
,
down
to
Blackfriars
Bridge
,
where
he
finds
a
baking
stony
corner
wherein
to
settle
to
his
repast
.
   
<EOS>
And
there
he
sits
,
munching
and
gnawing
,
and
looking
up
at
the
great
cross
on
the
summit
of
St
Paul
's
Cathedral
,
glittering
above
a
red
-
and
-
violet
-
tinted
cloud
of
smoke
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
boy
's
face
one
might
suppose
that
sacred
emblem
to
be
,
in
his
eyes
,
the
crowning
confusion
of
the
great
,
confused
city
---
<EOS>
so
golden
,
so
high
up
,
so
far
out
of
his
reach
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
sits
,
the
sun
going
down
,
the
river
running
fast
,
the
crowd
flowing
by
him
in
two
streams
---
everything
moving
on
to
some
purpose
and
to
one
end
---
until
he
is
stirred
up
and
told
to
"
move
on
"
too
.
    
Chapter
20
.
<EOS>
A
New
Lodger
 
<EOS>
The
long
vacation
saunters
on
towards
term
-
time
like
an
idle
river
very
leisurely
strolling
down
a
flat
country
to
the
sea
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
saunters
along
with
it
congenially
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
blunted
the
blade
of
his
penknife
and
broken
the
point
off
by
sticking
that
instrument
into
his
desk
in
every
direction
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
he
bears
the
desk
any
ill
will
,
but
he
must
do
something
,
and
it
must
be
something
of
an
unexciting
nature
,
which
will
lay
neither
his
physical
nor
his
intellectual
energies
under
too
heavy
contribution
.
 
<EOS>
He
finds
that
nothing
agrees
with
him
so
well
as
to
make
little
gyrations
on
one
leg
of
his
stool
,
and
stab
his
desk
,
and
gape
.
   
<EOS>
Kenge
and
Carboy
are
out
of
town
,
and
the
articled
clerk
has
taken
out
a
shooting
license
and
gone
down
to
his
father
's
,
and
Mr
Guppy
's
two
fellow
-
stipendiaries
are
away
on
leave
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
and
Mr
Richard
Carstone
divide
the
dignity
of
the
office
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Carstone
is
for
the
time
being
established
in
Kenge
's
room
,
<EOS>
whereat
Mr
Guppy
chafes
.
 
<EOS>
So
exceedingly
that
he
with
biting
sarcasm
informs
his
mother
,
in
the
confidential
moments
when
he
sups
with
her
off
a
lobster
and
lettuce
in
the
Old
Street
Road
,
that
he
is
afraid
the
office
is
hardly
good
enough
for
swells
,
and
that
if
he
had
known
there
was
a
swell
coming
,
he
would
have
got
it
painted
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
suspects
everybody
who
enters
on
the
occupation
of
a
stool
in
Kenge
and
Carboy
's
office
of
entertaining
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
sinister
designs
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
clear
that
every
such
person
wants
to
depose
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
be
ever
asked
how
,
why
,
when
,
or
wherefore
,
he
shuts
up
one
eye
and
shakes
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
strength
of
these
profound
views
,
he
in
the
most
ingenious
manner
takes
infinite
pains
to
counterplot
when
there
is
no
plot
,
and
plays
the
deepest
games
of
chess
without
any
adversary
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
source
of
much
gratification
to
Mr
Guppy
,
therefore
,
to
find
the
new
-
comer
constantly
poring
over
the
papers
in
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
,
<EOS>
for
he
well
knows
that
nothing
but
confusion
and
failure
can
come
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
His
satisfaction
communicates
itself
to
a
third
saunterer
through
the
long
vacation
in
Kenge
and
Carboy
's
office
,
to
wit
,
Young
Smallweed
.
   
<EOS>
Whether
Young
Smallweed
(
metaphorically
called
Small
and
eke
Chick
Weed
,
as
it
were
jocularly
to
express
a
fledgling
)
was
ever
a
boy
is
much
doubted
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
now
something
under
fifteen
and
an
old
limb
of
the
law
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
facetiously
understood
to
entertain
a
passion
for
a
lady
at
a
cigar
-
shop
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Chancery
Lane
and
for
her
sake
to
have
broken
off
a
contract
with
another
lady
,
to
whom
he
had
been
engaged
some
years
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
town
-
made
article
,
of
small
stature
and
weazen
features
,
but
may
be
perceived
from
a
considerable
distance
by
means
of
his
very
tall
hat
.
 
<EOS>
To
become
a
Guppy
is
the
object
of
his
ambition
.
 
<EOS>
He
dresses
at
that
gentleman
(
by
whom
he
is
patronized
)
,
talks
at
him
,
walks
at
him
,
founds
himself
entirely
on
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
honoured
with
Mr
Guppy
's
particular
confidence
and
occasionally
advises
him
,
from
the
deep
wells
of
his
experience
,
on
difficult
points
in
private
life
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
has
been
lolling
out
of
window
all
the
morning
after
trying
all
the
stools
in
succession
and
finding
none
of
them
easy
,
and
after
several
times
putting
his
head
into
the
iron
safe
with
a
notion
of
cooling
it
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
has
been
twice
dispatched
for
effervescent
drinks
,
and
has
twice
mixed
them
in
the
two
official
tumblers
and
stirred
them
up
with
the
ruler
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
propounds
for
Mr
Smallweed
's
consideration
the
paradox
that
the
more
you
drink
the
thirstier
you
are
and
reclines
his
head
upon
the
window
-
sill
in
a
state
of
hopeless
languor
.
   
<EOS>
While
thus
looking
out
into
the
shade
of
Old
Square
,
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
surveying
the
intolerable
bricks
and
mortar
,
Mr
Guppy
becomes
conscious
of
a
manly
whisker
emerging
from
the
cloistered
walk
below
and
turning
itself
up
in
the
direction
of
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
a
low
whistle
is
wafted
through
the
Inn
and
a
suppressed
voice
cries
,
"
Hip
!
 
<EOS>
Gup
-
py
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
do
n't
mean
it
!
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
<EOS>
aroused
.
 
<EOS>
"
Small
!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
Jobling
!
"
 
<EOS>
Small
's
head
looks
out
of
window
too
and
nods
to
Jobling
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
have
you
sprung
up
from
?
"
<EOS>
inquires
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
.
   
<EOS>
"
From
the
market
-
gardens
down
by
Deptford
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
stand
it
any
longer
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
enlist
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
'd
lend
me
half
a
crown
.
<EOS>
Upon
my
soul
,
I
'm
hungry
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jobling
looks
hungry
and
also
has
the
appearance
of
having
run
to
seed
in
the
market
-
gardens
down
by
Deptford
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
Just
throw
out
half
a
crown
if
you
have
got
one
to
spare
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
get
some
dinner
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
come
and
dine
with
me
?
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
throwing
out
the
coin
,
which
Mr
Jobling
catches
neatly
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
long
should
I
have
to
hold
out
?
"
says
Jobling
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
half
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
only
waiting
here
till
the
enemy
goes
,
returns
Mr
Guppy
,
butting
inward
with
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
enemy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
new
one
.
 
<EOS>
Going
to
be
articled
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
wait
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Can
you
give
a
fellow
anything
to
read
in
the
meantime
?
"
says
Mr
Jobling
.
   
<EOS>
Smallweed
suggests
the
law
list
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Jobling
declares
with
much
earnestness
that
he
"
ca
n't
stand
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
the
paper
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
shall
bring
it
down
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
had
better
not
be
seen
about
here
.
 
<EOS>
Sit
on
our
staircase
and
read
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
quiet
place
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jobling
nods
intelligence
and
acquiescence
.
 
<EOS>
The
sagacious
Smallweed
supplies
him
with
the
newspaper
and
occasionally
drops
his
eye
upon
him
from
the
landing
as
a
precaution
against
his
becoming
disgusted
with
waiting
and
making
an
untimely
departure
.
<EOS>
At
last
the
enemy
retreats
,
and
then
Smallweed
fetches
Mr
Jobling
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
and
how
are
you
?
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
shaking
hands
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
so
.
 
<EOS>
How
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
replying
that
he
is
not
much
to
boast
of
<EOS>
,
Mr
Jobling
ventures
on
the
question
,
"
How
is
SHE
?
"
 
<EOS>
This
Mr
Guppy
resents
as
a
liberty
,
retorting
,
"
Jobling
<EOS>
,
there
ARE
chords
in
the
human
mind
---
"
 
Jobling
begs
pardon
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Any
subject
but
that
!
<EOS>
"
says
Mr
Guppy
with
a
gloomy
enjoyment
of
his
injury
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
there
ARE
chords
,
Jobling
---
"
   
Mr
Jobling
begs
pardon
again
.
   
<EOS>
During
this
short
colloquy
,
the
active
Smallweed
,
who
is
of
the
dinner
party
,
has
written
in
legal
characters
on
a
slip
of
paper
,
"
Return
immediately
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
notification
to
all
whom
it
may
concern
<EOS>
,
he
inserts
in
the
letter
-
box
,
and
then
putting
on
the
tall
hat
at
the
angle
of
inclination
at
which
Mr
Guppy
wears
his
,
informs
his
patron
that
they
may
now
make
themselves
scarce
.
   
<EOS>
Accordingly
they
betake
themselves
to
a
neighbouring
dining
-
house
,
of
the
class
known
among
its
frequenters
by
the
denomination
slap
-
bang
,
where
the
waitress
,
a
bouncing
young
female
of
forty
,
is
supposed
to
have
made
some
impression
on
the
susceptible
Smallweed
,
of
whom
it
may
be
remarked
that
he
is
a
weird
changeling
to
whom
years
are
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
He
stands
precociously
possessed
of
centuries
of
owlish
wisdom
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
ever
lay
in
a
cradle
,
it
seems
as
if
he
must
have
lain
there
in
a
tail
-
coat
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
an
old
,
old
eye
,
has
Smallweed
;
and
he
drinks
and
smokes
in
a
monkeyish
way
;
and
his
neck
is
stiff
in
his
collar
;
and
he
is
never
to
be
taken
in
;
and
he
knows
all
about
it
,
whatever
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
in
his
bringing
up
he
has
been
so
nursed
by
Law
and
Equity
that
he
has
become
a
kind
of
fossil
imp
,
to
account
for
whose
terrestrial
existence
it
is
reported
at
the
public
offices
that
his
father
was
John
Doe
and
his
mother
the
only
female
member
of
the
Roe
family
,
also
that
his
first
long
-
clothes
were
made
from
a
blue
bag
.
   
<EOS>
Into
the
dining
-
house
,
unaffected
by
the
seductive
show
in
the
window
of
artificially
whitened
cauliflowers
and
poultry
,
verdant
baskets
of
peas
,
coolly
blooming
cucumbers
,
and
joints
ready
for
the
spit
,
Mr
Smallweed
leads
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
They
know
him
there
and
defer
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
his
favourite
box
,
he
bespeaks
all
the
papers
,
he
is
down
upon
bald
patriarchs
,
who
keep
them
more
than
ten
minutes
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
of
no
use
trying
him
with
anything
less
than
a
full
-
sized
"
bread
"
or
proposing
to
him
any
joint
in
cut
unless
it
is
in
the
very
best
cut
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
matter
of
gravy
he
is
adamant
.
   
<EOS>
Conscious
of
his
elfin
power
and
submitting
to
his
dread
experience
<EOS>
,
Mr
Guppy
consults
him
in
the
choice
of
that
day
's
banquet
,
turning
an
appealing
look
towards
him
as
the
waitress
repeats
the
catalogue
of
viands
and
saying
"
What
do
YOU
take
,
Chick
?
"
 
<EOS>
Chick
,
out
of
the
profundity
of
his
artfulness
,
preferring
"
veal
and
ham
and
French
beans
---
and
do
n't
you
forget
the
stuffing
,
Polly
"
<EOS>
(
with
an
unearthly
cock
of
his
venerable
eye
)
,
Mr
Guppy
and
Mr
Jobling
give
the
like
order
.
 
<EOS>
Three
pint
pots
of
half
-
and
-
half
are
superadded
.
 
<EOS>
Quickly
the
waitress
returns
bearing
what
is
apparently
a
model
of
the
Tower
of
Babel
but
what
is
really
a
pile
of
plates
and
flat
tin
dish
-
covers
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
,
approving
of
what
is
set
before
him
,
conveys
intelligent
benignity
into
his
ancient
eye
and
winks
upon
her
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
amid
a
constant
coming
in
,
and
going
out
,
and
running
about
,
and
a
clatter
of
crockery
,
and
a
rumbling
up
and
down
of
the
machine
which
brings
the
nice
cuts
from
the
kitchen
,
and
a
shrill
crying
for
more
nice
cuts
down
the
speaking
-
pipe
,
and
a
shrill
reckoning
of
the
cost
of
nice
cuts
that
have
been
disposed
of
,
and
a
general
flush
and
steam
of
hot
joints
,
cut
and
uncut
,
and
a
considerably
heated
atmosphere
in
which
the
soiled
knives
and
tablecloths
seem
to
break
out
spontaneously
into
eruptions
of
grease
and
blotches
of
beer
,
the
legal
triumvirate
appease
their
appetites
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jobling
is
buttoned
up
closer
than
mere
adornment
might
require
.
 
<EOS>
His
hat
presents
at
the
rims
a
peculiar
appearance
of
a
glistening
nature
,
as
if
it
had
been
a
favourite
snail
-
promenade
.
<EOS>
The
same
phenomenon
is
visible
on
some
parts
of
his
coat
,
and
particularly
at
the
seams
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
the
faded
appearance
of
a
gentleman
in
embarrassed
circumstances
;
even
his
light
whiskers
droop
with
something
of
a
shabby
air
.
   
<EOS>
His
appetite
is
so
vigorous
that
it
suggests
spare
living
for
some
little
time
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
makes
such
a
speedy
end
of
his
plate
of
veal
and
ham
,
bringing
it
to
a
close
while
his
companions
are
yet
midway
in
theirs
,
that
Mr
Guppy
proposes
another
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Guppy
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
,
"
I
really
do
n't
know
<EOS>
but
what
I
WILL
take
another
.
"
   
<EOS>
Another
being
brought
,
he
falls
to
with
great
goodwill
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
takes
silent
notice
of
him
at

until
he
is
half
way
through
this
second
plate
and
stops
to
take
an
enjoying
pull
at
his
pint
pot
of
half
-
and
-
half
(
also
renewed
)
and
stretches

legs
and
rubs

.
 
<EOS>
Beholding

in
which

of
contentment
,
Mr
Guppy
says
,
"
You
are
a
man
again
,
Tony
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
not
quite
yet
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
,
just
born
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
take
any
other

?
 
<EOS>
Grass
?
 
<EOS>
Peas
?
 
<EOS>
Summer

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
Guppy
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

do

what
I
WILL

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Order

;

)

"
Without
slugs
,
Polly
!
"
 
And

produced
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
growing
up
,
Guppy
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
,
plying
his
knife
and

with

relishing

.
   
<EOS>
"
Glad
to
hear

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
fact
,
I
have
just
turned
into
my
teens
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
.
   
<EOS>
He

no
more
until

,
which
he
achieves
as
Messrs.
Guppy
and
Smallweed
finish
theirs
,
thus

over
the
ground
in
excellent
style
and
beating
those
two
gentlemen
easily
by
a
veal
and
ham

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Small
,
"
says
Mr

,
"
what

about

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Marrow
puddings
,
"
says
Mr
Smallweed
instantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
!
"
<EOS>

Mr
Jobling
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
there
,

?
 
<EOS>
Thank

,
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
,
I
do

what
I
WILL

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Three
marrow

,
Mr
Jobling
adds
in
a

that
he
is
coming
of
age

.
 
<EOS>
To

succeed
,
by

Mr
Smallweed
,
"
three
Cheshires
,
"
and
to

"
three

rums
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
This
apex
of
the

happily

,
Mr
Jobling
puts
up
his

on
the
carpeted

(
having

the
box
to

)
,
leans

,
and

,
"
I
am

,
Guppy
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
arrived

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

,

,
"

,
"
about
---
<EOS>
you
do

mind
Smallweed
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
the
least
in

worid
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
the
pleasure
of
drinking
his
good
health
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
to
you
!
"
says
Mr
Smallweed
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was

,
what

NOW
,
"
pursues

Guppy
,
"
of

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

I

,
"
returns

Jobling
,
"
is
one
thing
,
my
dear
Guppy
,
and
what
I
may
think
before
dinner
is
another

.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
even
after
dinner
,
I
ask
myself

,
What
am
I
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
How
am
I
to
live
?
 
<EOS>
Ill
<EOS>
fo
manger
,
you
know
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
,
pronouncing
that

as

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ill
<EOS>
fo
manger
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
French
saying
,
and
mangering
is
as
necessary

me

it
is

Frenchman
.
 
<EOS>
Or
more
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
is
decidedly
of
opinion
"
much
more

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
any
man

told
me
,
"

,
"

you

,

,

---
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

Chesney

.
   
<EOS>
"
Chesney
Wold
.
 
<EOS>
(
I

.
)
<EOS>
If

as
I

,
I
should

---
<EOS>
well
,
I
should

pitched

him
,
"

Mr
Jobling
,

rum
-
and

;
"
I
should

let

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Still
,
Tony
,
you

on

wrong

of

post
then
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
talking
about
nothing
else
in

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Guppy
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
,
"
I
will
not

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
on
the
wrong
side
of
the
post
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
trusted
to
things
coming
round
.
"
   
<EOS>
That
very
popular
trust
in
flat
things
coming
round
!
 
<EOS>
Not
in
their
being
beaten
round
,
or
worked
round
,
but
in
their
"
coming
"
round
!
<EOS>
As

lunatic
should
trust
in
the
world
's
"
coming
"
triangular
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
confident

that

would
come
round
and
be
all
square
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
with
some

expression
and
perhaps

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
was
disappointed
.
 
<EOS>
They
never
did
.
<EOS>
And
when
it
came
to
creditors
making
rows
at
the
office
and
to

that
the
office
dealt
with
making

about
dirty

of

,
why
there

an
end

.
<EOS>
And

any
new

connexion

,
for
if
I

-
morrow
,
it

be
mentioned
and
would
sew
me
up
.
<EOS>
Then
what
's
a
fellow
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
keeping

the
way
and
living
cheap
down
about
the
market
-
gardens
,
but
what
's
the
use
of
living
cheap
when
you
have
got
no

?
 
<EOS>
You
might
as
well
live
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Better
,
"
Mr
Smallweed
thinks
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Certainly
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
the

way
;
and
fashion
and

have
been
my

,

n't

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
great
weaknesses
---
Damme
,

,
they
are
great
.
<EOS>
Well
,
"

Mr
Jobling
after

rum
-

-

,
"
what

fellow

,

,
BUT

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
comes
more
fully
into
the

to
state
what
,

,
a
fellow
can
do
.
 
<EOS>
His

is
the
gravely

manner
of
a
man
who
has
not
committed
himself
in
life
otherwise
than
as
he
has

.
   
<EOS>
"
Jobling
,
"

,
"

Smallweed
---
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

modestly

,
"
Gentlemen

!
"
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
---
Have

this

more

since
you
---
"
   
"
Say
,
got

!
"
<EOS>

Mr
Jobling

.
 
<EOS>
"
Say

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
-
o
-
o
!
 
<EOS>
Left

Inn
,
"
Mr
Smallweed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Since

,

,
"

;
"

a

I

.
 
<EOS>
You

Snagsby

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

,

,

AM

,
"
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,

!
 
<EOS>
I

with
him
through
some

that

.
 
<EOS>
Those

it

offer

.
 
<EOS>
They
may
---
or
they

not
---
have
some

to

which
may
---
or

---

shadow
on
my
existence
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
it
is
Mr
Guppy
's
perplexing
way
with
boastful
misery
to
tempt
his
particular
friends
into
this
subject
,
and
the
moment
they
touch
it
,
to
turn
on
them
with
that
trenchant
severity
about
the
chords
in
the
human
mind
,
both
Mr
Jobling
and
Mr
Smallweed
decline
the
pitfall
by
remaining
silent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Such
things
may
be
,
"
repeats
Mr
Guppy
,
"
or
they
may
not
be
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
no
part
of
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
enough
to
mention
that
both
Mr
and
Mrs
Snagsby
are
very
willing
to
oblige
me
and
that
Snagsby
has
,
in
busy
times
,
a
good
deal
of
copying
work
to
give
out
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
all
Tulkinghorn
's
,
and
an
excellent
business
besides
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
if
our
mutual
friend
Smallweed
were
put
into
the
box
,
he
could
prove
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
nods
and
appears
greedy
to
be
sworn
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
gentlemen
of
the
jury
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
"
---
<EOS>
I
mean
,
now
,
Jobling
---
you
may
say
this
is
a
poor
prospect
of
a
living
.
 
<EOS>
Granted
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
better
than
nothing
,
and
better
than
enlistment
.
 
<EOS>
You
want
time
.
 
<EOS>
There
must
be
time
for
these
late
affairs
to
blow
over
.
 
<EOS>
You
might
live
through
it
on
much
worse
terms
than
by
writing
for
Snagsby
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jobling
is
about
to
interrupt
when
the
sagacious
Smallweed
checks
him
with
a
dry
cough
and
the
words
,
"
Hem
!
 
Shakspeare
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
are
two
branches
to
this
subject
,
Jobling
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
.
<EOS>
"
That
is
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
come
to
the
second
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
Krook
,
the
Chancellor
,
across
the
lane
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
Jobling
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
in
his
encouraging
cross
-
examination
-
tone
,
"
I
think
you
know
Krook
,
the
Chancellor
,
across
the
lane
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
him
by
sight
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
him
by
sight
.
 
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
know
little
Flite
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Everybody
knows
her
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
.
   
<EOS>
"
Everybody
knows
her
.
 
<EOS>
VERY
well
.
 
<EOS>
Now
it
has
been
one
of
my
duties
of
late
to
pay
Flite
a
certain
weekly
allowance
,
deducting
from
it
the
amount
of
her
weekly
rent
,
which
I
have
paid
(
in
consequence
of
instructions
I
have
received
)
to
Krook
himself
,
regularly
in
her
presence
.
 
<EOS>
This
has
brought
me
into
communication
with
Krook
and
into
a
knowledge
of
his
house
and
his
habits
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
he
has
a
room
to
let
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
live
there
at
a
very
low
charge
under
any
name
you
like
,
as
quietly
as
if
you
were
a
hundred
miles
off
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
ask
no
questions
and
would
accept
you
as
a
tenant
at
a
word
from
me
---
 
before
the
clock
strikes
,
if
you
chose
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
tell
you
another
thing
,
Jobling
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
who
has
suddenly
lowered
his
voice
and
become
familiar
again
,
"
<EOS>
he
's
an
extraordinary
old
chap
---
always
rummaging
among
a
litter
of
papers
and
grubbing
away
at
teaching
himself
to
read
and
write
,
without
getting
on
a
bit
,
as
it
seems
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
most
extraordinary
old
chap
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
<EOS>
but
what
it
might
be
worth
a
fellow
's
while
to
look
him
up
a
bit
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
---
"
Mr
Jobling
begins
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
"
returns
Mr
Guppy
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
with
becoming
modesty
,
"
that
I
ca
n't
make
him
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
appeal
to
our
mutual
friend
Smallweed
whether
he
has
or
has
not
heard
me
remark
that
I
ca
n't
make
him
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
bears
the
concise
testimony
,
"
A
few
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
something
of
the
profession
and
something
of
life
,
Tony
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
"
and
<EOS>
it
's
seldom
I
ca
n't
make
a
man
out
,
more
or
less
.
 
<EOS>
But
such
an
old
card
as
this
,
so
deep
,
so
sly
,
and
secret
<EOS>
(
though
I
do
n't
believe
he
is
ever
sober
)
,
I
never
came
across
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
he
must
be
precious
old
,
you
know
,
and
he
has
not
a
soul
about
him
,
and
he
is
reported
to
be
immensely
rich
;
and
whether
he
is
a
smuggler
,
or
a
receiver
,
or
an
unlicensed
pawnbroker
,
or
a
money
-
lender
---
all
of
which
I
have
thought
likely
at
different
times
---
it
might
pay
you
to
knock
up
a
sort
of
knowledge
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
see
why
you
should
n't
go
in
for
it
,
when
everything
else
suits
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jobling
,
Mr
Guppy
,
and
Mr
Smallweed
all
lean
their
elbows
on
the
table
and
their
chins
upon
their
hands
,
and
look
at
the
ceiling
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
time
,
they
all
drink
,
slowly
lean
back
,
put
their
hands
in
their
pockets
,
and
look
at
one
another
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
the
energy
I
once
possessed
,
Tony
!
"
says
Mr
Guppy
with
a
sigh
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
there
are
chords
in
the
human
mind
---
"
   
<EOS>
Expressing
the
remainder
of
the
desolate
sentiment
in
rum
-
and
-
water
,
Mr
Guppy
concludes
by
resigning
the
adventure
to
Tony
Jobling
and
informing
him
that
during
the
vacation
and
while
things
are
slack
,
his
purse
,
"
as
far
as
three
or
four
or
even
five
pound
goes
,
"
will
be
at
his
disposal
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
never
shall
it
be
said
,
"
Mr
Guppy
adds
with
emphasis
,
"
that
William
Guppy
turned
his
back
upon
his
friend
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
latter
part
of
the
proposal
is
so
directly
to
the
purpose
that
Mr
Jobling
says
with
emotion
,
"
Guppy
,
my
trump
,
your
fist
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
presents
it
,
saying
,
"
Jobling
,
my
boy
,
there
it
is
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jobling
returns
,
"
Guppy
,
we
have
been
pals
now
for
some
years
!
"
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
replies
,
"
Jobling
,
we
have
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
then
shake
hands
,
and
Mr
Jobling
adds
in
a
feeling
