,
"
Thank
you
,
Guppy
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
<EOS>
but
what
I
WILL
take
another
glass
for
old
acquaintance
sake
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Krook
's
last
lodger
died
there
,
"
observes
Mr
Guppy
in
an
incidental
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
he
though
!
"
says
Mr
Jobling
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
verdict
.
 
<EOS>
Accidental
death
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
mind
that
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
says
Mr
Jobling
,
"
I
do
n't
mind
it
;
but
he
might
as
well
have
died
somewhere
else
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
devilish
odd
that
he
need
go
and
die
at
MY
place
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jobling
quite
resents
this
liberty
,
several
times
returning
to
it
with
such
remarks
as
,
<EOS>
"
There
are
places
enough
to
die
in
,
I
should
think
!
<EOS>
"
or
,
"
He
would
n't
have
liked
my
dying
at
HIS
place
,
I
dare
say
!
"
   
<EOS>
However
,
the
compact
being
virtually
made
,
Mr
Guppy
proposes
to
dispatch
the
trusty
Smallweed
to
ascertain
if
Mr
Krook
is
at
home
,
as
in
that
case
they
may
complete
the
negotiation
without
delay
.
<EOS>
Mr
Jobling
approving
,
Smallweed
puts
himself
under
the
tall
hat
and
conveys
it
out
of
the
dining
-
rooms
in
the
Guppy
manner
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
returns
with
the
intelligence
that
Mr
Krook
is
at
home
and
that
he
has
seen
him
through
the
shop

door
,
sitting
in
the
back

,
sleeping
"
like
one
o'clock
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
I
'll
pay
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
"
and
we
'll
go
and
see

.
 
<EOS>
Small
,
what
will
it
be
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
,
compelling
the
attendance
of
the
waitress
with
one

of
his

,
instantly
replies
as
follows
:
"
Four
veals
and
hams
is
three
,
and
four
potatoes
is
three
and
four
,
and
one
summer
cabbage
is
three
and
six
,
and
three
marrows
is
four
and
six
,
and
six
breads
is
five
,
and
three
Cheshires
is
five
and
three
,
and
four
half
-
pints
of
half
-
and
-
half
is
six
and
three
,
and
four
small
rums
is
eight
and
three
,
and
three
Pollys
is
eight
and
six
.
 
<EOS>
Eight
and
six
in
half
a
sovereign
,
Polly
,
and
eighteenpence
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
Not
at
all
excited
by
these
stupendous
calculations
,
Smallweed
dismisses
his
friends
with
a
cool
nod
and
remains
behind
to
take
a
little
admiring
notice
of
Polly
,
as
opportunity
may
serve
,
and
to
read
the
daily
papers
,
which
are
so
very
large
in
proportion
to
himself
,
shorn
of
his
hat
,
that
when
he
holds
up
the
Times
to
run
his
eye
over
the
columns
,
he
seems
to
have
retired
for
the
night
and
to
have
disappeared
under
the
bedclothes
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
and
Mr
Jobling
repair
to
the
rag
and
bottle
shop
,
where
they
find
Krook
still
sleeping
like
one
o'clock
,
that
is
to
say
,
breathing
stertorously
with
his
chin
upon
his
breast
and
quite
insensible
to
any
external
sounds
or
even
to
gentle
shaking
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
table
beside
him
,
among
the
usual
lumber
,
stand
an
empty
gin
-
bottle
and
a
glass
.
 
<EOS>
The
unwholesome
air
is
so
stained
with
this
liquor
that
even
the
green
eyes
of
the
cat
upon
her
shelf
,
as
they
open
and
shut
and
glimmer
on
the
visitors
,
look
drunk
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hold
up
here
!
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
giving
the
relaxed
figure
of
the
old
man
another
shake
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Krook
!
 
<EOS>
Halloa
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
it
would
seem
as
easy
to
wake
a
bundle
of
old
clothes
with
a
spirituous
heat
smouldering
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
see
such
a
stupor
as
he
falls
into
,
between
drink
and
sleep
?
"
says
Mr
Guppy
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
this
is
his
regular
sleep
,
"
returns
Jobling
,
rather
alarmed
,
"
it
'll
last
a
long
time
one
of
these
days
,
I
am
thinking
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
always
more
like
a
fit
than
a
nap
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
shaking
him
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Halloa
,
your
lordship
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
he
might
be
robbed
fifty
times
over
!
 
<EOS>
Open
your
eyes
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
much
ado
,
he
opens
them
,
but
without
appearing
to
see
his
visitors
or
any
other
objects
.
 
<EOS>
Though
he
crosses
one
leg
on
another
,
and
folds
his
hands
,
and
several
times
closes
and
opens
his
parched
lips
,
he
seems
to
all
intents
and
purposes
as
insensible
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
alive
,
at
any
rate
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
,
my
Lord
Chancellor
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
brought
a
friend
of
mine
,
sir
,
on
a
little
matter
of
business
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
still
sits
,
often
smacking
his
dry
lips
without
the
least
consciousness
.
 
<EOS>
After
some
minutes
he
makes
an
attempt
to
rise
.
 
<EOS>
They
help
him
up
,
and
he
staggers
against
the
wall
and
stares
at
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Mr
Krook
?
"
says
Mr
Guppy
in
some
discomfiture
.
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
looking
charming
,
Mr
Krook
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
pretty
well
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
in
aiming
a
purposeless
blow
at
Mr
Guppy
,
or
at
nothing
,
feebly
swings
himself
round
and
comes
with
his
face
against
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
remains
for
a
minute
or
two
,
heaped
up
against
it
,
and
then
staggers
down
the
shop
to
the
front
door
.
 
<EOS>
The
air
,
the
movement
in
the
court
,
the
lapse
of
time
,
or
the
combination
of
these
things
recovers
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
comes
back
pretty
steadily
,
adjusting
his
fur
cap
on
his
head
and
looking
keenly
at
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
servant
,
gentlemen
;
I
've
been
dozing
.
 
<EOS>
Hi
!
<EOS>
I
am
hard
to
wake
,
odd
times
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Rather
so
,
indeed
,
sir
,
"
responds
Mr
Guppy
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
 
<EOS>
You
've
been
a
-
trying
to
do
it
,
have
you
?
"
says
the
suspicious
Krook
.
   
<EOS>
"
Only
a
little
,
"
Mr
Guppy
explains
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
's
eye
resting
on
the
empty
bottle
,
he
takes
it
up
,
examines
it
,
and
slowly
tilts
it
upside
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
<EOS>
"
he
cries
like
the
hobgoblin
in
the
story
.
 
<EOS>
"
Somebody
's
been
making
free
here
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
assure
you
we
found
it
so
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
.
 
<EOS>
"
Would
you
allow
me
to
get
it
filled
for
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
certainly
I
would
!
"
<EOS>
cries
Krook
in
high
glee
.
 
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
would
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
mention
it
!
 
<EOS>
Get
it
filled
next
door
---
<EOS>
Sol
's
Arms
---
the
Lord
Chancellor
's
fourteenpenny
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
<EOS>
,
they
know
ME
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
so
presses
the
empty
bottle
upon
Mr
Guppy
that
that
gentleman
,
with
a
nod
to
his
friend
,
accepts
the
trust
and
hurries
out
and
hurries
in
again
with
the
bottle
filled
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
receives
it
in
his
arms
like
a
beloved
grandchild
and
pats
it
tenderly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
I
say
,
"
he
whispers
,
with
his
eyes
screwed
up
,
after
tasting
it
,
"
this
ai
n't
the
Lord
Chancellor
's
fourteenpenny
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
eighteenpenny
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
might
like
that
better
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
nobleman
,
sir
,
"
returns
Krook
with
another
taste
,
and
his
hot
breath
seems
to
come
towards
them
like
a
flame
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
baron
of
the
land
.
"
   
<EOS>
Taking
advantage
of
this
auspicious
moment
,
Mr
Guppy
presents
his
friend
under
the
impromptu
name
of
Mr
Weevle
and
states
the
object
of
their
visit
.
 
<EOS>
Krook
,
with
his
bottle
under
his
arm
(
he
never
gets
beyond
a
certain
point
of
either
drunkenness
or
sobriety
)
,
takes
time
to
survey
his
proposed
lodger
and
seems
to
approve
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'd
like
to
see
the
room
,
young
man
?
"
<EOS>
he
says
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
good
room
!
 
<EOS>
Been
whitewashed
.
 
<EOS>
Been
cleaned
down
with
soft
soap
and
soda
.
 
<EOS>
Hi
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
worth
twice
the
rent
,
letting
alone
my
company
when
you
want
it
and
such
a
cat
to
keep
the
mice
away
.
"
   
<EOS>
Commending
the
room
after
this
manner
,
the
old
man
takes
them
upstairs
,
where
indeed
they
do
find
it
cleaner
than
it
used
to
be
and
also
containing
some
old
articles
of
furniture
which
he
has
dug
up
from
his
inexhaustible
stores
.
 
<EOS>
The
terms
are
easily
concluded
---
 
for
the
Lord
Chancellor
can
not
be
hard
on
Mr
Guppy
,
associated
as
he
is
with
Kenge
and
Carboy
,
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
,
and
other
famous
claims
on
his
professional
consideration
---
and
it
is
agreed
that
Mr
Weevle
shall
take
possession
on
the
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weevle
and
Mr
Guppy
then
repair
to
Cook
's
Court
,
Cursitor
Street
,
where
the
personal
introduction
of
the
former
to
Mr
Snagsby
is
effected
and
(
more
important
)
<EOS>
the
vote
and
interest
of
Mrs
Snagsby
are
secured
.
 
<EOS>
They
then
report
progress
to
the
eminent
Smallweed
,
waiting
at
the
office
in
his
tall
hat
for
that
purpose
,
and
separate
,
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
explaining
that
he
would
terminate
his
little
entertainment
by
standing
treat
at
the
play
but
that
there
are
chords
in
the
human
mind
which
would
render
it
a
hollow
mockery
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
morrow
,
in
the
dusk
of
evening
,
Mr
Weevle
modestly
appears
at
Krook
's
,
by
no
means
incommoded
with
luggage
,
and
establishes
himself
in
his
new
lodging
,
where
the
two
eyes
in
the
shutters
stare
at
him
in
his
sleep
,
as
if
they
were
full
of
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
Mr
Weevle
,
who
is
a
handy
good
-
for
-
nothing
kind
of
young
fellow
,
borrows
a
needle
and
thread
of
Miss
Flite
and
a
hammer
of
his
landlord
and
goes
to
work
devising
apologies
for
window
-
curtains
,
and
knocking
up
apologies
for
shelves
,
and
hanging
up
his
two
teacups
,
milkpot
,
and
crockery
sundries
on
a
pennyworth
of
little
hooks
,
like
a
shipwrecked
sailor
making
the
best
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
But
what
Mr
Weevle
prizes
most
of
all
his
few
possessions
(
next
after
his
light
whiskers
,
for
which
he
has
an
attachment
that
only
whiskers
can
awaken
in
the
breast
of
man
)
is
a
choice
collection
of
copper
-
plate
impressions
from
that
truly
national
work
<EOS>
The
Divinities
of
Albion
,
or
Galaxy
Gallery
of
British
Beauty
,
representing
ladies
of
title
and
fashion
in
every
variety
of
smirk
that
art
,
combined
with
capital
,
is
capable
of
producing
.
 
<EOS>
With
these
magnificent
portraits
,
unworthily
confined
in
a
band
-
box
during
his
seclusion
among
the
market
-
gardens
,
he
decorates
his
apartment
;
and
as
the
Galaxy
Gallery
of
British
Beauty
wears
every
variety
of
fancy
dress
,
plays
every
variety
of
musical
instrument
,
fondles
every
variety
of
dog
,
ogles
every
variety
of
prospect
,
and
is
backed
up
by
every
variety
of
flower
-
pot
and
balustrade
,
the
result
is
very
imposing
.
   
<EOS>
But
fashion
is
Mr
Weevle
's
,
as
it
was
Tony
Jobling
's
,
weakness
.
<EOS>
To
borrow
yesterday
's
paper
from
the
Sol
's
Arms
of
an
evening
and
read
about
the
brilliant
and
distinguished
meteors
that
are
shooting
across
the
fashionable
sky
in
every
direction
is
unspeakable
consolation
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
To
know
what
member
of
what
brilliant
and
distinguished
circle
accomplished
the
brilliant
and
distinguished
feat
of
joining
it
yesterday
or
contemplates
the
no
less
brilliant
and
distinguished
feat
of
leaving
it
to
-
morrow
gives
him
a
thrill
of
joy
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
informed
what
the
Galaxy
Gallery
of
British
Beauty
is
about
,
and
means
to
be
about
,
and
what
Galaxy
marriages
are
on
the
tapis
,
and
what
Galaxy
rumours
are
in
circulation
,
is
to
become
acquainted
with
the
most
glorious
destinies
of
mankind
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weevle
reverts
from
this
intelligence
to
the
Galaxy
portraits
implicated
,
and
seems
to
know
the
originals
,
and
to
be
known
of
them
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
rest
he
is
a
quiet
lodger
,
full
of
handy
shifts
and
devices
as
before
mentioned
,
able
to
cook
and
clean
for
himself
as
well
as
to
carpenter
,
and
developing
social
inclinations
after
the
shades
of
evening
have
fallen
on
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
At
those
times
,
when
he
is
not
visited
by
Mr
Guppy
or
by
a
small
light
in
his
likeness
quenched
in
a
dark
hat
,
he
comes
out
of
his
dull
room
---
where
he
has
inherited
the
deal
wilderness
of
desk
bespattered
with
a
rain
of
ink
---
and
talks
to
Krook
or
is
"
very
free
,
"
as
they
call
it
in
the
court
,
commendingly
,
with
any
one
disposed
for
conversation
.
<EOS>
Wherefore
,
Mrs
Piper
,
who
leads
the
court
,
is
impelled
to
offer
two
remarks
to
Mrs
Perkins
:
firstly
,
that
if
her
Johnny
was
to
have
whiskers
,
she
could
wish
'em
to
be
identically
like
that
young
man
's
;
and
secondly
,
"
Mark
my
words
,
Mrs
Perkins
,
ma'am
,
and
do
n't
you
be
surprised
<EOS>
,
Lord
bless
you
,
if
that
young
man
comes
in
at
last
for
old
Krook
's
money
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
21
.
<EOS>
The
Smallweed
Family
 
<EOS>
In
a
rather
ill
-
favoured
and
ill
-
savoured
neighbourhood
,
though
one
of
its
rising
grounds
bears
the
name
of
Mount
Pleasant
,
the
Elfin
Smallweed
,
christened
Bartholomew
and
known
on
the
domestic
hearth
as
Bart
,
passes
that
limited
portion
of
his
time
on
which
the
office
and
its
contingencies
have
no
claim
.
 
<EOS>
He
dwells
in
a
little
narrow
street
,
always
solitary
,
shady
,
and
sad
,
closely
bricked
in
on
all
sides
like
a
tomb
,
but
where
there
yet
lingers
the
stump
of
an
old
forest
tree
whose
flavour
is
about
as
fresh
and
natural
as
the
Smallweed
smack
of
youth
.
   
<EOS>
There
has
been
only
one
child
in
the
Smallweed
family
for
several
generations
.
 
<EOS>
Little
old
men
and
women
there
have
been
,
but
no
child
,
until
Mr
Smallweed
's
grandmother
,
now
living
,
became
weak
in
her
intellect
and
fell
(
for
the
first
time
)
into
a
childish
state
.
 
<EOS>
With
such
infantine
graces
as
a
total
want
of
observation
,
memory
,
understanding
,
and
interest
,
and
an
eternal
disposition
to
fall
asleep
over
the
fire
and
into
it
,
Mr
Smallweed
's
grandmother
has
undoubtedly
brightened
the
family
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
's
grandfather
is
likewise
of
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
in
a
helpless
condition
as
to
his
lower
,
and
nearly
so
as
to
his
upper
,
limbs
,
but
his
mind
is
unimpaired
.
 
<EOS>
It
holds
,
as
well
as
it
ever
held
,
the
first
four
rules
of
arithmetic
and
a
certain
small
collection
of
the
hardest
facts
.
 
<EOS>
In
respect
of
ideality
,
reverence
,
wonder
,
and
other
such
phrenological
attributes
,
it
is
no
worse
off
than
it
used
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
that
Mr
Smallweed
's
grandfather
ever
put
away
in
his
mind
was
a
grub
at
first
,
and
is
a
grub
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
In
all
his
life
he
has
never
bred
a
single
butterfly
.
   
<EOS>
The
father
of
this
pleasant
grandfather
,
of
the
neighbourhood
of
Mount
Pleasant
,
was
a
horny
-
skinned
,
two
-
legged
,
money
-
getting
species
of
spider
who
spun
webs
to
catch
unwary
flies
and
retired
into
holes
until
they
were
entrapped
.
 
<EOS>
The
name
of
this
old
pagan
's
god
was
Compound
Interest
.
 
<EOS>
He
lived
for
it
,
married
it
,
died
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Meeting
with
a
heavy
loss
in
an
honest
little
enterprise
in
which
all
the
loss
was
intended
to
have
been
on
the
other
side
,
he
broke
something
---
something
necessary
to
his
existence
,
therefore
it
could
n't
have
been
his
heart
---
and
made
an
end
of
his
career
.
 
<EOS>
As
his
character
was
not
good
,
and
he
had
been
bred
at
a
charity
school
in
a
complete
course
,
according
to
question
and
answer
,
of
those
ancient
people
the
Amorites
and
Hittites
,
he
was
frequently
quoted
as
an
example
of
the
failure
of
education
.
   
<EOS>
His
spirit
shone
through
his
son
,
to
whom
he
had
always
preached
of
"
going
out
"
early
in
life
and
whom
he
made
a
clerk
in
a
sharp
scrivener
's
office
at
twelve
years
old
.
 
<EOS>
There
the
young
gentleman
improved
his
mind
,
which
was
of
a
lean
and
anxious
character
,
and
developing
the
family
gifts
,
gradually
elevated
himself
into
the
discounting
profession
.
 
<EOS>
Going
out
early
in
life
and
marrying
late
,
as
his
father
had
done
before
him
,
he
too
begat
a
lean
and
anxious
-
minded
son
,
who
in
his
turn
,
going
out
early
in
life
and
marrying
late
,
became
the
father
of
Bartholomew
and
Judith
Smallweed
,
twins
.
<EOS>
During
the
whole
time
consumed
in
the
slow
growth
of
this
family
tree
,
the
house
of
Smallweed
,
always
early
to
go
out
and
late
to
marry
,
has
strengthened
itself
in
its
practical
character
,
has
discarded
all
amusements
,
discountenanced
all
story
-
books
,
fairy
-
tales
,
fictions
,
and
fables
,
and
banished
all
levities
whatsoever
.
<EOS>
Hence
the
gratifying
fact
that
it
has
had
no
child
born
to
it
and
that
the
complete
little
men
and
women
whom
it
has
produced
have
been
observed
to
bear
a
likeness
to
old
monkeys
with
something
depressing
on
their
minds
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
present
time
,
in
the
dark
little
parlour
certain
feet
below
the
level
of
the
street
---
a
grim
,
hard
,
uncouth
parlour
,
only
ornamented
with
the
coarsest
of
baize
table
-
covers
,
and
the
hardest
of
sheet
-
iron
tea
-
trays
,
and
offering
in
its
decorative
character
no
bad
allegorical
representation
of
Grandfather
Smallweed
's
mind
---
 
seated
in
two
black
horsehair
porter
's
chairs
,
one
on
each
side
of
the
fire
-
place
,
the
superannuated
Mr
and
Mrs
Smallweed
while
away
the
rosy
hours
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
stove
are
a
couple
of
trivets
for
the
pots
and
kettles
which
it
is
Grandfather
Smallweed
's
usual
occupation
to
watch
,
and
projecting
from
the
chimney
-
piece
between
them
is
a
sort
of
brass
gallows
for
roasting
,
which
he
also
superintends
when
it
is
in
action
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
venerable
Mr
Smallweed
's
seat
and
guarded
by
his
spindle
legs
is
a
drawer
in
his
chair
,
reported
to
contain
property
to
a
fabulous
amount
.
 
<EOS>
Beside
him
is
a
spare
cushion
with
which
he
is
always
provided
in
order
that
he
may
have
something
to
throw
at
the
venerable
partner
of
his
respected
age
whenever
she
makes
an
allusion
to
money
---
a
subject
on
which
he
is
particularly
sensitive
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
where
's
Bart
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Grandfather
Smallweed
inquires
of
Judy
,
Bart
's
twin
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
an't
come
in
yet
,
"
says
Judy
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
his
tea
-
time
,
is
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
much
do
you
mean
to
say
it
wants
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ten
minutes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hey
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ten
minutes
.
"
<EOS>
(
Loud
on
the
part
of
Judy
.
)
   
<EOS>
"
Ho
!
"
says
Grandfather
Smallweed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ten
minutes
.
"
   
Grandmother
Smallweed
,
who
has
been
mumbling
and
shaking
her
head
at
the
trivets
,
hearing
figures
mentioned
,
connects
them
with
money
and
screeches
like
a
horrible
old
parrot
without
any
plumage
,
"
Ten
ten
-
pound
notes
!
"
   
<EOS>
Grandfather
Smallweed
immediately
throws
the
cushion
at
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Drat
you
,
be
quiet
!
"
says
the
good

,
"
I
'll
have
that
girl
in
to
her
tea
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
never
leave
off
if
she
took
it
by
herself
in
the
kitchen
.
"
   
<EOS>
Charley
is
accordingly
introduced
,
and
under
a
heavy
fire
of
eyes
,
sits
down
to
her
basin
and
a
Druidical
ruin
of
bread
and
butter
.
<EOS>
In
the
active
superintendence
of
this
young
person
,
Judy
Smallweed
appears
to
attain
a
perfectly
geological
age
and
to
date
from
the
remotest
periods
.
 
<EOS>
Her
systematic
manner
of
flying
at
her
and
pouncing
on
her
,
with
or
without
pretence
,
whether
or
no
,
is
wonderful
,
evincing
an
accomplishment
in
the
art
of
girl
-
driving
seldom
reached
by
the
oldest
practitioners
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
do
n't
stare
about
you
all
the
afternoon
,
"
cries
Judy
,
shaking
her
head
and
stamping
her
foot
as
she
happens
to
catch
the
glance
which
has
been
previously
sounding
the
basin
of
tea
,
"
but
take
your
victuals
and
get
back
to
your
work
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
miss
,
"
says
Charley
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
yes
,
"
returns
Miss
Smallweed
,
"
<EOS>
for
I
know
what
you
girls
are
.
 
<EOS>
Do
it
without
saying
it
,
and
then
I
may
begin
to
believe
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Charley
swallows
a
great
gulp
of
tea
in
token
of
submission
and
so
disperses
the
Druidical
ruins
that
Miss
Smallweed
charges
her
not
to
gormandize
,
which
"
in
you
girls
,
"
she
observes
,
is
disgusting
.
<EOS>
Charley
might
find
some
more
difficulty
in
meeting
her
views
on
the
general
subject
of
girls
but
for
a

at

.
   
<EOS>
"
See
who
it
is
,
and
do
n't
chew
when
you
open

!
"
<EOS>
cries
Judy
.
   
<EOS>
The
object
of
her
attentions
withdrawing
for
the
purpose
<EOS>
,
Miss
Smallweed
takes
that

of
jumbling
the
remainder
of
the
bread
and
butter
together
and
launching
two
or
three
dirty
tea

into
the
ebb

of
the
basin
of
tea
as
a
hint
that
she
considers
the
eating
and

terminated
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
!
 
<EOS>
Who
is
it
,
and
what
's
wanted
?
"
says
the
snappish
Judy
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
one
Mr
George
,
it
appears
.
 
<EOS>
Without
other

or

,
Mr
George
walks
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whew
!
"
says
Mr
George
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
hot
here
.
 
<EOS>
Always
a
fire
,
eh
?
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
do
right
to
get
used
to
one
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
George
makes
the
latter

as

nods
to
Grandfather
Smallweed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ho
!
<EOS>
It
's
you
!
"
<EOS>
cries
the
old
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
de

?
 
<EOS>
How
de
do
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Middling
,
"
replies
Mr
George
,
taking
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
granddaughter
I
have
had
the
honour
of
seeing
before
;
my
service
to
you
,
miss
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
my
grandson
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
ha'n't
seen

before
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
in
the
law
and
not

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

to

,

!
 
<EOS>
He
is
like

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
very
like

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
devilish

his

,
"
says
Mr
George
,
laying

and
not

on

last

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
does
the
world
use
you
,
Mr
George
?
"
<EOS>
Grandfather
Smallweed
inquires
,
slowly
rubbing
his
legs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
much
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
Like
a
football
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
is
a
swarthy
brown
man
of
fifty
,
well
made
,
and
good
looking
,
with
crisp
dark
hair
,
bright
eyes
,
and
a
broad
chest
.
 
<EOS>
His
sinewy
and
powerful
hands
,
as
sunburnt
as
his
face
,
have
evidently
been
used
to
a
pretty
rough
life
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
curious
about
him
is
that
he
sits
forward
on
his
chair
as
if
he
were
,
from
long
habit
,
allowing
space
for
some
dress
or
accoutrements
that
he
has
altogether
laid
aside
.
 
<EOS>
His
step
too
is
measured
and
heavy
and
would
go
well
with
a
weighty
clash
and
jingle
of
spurs
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
close
-
shaved
now
,
but
his
mouth
is
set
as
if
his
upper
lip
had
been
for
years
familiar
with
a
great
moustache
;
and
his
manner
of
occasionally
laying
the
open
palm
of
his
broad
brown
hand
upon
it
is
to
the
same
effect
.
<EOS>
Altogether
one
might
guess
Mr
George
to
have
been
a
trooper
once
upon
a
time
.
   
<EOS>
A
special
contrast
<EOS>
Mr
George
makes
to
the
Smallweed
family
.
<EOS>
Trooper
was
never
yet
billeted
upon
a
household
more
unlike
him
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
broadsword
to
an
oyster
-
knife
.
 
<EOS>
His
developed
figure
and
their
stunted
forms
,
his
large
manner
filling
any
amount
of
room
and
their
little
narrow
pinched
ways
,
his
sounding
voice
and
their
sharp
spare
tones
,
are
in
the
strongest
and
the
strangest
opposition
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
sits
in
the
middle
of
the
grim

,
leaning
a
little
forward
,
with
his
hands
upon
his
thighs
and
his
elbows
squared
,
he
looks
as

,
if
he

there

,
he
would

into
himself
the
whole

and
the

four

,
extra

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
rub

to
rub

into
'
em
?
"
<EOS>
he

of
Grandfather
Smallweed
after

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

's
partly

,
Mr
George
,
and
<EOS>
---
yes
---
it

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
The
cir
-
cu
-
la
-
tion
!
"
<EOS>
repeats
Mr
George
,
folding
his

and
seeming
to
become
two

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
much
of
that
,
I
should

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Truly
I
'm
old
,
Mr
George
,
"

Smallweed
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
older

HER
,
"
nodding

,
"

?
 
<EOS>
You

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Unlucky

!
"

George
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

old

.
 
<EOS>
Look

,

<EOS>
Hold

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
There

!
 
<EOS>
Think

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
The

's

"
<EOS>
Why

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

have
hands
to
Mr
George
,

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

<EOS>

"

?
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Just

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

---

"
   
"
When

,
"

Mr
George

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Just

.
 
<EOS>
When
there
is
any
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

read
or

?
"
   
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
Stuff
.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Folly
.
 
<EOS>
No
,

"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
I
say
!
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
I

,
when
I
am
a
day

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
friend
!
"
<EOS>
cries

Smallweed
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Never
!
 
<EOS>
Never
,

!
 
<EOS>
But

friend

the
city
that
I

---
HE

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
You
ca

?
"

George
,

"
You

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Devil
doubt

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Charley

,

the

,

,

,

"
How

!
 
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
The
trooper
(
if

he
be
or
have

)
takes

,
with

.
<EOS>
"
You
give
the
house
almost

.
 
<EOS>
It

a

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Then

,

,

to
Mr
Smallweed
's
friend
in
the
city
---
 
<EOS>
the
one
solitary
flight
of
that
esteemed
old

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
you
think
he
might
be
hard
upon
me
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
might
---
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
known
him
do
it
,
"
says
Grandfather
Smallweed
incautiously
,
"
twenty
times
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Incautiously
,
because
his
stricken
better
-
half
,
who
has

for

,

and
<EOS>
jabbers
"
Twenty

,
twenty
twenty
-

in

,
twenty

,
twenty

twenty

cent
,
twenty
---
"

the

,
which
the
visitor
,
to

this
singular
experiment
appears
to
be
a

,
snatches
from
her

as

her
in

usual

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a

.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a

---
a
brimstone

!
 
<EOS>
You
're
a

.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
chattering
clattering

witch
that
ought
to
be

!
"
<EOS>
gasps

old
man
,
prostrate

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
friend
,
will
you
shake
me
up

little
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
,
who
has
been
looking
first
at
one
of
them
and
then
at
the
other
,
as
if
he
were

,
takes
his
venerable

by
the

on

,
and
dragging

upright
in

chalr

if

,

whether
or
no
to
shake
all

of

and

into

.
 
<EOS>
Resisting

,
but
agitating
him
violently
enough
to
make
his
head
roll
like
a

's
,
he
puts
him
smartly
down

chair
again

-

old

.
   
<EOS>
"
O
Lord
!
"
<EOS>

Mr
Smallweed
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
'll
do
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
my
dear
friend
,
that
'll
do
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
dear

,
I
'm
out

.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Smallweed
says

not
without
evident
apprehensions
of
his
dear
friend
,
who
still
stands
over
him
looming

than

.
   
<EOS>
The
alarming
presence
,
however
,
gradually

into

and
falls
to

long

,

with

,
"
The

your
friend

the
city
begins
with

D
,
comrade
,
and
you
're
about

respecting

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
you
speak
,
Mr
George
?
<EOS>
"

old
man
.
   
<EOS>
The
trooper
shakes
his

,
and
leaning

with
his
right

on

and

supported
in

,
while

.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile

Smallweed

and
now

fans

away

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
take
it
,
"
he

"

(

)

pipe

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
But

,
<EOS>
you

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
After

,

soars

those
enchanting

which
its

and

,
and
<EOS>
again
he
and
Mrs
Smallweed
<EOS>
while
away

rosy

,
two

forgotten
as

by

Black
Serjeant
.
   
<EOS>
While
the
twain
are
faithful

,
Mr
George
strides
through

a
massive
kind

and
a
grave
-
enough

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
eight
o'clock
now
,
and
the
day
is
fast
drawing
in
.
 
<EOS>
He
stops
hard
by
Waterloo
Bridge
and
reads

playbill
,
decides
to
go
to
Astley
's
Theatre
.
 
<EOS>
Being
there
,
is
much
delighted
with
the
horses
and
the
feats
of
strength
;
looks
at
the

with

critical

;
disapproves
of
the
combats
as
giving
evidences
of

;
but
is
touched
home
by
the
sentiments
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
last
scene
,
when
the
Emperor
of
Tartary
gets
up

a
cart
and
condescends
to
bless
the
united
lovers
by
hovering
over

with
the
Union
Jack
,
his
eyelashes
are
moistened
with

.
   
<EOS>
The
theatre
over
<EOS>
,
Mr
George
comes
across

water
again
and
makes
his
way
to
that
curious
region
lying
about
the
Haymarket
and
Leicester
Square
which
is
a
centre
of
attraction
to
indifferent
foreign

and
indifferent
foreigners
,
racket
-

,

-
men
,

,

,

,

,

,
and
a
large

of
shabbiness
and

.
<EOS>
Penetrating
to
the
heart
of
this
region
,
he
arrives
by
a

and
a
long

passage
at

of
bare
walls
,
floors
,
roof
-
rafters
,
and
skylights
,
on
the
front
of
which
,
if
it
can
be
said
to
have
any
front
,
is
painted
GEORGE
'S
SHOOTING
GALLERY
,
&
c.
   
Into
George
's
Shooting
Gallery
,
&
c.
,
he
goes
;
and
in
it
there
are
gaslights
(
partly
turned
off
now
)
,
and
two
whitened
targets
for
rifle
-
shooting
,
and
archery
accommodation
,
and
fencing
appliances
,
and
all
necessaries
for
the
British
art
of
boxing
.
 
<EOS>
None
of
these
sports
or
exercises
being
pursued
in
George
's
Shooting
Gallery
to
-
night
,
which
is
so
devoid
of
company
that
a
little
grotesque
man
with
a
large
head
has
it
all
to
himself
and
lies
asleep
upon
the
floor
.
   
<EOS>
The
little
man
is
dressed
something
like
a
gunsmith
,
in
a
green
-
baize
apron
and
cap
;
and
his
face
and
hands
are
dirty
with
gunpowder
and
begrimed
with
the
loading
of
guns
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
lies
in
the
light
before
a
glaring
white
target
,
the
black
upon
him
shines
again
.
 
<EOS>
Not
far
off
is
the
strong
,
rough
,
primitive
table
with
a
vice
upon
it
at
which
he
has
been
working
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
little
man
with
a
face
all
crushed
together
,
who
appears
,
from
a
certain
blue
and
speckled
appearance
<EOS>
that
one
of
his
cheeks
presents
,
to
have
been
blown
up
,
in
the
way
of
business
,
at
some
odd
time
or
times
.
   
<EOS>
"
Phil
!
"
says
the
trooper
in
a
quiet
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
All
right
!
"
<EOS>
cries
Phil
,
scrambling
to
his
feet
.
   
<EOS>
"
Anything
been
doing
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Flat
as
ever
so
much
swipes
,
"
says
Phil
.
 
<EOS>
"
Five
dozen
rifle
and
a
dozen
pistol
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
aim
!
"
 
<EOS>
Phil
gives
a
howl
at
the
recollection
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shut
up
shop
,
Phil
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
Phil
moves
about
to
execute
this
order
,
it
appears
that
he
is
lame
,
though
able
to
move
very
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
speckled
side
of
his
face
he
has
no
eyebrow
,
and
on
the
other
side
he
has
a
bushy
black
one
,
which
want
of
uniformity
gives
him
a
very
singular
and
rather
sinister
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
seems
to
have
happened
to
his
hands
that
could
possibly
take
place
consistently
with
the
retention
of
all
the
fingers
,
for
they
are
notched
,
and
seamed
,
and
crumpled
all
over
.
 
<EOS>
He
appears
to
be
very
strong
and
lifts
heavy
benches
about
as
if
he
had
no
idea
what
weight
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
curious
way
of
limping
round
the
gallery
with
his
shoulder
against
the
wall
and
tacking
off
at
objects
he
wants
to
lay
hold
of
instead
of
going
straight
to
them
,
which
has
left
a
smear
<EOS>
all
round
the
four
walls
,
conventionally
called
"
Phil
's
mark
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
custodian
of
George
's
Gallery
in
George
's
absence
concludes
his
proceedings
,
when
he
has
locked
the
great
doors
and
turned
out
all
the
lights
but
one
,
which
he
leaves
to
glimmer
,
by
dragging
out
from
a
wooden
cabin
in
a
corner
two
mattresses
and
bedding
.
 
<EOS>
These
being
drawn
to
opposite
ends
of
the
gallery
,
the
trooper
makes
his
own
bed
and
Phil
makes
his
.
   
<EOS>
"
Phil
!
"
says
the
master
,
walking
towards
him
without
his
coat
and
waistcoat
,
and
looking
more
soldierly
than
ever
in
his
braces
.
<EOS>
"
You
were
found
in
a
doorway
,
were
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gutter
,
"
says
Phil
.
 
<EOS>
"
Watchman
tumbled
over
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
vagabondizing
came
natural
to
YOU
from
the
beginning
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
nat'ral
as
possible
,
"
says
Phil
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
guv'ner
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
can
not
even
go
straight
to
bed
,
but
finds
it
necessary
to
shoulder
round
two
sides
of
the
gallery
and
then
tack
off
at
his
mattress
.
 
<EOS>
The
trooper
,
after
taking
a
turn
or
two
in
the
rifle
-
distance
and
looking
up
at
the
moon
now
shining
through
the
skylights
,
strides
to
his
own
mattress
by
a
shorter
route
and
goes
to
bed
too
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
22
.
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
 
Allegory
looks
pretty
cool
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
,
though
the
evening
is
hot
,
for
both
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
windows
are
wide
open
,
and
the
room
is
lofty
,
gusty
,
and
gloomy
.
 
<EOS>
These
may
not
be
desirable
characteristics
when
November
comes
with
fog
and
sleet
or
January
with
ice
and
snow
,
but
they
have
their
merits
in
the
sultry
long
vacation
weather
.
 
<EOS>
They
enable
Allegory
,
though
it
has
cheeks
like
peaches
,
and
knees
like
bunches
of
blossoms
,
and
rosy
swellings
for
calves
to
its
legs
and
muscles
to
its
arms
,
to
look
tolerably
cool
to
-
night
.
   
<EOS>
Plenty
of
dust
comes
in
at
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
windows
,
and
plenty
more
has
generated
among
his
furniture
and
papers
.
 
<EOS>
It
lies
thick
everywhere
.
 
<EOS>
When
a
breeze
from
the
country
that
has
lost
its
way
takes
fright
and
makes
a
blind
hurry
to
rush
out
again
,
it
flings
as
much
dust
in
the
eyes
of
Allegory
as
the
law
-
or
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
one
of
its
trustiest
representatives
---
may
scatter
,
on
occasion
,
in
the
eyes
of
the
laity
.
   
<EOS>
In
his
lowering
magazine
of
dust
,
the
universal
article
into
which
his
papers
and
himself
,
and
all
his
clients
,
and
all
things
of
earth
,
animate
and
inanimate
,
are
resolving
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
sits
at
one
of
the
open
windows
enjoying
a
bottle
of
old
port
.
 
<EOS>
Though
a
hard
-
grained
man
,
close
,
dry
,
and
silent
,
he
can
enjoy
old
wine
with
the
best
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
priceless
bin
of
port
in
some
artful
cellar
under
the
Fields
,
which
is
one
of
his
many
secrets
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
dines
alone
in
chambers
,
as
he
has
dined
to
-
day
,
and
has
his
bit
of
fish
and
his
steak
or
chicken
brought
in
from
the
coffee
-
house
,
he
descends
with
a
candle
to
the
echoing
regions
below
the
deserted
mansion
,
and
heralded
by
a
remote
reverberation
of
thundering
doors
,
comes
gravely
back
encircled
by
an
earthy
atmosphere
and
carrying
a
bottle
from
which
he
pours
a
radiant
nectar
,
two
score
and
ten
years
old
,
that
blushes
in
the
glass
to
find
itself
so
famous
and
fills
the
whole
room
with
the
fragrance
of
southern
grapes
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
sitting
in
the
twilight
by
the
open
window
,
enjoys
his
wine
.
 
<EOS>
As
if
it
whispered
to
him
of
its
fifty
years
of
silence
and
seclusion
,
it
shuts
him
up
the
closer
.
 
<EOS>
More
impenetrable
than
ever
,
he
sits
,
and
drinks
,
and
mellows
as
it
were
in
secrecy
,
pondering
at
that
twilight
hour
on
all
the
mysteries
he
knows
,
associated
with
darkening
woods
in
the
country
,
and
vast
blank
shut
-
up
houses
in
town
,
and
perhaps
sparing
a
thought
or
two
for
himself
,
and
his
family
history
,
and
his
money
,
and
his
will
---
all
a
mystery
to
every
one
---
and
that
one
bachelor
friend
of
his
,
a
man
of
the
same
mould
and
a
lawyer
too
,
who
lived
the
same
kind
of
life
until
he
was
seventy
-
five
years
old
,
and
then
suddenly
conceiving
(
as
it
is
supposed
)
an
impression
that
it
was
too
monotonous
,
gave
his
gold
watch
to
his
hair
-
dresser
one
summer
evening
and
walked
leisurely
home
to
the
Temple
and
hanged
himself
.
   
<EOS>
But
Mr
Tulkinghorn
is
not
alone
to
-
night
to
ponder
at
his
usual
length
.
 
<EOS>
Seated
at
the
same
table
,
though
with
his
chair
modestly
and
uncomfortably
drawn
a
little
way
from
it
,
sits
a
bald
,
<EOS>
mild
,
shining
man
who
coughs
respectfully
behind
his
hand
when
the
lawyer
bids
him
fill
his
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Snagsby
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
"
to
go
over
this
odd
story
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
you
please
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
told
me
when
you
were
so
good
as
to
step
round
here
last
night
---
"
   
"
For
which
I
must
ask
you
to
excuse
me
if
it
was
a
liberty
,
sir
;
but
I
remember
that
you
had
taken
a
sort
of
an
interest
in
that
person
,
and
I
thought
it
possible
that
you
might
---
just
---
wish
---
to
---
"
   
Mr
Tulkinghorn
is
not
the
man
to
help
him
to
any
conclusion
or
to
admit
anything
as
to
any
possibility
concerning
himself
.
 
<EOS>
So
Mr
Snagsby
trails
off
into
saying
,
with
an
awkward
cough
,
"
I
must
ask
you
to
excuse
the
liberty
,
sir
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
told
me
,
Snagsby
,
that
you
put
on
your
hat
and
came
round
without
mentioning
your
intention
to
your
wife
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
prudent
I
think
,
because
it
's
not
a
matter
of
such
importance
that
it
requires
to
be
mentioned
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
returns
Mr
Snagsby
,
"
you
see
,
my
little
woman
is
---
not
to
put
too
fine
a
point
upon
it
---
inquisitive
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
inquisitive
.
<EOS>
Poor
little
thing
,
she
's
liable
to
spasms
,
and
it
's
good
for
her
to
have
her
mind
employed
.
 
<EOS>
In
consequence
of
which
she
employs
it
---
I
should
say
upon
every
individual
thing
she
can
lay
hold
of
,
whether
it
concerns
her
or
not
---
especially
not
.
 
<EOS>
My
little
woman
has
a
very
active
mind
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
drinks
and
murmurs
with
an
admiring
cough
behind
his
hand
,
"
Dear
me
,
very
fine
wine
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
you
kept
your
visit
to
yourself
last
night
?
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
to
-
night
too
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
and
to
-
night
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
My
little
woman
is
at
present
in
---
 
not
to
put
too
fine
a
point
on
it
---
in
a
pious
state
,
or
in
what
she
considers
such
,
and
attends
the
Evening
Exertions
(
which
is
the
name
they
go
by
)
of
a
reverend
party
of
the
name
of
Chadband
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
great
deal
of
eloquence
at
his
command
,
undoubtedly
,
but
I
am
not
quite
favourable
to
his
style
myself
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
neither
here
nor
there
.
 
<EOS>
My
little
woman
being
engaged
in
that
way
made
it
easier
for
me
to
step
round
in
a
quiet
manner
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
assents
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fill
your
glass
,
Snagsby
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
"
returns
the
stationer
with
his
cough
of
deference
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
wonderfully
fine
wine
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
rare
wine
now
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
fifty
years
old
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
indeed
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
surprised
to
hear
it
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
---
any
age
almost
.
"
 
<EOS>
After
rendering
this
general
tribute
to
the
port
,
Mr
Snagsby
in
his
modesty
coughs
an
apology
behind
his
hand
for
drinking
anything
so
precious
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
run
over
,
once
again
,
what
the
boy
said
?
<EOS>
"
asks
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
putting
his
hands
into
the
pockets
of
his
rusty
smallclothes
and
leaning
quietly
back
in
his
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
pleasure
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Then
,
with
fidelity
,
though
with
some
prolixity
,
the
law
-
stationer
repeats
Jo
's
statement
made
to
the
assembled
guests
at
his
house
.
<EOS>
On
coming
to
the
end
of
his
narrative
,
he
gives
a
great
start
and
breaks
off
with
,
"
Dear
me
,
<EOS>
sir
,
I
was
n't
aware
there
was
any
other
gentleman
present
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
is
dismayed
to
see
,
standing
with
an
attentive
face
between
himself
and
the
lawyer
at
a
little
distance
from
the
table
,
a
person
with
a
hat
and
stick
in
his
hand
who
was
not
there
when
he
himself
came
in
and
has
not
since
entered
by
the
door
or
by
either
of
the
windows
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
press
in
the
room
,
but
its
hinges
have
not
creaked
,
nor
has
a
step
been
audible
upon
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
this
third
person
stands
there
with
his
attentive
face
,
and
his
hat
and
stick
in
his
hands
,
and
his
hands
behind
him
,
a
composed
and
quiet
listener
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
a
stoutly
built
,
steady
-
looking
,
sharp
-
eyed
man
in
black
,
of
about
the
middle
-
age
.
 
<EOS>
Except
that
he
looks
at
Mr
Snagsby
as
if
he
were
going
to
take
his
portrait
,
there
is
nothing
remarkable
about
him
at
first
sight
but
his
ghostly
manner
of
appearing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
mind
this
gentleman
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
in
his
quiet
way
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
only
Mr
Bucket
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
indeed
,
sir
?
"
returns
the
stationer
,
expressing
by
a
cough
that
he
is
quite
in
the
dark
as

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

,

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

"

,
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
"

---

.
"
   
<EOS>
As

,

,
as

,
that

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Now
<EOS>
and

,

-

,
Mr

notices
that

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
Mr
Bucket
,

some

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
For

notices

,

,

<EOS>

Tom
-
all
<EOS>
-

-

,

-

.
 
<EOS>
Between

,

,

,

,

though

---

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

and

so

that

and

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Here
's

!
"
   
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Are

-

,

?
"
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Darby

"
all

,
"

,

"

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
As

Tom
-

-

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
Some

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
Whenever

.
<EOS>
Whenever

,

-

,

,

<EOS>

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Comparison

---

.
 
<EOS>
Toughy
has

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

?
"

,

<EOS>
"
Two

,

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
The

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

.

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

Whereabouts

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Saint

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

the

.
 
<EOS>
"
Jenny
and
me
knows
it
full

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
room
,

two
or

higher
than
the
door
,
is
so
low
that
the

of
the

the

would

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
offensive
to
every

;
even
the
gross

.
 
<EOS>
There
are
a

and

.
 
<EOS>
The

lie
asleep
where
they
stumbled
down
,
but
the
women
sit
by

.
 
<EOS>
Lying
in

of
the
woman

has
spoken
is

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
what
age
do
you
call
that

?
"
says

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

,
as
I
squared
it
myself
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
There
an't
a
doubt
that
it
was
the
other
one
with
this
one
's
dress
on
.
<EOS>
The
boy
was
exact
respecting
colours
and
everything
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
,
I
promised
you
as
a
man
that
he
should
be
sent
away
all
right
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
say
it
was
n't
done
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
kept
your
word
,
sir
,
"
returns
the
stationer
;
"
and
if
I
can
be
of
no
further
use
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
I
think
,
as
my
little
woman
will
be
getting
anxious
---
"
   
"
Thank
you
,
Snagsby
,
no
further
use
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
indebted
to
you
for
the
trouble
you
have
taken
already
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
good
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Mr
Snagsby
,
"
says
Mr
Bucket
,
accompanying
him
to
the
door
and
shaking
hands
with
him
over
and
over
again
,
"
what
I
like
in
you
is
<EOS>
that
you
're
a
man
it
's
of
no
use
pumping
;
that
's
what
YOU
are
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
know
you
have
done
a
right
thing
,
you
put
it
away
,
and
it
's
done
with
and
gone
,
and
there
's
an
end
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
YOU
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
certainly
what
I
endeavour
to
do
,
sir
,
"
returns
Mr
Snagsby
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
you
do
n't
do
yourself
justice
.
 
<EOS>
It
an't
what
you
endeavour
to
do
,
"
says
Mr
Bucket
,
shaking
hands
with
him
and
blessing
him
in
the
tenderest
manner
,
"
it
's
what
you
DO
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
what
I
estimate
in
a
man
in
your
way
of
business
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
makes
a
suitable
response
and
goes
homeward
so
confused
by
the
events
of
the
evening
that
he
is
doubtful
of
his
being
awake
and
out
---
doubtful
of
the
reality
of
the
streets
through
which
he
goes
---
<EOS>
doubtful
of
the
reality
of
the
moon
that
shines
above
him
.
<EOS>
He
is
presently
reassured
on
these
subjects
by
the
unchallengeable
reality
of
Mrs
Snagsby
,
sitting
up
with
her
head
in
a
perfect
beehive
of
curl
-
papers
and
night
-
cap
,
who
has
dispatched
Guster
to
the
police
-
station
with
official
intelligence
of
her
husband
's
being
made
away
with
,
and
who
within
the
last
two
hours
has
passed
through
every
stage
of
swooning
with
the
greatest
decorum
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
the
little
woman
feelingly
says
,
many
thanks
she
gets
for
it
!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
23
.
<EOS>
Esther
's
Narrative
 
<EOS>
We
came
home
from
Mr
Boythorn
's
after
six
pleasant
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
often
in
the
park
and
in
the
woods
and
seldom
passed
the
lodge
where
we
had
taken
shelter
without
looking
in
to
speak
to
the
keeper
's
wife
;
but
we
saw
no
more
of
Lady
Dedlock
,
except
at
church
on
Sundays
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
company
at
Chesney
Wold
;
and
although
several
beautiful
faces
surrounded
her
,
her
face
retained
the
same
influence
on
me
as
at
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
quite
know
even
now
whether
it
was
painful
or
pleasurable
,
whether
it
drew
me
towards
her
or
made
me
shrink
from
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
admired
her
with
a
kind
of
fear
,
and
I
know
that
in
her
presence
my
thoughts
always
wandered
back
,
as
they
had
done
at
first
,
to
that
old
time
of
my
life
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
a
fancy
,
on
more
than
one
of
these
Sundays
,
that
what
this
lady
so
curiously
was
to
me
,
I
was
to
her
---
<EOS>
I
mean
that
I
disturbed
her
thoughts
as
she
influenced
mine
,
though
in
some
different
way
.
<EOS>
But
when
I
stole
a
glance
at
her
and
saw
her
so
composed
and
distant
and
unapproachable
,
I
felt
this
to
be
a
foolish
weakness
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
felt
the
whole
state
of
my
mind
in
reference
to
her
to
be
weak
and
unreasonable
,
and
I
remonstrated
with
myself
about
it
as
much
as
I
could
.
   
<EOS>
One
incident
that
occurred
before
we
quitted
Mr
Boythorn
's
house
,
I
had
better
mention
in
this
place
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
walking
in
the
garden
with
Ada
and
<EOS>
when
I
was
told
that
some
one
wished
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
Going
into
the
breakfast
-
room
where
this
person
was
waiting
,
I
found
it
to
be
the
French
maid
who
had
cast
off
her
shoes
and
walked
through
the
wet
grass
on
the
day
when
it
thundered
and
lightened
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mademoiselle
,
"
she
began
,
looking
fixedly
at
me
with
her
too
-
eager
eyes
,
though
otherwise
presenting
an
agreeable
appearance
and
speaking
neither
with
boldness
nor
servility
,
"
I
have
taken
a
great
liberty
in
coming
here
,
but
you
know
how
to
excuse
it
,
being
so
amiable
,
mademoiselle
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
excuse
is
necessary
,
"
I
returned
,
"
if
you
wish
to
speak
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
my
desire
,
mademoiselle
.
 
<EOS>
A
thousand
thanks
for
the
permission
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
your
leave
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
not
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
in
a
quick
,
natural
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Mademoiselle
,
you
are
so
amiable
!
 
<EOS>
Listen
then
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
left
my
Lady
.
 
<EOS>
We
could
not
agree
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
is
so
high
,
so
very
high
.
 
<EOS>
Pardon
!
 
<EOS>
Mademoiselle
,
you
are
right
!
"
 
<EOS>
Her
quickness
anticipated
what
I
might
have
said
presently
<EOS>
but
as
yet
had
only
thought
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
for
me
to
come
here
to
complain
of
my
Lady
.
<EOS>
But
I
say
she
is
so
high
,
so
very
high
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
a
word
more
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
world
knows
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Assuredly
;
mademoiselle
,
I
am
thankful
for
your
politeness
.
<EOS>
Mademoiselle
,
I
have
an
inexpressible
desire
to
find
service
with
a
young
lady
who
is
good
,
accomplished
,
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
good
,
accomplished
,
and
beautiful
as
an
angel
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
could
I
have
the
honour
of
being
your
domestic
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
---
"
I
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
not
dismiss
me
so
soon
,
mademoiselle
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
with
an
involuntary
contraction
of
her
fine
black

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
hope
a
moment
!
 
<EOS>
Mademoiselle
<EOS>
,
I
know
this
service
would
be
more
retired
than
that
which
I
have
quitted
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
wish
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
this
service
would
be
less
distinguished
than
that
which
I
have
quitted
.
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
wish
that
,
I
know
that
I
should
win
less
,
as
to
wages
here
.
<EOS>
Good
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
content
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
assure
you
,
"
said
I
,
quite
embarrassed
by
the
mere
idea
of
having
such
an
attendant
,
"
that
I
keep
no
maid
---
"
   
"
Ah
,
mademoiselle
,
but
why
not
?
 
<EOS>
Why
not
,
when
you
can
have
one
so
devoted
to
you
!
 
<EOS>
Who
would
be
enchanted
to
serve
you
;
who
would
be
so
true
,
so
zealous
,
and
so
faithful
every
day
!
 
<EOS>
Mademoiselle
,
I
wish
with
all
my
heart
to
serve
you
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
speak
of
money
at
present
.
 
<EOS>
Take
me
as
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
For
nothing
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
so
singularly
earnest
that
I
drew
back
,
almost
afraid
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
Without
appearing
to
notice
it
,
in
her
ardour
she
still
pressed
herself
upon
me
,
speaking
in
a
rapid
subdued
voice
,
though
always
with
a
certain
grace
and
propriety
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mademoiselle
,
I
come
from
the
South
country
where
we
are
quick
and
where
we
like
and
dislike
very
strong
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
was
too
high
for
me
;
I
was
too
high
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
done
---
past
---
<EOS>
finlshed
!
 
<EOS>
Receive
me
as
your
domestic
,
and
I
will
serve
you
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
do
more
for
you
than
you
figure
to
yourself
now
.
 
<EOS>
Chut
!
 
<EOS>
Mademoiselle
<EOS>
,
I
will
---
 
<EOS>
no
matter
,
I
will
do
my
utmost
possible
in
all
things
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
accept
my
service
,
you
will
not
repent
it
.
 
<EOS>
Mademoiselle
,
you
will
not
repent
it
,
and
I
will
serve
you
well
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
how
well
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
lowering
energy
in
her
face
as
she
stood
looking
at
me
while
I
explained
the
impossibility
of
my
engagmg
her
(
without
thinking
it
necessary
to
say
how
very
little
I
desired
to
do
so
)
,
which
seemed
to
bring
visibly
before
me
some
woman
from
the
streets
of
Paris
in
the
reign
of
terror
.
   
<EOS>
She
heard
me
out
without
interruption
and
then
said
with
her
pretty
accent
and
in
her
mildest
voice
,
"
Hey
,
mademoiselle
,
I
have
received
my
answer
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
must
go
elsewhere
and
seek
what
I
have
not
found
here
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
graciously
let
me
kiss
your
hand
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
looked
at
me
more
intently
as
she
took
it
,
and
seemed
to
take
note
,
with
her
momentary
touch
,
of
every
vein
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
I
surprised
you
,
mademoiselle
,
on
the
day
of
the
storm
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
with
a
parting
curtsy
.
   
<EOS>
I
confessed
that
she
had
surprised
us
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
took
an
oath
,
mademoiselle
,
"
she
said
,
smiling
,
"
<EOS>
and
I
wanted
to
stamp
it
on
my
mind
so
that
I
might
keep
it
faithfully
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
will
!
 
<EOS>
Adieu
,
mademoiselle
!
"
   
<EOS>
So
ended
our
conference
,
which
I
was
very
glad
to
bring
to
a
close
.
<EOS>
I
supposed
she
went
away
from
the
village
,
<EOS>
for
I
saw
her
no
more
;
and
nothing
else
occurred
to
disturb
our
tranquil
summer
pleasures
until
six
weeks
were
out
<EOS>
and
we
returned
home
as
I
began
just
now
by
saying
.
   
<EOS>
At
that
time
,
and
for
a
good
many
weeks
after
that
time
,
Richard
was
constant
in
his
visits
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
coming
every
Saturday
or
Sunday
and
remaining
with
us
until
Monday
morning
,
he
sometimes
rode
out
on
horseback
unexpectedly
and
passed
the
evening
with
us
and
rode
back
again
early
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
as
vivacious
as
ever
and
told
us
he
was
very
industrious
,
but
I
was
not
easy
in
my
mind
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
me
that
his
industry
was
all
misdirected
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
find
that
it
led
to
anything
<EOS>
but
the
formation
of
delusive
hopes
in
connexion
with
the
suit
already
the
pernicious
cause
of
so
much
sorrow
and
ruin
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
got
at
the
core
of
that
mystery
now
,
he
told
us
,
and
nothing
could
be
plainer
than
that
the
will
under
which
he
and
Ada
were
to
take
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
many
thousands
of
pounds
must
be
finally
established
if
there
were
any
sense
or
justice
in
the
Court
of
Chancery
---
<EOS>
but
oh
,
what
a
great
IF
that
sounded
in
my
ears
---
and
that
this
happy
conclusion
could
not
be
much
longer
delayed
.
 
<EOS>
He
proved
this
to
himself
by
all
the
weary
arguments
on
that
side
he
had
read
,
and
every
one
of
them
sunk
him
deeper
in
the
infatuation
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
even
begun
to
haunt
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
He
told
us
how
he
saw
Miss
Flite
there
daily
,
how
they
talked
together
,
and
how
he
did
her
little
kindnesses
,
and
how
,
while
he
laughed
at
her
,
he
pitied
her
from
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
never
thought
---
<EOS>
never
,
my
poor
,
dear
,
sanguine
Richard
,
capable
of
so
much
happiness
then
,
and
with
such
better
things
before
him
---
 
<EOS>
what
a
fatal
link
was
riveting
between
his
fresh
youth
and
her
faded
age
,
between
his
free
hopes
and
her
caged
birds
,
and
her
hungry
garret
,
and
her
wandering
mind
.
   
<EOS>
Ada
loved
him
too
well
to
mistrust
him
much
in
anything
he
said
or
did
,
and
my
guardian
,
though
he
frequently
complained
of
the
east
wind
and
read
more
than
usual
in
the
growlery
,
preserved
a
strict
silence
on
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
thought
one
day
when
I
went
to
London
to
meet
Caddy
Jellyby
,
at
her
solicitation
,
I
would
ask
Richard
to
be
in
waiting
for
me
at
the
coach
-
office
,
that
we
might
have
a
little
talk
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
him
there
when
I
arrived
,
and
we
walked
away
arm
in
arm
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Richard
,
"
said
I
as
soon
as
I
could
begin
to
be
grave
with
him
,
"
are
you
beginning
to
feel
more
settled
now
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
,
my
dear
!
"
returned
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
all
right
enough
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
settled
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
mean
,
settled
?
"
returned
Richard
with
his
gay

.
   
<EOS>
"
Settled
in
the
law
,
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
aye
,
"
replied
Richard
,
"
I
'm
all
right
enough
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
said
that
before
,
my
dear
Richard
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
do
n't
think
it
's
an
answer
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
's
not
.
<EOS>
Settled
?
 
<EOS>
You
mean
,
do
I
feel
as

I
were

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
,
I
ca
n't

I
am
settling
down
,
"
said
Richard
,
strongly

"
down
,
"
as

,
"
because
one
ca

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
of

mean
the
---
 
forbidden

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

think

will

?
"

<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

Richard
.
   
<EOS>
We

a
little

,

Richard

in
his

most

:
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Esther
,
I

,
and
I

heaven
<EOS>
I
were

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
for
I

---
better
and

but

.
<EOS>
(
Somehow
,
I
mean
something
that
I
ca
n't

,
but
you
'll

.
)
 
<EOS>
If

,
I

Badger

Kenge

Carboy
like

,

,

---
"
   
"
ARE

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Richard
,
"
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Also
,

.
 
<EOS>
Now

's

;

,
Esther
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know

do

,
"

I.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
kinder
to
me

I
often

,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Esther
,
I
am
a
very
unfortunate
dog
not
to
be
more
settled
,
but
how
CAN
I
be
more
settled
?
 
<EOS>
If
you
lived
in
an
unfinished
house
,
you
could
n't
settle
down
in

;
if
you
were

to

you

unfinished
,
you
would
find
it

;
and
yet

's
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
was

this
unfinished

with
all

,
and
it

before

on

;

,
conscious

that
I
am
but

to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
We
were
in

,

<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Richard
!
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
You
have

,

Ada
's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,

"
I

.
<EOS>
You

,

<EOS>

Ada

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

<EOS>
But

ca

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

---

,

<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
And

,
proved

in

,
that
supposing
he

,

;

---
as

;
this

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>
For
,

,
how

end
<EOS>
,

,

<EOS>
I

To

---
alas

<EOS>
We

,

<EOS>
At

,

.
 
<EOS>
Caddy

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

!

Esther
,
"
Caddy
apologized
,
<EOS>
her
face
suffused
with
blushes
,
"
but
I
generally
call
Prince
my
darling
child
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
laughed
;
and
Caddy
laughed
and
blushed
,
and
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
has
caused
him
,
Esther
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Caused
whom
,
my
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
tiresome
thing
!
"
said
Caddy
,
laughing
,
with
her
pretty
face
on
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
darling
child
,
if
you
insist
upon
it
!
 
<EOS>
This
has
caused
him
weeks
of
uneasiness
and
has
made
him
delay
,
from
day
to
day
,
in
a
very
anxious

.
 
<EOS>
At
last
he
said
to
me
,
"
Caddy
,
if
Miss
Summerson
,
who
is
a
great

with

,

I

,
I

could
do

.
"
 
<EOS>
So
I
promised
I
would

.
 
<EOS>
And
I
made
up

mind
,
besides
,
"
said
Caddy
,
looking
at
me
hopefully
<EOS>
but

,
"
that

,
I

to

Ma
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
what
I
meant
when
I
said

my

that
I

a

.
 
<EOS>
And
if
you
thought

could

,
Esther
,
we

both

very

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
,
Caddy
,
"
said
I
,
pretending
to
consider
.
 
<EOS>
"
Really
,
I
think
I
could
do
a
greater
thing
than
that
if
the
need
were
pressing
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
at
your
service
and
the
darling
child
's
,
my
dear
,
whenever
you
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
Caddy
was
quite
transported
by
this
reply
of
mine
,
being
,
I
believe
,
as
susceptible
to
the
least
kindness
or
encouragement
as
any
tender
heart
that
ever
beat
in
this
world
;
and
after
another
turn
or
two
round
the
garden
,
during
which
she
put
on
an
entirely
new
pair
of
gloves
and
made
herself
as
resplendent
as
possible
that
she
might
do
no
avoidable
discredit
to
the
Master
of
Deportment
<EOS>
,
we
went
to
Newman
Street
direct
.
   
<EOS>
Prince
was
teaching
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
We
found
him
engaged
with
a
not
very
hopeful
pupil
---
a
stubborn
little
girl
with
a
sulky
forehead
,
a
deep
voice
,
and
an
inanimate
,
dissatisfied
mama
---
whose
case
was
certainly
not
rendered
more
hopeful
by
the
confusion
into
which
we
threw
her
preceptor
.
 
<EOS>
The
lesson
at
last
came
to
an
end
,
after
proceeding
as
discordantly
as
possible
;
and
when
the
little
girl
had
changed
her
shoes
and
had
had
her
white
muslin
extinguished
in
shawls
,
she
was
taken
away
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few
words
of
preparation
,
we
then
went
in
search
of
Mr
Turveydrop
,
whom
we
found
,
grouped
with
his
hat
and
gloves
,
as
a
model
of
deportment
,
on
the
sofa
in
his
private
apartment
---
the
only
comfortable
room
in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
have
dressed
at
his
leisure
in
the
intervals
of
a
light
collation
,
and
his
dressing
-
case
,
brushes
,
and
so
forth
,
all
of
quite
an
elegant
kind
,
lay
about
.
   
<EOS>
"
Father
,
Miss
Summerson
;
Miss
Jellyby
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Charmed
!
 
<EOS>
Enchanted
!
"
said
Mr
Turveydrop
,
rising
with
his
high
-

.
 
<EOS>
"
Permit
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
Handing
chairs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
seated
!
"
<EOS>
Kissing
the
tips
of
his
left
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
"
Overjoyed
!
"
 
<EOS>
Shutting
his

and
rolling
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
little
retreat
is
made
a
paradise
.
<EOS>
"
Recomposing
himself
on
the
sofa
like
the
second
gentleman
in
Europe
.
   
<EOS>
"
Again
you
find
us
,
Miss
Summerson
,
"
said
he
,
"
using
our
little
arts
to
polish
,
polish
!
 
<EOS>
Again
the
sex
stimulates
us
and
rewards
us
by
the
condescension
of
its
lovely
presence
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
much
in
these
times
(
and
we
have
made
an
awfully
degenerating
business
of
it
since
the
days
of
his
Royal
Highness
the
Prince
Regent
---
my

,

)

.
 
<EOS>
That

can
yet
bask
in
the
smile
of

,
my
dear

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
nothing
,
which
I
thought

;
and
he
took

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
son
,
"
said
Mr
Turveydrop
,
"
<EOS>
you
have
four

this

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
father
,
"
returned
Prince
,
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
My

father
,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Good

!
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
 
<EOS>
Is

!
 
<EOS>
Or

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Father
,
"

Prince
with

,
"
I

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Engaged
!
"
<EOS>
cried

Turveydrop
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
An
arrow

at

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

,

"

,
"

Miss
Summerson

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Jellyby
is
a
young

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Turveydrop

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

do

!
 
<EOS>
Pray

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Turveydrop

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Boy
,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Strike

,

.
 
<EOS>
Strike

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray

,

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
father
,
that

.
 
<EOS>
Caroline
<EOS>
and

duty
<EOS>
---

,

---

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Strike

,
"

Turveydrop
.
 
<EOS>
"
Strike
home
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
he
seemed
to
listen
,
I

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
father
,
"

Prince
,
"
we
well

little

,
and

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

;

,

---

---
 
our

.
 
<EOS>
You

,
father
;
and
we

truly

or

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Turveydrop
underwent
a
severe

and
came
upright
on
the
sofa
again
with
his
cheeks

over
his
stiff

,
a
perfect
model
of
parental

.
   
<EOS>
"
My
son
!
"
said
Mr
Turveydrop
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
children
!
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
resist
your
prayer
.
 
<EOS>
Be
happy
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
benignity
as
he
raised
his
future
daughter
-
in
-
law
and
stretched
out

hand
to

son
(
who
kissed
it
with
affectionate
respect
and

)
was
the
most
confusing
sight
I
ever
saw
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
children
,
"
said
Mr
Turveydrop
,
paternally
encircling
Caddy
with
his
left

as
she
sat

,
and

right

gracefully
on

hip
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
son
and
daughter
,
your
happiness
shall
be
my
care
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
watch
over
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
always
live
with
me
"
---
<EOS>
meaning
,
of
course
,
I
will
always
live
with
you
---
"
this
house
is
henceforth
as
much
yours
as
mine
;
consider
it
your
home
.
 
<EOS>
May
you
long
live
to
share
it
with
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
power
of
his
deportment
was
such
that
they
really
were
as
much
overcome
with
thankfulness
as
if
,
instead
of
quartering
himself
upon
them
for
the
rest
of
his
life
,
he
were
making
some
munificent
sacrifice
in
their
favour
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
myself
,
my
children
,
"
said
Mr
Turveydrop
,
"
I
am
falling
into
the
sear
and
yellow
leaf
,
and
it
is
impossible
to
say
how
long
the
last
feeble
traces
of
gentlemanly
deportment
may
linger
in
this
weaving
and
spinning
age
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
so
long
,
I
will
do
my
duty
to
society
and
will
show
myself
,
as
usual
,
about
town
.
 
<EOS>
My
wants
are
few
and
simple
.
 
<EOS>
My
little
apartment
here
,
my
few
essentials
for
the
toilet
,
my
frugal
morning
meal
,
and
my
little
dinner
will
suffice
.
 
<EOS>
I
charge
your
dutiful
affection
with
the
supply
of
these
requirements
,
and
I
charge
myself
with
all
the
rest
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
They
were
overpowered
afresh
by
his
uncommon
generosity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
son
,
"
said
Mr
Turveydrop
,
"
for
those
little
points
in
which
you
are
deficient
---
points
of
deportment
,
which
are
born
with
a
man
,
which
may
be
improved
by
cultivation
,
but
can
never
be
originated
---
 
<EOS>
you
may
still
rely
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
faithful
to
my
post
since
the
days
of
his
Royal
Highness
the
Prince
Regent
,
and
I
will
not

now
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
my
son
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
have

father
's
poor

with
a

of
pride
,
you
may
rest

that
he
will
do
nothing
to

.
 
<EOS>
For
yourself
,
Prince
,
whose
character
is
different
<EOS>
(
we

all

,
nor

)
,
work
,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
you
may
depend
I
will
do
,
dear
father
,
with
all

heart
,
"
replied
Prince
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no

it
,
"
said
Mr
Turveydrop
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
qualities
are
not
shining
,
my
dear
child
,
but
they
are
steady
and
useful
.
 
<EOS>
And
to
both

you
,
my
children
,
I
would
merely

,
in
the
spirit

a

whose

,
I

,
SOME
ray

light
,
take
care
of
the
establishment
,
take
care
of
my
simple
wants
,
and
bless
you

!
"
   
<EOS>
Old
Mr
Turveydrop
then
became
so
very
gallant
,
in
honour
of
the
occasion
,
that
I
told
Caddy
we
must
really
go
to
Thavies
Inn
at
once
if
we
were
to
go
at
all
that

.
 
<EOS>
So
we
took
our
departure
after
a
very
loving
farewell
between
Caddy
and
her
betrothed
,
and
during
our
walk
she
was
so
happy
and
so
full
of
old
Mr
Turveydrop
's
praises
that
I
would
not
have
said
a
word
in
his
disparagement
for
any
consideration
.
   
<EOS>
The
house
in
Thavies
Inn
had
bills
in
the
windows
annoucing
that
it
was
to
let
,
and
it
looked
dirtier
and
gloomier
and
ghastlier
than
ever
.
 
<EOS>
The
name
of
poor
Mr
Jellyby
had
appeared
in
the
list
of
bankrupts
but
a
day
or
two
before
,
and
he
was
shut
up
in
the
dining
-
room
with
two
gentlemen
and
a
heap
of
blue
bags
,
account
-
books
,
and
papers
,
making
the
most
desperate
endeavours
to
understand
his
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
They
appeared
to
me
to
be
quite
beyond
his
comprehension
,
for
when
Caddy
took
me
into
the
dining
-
room
by
mistake
and
we
came
upon
Mr
Jellyby
in
his
spectacles
,
forlornly
fenced
into
a
corner
by
the
great
dining
-
table
and
the
two
gentlemen
,
he
seemed
to
have
given
up
the
whole
thing
and
to
be
speechless
and
insensible
.
   
<EOS>
Going
upstairs
to
Mrs
Jellyby
's
room
(
the
children
were
all
screaming
in
the
kitchen
,
and
there
was
no
servant
to
be
seen
)
<EOS>
,
we
found
that
lady
in
the
midst
of
a
voluminous
correspondence
,
opening
,
reading
,
and
sorting
letters
,
with
a
great
accumulation
of
torn
covers
on
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
preoccupied
that
at
first
she
did
not
know
me
,
though
she
sat
looking
at
me
with
that

"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

THEY

,

.
   
<EOS>
They

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Everybody

,

,

of

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
We

,
through
Ada
and

drawing

Caddy
,

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

<EOS>
So

,
"
Come

!
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

,

,
"

"
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Charley
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If

,

<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,

,
"

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
An
Appeal
Case
 
<EOS>
As

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
of
both
of
you
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

is
not

for

standing

to
one

.
 
<EOS>
It

not

,
and
I
must
not

.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
come
,
my
young
cousins
,
begin

!
 
<EOS>
Bygones
shall
be
bygones
,
and
a
new
page
turned
for
you
to
write

in
.
"
   
<EOS>
Richard
gave

at
Ada

said
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
avoided

,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
until

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
,

,

part

.
<EOS>
Leave

.
 
<EOS>
If

do
otherwise
,
you
will
do

,
and
you

made
me

in
ever

.
"
   
<EOS>
A

succeeded
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cousin
Richard
,
"
said
Ada
then
,
raising

"
after
what
our

John
has
said
<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
Your
mind
<EOS>
may
he
quite

,

---

.
<EOS>
I
---

,

,
"

,

"

,

I
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
But

well

,

.
<EOS>
You

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

;
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
Even

;

,
Richard
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

---

<EOS>

"

"

,
Richard
---
for

---
 
<EOS>
and
I
pray
for
a

on

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
It

that
Richard

not

guardian
for

the

of

.
 
<EOS>
But

was

case
.
 
<EOS>
I
observed
with

that
from
this
hour
he
never
was
as
free

with
Mr
Jarndyce

before
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
every

,
but
he

;
and
solely
on
his
side
,
an

began
to

.
   
<EOS>
In
the
business
of

and

he
soon

,
and
even
his
grief
at

from
Ada
,
who
remained
in
Hertfordshire
while
he
,
Mr
Jarndyce
,

for

.
 
<EOS>
He
remembered
her
by
fits

,
even

,
and
at

would

.
 
<EOS>
But
in

he
would

some

by
which
they
were
both
to
be
made
rich

for

,
and
would
become
as
gay
as

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
busy
time
,
and
I
trotted
about
with

all

,
buying
a

of

of

he
stood
in

.
 
<EOS>
Of
the

he
would

if

had
been
left
to
his

I
say
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
perfectly
confidential
with
me
,
and
often
talked
so

and

about
his

and
his
vigorous

,
and
dwelt
so
much
upon
the

that
I

.
   
<EOS>
There

,

,

our

to

Richard
a

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

Force

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Humph
!
 
<EOS>
What

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Mostly

're

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Mad

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mostly

.
 
<EOS>
Six

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A

?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
How

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

and

,

,
"

George
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

that

.
 
<EOS>
One

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

.

<EOS>
Mr

directed

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

---
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
So

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No

,
"

<EOS>
"
I
ca

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

's

,

.

<EOS>
Richard
's

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

his

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
morning
of
the
day
appointed
for
Richard
's

.
<EOS>
We
had
no
more

to
make

;
I
had
completed
all
his
packing
early
in
the
afternoon
;
and
our
time
was
disengaged
until
night
,
when
he
was
to
go
to
Liverpool
for
Holyhead
.
 
<EOS>
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
being
again
expected
to
come
on
that
day
,
Richard
proposed
to
me
that
we
should
go
down
to
the
court
and
hear
what
passed
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
his
last
day
,
and
he
was
eager
to
go
,
and
I
had
never
been
there
<EOS>
,
I
gave
my
consent
and
we
walked
down
to
Westminster
,
where
the
court
was
then
sitting
.
 
<EOS>
We
beguiled
the
way
with
arrangements
concerning
the
letters
that
Richard
was
to
write
to
me
and
the
letters
that
I
was
to
write
to
him
and
with
a
great
many
hopeful
projects
.
 
<EOS>
My
guardian
knew
where
we
were
going
and
therefore
was
not
with
us
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
came
to
the
court
,
there
was
the
Lord
Chancellor
---
the
same
whom
I
had
seen
in
his
private
room
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
---
sitting
in
great
state
and
gravity
on
the
bench
,
with
the
mace
and
seals
on
a
red
table
below
him
and
an
immense
flat
nosegay
,
like
a
little
garden
,
which
scented
the
whole
court
.
 
<EOS>
Below
the
table
,
again
,
was
a
long
row
of
solicitors
,
with
bundles
of
papers
on
the
matting
at
their
feet
;
and
then
there
were
the
gentlemen
of
the
bar
in
wigs
and
gowns
---
some
awake
and
some
asleep
,
and
one
talking
,
and
nobody
paying
much
attention
to
what
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
The
Lord
Chancellor
leaned
back
in
his
very
easy
chair
with
his
elbow
on
the
cushioned
arm
and
his
forehead
resting
on
his
hand
;
some
of
those
who
were
present
dozed
;
some
read
the
newspapers
;
some
walked
about
or
whispered
in
groups
:
all
seemed
perfectly
at
their
ease
,
by
no
means
in
a
hurry
,
very
unconcerned
,
and
extremely
comfortable
.
   
<EOS>
To
see
everything
going
on
so
smoothly
and
to
think
of
the
roughness
of
the
suitors
'
lives
and
deaths
;
to
see
all
that
full
dress
and
ceremony
and
to
think
of
the
waste
,
and
want
,
and
beggared
misery
it
represented
;
to
consider
that
while
the
sickness
of
hope
deferred
was
raging
in
so
many
hearts
this
polite
show
went
calmly
on
from
day
to
day
,
and
year
to
year
,
in
such
good
order
and
composure
;
to
behold
the
Lord
Chancellor
and
the
whole

of
practitioners
under

looking
at
one
another
and
at
the
spectators
as
if
nobody
had
ever
heard
that
all
over
England
<EOS>
the
name
in
which
they
were
assembled
was
a
bitter
jest
,
was
held
in
universal
horror
,
contempt
,
and
indignation
,
was
known
for
something
so
flagrant
and
bad
that
little
short
of
a
miracle
could
bring
any
good
out
of
it
to
any
one
---
this
was
so
curious
and
self

to
me
,
who
had
no

of
it
,
that
it
was
at
first

,
and
I
could
not
comprehend
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
where
Richard
put
me
,
and
tried
to
listen
,
and
looked
about
me
;
but
there
seemed
to
be
no
reality
in
the
whole
scene
except
poor
little
Miss
Flite
,
the
madwoman
,
standing
on
a

and
nodding
at
it
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Flite
soon
espied
us
and
came
to
where
we
sat
.
 
<EOS>
She
gave
me
a
gracious
welcome
to
her
domain
and
indicated
,
with
much
gratification
and
pride
,
its
principal
attractions
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Kenge
also
came
to
speak
to
us
and
did
the
honours
of
the
place
in
much
the
same
way
,
with
the
bland
modesty
of
a

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
very
good
day
for
a
visit
,
he
said
;
he
would
have
preferred
the
first
day
of
term
;
but
it
was
imposing
,
it
was
imposing
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
had

there
half
an

,
the
case
in
progress
---
if

---
seemed

die

,

,

by

,
to

.
 
<EOS>
The
Lord

to

,
and
somebody

,
"
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
.
"
 
<EOS>
Upon

there

a

,

,
and

of

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
I
think
it
came
on
"
for
further
directions
"
---
about
some
bill
of
costs
,
to
the

my

,

was
confused
enough
.
<EOS>
But
I

twenty
-
three

said

"
in

,
"
and
none

They
chatted

it
with

,
and

,
and

this

,
and

,
and

,
and
there

more

,

,

.
<EOS>
After

"

,
"

,

<EOS>
I

Richard
on

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
ca
n't

,

.
 
<EOS>
Better

!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Richard

.
   
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
I

,

.

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Fitz

<EOS>

<EOS>
Gridley

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
that

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
My

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Oh
,

?
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Here

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
Nod

;

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,

!
 
<EOS>
Have

Fleet

?
 
<EOS>
Have

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Then

,

"
Worn

,
Mr
Gridley
?
 
<EOS>
After

?
 
<EOS>
That
ai
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I

!
 
<EOS>
Now

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

n't

.
 
<EOS>
Very

,

;

got
by

Lincoln
's

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
It

;
