the
Chancellor
.
 
<EOS>
Give
in
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
am
surprised
to
hear
a
man
of
your
energy
talk
of
giving
in
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
n't
do
that
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
half
the
fun
of
the
fair
in
the
Court
of
Chancery
.
<EOS>
George
,
you
lend
Mr
Gridley
a
hand
,
and
let
's
see
now
whether
he
wo
n't
be
better
up
than
down
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
very
weak
,
"
said
the
trooper
in
a
low
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
?
"
<EOS>
returned
Bucket
anxiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
only
want
to
rouse
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
to
see
an
old
acquaintance
giving
in
like
this
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
cheer
him
up
more
than
anything
if
I
could
make
him
a
little
waxy
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
welcome
to
drop
into
me
,
right
and
left
,
if
he
likes
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
never
take
advantage
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
roof
rang
with
a
scream
from
Miss
Flite
,
which
still
rings
in
my
ears
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
Gridley
!
"
she
cried
as
he
fell
heavily
and
calmly
back
from
before
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
without
my
blessing
.
 
<EOS>
After
so
many
years
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
sun
was
down
,
the
light
had
gradually
stolen
from
the
roof
,
and
the
shadow
had
crept
upward
.
 
<EOS>
But
to
me
the
shadow
of
that
pair
,
one
living
and
one
dead
,
fell
heavier
on
Richard
's
departure
than
the
darkness
of
the
darkest
night
.
 
<EOS>
And
through
Richard
's
farewell
words
I
heard
it
echoed
:
"
<EOS>
Of
all
my
old
associations
,
of
all
my
old
pursuits
and
hopes
,
of
all
the
living
and
the
dead
world
,
this
one
poor
soul
alone
comes
natural
to
me
,
and
I
am
fit
for
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
tie
of
many
suffering
years
between
us
two
,
and
it
is
the
only
tie
I
ever
had
on
earth
that
Chancery
has
not
broken
!
"
    
Chapter
25
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
Sees
It
All
 
<EOS>
There
is
disquietude
in
Cook
's
Court
,
Cursitor
Street
.
 
<EOS>
Black
suspicion
hides
in
that
peaceful
region
.
 
<EOS>
The
mass
of
Cook
's
Courtiers
are
in
their
usual
state
of
mind
,
no
better
and
no
worse
;
but
Mr
Snagsby
is
changed
,
and
his
little
woman
knows
it
.
   
<EOS>
For
Tom
-
all
-
Alone
's
and
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
persist
in
harnessing
themselves
,
a
pair
of
ungovernable
coursers
,
to
the
chariot
of
Mr
Snagsby
's
imagination
;
and
Mr
Bucket
drives
;
and
the
passengers
are
Jo
and
Mr
Tulkinghorn
;
and
the
complete
equipage
whirls
though
the
law
-
stationery
business
at
wild
speed
all
round
the
clock
.
<EOS>
Even
in
the
little
front
kitchen
where
the
family
meals
are
taken
,
it
rattles
away
at
a
smoking
pace
from
the
dinner
-
table
,
when
Mr
Snagsby
pauses
in
carving
the
first
slice
of
the
leg
of
mutton
baked
with
potatoes
and
stares
at
the
kitchen
wall
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
can
not
make
out
what
it
is
that
he
has
had
to
do
with
.
<EOS>
Something
is
wrong
somewhere
,
but
what
something
,
what
may
come
of
it
,
to
whom
,
when
,
and
from
which
unthought
of
and
unheard
of
quarter
is
the
puzzle
of
his
life
.
 
<EOS>
His
remote
impressions
of
the
robes
and
coronets
,
the
stars
and
garters
,
that
sparkle
through
the
surface
-
dust
of
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
chambers
;
his
veneration
for
the
mysteries
presided
over
by
that
best
and
closest
of
his
customers
,
whom
all
the
Inns
of
Court
,
all
Chancery
Lane
,
and
all
the
legal
neighbourhood
agree
to
hold
in
awe
;
his
remembrance
of
Detective
Mr
Bucket
with
his
forefinger
and
his
confidential
manner
,
impossible
to
be
evaded
or
declined
,
persuade
him
that
he
is
a
party
to
some
dangerous
secret
without
knowing
what
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
is
the
fearful
peculiarity
of
this
condition
that
,
at
any
hour
of
his
daily
life
,
at
any
opening
of
the
shop
-
door
,
at
any
pull
of
the
bell
,
at
any
entrance
of
a
messenger
,
or
any
delivery
of
a
letter
,
the
secret
may
take
air
and
fire
,
explode
,
and
blow
up
---
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
only
knows
whom
.
   
<EOS>
For
which
reason
,
whenever
a
man
unknown
comes
into
the
shop
(
as
many
men
unknown
do
)
and
says
,
"
Is
Mr
Snagsby
in
?
"
or
words
to
that
innocent
effect
,
Mr
Snagsby
's
heart
knocks
hard
at
his
guilty
breast
.
 
<EOS>
He
undergoes
so
much
from
such
inquiries
that
when
they
are
made
by
boys
he
revenges
himself
by
flipping
at
their
ears
over
the
counter
and
asking
the
young
dogs
what
they
mean
by
it
<EOS>
and
why
they
ca
n't
speak
out
at
once
?
 
<EOS>
More
impracticable
men
and
boys
persist
in
walking
into
Mr
Snagsby
's
sleep
and
terrifying
him
with
unaccountable
questions
,
so
that
often
when
the
cock
at
the
little
dairy
in
Cursitor
Street
breaks
out
in
his
usual
absurd
way
about
the
morning
,
Mr
Snagsby
finds
himself
in
a
crisis
of
nightmare
,
with
his
little
woman
shaking
him
and
saying
"
What
's
the
matter
with
the
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
little
woman
herself
is
not
the
least
item
in
his
difficulty
.
<EOS>
To
know
that
he
is
always
keeping
a
secret
from
her
,
that
he
has
under
all
circumstances
to
conceal
and
hold
fast
a
tender
double
tooth
,
which
her
sharpness
is
ever
ready
to
twist
out
of
his
head
,
gives
Mr
Snagsby
,
in
her
dentistical
presence
,
much
of
the
air
of
a
dog
who
has
a
reservation
from
his
master
and
will
look
anywhere
rather
than
meet
his
eye
.
   
<EOS>
These
various
signs
and
tokens
,
marked
by
the
little
woman
,
are
not
lost
upon
her
.
 
<EOS>
They
impel
her
to
say
,
"
Snagsby
has
something
on
his
mind
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
thus
suspicion
gets
into
Cook
's
Court
,
Cursitor
Street
.
 
<EOS>
From
suspicion
to
jealousy
,
Mrs
Snagsby
finds
the
road
as
natural
and
short
as
from
Cook
's
Court
to
Chancery
Lane
.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
jealousy
gets
into
Cook
's
Court
,
Cursitor
Street
.
 
<EOS>
Once
there
(
and
it
was
always
lurking
thereabout
)
,
it
is
very
active
and
nimble
in
Mrs
Snagsby
's
breast
,
prompting
her
to
nocturnal
examinations
of
Mr
Snagsby
's
pockets
;
<EOS>
to
secret
perusals
of
Mr
Snagsby
's
letters
;
to
private
researches
in
the
day
book
and
ledger
,
till
,
cash
-
box
,
and
iron
safe
;
to
watchings
at
windows
,
listenings
behind
doors
,
and
a
general
putting
of
this
and
that
together
by
the
wrong
end
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
is
so
perpetually
on
the
alert
that
the
house
becomes
ghostly
with
creaking
boards
and
rustling
garments
.
 
<EOS>
The
'
prentices
think
somebody
may
have
been
murdered
there
in
bygone
times
.
<EOS>
Guster
holds
certain
loose
atoms
of
an
idea
(
picked
up
at
Tooting
,
where
they
were
found
floating
among
the
orphans
)
that
there
is
buried
money
underneath
the
cellar
,
guarded
by
an
old
man
with
a
white
beard
,
who
can
not
get
out
for
seven
thousand
years
because
he
said
the
Lord
's
Prayer
backwards
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
was
Nimrod
?
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
repeatedly
inquires
of
herself
.
<EOS>
"
Who
was
that
lady
---
that
creature
?
 
<EOS>
And
who
is
that
boy
?
"
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Nimrod
being
as
dead
as
the
mighty
hunter
whose
name
Mrs
Snagsby
has
appropriated
,
and
the
lady
being
unproducible
,
she
directs
her
mental
eye
,
for
the
present
,
with
redoubled
vigilance
to
the
boy
.
"
<EOS>
And
who
,
"
quoth
Mrs
Snagsby
for
the
thousand
and
first
time
,
"
is
that
boy
?
 
<EOS>
Who
is
that
---
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
there
Mrs
Snagsby
is
seized
with
an
inspiration
.
   
<EOS>
He
has
no
respect
for
Mr
Chadband
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
to
be
sure
,
and
he
would
n't
have
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Naturally
he
would
n't
,
under
those
contagious
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
invited
and
appointed
by
Mr
Chadband
<EOS>
---
why
,
Mrs
Snagsby
heard
it
herself
with
her
own
ears
!
<EOS>
---
to
come
back
,
and
be
told
where
he
was
to
go
,
to
be
addressed
by
Mr
Chadband
<EOS>
;
and
he
never
came
!
 
<EOS>
Why
did
he
never
come
?
 
<EOS>
Because
he
was
told
not
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
Who
told
him
not
to
come
?
 
<EOS>
Who
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
sees
it
all
.
   
<EOS>
But
happily
(
and
Mrs
Snagsby
tightly
shakes
her
head
and
tightly
smiles
)
<EOS>
that
boy
was
met
by
Mr
Chadband
yesterday
in
the
streets
;
and
that
boy
,
as
affording
a
subject
which
Mr
Chadband
desires
to
improve
for
the
spiritual
delight
of
a
select
congregation
,
was
seized
by
Mr
Chadband
and
threatened
with
being
delivered
over
to
the
police
unless
he
showed
the
reverend
gentleman
where
he
lived
and
unless
he
entered
into
,
and
fulfilled
,
an
undertaking
to
appear
in
Cook
's
Court
to
-
morrow
night
,
"
to
-
mor
-
row
-
night
,
"
Mrs
Snagsby
repeats
for
mere
emphasis
with
another
tight
smile
and
another
tight
shake
of
her
head
;
and
to
-
morrow
night
that
boy
will
be
here
,
and
to
-
morrow
night
Mrs
Snagsby
will
have
her
eye
upon
him
and
upon
some
one
else
;
and
oh
,
you
may
walk
a
long
while
in
your
secret
ways
(
says
Mrs
Snagsby
with
haughtiness
and
scorn
)
,
but
you
ca
n't
blind
ME
!
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
sounds
no
timbrel
in
anybody
's
ears
,
but
holds
her
purpose
quietly
,
and
keeps
her
counsel
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
morrow
comes
,
the
savoury
preparations
for
the
Oil
Trade
come
,
the
evening
comes
.
<EOS>
Comes
Mr
Snagsby
in
his
black
coat
;
come
the
Chadbands
;
come
(
when
the
gorging
vessel
is
replete
)
<EOS>
the
'
prentices
and
Guster
,
to
be
edified
;
comes
at
last
,
with
his
slouching
head
,
and
his
shuflle
backward
,
and
his
shuffle
forward
,
and
his
shuffle
to
the
right
,
and
his
shuffle
to
the
left
,
and
his
bit
of
fur
cap
in
his
muddy
hand
,
which
he
picks
as
if
it
were
some
mangy
bird
he
had
caught
and
was
plucking
before
eating
raw
,
Jo
,
the
very
,
very
tough
subject
Mr
Chadband
is
to
improve
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
screws
a
watchful
glance
on
Jo
as
he
is
brought
into
the
little
drawing
-
room
by
Guster
.
 
<EOS>
He
looks
at
Mr
Snagsby
the
moment
he
comes
in
.
 
<EOS>
Aha
!
 
<EOS>
Why
does
he
look
at
Mr
Snagsby
?
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
looks
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
he
do
that
,
but
that
Mrs
Snagsby
sees
it
all
?
 
<EOS>
Why
else
should
that
look
pass
between
them
,
why
else
should
Mr
Snagsby
be
confused
and
cough
a
signal
cough
behind
his
hand
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
as
clear
as
crystal
that
Mr
Snagsby
is
that
boy
's
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
Peace
,
my
friends
,
"
says
Chadband
,
rising
and
wiping
the
oily
exudations
from
his
reverend
visage
.
 
<EOS>
"
Peace
be
with
us
!
 
<EOS>
My
friends
,
why
with
us
?
 
<EOS>
Because
,
"
with
his
fat
smile
,
"
it
can
not
be
against
us
,
because
it
must
be
for
us
;
because
it
is
not
hardening
,
because
it
is
softening
;
because
it
does
not
make
war
like
the
hawk
,
but
comes
home
unto
us
like
the
dove
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
my
friends
,
peace
be
with
us
!
 
<EOS>
My
human
boy
,
come
forward
!
"
   
<EOS>
Stretching
forth
his
flabby
paw
,
Mr
Chadband
lays
the
same
on
Jo
's
arm
and
considers
where
to
station
him
.
 
<EOS>
Jo
,
very
doubtful
of
his
reverend
friend
's
intentions
and
not
at
all
clear
but
that
something
practical
and
painful
is
going
to
be
done
to
him
,
mutters
,
"
You
let
me
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
said
nothink
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
let
me
alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
young
friend
,
"
says
Chadband
smoothly
,
"
I
will
not
let
you
alone
.
 
<EOS>
And
why
?
 
<EOS>
Because
I
am
a
harvest
-
labourer
,
because
I
am
a
toiler
and
a
moiler
,
because
you
are
delivered
over
unto
me
and
are
become
as
a
precious
instrument
in
my
hands
.
 
<EOS>
My
friends
,
may
I
so
employ
this
instrument
as
to
use
it
to
your
advantage
,
to
your
profit
,
to
your
gain
,
to
your
welfare
,
to
your
enrichment
!
 
<EOS>
My
young
friend
,
sit
upon
this
stool
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jo
,
apparently
possessed
by
an
impression
that
the
reverend
gentleman
wants
to
cut
his
hair
,
shields
his
head
with
both
arms
and
is
got
into
the
required
position
with
great
difficulty
and
every
possible
manifestation
of
reluctance
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
is
at
last
adjusted
like
a
lay
-
figure
,
Mr
Chadband
,
retiring
behind
the
table
,
holds
up
his
bear's
-
paw
and
says
,
"
My
friends
!
"
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
signal
for
a
general
settlement
of
the
audience
.
 
<EOS>
The
'
prentices
giggle
internally
and
nudge
each
other
.
<EOS>
Guster
falls
into
a
staring
and
vacant
state
,
compounded
of
a
stunned
admiration
of
Mr
Chadband
and
pity
for
the
friendless
outcast
whose
condition
touches
her
nearly
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
silently
lays
trains
of
gunpowder
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Chadband
composes
herself
grimly
by
the
fire
and
warms
her
knees
,
finding
that
sensation
favourable
to
the
reception
of
eloquence
.
   
<EOS>
It
happens
that
Mr
Chadband
has
a
pulpit
habit
of
fixing
some
member
of
his
congregation
with
his
eye
and
fatly

his
points
with
that
particular
person
,
who
is
understood
to
be
expected

inward

,
which
expression
of

,

so

,

of

and

Chadband
's

.
 
<EOS>

My

!
"

,

<EOS>

constant
than
his
own
,
hardly
less
quiet
than
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
And
into
whatsoever
atmosphere
of
secrecy
his
own
shadow
may
pass
,
let
all
concerned
in
the
secrecy
beware
!
 
<EOS>
For
the
watchful
Mrs
Snagsby
is
there
too
---
bone
of
his
bone
,
flesh
of
his
flesh
,
shadow
of
his
shadow
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
26
.
<EOS>
Sharpshooters
 
<EOS>
Wintry
morning
,
looking
with
dull
eyes
and
sallow
face
upon
the
neighbourhood
of
Leicester
Square
,
finds
its
inhabitants
unwilling
to
get
out
of
bed
.
 
<EOS>
Many
of
them
are
not
early
risers
at
the
brightest
of
times
,
being
birds
of
night
who
roost
when
the
sun
is
high
and
are
wide
awake
and
keen
for
prey
when
the
stars
shine
out
.
<EOS>
Behind
dingy
blind
and
curtain
,
in
upper
story
and
garret
,
skulking
more
or
less
under
false
names
,
false
hair
,
false
titles
,
false
jewellery
,
and
false
histories
,
a
colony
of
brigands
lie
in
their
first
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen
of
the
green
-
baize
road
who
could
discourse
from
personal
experience
of
foreign
galleys
and
home
treadmills
;
spies
of
strong
governments
that
eternally
quake
with
weakness
and
miserable
fear
,
broken
traitors
,
cowards
,
bullies
,
gamesters
,
shufflers
,
swindlers
,
and
false
witnesses
;
some
not
unmarked
by
the
branding
-
iron
beneath
their
dirty
braid
;
all
with
more
cruelty
in
them
than
was
in
Nero
,
and
more
crime
than
is
in
Newgate
.
 
<EOS>
For
howsoever
bad
the
devil
can
be
in
fustian
or
smock
-
frock
<EOS>
(
and
he
can
be
very
bad
in
both
)
,
he
is
a
more
designing
,
callous
,
and
intolerable
devil
when
he
sticks
a
pin
in
his
shirt
-
front
,
calls
himself
a
gentleman
,
backs
a
card
or
colour
,
plays
a
game
or
so
of
billiards
,
and
knows
a
little
about
bills
and
promissory
notes
than
in
any
other
form
he
wears
.
 
<EOS>
And
in
such
form
Mr
Bucket
shall
find
him
,
when
he
will
,
still
pervading
the
tributary
channels
of
Leicester
Square
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
wintry
morning
wants
him
not
and
wakes
him
not
.
 
<EOS>
It
wakes
Mr
George
of
the
shooting
gallery
and
his
familiar
.
 
<EOS>
They
arise
,
roll
up
and
stow
away
their
mattresses
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
George
,
having
shaved
himself
before
a
looking
-
glass
of
minute
proportions
,
then
marches
out
,
bare
-
headed
and
bare
-
chested
,
to
the
pump
in
the
little
yard
and
<EOS>
anon
comes
back
shining
with
yellow
soap
,
friction
,
drifting
rain
,
and
exceedingly
cold
water
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
rubs
himself
upon
a
large
jack
-
towel
,
blowing
like
a
military
sort
of
diver
just
come
up
,
his
hair
curling
tighter
and
tighter
on
his
sunburnt
temples
the
more
he
rubs
it
so
that
it
looks
as
if
it
never
could
be
loosened
by
any
less
coercive
instrument
than
an
iron
rake
or
a
curry
-
comb
---
as
he
rubs
,
and
puffs
,
and
polishes
,
and
blows
,
turning
his
head
from
side
to
side
the
more
conveniently
to
excoriate
his
throat
,
and
standing
with
his
body
well
bent
forward
to
keep
the
wet
from
his
martial
legs
,
Phil
,
on
his
knees
lighting
a
fire
,
looks
round
as
if
it
were
enough
washing
for
him
to
see
all
that
done
,
and
sufficient
renovation
for
one
day
to
take
in
the
superfluous
health
his
master
throws
off
.
   
<EOS>
When
Mr
George
is
dry
,
he
goes
to
work
to
brush
his
head
with
two
hard
brushes
at
once
,
to
that
unmerciful
degree
that
Phil
,
shouldering
his
way
round
the
gallery
in
the
act
of
sweeping
it
,
winks
with
sympathy
.
 
<EOS>
This
chafing
over
,
the
ornamental
part
of
Mr
George
's
toilet
is
soon
performed
.
 
<EOS>
He
fills
his
pipe
,
lights
it
,
and
marches
up
and
down
smoking
,
as
his
custom
is
,
while
Phil
,
raising
a
powerful
odour
of
hot
rolls
and
coffee
,
prepares
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
He
smokes
gravely
and
marches
in
slow
time
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
this
morning
's
pipe
is
devoted
to
the
memory
of
Gridley
in
his
grave
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
Phil
,
"
says
George
of
the
shooting

after

,
"
you
were

the
country
last

?
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
,
by
the
by
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
guv'ner
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
was
it
like
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
know
what
it
was
like
,
guv'ner
,
"
said
Phil
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
How
did

it
was
the
country
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
account
of
the
grass
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
And
the
swans
upon

,
"

after

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
was
a
-
eating
of
it
,
I
expect
,
"
says
Phil
.
   
<EOS>
The
master
resumes
his
march
,
and
the
man
resumes
his
preparation
of

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
necessarily
a
lengthened
preparation
,
being
limited
to
the
setting
forth
of
very
simple

for
two
and

the

;
but
as
Phil
has
to
sidle

of
the
gallery
for
every

he
wants
,
and
never
brings
two
objects
at
once
,
it
takes
time
under
the
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
the
breakfast
is
ready
.
 
<EOS>
Phil
announcing
it
,
Mr
George
knocks
the
ashes
out
of
his
pipe
on
the
hob
,
stands
his
pipe
itself
in
the
chimney
corner
,
and
sits
down
to
the
meal
.
<EOS>
When
he
has
helped
himself
,
Phil
follows
suit
,
sitting
at
the
extreme
end
of
the
little
oblong
table
and
taking
his
plate
on

.
 
<EOS>
Either
in
humility
,
or
to
hide
his
blackened
hands
,
or
because
it
is
his
natural
manner
of
eating
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
country
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
plying

and

;
"
why
,
I
suppose

never
clapped

on
the
country
,
Phil
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
the
marshes
once
,
"
says
Phil
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
marshes
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
THE
marshes
,

,
"
returns

.
   
<EOS>
"
Where

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"
says

;
<EOS>
"
but
I
see
'em
,
guv'ner
.
<EOS>
They
was
flat
.
 
<EOS>
And
miste
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Governor
and

Phil
,
expressive

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was

,
Phil
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
And
bred
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
elevates

one

,

to

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
not

's

,
"

George
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
many

.
 
Not

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She

.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
<EOS>
And

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
Bosh
!
<EOS>
Let

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
You
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
marshes

.

"
N

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
ca

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
,

,
"
Why

,

---
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"
agreeable

the

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

I
see

a
-

with

all
to

wery

,
and

,
"
Would

along
a
me
,

man
?
"
 
<EOS>
I

"
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
and

.
 
<EOS>
That

April
Fool
Day
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
able

;
and
when
April
Fool
Day
come
round
again
<EOS>
,

,

Now
,

,

're
one

eight

.
"
<EOS>
April
Fool

,

,
"
Now
,
old
chap
,
you
're
two
and

eight
in

.
"
 
<EOS>
In

,
I

and

eight

;

and

eight

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

there

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Drink

,

---
 
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
By

?
 
<EOS>
Took

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
Such

was
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
n't
much
of
a
beat
---
round
Saffron
Hill
,
Hatton
Garden
,
Clerkenwell
,
Smiffeld
,
and
there
---
poor
neighbourhood
,
where
they
uses
up
the
kettles
till
they
're
past

.
 
<EOS>
Most

the
tramping
tinkers
used
to
come
and
lodge
at
our

;
that
was
the
best

master
's

.
 
<EOS>
But

did
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I
warn't
like
him
.
<EOS>
He
could
sing
'em
a
good
song
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
!
 
<EOS>
He
could
play
'em
a
tune
on
any
sort

pot
you
please
,
so
as
it
was
iron
or
block

.
<EOS>
I
never
could
do
nothing
with
a
pot
but

or

---
never
had
a
note

in

.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
was
too
ill
-
looking
,
and
their
wives
complained

me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
were
mighty
particular
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
pass
muster
in
a
crowd
,
Phil
!
"
says
the
trooper
with
a
pleasant
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
guv'ner
,
"
returns
Phil
,
shaking
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
should
n't
.
<EOS>
I
was
passable
enough
when
I
went
with
the
tinker
,
though
nothing
to
boast
of
then
;
but
what
with
blowing
the
fire
with
my
mouth
when
I
was
young
,
and
spileing
my
complexion
,
and
singeing
my
hair
off
,
and
swallering
the
smoke
,
and
<EOS>
what
with
being
nat'rally
unfort'nate
in
the
way
of
running
against
hot
metal
and
marking
myself
by
sich
means
,
and
what
with
having
turn
-
ups
with
the
tinker
as
I
got
older
,
almost
whenever
he
was
too
far
gone
in
drink
---
which
was
almost
always
---
my
beauty
was
queer
,
wery
queer
,
even
at
that
time
.
<EOS>
As
to
since
,
what
with
a
dozen
years
in
a
dark
forge
where
the
men
was
given
to
larking
,
and
what
with
being

in
a
accident
at
a
gas
-
works
,
and
what

being

case
-
filling
at
the

business
,
I
am
ugly
enough
to
be
made
a
show
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
Resigning
himself
to
which
condition
with
a
perfectly
satisfied
manner
,
Phil
begs
the
favour
of
another
cup
of
coffee
.
 
<EOS>
While

,
he
says
,
"
It
was
after
the
case
-
filling
blow
-
up
when
I
first
see
you
,
commander
.
 
<EOS>
You
remember
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
remember
,
Phil
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
walking
along
in
the
sun
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Crawling
,
guv'ner
,
again
a
wall
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
Phil
---
shouldering
your
way
on
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
In
a
night
-
cap
!
"
exclaims
Phil
,
excited
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
a
night
-
cap
---
"
   
"
And
hobbling
with
a
couple
of
sticks
!
<EOS>
"
cries
Phil
,
still
more

.
   
<EOS>
"
With
a
couple
of
sticks
.
 
<EOS>
When
---
"
   
"
When
you
stops
,
you
know
,
"
cries
Phil
,
putting
down
his

and
hastily

his

from

,
"
and
says
to
me
,
"
What
,
comrade
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
in
the
wars
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
did

say
much
to

,
commander
,
then
,
for
I
was
took
by
surprise
that

was

.
 
<EOS>
But
you

,

,

as

,
so
that

was
like

glass
of
something

,
"
What
accident
have
you
met

?
 
<EOS>
You
have

.
 
<EOS>
What
's
amiss
,
old

?
 
<EOS>
Cheer
up
,
and
tell

!
"
 
<EOS>
Cheer
up
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
cheered

!
 
<EOS>
I
says
as
much
to
you
,
you
says
more
to
me
,
I
says
more
to
you
,
you
says
more
to
me
,
and
here
I
am
,
commander
!
 
<EOS>
Here
I
am
,
commander
!
"
<EOS>
cries
Phil
,
who
has
started
from
his
chair
and
unaccountably
begun
to
sidle
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
a
mark
's
wanted
,
or
if
it
will
improve
the
business
,
let
the
customers
take
aim
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
They
ca
n't
spoil
MY
beauty
.
 
<EOS>
I'M
all
right
.
 
<EOS>
Come
on
!
 
<EOS>
If
they
want
a
man
to
box
at
,
let
'em
box
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
Let
'em
knock
me
well
about

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
want
a
light
-
weight
to
be
throwed
for
practice
,
Cornwall
,
Devonshire
,
or
Lancashire
,
let
'em
throw
me
.
 
<EOS>
They
wo
n't
hurt
ME
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
throwed
,
all
sorts
of
styles
,
all
my
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
unexpected
speech
,
energetically

and

by
action
illustrative
of
the
various
exercises
referred
to
,
Phil
Squod
shoulders
his
way
<EOS>
round
three
sides
of
the
gallery
,
and
abruptly
tacking
off
at
his
commander
,
makes
a
butt
at
him
with
his
head
,
intended
to
express
devotion
to
his
service
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
begins
to
clear
away
the
breakfast
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
,
after
laughing
cheerfully
and
clapping
him
on
the
shoulder
,
assists
in
these
arrangements
and
helps
to
get
the
gallery
into
business

.
 
<EOS>
That
done
,
he
takes
a
turn
at
the
dumb
-
bells
,
and
afterwards
weighing
himself
and
opining
that
he
is
getting
"
too
fleshy
,
"
engages
with
great
gravity
in
solitary
broadsword
practice
.
 
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Phil
has
fallen
to
work
at
his
usual
table
,
where
he
screws
and
unscrews
,
and
cleans
,
and
files
,
and
whistles
into
small

,
and
blackens
himself
more
and
more
,
and
seems
to
do
and
undo
everything
that
can
be
done
and
undone
about
a
gun
.
   
<EOS>
Master
and
man
are
at
length
disturbed
by
footsteps
in
the
passage
,
where
they
make
an
unusual
sound
,
denoting
the
arrival
of
unusual
company
.
 
<EOS>
These
steps
,
advancing
nearer
and
nearer
to
the
gallery
,
bring
into
it
a
group
at
first
sight
scarcely
reconcilable
with
any
day
in
the
year
but
the
fifth
of
November
.
   
<EOS>
It
consists
of
a
limp
and
ugly
figure
carried
in
a

by
two

and
attended
by
a
lean
female
with
a

like
a

mask
,
who
might

expected

to
recite

popular

commemorative
of
the
time
when
they
did
contrive
to
blow
Old
England
up
alive
but
for
her
keeping
her
lips
tightly
and
defiantly
closed
as
the
chair
is
put
down
.
 
<EOS>
At
which
point
the
figure
in
it
gasping
,
"
O
Lord
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
shaken
!
<EOS>
"
adds
,
"
How
de
do
,
my
dear
friend
,
how
de
do
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
George
then

,
in

,
the
venerable
Mr
Smallweed
out

,

Judy
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
George
,

,
"

,

"

?
 
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
ca

,

.

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hum
!
 
<EOS>
She

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
So

,

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

!
"
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
"
   
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

,

<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Oh

!
"
   
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
O

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
 
<EOS>
My

,
your

---

.
 
<EOS>
O
Lord
,
he
is
very

!
 
<EOS>
Judy
,
draw

.
<EOS>
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
O

!
"
and

's

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

friend
!
 
<EOS>
So

!
 
<EOS>
And

?
 
<EOS>
It
's

.
 
<EOS>
It

!
 
<EOS>
You
never

accidentally
<EOS>
,

,

?
"

Smallweed
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
He
<EOS>
---
Oh
,

!
<EOS>
---
he
never

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

George
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

a

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
He
might
n't
mean

---

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
George
,
will

to

?
"
   
<EOS>
Obedient

the
trooper
,
Phil

,
empty
-

,
to
the
other

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
,

,
falls
to
rubbing
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
're
doing

,
Mr
George
?
<EOS>
"
he
says

the
trooper
,
squarely

faced

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are

,

Powers
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
answers
with

,
adding
,
"
Go
on
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
not

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

George
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

such

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha

!
 
<EOS>
Go

!
"

Mr
George
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
friend
!
 
<EOS>
But
that
sword
looks
awful
gleaming
and

.
<EOS>
It
might
cut
somebody
,
by
accident
.
 
<EOS>
It
makes
me

,
Mr
George
.
 
<EOS>
Curse
him
!
"
says
the
excellent
old
gentleman
apart
to
Judy
as
the
trooper
takes
a
step
or
two
away
to
lay

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
owes
me
money
,
and
might
think
of
paying
off
old
scores
in
this
murdering
place
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
your
brimstone
grandmother
was
here
,
and
he
'd
shave
her
head
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
,
returning
,
folds

,
and
looking
down
at
the
old
man
,
sliding
every
moment
lower
and
lower
in
his
chair
,
says
quietly
,
"
Now
for
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ho
!
"
<EOS>
cries
Mr
Smallweed
,
rubbing
his
hands
with
an
artful
chuckle
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Now
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
Now
for
what
,
my
dear
friend
?
"
   
"
For
a
pipe
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
who
with
great

sets
his
chair
in
the

-

,
takes
his
pipe
from
the
grate
,
fills
it
and
lights

,
and
falls
to
smoking
peacefully
.
   
<EOS>
This
tends
to
the
discomfiture
of
Mr
Smallweed
,
who
finds
it
so
difficult
to
resume
his
object
,
whatever
it
may
be
,
that
he
becomes
exasperated
and
secretly
claws
the
air
with
an
impotent
vindictiveness
expressive
of
an
intense
desire
to
tear
and
rend
the
visage
of
Mr
George
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
excellent
old
gentleman
's
nails
are
long
and
leaden
,
and
his
hands
lean
and
veinous
,
and
his
eyes
green
and
watery
;
and
,
over
and
above
this
,
as
he
continues
,
while
he
claws
,
to
slide
down
in
his
chair
and
to
collapse
into
a
shapeless
bundle
,
he
becomes
such
a
ghastly
spectacle
,
even
in
the
accustomed
eyes
of
Judy
,
that
that
young
virgin
pounces
at
him
with
something
more
than
the
ardour
of
affection
and
so
shakes
him
up
and
pats
and
pokes
him
in
divers
parts
of
his
body
,
but
particularly
in
that
part
which
the
science
of
self
-
defence
would
call
his
wind
,
that
in
his
grievous
distress
he
utters
enforced
sounds
like
a
paviour
's
rammer
.
   
<EOS>
When
Judy
has
by
these
means
set
him
up
again
in
his
chair
,
with
a
white
face
and
a
frosty
nose
(
but
still
clawing
)
,
she
stretches
out
her
weazen
forefinger
and
gives
Mr
George
one
poke
in
the
back
.
<EOS>
The
trooper
raising
his
head
,
she
makes
another
poke
at
her
esteemed
grandfather
,
and
having
thus
brought
them
together
,
stares
rigidly
at
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
!
 
<EOS>
Ho
,
ho
!
 
<EOS>
U
---
u
---
<EOS>
u
<EOS>
---
ugh
!
"
<EOS>
chatters
Grandfather
Smallweed
,
swallowing
his
rage
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
friend
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
still
clawing
)
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
what
,
"
says
Mr
George
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
one

,
and
I
ca
n't

about

about
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
n't
the
art
to
do

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not

enough
.
 
<EOS>
It
do
n't
suit
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
go
winding
round

round

,
"

trooper
,

,
"
damme
,

do

!
"
   
<EOS>
And

.
   
<EOS>

"

"

?
 
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

out

!
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

!
 
<EOS>
It

her

.
 
<EOS>

wo

"

"

<EOS>
I

;

"
(

"

<EOS>
This

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Then
Judy
pokes
Mr
Smallweed
once
,
and
Mr
Smallweed
pokes
Judy
once
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
ready
,
"
says
the
trooper
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Phil
,
you

old

to

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's

!
 
<EOS>
Are

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
makes
no
reply
,
but
seizing
the
chair
and
its

,
sidles

,
tightly

by

now

Mr
Smallweed
,
and

the

as
if
he
had
an
acceptable

to
carry
the
old
gentleman
to
the
nearest

.
 
<EOS>
His

trust
,
however
,
terminating
at
the
cab
,
he
deposits

there
;
and
the

Judy
takes
her
place
beside
him
,
and
the
chair
embellishes
the
roof
,
and
Mr
George
takes
the
vacant
place
upon
the
box
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
is
quite
confounded
by
the
spectacle
he
beholds
from
time
to
time
as
he
peeps
into
the
cab
through
the
window
behind
him
,
where
the
grim
Judy
is
always
motionless
,
and
the
old
gentleman
with
his
cap
over
one
eye
is
always
sliding
off
the
seat
into
the
straw
and
looking
upward
at
him
out
of
his
other
eye
with
a
helpless
expression
of
being
jolted
in
the
back
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
27
.
<EOS>
More
Old
Soldiers
Than
One
 
Mr
George
has
not
far
to
ride
with
folded
arms
upon
the
box
,
for
their
destination
is
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
driver
stops
his
horses
,
Mr
George
alights
,
and
looking
in
at
the
window
,
says
,
"
What
,
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
your
man
,
is
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
him
,
Mr
George
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
have
heard
of
him
---
seen
him
too
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
know
him
,
and
he
do
n't
know
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
ensues
the
carrying
of
Mr
Smallweed
upstairs
,
which
is
done
to
perfection
with
the
trooper
's
help
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
borne
into
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
great
room
and
deposited
on
the
Turkey
rug
before
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
is
not
within
at
the
present
moment
but
will
be
back
directly
.
 
<EOS>
The
occupant
of
the
pew
in
the
hall
,
having
said
thus
much
,
stirs
the
fire
and
leaves
the
triumvirate
to
warm
themselves
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
is
mightily
curious
in
respect
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
looks
up
at
the
painted
ceiling
,
looks
round
at
the
old
law
-
books
,
contemplates
the
portraits
of
the
great
clients
,
reads
aloud
the
names
on
the
boxes
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
Baronet
,
"
"
Mr
George
reads
thoughtfully
.
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
 
<EOS>
"
Manor
of
Chesney
Wold
.
"
 
Humph
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
George
stands
looking
at
these
boxes
a
long
while
---
as
if
they
were
pictures
---
and
comes
back
to
the
fire
repeating
,
"
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
Baronet
,
and
Manor
of
Chesney
Wold
,
hey
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Worth
a
mint
of
money
,
Mr
George
!
"
<EOS>
whispers
Grandfather
Smallweed
,
rubbing
his
legs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Powerfully
rich
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
do
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
This
old
gentleman
,
or
the
Baronet
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
gentleman
,
this
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
have
heard
;
and
knows
a
thing
or
two
,
I
'll
hold
a
wager
.
 
<EOS>
Not
bad
quarters
,
either
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
looking
round
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
See
the
strong
-
box
yonder
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
reply
is
cut
short
by
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
arrival
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
change
in
him
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Rustily
drest
,
with
his
spectacles
in
his
hand
,
and
their
very
case
worn
threadbare
.
 
<EOS>
In
manner
,
close
and
dry
.
 
<EOS>
In
voice
,
husky
and
low
.
 
<EOS>
In
face
,
watchful
behind
a
blind
;
habitually
not
uncensorious
and
contemptuous
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
The
peerage
may
have
warmer
worshippers
and
faithfuller
believers
than
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
after
all
,
if
everything
were
known
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
morning
,
Mr
Smallweed
,
good
morning
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
says
as
he
comes
in
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
brought
the
sergeant
,
I
see
.
 
<EOS>
Sit
down
,
sergeant
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Tulkinghorn
takes
off
his
gloves
and
puts
them
in
his
hat
,
he
looks
with
half
-
closed
eyes
across
the
room
to
where
the
trooper
stands
and
says
within
himself
perchance
,
"
You
'll
do
,
my
friend
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
sergeant
<EOS>
,
"
he
repeats
as
he
comes
to
his
table
,
which
is
set
on
one
side
of
the
fire
,
and
takes
his
easy
-
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Cold
and
raw
<EOS>
this
morning
,
cold
and
raw
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
warms
before
the
bars
,
alternately
,
the
palms
and
knuckles
of
his
hands
and
looks
(
from
behind
that
blind
which
is
always
down
)
at
the
trio
sitting
in
a
little
semicircle
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
can
feel
what
I
am
about
"
(
as
perhaps
he
can
in
two
senses
)
,
"
Mr
Smallweed
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
is
newly
shaken
up
by
Judy
to
bear
his
part
in
the
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
brought
our
good
friend
the
sergeant
,
I
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
returns
Mr
Smallweed
,
very
servile
to
the
lawyer
's
wealth
and
influence
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
does
the
sergeant
say
about
this
business
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
George
,
"
says
Grandfather
Smallweed
with
a
tremulous
wave
of
his
shrivelled
hand
,
"
this
is
the
gentleman
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
salutes
the
gentleman
but
otherwise
sits
bolt
upright
and
profoundly
silent
---
very
forward
in
his
chair
,
as
if
the
full
complement
of
regulation
appendages
for
a
field
-
day
hung
about
him
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
proceeds
,
"
<EOS>
Well
,
George
---
I
believe
your
name
is
George
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
,
Sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
,
George
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
returns
the
trooper
,
"
but
I
should
wish
to
know
what
YOU
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
in
point
of
reward
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
in
point
of
everything
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
is
so
very
trying
to
Mr
Smallweed
's
temper
that
he
suddenly
breaks
out
with
"
<EOS>
You
're
a
brimstone
beast
!
"
<EOS>
and
as
suddenly
asks
pardon
of
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
excusing
himself
for
this
slip
of
the
tongue
by
saying
to
Judy
,
"
I
was
thinking
of
your
grandmother
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
supposed
,
sergeant
,
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
resumes
as
he
leans
on
one
side
of
his
chair
and
crosses
his
legs
,
"
that
Mr
Smallweed
might
have
sufficiently
explained
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
It
lies
in
the
smallest
compass
,
however
.
 
<EOS>
You
served
under
Captain
Hawdon
at
one
time
,
and
were
his
attendant
in
illness
,
and
rendered
him
many
little
services
,
and
were
rather
in
his
confidence
,
I
am
told
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
so
,
is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
that
is
so
,
"
says
Mr
George
with
military
brevity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
you
may
happen
to
have
in
your
possession
something
---
 
anything
,
no
matter
what
;
accounts
,
instructions
,
orders
,
a
letter
,
anything
---
in
Captain
Hawdon
's
writing
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
compare
his
writing
with
some
that
I
have
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
can
give
me
the
opportunity
,
you
shall
be
rewarded
for
your
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
Three
,
four
,
five
,
guineas
,
you
would
consider
handsome
,
I
dare
say
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Noble
,
my
dear
friend
!
"
<EOS>
cries
Grandfather
Smallweed
,
screwing
up
his
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
not
,
say
how
much
more
,
in
your
conscience
as
a
soldier
,
you
can
demand
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
need
for
you
to
part
with
the
writing
,
against
your
inclination
---
though
I
should
prefer
to
have
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
sits
squared
in
exactly
the
same
attitude
,
looks
at
the
painted
ceiling
,
and
says
never
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
The
irascible
Mr
Smallweed
scratches
the
air
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
question
is
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
in
his
methodical
,
subdued
,
uninterested
way
,
"
first
,
whether
you
have
any
of
Captain
Hawdon
's
writing
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
First
,
whether
I
have
any
of
Captain
Hawdon
's
writing
,
sir
,
"
repeats
Mr
George
.
   
<EOS>
"
Secondly
,
what
will
satisfy
you
for
the
trouble
of
producing
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Secondly
,
what
will
satisfy
me
for
the
trouble
of
producing
it
,
sir
,
"
repeats
Mr
George
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thirdly
,
you
can
judge
for
yourself
whether
it
is
at
all
like
that
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
suddenly
handing
him
some
sheets
of
written
paper
tied
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whether
it
is
at
all
like
that
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Just
so
,
"
repeats
Mr
George
.
   
<EOS>
All
three
repetitions
Mr
George
pronounces
in
a
mechanical
manner
,
looking
straight
at
Mr
Tulkinghorn
;
nor
does
he
so
much
as
glance
at
the
affidavit
in
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
,
that
has
been
given
to
him
for
his
inspection
(
though
he
still
holds
it
in
his
hand
)
,
but
continues
to
look
at
the
lawyer
with
an
air
of
troubled
meditation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
replies
Mr
George
,
rising
erect
and
looking
immense
,
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
,
if
you
'll
excuse
me
,
have
nothing
to
do
with
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
outwardly
quite
undisturbed
,
demands
,
"
<EOS>
Why
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
"
returns
the
trooper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Except
on
military
compulsion
,
I
am
not
a
man
of
business
.
 
<EOS>
Among
civilians
I
am
what
they
call
in
Scotland
a
ne'er
-
do
-
weel
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
head
for
papers
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
stand
any
fire
better
than
a
fire
of
cross
questions
.
 
<EOS>
I
mentioned
to
Mr
Smallweed
,
only
an
hour
or
so
ago
,
that
when
I
come
into
things
of
this
kind
I
feel
as
if
I
was
being
smothered
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
is
my
sensation
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
looking
round
upon
the
company
,
"
at
the
present
moment
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
,
he
takes
three
strides
forward
to
replace
the
papers
on
the
lawyer
's
table
and
three
strides
backward
to
resume
his
former
station
,
where
he
stands
perfectly
upright
,
now
looking
at
the
ground
and
now
at
the
painted
ceillhg
,
with
his
hands
behind
him
as
if
to
prevent
himself
from
accepting
any
other
document
whatever
.
   
<EOS>
Under
this
provocation
,
Mr
Smallweed
's
favourite
adjective
of
disparagement
is
so
close
to
his
tongue
that
he
begins
the
words
"
my
dear
friend
"
with
the
monosyllable
"
brim
,
"
thus
converting
the
possessive
pronoun
into
brimmy
and
appearing
to
have
an
impediment
in
his
speech
.
 
<EOS>
Once
past
this
difficulty
,
however
,
he
exhorts
his
dear
friend
in
the
tenderest
manner
not
to
be
rash
,
but
to
do
what
so
eminent
a
gentleman
requires
,
and
to
do
it
with
a
good
grace
,
confident
that
it
must
be
unobjectionable
as
well
as
profitable
.
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
merely
utters
an
occasional
sentence
,
as
,
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
best
judge
of
your
own
interest
,
sergeant
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Take
care
<EOS>
you
do
no
harm
by
this
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
Please
yourself
,
please
yourself
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
know
what
you
mean
,
that
's
quite
enough
.
"
 
<EOS>
These
he
utters
with
an
appearance
of
perfect
indifference
as
he
looks
over
the
papers
on
his
table
and
prepares
to
write
a
letter
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
looks
distrustfully
from
the
painted
ceiling
to
the
ground
,
from
the
ground
to
Mr
Smallweed
,
from
Mr
Smallweed
to
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
and
from
Mr
Tulkinghorn
to
the
painted
ceiling
again
,
often
in
his
perplexity
changing
the
leg
on
which
he
rests
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
assure
you
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
"
not
to
say
it
offensively
,
that
between
you
and
Mr
Smallweed
here
,
I
really
am
being
smothered
fifty
times
over
.
 
<EOS>
I
really
am
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
a
match
for
you
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
allow
me
to
ask
why
you
want
to
see
the
captain
's
hand
,
in
the
case
that
I
could
find
any
specimen
of
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
quietly
shakes
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
were
a
man
of
business
,
sergeant
,
you
would
not
need
to
be
informed
that
there
are
confidential
reasons
,
very
harmless
in
themselves
,
for
many
such
wants
in
the
profession
to
which
I
belong
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
you
are
afraid
of
doing
any
injury
to
Captain
Hawdon
,
you
may
set
your
mind
at
rest
about
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
He
is
dead
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
IS
he
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
quietly
sits
down
to
write
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
says
the
trooper
,
looking
into
his
hat
after
another
disconcerted
pause
,
"
I
am
sorry
not
to
have
given
you
more
satisfaction
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
would
be
any
satisfaction
to
any
one
that
I
should
be
confirmed
in
my
judgment
that
I
would
rather
have
nothing
to
do
with
this
by
a
friend
of
mine
who
has
a
better
head
for
business
than
I
have
,
and
who
is
an
old
soldier
,
I
am
willing
to
consult
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I
really
am
so
completely
smothered
myself
at
present
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
passing
his
hand
hopelessly
across
his
brow
,
"
that
I
do
n't
know
<EOS>
but
what
it
might
be
a
satisfaction
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
,
hearing
that
this
authority
is
an
old
soldier
,
so
strongly
inculcates
the
expediency
of
the
trooper
's
taking
counsel
with
him
,
and
particularly
informing
him
of
its
being
a
question
of
five
guineas
or
more
,
that
Mr
George
engages
to
go
and
see
him
.
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
says
nothing
either
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
consult
my
friend
,
then
,
by
your
leave
,
sir
,
"
says
the
trooper
,
"
and
I
'll
take
the

of
looking
in
again
with
the
final
answer
in
the
course
of
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
,
if
you
wish
to
be
carried
downstairs
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
In
a
moment
,
my

friend
,
in
a

.
 
<EOS>
Will

first

me

half

this

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
hurry
yourself
on
my
account
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
trooper
retires
to
a
distant
part
of
the
room
and
resumes
his
curious
inspection
of
the
boxes
,
strong
and
otherwise
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
was
n't
as
weak
as
a

baby
,
sir
,
"
whispers
Grandfather
Smallweed
,
drawing

down

and
flashing
some

,
"
I
'd
tear
the
writing
away
from
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
got
it
buttoned
in

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
him
put
it
there
.
 
<EOS>
Judy
saw
him

it
there
.
 
<EOS>
Speak
up
,
you
crabbed
image
for
the
sign
of
a

-
stick
shop
,
and
say
you
saw
him
put
it
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
vehement
conjuration
the
old
gentleman
accompanies
with
such
a

at
his
granddaughter
that
it
is
too
much
for
his
strength
,
and

,

Tulkinghorn

,
until

arrested

Judy
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Violence
will
not

me
,
my
friend
,
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
then

coolly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
I
know
,
I
know
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
chafing
and

---
<EOS>
it
's
---
 
<EOS>
it
's
worse
than
your
smattering
chattering
magpie
of
a
grandmother
,
"
to
the
imperturbable
Judy
,
who
only

at
the
fire
,
"
to
know
he
has

what
's
wanted

wo
n't

.
 
<EOS>
He
,
not
to
give
it
up
!
<EOS>
HE
!
 
<EOS>
A
vagabond
!
 
<EOS>
But
never
mind
,

,
never

.
 
<EOS>
At
the
most
,
he
has
only
his

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
him

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
If
he
wo

with

,

,

!
<EOS>
Now
,

Mr
George
,
"

,
"
I

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

.
   
<EOS>
It
is
more
difficult
to

,
Mr
George
finds
,

,

and

button
 
---
having
,

,
a

to

---
that
some

's

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
and
he

in

.
   
<EOS>
By

cloisterly
Temple
,
and

(
there
,
not
without
a

at
Hanging
-
Sword

,
which
would
seem
to
be
something
in

)
,
and
by
Blackfriars
Bridge
,
and
Blackfriars
Road
,
Mr
George
sedately

to
a
street
of
little
shops
lying
somewhere
in
that
ganglion
of
roads
from
Kent
and
Surrey
,
and
of

from
the
bridges
of
London
,
centring
in
the
far
-

elephant
who
has
lost
his
castle
formed
of
a

four
-

to
a
stronger
iron

than
he
,
ready
to

into

.
 
<EOS>
To
one

in

,

a

's

,
having

,

Pan
's

,
and
a

,

certain

,
Mr
George
directs
his

.
 
<EOS>
And

at
a

,
as
he

woman
,

,

-

,

George

,
"
She
's

greens
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
her
,
except

a

-

,
when
she
was
n't
washing
greens
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
subject
of
this

is
at

so
occupied

at

that
she

until
,

her

together
when

,

.
 
<EOS>
Her

.
   
<EOS>
"
George
,
I
never
see
you
<EOS>
but
I
wish
you
was
a

away
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
trooper
,
without

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"
George
,

Matthew
Bagnet

.
 
<EOS>
You

that
resfless

---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
 
<EOS>
I

,
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's

use

?
<EOS>
WHY

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

animal
,

,
"
returns

trooper

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>

,
something

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

to

the
animal

Mat

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bagnet
is
not
at

.
 
<EOS>
Rather
large

,
a

in

,

which
have

healthy
,

,

<EOS>
A

,

of

five

.
 
<EOS>
Clean
,

,
and
so

(

)

<EOS>
appear

her

,

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
Mat

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

"

<EOS>
"
Ah
,
George
,
George
!
 
<EOS>

's

,
SHE'D

<EOS>
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>

's

---
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
If

meet

Mat

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bagnet
,
who
seems

a

to
be
under
little

with

,
but

,

by

Mr
George
in

face
with
a

of
greens
and
taking
her
tub
into
the
little

behind

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Quebec
,
my
poppet
,
"
says
George
,
following
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
And
little
Malta
,

!
 
<EOS>
Come
and
kiss
your
Bluffy
!
"
   
<EOS>
These
young
ladies
---
not
supposed

,

always
so
called
in
the

from

birth
in

---
are

on
three
-

,
the
younger
(
some

old
)
in
learning

out
of

,
the

(
eight
or
nine
perhaps
)
in
teaching
her
and
sewing
with

.
 
<EOS>
Both
hail
Mr
George
with
acclamations
as
an
old
friend
and
after
some
kissing
and

plant

beside

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
's
young
Woolwich
?
"

Mr
George
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
There
now
!
<EOS>
"
cries
Mrs
Bagnet
,
turning

from
her

(
for

)
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Would
you
believe

?
 
<EOS>
Got
an
engagement
at

theayter
,
with

father
,
to
play

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
done
,
my
godson
!
"
<EOS>
cries
Mr
George
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe

!
"
says
Mrs
Bagnet
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
Briton
.
 
<EOS>
That
's

Woolwich
is
.
 
<EOS>
A
Briton
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
Mat
blows
away
at
his
bassoon
,
and
you
're
respectable
civilians
one
and
all
,
"
says
Mr
George
.
 
<EOS>
"
Family
people
.
 
<EOS>
Children
growing
up
.
 
<EOS>
Mat
's
old
mother
in
Scotland
,
and
your
old
father
somewhere
else
,
corresponded
with
,
and
helped
a
little
,
and
---
<EOS>
well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
To

,
I
do
n't

I
should
n't

wished
a
hundred
mile
away
,
for
I
have
not
much
to
do
with
all
this
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
is
becoming
thoughtful
,
sitting
before
the
fire
in
the
whitewashed
room
,
which
has
a
sanded
floor
and
a
barrack
smell
and
contains
nothing
superfluous
and
has
not
a
visible
speck
of
dirt
or
dust
in
it
,
from
the
faces
of
Quebec
and
Malta
to
the
bright
tin
pots
and
pannikins
upon
the
dresser
shelves
---
Mr
George
is
becoming
thoughtful
,
sitting
here
while
Mrs
Bagnet
is
busy
,
when
Mr
Bagnet
and
young
Woolwich
opportunely
come
home
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bagnet
is
an
ex
-
artilleryman
,
tall
and
upright
,
with
shaggy
eyebrows
and
whiskers
like
the
fibres
of
a
coco
-
nut
,
not
a
hair
upon
his
head
,
and
a
torrid
complexion
.
 
<EOS>
His
voice
,
short
,
deep
,
and
resonant
,
is
not
at
all
unlike
the
tones
of
the
instrument
to
which
he
is
devoted
.
<EOS>
Indeed
there
may
be
generally
observed
in
him
an
unbending
,
unyielding
,
brass
-
bound
air
,
as
if
he
were
himself
the
bassoon
of
the
human
orchestra
.
 
<EOS>
Young
Woolwich
is
the
type
and
model
of
a
young
drummer
.
   
<EOS>
Both
father
and
son
salute
the
trooper
heartily
.
 
<EOS>
He
saying
,
in
due
season
,
that
he
has
come
to
advise
with
Mr
Bagnet
<EOS>
,
Mr
Bagnet
hospitably
declares
that
he
will
hear
of
no
business
until
after
dinner
and
that
his
friend
shall
not
partake
of
his
counsel
without
first
partaking
of
boiled
pork
and
greens
.
 
<EOS>
The
trooper
yielding
to
this
invitation
<EOS>
,
he
and
Mr
Bagnet
,
not
to
embarrass
the
domestic
preparations
,
go
forth
to
take
a
turn
up
and
down
the
little
street
,
which
they
promenade
with
measured
tread
and
folded
arms
,
as
if
it
were
a
rampart
.
   
<EOS>
"
George
,
"
says
Mr
Bagnet
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
my
old
girl
that
advises
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
own
to
it
before
her
.
<EOS>
Discipline
must
be
maintained
.
 
<EOS>
Wait
till
the
greens
is
off
her
mind
.
 
<EOS>
Then
we
'll
consult
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
the
old
girl
says
,
<EOS>
do
---
do
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
intend
to
,
Mat
,
"
replies
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
would
sooner
take
her
opinion
than
that
of
a
college
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
College
,
"
returns
Mr
Bagnet
in
short
sentences
,
bassoon
-
like
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
college
could
you
leave
---
in
another
quarter
of
the
world
---
 
with
nothing
but
a
grey
cloak
and
an
umbrella
---
to
make
its
way
home
to
Europe
?
 
<EOS>
The
old
girl
would
do
it
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Did
it
once
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

's

"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,
"
saves
.
 
<EOS>
Has

.
 
<EOS>
With

in

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
But

's

.
 
<EOS>

greens
is

.
 
<EOS>
Then

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She

!
"

<EOS>
"

's

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
Discipline

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

.

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>
Proceeding

,

,
keeping
step

,
until

by
Quebec

to
the

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Having

with

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Young
Woolwich
's

,

,

,

,
is

as

in

the

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

,

(

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
That

girl

,

Mr

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
But

well

<EOS>
Gridley

<EOS>
A

.
"
   
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
takes
his

in
great

,
the
greater
because
a
clerk
coming

stairs
has

the

of
all
and
evidently

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
pretty
character
to

,
"
the
trooper

as

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
threatening
,
murderous
,
dangerous
fellow
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
looking
up
,
he
sees
the
clerk
looking
down

and
marking
him
as

passes
a
lamp
.
 
<EOS>
This
so
intensifies
his
dudgeon
that
for

minutes
he
is
in

ill

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
whistles
that
off
like
the
rest
of
it
and
marches
home
to
the
shooting
gallery
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
28
.
<EOS>
The
Ironmaster
 
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
has
got
the
better
,
for
the
time
being
,
of
the
family
gout
and
is
once
more
,
in
a
literal
no
less
than
in
a
figurative
point
of
view
,
upon
his
legs
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
at
his
place
in
Lincolnshire
;
but
the
waters
are
out
again
on
the
low
-
lying
grounds
,
and
the
cold
and
damp
steal
into
Chesney
Wold
,
though
well
defended
,
and
eke
into
Sir
Leicester
's
bones
.
 
<EOS>
The
blazing
fires
of
faggot
and
coal
---
Dedlock
timber
and
antediluvian
forest
---
that
blaze
upon
the
broad
wide
hearths
and
wink
in
the
twilight
on
the
frowning
woods
,
sullen
to
see
how
trees
are
sacrificed
,
do
not
exclude
the
enemy
.
 
<EOS>
The
hot
-
water
pipes
that
trail
themselves
all
over
the
house
,
the
cushioned
doors
and
windows
,
and
the
screens
and
curtains
fail
to
supply
the
fires
'
deficiencies
and
to
satisfy
Sir
Leicester
's
need
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
the
fashionable
intelligence
proclaims
one
morning
to
the
listening
earth
that
Lady
Dedlock
is
expected
shortly
to
return
to
town
for
a
few
weeks
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
melancholy
truth
that
even
great
men
have
their
poor
relations
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
great
men
have
often
more
than
their
fair
share
of
poor
relations
,
inasmuch
as
very
red
blood
of
the
superior
quality
,
like
inferior
blood
unlawfully
shed
,
WILL
cry
aloud
and
WILL
be
heard
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
's
cousins
,
in
the
remotest
degree
,
are
so
many
murders
in
the
respect
that
they
"
will
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
Among
whom
there
are
cousins
who
are
so
poor
that
one
might
almost
dare
to
think
it
would
have
been
the
happier
for
them
never
to
have
been
plated
links
upon
the
Dedlock
chain
of
gold
,
but
to
have
been
made
of
common
iron
at
first
and
done
base
service
.
   
<EOS>
Service
,
however
(
with
a
few
limited
reservations
,
genteel
but
not
profitable
)
,
they
may
not
do
,
being
of
the
Dedlock
dignity
.
 
<EOS>
So
they
visit
their
richer
cousins
,
and
get
into
debt
when
they
can
,
and
live
but
shabbily
when
they
ca
n't
,
and
find
---
the
women
no
husbands
,
and
the
men
no
wives
---
and
ride
in
borrowed
carriages
,
and
sit
at
feasts
that
are
never
of
their
own
making
,
and
so
go
through
high
life
.
 
<EOS>
The
rich
family
sum
has
been
divided
by
so
many
figures
,
and
they
are
the
something
over
that
nobody
knows
what
to
do
with
.
   
<EOS>
Everybody
on
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
's
side
of
the
question
and
of
his
way
of
thinking
would
appear
to
be
his
cousin
more
or
less
.
<EOS>
From
my
Lord
Boodle
,
through
the
Duke
of
Foodle
,
down
to
Noodle
,
Sir
Leicester
,
like
a
glorious
spider
,
stretches
his
threads
of
relationship
.
 
<EOS>
But
while
he
is
stately
in
the
cousinship
of
the
Everybodys
,
he
is
a
kind
and
generous
man
,
according
to
his
dignified
way
,
in
the
cousinship
of
the
Nobodys
;
and
at
the
present
time
,
in
despite
of
the
damp
,
he
stays
out
the
visit
of
several
such
cousins
at
Chesney
Wold
with
the
constancy
of
a
martyr
.
   
<EOS>
Of
these
,
foremost
in
the
front
rank
stands
Volumnia
Dedlock
,
a
young
lady
(
of
sixty
)
who
is
doubly
highly
related
,
having
the
honour
to
be
a
poor
relation
,
by
the
mother
's
side
,
to
another
great
family
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Volumnia
,
displaying
in
early
life
a
pretty
talent
for
cutting
ornaments
out
of
coloured
paper
,
and
also
for
singing
to
the
guitar
in
the
Spanish
tongue
,
and
propounding
French
conundrums
in
country
houses
,
passed
the
twenty
years
of
her
existence
between
twenty
and
forty
in
a
sufficiently
agreeable
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Lapsing
then
out
of
date
and
being
considered
to
bore
mankind
by
her
vocal
performances
in
the
Spanish
language
<EOS>
,
she
retired
to
Bath
,
where
she
lives
slenderly
on
an
annual
present
from
Sir
Leicester
and
whence
<EOS>
she
makes
occasional
resurrections
in
the
country
houses
of
her
cousins
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
an
extensive
acquaintance
at
Bath
among
appalling
old
gentlemen
with
thin
legs
and
nankeen
trousers
,
and
is
of
high
standing
in
that
dreary
city
.
<EOS>
But
she
is
a
little
dreaded
elsewhere
in
consequence
of
an
indiscreet
profusion
in
the
article
of
rouge
and
persistency
in
an
obsolete
pearl
necklace
like
a
rosary
of
little
bird's
-
eggs
.
   
<EOS>
In
any
country
in
a
wholesome
state
,
Volumnia
would
be
a
clear
case
for
the
pension
list
.
 
<EOS>
Efforts
have
been
made
to
get
her
on
it
,
and
when
William
Buffy
came
in
,
it
was
fully
expected
that
her
name
would
be
put
down
for
a
couple
of
hundred
a
year
.
 
<EOS>
But
William
Buffy
somehow
discovered
,
contrary
to
all
expectation
,
that
these
were
not
the
times
when
it
could
be
done
,
and
this
was
the
first
clear
indication
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
had
conveyed
to
him
that
the
country
was
going
to
pieces
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
likewise
the
Honourable
Bob
Stables
,
who
can
make
warm
mashes
with
the
skill
of
a
veterinary
surgeon
and
is
a
better
shot
than
most
gamekeepers
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
for
some
time
particularly
desirous
to
serve
his
country
in
a
post
of
good
emoluments
,
unaccompanied
by
any
trouble
or
responsibility
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
well
-
regulated
body
politic
this
natural
desire
on
the
part
of
a
spirited
young
gentleman
so
highly
connected
would
be
speedily
recognized
,
but
<EOS>
somehow
William
Buffy
found
when
he
came
in
that
these
were
not
times
in
which
he
could
manage
that
little
matter
either
,
and
this
was
the
second
indication
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
had
conveyed
to
him
that
the
country
was
going
to
pieces
.
   
<EOS>
The
rest
of
the
cousins
are
ladies
and
gentlemen
of
various
ages
and
capacities
,
the
major
part
amiable
and
sensible
and
likely
to
have
done
well
enough
in
life
if
they
could
have
overcome
their
cousinship
;
as
it
is
,
they
are
almost
all
a
little
worsted
by
it
,
and
lounge
in
purposeless
and
listless
paths
,
and
seem
to
be
quite
as
much
at
a
loss
how
to
dispose
of
themselves
as
anybody
else
can
be
how
to
dispose
of
them
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
society
,
and
where
not
,
my
Lady
Dedlock
reigns
supreme
.
<EOS>
Beautiful
,
elegant
,
accomplished
,
and
powerful
in
her
little
world
(
for
the
world
of
fashion
does
not
stretch
ALL
the
way
from
pole
to
pole
)
,
her
influence
in
Sir
Leicester
's
house
,
however
haughty
and
indifferent
her
manner
,
is
greatly
to
improve
it
and
refine
it
.
<EOS>
The
cousins
,
even
those
older
cousins
who
were
paralysed
when
Sir
Leicester
married
her
,
do
her
feudal
homage
;
and
the
Honourable
Bob
Stables
daily
repeats
to
some
chosen
person
between
breakfast
and
lunch
his
favourite
original
remark
,
that
she
is
the
best
-
groomed
woman
in
the
whole
stud
.
   
<EOS>
Such
the
guests
in
the
long
drawing
-
room
at
Chesney
Wold
this
dismal
night
when
the
step
on
the
Ghost
's
Walk
(
inaudible
here
,
however
)
might
be
the
step
of
a
deceased
cousin
shut
out
in
the
cold
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
near
bed
-
time
.
 
<EOS>
Bedroom
fires
blaze
brightly
all
over
the
house
,
raising
ghosts
of
grim
furniture
on
wall
and

.
<EOS>
Bedroom
candlesticks
bristle
on
the
distant
table
by
the
door
,
and
cousins
yawn
on
ottomans
.
 
<EOS>
Cousins
at
the
piano
,
cousins
at
the
soda
-
water
tray
,
cousins
rising
from
the
card
-
table
<EOS>
,
cousins
gathered
round
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Standing
on
one

of
his
own
peculiar
fire
(
for
there
are
two
)
,
Sir
Leicester
.
 
<EOS>
On
the

of
the
broad
hearth
,
my
Lady
at
her

.
 
<EOS>
Volumnia
,
as
one
of
the
more
privileged
cousins
,
in
a
luxurious
chair
between

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
glancing
,
with
magnificent
displeasure
,
at
the
rouge
and
the
pearl
necklace
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
occasionally
meet
on
my

here
,
"
drawls
Volumnia
,
whose

perhaps
are
already
hopping
up
it
to

,

of
very

,
"
one
of
the
prettiest
girls
,
I

,
that
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
PROTEGEE
of

Lady
's
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
so
.
 
<EOS>
I

that
some

eye
must

girl

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
A
dolly
sort

,
"

"

such

"
   
<EOS>
Sir

,

<EOS>
Rosa

.

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Sir

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.

.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?

<EOS>
The

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
Has

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
All

's
eyes
are
on
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
In
search
of
what
?
 
<EOS>
Of
any
hand
that
is
no
more
,
of
any
hand
that
never
was
,
of
any
touch
that
might
have
magically
changed
her
life
?
<EOS>
Or
does
she
listen
to
the
Ghost
's
Walk
and
think
what
step
does
it
most
resemble
?
 
<EOS>
A
man
's
?
 
<EOS>
A
woman
's
?
 
<EOS>
The
pattering
of
a
little
child
's
feet
,
ever
coming
on
---
on
---
on
?
 
<EOS>
Some
melancholy
influence
is
upon
her
,
or
why
should
so
proud
a
lady
close
the
doors
and
sit
alone
upon
the
hearth
so
desolate
?
   
<EOS>
Volumnia
is
away
next
day
,
and
all
the
cousins
are
scattered
before
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
cousin
of
the
batch
but
is
amazed
to
hear
from
Sir
Leicester
at
breakfast
-
time
of
the
obliteration
of
landmarks
,
and
opening
of
floodgates
,
and
cracking
of
the
framework
of
society
,
manifested
through
Mrs
Rouncewell
's
son
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
cousin
of
the
batch
but
is
really
indignant
,
and
connects
it
with
the
feebleness
of
William
Buffy
when
in
office
,
and
really
does
feel
deprived
of
a
stake
in
the
country
---
or
the
pension
list
---
or
something
---
by
fraud
and
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Volumnia
,
she
is
handed
down
the
great
staircase
by
Sir
Leicester
,
as
eloquent
upon
the
theme
as
if
there
were
a
general
rising
in
the
north
of
England
to
obtain
her
rouge
-
pot
and
pearl
necklace
.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
,
with
a
clatter
of
maids
and
valets
---
for
it
is
one
appurtenance
of
their
cousinship
that
however
difficult
they
may
find
it
to
keep
themselves
,
they
MUST
keep
maids
and
valets
---
the
cousins
disperse
to
the
four
winds
of
heaven
;
and
the
one
wintry
wind
that
blows
<EOS>
to
-
day
shakes
a
shower
from
the
trees
near
the
deserted
house
,
as
if
all
the
cousins
had
been
changed
into
leaves
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
29
.
<EOS>
The
Young
Man
 
<EOS>
Chesney
Wold
is
shut
up
,
carpets
are
rolled
into
great
scrolls
in
corners
of
comfortless
rooms
,
bright
damask
does
penance
in
brown
holland
,
carving
and
gilding
puts
on
mortification
,
and
the
Dedlock
ancestors
retire
from
the
light
of
day
again
.
 
<EOS>
Around
and
around
the
house
<EOS>
the
leaves
fall
thick
,
but
never
fast
,
for
they
come
circling
down
with
a
dead
lightness
that
is
sombre
and
slow
.
 
<EOS>
Let
the
gardener
sweep
and
sweep
the
turf
as
he
will
,
and
press
the
leaves
into
full
barrows
,
and
wheel
them
off
,
still
they
lie
ankle
-
deep
.
 
<EOS>
Howls
<EOS>
the
shrill
wind
round
Chesney
Wold
;
the
sharp
rain
beats
,
the
windows
rattle
,
and
the
chimneys
growl
.
 
<EOS>
Mists
hide
in
the
avenues
,
veil
the
points
of
view
,
and
move
in
funeral
-
wise
across
the
rising
grounds
.
 
<EOS>
On
all
the
house
there
is
a
cold
,
blank
smell
like
the
smell
of
a
little
church
,
though
something
dryer
,
suggesting
that
the
dead
and
buried
Dedlocks
walk
there
in
the
long
nights
and
leave
the
flavour
of
their
graves
behind
them
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
house
in
town
,
which
is
rarely
in
the
same
mind
as
Chesney
Wold
at
the
same
time
,
seldom
rejoicing
when
it
rejoices
or
mourning
when
it
mourns
,
expecting
when
a
Dedlock
dies
---
the
house
in
town
shines
out
awakened
.
 
<EOS>
As
warm
and
bright
as
so
much
state
may
be
,
as
delicately
redolent
of
pleasant
scents
that
bear
no
trace
of
winter
as
hothouse
flowers
can
make
it
,
soft
and
hushed
so
that
the
ticking
of
the
clocks
and
the
crisp
burning
of
the
fires
alone
disturb
the
stillness
in
the
rooms
,
it
seems
to
wrap
those
chilled
bones
of
Sir
Leicester
's
in
rainbow
-
coloured
wool
.
 
<EOS>
And
Sir
Leicester
is
glad
to
repose
in
dignified
contentment
before
the
great
fire
in
the
library
,
condescendingly
perusing
the
backs
of
his
books
or
honouring
the
fine
arts
with
a
glance
of
approbation
.
<EOS>
For
he
has
his
pictures
,
ancient
and
modern
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
the
Fancy
Ball
School
in
which
art
occasionally
condescends
to
become
a
master
,
which
would
be
best
catalogued
like
the
miscellaneous
articles
in
a
sale
.
 
<EOS>
As
"
Three
high
-
backed
chairs
,
a
table
and
cover
,
long
-
necked
bottle
(
containing
wine
)
,
one
flask
,
one
Spanish
female
's
costume
,
three
-
quarter
face
portrait
of
Miss
Jogg
the
model
,
and
a
suit
of
armour
containing
Don
Quixote
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Or
"
One
stone
terrace
(
cracked
)
,
<EOS>
one
gondola
in
distance
,
one
Venetian
senator
's
dress
complete
,
richly
embroidered
white
satin
costume
with
profile
portrait
of
Miss
Jogg
the
model
<EOS>
,
one
Scimitar
superbly
mounted
in
gold
with
jewelled
handle
,
elaborate
Moorish
dress
(
very
rare
)
,
and
Othello
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
comes
and
goes
pretty
often
,
there
being
estate
business
to
do
,
leases
to
be
renewed
,
and
so
on
.
 
<EOS>
He
sees
my
Lady
pretty
often
,
too
;
and
he
and
she
are
as
composed
,
and
as
indifferent
,
and
take
as
little
heed
of
one
another
,
as
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
it
may
be
that
my
Lady
fears
this
Mr
Tulkinghorn
and
that
he
knows
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
he
pursues
her
doggedly
and
steadily
,
with
no
touch
of
compunction
,
remorse
,
or
pity
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
her
beauty
and
all
the
state
and
brilliancy
surrounding
her
only
gives
him
the
greater
zest
for
what
he
is
set
upon
and
makes
him
the
more
inflexible
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
be
cold
and
cruel
,
whether
immovable
in
what
he
has
made
his
duty
,
whether
absorbed
in
love
of
power
,
whether
determined
to
have
nothing
hidden
from
him
in
ground
where
he
has
burrowed
among
secrets
all
his
life
,
whether
he
in
his
heart
despises
the
splendour
of
which
he
is
a
distant
beam
,
whether
he
is
always
treasuring
up
slights
and
offences
in
the
affability
of
his
gorgeous
clients
---
whether
he
be
any
of
this
,
or
all
of
this
,
it
may
be
that
my
Lady
had
better
have
five
thousand
pairs
of
fashionahle
eyes
upon
her
,
in
distrustful
vigilance
,
than
the
two
eyes
of
this
rusty
lawyer
with
his
wisp
of
neckcloth
and
his
dull
black
breeches
tied
with
ribbons
at
the
knees
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
sits
in
my
Lady
's
room
---
that
room
in
which
Mr
Tulkinghorn
read
the
affidavit
in
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
---
 
particularly
complacent
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
,
as
on
that
day
,
sits
before
the
fire
with
her
screen
in
her
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
is
particularly
complacent
because
he
has
found
in
his
newspaper
some
congenial
remarks
bearing
directly
on
the
floodgates
and
the
framework
of
society
.
 
<EOS>
They
apply
so
happily
to
the
late
case
that
Sir
Leicester
has
come
from
the
library
to
my
Lady
's
room
expressly
to
read
them
aloud
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
man
who
wrote
this
article
,
"
he
observes
by
way
of
preface
,
nodding
at
the
fire
as
if
he
were
nodding
down
at
the
man
from
a
mount
,
"
has
a
well
-
balanced
mind
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
's
mind
is
not
so
well
balanced
but
that
he
bores
my
Lady
,
who
,
after
a
languid
effort
to
listen
,
or
rather
a
languid
resignation
of
herself
to
a
show
of
listening
,
becomes
distraught
and
falls
into
a
contemplation
of
the
fire
as
if
it
were
her
fire
at
Chesney
Wold
,
and
she
had
never
left
it
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
,
quite
unconscious
,
reads
on
through
his
double
eye
-
glass
,
occasionally
stopping
to
remove
his
glass
and
express
approval
,
as
"
Very
true
indeed
,
"
"
Very
properly
put
,
"
"
I
have
frequently
made
the
same
remark
myself
,
"
invariably
losing
his
place
after
each
observation
,
and
going
up
and
down
the
column
to
find
it
again
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
is
reading
with
infinite
gravity
and
state
when
the
door
opens
,
and
the
Mercury
in
powder
makes
this
strange
announcement
,
"
The
young
man
,
my
Lady
,
of
the
name
of
Guppy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
pauses
,
stares
,
repeats
in
a
killing
voice
,
"
The
young
man
of
the
name
of
Guppy
?
"
   
<EOS>
Looking
round
,
he
beholds
the
young
man
of
the
name
of
Guppy
,
much
discomfited
and
not
presenting
a
very
impressive
letter
of
introduction
in
his
manner
and
appearance
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"
says
Sir
Leicester
to
Mercury
,
"
what
do
you
mean
by
announcing
with
this
abruptness
a
young
man
of
the
name
of
Guppy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Sir
Leicester
,
but
my
Lady
said
she
would
see
the
young
man
whenever
he
called
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
aware
that
you
were
here
,
Sir
Leicester
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
apology
,
Mercury
directs
a
scornful
and
indignant
look
at
the
young
man
of
the
name
of
Guppy
which
plainly
says
,
"
What
do
you
come
calling
here
for
and
getting
ME
into
a
row
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
him
those
directions
,
"
says
my
Lady
.
<EOS>
"
Let
the
young
man
wait
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
no
means
,
my
Lady
.
 
<EOS>
Since
he
has
your
orders
to
come
,
I
will
not
interrupt
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
in
his
gallantry
retires
,
rather
declining
to
accept
a
bow
from
the
young
man
as
he
goes
out
and
majestically
supposing
him
to
be
some
shoemaker
of
intrusive
appearance
.
   
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
looks
imperiously
at
her
visitor
when
the
servant
has
left
the
room
,
casting
her
eyes
over
him
from
head
to
foot
.
 
<EOS>
She
suffers
him
to
stand
by
the
door
and
asks
him
what
he
wants
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
your
ladyship
would
have
the
kindness
to
oblige
me
with
a
little
conversation
,
"
returns
Mr
Guppy
,
embarrassed
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
,
of
course
,
the
person
who
has
written
me
so
many
letters
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Several
,
your
ladyship
.
 
<EOS>
Several
before
your
ladyship
condescended
to
favour
me
with
an
answer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
could
you
not
take
the
same
means
of
rendering
a
Conversation
unnecessary
?
 
<EOS>
Can
you
not
still
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
screws
his
mouth
into
a
silent
"
No
!
"
and
shakes
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
strangely
importunate
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
should
appear
,
after
all
,
that
what
you
have
to
say
does
not
concern
me
---
and
I
do
n't
know
how
it
can
,
and
do
n't
expect
that
it
will
<EOS>
---
you
will
allow
me
to
cut
you
short
with
but
little
ceremony
.
 
<EOS>
Say
what
you
have
to
say
,
if
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
Lady
,
with
a
careless
toss
of
her
screen
,
turns
herself
towards
the
fire
again
,
sitting
almost
with
her
back
to
the
young
man
of
the
name
of
Guppy
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
your
ladyship
's
permission
,
then
,
"
says
the
young
man
,
"
I
will
now
enter
on
my
business
.
 
<EOS>
Hem
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
,
as
I
told
your
ladyship
in
my
first
letter
,
in
the
law
.
 
<EOS>
Being
in
the
law
,
I
have
learnt
the
habit
of
not
committing
myself
in
writing
,
and
therefore
I
did
not
mention
to
your
ladyship
the
name
of
the
firm
with
which
I
am
connected
and
in
which
my
standing
---
and
I
may
add
income
---
is
tolerably
good
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
now
state
to
your
ladyship
,
in
confidence
,
that
the
name
of
that
firm
is
Kenge
and
Carboy
,
of
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
which
may
not
be
altogether
unknown
to
your
ladyship
in
connexion
with
the
case
in
Chancery
of
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
Lady
's
figure
begins
to
be
expressive
of
some
attention
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
ceased
to
toss
the
screen
and
holds
it
as
if
she
were
listening
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
may
say
to
your
ladyship
at
once
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
a
little
emboldened
,
"
it
is
no
matter
arising
out
of
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
that
made
me
so
desirous
to
speak
to
your
ladyship
,
which
conduct
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
did
appear
,
and
does
appear
,
obtrusive
---
in
fact
,
almost
blackguardly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
After
waiting
for
a
moment
to
receive
some
assurance
to
the
contrary
,
and
not
receiving
any
,
Mr
Guppy
proceeds
,
"
If
it
had
been
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
,
I
should
have
gone
at
once
to
your
ladyship
's
solicitor
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
of
the
Fields
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
the
pleasure
of
being
acquainted
with
Mr
Tulkinghorn
---
at
least
we
move
when
we
meet
one
another
---
and
if
it
had
been
any
business
of
that
sort
,
I
should
have
gone
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
Lady
turns
a
little
round
and
says
,
"
You
had
better
sit
down
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
your
ladyship
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
does
so
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
your
ladyship
"
---
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
refers
to
a
little
slip
of
paper
on
which
he
has
made
small
notes
of
his
line
of
argument
and
which
seems
to
involve
him
in
the
densest
obscurity
whenever
he
looks
at
it
---
"
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
!
<EOS>
---
I

<EOS>
Esther

,
and
why
did
it
matter
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
Why
could
not
I
,
going
up
to
bed
with
my
basket
of
keys
,
stop
to
sit
down
by
her
fire
and
accommodate
myself
for
a
little
while
to
her
,
at
least
as
well
as
to
anybody
else
,
and
not
trouble
myself
about
the
harmless
things
she
said
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
Impelled
towards
her
,
as
I
certainly
was
,
for
I
was
very
anxious
that
she
should
like
me
and
was
very
glad
indeed
<EOS>
that
she
did
,
why
should
I
harp
afterwards
,
with
actual
distress
and
pain
,
on
every
word
she
said
and
weigh
it
over
and
over
again
in
twenty
scales
?
 
<EOS>
Why
was
it
so
worrying
to
me
to
have
her
in
our
house
,
and
confidential
to
me
every
night
,
when
I
yet
felt
that
it
was
better
and
safer
somehow
that
she
should
be
there
than
anywhere
else
?
 
<EOS>
These
were
perplexities
and
contradictions
that
I
could
not
account
for
.
 
<EOS>
At
least
,
if
I
could
---
but
I
shall
come
to
all
that
by
and
by
,
and
it
is
mere
idleness
to
go
on
about
it
now
.
   
<EOS>
So
when
Mrs
Woodcourt
went
away
,
I
was
sorry
to
lose
her
but
was
relieved
too
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
Caddy
Jellyby
came
down
,
and
Caddy
brought
such
a
packet
of
domestic
news
that
it
gave
us
abundant
occupation
.
   
<EOS>
First
Caddy
declared
(
and
would
at
first
declare
nothing
else
)
that
I
was
the
best
adviser
that
ever
was
known
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
my
pet
said
,
was
no
news
at
all
;
and
this
,
I
said
,
of
course
,
was
nonsense
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Caddy
told
us
that
she
was
going
to
be
married
in
a
month
and
that
if
Ada
and
I
would
be
her
bridesmaids
,
she
was
the
happiest
girl
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
this
was
news
indeed
;
and
I
thought
we
never
should
have
done
talking
about
it
,
we
had
so
much
to
say
to
Caddy
,
and
Caddy
had
so
much
to
say
to
us
.
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
that
Caddy
's
unfortunate
papa
had
got
over
his
bankruptcy
---
"
gone
through
the
Gazette
,
"
was
the
expression
Caddy
used
,
as
if
it
were
a
tunnel
---
with
the
general
clemency
and
commiseration
of
his
creditors
,
and
had
got
rid
of
his
affairs
in
some
blessed
manner
without
succeeding
in
understanding
them
,
and
had
given
up
everything
he
possessed
(
which
was
not
worth
much
,
I
should
think
,
to
judge
from
the
state
of
the

)
,
and
had
satisfied
every
one

that
he
could
do
no
more
,
poor
man
.
<EOS>
So
,
he
had
been
honourably
dismissed
to
"
the
office
"
to
begin
the
world
again
.
 
<EOS>
What
he
did
at
the
office
,
I
never
knew
;
Caddy
said
he
was
a
"
custom
-
house
and
general
agent
,
"
and
the
only
thing
I
ever
understood
about
that
business
was
that
when
he
wanted
money
more
than
usual
he
went
to
the
docks
to
look
for
it
,
and
hardly
ever
found
it
.
   
<EOS>
As
soon
as
her
papa
had
tranquillized

by
becoming
this
shorn

,
and
they
had
removed
to
a
furnished

in
Hatton
Garden
(
where
I
found
the
children
,
when
I

there
,
cutting

horse

out

the

of
the
chairs
and

with

)
,
Caddy
had
brought

Turveydrop
;
and
poor
Mr
Jellyby
,
being
very

,
had
deferred
to
Mr
Turveydrop
's

so
submissively
that
they
had

excellent

.
 
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
old
Mr
Turveydrop
,
thus
familiarized
with
the
idea
of
his
son
's

,
had
worked

the

as

near

to
the

in
Newman
Street
when

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
your
papa
,
Caddy
.
 
<EOS>
What
did
he
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Poor
Pa
,
"
said
Caddy
,
"
only
cried
and
said
he
hoped
we
might
get
on
better
than
he
and
Ma
had
got

.
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't
say
so
before
Prince
,
he
only
said

to
me
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
said
,
"
My
poor
girl
,
you
have

,

,

---

.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

,

Pa

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

I
DID

.
 
<EOS>
Then

's

,

Pa

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indians
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"
wild

.
 
<EOS>
And

"
<EOS>
---

,
poor

,

---
 
"
that

.
"
   
<EOS>
Ada

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,

;

"
   
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
You

Ma

,
Esther
<EOS>
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

.
 
<EOS>
She

"

"
<EOS>

,

,

!
"
and

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
And
about
your

,
Caddy
?
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
For
she
was
under
no

with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my

Esther
,
"
she

,

"
I

and

my
dear
Prince
never
to

.
 
<EOS>
If

concerned
an

for
Borrioboola
,
Ma
would

and
would

.
 
<EOS>
Being
what
it
is
,
she
neither

.
"
   
<EOS>
Caddy
was
not
at
all
deficient
in
natural

for
her
mother
,
but
mentioned
this
with
tears
as
an

,
which
I
am

.
 
<EOS>
We
were
sorry
for
the
poor
dear
girl
and
found
so
much
to
admire
in
the
good
disposition
which
had
survived
under
such

that
we
both
at
once
(
I
mean
Ada
and
I
)
proposed
a
little
scheme
that
made
her
perfectly

.
 
<EOS>
This
was
her
staying
with
us
for
three
weeks
,
my
staying
with
her
for
one
,
and
our
all
three
contriving
and

,
and

,
and

,
and

,
and
doing
the

best
<EOS>
we
could
think
of
to

.
 
<EOS>
My
guardian
being
as
pleased
with
the
idea
as
Caddy
was
,
we
took
her
home
next
day
to
arrange
the
matter
and
brought
her
out
again
in

with

and
all

that
could

,

Mr
Jellyby
had

in
the
docks
I

,
but
which
he
at
all

.
 
<EOS>
What
my
guardian
would
not
have
given
her
if
we
had

him
,
it
would
be
difficult
to
say
,
but
we
thought
it
right
to
compound
for
no
more
than
her
wedding
-
dress
and

.
<EOS>
He
agreed
to
this
compromise
,
and
if
Caddy
had
ever
been
happy
in
her
life
,
she
was
happy
when
we

.
   
<EOS>
She
was
clumsy
enough
with
her
needle
,
poor
girl
,
and
pricked
her
fingers
as
much
as
she
had
been
used
to
ink

.
 
<EOS>
She
could
not
help
reddening
a
little
now
<EOS>
and
then
,
partly
with
the
smart
and
partly

at
being
able
to
do
no
better
,
<EOS>
but
she
soon
got
over
that
and
began
to
improve
rapidly
.
 
<EOS>
So
day
after
day
she
,
and
my
darling
,
and
my
little
maid
Charley
,
and
a
milliner
out
of
the
town
,
and
I
,
sat
hard
at
work
,
as
pleasantly
as
possible
.
   
<EOS>
Over
and
above
this
,
Caddy
was
very
anxious
"
to
learn
housekeeping
,
"
as
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
mercy
upon
us
!
 
<EOS>
The
idea
of
her
learning
housekeeping
of
a
person
of
my
vast
experience
was
such

joke
that
I
laughed
,
and
coloured
up
,
and
fell
into
a
comical

when
she
proposed

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
said
,
"
Caddy
,
I
am
sure
you
are
very
welcome
to
learn
anything
that
you
can
learn
of
ME
,
my
dear
,
"
and
I
showed
her
all
my
books
and

and
all
my
fidgety
ways
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
have
supposed
that
I
was
showing
her
some
wonderful

,
by
her
study
of
them
;
and
if
you
had
seen
her
,
whenever
I
jingled
my

keys
,
get
up
and

me
,
certainly

might

that
there
never
was

greater

than
I
with
a
blinder

than
Caddy
Jellyby
.
   
<EOS>
So
what
with
working
and

,
and
lessons
to
Charley
,
and
backgammon
in
the

with
my

,
and
duets

Ada
,
the
three
weeks
slipped
fast

.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
went
home
with
Caddy
to
see
what
could
be
done
there
,
and
Ada
and
Charley
remained
behind
to
take

my

.
   
<EOS>
When
I
say
I
went
home
with
Caddy
,
I
mean
to
the
furnished
lodging
in
Hatton
Garden
.
 
<EOS>
We
went
to
Newman
Street
two
or
three
times
,
where
preparations
were
in
progress
too
---
a
good
many
,
I
observed
,
for
enhancing
the
comforts
of
old
Mr
Turveydrop
,
and
a
few
for
putting
the
newly
married
couple
away
cheaply
at
the
top
of
the
house
---
but
our
great
point
was
to
make
the
furnished
lodging
decent
for
the
wedding
-
breakfast
and
to
imbue
Mrs
Jellyby
beforehand
with
some
faint
sense
of
the
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
The
latter
was
the
more
difficult
thing
of
the
two
because
Mrs
Jellyby
and
an
unwholesome
boy
occupied
the
front
sitting
-
room
(
the
back
one
was
a
mere
closet
)
,
and
it
was
littered
down
with
waste
-
paper
and
Borrioboolan
documents
,
as
an
untidy
stable
might
be
littered
with
straw
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Jellyby
sat
there
all
day
drinking
strong
coffee
,
dictating
,
and
holding
Borrioboolan
interviews
by
appointment
.
 
<EOS>
The
unwholesome
boy
,
who
seemed
to
me
to
be
going
into
a
decline
,
took
his
meals
out
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Jellyby
came
home
,
he
usually
groaned
and
went
down
into
the
kitchen
.
<EOS>
There
he
got
something
to
eat
if
the
servant
would
give
him
anything
,
and
then
,
feeling
that
he
was
in
the
way
,
went
out
and
walked
about
Hatton
Garden
in
the
wet
.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
children
scrambled
up
and
tumbled
down
the
house
as
they
had
always
been
accustomed
to
do
.
   
<EOS>
The
production
of
these
devoted
little
sacrifices
in
any
presentable
condition
being
quite
out
of
the
question
at
a
week
's
notice
,
I
proposed
to
Caddy
that
we
should
make
them
as
happy
as
we
could
on
her
marriage
morning
in
the
attic
where
they
all
slept
,
and
should
confine
our
greatest
efforts
to
her
mama
and
her
mama
's
room
,
and
a
clean
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
In
truth
Mrs
Jellyby
required
a
good
deal
of
attention
,
the
lattice
-
work
up
her
back
having
widened
considerably
since
I
first
knew
her
and
her
hair
looking
like
the
mane
of
a
dustman
's
horse
.
   
<EOS>
Thinking
that
the
display
of
Caddy
's
wardrobe
would
be
the
best
means
of
approaching
the
subject
,
I
invited
Mrs
Jellyby
to
come
and
look
at
it
spread
out
on
Caddy
's
bed
in
the
evening
after
the
unwholesome
boy
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Miss
Summerson
,
"
said
she
,
rising
from
her
desk
with
her
usual
sweetness
of
temper
,
"
these
are
really
ridiculous
preparations
,
though
your
assisting
them
is
a
proof
of
your
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
something
so
inexpressibly
absurd
to
me
in
the
idea
of
Caddy
being
married
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Caddy
,
you
silly
,
silly
,
silly
puss
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
came
upstairs
with
us
notwithstanding
and
looked
at
the
clothes
in
her
customary

.
 
<EOS>
They

one

,

she
said

,

"
My

Summerson
,

this

!
"
   
<EOS>
On

,

was

.
 
<EOS>
And

"
Will

?
 
<EOS>
For

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well

"

,
"
<EOS>
you

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Caddy

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

"
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

"
   
<EOS>
The

Mrs
Jellyby

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
The

Mrs
Jellyby
would

to

this

tried

by
the

,
and
the

to

<EOS>

that

to
Africa
,

.
   
<EOS>
The

was
rather

,
but

Mrs
Jellyby
's

had

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Poor
Mr
Jellyby
,
who
very

and
almost

when

.
<EOS>
But

---

's

,

,
