.
<EOS>
But

came
regularly

and
sat

,

wall
,
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
Pa
!
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Ma

,

.
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
Ma
's

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jellyby

<EOS>
"
My

"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

!
"

<EOS>
It

,

"

<EOS>

---
"
   
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
But

"
   
<EOS>
I

Thavies
Inn
that
Richard

as

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
Never

,

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
I

Mrs
Jellyby
never

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
In

,

<EOS>

,

Caddy

<EOS>
But

,

---
<EOS>
and

---
 
that

as

.
   
<EOS>
We

,

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Then

old
<EOS>
Mr
Turveydrop
downstairs
,

not

,
benignly

own

.
 
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

Turveydrop
,
"

;
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
I

---

,

Regent
 
<EOS>
---

,
but

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
and

Pardiggle
were
of

---
Mr
Pardiggle
,
an

man
with

,

was

about

,

Mrs
Pardiggle
's

,

'

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Quale
,
with
his

brushed
back
as
usual

his

of

much
,
was
also

,
not
in

,
but
as
the
accepted
of
a
young
---
at

,

---

,
a
Miss
Wisk
,
who
was
also

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Wisk
's
mission
,
my
guardian
said
,
was
to
show
the
world
that
woman
's
mission
was
man
's
mission
and
that
the
only
genuine
mission
of
both
man
and
woman
was
to
be
always
moving
declaratory

about
things
in
general
at
public

.
 
<EOS>
The
guests
were
few
,
but
were
,
as
one
might
expect
at
Mrs
Jellyby
's
,
all
devoted
to
public

only
.
<EOS>
Besides
those
I
have
mentioned
,
there
was
an
extremely
dirty
lady
with
her
bonnet
all

and
the
ticketed
price
of
her
dress
still

on
it
,
<EOS>
whose
neglected
home
,
Caddy
told
me
,
was
like

,
but
whose
church
was
like
a
fancy

.
 
<EOS>
A
very
contentious
gentleman
,
who
said
it
was
his
mission
to
be
everybody
's
brother
but
who
appeared
to
be
on
terms
of
coolness
with
the
whole
of
his
large
family
,
completed
the
party
.
   
<EOS>
A
party
,
having
less
in
common
with
such
an
occasion
,
could
hardly
have
been
got
together
by
any
ingenuity
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
mean
mission
as
the
domestic
mission
was
the
very
last
thing
to
be
endured
among
them
;
indeed
,
Miss
Wisk
informed

,

before

,
that
the
idea
of
woman
's
mission
lying
chiefly
in
the
narrow

of
home
was
an
outrageous
slander
on
the
part
of
her
tyrant
,
man
.
 
<EOS>
One
other

was
that
nobody
with
a
mission
---
except
Mr
Quale
,
whose
mission
,
as
I

formerly

,
was
to

's
mission
---
 
cared

for

's
mission
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Pardiggle
being
as
clear
that
the

was
her

of

upon
the

and
applying

like

;
as
Miss
Wisk
was
that

from

her

,
man
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Jellyby
,
all

,
sat
smiling
at
the
limited
vision
that
could
see
anything
but
Borrioboola
-
Gha
.
   
<EOS>
But
I
am
anticipating
now
the
purport

our

on
the
ride

instead
of
first

Caddy
.
 
<EOS>
We
all

to

,

Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Of
the

<EOS>
old
Mr
Turveydrop
,

(

inside

)

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Miss

,

as

,

,
as

woman
's

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs
Jellyby
,
with
her
calm

and
her

,
looked
the
least

of

.
   
<EOS>
We
duly
came
back
to

,
and
Mrs
Jellyby
sat
at
the
head
of
the
table
and
Mr
Jellyby
at

.
 
<EOS>
Caddy
had
previously
stolen
upstairs
to
hug

children
again
and
tell

that
her
name
was
Turveydrop
.
 
<EOS>
But

,

,

that
I
could
do
nothing
on

<EOS>

<EOS>

(
out

.
 
<EOS>
None

<EOS>
Chapter
31
.
<EOS>
Nurse
and
Patient
 
I
had
not

at
home
again
many
days
when
one

I
went

to

Charley
's

and
see

she
was

-

.
 
<EOS>
Writing
was
a
trying
business
to
Charley
,
who
seemed
to
have
no
natural
power
over
a
pen
,
but
in
whose
hand
every
pen
appeared
to
become
perversely
animated
,
and
to
go
wrong
and
crooked
,
and
to
stop
,
and
splash
,
and
sidle
into
corners
like
a
saddle
-
donkey
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
odd
to
see
what
old
letters
Charley
's
young
hand
had
made
,
they
so
wrinkled
,
and
shrivelled
,
and
tottering
,
it
so
plump
and
round
.
<EOS>
Yet
Charley
was
uncommonly
expert
at
other
things
and
had
as
nimble
little
fingers
as
I
ever
watched
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Charley
,
"
said
I
,

over

in
which

as
square
,

,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
If

to

round
,
we

be

,
Charley
.
"
   
<EOS>
Then

,

Charley

,
and
the

would
n't
join
Charley
's
neatly
,
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
Never

,
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
We

.
"
   
<EOS>
Charley

,

copy

,

"

,

.

?
"

<EOS>
I

And

"
By

's

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
For

.
   
<EOS>
I

ill

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

.
 
<EOS>
No

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Like

"

"
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
"

,
"
how
that

.
"
   
<EOS>
My

<EOS>
The
alacrity
with
which
Charley
brought
my
bonnet
and
veil
,
and
having
dressed
me
,
quaintly
pinned
herself
into
her
warm
shawl
and
made
herself
look
like
a
little
old
woman
,
sufficiently
expressed
her
readiness
.
 
<EOS>
So
Charley
and
I
,
without
saying
anything
to
any
one
,
went
out
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
cold
,
wild
night
,
and
the
trees
shuddered
in
the
wind
.
<EOS>
The
rain
had
been
thick
and
heavy
all
day
,
and
with
little
intermission
for
many
days
.
 
<EOS>
None
was
falling
just
then
,
however
.
<EOS>
The
sky
had
partly
cleared
,
but
was
very
gloomy
---
even
above
us
,
where
a
few
stars
were
shining
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
north
and
north
-
west
,
where
the
sun
had
set
three
hours
before
,
there
was
a
pale
dead
light
both
beautiful
and
awful
;
and
into
it
long
sullen
lines
of
cloud
waved
up
like
a
sea
stricken
immovable
as
it
was
heaving
.
 
<EOS>
Towards
London
a
lurid
glare
overhung
the
whole
dark
waste
,
and
the
contrast
between
these
two
lights
,
and
the
fancy
which
the
redder
light
engendered
of
an
unearthly
fire
,
gleaming
on
all
the
unseen
buildings
of
the
city
and
on
all
the
faces
of
its
many
thousands
of
wondering
inhabitants
,
was
as
solemn
as
might
be
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
no
thought
that
night
---
<EOS>
none
,
I
am
quite
sure
---
of
what
was
soon
to
happen
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
always
remembered
since
that
when
we
had
stopped
at
the
garden
-
gate
to
look
up
at
the
sky
,
and
when
we
went
upon
our
way
,
I
had
for
a
moment
an
undefinable
impression
of
myself
as
being
something
different
from
what
I
then
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
was
then
<EOS>
and
there
that
I
had
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
ever
since
connected
the
feeling
with
that
spot
and
time
and
with
everything
associated
with
that
spot
and
time
,
to
the
distant
voices
in
the
town
,
the
barking
of
a
dog
,
and
the
sound
of
wheels
coming
down
the
miry
hill
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
Saturday
night
,
and
most
of
the
people
belonging
to
the
place
where
we
were
going
were
drinking
elsewhere
.
 
<EOS>
We
found
it
quieter
than
I
had
previously
seen
it
,
though
quite
as
miserable
.
<EOS>
The
kilns
were
burning
,
and
a
stifling
vapour
set
towards
us
with
a
pale
-
blue
glare
.
   
<EOS>
We
came
to
the
cottage
,
where
there
was
a
feeble
candle
in
the
patched
window
.
 
<EOS>
We
tapped
at
the
door
and
went
in
.
 
<EOS>
The
mother
of
the
little
child
who
had
died
was
sitting
in
a
chair
on
one

of
the
poor
fire
by
the
bed
;
and
opposite

her
,
a
wretched
boy
,
supported
by
the
chimney

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
held
under
his
arm
,
like

little

,
a
fragment
of
a
fur
cap
;
and
as
he
tried
to
warm
himself
,
he
shook
until
the
crazy
door
and
window
shook
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
was
closer
than
before
and
had
an
unhealthy
and
a
very
peculiar

.
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
lifted
by
veil
when
I
first
spoke
to
the
woman
,
which
was
at
the
moment
of
our
going
in
.
 
<EOS>
The
boy
staggered
up
instantly
and
stared
at
me
with
a
remarkable
expression
of
surprise
and
terror
.
   
<EOS>
His
action
was
so
quick
and
my
being
the
cause
of
it
was
so

that
I
stood
still

of

nearer
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
go
no
more
to
the
berryin
ground
,
"
muttered

boy
;
"
I
ai
n't
a
-
going
there
,
so
I
tell
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
lifted
my

spoke

woman
.
 
<EOS>
She

"
Do

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
'll

,
"
and

"
Jo
,
Jo
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
wot
she
's
come

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
lady
there
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
come
to

to
go
along

her
to
the
berryin

.
 
<EOS>
I
wo

to
the
berryin

.
 
<EOS>
I
do

the
name

.
 
<EOS>
She
might
go
a
-
berryin
ME
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
His

came
on

,
and
as
he
leaned

,
he

the

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
talking
off
and
on
about
such
like

,

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
you
stare
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
MY
lady
,
Jo
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
?
"
returned
the
boy
doubtfully
,
and
surveying
me
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
looks
to
me
the
t'other
one
.
<EOS>
It
ai
n't
the
bonnet
,
nor
yet
it
ai
n't
the
gownd
,
but
she
looks
to
me
the
t'other
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
little
Charley
,
with
her

experience
of
illness
and

,
had
pulled

her

now

.
 
<EOS>
Except

shown

's

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
YOU

.
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
the
lady
the
t'other

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Charley
shook
her

as

methodically
drew
his

about
him
and
made

as
warm
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
s'pose
she
ai

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>
"
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm

-
being
froze
,
"

,

,
"

,
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

---

.

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Had

,
Jo
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
-

-

's
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Whenever

fixed

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

<EOS>
"
When

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

London
yes'day
,
"

,
now

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
-

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where

going
?
<EOS>
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Somewheres
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

,

,

?
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
Every

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
It

.

<EOS>
He

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
He

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
've

(

)
;

ca

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Hark
!
<EOS>
Here

!
"
   
<EOS>
The

in
as

,

the

that

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
There

,

Mrs

.
   
<EOS>
The

here

there
,
and

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

.
 
<EOS>
One

,

the

,

so

,

<EOS>
And

,

,
<EOS>
"
Jenny
,
your

's

,

,

<EOS>
They

"

"

"

<EOS>
Jenny
,

!
   
<EOS>
Young

,

,

<EOS>
She

,
and
presenfty
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
Charley
,

,

,

Jo
,
just

.
   
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
For

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
   
<EOS>

,

I

"

;
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

---

<EOS>
They

<EOS>
Then

"

ai

,

ai

.
 
<EOS>
Is

THREE

?
"
   
<EOS>
Charley

.
 
<EOS>
I

myself

.
   
<EOS>
But

that
he
acknowledged
that
influence
in
me
,
I
led
the
way
straight
home
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
far
,
only
at
the
summit
of
the
hill
.
 
<EOS>
We
passed
but
one
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
doubted
if
we
should
have
got
home
without
assistance
,
the
boy
's
steps
were
so
uncertain
and
tremulous
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
no
complaint
,
however
,
and
was
strangely
unconcerned
about
himself
,
if
I
may
say
so
strange
a
thing
.
   
<EOS>
Leaving
him
in
the
hall
for
a
moment
,
shrunk
into
the
corner
of
the
window
-
seat
and
staring
with
an
indifference
that
scarcely
could
be
called
wonder
at
the
comfort
and
brightness
about
him
<EOS>
,
I
went
into
the
drawing
-
room
to
speak
to
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
There
I
found
Mr
Skimpole
,
who
had
come
down
by
the
coach
,
as
he
frequently
did
without
notice
,
and
never
bringing
any
clothes
with
him
,
but
always
borrowing
everything
he
wanted
.
   
<EOS>
They
came
out
with
me
directly
to
look
at
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
The
servants
had
gathered
in
the
hall
too
,
and
he
shivered
in
the
window
-
seat
with
Charley
standing
by
him
,
like
some
wounded
animal
that
had
been
found
in
a
ditch
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
sorrowful
case
,
"
said
my
guardian
after
asking
him
a
question
or
two
and
touching
him
and
examining
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
,
Harold
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
turn
him
out
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
my
guardian
,
almost
sternly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Jarndyce
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
you
know
what
I
am
:
I
am
a
child
.
 
<EOS>
Be
cross
to
me
if
I
deserve
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
a
constitutional
objection
to
this
sort
of
thing
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
had
,
when
I
was
a
medical
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
not
safe
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
very
bad
sort
of
fever
about
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
had
retreated
from
the
hall
to
the
drawing
-
room
again
and
said
this
in
his
airy
way
,
seated
on
the
music
-
stool
as
we
stood
by
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
say
it
's
childish
,
"
observed
Mr
Skimpole
,
looking
gaily
at
us
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
dare
say
it
may
be
;
but
I
AM
a
child
,
and
I
never
pretend
to
be
anything
else
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
put
him
out
in
the
road
,
you
only
put
him
where
he
was
before
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
be
no
worse
off
than
he
was
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
Even
make
him
better
off
,
if
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
Give
him
sixpence
,
or
five
shillings
,
or
five
pound
ten
---
you
are
arithmeticians
,
and
I
am
not
---
and
get
rid
of
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
is
he
to
do
then
?
"
asked
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
life
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
with
his
engaging
smile
,
"
I
have
not
the
least
idea
what
he
is
to
do
then
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
no
doubt
he
'll
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
is
it
not
a
horrible
reflection
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
to
whom
I
had
hastily
explained
the
unavailing
efforts
of
the
two
women
,
"
is
it
not
a
horrible
reflection
,
"
walking
up
and
down
and
rumpling
his
hair
,
"
that
if
this
wretched
creature
were
a
convicted
prisoner
,
his
hospital
would
be
wide
open
to
him
,
and
he
would
be
as
well
taken
care
of
as
any
sick
boy
in
the
kingdom
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Jarndyce
,
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
you
'll
pardon
the
simplicity
of
the
question
,
coming
as
it
does
from
a
creature
who
is
perfectly
simple
in
worldly
matters
,
but
why
ISN'T
he
a
prisoner
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
My
guardian
stopped
and
looked
at
him
with
a
whimsical
mixture
of
amusement
and
indignation
in
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
young
friend
is
not
to
be
suspected
of
any
delicacy
,
I
should
imagine
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
unabashed
and
candid
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
me
that
it
would
be
wiser
,
as
well
as
in
a
certain
kind
of
way
more
respectable
,
if
he
showed
some
misdirected
energy
that
got
him
into
prison
.
 
<EOS>
There
would
be
more
of
an
adventurous
spirit
in
it
,
and
consequently
more
of
a
certain
sort
of
poetry
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
,
"
returned
my
guardian
,
resuming
his
uneasy
walk
,
"
that
there
is
not
such
another
child
on
earth
as
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
really
?
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
confess
I
do
n't
see
why
our
young
friend
,
in
his
degree
,
should
not
seek
to
invest
himself
with
such
poetry
as
is
open
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
no
doubt
born
with
an
appetite
---
<EOS>
probably
,
when
he
is
in
a
safer
state
of
health
,
he
has
an
excellent
appetite
.
 
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
At
our
young
friend
's
natural
dinner
hour
,
most
likely
about
noon
,
our
young
friend
says
in
effect
to
society
,
"
I
am
hungry
;
will
you
have
the
goodness
to
produce
your
spoon
and
feed
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
Society
,
which
has
taken
upon
itself
the
general
arrangement
of
the
whole
system
of
spoons
and
professes
to
have
a
spoon
for
our
young
friend
,
does
NOT
produce
that
spoon
;
and
our
young
friend
,
therefore
,
says
"
You
really
must
excuse
me
if
I
seize
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
Now
,
this
appears
to
me
a
case
of
misdirected
energy
,
which
has
a
certain
amount
of
reason
in
it
and
a
certain

of
romance
;
and
I
do
n't
know
but
what
I
should
be
more
interested
in
our
young
friend
,
as
an

of
such
a
case
,
than
merely
as
a
poor
vagabond
---
which
any
one
can
be
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
meantime
,
"
I
ventured
to
observe
,
"
he
is
getting
worse
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
meantime
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
cheerfully
,
"
as
Miss
Summerson
,
with
her
practical
good

,
observes
,
he
is
getting
worse
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
recommend
your
turning
him
out
before
he
gets
still
worse
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
amiable
face
with
which
he
said
it
<EOS>
,
I
think
I
shall
never
forget
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
little
woman
,
"
observed
my
guardian
,
tuming
to
me
,
<EOS>
"
I
can
ensure
his
admission
into
the
proper
place
by
merely
going
there
to
enforce
it
,
though
it
's
a
bad
state
of
things
when
,
in
his
condition
,
that
is
necessary
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
growing
late
,
and
is
a
very
bad
night
,
and
the
boy
is
worn
out
already
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
bed
in
the
wholesome
loft
-
room
by
the
stable
;
we
had
better
keep
him
there
till
morning
,
when
he
can
be
wrapped
up
and
removed
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
do
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
with
his
hands
upon
the
keys
of
the
piano
as
we

.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
back
to
our
young
friend
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
I
envy
you
your
constitution
,
Jarndyce
!
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
with
playful
admiration
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mind
these
things
;
<EOS>
neither
does
Miss
Summerson
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
ready
at
all
times
to
go
anywhere
,
and
do
anything
.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
will
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
will
at
all
---
and
no
wo
n't
---
simply
ca
n't
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
recommend
anything
for
the
boy
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
my
guardian
,
looking
back
over
his
shoulder
half
angrily
;
only
half
angrily
,
for
he
never
seemed
to
consider
Mr
Skimpole
an
accountable
being
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Jarndyce
,
I
observed
a
bottle
of
cooling
medicine
in
his
pocket
,
and
it
's
impossible
for
him
to
do
better
than
take
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
tell
them
to
sprinkle
a
little
vinegar
about
the
place
where
he
sleeps
and
to
keep
it
moderately
cool
and
him
moderately
warm
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
mere
impertinence
in
me
to
offer
any
recommendation
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Summerson
has
such
a
knowledge
of
detail
and
such
a
capacity
for
the
administration
of
detail
that
she
knows
all
about
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
went
back
into
the
hall
and
explained
to
Jo
what
we
proposed
to
do
,
which
Charley
explained
to
him
again
and
which
he
received
with
the
languid
unconcern
I
had
already
noticed
,
wearily
looking
on
at
what
was
done
as
if
it
were
for
somebody
else
.
 
<EOS>
The
servants
compassionating
his
miserable
state
and
being
very
anxious
to
help
,
we
soon
got
the
loft
-
room
ready
;
and
some
of
the
men
about
the
house
carried
him
across
the
wet
yard
,
well
wrapped
up
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
pleasant
to
observe
how
kind
they
were
to
him
and
how
there
appeared
to
be
a
general
impression
among
them
that
frequently
calling
him
"
Old
Chap
"
was
likely
to
revive
his
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
Charley
directed
the
operations
and
went
to
and
fro
between
the
loft
-
room
and
the
house
with
such
little
stimulants
and
comforts
as
we
thought
it
safe
to
give
him
.
 
<EOS>
My
guardian
himself
saw
him
before
he
was
left
for
the
night
and
reported
to
me
when
he
returned
to
the
growlery
to
write
a
letter
on
the
boy
's
behalf
,
which
a
messenger
was
charged
to
deliver
at
day
-
light
in
the
morning
,
that
he
seemed
easier
and
inclined
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
fastened
his
door
on
the
outside
,
he
said
,
in
case
of
his
being
delirious
,
but
had
so
arranged
that
he
could
not
make
any
noise
without
being
heard
.
   
<EOS>
Ada
being
in
our
room
with
a
cold
,
Mr
Skimpole
was
left
alone
all
this
time
and
entertained
himself
by
playing
snatches
of
pathetic
airs
and
sometimes
singing
to
them
(
as
we
heard
at
a
distance
)
with
great
expression
and
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
rejoined
him
in
the
drawing
-
room
he
said
he
would
give
us
a
little
ballad
which
had
come
into
his
head
"
apropos
of
our
young
friend
,
"
and
he
sang
one
about
a
peasant
boy
,
      
"
Thrown
on
the
wide
world
,
doomed
to
wander
and
roam
,
    
Bereft
of
his
parents
,
bereft
of
a
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
quite
exquisitely
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
song
that
always
made
him
cry
,
he
told
us
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
extremely
gay
all
the
rest
of
the
evening
,
for
he
absolutely
chirped
---
those
were
his
delighted
words
---
when
he
thought
by
what
a
happy
talent
for
business
he
was
surrounded
.
 
<EOS>
He
gave
us
,
in
his
glass
of
negus
,
"
Better
health
to
our
young
friend
!
"
and
supposed
and
gaily
pursued
the
case
of
his
being
reserved
like
Whittington
to
become
Lord
Mayor
of
London
.
 
<EOS>
In
that
event
,
no
doubt
,
he
would
establish
the
Jarndyce
Institution
and
the
Summerson
Almshouses
,
and
a
little
annual
Corporation
Pilgrimage
to
St
Albans
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
doubt
,
he
said
,
that
our
young
friend
was
an
excellent
boy
in
his
way
,
but
his
way
was
not
the
Harold
Skimpole
way
;
what
Harold
Skimpole
was
,
Harold
Skimpole
had
found
himself
,
to
his
considerable
surprise
,
when
he
first
made
his
own
acquaintance
;
he
had
accepted
himself
with
all
his
failings
and
had
thought
it
sound
philosophy
to
make
the
best
of
the
bargain
;
and
he
hoped
we
would
do
the
same
.
   
<EOS>
Charley
's
last
report
was
that
the
boy
was
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
see
,
from
my
window
,
the
lantern
they
had
left
him
burning
quietly
;
and
I
went
to
bed
very
happy
to
think
that
he
was
sheltered
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
more
movement
and
more
talking
than
usual
a
little
before
daybreak
,
and
it
awoke
me
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
was
dressing
,
I
looked
out
of
my
window
and
asked
one
of
our
men
who
had
been
among
the
active
sympathizers
last
night
whether
there
was
anything
wrong
about
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
lantern
was
still
burning
in
the
loft
-
window
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
boy
,
miss
,
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
worse
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gone
,
miss
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
,
miss
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Gone
clean
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
what
time
of
the
night
he
had
gone
,
or
how
,
or
why
,
it
seemed
hopeless
ever
to
divine
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
remaining
as
it
had
been
left
,
and
the
lantern
standing
in
the
window
,
it
could
only
be
supposed
that
he
had
got
out
by
a
trap
in
the
floor
which
communicated
with
an
empty
cart
-
house
below
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
shut
it
down
again
,
if
that
were
so
;
and
it
looked
as
if
it
had
not
been
raised
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
of
any
kind
was
missing
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
fact
being
clearly
ascertained
,
we
all
yielded
to
the
painful
belief
that
delirium
had
come
upon
him
in
the
night
and
that
,
allured
by
some
imaginary
object
or
pursued
by
some
imaginary
horror
,
he
had
strayed
away
in
that
worse
than
helpless
state
;
all
of
us
,
that
is
to
say
,
but
Mr
Skimpole
,
who
repeatedly
suggested
,
in
his
usual
easy
light
style
,
that
it
had
occurred
to
our
young
friend
that
he
was
not
a
safe
inmate
,
having
a
bad
kind
of
fever
upon
him
,
and
that
he
had
with
great
natural
politeness
taken
himself
off
.
   
<EOS>
Every
possible
inquiry
was
made
,
and
every
place
was
searched
.
 
<EOS>
The
brick
-
kilns
were
examined
,
the
cottages
were
visited
,
the
two
women
were
particularly
questioned
,
but
they
knew
nothing
of
him
,
and
nobody
could
doubt
that
their
wonder
was
genuine
.
 
<EOS>
The
weather
had
for
some
time
been
too
wet
and
the
night
itself
had
been
too
wet
to
admit
of
any
tracing
by
footsteps
.
 
<EOS>
Hedge
and
ditch
,
and
wall
,
and
rick
and
stack
,
were
examined
by
our
men
for
a
long
distance
round
,
lest
the
boy
should
be
lying
in
such
a
place
insensible
or
dead
;
but
nothing
was
seen
to
indicate
that
he
had
ever
been
near
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
time
when
he
was
left
in
the
loft
-
room
,
he
vanished
.
   
<EOS>
The
search
continued
for
five
days
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
mean
that
it
ceased
even
then
,
but
that
my
attention
was
then
diverted
into
a
current
very
memorable
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
As
Charley
was
at
her
writing
again
in
my
room
in
the
evening
,
and
as
I
sat
opposite
to
her
at
work
,
I
felt
the
table
tremble
.
<EOS>
Looking
up
,
I
saw
my
little
maid
shivering
from
head
to
foot
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charley
,
"
said
I
,
"
are
you
so
cold
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
am
,
miss
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
hold
myself
still
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
so
yesterday
at
about
this
same
time
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
uneasy
,
I
think
I
'm
ill
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
heard
Ada
's
voice
outside
,
and
I
hurried
to
the
door
of
communication
between
my
room
and
our
pretty
sitting
-
room
,
and
locked

.
 
<EOS>
Just
in
time
,
for
she
tapped
at
it
while
my
hand
was
yet
upon
the
key
.
   
<EOS>
Ada
called
to
me
to
let
her
in
,
but
I
said
,
"
Not
now
,
my
dearest
.
<EOS>
Go
away
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
the
matter
;
I
will
come
to
you
presently
.
"
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
It
was
a
long
,
long
time
before
my
darling
girl
<EOS>
and
I
were
companions
again
.
   
<EOS>
Charley
fell
ill
.
 
<EOS>
In
twelve
hours
she
was
very
ill
.
 
<EOS>
I
moved
her
to
my
room
,
and
laid
her
in
my
bed
,
and
sat
down
quietly
to
nurse
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
my
guardian
all
about
it
,
and
why
I
felt
it
was
necessary
that
I
should
seclude
myself
,
and
my
reason
for
not
seeing
my
darling
above
all
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
she
came
very
often
to
the
door
,
and
called
to
me
,
and
even
reproached
me
with
sobs
and
tears
;
but
I
wrote
her
a
long
letter
saying
that
she
made
me
anxious
and
unhappy
and
imploring
her
,
as
she
loved
me
and
wished
my
mind
to
be
at
peace
,
to
come
no
nearer
than
the
garden
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
she
came
beneath
the
window
even
oftener
than
she
had
come
to
the
door
,
and
if
I
had
learnt
to
love
her
dear
sweet
voice
before
when
we
were
hardly
ever
apart
<EOS>
,
how
did
I
learn
to
love
it
then
,
when
I
stood
behind
the
window

listening
and
replying
,
but
not
so
much
as
looking
out
!
 
<EOS>
How
did
I
learn
to
love
it
afterwards
,
when
the
harder
time
came
!
   
<EOS>
They
put
a
bed
for
me
in
our
sitting
-
room
;
and
by
keeping
the
door
wide
open
,
I
turned
the
two
rooms
into
one
,
now
that
Ada
had
vacated
that
part
of
the
house
,
and
kept
them
always
fresh
and
airy
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
not
a
servant
in
or
about
the
house
but
was
so
good
that
they
would
all
most
gladly
have
come
to
me
at
any
hour
of
the
day
or
night
without
the
least
fear
or
unwillingness
,
but
I
thought
it
best
to
choose
one
worthy
woman
who
was
never
to
see
Ada
and
whom
I
could
trust
to
come
and
go
with
all
precaution
.
 
<EOS>
Through
her
means
I
got
out
to
take
the
air
with
my
guardian
when
there
was
no
fear
of
meeting
Ada
,
and
wanted
for
nothing
in
the
way
of
attendance
,
any
more
than
in
any
other
respect
.
   
<EOS>
And
thus
poor
Charley
sickened
and
grew
worse
,
and
fell
into
heavy
danger
of
death
,
and
lay
severely
ill
for
many
a
long
round
of
day
and
night
.
 
<EOS>
So
patient
she
was
,
so
uncomplaining
,
and
inspired
by
such
a
gentle
fortitude
that
very
often
as
I
sat
by
Charley
holding
her
head
in
my
arms
<EOS>
---
repose
would
come
to
her
,
so
,
when
it
would
come
to
her
in
no
other
attitude
---
I
silently
prayed
to
our
Father
in
heaven
that
I
might
not
forget
the
lesson
which
this
little
sister
taught
me
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
very
sorrowful
to
think
that
Charley
's
pretty
looks
would
change
and
be
disfigured
,
even
if
she
recovered
---
she
was
such
a
child
with
her
dimpled
face
---
but
that
thought
was
,
for
the
greater
part
,
lost
in
her
greater
peril
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
was
at
the
worst
,
and
her
mind
rambled
again
to
the
cares
of
her
father
's
sick
bed
and
the
little
children
,
she
still
knew
me
so
far
as
that
she
would
be
quiet
in
my
arms
when
she
could
lie
quiet
nowhere
else
,
and
murmur
out
the
wanderings
of
her

less

.
 
<EOS>
At
those
times
I
used
to
think
,
how
should
I
ever
tell
the
two
remaining

that
the
baby
who
had
learned
of
her

to
be

them
in

was
dead
!
   
<EOS>
There
were
other

when
Charley
knew
me
well
and
talked
to
me
,
telling
me
that
she
sent
her
love
to
Tom
and
Emma
and
that
she
was
sure
Tom
would
grow
up
to
be
a
good

.
 
<EOS>
At
those
times
Charley
would
speak
to
me
of
what
she
had
read
to
her
father
as
well
as
she
could
to
comfort

,
of
that
young
man
carried
out
to
be

who
was

only

of

a

,
of
the
ruler
's
daughter
raised
up
by

upon

of

.
 
<EOS>
And
Charley
told
me
that
when
her
father
died
she
had
kneeled
down
and
prayed
in
her
first
sorrow
that
he
likewise
might
be
raised

and
given

to
his

,
and
that
if

never

,
she
thought

likely
that
it
might
come

.
 
<EOS>
Then
would
I
show
Tom
how
these
people
of
old
days
had
been
brought
back
to
life
on
earth
,
only
that
we
might
know

!
   
<EOS>
But

all

various

there
were
in
Charley
's
illness
,
there
was
not
one
when
she
lost
the
gentle

I
have
spoken
of
.
<EOS>
And

many
,

I

in

of

in
the

,

,
on

.
   
<EOS>
And
Charley
did

.
 
<EOS>
She
flutteringiy
and
slowly
turned
the
dangerous
point
,
after
long

,

.
 
<EOS>
The
hope
that
never

,
from
the
first
,
of
Charley
being
in
outward
appearance
<EOS>
Charley
any

and
even

,

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
morning
when
I
could
tell
Ada
all
this
as

;
and

Charley

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

.
   
<EOS>
Happily

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
able

hide

I
felt
at
tea

,
but
I
was
past

,
and

I

.
   
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
But

;

<EOS>

with

.
   
<EOS>
In

I

Charley
,
with
which
view
<EOS>
I

,
"
You

"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
Strong

"
   
"
Quite

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

;

<EOS>
It

!
"
<EOS>
and

out

<EOS>
"

,

"

"

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
If

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
"
<EOS>
---
how

<EOS>

---
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
So

Charley
cry

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Trust

,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
little

,
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
I

to
-

that
I
do

and
that

.
"
   
<EOS>
For
that

poor
child
thanked

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

morning
,

Ada

,

to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
At

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Charley

,
and
I
lay

,
for
I
was
very

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
the
doctor
that
night
and
asked

that
I

relative

nothing
of
my

in

as

.
<EOS>
I
have

that

,
and
of
day
melting
into

;
but
I
was
just
able

the
first
morning
to
get

window
and

.
   
<EOS>
On
the
second
morning
I
heard

dear

---
<EOS>
Oh
,
how
dear
now
!
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
outside
;
and
I
asked
Charley
,
with
some
difficulty
(
speech
being
painful
to
me
)
,
to
go
and

I
was

.
 
<EOS>
I
heard

,
"
Do

,
Charley
,
for
the
world
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
does
my
own
Pride
look
,
Charley
?
<EOS>
"
I
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
Disappointed
,
miss
,
"
said
Charley
,
peeping
through

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
know
she
is
very
beautiful
this

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
indeed
,
miss
,
"
answered
Charley
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Still
looking
up
at
the
window
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
her
blue
clear
eyes
,
God
bless
them
,
always
loveliest
when
raised
like
that
!
   
<EOS>
I
called
Charley
to
me
and
gave
her
her
last
charge
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Charley
,
when
she

am
ill
,

.
 
<EOS>
Keep

,
Charley
,
if
you
love
me
truly
,
to
the
last
!
 
<EOS>
Charley
,
if
you
let
her
in
but
once
,
only
to
look
upon
me
for
one

as
I
lie
here
,
I
shall
die
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
will
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
will
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
promised
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
it
,
my
dear
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
come
and
sit
beside
me
for
a
little
while
,
and
touch
me
with
your
hand
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
can
not
see
you
,
Charley
;
I
am
blind
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
32
.
<EOS>
The
Appointed
Time
 
<EOS>
It
is
night
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
---
perplexed
and
troublous
valley
of
the
shadow
of
the
law
,
where
suitors
generally
find
but
little
day
---
and
fat
candles
are
snuffed
out
in
offices
,
and
clerks
have
rattled
down
the
crazy
wooden
stairs
and
dispersed
.
 
<EOS>
The
bell
that
rings
at
nine
o'clock
has
ceased
its
doleful
clangour
about
nothing
;
the
gates
are
shut
;
and
the
night
-
porter
,
a
solemn
warder
with
a
mighty
power
of
sleep
,
keeps
guard
in
his
lodge
.
 
<EOS>
From
tiers
of
staircase
windows
clogged
lamps
like
the
eyes
of
Equity
,
bleared
Argus
with
a
fathomless
pocket
for
every
eye
and
an
eye
upon
it
,
dimly
blink
at
the
stars
.
 
<EOS>
In
dirty
upper
casements
,
here
and
there
,
hazy
little
patches
of
candlelight
reveal
where
some
wise
draughtsman
and
conveyancer
yet
toils
for
the
entanglement
of
real
estate
in
meshes
of
sheep
-
skin
,
in
the
average
ratio
of
about
a
dozen
of
sheep
to
an
acre
of
land
.
 
<EOS>
Over
which
bee
-
like
industry
these
benefactors
of
their
species
linger
yet
,
<EOS>
though
office
-
hours
be
past
,
that
they
may
give
,
for
every
day
,
some
good
account
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
neighbouring
court
,
where
the
Lord
Chancellor
of
the
rag
and
bottle
shop
dwells
,
there
is
a
general
tendency
towards
beer
and
supper
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Piper
and
Mrs
Perkins
,
whose
respective
sons
,
engaged
with
a
circle
of
acquaintance
in
the
game
of
hide
and
seek
,
have
been
lying
in
ambush
about
the
by
-
ways
of
Chancery
Lane
for
some
hours
and
scouring
the
plain
of
the
same
thoroughfare
to
the
confusion
of
passengers
---
Mrs
Piper
and
Mrs
Perkins
have
but
now
exchanged
congratulations
on
the
children
being
abed
,
and
they
still
linger
on
a
door
-
step
over
a
few
parting
words
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Krook
and
his
lodger
,
and
the
fact
of
Mr
Krook
's
being
"
continually
in
liquor
,
"
and
the
testamentary
prospects
of
the
young
man
are
,
as
usual
,
the
staple
of
their
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
have
something
to
say
,
likewise
,
of
the
Harmonic
Meeting
at
the
Sol
's
Arms
,
where
the
sound
of
the
piano
through
the
partly
opened
windows
jingles
out
into
the
court
,
and
where
Little
Swills
,
after
keeping
the
lovers
of
harmony
in
a
roar
like
a
very
Yorick
,
may
now
be
heard
taking
the
gruff
line
in
a
concerted
piece
and
sentimentally
adjuring
his
friends
and
patrons
to
"
Listen
,
listen
,
listen
,
tew
the
wa
-
ter
fall
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Perkins
and
Mrs
Piper
compare
opinions
on
the
subject
of
the
young
lady
of
professional
celebrity
who
assists
at
the
Harmonic
Meetings
and
who
has
a
space
to
herself
in
the
manuscript
announcement
in
the
window
,
Mrs
Perkins
possessing
information
that
she
has
been
married
a
year
and
a
half
,
though
announced
as
Miss
M
Melvilleson
,
the
noted
siren
,
and
that
her
baby
is
clandestinely
conveyed
to
the
Sol
's
Arms
every
night
to
receive
its
natural
nourishment
during
the
entertainments
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sooner
than
which
,
myself
,
"
says
Mrs
Perkins
,
"
I
would
get
my
living
by
selling
lucifers
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Piper
,
as
in
duty
bound
,
is
of
the
same
opinion
,
holding
that
a
private
station
is
better
than
public
applause
,
and
thanking
heaven
for
her
own
(
and
,
by
implication
,
Mrs
Perkins
'
)
respectability
.
 
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
pot
-
boy
of
the
Sol
's
Arms
appearing
with
her
supper
-
pint
well
frothed
,
Mrs
Piper
accepts
that
tankard
and
retires
indoors
,
first
giving
a
fair
good
night
to
Mrs
Perkins
,
who
has
had
her
own
pint
in
her
hand
ever
since
it
was
fetched
from
the
same
hostelry
by
young
Perkins
before
he
was
sent
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
Now
there
is
a
sound
of
putting
up
shop
-
shutters
in
the
court
and
a
smell
as
of
the
smoking
of
pipes
;
and
shooting
stars
are
seen
in
upper
windows
,
further
indicating
retirement
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
too
,
the
policeman
begins
to
push
at
doors
;
to
try
fastenings
;
to
be
suspicious
of
bundles
;
and
to
administer
his
beat
,
on
the
hypothesis
that
every
one
is
either
robbing
or
being
robbed
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
close
night
,
though
the
damp
cold
is
searching
too
,
and
there
is
a
laggard
mist
a
little
way
up
in
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
fine
steaming
night
to
turn
the
slaughter
-
houses
,
the
unwholesome
trades
,
the
sewerage
,
bad
water
,
and
burial
-
grounds
to
account
,
and
give
the
registrar
of
deaths
some
extra
business
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
something
in
the
air
<EOS>
---
there
is
plenty
in
it
---
or
it
may
be
something
in
himself
that
is
in
fault
;
but
Mr
Weevle
,
otherwise
Jobling
,
is
very
ill
at
ease
.
 
<EOS>
He
comes
and
goes
between
his
own
room
and
the
open
street
door
twenty
times
an
hour
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
doing
so
ever
since
it
fell
dark
.
 
<EOS>
Since
the
Chancellor
shut
up
his
shop
,
which
he
did
very
early
to
-
night
,
Mr
Weevle
has
been
down
and
up
,
and
down
and
up
(
with
a
cheap
tight
velvet
skull
-
cap
on
his
head
,
making
his
whiskers
look
out
of
all
proportion
)
,
oftener
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
no
phenomenon
that
Mr
Snagsby
should
be
ill
at
ease
too
,
for
he
always
is
so
,
more
or
less
,
under
the
oppressive
influence
of
the
secret
that
is
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
Impelled
by
the
mystery
of
which
he
is
a
partaker
and
yet
in
which
he
is
not
a
sharer
,
Mr
Snagsby
haunts
what
seems
to
be
its
fountain
-
head
---
the
rag
and
bottle
shop
in
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
an
irresistible
attraction
for
him
.
 
<EOS>
Even
now
,
coming
round
by
the
Sol
's
Arms
with
the
intention
of
passing
down
the
court
,
and
out
at
the
Chancery
Lane
end
,
and
so
terminating
his
unpremeditated
after
-
supper
stroll
of
ten
minutes
'
long
from
his
own
door
and
back
again
,
Mr
Snagsby
approaches
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
Mr
Weevle
?
"
says
the
stationer
,
stopping
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
YOU
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
says
Weevle
,
"
Here
I
am
,
Mr
Snagsby
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Airing
yourself
,
as
I
am
doing
,
before
you
go
to
bed
?
"
<EOS>
the
stationer
inquires
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
there
's
not
much
air
to
be
got
here
;
and
what
there
is
,
is
not
very
freshening
,
"
Weevle

,
glancing
up
and
down
the
court
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
true
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
observe
,
"
says
Mr
Snagsby
,
pausing
to
sniff
and
taste
the
air
a
little
,
"
do

you
observe
,
<EOS>
Mr
Weevle
,
that
you
're
---
not
to
put
too
fine
a
point
upon
it
---
that
you
're
rather
greasy
here
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
have
noticed
myself
that
there
is
a
queer
kind

flavour
in

place
to
-
night
,
"
Mr
Weevle

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
's
chops
at
the
Sol
's
Arms
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Chops
,
do
you
think
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Chops
,
eh
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
sniffs
and
tastes
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
should
say
their
cook
at
the
Sol
wanted
a
little
looking
after
.
 
<EOS>
She
has

,

!
 
<EOS>
And
I
do
n't
think
"
---
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
sniffs

again
and
then
spits
and
wipes

---
"
I
do
n't
think
---
 
not

---
that
they

the

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

tainting

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
IS

tainting

weather
,
"
says
Mr
Snagsby
,
"
and
I
find
it
sinking
to
the

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
By
George
!
 
<EOS>
I

,
"
returns

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,

,

,

,

,
"

,
looking
in

other
's

along

and

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
live
in

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

of
an

,

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
But

's

did

,
in

,

I

.
<EOS>
That

difference
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
quite
enough
about
it
,
"
returns
Tony
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
agreeable
,

?
"
<EOS>
pursues
Mr
Snagsby
,

behind

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Krook
ought
to
consider

in

rent
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope

does
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope

does
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
find

rent
too
high
,

,

?
"
returns

stationer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rents
ARE
high
about
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
it
is

,
but

law

to

up
in

.
 
<EOS>
Not
,
"
adds
Mr
Snagsby
with

,
"
that
I
mean
to
say

against
the
profession
I
get
my

by
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weevle
again

up

down
the
court
and
then

at

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
,

,

and

of
not

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,

,
"

,

,
"
that
he

---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Who
's

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
deceased
,

,
"
says
Mr
Snagsby
,
twitching

and
right

towards

and

his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

!
<EOS>
"
returns

-

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Which

,

,
"

,

Mr

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
There

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just

,
"
observes

.
"
<EOS>
Quite
a

in

.
 
<EOS>
Quite

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,

Weevle
,
I

night
"
---
<EOS>
Mr
Snagsby
speaks
as
if
it
made
him
desolate
to
go
,
though
he
has
been
casting
about
for
any

of

ever
since

to

---
"
my
little
woman
will
be
looking

else
.
 
<EOS>
Good

,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
If
Mr
Snagsby
hastens
home
to
save
his
little
woman
the
trouble
of
looking

him
,
he
might

.
 
<EOS>
His

woman
has
had
her

upon

round
the
Sol
's
Arms
all
this
time
and
now

with

,
honourmg

Weevle
and

past
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
know
me
again
,

,
at

,
"
says
Mr
Weevle
to

;
"
and
I
ca
n't

,
whoever

,

.
 
<EOS>
Is
this
fellow
NEVER
coming
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
fellow
approaches
as
he
speaks
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weevle
softly
holds
up
his
finger
,
and
draws
him
into
the
passage
,
and
closes
the
street
door
.
 
<EOS>
Then
they
go
upstairs
,
Mr
Weevle
heavily
,
and
Mr
Guppy
(
for
it
is
he
)
very
lightly

.
 
<EOS>
When
they
are
shut
into
the
back
room
,
they
speak
low
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
had
gone
to
Jericho
at
least
instead
of
coming
here
,
"
says
Tony
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
said
about
ten
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
said
about
ten
,
"
Tony

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

you
did
say

.
 
<EOS>
But
according

my

,
it
's
ten
times
ten
<EOS>
---
it
's
a
hundred
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
had
such
a
night
in
my
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
has
been
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
it
!
"
says
Tony
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
has
been
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
But
here
have
I
been
stewing
and

in
this

crib
till

have
had
the

.
 
<EOS>
THERE
'S
a
blessed
-
looking

!
"
<EOS>

,

with

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
IS

?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
so

as
you

.
 
<EOS>
It
has

smouldering
like
that
ever
since

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

's

,
Tony

"
<EOS>

,

,

down
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
William
Guppy
,
"
replies

,
"
I
am
in
the

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
this
unbearably
dull
,
suicidal
room
---
and
old
Boguey
downstairs
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Weevle
moodily
pushes
the
snuffers
-

from

with

,
leans
his

on

,
puts

,

at

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
,
observing

,
slightly

and
sits
down
on

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Was

that
Snagsby
talking
to

,
Tony
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

---

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

"

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

,
William
G
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>

,

!

<EOS>
Mr

round

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

was
,
"
growls
Tony
,
without

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
some
fashionable
conversation
,
here
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Finding
by
this

that
his

,
Mr

about
upon

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
Tony
,
"

,
"
I

,
for
no

knows
what

is
when

does
come
upon

better

,
and

'

.
 
<EOS>
But

when

is

,
and
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,

,
"

Guppy
,
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

that

and

to

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
William
Guppy
,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
Dash
<EOS>
it
,
Tony
,
"

,
"
you

'

NOT

.
 
<EOS>
You
,
Tony
,
possess

.
 
<EOS>

---

,

,

I

same
<EOS>
---

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
Tony
,

,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Tony

,

,
"
William
Guppy
,

!
"
 
<EOS>

,
"
I

,
Tony
,

.

<EOS>
"
And

,
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Is

of
Krook
to

to
-
night
to

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
.
 
<EOS>
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

do

?
 
<EOS>
HE
do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
Said
to
-
day
was
his
birthday
and
he
'd

over
to
-

at

.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
have
drunk

.
 
<EOS>
He
has

all

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
has

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Forgotten
?
 
<EOS>
Trust

for

.
 
<EOS>
He
never

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw

to
-
night
,

---

---
and

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
At

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tony

"

"

ca

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Read
!
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
He

.
 
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

"

"
A

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

<EOS>
Mr

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
"

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Confound

<EOS>
,

wo
n't

---
smears

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
Boguey

a

.

<EOS>
The

-

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

,

?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't

too

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

---
"

You
ca

,
"

Tony

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
nods

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

in
my
hands
---
a
legal
friend
of
yours
---
for
security
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
forces
us
to
it
,
they
'll
be
producible
,
wo
n't
they
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ye
-
es
,
"
is
Mr
Weevle
's
reluctant
admission
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Tony
,
"
remonstrates
his
friend
,
"
how
you
look
!
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
doubt
William
Guppy
?
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
suspect
any
harm
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suspect
anything
more
than
I
know
,
William
,
"
returns
the
other
gravely
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
you
know
?
"
urges
Mr
Guppy
,
raising
his
voice
a
little
;
but
on
his
friend
's
once
more
warning
him
,
"
I
tell
you
,
you
ca
n't
speak
too
low
,
"
he
repeats
his
question
without
any
sound
at
all
,
forming
with
his
lips
only
the
words
,
"
<EOS>
What
do
you
know
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
three
things
.
 
<EOS>
First
,
I
know
that
here
we
are
whispering
in
secrecy
,
a
pair
of
conspirators
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
says
Mr
Guppy
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
we
had
better
be
that
than
a
pair
of
noodles
,
which
we
should
be
if
we
were
doing
anything
else
,
for
it
's
the
only

of
doing

we
want

.
 
<EOS>
Secondly
?
"
   
"
Secondly
,
it
's
not
made
out
to
me
how
it
's
likely
to
be
profitable
,
after
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
casts
up
his
eyes
at
the
portrait
of
Lady
Dedlock
over
the
mantelshelf
and
replies
,
<EOS>
"
Tony
,
you
are
asked
to
leave
that
to
the
honour
of
your
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
its
being
calculated
to
serve
that
friend
in
those
chords
of
the
human
mind
which
---
which
need

be
called
into
agonizing
vibration
on
the
present

---
your
friend
is
no
fool
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
eleven
o'clock
striking
by
the
bell
of
Saint
Paul
's
.
 
<EOS>
Listen
and
you
'll
hear
all
the
bells
in
the
city
jangling
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Both
sit
silent
,
listening
to
the
metal
voices
,
near
and
distant
,
resounding
from
towers
of
various
heights
,
in

more
various
than
their
situations
.
 
<EOS>
When
these
at
length
cease
,
all
seems
more
mysterious
and
quiet
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
One
disagreeable
result
of
whispering
is
that
it
seems
to
evoke
an
atmosphere
of
silence
,
haunted
by
the
ghosts
of
sound
---
<EOS>
strange
cracks
and
tickings
,
the
rustling
of
garments
that
have
no
substance
in
them
,
and
the
tread
of
dreadful
feet
that
would
leave
no
mark
on
the
sea
-
sand
or
the
winter
snow
.
 
<EOS>
So
sensitive
the
two
friends
happen
to
be
that
the
air
is
full
of
these
phantoms
,
and
the
two
look
over
their
shoulders
by
one
consent
to
see
that
the
door
is
shut
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Tony
?
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
drawing
nearer
to
the
fire
and
biting
his
unsteady
thumb
-
nail
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
going
to
say
,
thirdly
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
far
from
a
pleasant
thing
to
be
plotting
about
a
dead
man
in
the
room
where
he
died
,
especially
when
you
happen
to
live
in
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
we
are
plotting
nothing
against
him
,
Tony
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
May
be
not
,
still
I
do
n't
like

.
 
<EOS>
Live
here
by
yourself
and
see
how
YOU
like

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
dead
men
,
Tony
,
"
proceeds
Mr
Guppy
,
evading
this

,
"
there

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

there

,
but
in
most

you
let

,
and
---
and
they
let
you
alone
,
"
Tony

.
   
<EOS>
The
two
look
at
each
other

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
makes
a

remark
to
the
effect
that
they
may
be
doing
the
deceased
a
service
,
that
he

so
.
 
<EOS>
There

an
oppressive
blank
until
Mr
Weevle
,
by
stirring
the
fire
suddenly
,
makes
Mr
Guppy
start

.
   
<EOS>
"
Fah
!
<EOS>
Here
's
more
of
this
hateful
soot
hanging
about
,
"
says

.
<EOS>
"
Let

open

window
a
bit
and
get
a

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
too
close
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
raises
the
sash
,
and
they
both
rest
on
the
window
-
sill
,
half
in
and
half

of

.
 
<EOS>
The
neighbouring
houses
are
too
near
to
admit
of
their
seeing
any
sky
without
craning
their
necks
and
looking

,
but
lights
in

here

there
,

,
and
the
new
expression
that
there

of

,
they
find
to

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
,
noiselessly

on
the
window
-

,
resumes
his
whisperirig
in
quite
a
light
-
comedy

.
   
<EOS>
"
By
the
by
,
Tony
,
do

forget
old
Smallweed
,
"
meaning
the
younger
of

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
let

into
this
,

.
 
<EOS>
That
grandfather
of
his
is
too

.
 
<EOS>
It
runs
in
the

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
remember
,
"

Tony
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
up
to
all
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
as
to
Krook
,
"
resumes

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,

any
other
papers
of

,
as
he
has

,

have

such

?
"
   
<EOS>
Tony

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
Ca
n't
Imagine
.
 
<EOS>
If

this

without
rousing

,
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
How
can
I
know
without
seeing
them
,
when
he
do

?
 
<EOS>
He
is
always
spelling

from

,
and
chalking

over
the

the
shop
-

,
and
asking
what
this

and

;
but
his
whole

from

may

the
waste
-
paper
he

as
,
for
anything

.
 
<EOS>
It

to
think

possessed

documents
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
going
to
learn

them
this
last
quarter
of
a
century
<EOS>
,
I
should

,
from

he

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How

first

,

?
 
<EOS>
That
's

,
"
Mr

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
may

found
papers
in
something
he

,
where
papers
were
not

,
and
may

into
his

from
the

that
they

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Or

may
have

in
,

.
 
<EOS>
Or

may

by

whatever

HAS

,
and
by

,
and

about
the
Lord

's
Court
and
hearing
of
documents
for

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
sitting
on
the
window
-

,

and

all
these
possibilities
in

,
continues

tap

,
and

,
and

,
until

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
in
the
devil
's

,
"

,
"

!
 
<EOS>
Look

!
"
   
<EOS>
A
thick
,
yellow

defiles
them
,
which
is
offensive
to
the
touch
and

and
more

to

.
 
<EOS>
A
stagnant
,

oil
with
some

that

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
been
doing

?
 
<EOS>
What
have
you
been
pouring
out
of
window
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
pouring
out
of
window
!
 
<EOS>
Nothing
,
I
swear
!
 
<EOS>
Never
,
since
I
have
been
here
!
"
cries
the
lodger
.
   
<EOS>
And
yet
look
here
---
and
look
here
!
 
<EOS>
When
he
brings
the
candle
here
,
from
the
corner
of
the
window
-
sill
,
it
slowly
drips
and
creeps
away
down
the
bricks
,
<EOS>
here
lies
in
a
little
thick

.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
horrible
house
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
shutting
down

.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
some
water
<EOS>
or
I
shall
cut
my
hand
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
so
washes
,
and
rubs
,
and
scrubs
,
and
smells
,
and
washes
,
that
he
has
not
long
restored
himself
with
a
glass
of

and
stood

before
the
fire
when
Saint
Paul
's
bell
strikes
twelve
and
all
those
other

strike
twelve
from
their

of
various
heights
in
the
dark
air
,
and
in
their
many
tones
.
 
<EOS>
When
all
is

again
,
the
lodger
says
,
"
It
's
the
appointed
time
at
last
.
<EOS>
Shall
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
nods

gives

a
"
lucky
touch
"
on
the
back
,
but
not
with
the
washed
hand
,
though
it
is
his
right
hand
.
   
<EOS>
He

downstairs
,
and
Mr
Guppy
tries
to
compose
himself
before
the
fire
for
waiting
a
long

.
 
<EOS>
But
in
no
more
than
a
minute
or
two
the
stairs
creak
and
Tony
comes
swiftly
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
got
them
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Got
them
!
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
's
not
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
has
been
so
horribly
frightened
in
the
short

that
his
terror
seizes
the
other
,
who
makes
a
rush
at
him
and
asks

,
"
What
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
make
him
hear
,
and
I
softly
opened
the
door
and
looked
in
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
burning
smell
is
there
---
and
the
soot
is
there
,
and
the
oil
is
there
---
and
he
is
not
there
!
"
 
<EOS>
Tony
ends
this
with
a

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
takes
the
light
.
 
<EOS>
They
go
down
,
more
dead
than
alive
,
and
holding
one
another
,
push
open
the
door
of
the
back
shop
.
 
<EOS>
The
cat
has
retreated
close
to
it
and
stands
snarling
,
not
at
them
,
at
something
on
the
ground
before
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
very
little
fire
left
in
the
grate
,
but
there
is
a
smouldering
,
suffocating
vapour
in
the
room
and
a
dark
,
greasy
coating
on
the
walls
and
ceiling
.
 
<EOS>
The
chairs
and
table
,
and
the
bottle
so
rarely
absent
from
the
table
,
all
stand
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
On
one
chair
-
back
hang
the
old
man
's
hairy
cap
and
coat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
!
"
<EOS>
whispers
the
lodger
,
pointing
his
friend
's
attention
to
these
objects
with
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
so
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
saw
him
last
,
he
took
his
cap
off
,
took

the
little
bundle
of
old
letters
,
hung
his

on
the

the
chair
---
his

,
for
he

pulled

before
he
went

put

---
and
I

,

is

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Is

somewhere
?
 
<EOS>
They
look
up
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
   
<EOS>
"
See
!
"
<EOS>
whispers
Tony
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
the
foot
of
the
same
chair
there
lies
a
dirty
bit

thin
red

that
they
tie

.
 
<EOS>
That
went
round
the
letters
.
 
<EOS>
He
undid

,
leering

at
me
,
before
he
began
to
turn

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's

cat
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mad
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
And
no
wonder
in
this
evil

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
They
advance
slowly
,
looking
at
all
these
things
.
 
<EOS>
The
cat
remains
where
they
found
her
,
still
snarling
at
the
something
on
the
ground
before
the
fire
and
between
the
two

.
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Hold
up
the
light
.
   
<EOS>
Here
is
a
small
burnt
patch
of
flooring
;
here
is
the

from
a
little
bundle
of

,
but
not
so

usual
,
seeming

;
and
here

---
is

of
a
small

sprinkled
with
white

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
horror
,
he
IS
here
!
 
<EOS>
And
this
from
which
we
run
away
,
striking
out
the
light
and
overturning
one
another
into
the
street
,
is
all
that
represents
him
.
   
<EOS>
Help
,
help
,
help
!
 
<EOS>
Come
into
this
house
for

's
sake
!
 
<EOS>
Plenty
will
come
in
,
but
none
can
help
.
 
<EOS>
The
Lord
Chancellor
of
that
court
,
true
to
his
title
in
his
last
act
,
has
died
the
death
of
all
lord

in
all

and
of
all

in
all
places
under
all
names
soever
,
where
false
pretences
are
made
,
and
where
injustice
is
done
.
 
<EOS>
Call
the
death
by
any
name
your
Highness
will
,
attribute
it
to
whom
you
will
,
or
say
it
might

been
prevented
how
you
will
,
it
is
the
same
death
eternally
---
inborn
,

,
engendered
in
the

of
the
vicious

itself
,
and
that
only
---
spontaneous

,
and
none
other
of
all
the
deaths
that

died
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
33
.
<EOS>
Interlopers
 
<EOS>
Now
do
those
two
gentlemen
not

at

's

reappear

(

,

)
,

,

's

,

.
<EOS>
Now

note

,

,
how
the

Chancery

was
yesterday
,

,

into

of
the

by
the

.
 
<EOS>
Now

set
forth
how

,

<EOS>

)
<EOS>
how

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
One

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

.

,

.

Mrs
Snagsby
's
pertinacity
in
that
fixed
gaze
.
 
<EOS>
His
mental
sufferings
are
so
great
that
he
entertains
wandering
ideas
of
delivering
himself
up
to
justice
and
requiring
to
be
cleared
if
innocent
and
punished
with
the
utmost
rigour
of
the
law
if
guilty
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weevle
and
Mr
Guppy
,
having
taken
their
breakfast
,
step
into
Lincoln
's
Inn
to
take
a
little
walk
about
the
square
and
clear
as
many
of
the
dark
cobwebs
out
of
their
brains
as
a
little
walk
may
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
can
be
no
more
favourable
time
than
the
present
,
Tony
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
after
they
have
broodingly
made
out
the
four
sides
of
the
square
,
"
for
a
word
or
two
between
us
upon
a
point
on
which
we
must
,
with
very
little
delay
,
come
to
an
understanding
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
tell
you
what
,
William
G
!
"
<EOS>
returns
the
other
,
eyeing
his
companion
with
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
If
it
's
a
point
of
conspiracy
,
you
need
n't
take
the
trouble
to
mention
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
enough
of
that
,
and
I
ai
n't
going
to
have
any
more
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
have
YOU
taking
fire
next
or
blowing
up
with
a
bang
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
supposititious
phenomenon
is
so
very
disagreeable
to
Mr
Guppy
that
his
voice
quakes
as
he
says
in
a

,
"
Tony
,
I
should
have
thought
that
what
we

through
last

would
have

lesson
to
you
never
to
be
personal
any
more
as
long

you
lived
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To

Mr
Weevle
returns
,
"
William
,
I
should
have

it
would
have
been
a
lesson
to
YOU
never
to
conspire
any
more
as
long
as
you

.
"
 
<EOS>
To

Mr
Guppy

,
"
Who
's

?
"
 
<EOS>
To

Mr
Jobling

,
"
Why
,
YOU
are
!
"
 
<EOS>
To

<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
retorts
,
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
am
not
.
"
 
<EOS>
To

Mr
Jobling

,
"
Yes
,
you
are
!
"
 
<EOS>
To

<EOS>
Mr
Guppy

,
"
<EOS>
Who

?
"
 
<EOS>
To

<EOS>
Mr
Jobling

,
"
I
say

!
"
 
<EOS>
To

<EOS>

,
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

?
"
 
<EOS>
To

Mr
Jobling

,
"
Yes
,
indeed
!
"
 
<EOS>
And

,

for

.
   
<EOS>
"
Tony
,
"
says
Mr

,
"

friend
out
instead

,
you
would

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
Possessing

,
Tony
,
all
that

eye
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
Blow
the
eye
!
"
<EOS>
cries

Weevle
,
cutting

.
 
<EOS>
"
Say
what
you
have
got
to

!
"
   
<EOS>
Finding

in
this

,
Mr

only

through

in

,
"
Tony
,

I

there

on

we
must
come
to

understanding
pretty

,
I
say
so

any

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
know

is

arranged

in
all

that
are
tried
what

to

.
 
<EOS>
Is

on

mo
---
gentleman
?
"
<EOS>
(

,
"

"
better

.
)
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
 
<EOS>
THE

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

.
 
<EOS>
Those

"
---
<EOS>
Mr

"

of

,

,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

in

,

,

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Whether

to

?

.
   
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
THAT

?
<EOS>
"
pointing

.
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
I
feel

;
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

---

,

,

,
Tony
,

?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Talk

's

?

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

,

!
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

ugh
!
<EOS>
---

.

<EOS>
"

really

,
"

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
While

are
so

,
a

-

the
square
,
on
the
box
of
which
vehicle
a
very
tall
hat
makes
itself
manifest
to
the

.
 
<EOS>
Inside
the

,
and
consequently

,

,

,

Smallweed

,

Judy
.
   
<EOS>
An

,

(
surmounting
Mr
Smallweed
the

)

,
Mr
Smallweed
the
elder
pokes

Guppy
,
"
How
de

,

!
 
<EOS>
How

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
Chick
and

want
here
at
this

,

!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

Smallweed
,
"

?
 
<EOS>
Would

-

,

?
 
<EOS>
Would

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,
"
The
public
-
house
in
the
court
?
"
 
<EOS>
And

prepare
to

the

to
the
Sol
's
Arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
your
fare
!
"
says
the
patriarch
to
the

with
a

and
shaking
his
incapable
fist
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ask
me
for
a

more
,

I
'll

.
 
<EOS>
My

men
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Allow
me
to

round

neck
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
squeeze
you
tighter
than
I
can

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Lord
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
bones
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
well
that
the
Sol
is
not
far
off
,
for
Mr
Weevle
presents
an
apoplectic
appearance
before
half
the

is
accomplished
.
<EOS>
With
no
worse
aggravation
of
his
symptoms
,
however
,
than
the
utterance
of
divers
croaking
sounds
expressive
of
obstructed

,
he
fulils
his
share
of
the
porterage
and
<EOS>
the
benevolent
old
gentleman
is
deposited
by
his
own
desire
in
the
parlour
of
the
Sol
's
Arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Lord
!
"
<EOS>
gasps
Mr
Smallweed
,
looking
about
him
,
breathless
,
from
an
arm
-
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
bones
and
back
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
aches
and
pains
!
 
<EOS>
Sit
down
,
you
dancing
,
prancing
,
shambling
,
scrambling
poll
-

!
 
<EOS>
Sit
down
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
little
apostrophe
to
Mrs
Smallweed
is
occasioned
by
a
propensity
on
the
part
of
that
unlucky
old
lady
whenever
she
finds
herself
on
her
feet
to
amble
about
and
"
set
"
to
inanimate
objects
,
accompanying
herself
with
a
chattering
noise
,
as
in
a
witch
dance
.
<EOS>
A
nervous
affection
has
probably
as
much
to
do
with
these
demonstrations
as
any
imbecile
intention
in
the
poor
old
woman
,
but
on
the
present
occasion
they
are
so
particularly
lively
in
connexion
with
the
Windsor
arm
-
chair
,
fellow
to
that
in
which
Mr
Smallweed
is
seated
,
that
she
only
quite
desists
when
her
grandchildren
have
held
her
down
in
it
,
her
lord
in
the
meanwhile
bestowing
upon
her
,
with
great

,
the
endearing
epithet
of
"
a
pig
-
headed
jackdaw
,
"
repeated
a
surprising
number
of

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
sir
,
"
Grandfather
Smallweed
then

,

Guppy
,
"
there

here
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you

it
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Heard
of

,

!
 
<EOS>
Why
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
discovered

.
 
<EOS>
You

discovered

!
 
<EOS>
Bart
,
THEY
discovered

!
"
   
<EOS>
The
two

stare
at
the
Smallweeds
,
who
return

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
friends
,
"
whines
Grandfather
Smallweed
,

,
"
I

a

for

the

of

the
ashes
of
Mrs
Smallweed
's
brother
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
"
says
Mr
Guppy
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Smallweed
's
brother
,
my
dear
friend
---
her
only
relation
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
not
on
terms
,
which
is
to
be
deplored
now
,
but
he
never
WOULD
be
on
terms
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
fond
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
eccentric
<EOS>
---
he
was
very
eccentric
.
 
<EOS>
Unless
he
has
left
a
will
(
which
is
not

all

)
I
shall

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
down
to

after

property
;
it
must

,
it
must

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
come
down
,
"
repeats
Grandfather
Smallweed
,
hooking
the
air
towards
him
with
all
his
ten
fingers

once
,
"
to
look
after
the
property
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
Small
,
"
says

Mr
Guppy
,
"
you

that

old
man

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
two
were
so
close

that
I

,
"
returns
that
old
bird
with
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
I
was

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Besides

,

nothing

you
,
you

,
whether
he

or

,
"

Judy
.
 
<EOS>
Also

a

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
never

in

,
"
observed

"
I

"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Mr

,

<EOS>
Krook

Smallweed

;

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
,

,

.

<EOS>
Mrs

,
"
Seventy
-

pound

!
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
Seventy
-

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Will

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
You
hag
<EOS>
,

,

"
 
<EOS>

The

!
 
<EOS>
The

!
 
<EOS>
Property
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>
Young

<EOS>

M

,

that

level

<EOS>
Mr

"
The

"

"
J*G*B

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Out

<EOS>

;

,

,

<EOS>
In

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
Presently

.
 
<EOS>
Is

---
?
 
<EOS>
No
,

's

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
This

---
"
   
"
I

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Merely

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
besides

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

.
   
<EOS>
"
In

,

,
"

<EOS>
---

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
If

?
 
<EOS>
No
,

,

.
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"

this
being
the
last
time
you
will
have
the
opportunity
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
is
quite
sure
.
 
<EOS>
And
indeed
he
has
no
such
wish
at
present
,
by
any
means
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
enough
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
dispense
with
excuses
.
 
<EOS>
Good
evening
to
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
she
rings
for
Mercury
to
show
the
young
man
of
the
name
of
Guppy
out
.
   
<EOS>
But
in
that
house
,
in
that
same
moment
,
there
happens
to
be
an
old
man
of
the
name
of
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
old
man
,
coming
with
his
quiet
footstep
to
the
library
,
has
his
hand
at
that
moment
on
the
handle
of
the
door
---
comes
in
---
and
comes
face
to
face
with
the
young
man
as
he
is
leaving
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
One
glance
between
the
old
man
and
the
lady
,
and
for
an
instant
the
blind
that
is
always
down
flies
up
.
 
<EOS>
Suspicion
,
eager
and
sharp
,
looks
out
.
 
<EOS>
Another
instant
,
close
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Lady
Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
a
thousand
times
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
so
very
unusual
to
find
you
here
at
this

.
 
<EOS>
I
supposed
the
room
was
empty
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
 
<EOS>
She
negligently
calls
him
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
Remain
here
,
I
beg
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
out
to
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
more
to
say
to
this
young
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
disconcerted
young
man
bows
,
as
he
goes
out
,
and
cringingly
hopes
that
Mr
Tulkinghorn
of
the
Fields
is
well
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
?
<EOS>
"
says
the
lawyer
,
looking
at

from
under

,
though

to
look
again
---
not
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
From
Kenge
and

's
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Kenge
and
Carboy
's
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
Name
of
Guppy
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,

,
Mr
Guppy
,
I
am

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Happy

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
be
too
well
,
sir
,
for
the
credit
of
the

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
Mr

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

sneaks

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
such
a
foil
in
his
old
-
fashioned
rusty
black
to
Lady
Dedlock
's
brightness
,
hands
her
down
the
staircase
to
her

.
 
<EOS>
He
returns
rubbing
his
chin
,
and
rubs
it
a
good
deal
in
the
course
of
the
evening
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
34
.
<EOS>
A
Turn
of
the
Screw
 
"
Now
,
what
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
"
may
this
be
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
blank
cartridge
or
ball
?
 
<EOS>
A
flash
in
the
pan
or
a
shot
?
"
   
<EOS>
An
open
letter
is
the
subject
of
the
trooper
's
speculations
,
and
it
seems
to
perplex
him
mightily
.
 
<EOS>
He
looks
at
it
at
arm
's
length
,
brings
it
close
to
him
,
holds
it
in
his
right
hand
,
holds
it
in
his
left
hand
,
reads
it
with
his
head
on
this
side
,
with
his
head
on
that
side
,
contracts
his
eyebrows
,
elevates
them
,
still
can
not
satisfy
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
smooths
it
out
upon
the
table
with
his
heavy
palm
,
and
thoughtfully
walking
up
and
down
the
gallery
,
makes
a
halt
before
it
every
now
and
then
to
come
upon
it
with
a
fresh
eye
.
<EOS>
Even
that
wo
n't
do
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
,
"
Mr
George
still
muses
,
"
blank
cartridge
or
ball
?
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
Squod
,
with
the
aid
of
a
brush
and
paint
-
pot
,
is
employed
in
the
distance
whitening
the
targets
,
softly
whistling
in
quick
-
march
time
and
in
drum
-
and
-
fife
manner
that
he
must
and
will
go
back
again
to
the
girl
he
left
behind
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Phil
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
trooper
beckons
as
he
calls
him
.
   
<EOS>
Phil
approaches
in
his
usual
way
,
sidling
off
at
first
as
if
he
were
going
anywhere
else
and
then
bearing
down
upon
his
commander
like
a
bayonet
-
charge
.
 
<EOS>
Certain
splashes
of
white
show
in
high
relief
upon
his
dirty
face
,
and
he
scrapes
his
one
eyebrow
with
the
handle
of
the
brush
.
   
<EOS>
"
Attention
,
Phil
!
 
Listen
to
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Steady
,
commander
,
steady
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
Sir
.
 
<EOS>
Allow
me
to
remind
you
(
though
there
is
no
legal
necessity
for
my
doing
so
,
as
you
are
aware
)
that
the
bill
at
two
months
'
date
drawn
on
yourself
by
Mr
Matthew
Bagnet
,
and
by
you
accepted
,
for
the
sum
of
ninety
-
seven
pounds
four
shillings
and
ninepence
,
will
become
due
to
-
morrow
,
when
you
will
please
be
prepared
to
take
up
the
same
on
presentation
.
 
<EOS>
Yours
,
Joshua
Smallweed
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
make
of
that
,
Phil
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mischief
,
guv'ner
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
replies
Phil
after
pensively
tracing
out
a
cross
-
wrinkle
in
his
forehead
with
the
brush
-
handle
,
"
that
mischeevious
consequences
is
always
meant
when
money
's
asked
for
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lookye
,
Phil
,
"
says
the
trooper
,
sitting
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
First
and
last
,
I
have
paid
,
I
may
say
,
half
as
much
again
as
this
principal
in
interest
and
one
thing
and
another
.
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
intimates
by
sidling
back
a
pace
or
two
,
with
a
very
unaccountable
wrench
of
his
wry
face
,
that
he
does
not
regard
the
transaction
as
being
made
more
promising
by
this

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
lookye
further
,
Phil
,
"
says
the
trooper
,
staying
his
premature
conclusions
with
a

of

hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
has
always
been
an
understanding
that
this
bill
was
to
be
what
they
call

.
 
<EOS>
And
it
has
been
renewed
no
end

times
.
 
<EOS>
What
do

now
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
that
I
think
the
times
is
come
to
a
end
at
last
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
?
 
<EOS>
Humph
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
much
of
the
same
mind
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Joshua
Smallweed
is
him
that
was
brought
here
in
a
chair
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
same
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Guv'ner
,
"
says
Phil
with
exceeding
gravity
,
"
he
's
a
leech
in
his
dispositions
,
he
's
a
screw
and
a
wice
in
his
actions
,
a
snake
in
his
twistings
,
and
a
lobster
in
his
claws
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
thus
expressively
uttered
his
sentiments
,
Mr
Squod
,
after
waiting
a
little
to
ascertain
if
any
further
remark
be
expected
of

,
gets
back
by
his
usual
series
of
movements
to
the
target
he
has
in
hand
and
vigorously
signifies
through
his
former

medium
that
he
must
and
he
will
return
to
that
ideal
young
lady
.
<EOS>
George
,
having
folded
the
letter
,
walks
in
that
direction
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
IS
a
way
,
commander
,
"
says
Phil
,
looking
cunningly
at
him
,
"
of
settling
this
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Paying
the
money
,
I
suppose
?
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
could
.
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
shakes
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
guv'ner
,
no
;
not
so
bad
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
There
IS
a
way
,
"
says
Phil
with
a
highly
artistic

of
his
brush
;
"
what
I
'm
a
-
doing
at
present
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whitewashing
.
"
   
Phil
nods
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
pretty
way
that
would
be
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
what
would
become
of
the
Bagnets
in

?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know

would
be

old

?
 
<EOS>
YOU'RE
a
moral
character
<EOS>
,
"
says
the
trooper
,
eyeing
him
in
his
large
way
with
no

;
"
upon
my
life
you
are
,
Phil
!
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
,
on
one
knee
at
the
target
,
is
in
course
of
protesting
earnestly
,
though
not
without
many
allegorical
scoops
of
his
brush
and
smoothings
of
the
white
surface
round
the
rim
with
his
thumb
,
that
he
had
forgotten
the
Bagnet
responsibility
and
would
not
so
much
as
injure
a
hair
of
the
head
of
any
member
of
that
worthy
family
when
steps
are
audible
in
the
long
passage
without
,
and
a
cheerful
voice
is
heard
to
wonder
whether
George
is
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
Phil
,
with
a
look
at
his
master
,
hobbles
up
,
saying
,
"
Here
's
the
guv'ner
,
Mrs
Bagnet
!
 
<EOS>
Here
he
is
!
"
<EOS>
and
the
old
girl
herself
,
accompanied
by
Mr
Bagnet
,
appears
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
girl
never
appears
in
walking
trim
,
in
any
season
of
the
year
,
without
a
grey
cloth
cloak
,
coarse
and
much
worn
but
very
clean
,
which
is
,
undoubtedly
,
the
identical
garment
rendered
so
interesting
to
Mr
Bagnet
by
having
made
its
way
home
to
Europe
from
another
quarter
of
the
globe
in
company
with
Mrs
Bagnet
and
an
umbrella
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
faithful
appendage
is
also
invariably
a
part
of
the
old
girl
's
presence
out
of
doors
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
of
no
colour
known
in
this
life
and
has
a
corrugated
wooden
crook
for
a
handle
,
with
a
metallic
object
let
into
its
prow
,
or
beak
,
resembling
a
little
model
of
a
fanlight
over
a
street
door
or
one
of
the
oval
glasses
out
of
a
pair
of
spectacles
,
which
ornamental
object
has
not
that
tenacious
capacity
of
sticking
to
its
post
that
might
be
desired
in
an
article
long
associated
with
the
British
army
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
girl
's
umbrella
is
of
a
flabby
habit
of
waist
and
seems
to
be
in
need
of
stays
---
an
appearance
that
is
possibly
referable
to
its
having
served
through
a
series
of
years
at
home
as
a
cupboard
and
on
journeys
as
a
carpet
bag
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
puts
it
up
,
having
the
greatest
reliance
on
her
well
-
proved
cloak
with
its
capacious
hood
,
but
generally
uses
the
instrument
as
a
wand
with
which
to
point
out
joints
of
meat
or
bunches
of
greens
in
marketing
or
to
arrest
the
attention
of
tradesmen
by
a
friendly
poke
.
 
<EOS>
Without
her
market
-
basket
,
which
is
a
sort
of
wicker
well
with
two
flapping
lids
,
she
never
stirs
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
Attended
by
these
her
trusty
companions
,
therefore
,
her
honest
sunburnt
face
looking
cheerily
out
of
a
rough
straw
bonnet
,
Mrs
Bagnet
now
arrives
,
fresh
-
coloured
and
bright
,
in
George
's
Shooting
Gallery
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
George
,
old
fellow
,
"
says
she
,
"
and
how
do
YOU
do
,
this
sunshiny
morning
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Giving
him
a
friendly
shake
of
the
hand
,
Mrs
Bagnet
draws
a
long
breath
after
her
walk
and
sits
down
to
enjoy
a
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Having
a
faculty
,
matured
on
the
tops
of
baggage
-
waggons
and
in
other
such
positions
,
of
resting
easily
anywhere
,
she
perches
on
a
rough
bench
,
unties
her
bonnet
-
strings
,
pushes
back
her
bonnet
,
crosses
her
arms
,
and
looks
perfectly
comfortable
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bagnet
in
the
meantime
has
shaken
hands
with
his
old
comrade
and
with
Phil
,
on
whom
Mrs
Bagnet
likewise
bestows
a
good
-
humoured
nod
and
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
George
,
"
said
Mrs
Bagnet
briskly
,
"
here
we
are
,
Lignum
and
myself
"
---
she
often
speaks
of
her
husband
by
this
appellation
,
on
account
,
as
it
is
supposed
,
of
Lignum
Vitae
having
been
his
old
regimental
nickname
when
they
first
became
acquainted
,
in
compliment
to
the
extreme
hardness
and
toughness
of
his
physiognomy
---
"
just
looked
in
,
we
have
,
to
make
it
all
correct
as
usual
about
that
security
.
 
<EOS>
Give
him
the
new
bill
to
sign
,
George
,
and
he
'll
sign
it
like
a
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
coming
to
you
this
morning
,
"
observes
the
trooper
reluctantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
we
thought
you
'd
come
to
us
this
morning
,
but
we
turned
out
early
and
left
Woolwich
,
the
best
of
boys
,
to
mind
his
sisters
and
came
to
you
instead
---
as
you
see
!
 
<EOS>
For
Lignum
,
he
's
tied
so
close
now
,
and
gets
so
little
exercise
,
that
a
walk
does
him
good
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
's
the
matter
,
George
?
"
asks
Mrs
Bagnet
,
stopping
in
her
cheerful
talk
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
look
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
quite
myself
,
"
returns
the
trooper
;
"
I
have
been
a
little
put
out
,
Mrs
Bagnet
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
bright
quick
eye
catches
the
truth
directly
.
 
<EOS>
"
George
!
"
<EOS>
holding
up
her
forefinger
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
tell
me
there
's
anything
wrong
about
that
security
of
Lignum
's
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
do
it
,
George
,
on
account
of
the
children
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
trooper
looks
at
her
with
a
troubled
visage
.
   
<EOS>
"
George
,
"
says
Mrs
Bagnet
,
using
both
her
arms
for
emphasis
and
occasionally
bringing
down

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
never

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

?
 
<EOS>
Well
,

,

I

HIS

.
 
<EOS>
This
,

,
I

speaking

.
 
<EOS>
This

.
"
   
<EOS>
Grandfather
Smallweed

in

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Judy
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>
Give

.
<EOS>
Did

say
what
does

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,

,
come
,

,
Mr
Smallweed
,
"
urges

trooper
,

"

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

---
it
<EOS>
,

<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
says

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
That

!
"
 
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
As

,

,

Matthew

<EOS>
Now

,

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
There

.
)
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Ha

"
   
<EOS>
"
Ha

!
"
<EOS>

Smallweed
.
 
<EOS>
In

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
if

.

<EOS>
Here

,
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
 
<EOS>
Unless

,

Judy
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I

,
Mr
George
"
---
old

,

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
Why
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Go

!
"
   
<EOS>
The

rise
and

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bagnet
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
to
the
devil
!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
What
?
 
<EOS>
You

!
 
<EOS>

;

)

!
"
   
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
Utterly

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,
in

,

like

and

in

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Mat
,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>

,

?
"

Mr

,

,

"
If

girl
had

---
I

!
"
 
<EOS>
Having

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
When

present

in
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
is
engaged
and
not

.
 
<EOS>
He
is

,
for
when

,

,

,

,

that
Mr

has

.
 
<EOS>
They
do

,

,

,

<EOS>
the

's

<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
She

,
for

to

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

"
Yes
,

.
 
<EOS>
Formerly
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
My

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
But

(
calculating

by

)
<EOS>
that

<EOS>
"
George
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

!
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

---

,

?
"
 
<EOS>
Cheer

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
The

,
"
Let

!
<EOS>
"
they
pass

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
men
,

?
 
<EOS>
Sergeant
,
I

the

I
do
n't

company
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sergeant

---
dashed
within

last

as

,
and

---

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

Tulkinghorn
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
get

debt
,
you

or

.
<EOS>
You
have

to

,
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
Sergeant
is
sorry

he
is
not

money
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
!
 
<EOS>
Then
the
other
man
---
this
man
,
if
this
is
he
---
must
pay
it
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sergeant
is
sorry
to

that
the
other
man
is
not
prepared
with
the
money
either
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
!
 
<EOS>
Then
you
must

between
you
or
you
<EOS>
must
both

for

and
both

.
 
<EOS>
You
have

and
must

.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
to
pocket
other
people
's
pounds
,
shillings
,
and
pence
and
escape
scot
-
free
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
lawyer
sits
down
in
his
easy
-
chair
and
stirs
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
George
hopes
he
will
have
the
goodness
to
---
    
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
sergeant
,
I
have
nothing
to
say
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
your
associates
and
do
n't
want
you
here
.
 
<EOS>
This
matter
is
not
at
all
in
my
course
of
practice
and
is
not

my
office
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
is
good
enough
to
offer
these
affairs
to
me
,
but
they
are
not
in
my
way
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
go
to
Melchisedech
's
in
Clifford
's
Inn
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
make
an
apology
to
you
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
"
for
pressing
myself
upon
you
with
so

---
which
is
almost
as
unpleasant
to
me
as
it
can

to
you
---
but
<EOS>
would
you
let
me
say
a
private

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
rises
with
his
hands
in

and
walks
into
one

window

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
time
to
waste
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

the

<EOS>
"

"

"

---
<EOS>
nominally
,

---

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
This

?
"
   
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

"
'

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

!
"

?

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
35
.
<EOS>
Esther
's
Narrative
 
<EOS>
I
lay
ill
through
several
weeks
,
and
the
usual
tenor
of
my
life
became
like
an
old
remembrance
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
was
not
the
effect
of
time
so
much
as
of
the
change
in
all
my
habits
made
by
the
helplessness
and
inaction
of
a
sick
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
Before
I
had
been
confined
to
it
many
days
,
everything
else
seemed
to
have
retired
into
a
remote
distance
where
there
was
little
or
no
separation
between
the
various
stages
of
my
life
which
had
been
really
divided
by
years
.
 
<EOS>
In
falling
ill
,
I
seemed
to
have
crossed
a
dark
lake
and
to
have
left
all
my
experiences
,
mingled
together
by
the
great
distance
,
on
the
healthy
shore
.
   
<EOS>
My
housekeeping
duties
,
though
at
first
it
caused
me
great
anxiety
to
think
that
they
were
unperformed
,
were
soon
as
far
off
as
the
oldest
of
the
old
duties
at
Greenleaf
or
the
summer
afternoons
when
I
went
home
from
school
with
my
portfolio
under
my
arm
,
and
my
childish
shadow
at
my
side
,
to
my
godmother
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
never
known
before
how
short
life
really
was
and
into
how
small
a
space
<EOS>
the
mind
could
put
it
.
   
<EOS>
While
I
was
very
ill
,
the
way
in
which
these
divisions
of
time
became
confused
with
one
another
distressed
my
mind
exceedingly
.
<EOS>
At
once
a
child
,
an
elder
girl
,
and
the
little
woman
I
had
been
so
happy
as
,
I
was
not
only
oppressed
by
cares
and
difficulties
adapted
to
each
station
,
but
by
the
great
perplexity
of
endlessly
trying
to
reconcile
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
that
few
who
have
not
been
in
such
a
condition
can
quite
understand
what
I
mean
or
what
painful
unrest
arose
from
this
source
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
same
reason
I
am
almost
afraid
to
hint
at
that
time
in
my
disorder
---
it
seemed
one
long
night
,
but
I
believe
there
were
both
nights
and
days
in
it
---
when
I
laboured
up
colossal
staircases
,
ever
striving
to
reach
the
top
,
and
ever
turned
,
as
I
have
seen
a
worm
in
a
garden
path
,
by
some
obstruction
,
and
labouring
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
perfectly
at
intervals
,
and
I
think
vaguely
at
most
times
,
that
I
was
in
my
bed
;
and
I
talked
with
Charley
,
and
felt
her
touch
,
and
knew
her
very
well
;
yet
I
would
find
myself
complaining
,
"
Oh
,
more
of
these
never
-
ending
stairs
,
Charley
---
more
and
more
---
piled
up
to
the
sky
,
I
think
!
"
<EOS>
and
labouring
on
again
.
   
<EOS>
Dare
<EOS>
I
hint
at
that
worse
time
when
,
strung
together
somewhere
in
great
black
space
,
there
was
a
flaming
necklace
,
or
ring
,
or
starry
circle
of
some
kind
,
of
which
I
was
one
of
the
beads
!
 
<EOS>
And
when
my
only
prayer
was
to
be
taken
off
from
the
rest
and
when
it
was
such
inexplicable
agony
and
misery
to
be
a
part
of
the
dreadful
thing
?
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
less
I
say
of
these
sick
experiences
,
the
less
tedious
and
the
more
intelligible
I
shall
be
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
recall
them
to
make
others
unhappy
or
because
I
am
now
the
least
unhappy
in
remembering
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
if
we
knew
more
of
such
strange
afflictions
we
might
be
the
better
able
to
alleviate
their
intensity
.
   
<EOS>
The
repose
that
succeeded
,
the
long
delicious
sleep
,
the
blissful
rest
,
when
in
my
weakness
I
was
too
calm
to
have
any
care
for
myself
and
could
have
heard
(
or
<EOS>
so
I
think
now
)
that
I
was
dying
,
with
no
other
emotion
than
with
a
pitying
love
for
those
I
left
behind
<EOS>
---
this
state
can
be
perhaps
more
widely
understood
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
in
this
state
when
I
first
shrunk
from
the
light
as
it
twinkled
on
me
once
more
,
and
knew
with
a
boundless
joy
for
which
no
words
are
rapturous
enough
that
I
should
see
again
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
heard
my
Ada
crying
at
the
door
,
day
and
night
;
I
had
heard
her
calling
to
me
that
I
was
cruel
and
did
not
love
her
;
I
had
heard
her
praying
and
imploring
to
be
let
in
to
nurse
and
comfort
me
and
to
leave
my
bedside
no
more
;
but
I
had
only
said
,
when
I
could
speak
,
"
Never
,
my
sweet
girl
,
never
!
"
<EOS>
and
I
had
over
and
over
again
reminded
Charley
that
she
was
to
keep
my
darling
from
the
room
whether
I
lived
or
died
.
 
<EOS>
Charley
had
been
true
to
me
in
that
time
of
need
,
and
with
her
little
hand
and
her
great
heart
had
kept
the
door
fast
.
   
<EOS>
But
now
,
my
sight
strengthening
and
the
glorious
light
coming
every

more
fully
and

on
me
,
I
could
read

that
my
dear
wrote
to
me
every

and
could
put
them
to
my
lips
and
lay
my

upon

with
no

.
 
<EOS>
I
could
see
my
little
maid
,
so

so

,
going
about
the
two
rooms
setting
everything
in

and
speaking

from

.
 
<EOS>
I
could

the

in

house
and
the

it
expressed
on
the

all

.
 
<EOS>
I
could
weep
in
the

of
my
heart
and
be
as

in
my

as
ever

.
   
<EOS>
By

.
 
<EOS>
Instead

,
with

,

,

a

,
until
I

,
and

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
How

raised

!
 
<EOS>
The

---
sent

,

,
to
