the

,

she

glad
<EOS>
,

<EOS>

here

and

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes

you

,
"

,
"
<EOS>
Rest

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As

,
"
I

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
Chesney
Wold
 
<EOS>
Charley
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
This
was
my
first
gain
from
my
illness
.
 
<EOS>
How
little
I
had
lost
,
when
the
wide
world
was
so
full
of
delight
for
me
.
   
<EOS>
My
guardian
intending
to
go
back
immediately
<EOS>
,
we
appointed
,
on
our
way
down
,
a
day
when
my
dear
girl
should
come
.
 
<EOS>
I
wrote
her
a
letter
,
of
which
he
took
charge
,
and
he
left
us
within
half
an
hour
of
our
arrival
at
our
destination
,
on
a
delightful
evening
in
the
early
summer
-
time
.
   
<EOS>
If
a
good
fairy
had
built
the
house
for
me
with
a
wave
of
her
wand
,
and
I
had
been
a
princess
and
her
favoured
god
-
child
,
I
could
not
have
been
more
considered
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
So
many
preparations
were
made
for
me
and
such
an
endearing
remembrance
was
shown
of
all
my
little
tastes
and
likings
that
I
could
have
sat
down
,
overcome
,
a
dozen
times
before
I
had
revisited
half
the
rooms
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
better
than
that
,
however
,
by
showing
them
all
to
Charley
instead
.
 
<EOS>
Charley
's
delight
calmed
mine
;
and
after
we
had
had
a
walk
in
the
garden
,
and
Charley
had
exhausted
her
whole
vocabulary
of
admiring
expressions
,
I
was
as
tranquilly
happy
as
I
ought
to
have
been
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
comfort
to
be
able
to
say
to
myself
after
tea
,
"
Esther
,
<EOS>
my
dear
,
I
think
you
are
quite
sensible
enough
to
sit
down
now
and
write
a
note
of
thanks
to
your
host
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
had
left
a
note
of
welcome
for
me
,
as
sunny
as
his
own
face
,
and
had
confided
his
bird
to
my
care
,
which
I
knew
to
be
his
highest
mark
of
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
I
wrote
a
little
note
to
him
in
London
,
telling
him
how
all
his
favourite
plants
and
trees
were
looking
,
and
how
the
most
astonishing
of
birds
had
chirped
the
honours
of
the
house
to
me
in
the
most
hospitable
manner
,
and
how
,
after
singing
on
my
shoulder
,
to
the
inconceivable
rapture
of
my
little
maid
,
he
was
then
at
roost
in
the
usual
corner
of
his
cage
,
but
whether
dreaming
or
no
<EOS>
I
could
not
report
.
 
<EOS>
My
note
finished
and
sent
off
to
the
post
,
I
made
myself
very
busy
in
unpacking
and
arranging
;
and
I
sent
Charley
to
bed
in
good
time
and
told
her
I
should
want
her
no
more
that
night
.
   
<EOS>
For
I
had
not
yet
looked
in
the
glass
and
had
never
asked
to
have
my
own
restored
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
this
to
be
a
weakness
which
must
be
overcome
,
but
I
had
always
said
to
myself
that
I
would
begin
afresh
when
I
got
to
where
I
now
was
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
had
wanted
to
be
alone
,
and
therefore
I
said
,
now
alone
,
in
my
own
room
,
"
Esther
,
if
you
are
to
be
happy
,
if
you
are
to
have
any
right
to
pray
to
be
true
-
hearted
,
you
must
keep
your
word
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
was
quite
resolved
to
keep
it
,
but
I
sat
down
for
a
little
while
first
to
reflect
upon
all
my
blessings
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
I
said
my
prayers
and
thought
a
little
more
.
   
<EOS>
My
hair
had
not
been
cut
off
,
though
it
had
been
in
danger
more
than
once
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
long
and
thick
.
 
<EOS>
I
let
it
down
,
and
shook
it
out
,
and
went
up
to
the
glass
upon
the
dressing
-
table
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
muslin
curtain
drawn
across
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
drew
it
back
and
stood
for
a
moment
looking
through
such
a
veil
of
my
own
hair
that
I
could
see
nothing
else
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
put
my
hair
aside
and
looked
at
the
reflection
in
the
mirror
,
encouraged
by
seeing
how
placidly
it
looked
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
much
changed
---
oh
,
very
,
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
my
face
was
so
strange
to
me
that
I
think
I
should
have
put
my
hands
before
it
and
started
back
but
for
the
encouragement
I
have
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
Very
soon
it
became
more
familiar
,
and
then
I
knew
the
extent
of
the
alteration
in
it
better
than
I
had
done
at
first
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
like
what
I
had
expected
,
but
I
had
expected
nothing
definite
,
and
I
dare
say
anything
definite
would
have
surprised
me
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
never
been
a
beauty
and
had
never
thought
myself
one
,
but
I
had
been
very
different
from
this
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
all
gone
now
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven
was
so
good
to
me
that
I
could
let
it
go
with
a
few
not
bitter
tears
and
could
stand
there
arranging
my
hair
for
the
night
quite
thankfully
.
   
<EOS>
One
thing
troubled
me
,
and
I
considered
it
for
a
long
time
before
I
went
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
kept
Mr
Woodcourt
's
flowers
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
were
withered
I
had
dried
them
and
put
them
in
a
book
that
I
was
fond
of
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
knew
this
,
not
even
Ada
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
doubtful
whether
I
had
a
right
to
preserve
what
he
had
sent
to
one
so
different
---
whether
it
was
generous
towards
him
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
wished
to
be
generous
to
him
,
even
in
the
secret
depths
of
my
heart
,
which
he
would
never
know
,
because
I
could
have
loved
him
---
could
have
been
devoted
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
I
came
to
the
conclusion
that
I
might
keep
them
if
I
treasured
them
only
as
a
remembrance
of
what
was
irrevocably
past
and
gone
,
never
to
be
looked
back
on
any
more
,
in
any
other
light
.
<EOS>
I
hope
this
may
not
seem
trivial
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
much
in
earnest
.
   
<EOS>
I
took
care
to
be
up
early
in
the
morning
and
to
be
before
the
glass
when
Charley
came
in
on
tiptoe
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
,
miss
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Charley
,
starting
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
that
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Charley
,
"
said
I
,
quietly
putting
up
my
hair
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
am
very
well
indeed
,
and
very
happy
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
saw
it
was
a
weight
off
Charley
's
mind
,
but
it
was
a
greater
weight
off
mine
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
the
worst
now
and
was
composed
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
not
conceal
,
as
I
go
on
,
the
weaknesses
I
could
not
quite
conquer
,
but
they
always
passed
from
me
soon
and
the
happier
frame
of
mind
stayed
by
me
faithfully
.
   
<EOS>
Wishing
to
be
fully
re
-
established
in
my
strength
and
my
good
spirits
before
Ada
came
,
I
now
laid
down
a
little
series
of
plans
with
Charley
for
being
in
the
fresh
air
all
day
long
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
to
be
out
before
breakfast
,
and
were
to
dine
early
,
and
were
to
be
out
again
before
and
after
dinner
,
and
were
to
talk
in
the
garden
after
tea
,
and
were
to
go
to
rest
betimes
,
and
were
to
climb
every
hill
and
explore
every
road
,
lane
,
and
field
in
the
neighbourhood
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
restoratives
and
strengthening
delicacies
,
Mr
Boythorn
's
good
housekeeper
was
for
ever
trotting
about
with
something
to
eat
or
drink
in
her
hand
;
I
could
not
even
be
heard
of
as
resting
in
the
park
<EOS>
but
she
would
come
<EOS>
trotting
after
me
with
a
basket
,
her
cheerful
face
shining
with
a
lecture
on
the
importance
of
frequent
nourishment
.
 
<EOS>
Then
there
was
a
pony
expressly
for
my
riding
,
a
chubby
pony
with
a
short
neck
and
a
mane
all
over
his
eyes
who
could
canter
---
when
he
would
---
so
easily
and
quietly
that
he
was
a
treasure
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
very
few
days
he
would
come
to
me
in
the
paddock
when
I
called
him
,
and
eat
out
of
my
hand
,
and
follow
me
about
.
 
<EOS>
We
arrived
at
such
a
capital
understanding
that
when
he
was
jogging
with
me
lazily
,
and
rather
obstinately
,
down
some
shady

,
if
I
patted

and
said
,
"
Stubbs
,
I
am
surprised
you
do
n't
canter
when
you
know
how
much
I
like
it
;
and
I
think
you
might
oblige
me
,
for
you
are
only
getting
stupid
and
going
to
sleep
,
"
he
would
give
his
head
a
comical
shake
or
two
and
set
off
directly
,
while
Charley
would
stand
still
and
laugh
with
such
enjoyment
that
her
laughter
was
like
music
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
who
had
given
Stubbs
his
name
,
but
it
seemed
to
belong
to
him
as
naturally
as
his
rough
coat
.
 
<EOS>
Once
we
put
him
in
a
little
chaise
and
drove
him
triumphantly
through
the
green
lanes
for
five
miles
;
but
<EOS>
all
at
once
,
as
we
were
extolling
him
to
the
skies
,
he
seemed
to
take
it
ill
that
he
should
have
been
accompanied
so
far
by
the
circle
of
tantalizing
little
gnats
that
had
been
hovering
round
and
round
his
ears
the
whole
way
without
appearing
to
advance
an
inch
,
and
stopped
to
think
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
he
came
to
the
decision
that
it
was
not
to
be
borne
,
for
he
steadily
refused
to
move
until
I
gave
the
reins
to
Charley
and
got
out
and
walked
,
when
he
followed
me
with
a
sturdy
sort
of
good
humour
,
putting
his
head
under
my
arm
and
rubbing
his
ear
against
my
sleeve
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
for
me
to
say
,
"
Now
,
Stubbs
,
I
feel
quite
sure
from
what
I
know
of
you
that
you
will
go
on
if
I
ride
a
little
while
,
"
for
the
moment
I
left
him
,
he
stood
stock
still
again
.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
I
was
obliged
to
lead
the
way
,
as
before
;
and
in
this
order
we
returned
home
,
to
the
great
delight
of
the
village
.
   
<EOS>
Charley
<EOS>
and
I
had
reason
to
call
it
the
most
friendly
of
villages
<EOS>
,
I
am
sure
,
for
in
a
week
's
time
the
people
were
so
glad
to
see
us
go
by
,
though
ever
so
frequently
in
the
course
of
a
day
,
that
there
were
faces
of
greeting
in
every
cottage
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
known
many
of
the
grown
people
before
and
almost
all
the
children
,
but
now
the
very
steeple
began
to
wear
a
familiar
and
affectionate
look
.
 
<EOS>
Among
my
new
friends
was
an
old
old
woman
who
lived
in
such
a
little
thatched
and
whitewashed
dwelling
that
when
the
outside
shutter
was
turned
up
on
its
hinges
,
it
shut
up
the
whole
house
-
front
.
 
<EOS>
This
old
lady
had
a
grandson
who
was
a
sailor
,
and
I
wrote
a
letter
to
him
for
her
and
drew
at
the
top
of
it
the
chimney
-
corner
in
which
she
had
brought
him
up
and
where
his
old
stool
yet
occupied
its
old
place
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
considered
by
the
whole
village
the
most
wonderful
achievement
in
the
world
,
but
when
an
answer
came
back
all
the
way
from
Plymouth
,
in
which
he
mentioned
that
he
was
going
to
take
the
picture
all
the
way
to
America
,
and
from
America
would
write
again
,
I
got
all
the
credit
that
ought
to
have
been
given
to
the
post
-
office
and
was
invested
with
the
merit
of
the
whole
system
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
,
what
with
being
so
much
in
the
air
,
playing
with
so
many
children
,
gossiping
with
so
many
people
,
sitting
on
invitation
in
so
many
cottages
,
going
on
with
Charley
's
education
,
and
writing
long
letters
to
Ada
every
day
,
I
had
scarcely
any
time
to
think
about
that
little
loss
of
mine
and
was
almost
always
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
did
think
of
it
at
odd
moments
now
<EOS>
and
then
,
I
had
only
to
be
busy
and
forget
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
it
more
than
I
had
hoped
I
should
once
when
a
child
said
,
"
Mother
,
why
is
the
lady
not
a
pretty
lady
now
like
she
used
to
be
?
"
 
<EOS>
But
when
I
found
the
child
was
not
less
fond
of
me
,
and
drew
its
soft
hand
over
my
face
with
a
kind
of
pitying
protection
in
its
touch
,
that
soon
set
me
up
again
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
many
little
occurrences
which
suggested
to
me
,
with
great
consolation
,
how
natural
it
is
to
gentle
hearts
to
be
considerate
and
delicate
towards
any
inferiority
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
these
particularly
touched
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
happened
to
stroll
into
the
little
church
when
a
marriage
was
just
concluded
,
and
the
young
couple
had
to
sign
the
register
.
   
<EOS>
The
bridegroom
,
to
whom
the
pen
was
handed
first
,
made
a
rude
cross
for
his
mark
;
the
bride
,
who
came
next
,
did
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
had
known
the
bride
when
I
was
last
there
,
not
only
as
the
prettiest
girl
in
the
place
,
but
as
having
quite
distinguished
herself
in
the
school
,
and
I
could
not
help
looking
at
her
with
some
surprise
.
<EOS>
She
came
aside
and
whispered
to
me
,
while
tears
of
honest
love
and
admiration
stood
in
her
bright
eyes
,
"
He
's
a
dear
good
fellow
,
miss
;
but
he
ca
n't
write
yet
---
he
's
going
to
learn
of
me
---
and
I
would
n't
shame
him
for
the
world
!
"
 
<EOS>
Why
,
what
had
I
to
fear
,
I
thought
,
when
there
was
this
nobility
in
the
soul
of
a
labouring
man
's
daughter
!
   
<EOS>
The
air
blew
as
freshly
and
revivingly
upon
me
as
it
had
ever
blown
,
and
the
healthy
colour
came
into
my
new
face
as
it
had
come
into
my
old
one
.
 
<EOS>
Charley
was
wonderful
to
see
,
she
was
so
radiant
and
so
rosy
;
and
we
both
enjoyed
the
whole
day
and
slept
soundly
the
whole
night
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
favourite
spot
of
mine
in
the
park
-
woods
of
Chesney
Wold
where
a
seat
had
been
erected
commanding
a
lovely
view
.
 
<EOS>
The
wood
had
been
cleared
and
opened
to
improve
this
point
of
sight
,
and
the
bright
sunny
landscape
beyond
was
so
beautiful
that
I
rested
there
at
least
once
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
A
picturesque
part
of
the
Hall
,
called
the
Ghost
's
Walk
,
was
seen
to
advantage
from
this
higher
ground
;
and
the
startling
name
,
and
the
old
legend
in
the
Dedlock
family
which
I
had
heard
from
Mr
Boythorn
accounting
for
it
,
mingled
with
the
view
and
gave
it
something
of
a
mysterious
interest
in
addition
to
its
real
charms
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
bank
here
,
too
,
which
was
a
famous
one
for
violets
;
and
as
it
was
a
daily
delight
of
Charley
's
to
gather
wild
flowers
,
she
took
as
much
to
the
spot
as
I
did
.
   
<EOS>
It
would
be
idle
to
inquire
now
why
I
never
went
close
to
the
house
or
never
went
inside
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
family
were
not
there
,
I
had
heard
on
my
arrival
,
and
were
not
expected
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
far
from
being
incurious
or
uninterested
about
the
building
;
on
the
contrary
,
I
often
sat
in
this
place
wondering
how
the
rooms
ranged
and
whether
any
echo
like
a
footstep
really
did
resound
at
times
,
as
the
story
said
,
upon
the
lonely
Ghost
's
Walk
.
 
<EOS>
The
indefinable
feeling
with
which
Lady
Dedlock
had
impressed
me
may
have
had
some
influence
in
keeping
me
from
the
house
even
when
she
was
absent
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
sure
.
 
<EOS>
Her
face
and
figure
were
associated
with
it
,
naturally
;
but
I
can
not
say
that
they
repelled
me
from
it
,
though
something
did
.
 
<EOS>
For
whatever
reason
or
no
reason
,
I
had
never
once
gone
near
it
,
down
to
the
day
at
which
my
story
now
arrives
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
resting
at
my
favourite
point
after
a
long
ramble
,
and
Charley
was
gathering
violets
at
a
little
distance
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
looking
at
the
Ghost
's
Walk
lying
in
a
deep
shade
of
masonry
afar
off
and
picturing
to
myself
the
female
shape
that
was
said
to
haunt
it
when
I
became
aware
of
a
figure
approaching
through
the
wood
.
 
<EOS>
The
perspective
was
so
long
and
so
darkened
by
leaves
,
and
the
shadows
of
the
branches
on
the
ground
made
it
so
much
more
intricate
to
the
eye
,
that
at
first
I
could
not
discern
what
figure
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
By
little
and
little
it
revealed
itself
to
be
a
woman
's
---
a
lady
's
---
Lady
Dedlock
's
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
alone
and
coming
to
where
I
sat
with
a
much
quicker
step
<EOS>
,
I
observed
to
my
surprise
,
than
was
usual
with
her
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
fluttered
by
her
being
unexpectedly
so
near
<EOS>
(
she
was
almost
within
speaking
distance
before
I
knew
her
)
and
would
have
risen
to
continue
my
walk
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
could
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
rendered
motionless
.
<EOS>
Not
so
much
by
her
hurried
gesture
of
entreaty
,
not
so
much
by
her
quick
advance
and
outstretched
hands
,
not
so
much
by
the
great
change
in
her
manner
and
the
absence
of
her
haughty
self
-
restraint
,
as
by
a
something
in
her
face
that
I
had
pined
for
and
dreamed
of
when
I
was
a
little
child
,
something
I
had
never
seen
in
any
face
,
something
I
had
never
seen
in
hers
before
.
   
<EOS>
A
dread
and
faintness
fell
upon
me
,
and
I
called
to
Charley
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
stopped
upon
the
instant
and
changed
back
almost
to
what
I
had
known
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Summerson
,
I
am
afraid
I
have
startled
you
,
"
she
said
,
now
advancing
slowly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
scarcely
be
strong
yet
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
very
ill
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
much
concerned
to
hear
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
could
no
more
have
removed
my
eyes
from
her
pale
face
than
I
could
have
stirred
from
the
bench
on
which
I
sat
.
 
<EOS>
She
gave
me
her
hand
,
and
its
deadly
coldness
,
so
at
variance
with
the
enforced
composure
of
her
features
,
deepened
the
fascination
that
overpowered
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
what
was
in
my
whirling
thoughts
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
recovering
again
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
kindly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
quite
well
but
a
moment
ago
,
Lady
Dedlock
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
this
your
young
attendant
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
send
her
on
before
and
walk
towards
your
house
with
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Charley
,
"
said
I
,
"
take
your
flowers
home
,
and
I
will
follow
you
directly
.
"
   
<EOS>
Charley
,
with
her
best
curtsy
,
blushingly
tied
on
her
bonnet
and
went
her
way
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
was
gone
,
Lady
Dedlock
sat
down
on
the
seat
beside
me
.
   
<EOS>
I
can
not
tell
in
any
words
what
the
state
of
my
mind
was
when
I
saw
in
her
hand
my
handkerchief
with
which
I
had
covered
the
dead
baby
.
   
<EOS>
I
looked
at
her
,
but
I
could
not
see
her
<EOS>
,
I
could
not
hear
her
,
I
could
not
draw
my
breath
.
 
<EOS>
The
beating
of
my
heart
was
so
violent
and
wild
that
I
felt
as
if
my
life
were
breaking
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
she
caught
me
to
her
breast
,
kissed
me
,
wept
over
me
,
compassionated
me
,
and
called
me
back
to
myself
;
when
she
fell
down
on
her
knees
and
cried
to
me
,
"
Oh
,
my
child
,
my
child
,
I
am
your
wicked
and
unhappy
mother
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
try
to
forgive
me
!
"
<EOS>
---
when
I
saw
her
at
my
feet
on
the
bare
earth
in
her
great
agony
of
mind
,
I
felt
,
through
all
my
tumult
of
emotion
,
a
burst
of
gratitude
to
the
providence
of
God
that
I
was
so
changed
as
that
I
never
could
disgrace
her
by
any
trace
of
likeness
,
as
that
nobody
could
ever
now
look
at
me
and
look
at
her
and
remotely
think
of
any
near
tie
between
us
.
   
<EOS>
I
raised
my
mother
up
,
praying
and
beseeching
her
not
to
stoop
before
me
in
such
affliction
and
humiliation
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
so
in
broken
,
incoherent
words
,
<EOS>
for
besides
the
trouble
I
was
in
,
it
frightened
me
to
see
her
at
MY
feet
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
---
or
I
tried
to
tell
her
---
that
if
it
were
for
me
,
her
child
,
under
any
circumstances
to
take
upon
me
to
forgive
her
,
I
did
it
,
and
had
done
it
,
many
,
many
years
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
that
my
heart
overflowed
with
love
for
her
,
that
it
was
natural
love
which
nothing
in
the
past
had
changed
or
could
change
.
<EOS>
That
it
was
not
for
me
,
then
resting
for
the
first
time
on
my
mother
's
bosom
,
to
take
her
to
account
for
having
given
me
life
,
but
that
my
duty
was
to
bless
her
and
receive
her
,
though
the
whole
world
turned
from
her
,
and
that
I
only
asked
her
leave
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
held
my
mother
in
my
embrace
,
and
she
held
me
in
hers
,
and
among
the
still
woods
in
the
silence
of
the
summer
day
there
seemed
to
be
nothing
but
our
two
troubled
minds
that
was
not
at
peace
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
bless
and
receive
me
,
"
groaned
my
mother
,
"
it
is
far
too
late
.
<EOS>
I
must
travel
my
dark
road
alone
,
and
it
will
lead
me
where
it
will
.
 
<EOS>
From
day
to
day
,
sometimes
from
hour
to
hour
,
I
do
not
see
the
way
before
my
guilty
feet
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
earthly
punishment
I
have
brought
upon
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
bear
it
,
and
I
hide
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Even
in
the
thinking
of
her
endurance
,
she
drew
her
habitual
air
of
proud
indifference
about
her
like
a
veil
,
though
she
soon
cast
it
off
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
keep
this
secret
,
if
by
any
means
it
can
be
kept
,
not
wholly
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
husband
,
wretched
and
dishonouring
creature
that
I
am
!
"
   
<EOS>
These
words
she
uttered
with
a
suppressed
cry
of
despair
,
more
terrible
in
its
sound
than
any
shriek
.
 
<EOS>
Covering
her
face
with
her
hands
,
she
shrank
down
in
my
embrace
as
if
she
were
unwilling
that
I
should
touch
her
;
nor
could
I
,
by
my
utmost
persuasions
or
by
any
endearments
I
could
use
,
prevail
upon
her
to
rise
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
,
no
,
no
,
no
,
she
could
only
speak
to
me
so
<EOS>
;
she
must
be
proud
and
disdainful
everywhere
else
;
she
would
be
humbled
and
ashamed
there
,
in
the
only
natural
moments
of
her
life
.
   
<EOS>
My
unhappy
mother
told
me
that
in
my
illness
she
had
been
nearly
frantic
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
but
then
known
that
her
child
was
living
.
 
<EOS>
She
could
not
have
suspected
me
to
be
that
child
before
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
followed
me
down
here
to
speak
to
me
but
once
in
all
her
life
.
 
<EOS>
We
never
could
associate
,
never
could
communicate
,
never
probably
from
that
time
forth
could
interchange
another
word
on
earth
.
 
<EOS>
She
put
into
my
hands
a
letter
she
had
written
for
my
reading
only
and
said
when
I
had
read
it
and
destroyed
it
---
but
not
so
much
for
her
sake
,
since
she
asked
nothing
,
as
for
her
husband
's
and
my
own
---
I
must
evermore
consider
her
as
dead
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
believe
that
she
loved
me
,
in
this
agony
in
which
I
saw
her
,
with
a
mother
's
love
,
she
asked
me
to
do
that
,
for
then
I
might
think
of
her
with
a
greater
pity
,
imagining
what
she
suffered
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
put
herself
beyond
all
hope
and
beyond
all
help
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
she
preserved
her
secret
until
death
or
it
came
to
be
discovered
and
she
brought
dishonour
and
disgrace
upon
the
name
she
had
taken
,
it
was
her
solitary
struggle
always
;
and
no
affection
could
come
near
her
,
and
no
human
creature
could
render
her
any
aid
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
is
the
secret
safe
so
far
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
safe
now
,
dearest
mother
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
very
near
discovery
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
saved
by
an
accident
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
lost
by
another
accident
---
to
-
morrow
,
any
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
dread
a
particular
person
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
 
<EOS>
Do
not
tremble
and
cry
so
much
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
worthy
of
these
tears
,
"
said
my
mother
,
kissing
my
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
dread
one
person
very
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
An
enemy
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not
a
friend
.
 
<EOS>
One
who
is
too
passionless
to
be
either
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
's
lawyer
,
mechanically
faithful
without
attachment
,
and
very
jealous
of
the
profit
,
privilege
,
and
reputation
of
being
master
of
the
mysteries
of
great
houses
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
he
any
suspicions
?
"
   
"
Many
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
of
you
?
<EOS>
"
I
said
alarmed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
 
<EOS>
He
is
always
vigilant
and
always
near
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
keep
him
at
a
standstill
,
but
I
can
never
shake
him
off
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
he
so
little
pity
or
compunction
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
none
,
and
no
anger
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
indifferent
to
everything
but
his
calling
.
 
<EOS>
His
calling
is
the
acquisition
of
secrets
and
the
holding
possession
of
such
power
as
they
give
him
,
with
no
sharer
or
opponent
in
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Could
you
trust
in
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
try
.
 
<EOS>
The
dark
road
I
have
trodden
for
so
many
years
will
end
where
it
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
follow
it
alone
to
the
end
,
whatever
the
end
be
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
near
<EOS>
,
it
may
be
distant
;
while
the
road
lasts
,
nothing
turns
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
mother
,
are
you
so
resolved
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
AM
resolved
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
long
outbidden
folly
with
folly
,
pride
with
pride
,
scorn
with
scorn
,
insolence
with
insolence
,
and
have
outlived
many
vanities
with
many
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
outlive
this
danger
,
and
outdie
it
,
if
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
closed
around
me
almost
as
awfully
as
if
these
woods
of
Chesney
Wold
had
closed
around
the
house
,
but
my
course
through
it
is
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
<EOS>
but
one
<EOS>
;
I
can
have
but
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jarndyce
---
"
 
I
was
beginning
when
my
mother
hurriedly
inquired
,
"
Does
HE
suspect
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
Be
assured
that
he
does
not
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
I
told
her
what
he
had
related
to
me
as
his
knowledge
of
my
story
.
<EOS>
"
But
he
is
so
good
and
sensible
,
"
said
I
,
"
that
perhaps
if
he
knew
---
"
   
My
mother
,
who
until
this
time
had
made
no
change
in
her
position
,
raised
her
hand
up
to
my
lips
and
stopped
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
Confide
fully
in
him
<EOS>
,
"
she
said
after
a
little
while
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
my
free

---
a
small
gift
from
such
a
mother
to
her
injured
child
!
<EOS>
---
but
do
not
tell
me
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Some
pride
is
left
in
me
even
yet
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
explained
,
as
nearly
as
I
could
then
,
or
can
recall
now
---
for
my
agitation
and
distress
throughout
<EOS>
were
so
great
that
I
scarcely

myself
,
though
every

that
was
uttered
in
the
mother

,
so

so

,
which
in

had

,

,
<EOS>
had

,
made

<EOS>
---
I
say

,
how

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

mother
answered
no
,

;
no

.
 
<EOS>
Through
the

that
lay
before

,
she
must

alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
child
,
my
child
!
"
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
the
last
time
!
 
<EOS>
These
kisses
for
the
last
time
!
 
<EOS>
These
arms
upon
my
neck
for
the
last
time
!
 
<EOS>
We
shall
meet
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
To
hope
to
do
what
I
seek
to
do
,
I
must
be
what
I
have
been
so
long
.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
my
reward
and
doom
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
hear
of
Lady
Dedlock
,
brilliant
,
prosperous
,
and
flattered
,
think
of
your
wretched
mother
,
conscience

,
underneath
that
mask
!
<EOS>
Think
that
the
reality

in
her
suffering
,
in
her
useless

,
in
her
murdering
within

the
only

is

!
 
<EOS>
And
then
forgive
her
if
you
can
,
and
cry

to
forgive
her
,
which
it
never
can
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
held
one
another
for
a
little
space
yet
,
but
she
was
so
firm
that
she
took
my
hands
away
,
and
put

and
with

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
alone
,
and
calm

quiet
below
me
in
the
sun
and

the
old
house
,
with
its

,
on

but

.
   
<EOS>
Stunned

,
as

I
had

in

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

that

,
and

that
there

upon

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
but

and
felt
that

might
return
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
home
very

and

,

that
I

over

would

.
 
<EOS>
Safe

my
own
room
,
I
read
the
letter
.
 
<EOS>
I
clearly
derived
from
it
---
and
that
was
much
then
---
that
I
had
not
been
abandoned
by
my
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Her
elder
and
only
sister
,
the
godmother
of
my
childhood
,
discovering

of
life
in
me
when
I
had
been

,
had
in
her
stern

duty
,
with
no

that
I
should

,
reared

in

and
had
never
again

my
mother
's
face
from
within
a

.
 
<EOS>
So

I
hold

that
until

a
short
time
back
I
had
never
,
to

own
mother
's

,
breathed
---
had
been
buried
---
had
never
been
endowed
with
life
---
had
never
borne
a
name
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
first

in
the
church
she
had
been

and
had
thought
of
what
would
have
been
like

it
had
ever
lived
,
and
had
lived
on
,
but
that
was
all
then
.
   
<EOS>
What
more

letter

needs
not

.
 
<EOS>
It

its

.
   
<EOS>
My

was
to
burn
what
my
mother
had
written
and
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
hope

that

then

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
That

a

of
myself
as
the

of

and

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
   
<EOS>
These

I

.
 
<EOS>
I
fell

<EOS>
worn

,
and

to

that
I

back

of

for

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
more

,

her
against

,
of
the
owner

Chesney
Wold
,

new

of

old

,
"
<EOS>
Your

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

---
and

---

,

will

,

"
 
<EOS>
With

,
"
Pray

sins

others

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I

,
and
I

the

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps

<EOS>
As

.
   
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Then

.
 
<EOS>
Thence
<EOS>
the

,
and

court

where
the
principal

was
(

)
,

,

<EOS>
So

whose

,

,

of

Ghost
's

and
one

that
might

.
   
<EOS>
The

was
paved
here
,
like
the
terrace
overhead
,
and
my

from

.
<EOS>
Stopping

,
but

,
I
was
passing

,
and
in

window
,
<EOS>
when

that

,

.
<EOS>
Seized

,

,
and
never

until
I
had

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
Not

I
was
alone
in

the

and
had
again

dejected
and
unhappy
there
<EOS>
did
I
begin
to
know
how
wrong

<EOS>
this
state
was
.
 
<EOS>
But

my
darling
who
was

the
morrow
,
I
found
a
joyful
letter
,
full

that
I

been

;

,
I

,
asking

Durden
,

that

that

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Two

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
That

;
and

.
   
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
I
renewed
my

and
prayed
to

in

,
pouring

for

and

and

.
 
<EOS>
It

;
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
was
to

.
 
<EOS>
How
to
help
myself

the

better

by

along
the

she
was
to

,
I

;

---

,

---

and

.
 
<EOS>
On

,
we

that

was
in
its

,

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

because
I
at

<EOS>
---
I

---

?
 
<EOS>

,

?
 
<EOS>
Might

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
Jarndyce

Jarndyce
 
<EOS>

to
the
four

for
to
-

.
 
<EOS>
Puff
!
 
<EOS>
Gone
!
 
<EOS>
Who

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was

<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
's

I

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

!
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
What

!
"
   
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
He

,
no

.
 
<EOS>
He

the
dear

---

---

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
He

.
 
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
Fresh

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Indeed

<EOS>
He

,

in
hearing

my

,

in
the

now

,

appreciated
health
the

when
somebody

was
ill
,
did

<EOS>
but
what

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,

Richard
,
"

,
"
full

,
which

.
 
<EOS>
Now
that
's

<EOS>
,

,

full

!
 
<EOS>
In

<EOS>
This

,

Richard
,

by

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

<EOS>
Some

"

?

"
My

<EOS>

DON'T

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

youth

,

.
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
He

Coavinses
(

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

---
that

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
If

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Then

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh

!
"

in

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
my

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
may

to

;

,

many

that

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

so

for
Richard
that

not

,

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

that

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Indeed

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

Vale

Taunton
---
his

---

.
 
<EOS>
I
had

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

old

velvet
reticule
.
<EOS>
Such
mean
little
boys
,
when
they
were
not
dancing
,
with
string
,
and
marbles
,
and
cramp

bones
in

,
and
the
most
untidy

---
and
heels

.
   
<EOS>
I
asked
Caddy
what
had
made

parents
choose
this
profession
for

.
 
<EOS>
Caddy
said
she
did
n't
know
;
perhaps
they
were
designed
for

,
perhaps

.
 
<EOS>
They
were
all
people
in
humble

,
and
the
melancholy
boy
's
mother
kept
a
ginger
-

shop
.
   
<EOS>
We
danced
for
an
hour
with
great
gravity
,
the
melancholy
child
doing
wonders
with
his
lower

,
in
which
there
appeared
to

some

.
<EOS>
Caddy
,
while
she
was

of
her

and
was

founded
upon
him
,
had
acquired

of
her
own
,
which
,
united
to
her
pretty

,

.
 
<EOS>
She
already
relieved

of
much

these

,
and
he

in

do

.
 
<EOS>
He
always
played
the

.
 
<EOS>
The
affectation
of
the
gauzy
child
,
and
her

to
the
boys
,
was
a
sight
.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
we
danced
an
hour
by

.
   
<EOS>

,
Caddy
's

town
to

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I

in

room
in

,

the

.
 
<EOS>
The
two
out

door
boys
went
upon

to

half

and
pull
the
in

's

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

"
Not

"

"
<EOS>

should
be
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
39
.
<EOS>
Attorney
and
Client
 
The
name
of
Mr
Vholes
,
preceded
by
the
legend
Ground
-
Floor
,
is
inscribed
upon
a
door
-
post
in
Symond
's
Inn
,
Chancery
Lane
---
a
little
,
pale
,
wall
-
eyed
,
woebegone
inn
like
a
large
dust
-
binn
of
two
compartments
and
a
sifter
.
 
<EOS>
It
looks
as
if
Symond
were
a
sparing
man
in
his
way
and
constructed
his
inn
of
old
building
materials
which
took
kindly
to
the
dry
rot
and
to
dirt
and
all
things
decaying
and
dismal
,
and
perpetuated
Symond
's
memory
with
congenial
shabbiness
.
 
<EOS>
Quartered
in
this
dingy
hatchment
commemorative
of
Symond
are
the
legal
bearings
of
Mr
Vholes
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes
's
office
,
in
disposition
retiring
and
in
situation
retired
,
is
squeezed
up
in
a
corner
and
blinks
at
a
dead
wall
.
<EOS>
Three
feet
of
knotty
-
floored
dark
passage
bring
the
client
to
Mr
Vholes
's
jet
-
black
door
,
in
an
angle
profoundly
dark
on
the
brightest
midsummer
morning
and
encumbered
by
a
black
bulk
-
head
of
cellarage
staircase
against
which
belated
civilians
generally
strike
their
brows
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes
's
chambers
are
on
so
small
a
scale
that
one
clerk
can
open
the
door
without
getting
off
his
stool
,
while
the
other
who
elbows
him
at
the
same
desk
has
equal
facilities
for
poking
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
A
smell
as
of
unwholesome
sheep
blending
with
the
smell
of
must
and
<EOS>
dust
is
referable
to
the
nightly
(
and
often
daily
)
consumption
of
mutton
fat
in
candles
and
to
the
fretting
of
parchment
forms
and
skins
in
greasy
drawers
.
<EOS>
The
atmosphere
is
otherwise
stale
and
close
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
was
last
painted
or
whitewashed
beyond
the
memory
of
man
,
and
the
two
chimneys
smoke
,
and
there
is
a
loose
outer
surface
of
soot
evervwhere
,
and
the
dull
cracked
windows
in
their
heavy
frames
have
<EOS>
but
one
piece
of
character
in
them
,
which
is
a
determination
to
be
always
dirty
and
always
shut
unless
coerced
.
 
<EOS>
This
accounts
for
the
phenomenon
of
the
weaker
of
the
two
usually
having
a
bundle
of
firewood
thrust
between
its
jaws
in
hot
weather
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes
is
a
very
respectable
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
not
a
large
business
,
but
he
is
a
very
respectable
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
allowed
by
the
greater
attorneys
who
have
made
good
fortunes
or
are
making
them
to
be
a
most
respectable
man
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
misses
a
chance
in
his
practice
,
which
is
a
mark
of
respectability
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
takes
any
pleasure
,
which
is
another
mark
of
respectability
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
reserved
and
serious
,
which
is
another
mark
of
respectability
.
 
<EOS>
His
digestion
is
impaired
,
which
is
highly
respectable
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
is
making
hay
of
the
grass
which
is
flesh
,
for
his
three
daughters
.
 
<EOS>
And
his
father
is
dependent
on
him
in
the
Vale
of
Taunton
.
   
<EOS>
The
one
great
principle
of
the
English
law
is
to
make
business
for
itself
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
other
principle
distinctly
,
certainly
,
and
consistently
maintained
through
all
its
narrow
turnings
.
 
<EOS>
Viewed
by
this
light
<EOS>
it
becomes
a
coherent
scheme
and
not
the
monstrous
maze
<EOS>
the
laity
are
apt
to
think
it
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
but
once
clearly
perceive
that
its
grand
principle
is
to
make
business
for
itself
at
their
expense
,
and
surely
they
will
cease
to
grumble
.
   
<EOS>
But
not
perceiving
this
quite
plainly
---
only
seeing
it
by
halves
in
a
confused
way
---
the
laity
sometimes
suffer
in
peace
and
pocket
,
with
a
bad
grace
,
and
DO
grumble
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
Then
this
respectability
of
Mr
Vholes
is
brought
into
powerful
play
against
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Repeal
this
statute
,
my
good

?
"
says

Kenge

.
 
<EOS>
"
Repeal

,
my

?
 
<EOS>
Never
,

.
<EOS>
Alter

,

,

what

on

,

,

,

Vholes
?
 
<EOS>
Sir
,

.
 
<EOS>
Now

---
I

---

Vholes
.
<EOS>
Diligent
,

,

,
acute

.
 
<EOS>
My

,
I

,

;
but
I

Vholes
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
respectability
of
Mr
Vholes
has
even

cited
with

effect
before
Parliamentary

,
as

blue

of
a

's

.
 
<EOS>
"
Question
(

eight

-
nine
)
:
If
I
understand

,

?
 
<EOS>
Answer
:
<EOS>
Yes
,

.
 
<EOS>
Question
:
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
Answer
:
<EOS>
Most

.
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
Answer
:
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
They

ME

;
quite

.
 
<EOS>
Question
:
<EOS>
But

?
 
<EOS>
Answer
<EOS>
:
I
have

.
 
<EOS>
Question
:
<EOS>
Can

instance
any
type

?
<EOS>
Answer
:
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I

Vholes
.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Question
:
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes

?
 
<EOS>

"
---

<EOS>
"
Mr
Vholes
is

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
So

,

no

that
they
do

,

Vholes

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

"

.
 
<EOS>

"

found
that
out
long
ago
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
C
,
"
returns
Vholes
,
"
I
wish
to
say
no
more
of
any
third
party
than
is
necessary
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
leave
my
good
name
unsullied
,
together
with
any
little
property
of
which
I
may
become
possessed
through
industry
and
perseverance
,
to
my
daughters
Emma
,
Jane
,
and
Caroline
.
 
<EOS>
I
also
desire
to
live
in
amity
with
my
professional
brethren
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Skimpole
did
me
the
honour
,
sir
---
I
will
not
say
the
very
high
honour
,
for
I
never
stoop
to
flattery
---
of
bringing
us
together
in
this
room
<EOS>
,
I
mentioned
to
you
that
I
could
offer
no
opinion
or
advice
as
to
your
interests
while
those
interests
were
entrusted
to
another
member
of
the

.
 
<EOS>
And
I
spoke
in
such
terms
as
I
was
bound
to
speak
of
Kenge
and
Carboy
's
office
,
which
stands
high
.
 
<EOS>
You
,
sir
,
thought
fit
to
withdraw
your
interests
from
that

nevertheless
and
to

to

.
 
<EOS>
You
brought

with
clean
hands
,
sir
,
and
I
accepted
them
with
clean
hands
.
<EOS>
Those
interests
are
now
paramount
in
this
office
.
 
<EOS>
My
digestive
functions
,
as
you
may
have
heard
me
mention
,
are
not
in
a
good

,
and
rest
might
improve

;
but
I
shall
not
rest
,
sir
,
while
I

.
 
<EOS>
Whenever

want

,

.
 
<EOS>
Summon

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
During

long

,
sir
,
I
shall

to
studying
your
interests
more

to

for
moving
heaven

earth
(
including
,
of

,
the
Chancellor
)
after
Michaelmas
term
;
and
when
I
ultimately

you
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
Vholes
with
the

,
"

I
ultimately

you
,
sir
,
with
all

,
on
your
accession
to
fortune
---
<EOS>
which
,
but
that
I
never
give
hopes
,
I
might
say
something
further
about
---
you
will
owe
me
nothing
beyond
whatever
little
balance
may
be
then
outstanding
of
the

as
between

and
client
not

.
 
<EOS>
I

no

you
,
Mr
C
,
but

---
not

,

:
<EOS>
that

I
stipulate

---
of

.
 
<EOS>
My

prosperously
ended
,
all
between

is
ended
.
"
   
<EOS>
Vholes
finally
adds
,
by

to
this

his

,
that

Mr

,
perhaps
Mr
C
will

.
   
<EOS>
"
For

of

,

,
"
observes

,

,
"
and
these

mount
up
,
and
I
do

.
 
<EOS>
When

on

present

I

---
<EOS>
it

of
mine
that
there
never

between

and
client
---
<EOS>
that

's

.
 
<EOS>
No
,
Mr
C
,

of

here
,
sir
.
<EOS>
This
,
"
Vholes
gives
the
desk
one

again
,
"
is
your
rock
;
it
pretends
to
be
nothing
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
client
,
with
his
dejection
insensibly
relieved
and
his
vague
hopes
rekindled
,
takes
pen
and
ink
and
writes
the
draft
,
not
without
perplexed
consideration
and
calculation
of
the
date
it
may
bear
,
implying
scant
effects
in
the
agent
's
hands
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
while
,
Vholes
,
buttoned
up
in
body
and
mind
,
looks
at
him
attentively
.
<EOS>
All
the
while
,
Vholes
's
official
cat
watches
the
mouse
's
hole
.
   
<EOS>
Lastly
,
the
client
,
shaking
hands
,
beseeches
Mr
Vholes
,
for
heaven
's

and
earth
's

,
to
do

utmost
to
"
pull
him
through
"
the
Court
of
Chancery
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes
,
who
never
gives
hopes
,
lays
his
palm
upon
the
client
's
shoulder
and
answers
with
a
smile
,
"
Always
here
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Personally
,
or
by
letter
,
you
will
always
find
me
here
,
sir
,
with
my
shoulder
to
the

.
"
 
<EOS>
Thus
they
part
,
and
Vholes
,
left
alone
,
employs
himself
in
carrying
sundry
little
matters
out
of
his
diary
into
his
draft
bill
book
for
the
ultimate
behoof
of
his
three
daughters
.
 
<EOS>
So
might
an
industrious
fox
or
bear
make
up
his
account
of
chickens
or
stray
travellers
with
an
eye
to
his
cubs
,
not
to
disparage
by
that
word
the
three
raw
-
visaged
,
lank
,
and
buttoned
-
up
maidens
who
dwell
with
the
parent
Vholes
in
an
earthy
cottage
situated
in
a
damp
garden
at
Kennington
.
   
<EOS>
Richard
,
emerging
from
the
heavy
shade
of
Symond
's
Inn
into
the
sunshine
of
Chancery
Lane
---
for
there
happens
to
be
sunshine
there
to
-
day
---
walks
thoughtfully
on
,
and
turns
into
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
and
passes
under
the
shadow
of
the
Lincoln
's
Inn
trees
.
 
<EOS>
On
many
such
loungers
have
the
speckled
shadows
of
those
trees
often
fallen
;
on
the
like
bent
head
,
the
bitten
nail
,
the
lowering
eye
,
the
lingering
step
,
the
purposeless
and
dreamy
air
,
the
good
consuming
and
consumed
,
the
life
turned
sour
.
 
<EOS>
This
lounger
is
not
shabby
yet
,
but
that
may
come
.
 
<EOS>
Chancery
,
which
knows
no
wisdom
but
in
precedent
,
is
very
rich
in
such
precedents
;
and
why
should
one
be
different
from
ten
thousand
?
   
<EOS>
Yet
the
time
is
so
short
since
his
depreciation
began
that
as
he
saunters
away
,
reluctant
to
leave
the
spot
for
some
long
months
together
,
<EOS>
though
he
hates
it
,
Richard
himself
may
feel
his
own
case
as
if
it
were
a
startling
one
.
 
<EOS>
While
his
heart
is
heavy
with
corroding
care
,
suspense
,
distrust
,
and
doubt
,
it
may
have
room
for
some
sorrowful
wonder
when
he
recalls
how
different
his
first
visit
there
,
<EOS>
how
different
he
,
how
different
all
the
colours
of
his
mind
.
<EOS>
But
injustice
breeds
injustice
;
the
fighting
with
shadows
and
being
defeated
by
them
necessitates
the
setting
up
of
substances
to
combat
;
from
the
impalpable
suit
which
no
man
alive
can
understand
,
the
time
for
that
being
long
gone
by
,
it
has
become
a
gloomy
relief
to
turn
to
the
palpable
figure
of
the
friend
who
would
have
saved
him
from
this
ruin
and
make
HIM
his
enemy
.
 
<EOS>
Richard
has
told
Vholes
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
Is
he
in
a
hardened
or
a
softened
mood
,
he
still
lays
his
injuries
equally
at
that
door
;
he
was
thwarted
,
in
that
quarter
,
of
a
set
purpose
,
and
that
purpose
could
only
originate
in
the
one
subject
that
is
resolving
his
existence
into
itself
;
besides
,
it
is
a
justification
to
him
in
his
own

to
have
an
embodied
antagonist
and

.
   
<EOS>
Is
Richard
a
monster
in
all
this
,
or
would
Chancery
be
found
rich
in
such
precedents
too
if
they
could
be
got
for
citation
from
the
Recording
Angel
?
   
<EOS>
Two
pairs
of
eyes
not
unused
to
such
people
look
after
him
,
as
,
biting
his
nails
and

,
he
crosses
the
square
and
is
swallowed
up
by

shadow

the
southern

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
and
Mr
Weevle
are
the
possessors
of
those
eyes
,
and
they
have
been
leaning
in
conversation
against
the
low
stone

under

.
 
<EOS>
He
passes
close
by
them
,
seeing
nothing
but
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
William
,
"
says
Mr

,

,
"
there
's

going

!
 
<EOS>
It
's
not

case

,
but
it
's

combustion
it
is
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

Mr

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
would
n't
keep
out
of
Jarndyce
,
and
I

's
over

and
ears

.
 
<EOS>
I
never

of

.
<EOS>
He
was
as
high
as
the
monument
when

was

at

.
<EOS>
A
good
riddance
to
me
,

!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
Tony
,
that
as
I
was
mentioning
is
what
they
're
up
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
,
refolding
his
arms
,
resettles
himself
against
the
parapet
,
as
resuming
a
conversation
of
interest
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
still
up
to

,

,
"

Mr
Guppy
,
"
still

,

,

and

.
 
<EOS>
At
this
rate

'll
be
at

these
seven

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
Small
is
helping
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Small
left
us
at
a
week
's
notice
.
 
<EOS>
Told
Kenge
his
grandfather
's
business
was
too
much
for
the
old
gentleman
and
he
could
better
himself
by

.
 
<EOS>
There
had

between

and
Small
on

so

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
said
you
<EOS>
and
I
began

,
and
as
he
had
me
there
---
<EOS>
for
we
did
<EOS>
---
I
put
our

on
the
old

.
 
<EOS>
That
's
how
I
come
to
know
what
they
're
up
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
looked
in
at
all
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tony
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
,
a

,
"
to

unreserved
with
you
,
I
do
n't
greatly
relish
the
house
,
except
in
your

,
and
therefore
I
have
not
;
and
therefore
I
proposed
this
little
appointment
for
our
fetching
away
your
things
.
 
<EOS>
There
goes
the
hour
by
the
clock
!
 
<EOS>
Tony
"
---
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
becomes
mysteriously
and
tenderly
eloquent
---
"
it
is
necessary
that
I
should
impress
upon
your
mind
once
more
that
circumstances
over
which
I
have
no

have
made
a

in
my
most
cherished

and
in
that
unrequited
image
which
I
formerly
mentioned
to
you
as
a
friend
.
<EOS>
That
image
is
shattered
,
and
that
idol
is
laid
low
.
 
<EOS>
My
only
wish
now
in
connexion
with
the
objects
which
I
had
an
idea
of
carrying
out
in
the
court
with
your

as

friend
is
to
let
'em
alone
and
bury
'em
in

.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
it
possible
,
do
you
think
it
at
all
likely
<EOS>
(
I
put
it
to

,
Tony
,
as

friend
)
,
from
your
knowledge
of
that
capricious

deep
old
character
who
fell

to
the
---
spontaneous

,
<EOS>
do
you
,
Tony
,
think
it
at
all
likely
that
on
second
thoughts
he
put
those
letters
away
anywhere
,
after
you
saw
him
alive
,
and
that
they
were
not
destroyed
that
night
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weevle
reflects
for
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
Shakes
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
Decidedly
thinks
not
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tony
,
"
says
Mr
Guppy
as
they
walk
towards
the
court
,
"
once
again
understand
me
,
as
a
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Without
entering
into
further
explanations
,
I
may
repeat
that
the
idol
is
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
purpose
to
serve
now
but
burial
in
oblivion
.
 
<EOS>
To
that
I
have
pledged
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
owe
it
to
myself
,
and
I
owe
it
to
the
shattered
image
,
as
also
to
the
circumstances
over
which
I
have
no
control
.
<EOS>
If
you
was
to
express
to
me
by
a
gesture
,
by
a
wink
,
that
you
saw
lying
anywhere
in
your
late
lodgings
any
papers
that
so
much
as
looked
like
the
papers
in
question
,
I
would
pitch
them
into
the
fire
,
sir
,
on
my
own
responsibility
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Weevle
nods
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
,
much
elevated
in
his
own
opinion
by
having
delivered
these
observations
,
with
an
air
in
part
forensic
and
in
part
romantic
---
this
gentleman
having
a
passion
for
conducting
anything
in
the
form
of
an
examination
,
or
delivering
anything
in
the
form
of
a
summing
up
or
a
speech
---
accompanies
his
friend
with
dignity
to
the
court
.
   
<EOS>
Never
since
it
has
been
a
court
has
it
had
such
a
Fortunatus
'
purse
of
gossip
as
in
the
proceedings
at
the
rag
and
bottle
shop
.
<EOS>
Regularly
,
every
morning
at
eight
,
is
the
elder
Mr
Smallweed
brought
down
to
the
corner
and
carried
in
,
accompanied
by
Mrs
Smallweed
,
Judy
,
and
Bart
;
and
regularly
,
all
day
,
do
they
all
remain
there
until
nine
at
night
,
solaced
by
gipsy
dinners
,
not
abundant
in
quantity
,
from
the
cook
's
shop
,
rummaging
and
searching
,
digging
,
delving
,
and
diving
among
the
treasures
of
the
late
lamented
.
 
<EOS>
What
those
treasures
are
they
keep
so
secret
that
the
court
is
maddened
.
 
<EOS>
In
its
delirium
it
imagines
guineas
pouring
out
of
tea
-
pots
,
crown
-
pieces
overflowing
punch
-
bowls
,
old
chairs
and
mattresses
stuffed
with
Bank
of
England
notes
.
 
<EOS>
It
possesses
itself
of
the
sixpenny
history
(
with
highly
coloured
folding
frontispiece
)
of
Mr
Daniel
Dancer
and
his

Chapter

.
<EOS>
National
and

England

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

's

,

it
as
opportunely
turned
out
,
on
the
other
hand
,
that
Sir
Thomas
Doodle
had
in
his
own
bosom
expressly
booked
Lord
Coodle
to
go
down
to
posterity
as
the
mirror
of
virtue
and
honour
.
 
<EOS>
Still
England
has
been
some
weeks
in
the
dismal
strait
of
having
no
pilot
(
as
was
well
observed
by
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
)
to
weather
the
storm
;
and
the
marvellous
part
of
the
matter
is
that
England
has
not
appeared
to
care
very
much
about
it
,
but
has
gone
on
eating
and
drinking
and
marrying
and
giving
in
marriage
as
the
old
world
did
in
the
days
before
the
flood
.
 
<EOS>
But
Coodle
knew
the
danger
,
and
Doodle
knew
the
danger
,
and
all
their
followers
and
hangers
-
on
had
the
clearest
possible
perception
of
the
danger
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
Sir
Thomas
Doodle
has
not
only
condescended
to
come
in
,
but
has
done
it
handsomely
,
bringing
in
with
him
all
his
nephews
,
all
his
male
cousins
,
and
all
his
brothers
-
in
-
law
.
 
<EOS>
So
there
is
hope
for
the
old
ship
yet
.
   
<EOS>
Doodle
has
found
that
he
must
throw
himself
upon
the
country
,
chiefly
in
the
form
of
sovereigns
and
beer
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
metamorphosed
state
he
is
available
in
a
good
many
places
simultaneously
and
can
throw
himself
upon
a
considerable
portion
of
the
country
at
one
time
.
 
<EOS>
Britannia
being
much
occupied
in
pocketing
Doodle
in
the
form
of
sovereigns
,
and
swallowing
Doodle
in
the
form
of
beer
,
and
in
swearing
herself
black
in
the
face
that
she
does
neither
---
 
plainly
to
the
advancement
of
her
glory
and
morality
---
the
London
season
comes
to
a
sudden
end
,
through
all
the
Doodleites
and
Coodleites
dispersing
to
assist
Britannia
in
those
religious
exercises
.
   
<EOS>
Hence
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
housekeeper
at
Chesney
Wold
,
foresees
,
though
no
instructions
have
yet
come
down
,
that
the
family
may
shortly
be
expected
,
together
with
a
pretty
large
accession
of
cousins
and
others
who
can
in
any
way
assist
the
great
Constitutional
work
.
 
<EOS>
And
hence
the
stately
old
dame
,
taking
Time
by
the
forelock
,
leads
him
up
and
down
the
staircases
,
and
along
the
galleries
and
passages
,
and
through
the
rooms
,
to
witness
before
he
grows
any
older
that
everything
is
ready
,
that
floors
are
rubbed
bright
,
carpets
spread
,
curtains
shaken
out
,
beds
puffed
and
patted
,
still
-
room
and
kitchen
cleared
for
action
---
all
things
prepared
as
beseems
the
Dedlock
dignity
.
   
<EOS>
This
present
summer
evening
,
as
the
sun
goes
down
,
the
preparations
are
complete
.
 
<EOS>
Dreary
and
solemn
the
old
house
looks
,
with
so
many
appliances
of
habitation
and
with
no
inhabitants
except
the
pictured
forms
upon
the
walls
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
these
come
and
go
,
a
Dedlock
in
possession
might
have
ruminated
passing
along
<EOS>
;
so
did
they
see
this
gallery
hushed
and
quiet
,
as
I
see
it
now
;
so
think
,
as
I
think
,
of
the
gap
that
they
would
make
in
this
domain
when
they
were
gone
;
so
find
it
,
as
I
find
it
,
difficult
to
believe
that
it
could
be
without
them
;
so
pass
from
my
world
,
as
I
pass
from
theirs
,
now
closing
the
reverberating
door
;
so
leave
no
blank
to
miss
them
,
and
so
die
.
   
<EOS>
Through
some
of
the
fiery
windows
beautiful
from
without
,
and
set
,
at
this
sunset
hour
,
not
in
dull
-
grey
stone
but
in
a
glorious
house
of
gold
,
the
light
excluded
at
other
windows
pours
in
rich
,
lavish
,
overflowing
like
the
summer
plenty
in
the
land
.
 
<EOS>
Then
do
the
frozen
Dedlocks
thaw
.
 
<EOS>
Strange
movements
come
upon
their
features
as
the
shadows
of
leaves
play
there
.
 
<EOS>
A
dense
justice
in
a
corner
is
beguiled
into
a
wink
.
 
<EOS>
A
staring
baronet
,
with
a
truncheon
,
gets
a
dimple
in
his
chin
.
 
<EOS>
Down
into
the
bosom
of
a
stony
shepherdess
there
steals
a
fleck
of
light
and
warmth
that
would
have
done
it
good
a
hundred
years
ago
.
 
<EOS>
One
ancestress
of
Volumnia
,
in
high
-
heeled
shoes
,
very
like
her
---
casting
the
shadow
of
that
virgin
event
before
her
full
two
centuries
<EOS>
---
shoots
out
into
a
halo
and
becomes
a
saint
.
 
<EOS>
A
maid
of
honour
of
the
court
of
Charles
the
Second
,
with
large
round
eyes
(
and
other
charms
to
correspond
)
,
seems
to
bathe
in
glowing
water
,
and
it
ripples
as
it
glows
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
fire
of
the
sun
is
dying
.
 
<EOS>
Even
now
the
floor
is
dusky
,
and
shadow
slowly
mounts
the
walls
,
bringing
the
Dedlocks
down
like
age
and
death
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
upon
my
Lady
's
picture
over
the
great
chimney
-
piece
,
a
weird
shade
falls
from
some
old
tree
,
that
turns
it
pale
,
and
flutters
it
,
and
looks
as
if
a
great
arm
held
a
veil
or
hood
,
watching
an
opportunity
to
draw
it
over
her
.
 
<EOS>
Higher
and
darker
rises
shadow
on
the
wall
---
now
a
red
gloom
on
the
ceiling
---
now
the
fire
is
out
.
   
<EOS>
All
that
prospect
,
which
from
the
terrace
looked
so
near
,
has
moved
solemnly
away
and
changed
---
not
the
first
nor
the
last
of
beautiful
things
that
look
so
near
and
will
so
change
---
into
a
distant
phantom
.
 
<EOS>
Light
mists
arise
,
and
the
dew
falls
,
and
all
the
sweet
scents
in
the
garden
are
heavv
in
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
Now
the
woods
settle
into
great
masses
as
if
they
were
each
one
profound
tree
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
the
moon
rises
to
separate
them
,
and
to
glimmer
here
and
there
in
horizontal
lines
behind
their
stems
,
and
to
make
the
avenue
a
pavement
of
light
among
high
cathedral
arches
fantastically
broken
.
   
<EOS>
Now
the
moon
is
high
;
and
the
great
house
,
needing
habitation
more
than
ever
,
is
like
a
body
without
life
.
 
<EOS>
Now
it
is
even
awful
,
stealing
through
it
,
to
think
of
the
live
people
who
have
slept
in
the
solitary
bedrooms
,
to
say
nothing
of
the
dead
.
 
<EOS>
Now
is
the
time
for
shadow
,
when
every
corner
is
a
cavern
and
every
downward
step
a
pit
,
when
the
stained
glass
is
reflected
in
pale
and
faded
hues
upon
the
floors
,
when
anything
and
everything
can
be
made
of
the
heavy
staircase
beams
excepting
their
own
proper
shapes
,
when
the
armour
has
dull
lights
upon
it
not
easily
to
be
distinguished
from
stealthy
movement
,
and
when
barred
helmets
are
frightfully
suggestive
of
heads
inside
.
 
<EOS>
But
of
all
the
shadows
in
Chesney
Wold
,
the
shadow
in
the
long
drawing
-
room
upon
my
Lady
's
picture
is
the
first
to
come
,
the
last
to
be
disturbed
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
hour
and
by
this
light
it
changes
into
threatening
hands
raised
up
and
menacing
the
handsome
face
with
every
breath
that
stirs
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
not
well
,
ma'am
,
"
says
a
groom
in
Mrs
Rouncewell
's
audience
-
chamber
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
Lady
not
well
!
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
Lady
has
been
but
poorly
,
ma'am
,
since
she
was
last
here
---
 
I
do
n't
mean
with
the
family
,
ma'am
,
but
when
she
was
here
as
a
bird
of
passage
like
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
has
not
been
out
much
for
her
and
has
kept
her
room
a
good
deal
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Chesney
Wold
,
Thomas
,
"
rejoins
the
housekeeper
with
proud
complacency
,
"
will
set
my
Lady
up
!
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
finer
air
and
no
healthier
soil
in
the
world
!
"
   
<EOS>
Thomas
may
have
his
own
personal
opinions
on
this
subject
,
probably
hints
them
in
his
manner
of
smoothing
his
sleek
head
from
the
nape
of
his
neck
to
his
temples
,
but
he
forbears
to
express
them
further
and
retires
to
the
servants
'
hall
to
regale
on
cold
meat
-
pie
and
ale
.
   
<EOS>
This
groom
is
the
pilot
-
fish
before
the
nobler
shark
.
 
<EOS>
Next
evening
,
down
come
Sir
Leicester
and
my
Lady
with
their
largest
retinue
,
and
down
come
the
cousins
and
others
from
all
the
points
of
the
compass
.
 
<EOS>
Thenceforth
for
some
weeks
backward
and
forward
<EOS>
rush
mysterious
men
with
no
names
,
who
fly
about
all
those
particular
parts
of
the
country
on
which
Doodle
is
at
present
throwing
himself
in
an
auriferous
and
malty
shower
,
but
who
are
merely
persons
of
a
restless
disposition
and
never
do
anything
anywhere
.
   
<EOS>
On
these
national
occasions
Sir
Leicester
finds
the
cousins
useful
.
<EOS>
A
better
man
than
the
Honourable
Bob
Stables
to
meet
the
Hunt
at
dinner
,
there
could
not
possibly
be
.
 
<EOS>
Better
got
up
gentlemen
than
the
other
cousins
to
ride
over
to
polling
-
booths
and
hustings
here
and
there
,
and
show
themselves
on
the
side
of
England
,
it
would
be
hard
to
find
.
 
<EOS>
Volumnia
is
a
little
dim
,
but
she
is
of
the
true
descent
;
and
there
are
many
who
appreciate
her
sprightly
conversation
,
her
French
conundrums
so
old
as
to
have
become
in
the
cycles
of
time
almost
new
again
,
the
honour
of
taking
the
fair
Dedlock
in
to
dinner
,
or
even
the
privilege
of
her
hand
in
the
dance
.
 
<EOS>
On
these
national
occasions
dancing
may
be
a
patriotic
service
,
and
Volumnia
is
constantly
seen
hopping
about
for
the
good
of
an
ungrateful
and
unpensioning
country
.
   
<EOS>
My
Lady
takes
no
great
pains
to
entertain
the
numerous
guests
,
and
being
still
unwell
,
rarely
appears
until
late
in
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
But
at
all
the
dismal
dinners
,
leaden
lunches
,
basilisk
balls
,
and
other
melancholy
pageants
,
her
mere
appearance
is
a
relief
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Sir
Leicester
,
he
conceives
it
utterly
impossible
that
anything
can
be
wanting
,
in
any
direction
,
by
any
one
who
has
the
good
fortune
to
be
received
under
that
roof
;
<EOS>
and
in
a
state
of
sublime
satisfaction
,
he
moves
among
the
company
,
a
magnificent
refrigerator
.
   
<EOS>
Daily
<EOS>
the
cousins
trot
through
dust
and
canter
over
roadside
turf
,
away
to
hustings
and
polling
-
booths
(
with
leather
gloves
and
hunting
-
whips
for
the
counties
and
kid
gloves
and
riding
-
canes
for
the
boroughs
)
,
and
daily
bring
back
reports
on
which
Sir
Leicester
holds
forth
after
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Daily
the
restless
men
who
have
no
occupation
in
life
present
the
appearance
of
being
rather
busy
.
<EOS>
Daily
Volumnia
has
a
little
cousinly
talk
with
Sir
Leicester
on
the
state
of
the
nation
,
from
which
Sir
Leicester
is
disposed
to
conclude
that
Volumnia
is
a
more
reflecting
woman
than
he
had
thought
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
we
getting
on
?
"
says
Miss
Volumnia
,
clasping
her
hands
.
<EOS>
"
ARE
we
safe
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
mighty
business
is
nearly
over
by
this
time
,
and
Doodle
will
throw
himself
off
the
country
in
a
few
days
more
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
has
just
appeared
in
the
long
drawing
-
room
after
dinner
,
a
bright
particular
star
surrounded
by
clouds
of
cousins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Volumnia
,
"
replies
Sir
Leicester
,
who
has
a
list
in
his
hand
,
"
we
are
doing
tolerably
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Only
tolerably
!
"
   
Although
it
is
summer
weather
,
Sir
Leicester
always
has
his
own
particular
fire
in
the
evening
.
 
<EOS>
He
takes
his
usual
screened
seat
near
it
and
repeats
with
much
firmness
and
a
little
displeasure
,
as
who
should
say
,
I
am
not
a
common
man
,
and
when
I
say
tolerably
,
it
must
not
be
understood
as
a
common
expression
,
"
Volumnia
,
we
are
doing
tolerably
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
least
there
is
no
opposition
to
YOU
,
"
Volumnia
asserts
with
confidence
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Volumnia
.
 
<EOS>
This
distracted
country
has
lost
its
senses
in
many
respects
,
I
grieve
to
say
,
but
---
"
   
"
It
is
not
so
mad
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
Volumnia
's
finishing
the
sentence
restores
her
to
favour
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
,
with
a
gracious
inclination
of
his
head
,
seems
to
say
to
himself
,
"
A
sensible
woman
this
,
on
the
whole
,
though
occasionally
precipitate
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
fact
,
as
to
this
question
of
opposition
,
the
fair
Dedlock
's
observation
was
superfluous
,
Sir
Leicester
on
these
occasions
always
delivering
in
his
own
candidateship
,
as
a
kind
of
handsome
wholesale
order
to
be
promptly
executed
.
 
<EOS>
Two
other
little
seats
that
belong
to
him
he
treats
as
retail
orders
of
less
importance
,
merely
sending
down
the
men
and
signifying
to
the
tradespeople
,
"
You
will
have
the
goodness
to
make
these
materials
into
two
members
of
Parliament
and
to
send
them
home
when
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
regret
to
say
,
Volumnia
,
that
in
many
places
the
people
have
shown
a
bad
spirit
,
and
that
this
opposition
to
the
government
has
been
of
a
most
determined
and
most
implacable
description
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
W
-
r
-
retches
!
"
says
Volumnia
.
   
<EOS>
"
Even
,
"
proceeds
Sir
Leicester
,
glancing
at
the
circumjacent
cousins
on
sofas
and
ottomans
,
"
even
in
many
---
in
fact
,
in
most
---
of
those
places
in
which
the
government
has
carried
it
against
a
faction
---
"
   
(
Note
,
by
the
way
,
that
the
Coodleites
are

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Real

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Sir

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Lady

"
   
<EOS>
By

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A

"

,
"
implying

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
By

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
no

<EOS>
Sir

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

;
<EOS>

(

<EOS>
Chapter
41
.
<EOS>
In
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
Room
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
arrives
in
his
turret
-
room
a
little

by
the
journey
up
,
though
leisurely
performed
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
an
expression
on
his
face
as
if
he
had
discharged
his
mind
of
some
grave
matter
and
were
,
in
his
close

,
satisfied
.
 
<EOS>
To
say
of
a
man
so
severely
and
strictly
self
-

that
he
is

would
be

do
him
as
great
an

as
to
suppose
him
troubled
with
love
or

or
any

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
sedately
satisfied
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
there
is
a
rather
increased
sense
of
power
upon
him
as
he
loosely

one
of
his
veinous

with
his
other

and
holding
it
behind
his
back
walks
noiselessly
up
and
down
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
a
capacious
writing
-
table
in
the
room
on
which
is
a
pretty
large
accumulation
of
papers
.
 
<EOS>
The
green

is
lighted
,
his
reading
-

lie
upon

,
the
easy
-
chair
is

up
to

,
and
it

as

had

to

upon
these

on

before

.
 
<EOS>
But

happens
not
to
be
in

.
 
<EOS>
After

the
documents
awaiting
his
notice
---
with

,
the
old

's
sight
for
print

being
defective
at

---
he
opens

French
window
and
steps

upon

.
<EOS>
There

again

up

,

,
if
a

any

,
from
the
story
he
has
related
downstairs
.
   
<EOS>
The
time
was
once
when
men
as
knowing
as
Mr
Tulkinghorn
would
walk
on
turret
-
tops
in

and
look

.
 
<EOS>
Hosts
of

are
visible

-

,
though

.
 
<EOS>
If

,
it

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

.
   
<EOS>
As

in

.
 
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

he

<EOS>
These

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Is

?
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Both

<EOS>
"
Lady

?
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

?
"

.

"

.
 
<EOS>
Is

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
So
!
 
<EOS>
Anger

.
 
<EOS>
All

.
 
<EOS>
What

!
 
<EOS>
Mr

's

,
with

a

<EOS>
"
No
,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
Sir
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

,

---

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,
throws

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
Is

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
And

do

,
thinks
the
lawver
,
watchful
of
the
firm

with

she

!
   
<EOS>
"
I
will

,

Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
Pray

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
You
can

.
 
<EOS>
Do
what
remains
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lady
Dedlock
,
there

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Their
need
for
watching
one
another
should
be
over
now
,
but
they
do
it
all
this

,
and
the
stars
watch

through

.
 
<EOS>
Away
in
the
moonlight
lie
the
woodland
fields
at
rest
,
and
the
wide
house
is
as
quiet
as
the
narrow
one
.
 
<EOS>
The
narrow
one
!
<EOS>
Where
are
the
digger
and
the
spade
,
this
peaceful
night
,
destined
to
add
the
last
great
secret
to
the
many
secrets
of
the
Tulkinghorn
existence
?
 
<EOS>
Is
the
man
born
yet
,
is
the
spade
wrought
yet
?
 
<EOS>
Curious
questions
to
consider
,
more
curious
perhaps
not
to
consider
,
under
the
watching
stars
upon
a
summer
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
repentance
or
remorse
or
any
feeling
of
mine
,
"
Lady
Dedlock
presently
proceeds
,
"
I
say
not
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
were
not
dumb
,
you
would
be
deaf
.
 
<EOS>
Let
that
go
by
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
for
your
ears
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
makes
a
feint
of
offering
a
protest
,
but
she
sweeps
it
away
with
her
disdainful
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
other
and
very
different
things
I
come
to
speak
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
My
jewels
are
all
in
their
proper
places
of
keeping
.
 
<EOS>
They
will
be
found
there
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
my
dresses
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
all
the
valuables
I
have
.
 
<EOS>
Some
ready
money
I
had
with
me
,
please
to
say
,
but
no
large
amount
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
wear
my
own
dress
,
in
order
that
I
might
avoid
observation
.
<EOS>
I
went
to
be
henceforward
lost
.
 
<EOS>
Make
this
known
.
 
<EOS>
I
leave
no
other
charge
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
quite
unmoved
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
sure
that
I
understand
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
want
---
"
   
"
To
be
lost
to
all
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
leave
Chesney
Wold
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
go
this
hour
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
shakes
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
She
rises
,
but
he
,
without
moving
hand
from
chair
-
back
or
from
old
-
fashioned
waistcoat
and
shirt
-
frill
,
shakes
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
 
<EOS>
Not
go
as
I
have
said
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
No
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
"
he
very
calmly
replies
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
the
relief
that
my
disappearance
will
be
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
forgotten
the
stain
and
blot
upon
this
place
,
and
where
it
is
,
and
who
it
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
not
by
any
means
.
"
   
<EOS>
Without
deigning
to
rejoin
,
she
moves
to
the
inner
door
and
has
it
in
her
hand
when
he
says
to
her
,
without
himself
stirring
hand
or
foot
or
raising
his
voice
,
"
Lady
Dedlock
,
have
the
goodness
to
stop
and
hear
me
,
or
before
you
reach
the
staircase
I
shall
ring
the
alarm
-
bell
and
rouse
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
I
must
speak
out
before
every
guest
and
servant
,
every
man
and
woman
,
in
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
has
conquered
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
falters
,
trembles
,
and
puts
her
hand
confusedly
to
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
Slight
tokens
these
in
any
one
else
,
but
when
so
practised
an
eye
as
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
sees
indecision
for
a
moment
in
such
a
subject
,
he
thoroughly
knows
its
value
.
   
<EOS>
He
promptly
says
again
,
"
Have
the
goodness
to
hear
me
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
"
and
motions
to
the
chair
from
which
she
has
risen
.
 
<EOS>
She
hesitates
,
but
he
motions
again
,
and
she
sits
down
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
relations
between
us
are
of
an
unfortunate
description
,
Lady
Dedlock
;
but
as
they
are
not
of
my
making
,
I
will
not
apologize
for
them
.
 
<EOS>
The
position
I
hold
in
reference
to
Sir
Leicester
is
so
well
known
to
you
that
I
can
hardly
imagine
but
that
I
must
long
have
appeared
in
your
eyes
the
natural
person
to
make
this
discovery
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
she
returns
without
looking
up
from
the
ground
on
which
her
eyes
are
now
fixed
,
"
I
had
better
have
gone
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
far
better
not
to
have
detained
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
more
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Excuse
me
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
if
I
add
a
little
more
to
hear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to
hear
it
at
the
window
,
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
breathe
where
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
jealous
glance
as
she
walks
that
way
<EOS>
betrays
an
instant
's
misgiving
that
she
may
have
it
in
her
thoughts
to
leap
over
,
and
dashing
against
ledge
and
cornice
,
strike
her
life
out
upon
the
terrace
below
.
 
<EOS>
But
a
moment
's
observation
of
her
figure
as
she
stands
in
the
window
without
any
support
,
looking
out
at
the
stars
 
---
not
up
-
gloomily
out
at
those
stars
which
are
low
in
the
heavens
,
reassures
him
.
 
<EOS>
By
facing
round
as
she
has
moved
,
he
stands
a
little
behind
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lady
Dedlock
,
I
have
not
yet
been
able
to
come
to
a
decision
satisfactory
to
myself
on
the
course
before
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
clear
what
to
do
or
how
to
act
next
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
request
you
,
in
the
meantime
,
to
keep
your
secret
as
you
have
kept
it
so
long
and
not
to
wonder
that
I
keep
it
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
pauses
,
but
she
makes
no
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
Lady
Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
an
important
subject
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
honouring
me
with
your
attention
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
might
have
known
it
from
what
I
have
seen
of
your
strength
of
character
.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
not
to
have
asked
the
question
,
but
I
have
the
habit
of
making
sure
of
my
ground
,
step
by
step
,
as
I
go
on
.
 
<EOS>
The
sole
consideration
in
this
unhappy
case
is
Sir
Leicester
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
why
,
"
she
asks
in
a
low

and
without
removing
her
gloomy
look
from
those
distant
stars
,
"
do
you
detain
me
in
his
house
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Because
he
IS
the
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
,
I
have
no
occasion
to
tell
you
that
Sir
Leicester
is
a
very
proud
man
,
that
his
reliance
upon
you
is
implicit
,
that
the
fall
of
that
moon
out
of
the
sky
would
not

him
more
than
your
fall
from
your
high
position
as
his
wife
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
breathes
quickly
and
heavily
,
but
she
stands
as
unflinchingly
as
ever
he
has
seen
her
in
the
midst
of
her
grandest
company
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
declare

you
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
that
with
anything
short
of
this
case
that
I
have
,
I
would
as

have
hoped
to
root
up
by
means

my
own
strength
and
my
own
hands
<EOS>
the
oldest
tree
on
this
estate
as
to
shake
your
hold
upon
Sir
Leicester
and
Sir
Leicester
's
trust
and
confidence
in
you
.
 
<EOS>
And
even
now
,
with
this
case
,
I
hesitate
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
he
could
doubt
(
that
,
even
with
him
,
is
impossible
)
,
but
that
nothing
can
prepare
him
for
the
blow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
my
flight
?
<EOS>
"
she
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Think
of
it
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
flight
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
would
spread
the
whole
truth
,
and
a
hundred

the
whole
truth
,
far

.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
impossible
to
save
the
family
credit
for
a
day
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
to
be
thought
of
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
is
a
quiet
decision
in
his
reply
which
admits
of
no

.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
speak
of
Sir
Leicester
being
the
sole

,
he
and
the
family
credit
are
one
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester

,
Sir
Leicester

Chesney
Wold
,
Sir
Leicester
and
his
ancestors
and
his

"
---
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
very
dry
here
---
"
are
<EOS>
,
I
need
not
say
to
you
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
inseparable
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
pursuing
his
case
in
his
jog
-

style
,
"
I
have
much
to
consider
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
to
be
hushed
up
if
it
can

.
 
<EOS>
How
can

be
,
if
Sir
Leicester
is
driven

laid

?
 
<EOS>
If
I

upon
him
to
-

morning
,
how
could
the

in
him
be
accounted

?
 
<EOS>
What
could
have
caused

?
 
<EOS>
What
could

?
 
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
,
the
wall
-
chalking
and
the
street
-

would
come
on

,
and
you
are
to
remember
that
it

not

you

(
<EOS>
whom
<EOS>
I
can
not
at
all
consider
in
this

)
but
your

,
Lady
Dedlock
,
your
husband
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
gets
plainer
as
he
gets
on
,
but
not
an
atom
more

or

.
   
<EOS>
"
There

another

,
"
he

,
"
in

the
case
presents

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
is
devoted
to
you
almost
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
might
not
be
able
to
overcome
that
infatuation
,
even
knowing
what
we
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
putting
an
extreme
case
,
but
it
might
be
so
.
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
it
were
better
that
he
knew
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Better
for
common

,
better

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
must
take
all
this
into
account
,
and
it
combines
to
render
a
decision
very
difficult
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
stands
looking
out
at
the
same
stars
without
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
beginning
to
pale
,
and
she
looks
as
if
their
coldness
froze
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
experience
teaches
me
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
who
has
by
this
time
got
his
hands
in
his

and
is
going
on
in
his
business
consideration
of
the
matter
like

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
experience
teaches
me
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
that
most
of
the
people
I
know
would
do
far
better
to
leave
marriage
alone
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
at
the
bottom
of
three
fourths
of
their
troubles
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
thought
when
Sir
Leicester
married
,
and
so
I
always
have
thought
since
.
 
<EOS>
No
more
about
that
.
<EOS>
I
must
now
be
guided
by
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meanwhile
I
must
beg
you
to
keep
your
own
counsel
,
and
I
will
keep
mine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
to
drag
my
present
life
on
,
holding
its

at
your
pleasure
,
day

?
<EOS>
"
she

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
afraid
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

has
been
so

,
and

you

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,

Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
I

without

.
"
   
<EOS>
She

all

as

.
   
<EOS>
"
We

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Precisely

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
Lady
Dedlock
,

that

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
but
<EOS>
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
She

in
the
same

for

before

,
"
Is
there
anything

to

sald
to
-

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
returns
methodically
as
he
softly
rubs

,
"
I
should
like
to
be

of
your

,
Lady
Dedlock
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
be

of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
would
wish

to
remind

,
as

,
<EOS>
in

Leicester
,
that

I

Leicester
's

.
 
<EOS>
I

Dedlock

,

,
if
the

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
attest

,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Both
before
and
after
saving
it
<EOS>
she
remains

,
but

length

,
and

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
opens
both
the
doors
exactly
as
he
would
have
done
yesterday
,
or
as
he
would
have
done
ten
years
ago
,
and
makes
his
old
-
fashioned
bow
as
she
passes
out
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
an
ordinary
look
that
he
receives
from
the
handsome
face
as
it
goes
into
the
darkness
,
and
it
is
not
an
ordinary
movement
,
though
a
very
slight
one
,
that
acknowledges
his
courtesy
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
he
reflects
when
he
is
left
alone
,
the
woman
has
been
putting
no
common
constraint
upon
herself
.
   
<EOS>
He
would
know
it
all
the
better
if
he
saw
the
woman
pacing
her
own
rooms
with
her
hair
wildly
thrown
from
her
flung
-
back
face
,
her
hands
clasped
behind
her
head
,
her
figure
twisted
as
if
by
pain
.
<EOS>
He
would
think
so
all
the
more
if
he
saw
the
woman
thus
hurrying
up
and
down
for
hours
,
without
fatigue
,
without
intermission
,
followed
by
the
faithful
step
upon
the
Ghost
's
Walk
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
shuts
out
the
now
chilled
air
,
draws
the
window
-
curtain
,
goes
to
bed
,
and
falls
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
And
truly
when
the
stars
go
out
and
the
wan
day
peeps
into
the
turret
-
chamber
,
finding
him
at
his
oldest
<EOS>
,
he
looks
as
if
the
digger
and
the
spade
were
both
commissioned
and
would
soon
be
digging
.
   
<EOS>
The
same
wan
day
peeps
in
at
Sir
Leicester
pardoning
the
repentant
country
in
a
majestically
condescending
dream
;
and
at
the
cousins
entering
on
various
public
employments
,
principally
receipt
of
salary
;
and
at
the
chaste
Volumnia
,
bestowing
a
dower
of
fifty
thousand
pounds
upon
a
hideous
old
general
with
a
mouth
of
false
teeth
like
a
pianoforte
too
full
of
keys
,
long
the
admiration
of
Bath
and
the
terror
of
every
other
commuuity
.
 
<EOS>
Also
into
rooms
high
in
the
roof
,
and
into
offices
in
court
-
yards
,
and
over
stables
,
where
humbler
ambition
dreams
of
bliss
,
in
keepers
'
lodges
,
and
in
holy
matrimony
with
Will
or
Sally
.
 
<EOS>
Up
comes
the
bright
sun
,
drawing
everything
up
with
it
---
the
Wills
and
Sallys
,
the
latent
vapour
in
the
earth
,
the
drooping
leaves
and
flowers
,
the
birds
and
beasts
and
creeping
things
,
the
gardeners
to
sweep
the
dewy
turf
and
unfold
emerald
velvet
where
the
roller
passes
,
the
smoke
of
the
great
kitchen
fire
wreathing
itself
straight
and
high
into
the
lightsome
air
.
 
<EOS>
Lastly
,
up
comes
the
flag
over
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
unconscious
head
cheerfully
proclaiming
that
Sir
Leicester
and
Lady
Dedlock
are
in
their
happy
home
and
that
there
is
hospitality
at
the
place
in
Lincolnshire
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
42
.
<EOS>
In
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
Chambers
 
From
the
verdant
undulations
and
the
spreading
oaks
of
the
Dedlock
property
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
transfers
himself
to
the
stale
heat
and
dust
of
London
.
 
<EOS>
His
manner
of
coming
and
going
between
the
two
places
is
one
of
his
impenetrabilities
.
 
<EOS>
He
walks
into
Chesney
Wold
as
if
it
were
next
door
to
his
chambers
and
returns
to
his
chambers
as
if
he
had
never
been
out
of
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
.
 
<EOS>
He
neither
changes
his
dress
before
the
journey
nor
talks
of
it
afterwards
.
<EOS>
He
melted
out
of
his
turret
-
room
this
morning
,
just
as
now
,
in
the
late
twilight
,
he
melts
into
his
own
square
.
   
<EOS>
Like
a
dingy
London
bird
among
the
birds
at
roost
in
these
pleasant
fields
,
where
the
sheep
are
all
made
into
parchment
,
the
goats
into
wigs
,
and
the
pasture
into
chaff
,
the
lawyer
,
smoke
-
dried
and
faded
,
dwelling
among
mankind
but
not
consorting
with
them
,
aged
without
experience
of
genial
youth
,
and
so
long
used
to
make
his
cramped
nest
in
holes
and
corners
of
human
nature
that
he
has
forgotten
its
broader
and
better
range
,
comes
sauntering
home
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
oven
made
by
the
hot
pavements
and
hot
buildings
,
he
has
baked
himself
dryer
than
usual
;
and
he
has
in
his
thirsty
mind
his
mellowed
port
-
wine
half
a
century
old
.
   
<EOS>
The
lamplighter
is
skipping
up
and
down
his
ladder
on
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
side
of
the
Fields
when
that
high
-
priest
of
noble
mysteries
arrives
at
his
own
dull
court
-
yard
.
 
<EOS>
He
ascends
the
door
-
steps
and
is
gliding
into
the
dusky
hall
when
he
encounters
,
on
the
top
step
,
a
bowing
and
propitiatory
little
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
Snagsby
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
you
are
well
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
just
giving
you
up
,
sir
,
and
going
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
want
with
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"

Mr
Snagsby
,
holding

in
his

his
best

,
"
I
was
wishful
to
say

word

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Can

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Say

.
"
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

,
"
it

relating
---
not

---
to

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
French
,

?
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Her

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

,
"
it

.
 
<EOS>
My

is
very
great
<EOS>
---
at

,

,

---
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

you

---

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

---

<EOS>
Now

,

When

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
Mr

,

"
These
women

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

's

!
 
<EOS>
But
I

THIS

!
"
   
<EOS>
So

,

,

into

murky

,
lights

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
too
dark
to
see
much

the
Allegory
over
-
head
there
,
but
that
importunate
Roman
,
who
is
for

and

,
is
at
his
old
work
pretty

.
 
<EOS>
Not
honouring
him
with
much

,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
takes

,
unlocks

in
which
there

another
key
,
which

in

there

another
,
and
so

to

cellar
-
key
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
He
is

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's

?
 
<EOS>

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
HAVE

!
"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Lies

"

so
like
a
bodily
spring
upon
the
subject
of
it
that
such
subject
involuntarily
starts
and
fails
back
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
case
at
present
,
though
Mademoiselle
Hortense
,
with
her
eyes
almost
shut
up
(
but
still
looking
out
sideways
)
,
is
only
smiling
contemptuously
and
shaking
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
mistress
,
"
says
the
lawyer
,
tapping
the
key
hastily
upon
the
chimney
-
piece
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
anything
to
say
,
say
it
,
say
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
you
have
not
use
me
well
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
been
mean
and
shabby
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mean
and
shabby
,
eh
?
<EOS>
"
returns
the
lawyer
,
rubbing
his
nose
with
the
key
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
that
I
tell
you
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
you
have
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
attrapped
me
---
catched
me
---
to
give
you
information
;
you
have
asked
me
to
show
you
the
dress
of
mine
my
Lady
must
have
wore
that
night
,
you
have
prayed
me
to
come
in
it
here
to
meet
that
boy
.
 
<EOS>
Say
!
<EOS>
Is
it
not
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mademoiselle
Hortense
makes
another
spring
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
vixen
,
a
vixen
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
seems
to
meditate
as
he
looks
distrustfully
at
her
,
then
he
replies
,
"
<EOS>
Well
,
wench
,
well
.
<EOS>
I
paid
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
paid
me
!
"
<EOS>
she
repeats
with
fierce
disdain
.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
sovereign
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
change
them
<EOS>
,
I
re
-
fuse
them
,
<EOS>
I
des
-
pise
them
,
I
throw
them
from
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
Which
she
literally
does
,
taking
them
out
of
her
bosom
as
she
speaks
and
flinging
them
with
such
violence
on
the
floor
that
they
jerk
up
again
into
the
light
before
they
roll
away
into
corners
and
slowly
settle
down
there
after
spinning
vehemently
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
!
"
says
Mademoiselle
Hortense
,
darkening
her
large
eyes
again
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
paid
me
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
,
my
God
,
<EOS>
oh
yes
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
rubs
his
head
with
the
key
while
she
entertains
herself
with
a
sarcastic
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
rich
,
my
fair
friend
,
"
he
composedly
observes
,
"
to
throw
money
about
in
that
way
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
AM
rich
,
"
she
returns
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
rich
in
hate
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
my
Lady
,
of
all
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Know
it
?
 
<EOS>
How
should
I
know
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
you
have
known
it
perfectly
before
you
prayed
me
to
give
you
that
information
.
 
<EOS>
Because
you
have
known
perfectly
that
I
was
en
-
r
-
r
-
r
-
raged
!
"
 
<EOS>
It
appears
impossible
for
mademoiselle
to
roll
the
letter
"
r
"
sufficiently
in
this
word
,
notwithstanding
that
she
assists
her
energetic
delivery
by
clenching
both
her
hands
and
setting
all
her
teeth
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
knew
that
,
did
I
?
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
examining
the
wards
of
the
key
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
without
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
blind
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
made
sure
of
me
because
you
knew
that
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
reason
!
 
<EOS>
I
det
-
est
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mademoiselle
folds
her
arms
and
throws
this
last
remark
at
him
over
one
of
her
shoulders
.
   
<EOS>
"
Having
said
this
,
have
you
anything
else
to
say
,
mademoiselle
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
yet
placed
.
 
<EOS>
Place
me
well
.
 
<EOS>
Find
me
a
good
condition
!
<EOS>
If
you
can
not
,
or
do
not
choose
to
do
that
,
employ
me
to
pursue
her
,
to
chase
her
,
to
disgrace
and
to
dishonour
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
help
you
well
,
and
with
a
good
will
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
what
YOU
do
.
 
<EOS>
Do
I
not
know
that
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
appear
to
know
a
good
deal
,
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
retorts
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
not
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
that
I
am
so
weak
as
to
believe
,
like
a
child
,
that
I
come
here
in
that
dress
to
rec
-
cive
that
boy
only
to
decide
a
little
bet
,
a
wager
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
,
my
God
,
<EOS>
oh
yes
!
"
 
<EOS>
In
this
reply
,
down
to
the
word
"
wager
"
inclusive
,
mademoiselle
has
been
ironically
polite
and
tender
,
then
as
suddenly
dashed
into
the
bitterest
and
most
defiant
scorn
,
with
her
black
eyes
in
one
and
the
same
moment
very
nearly
shut
and
staringly

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
let
us
see
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
tapping
his
chin
with
the
key
and
looking
imperturbably
at
her
,
"
how
this
matter
stands
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
Let
us
see
,
"
mademoiselle
assents
,
with
many
angry
and
tight

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
come
here
to
make
a
remarkably
modest
demand
,
which
you
have
just
stated
,
and
it
not
being
conceded
,
you
will
come
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
again
,
"
says
mademoiselle
with
more
tight
and
angry
