.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
many
times
again
.
 
<EOS>
In
effect
,
for
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
not
only
here
,
but
you
will
go
to
Mr
,
Snagsby
's
too
,
perhaps
?
<EOS>
That
visit
not
succeeding
either
,
you
will
go
again
perhaps
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
again
,
"
repeats
mademoiselle
,
cataleptic
with
determination
.
"
<EOS>
And
yet
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
many
times
again
.
 
<EOS>
In
effect
,
for
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Mademoiselle
Hortense
,
let
me
recommend
you
to
take
the
candle
and
pick
up
that
money
of
yours
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
you
will
find
it
behind
the
clerk
's
partition
in
the
corner
yonder
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
She
merely
throws
a
laugh
over
her
shoulder
and
stands
her
ground
with
folded
arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
will
not
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
poorer
you
;
so
much
the
richer
<EOS>
I
!
 
<EOS>
Look
,
mistress
,
this
is
the
key
of
my
wine
-
cellar
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
large
key
,
but
the
keys
of
prisons
are
larger
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
city
there
are
houses
of
correction
(
where
the
treadmills
are
,
for
women
)
,
the
gates
of
which
are
very
strong
and
heavy
,
and
no
doubt
the
keys
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
<EOS>
a
lady
of
your
spirit
and
activity
would
find
it
an
inconvenience
to
have
one
of
those
keys
turned
upon
her
for
any
length
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
mademoiselle
replies
without
any
action
and
in
a
clear
,
obliging

,
"
that
you
are
a
miserable
wretch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Probably
,
"
returns
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
quietly
blowing
his
nose
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
ask
what
you
think
of
myself
;
I
ask
what
you
think
of
the
prison
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
.
 
<EOS>
What
does
it
matter
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
it
matters
this
much
,
mistress
,
"
says
the
lawyer
,
deliberately
putting
away
his
handkerchief
and

;
"
the
law
is
so
despotic
here
that
it
interferes
to
prevent
any
of
our
good
English
citizens
from
being
troubled
,
even
by
a
lady
's
visits
against
his
desire
.
 
<EOS>
And
on
his
complaining
that
he
is
so
troubled
,
it
takes
hold
of
the
troublesome
lady
and
shuts
her
up
in
prison
under
hard
discipline
.
 
<EOS>
Turns
the
key
upon
her
,
mistress
.
<EOS>
"
Illustrating
with
the
cellar
-
key
.
   
<EOS>
"
Truly
?
"
returns
mademoiselle
in
the
same
pleasant
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
droll
!
 
<EOS>
But
---
my
faith
!
 
<EOS>
---
still
what
does
it
matter
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
fair
friend
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
"
make
another
visit
here
,
or
at
Mr
Snagsby
's
,
and
you
shall
learn
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
that
case
you
will
send
me
to
the
prison
,
perhaps
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
.
"
   
It
would
be
contradictory
for
one
in
mademoiselle
's
state
of
agreeable
jocularity
to
foam
at
the
mouth
,
otherwise
a
tigerish
expansion
thereabouts
might
look
as
if
a
very
little
more
would
make
her
do
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
a
word
,
mistress
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
"
I
am
sorry
to
be
unpolite
,
but
if
you
ever
present
yourself
uninvited
here
---
or
there
---
again
,
I
will
give
you
over
to
the
police
.
 
<EOS>
Their
gallantry
is
great
,
but
they
carry
troublesome
people
through
the
streets
in
an
ignominious
manner
,
strapped
down
on
a
board
,
my
good
wench
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
prove
you
,
"
whispers
mademoiselle
,
stretching
out
her
hand
,
"
I
will
try
if
you
dare
to
do
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
,
"
pursues
the
lawyer
without
minding
her
,
"
<EOS>
I
place
you
in
that
good
condition
of
being
locked
up
in
jail
,
it
will
be
some
time
before
you
find
yourself
at
liberty
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
prove
you
,
"
repeats
mademoiselle
in
her
former
whisper
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
proceeds
the
lawyer
,
still
without
minding
her
,
"
you
had
better
go
.
 
<EOS>
Think
twice
before
you
come
here
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Think
you
,
"
she
answers
,
"
twice
two
hundred
times
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
dismissed
by
your
lady
,
you
know
,
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
observes
,
following
her
out
upon
the
staircase
,
"
as
the
most
implacable
and
unmanageable
of
women
.
 
<EOS>
Now
turn
over
a
new
leaf
and
take
warning
by
what
I
say
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
For
what
I
say
,
I
mean
;
and
what
I
threaten
,
I
will
do
,
mistress
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
goes
down
without
answering
or
looking
behind
her
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
is
gone
,
he
goes
down
too
,
and
returning
with
his
cobweb
-
covered
bottle
,
devotes
himself
to
a
leisurely
enjoyment
of
its
contents
,
now
and
then
,
as
he
throws
his
head
back
in
his
chair
,
catching
sight
of
the
pertinacious
Roman
pointing
from
the
ceiling
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
43
.
<EOS>
Esther
's
Narrative
 
<EOS>
It
matters
little
now
how
much
I
thought
of
my
living
mother
who
had
told
me
evermore
to
consider
her
dead
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
venture
to
approach
her
or
to
communicate
with
her
in
writing
,
for
my
sense
of
the
peril
in
which
her
life
was
passed
was
only
to
be
equalled
by
my
fears
of
increasing
it
.
 
<EOS>
Knowing
that
my
mere
existence
as
a
living
creature
was
an
unforeseen
danger
in
her
way
<EOS>
,
I
could
not
always
conquer
that
terror
of
myself
which
had
seized
me
when
I
first
knew
the
secret
.
 
<EOS>
At
no
time
did
I
dare
to
utter
her
name
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
as
if
I
did
not
even
dare
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
conversation
anywhere
,
when
I
was
present
,
took
that
direction
,
as
it
sometimes
naturally
did
,
I
tried
not
to
hear
:
I
mentally
counted
,
repeated
something
that
I
knew
,
or
went
out
of
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
conscious
now
that
I
often
did
these
things
when
there
can
have
been
no
danger
of
her
being
spoken
of
,
but
I
did
them
in
the
dread
I
had
of
hearing
anything
that
might
lead
to
her
betrayal
,
and
to
her
betrayal
through
me
.
   
<EOS>
It
matters
little
now
how
often
I
recalled
the
tones
of
my
mother
's
voice
,
wondered
whether
I
should
ever
hear
it
again
as
I
so
longed
to
do
,
and
thought
how
strange
and
desolate
it
was
that
it
should
be
so
new
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
matters
little
that
I
watched
for
every
public
mention
of
my
mother
's
name
;
that
I
passed
and
repassed
the
door
of
her
house
in
town
,
loving
it
,
but
afraid
to
look
at
it
;
that
I
once
sat
in
the
theatre
when
my
mother
was
there
and
saw
me
,
and
when
we
were
so
wide
asunder
before
the
great
company
of
all
degrees
that
any
link
or
confidence
between
us
seemed
a
dream
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
all
,
all
over
.
 
<EOS>
My
lot
has
been
so
blest
that
I
can
relate
little
of
myself
which
is
not
a
story
of
goodness
and
generosity
in
others
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
well
pass
that
little
and
go
on
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
were
settled
at
home
again
,
Ada
and
I
had
many
conversations
with
my
guardian
of
which
Richard
was
the
theme
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
was
deeply
grieved
that
he
should
do
their
kind
cousin
so
much
wrong
,
but
she
was
so
faithful
to
Richard
that
she
could
not
bear
to
blame
him
even
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
My
guardian
was
assured
of
it
,
and
never
coupled
his
name
with
a
word
of
reproof
.
 
<EOS>
"
Rick
is
mistaken
,
my
dear
,
"
he
would
say
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
We
have
all
been
mistaken
over
and
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
trust
to
you
and
time
to
set
him
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
knew
afterwards
what
we
suspected
then
,
that
he
did
not
trust
to
time
until
he
had
often
tried
to
open
Richard
's
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
had
written
to
him
,
gone
to
him
,
talked
with
him
,
tried
every
gentle
and
persuasive
art
his
kindness
could
devise
.
 
<EOS>
Our
poor
devoted
Richard
was
deaf
and
blind
to
all
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
were
wrong
,
he
would
make
amends
when
the
Chancery
suit
was
over
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
were
groping
in
the
dark
,
he
could
not
do
better
than
do
his
utmost
to
clear
away
those
clouds
in
which
so
much
was
confused
and
obscured
.
 
<EOS>
Suspicion
and
misunderstanding
were
the
fault
of
the
suit
?
 
<EOS>
Then
let
him
work
the
suit
out
and
come
through
it
to
his
right
mind
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
his
unvarying
reply
.
 
<EOS>
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
had
obtained
such
possession
of
his
whole
nature
that
it
was
impossible
to
place
any
consideration
before
him
which
he
did
not
,
with
a
distorted
kind
of
reason
,
make
a
new
argument
in
favour
of
his
doing
what
he
did
.
"
<EOS>
So
that
it
is
even
more
mischievous
,
"
said
my
guardian
once
to
me
,
"
to
remonstrate
with
the
poor
dear
fellow
than
to
leave
him
alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
took
one
of
these
opportunities
of
mentioning
my
doubts
of
Mr
Skimpole
as
a
good

for
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Adviser
!
"
returned
my
guardian
,
laughing
,
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
who
would
advise
with
Skimpole
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Encourager
would
perhaps
have
been
a
better
word
,
"
said

"
Encourager
!
"
<EOS>
returned
my
guardian
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
could
be
encouraged
by
Skimpole
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
Richard
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
replied
.
 
<EOS>
"
Such
an
unworldly
,
uncalculating
,
gossamer
creature
is
a
relief
to
him
and
an
amusement
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
to
advising
or

or

anybody
or
anything
,
it
is

not

be

in
such

as
Skimpole
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
cousin
John
,
"
said

,
who
had
just

us
and
now
looked

,
"
what
made
him
such
a
child
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
made
him
such
a
child
?
"
inquired
my
guardian
,
rubbing
his
head
,
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
cousin
John
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
he
slowly

,

more
and

,
"
he
is
all
sentiment
,
and
---
and
susceptibility
,
and
---
and
sensibility
,
and
---
 
and
imagination
.
 
<EOS>
And
these
qualities
are
not
regulated
in
him
,
somehow
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
the
people
who
admired
him
for
them
in
his
youth
attached
too
much
importance
to
them
and
too
little
to
any
training
that
would
have
balanced
and
adjusted
them
,
and
so
he
became
what
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
Hey
?
"
said
my
guardian
,
stopping
short
and
looking
at

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
,
you
two
?
"
   
<EOS>
Ada
,
glancing
at
me
,
said
she
thought
it
was
a
pity
he
should
be
an

to
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
it
is
,
<EOS>
so
it
is
,
"
returned
my
guardian

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
must
not

.
 
<EOS>
We
must
arrange

.
 
<EOS>
I
must
prevent
it
.
 
<EOS>
That
will
never
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
I
said
I
thought
it
was
to
be
regretted
that
he
had
ever
introduced
Richard
to
Mr
Vholes
for

.
   
<EOS>
"
Did

?
"
said

guardian
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
there
you
have
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
There

have
the
man
!
 
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
mercenary
in
that
with

.
 
<EOS>
He
has
no

of
the
value

.
 
<EOS>
He
introduces
Rick
,
and
then
he
is
good

Mr
Vholes
and

five
pounds
of

.
 
<EOS>
He

nothing

and

.
 
<EOS>
He
told

himself
,
I
'll
be
bound
,
my

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
!
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Exactly
!
"
cried
my
guardian
,
quite

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
you
have
the
man
!
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
meant
any
harm
by
it
or
was
conscious
of
any

in
it
,
he
would
n't

.
 
<EOS>
He
tells

as
he

in

.
 
<EOS>
But
you
shall
see
him
in

,
and
then

better
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
pay
a
visit
to
Harold
Skimpole
and
caution

on
these
points
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
bless
you
,
my
dears
,
an
infant
,
an
infant
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
pursuance
of
this
plan
,
we
went
into
London
on
an
early
day
and
presented
ourselves
at
Mr
Skimpole
's
door
.
   
<EOS>
He
lived
in
a
place
called
the
Polygon
,
in
Somers
Town
,
where
there
were
at
that
time
a
number
of
poor
Spanish
refugees
walking
about
in
cloaks
,
smoking
little
paper
cigars
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
was
a
better
tenant
than
one
might
have
supposed
,
in
consequence
of
his
friend
Somebody
always
paying
his
rent
at
last
,
or
whether
his
inaptitude
for
business
rendered
it
particularly
difficult
to
turn
him
out
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
;
but
he
had
occupied
the
same
house
some
years
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
a
state
of
dilapidation
quite
equal
to
our
expectation
.
 
<EOS>
Two
or
three
of
the
area
railings
were
gone
,
the
water
-
butt
was
broken
,
the
knocker
was
loose
,
the
bell
-
handle
had
been
pulled
off
a
long
time
to
judge
from
the
rusty
state
of
the
wire
,
and
dirty
footprints
on
the
steps
were
the
only
signs
of
its
being
inhabited
.
   
<EOS>
A
slatternly
full
-
blown
girl
who
seemed
to
be
bursting
out
at
the
rents
in
her
gown
and
the
cracks
in
her
shoes
like
an
over
-
ripe
berry
answered
our
knock
by
opening
the
door
a
very
little
way
and
stopping
up
the
gap
with
her
figure
.
 
<EOS>
As
she
knew
Mr
Jarndyce
(
indeed
Ada
and
I
both
thought
that
she
evidently
associated
him
with
the
receipt
of
her
wages
)
,
she
immediately
relented
and
allowed
us
to
pass
in
.
 
<EOS>
The
lock
of
the
door
being
in
a
disabled
condition
<EOS>
,
she
then
applied
herself
to
securing
it
with
the
chain
,
which
was
not
in
good
action
either
,
and
said
would
we
go
upstairs
?
   
<EOS>
We
went
upstairs
to
the
first
floor
,
still
seeing
no
other
furniture
than
the
dirty
footprints
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
without
further
ceremony
entered
a
room
there
,
and
we
followed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
dingy
enough
and
not
at
all
clean
,
but
furnished
with
an
odd
kind
of
shabby
luxury
,
with
a
large
footstool
,
a
sofa
,
and
plenty
of
cushions
,
an
easy
-
chair
,
and
plenty
of
pillows
,
a
piano
,
books
,
drawing
materials
,
music
,
newspapers
,
and
a
few
sketches
and
pictures
.
 
<EOS>
A
broken
pane
of
glass
in
one
of
the
dirty
windows
was
papered
and
wafered
over
,
but
there
was
a
little
plate
of
hothouse
nectarines
on
the
table
,
and
there
was
another
of
grapes
,
and
another
of
sponge
-
cakes
,
and
there
was
a
bottle
of
light
wine
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
himself
reclined
upon
the
sofa
in
a
dressing
-
gown
,
drinking
some
fragrant
coffee
from
an
old
china
cup
<EOS>
---
it
was
then
about
mid
-
day
---
and
looking
at
a
collection
of
wallflowers
in
the
balcony
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
not
in
the
least
disconcerted
by
our
appearance
,
but
rose
and
received
us
in
his
usual
airy

.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
,
you
see
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
when
we
were
seated
,
not
without
some
little
difficulty
,
the
greater
part
of
the
chairs
being
broken
.
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
my
frugal
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
Some
men
want
legs
of
beef
and
mutton
for
breakfast
;
I
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
my
peach
,
my
cup
of
coffee
,
and
my
claret
;
I
am
content
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
them
for
themselves
,
but
they
remind
me
of
the
sun
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
solar
about
legs
of
beef
and
mutton
.
 
<EOS>
Mere
animal
satisfaction
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
our
friend
's
consulting
-
room
(
or
would
be
,
if
he
ever
prescribed
)
,
his
sanctum
,
his
studio
,
"
said
my
guardian
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
turning
his
bright

about
,
"
this
is
the
bird
's
cage
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
where
the
bird
lives
and
sings
.
 
<EOS>
They
pluck
his
feathers
now
and
then
and
clip
his
wings
,
but
he
sings
,
he
sings
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
handed
us
the
grapes
,
repeating
in
his

,
"
He
sings
!
<EOS>
Not
an
ambitious
note
,
but
still
he
sings
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
These
are
very
fine
,
"
said
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
present
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
!
<EOS>
Some
amiable
gardener
sells
them
.
 
<EOS>
His
man
wanted
to
know
,
when
he
brought
them
last

,
whether
he
should
wait
for

.
 
<EOS>
"
Really
,
my
friend
,
"
I
said
,
"
I
think
not
---
if
your
time
is
of
any
value
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
was
,
for
he
went
away
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
guardian
looked
at
us
with
a
smile
,
as
though
he
asked
us
,
"
Is
it
possible
to
be
worldly
with
this
baby
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
day
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
gaily
taking
a
little
claret
in

,
"
that
will
ever
be
remembered
here
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
call

Saint
Clare
and
Saint
Summerson
day
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
see
my
daughters
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
blue
-
eyed
daughter
who
is
my
Beauty
daughter
<EOS>
,
I
have
a
Sentiment

,

I

Comedy

.
 
<EOS>
You
must
see
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
be
enchanted
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
going
to
summon

when
my
guardian
interposed
and

to
pause
a

,
as

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

Jarndyce
,
"
he

,
going
back

sofa
,
"
as
many

as
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
Time
is
no
object
here
.
 
<EOS>
We
never
know
what
o'clock
it
is
,
and
we
never
care
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
way
to
get
on
in
life
,
you
'll
tell
me
?
 
<EOS>
Certainly
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
DON'T
get
on
in
life
.
<EOS>
We
do
n't
pretend
to
do
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
My
guardian
looked
at
us
again
,
plainly
saying
,
"
You
hear
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Harold
,
"
he
began
,
"
the
word
I
have
to
say
relates
to
Rick
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
dearest
friend
I
have
!
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
cordially
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
he
ought
not
to
be
my
dearest
friend
,
as
he
is
not
on
terms
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
is
,
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
help
it
;
he
is
full
of
youthful
poetry
,
and
I
love
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
like
it
,
I
ca
n't
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
love
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
engaging
frankness
with
which
he
made
this
declaration
really
had
a
disinterested
appearance
and
captivated
my
guardian
,
if
not
,
for
the
moment
,
Ada
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
welcome
to
love
him
as
much
as
you
like
,
"
returned
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
but
we
must
save
his
pocket
,
Harold
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
His
pocket
?
 
<EOS>
Now
you
are
coming
to
what
I
do
n't
understand
.
"
 
<EOS>
Taking
a
little
more
claret
and
dipping
one
of
the
cakes
in
it
,
he
shook
his
head
and
smiled
at
Ada
and
me
with
an
ingenuous
foreboding
that
he
never
could
be
made
to
understand
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
go
with
him
here
or
there
,
"
said
my
guardian
plainly
,
"
you
must
not
let
him
pay
for
both
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Jarndyce
,
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
,
his
genial
face
irradiated
by
the
comicality
of
this
idea
,
"
what
am
I
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
takes
me
anywhere
,
I
must
go
.
 
<EOS>
And
how
can
I
pay
?
 
<EOS>
I
never
have
any
money
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
any
money
,
I
do
n't
know
anything
about
it
.
<EOS>
Suppose
I
say
to
a
man
,
how
much
?
 
<EOS>
Suppose
the
man
says
to
me
seven
and
sixpence
?
 
<EOS>
I
know
nothing
about
seven
and
sixpence
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
for
me
to
pursue
the
subject
with
any
consideration
for
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
go
about
asking
busy
people
what
seven
and
sixpence
is
in
Moorish
---
which
I
do
n't
understand
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
I
go
about
asking
them
what
seven
and
sixpence
is
in
Money
---
which
I
do
n't
understand
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
by
no
means
displeased
with
this
artless
reply
,
"
if
you
come
to
any
kind
of
journeying
with
Rick
,
you
must
borrow
the
money
of
me
(
never
breathing
the
least
allusion
to
that
circumstance
)
,
and
leave
the
calculation
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Jarndyce
,
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
I
will
do
anything
to
give
you
pleasure
,
but
it
seems
an
idle
form
---
a
superstition
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
give
you
my
word
,
Miss
Clare
and
my
dear
Miss
Summerson
<EOS>
,
I
thought
Mr
Carstone
was
immensely
rich
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
he
had
only
to
make
over
something
,
or
to
sign
a
bond
,
or
a
draft
,
or
a

,
or
a
bill
,
or
to
put
something
on
a

somewhere
,
to
bring
down

shower
of
money
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
it
is
not
so
,
sir
,
"
said
Ada
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
poor
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
really
?
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
with
his
bright
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
surprise
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
not
being
the
richer
for
trusting
in
a
rotten
reed
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
laying
his
hand
emphatically
on
the
sleeve
of
Mr
Skimpole
's
dressing
-
gown
,
"
be
you
very
careful
not
to
encourage
him
in
that
reliance
,
Harold
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
good
friend
,
"
returned
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
and
my
dear
Miss
Siunmerson
,
and
my
dear
Miss
Clare
,
how
can
I
do
that
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
business
,
and
I
do
n't
know
business
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
he
who
encourages
me
.
<EOS>
He
emerges
from
great
feats
of
business
,
presents
the
brightest
prospects
before
me
as
their
result
,
and
calls
upon
me
to
admire
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
admire
them
---
as
bright
prospects
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
know
no
more
about
them
,
and
I
tell
him
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
helpless
kind
of
candour
with
which
he
presented
this
before
us
,
the
light
-
hearted
manner
in
which
he
was
amused
by
his
innocence
,
the
fantastic
way
in
which
he
took
himself
under
his
own
protection
and
argued
about
that
curious
person
,
combined
with
the
delightful
ease
of
everything
he
said
exactly
to
make
out
my
guardian
's
case
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
I
saw
of
him
,
the
more
unlikely
it
seemed
to
me
,
when
he
was
present
,
that
he
could
design
,
conceal
,
or
influence
anything
;
and
yet
the
less
likely
that
appeared
when
he
was
not
present
,
and
the
less
agreeable
<EOS>
it
was
to
think
of
his
having
anything
to
do
with
any
one
for
whom
I
cared
.
   
<EOS>
Hearing
that
his
examination
(
as
he
called
it
)
was
now
over
,
Mr
Skimpole
left
the
room
with
a
radiant
face
to
fetch
his
daughters
(
his
sons
had
run
away
at
various
times
)
,
leaving
my
guardian
quite
delighted
by
the
manner
in
which
he
had
vindicated
his
childish
character
.
 
<EOS>
He
soon
came
back
,
bringing
with
him
the
three
young
ladies
and
Mrs
Skimpole
,
who
had
once
been
a
beauty
but
was
now
a
delicate
high
-
nosed
invalid
suffering
under
a
complication
of
disorders
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
is
my
Beauty
daughter
,
Arethusa
---
plays
and
sings
odds
and
ends
like
her
father
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
my
Sentiment
daughter
,
Laura
<EOS>
---
plays
a
little
but
do
n't
sing
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
my
Comedy
daughter
,
Kitty
---
sings
a
little
but
do
n't
play
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
draw
a
little
and
compose
a
little
,
and
none
of
us
have
any
idea
of
time
or
money
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Skimpole
sighed
,
I
thought
,
as
if
she
would
have
been
glad
to
strike
out
this
item
in
the
family
attainments
.
 
<EOS>
I
also
thought
that
she
rather
impressed
her
sigh
upon
my
guardian
and
that
she
took
every
opportunity
of
throwing
in
another
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
pleasant
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
turning
his
sprightly
eyes
from
one
to
the
other
of
us
,
"
and
it
is
whimsically
interesting
to
trace
peculiarities
in
families
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
family
we
are
all
children
,
and
I
am
the
youngest
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
daughters
,
who
appeared
to
be
very
fond
of
him
,
were
amused
by
this
droll
fact
,
particularly
the
Comedy
daughter
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dears
,
it
is
true
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
is
it
not
?
 
<EOS>
So
it
is
,
and
so
it
must
be
,
because
like
the
dogs
in
the
hymn
,
"
it
is
our
nature
to
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Now
,
here
is
Miss
Summerson
with
a
fine
administrative
capacity
and
a
knowledge
of
details
perfectly
surprising
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
sound
very
strange
in
Miss
Summerson
's
ears
,
I
dare
say
,
that
we
know
nothing
about
chops
in
this
house
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
do
n't
,
not
the
least
.
 
<EOS>
We
ca
n't
cook
anything
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
A
needle
and
thread
<EOS>
we
do
n't
know
how
to
use
.
 
<EOS>
We
admire
the
people
who
possess
the
practical
wisdom
we
want
,
but
we
do
n't
quarrel
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
Then
why
should
they
quarrel
with
us
?
 
<EOS>
Live
and
let
live
<EOS>
,
we
say
to
them
.
<EOS>
Live
upon
your
practical
wisdom
,
and
let
us
live
upon
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
laughed
,
but
as
usual
seemed
quite
candid
and
really
to
mean
what
he
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
sympathy
,
my
roses
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
sympathy
for
everything
.
 
<EOS>
Have
we
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
papa
!
"
cried
the
three
daughters
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
fact
,
that
is
our
family
department
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
in
this
hurly
-
burly
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
capable
of
looking
on
and
of
being
interested
,
and
we
DO
look
on
,
and
we
ARE
interested
.
 
<EOS>
What
more
can
we
do
?
 
<EOS>
Here
is
my
Beauty
daughter
,
married
these
three
years
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
dare
say
her
marrying
another
child
,
and
having
two
more
,
was
all
wrong
in
point
of
political
economy
,
but
it
was
very
agreeable
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
our
little
festivities
on
those
occasions
and
exchanged
social
ideas
.
 
<EOS>
She
brought
her
young
husband
home
one
day
,
and
they
and
their
young
fledglings
have
their
nest
upstairs
.
<EOS>
I
dare
say
at
some
time
or
other
Sentiment
and
Comedy
will
bring
THEIR
husbands
home
and
have
THEIR
nests
upstairs
too
.
 
<EOS>
So
we
get
on
<EOS>
,
we
do
n't
know
how
,
but
somehow
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
looked
very
young
indeed
to
be
the
mother
of
two
children
,
and
I
could
not
help
pitying
both
her
and
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
evident
that
the
three
daughters
had
grown
up
as
they
could
and
had
had
just
as
little
haphazard
instruction
as
qualified
them
to
be
their
father
's
playthings
in
his
idlest
hours
.
 
<EOS>
His
pictorial
tastes
were
consulted
,
I
observed
,
in
their
respective
styles
of
wearing
their
hair
,
the
Beauty
daughter
being
in
the
classic
manner
,
the
Sentiment
daughter
luxuriant
and

,
and
the
Comedy
daughter
in
the
arch
style
,
with
a
good
deal
of
sprightly
forehead
,
and
vivacious
little
curls
dotted
about
the

of
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
dressed
to
correspond
,
though
in
a
most
untidy
and
negligent
way
.
   
<EOS>
Ada
and
I
conversed
with
these
young
ladies
and
found
them
wonderfully
like
their
father
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meanwhile
Mr
Jarndyce
(
who
had
been
rubbing
his
head
to
a
great
extent
,
and
hinted
at
a
change
in
the
wind
)
talked
with
Mrs
Skimpole
in
a
corner
,
where
we
could
not
help
hearing
the
chink
of
money
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
had
previously
volunteered
to
go
home
with
us
and
had
withdrawn
to
dress
himself
for
the
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
roses
,
"
he
said
when
he
came
back
,
"
take
care
of
mama
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
poorly
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
By
going
home
with
Mr
Jarndyce
for
a
day
or
two
,
I
shall
hear
the
larks
sing
and
preserve
my
amiability
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
tried
,
you
know
,
and
would
be
tried
again
if
I
remained
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
bad
man
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Comedy
daughter
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
the
very
time
when
he
knew
papa
was
lying
ill
by
his
wallflowers
,
looking
at
the
blue
sky
,
"
Laura
complained
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
the
smell
of
hay
was
in
the
air
!
"
said
Arethusa
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
showed
a
want
of
poetry
in
the
man
,
"
Mr
Skimpole
assented
,
but
with
perfect
good
humour
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
coarse
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
absence
of
the
finer
touches
of
humanity
in
it
!
 
<EOS>
My
daughters
have
taken
great
offence
,
"
he
explained
to
us
,
"
at
an
honest
man
---
"
   
"
Not
honest
,
papa
.
 
<EOS>
Impossible
!
<EOS>
"
they
all
three
protested
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
a
rough
kind
of
fellow
---
a
sort
of
human
hedgehog
rolled
up
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
who
is
a
baker
in
this
neighbourhood
and
from
whom
we
borrowed
a
couple
of
armchairs
.
 
<EOS>
We
wanted
a
couple
of
arm
-
chairs
,
and
we
had
n't
got
them
,
and
therefore
of
course
we
looked
to
a
man
who
HAD
got
them
,
to
lend
them
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
This
morose
person
lent
them
,
and
we
wore
them
out
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
were
worn
out
,
he
wanted
them
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
them
back
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
contented
,
you
will
say
.
 
<EOS>
Not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
objected
to
their
being
worn
.
 
<EOS>
I
reasoned
with
him
,
and
pointed
out
his
mistake
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
Can
you
,
at
your
time
of
life
,
be
so
headstrong
,
my
friend
,
as
to
persist
that
an
arm
-
chair
is
a
thing
to
put
upon
a
shelf
and
look
at
?
 
<EOS>
That
it
is
an
object
to
contemplate
,
to
survey
from
a
distance
,
to
consider
from
a
point
of
sight
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
KNOW
that
these
arm
-
chairs
were
borrowed
to
be
sat
upon
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
was
unreasonable
and
unpersuadable
and
used
intemperate
language
.
 
<EOS>
Being
as
patient
as
I
am
at
this
minute
,
I
addressed
another
appeal
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
,
"
Now
,
my
good
man
,
however
our
business
capacities
may
vary
,
we
are
all
children
of
one
great
mother
,
Nature
.
 
<EOS>
On
this
blooming
summer
morning
here
you
see
me
"
(
I
was
on
the
sofa
)
"
with
flowers
before
me
,
fruit
upon
the
table
,
the
cloudless
sky
above
me
,
the
air
full
of
fragrance
,
contemplating
Nature
.
 
<EOS>
I
entreat
you
,
by
our
common
brotherhood
,
not
to
interpose
between
me
and
a
subject
<EOS>
so
sublime
,
the
absurd
figure
of
an
angry
baker
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
he
did
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
raising
his
laughing
eyes
in
playful
astonishinent
;
"
he
did
interpose
that
ridiculous
figure
,
and
he
does
,
and
he
will
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
therefore
I
am
very
glad
to
get
out
of
his
way
and
to
go
home
with
my
friend
Jarndyce
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
escape
his
consideration
that
Mrs
Skimpole
and
the
daughters
remained
behind
to
encounter
the
baker
,
but
this
was
so
old
a
story
to
all
of
them
that
it
had
become
a
matter
of
course
.
<EOS>
He
took
leave
of
his
family
with
a
tenderness
as
airy
and
graceful
as
any
other
aspect
in
which
he
showed
himself
and
rode
away
with
us
in
perfect
harmony
of
mind
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
an
opportunity
of
seeing
through
some
open
doors
,
as
we
went
downstairs
,
that
his
own
apartment
was
a
palace
to
the
rest
of
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
I
could
have
no
anticipation
,
and
I
had
none
,
that
something
very
startling
to
me
at
the
moment
,
and
ever
memorable
to
me
in
what
ensued
from
it
,
was
to
happen
before
this
day
was
out
.
 
<EOS>
Our
guest
was
in
such
spirits
on
the
way
home
that
I
could
do
nothing
but
listen
to
him
and
wonder
at
him
;
nor
was
I
alone
in
this
,
for
Ada
yielded
to
the
same
fascination
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
my
guardian
,
the
wind
,
which
had
threatened
to
become
fixed
in
the
east
when
we
left
Somers
Town
,
veered
completely
round
before
we
were
a
couple
of
miles
from
it
.
   
<EOS>
Whether
of
questionable
childishness
or
not
in
any
other
matters
,
Mr
Skimpole
had
a
child
's
enjoyment
of
change
and
bright
weather
.
<EOS>
In
no
way
wearied
by
his
sallies
on
the
road
,
he
was
in
the
drawing
-
room
before
any
of
us
;
and
I
heard
him
at
the
piano
while
I
was
yet
looking
after
my
housekeeping
,
singing
refrains
of
barcaroles
and
drinking
songs
,
Italian
and
German
,
by
the
score
.
   
<EOS>
We
were
all
assembled
shortly
before
dinner
,
and
he
was
still
at
the
piano
idly
picking
out
in
his
luxurious
way
little
strains
of
music
,
and
talking
between
whiles
of
finishing
some
sketches
of
the
ruined
old
Verulam
wall
to
-
morrow
,
which
he
had
begun
a
year
or
two
ago
and
had
got
tired
of
,
when
a
card
was
brought
in
and
my
guardian
read
aloud
in
a
surprised
voice
,
"
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
visitor
was
in
the
room
while
it
was
yet
turning
round
with
me
and
before
I
had
the
power
to
stir
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
had
it
,
I
should
have
hurried
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
even
the
presence
of
mind
,
in
my
giddiness
,
to
retire
to
Ada
in
the
window
,
or
to
see
the
window
,
or
to
know
where
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
my
name
and
found
that
my
guardian
was
presenting
me
before
I
could
move
to
a
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
be
seated
,
Sir
Leicester
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
said
Sir
Leicester
in

as
he
bowed
and

,
"
I
do
myself
the
honour
of
calling
here
---
"
   
"
You
do
ME
the
honour
,
Sir
Leicester
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
---
of
calling
here
on
my
road
from
Lincolnshire
to
express
my
regret
that
any
cause
of
complaint
,
however
strong
,
that
I
may
have
against
a
gentleman
<EOS>
who
---
who
is
known

and
has

host
,
and
to

therefore
I
will

,

,

there

to

at
my

,
Chesney

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
Sir
Leicester
,
and
on

of
those
ladies
(
who

present
)
and

I
thank

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
possible
,
Mr
Jarndyce
,
that
the
gentleman
to

,
for
the

I
have
mentioned
,
I
refrain
from
making
further

---
 
it
is
possible
,
Mr
Jarndyce
,
that
that
gentleman
may
have
done
me
the
honour
so
far
to
misapprehend
my
character
as
to

that

not

,

its

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,
that
the

the
reverse
.
"
   
<EOS>
My

delicately

without

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
has
given
me
pain
,
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
Sir
Leicester
weightily

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
assure

,
sir
,
it
has
given
---
me
---
pain
---
to

from
the
housekeeper
at
Chesney
Wold
that
a

who
was
in
your
company
in
that

the

,
and
who
would

,

,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Here

read
,
with

,
through

,
"
Mr
Hirrold
---
Herald
---
 
Harold
---
Skampling
---
Skumpling
---
I

---
Skimpole
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This

Mr
Harold
Skimpole
,
"
said

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
exclaimed

Leicester
,
"
I

happy

and
to

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
So

,
I
shall

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
"
said

with

"

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
"
   
<EOS>
Sir

seemed

.
 
<EOS>
"
An

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
A

.
 
<EOS>
A
mere

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
seemed
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
hoped

have

be

when

next

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

professed
himself
much

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Skimpole
mentioned
,
"

,

"

,

,

,

"
   
(
"

,

)

.
"
 
<EOS>
Sir

to

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

,

,

)
<EOS>

,
<EOS>
does
,
I

,

---

---
pain
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
say

,
Sir
Leicester
,
"
returned
my

.
<EOS>
"
I
am
very

,
as
I

sure

all

,
of

.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
the
mistake
was
mine
,
and
I
ought
to
apologize
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
once
looked
up
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
seen
the
visitor
and
had
not
even

to

to

the

.
 
<EOS>
It
surprises
me
to
find
that
I
can
recall
it
,
<EOS>
for
it
seemed
to
make
no

on

as

.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
them
speaking
,
but
my
mind
was
so
confused
and
<EOS>
my
instinctive
avoidance
of
this
gentleman
made
his

so
distressing
to
me
that
I
thought
I
understood
nothing
,
through
the

in

and

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
mentioned
the
subject
to
Lady
Dedlock
,
"
said

Leicester
,
rising
,
"
and
my
Lady
informed

that

Mr

and

on

in

.
 
<EOS>
Permit

,
Mr
Jarndyce
,
to

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Circumstances
undoubtedly
prevent
my

that
it

to

that
Mr
Boythorn
had

,
but

are

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
my
old
opinion
of
him
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
lightly

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
An
amiable
bull
who
is
detenined
to
make
every
colour
scarlet
!
"
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
coughed
as
if
he
could
not
possibly
hear
another
word
in
reference
to
such
an
individual
and
took
his

with
great

and

.
 
<EOS>
I
got
to
my
own
room
with
all

speed
and
remained
there
until
I
had
recovered
my
self
-
command
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
been
very
much
disturbed
,
but
I
was
thankful
to
find
when
I
went
downstairs
again
that
they
only
rallied
me
for
having
been
shy
and
mute
before
the
great
Lincolnshire
baronet
.
   
<EOS>
By
that
time
I
had
made
up
my
mind
that
the
period
was
come
when
I
must
tell
my
guardian
what
I
knew
.
 
<EOS>
The
possibility
of
my
being
brought
into
contact
with
my
mother
,
of
my
being
taken
to
her
house
,
even
of
Mr
Skimpole
's
,
however

associated

me
,
receiving

and

from
her
husband
,
was
so
painful
that
I
felt
I
could
no

without

.
   
<EOS>
When

had

for
the

,
and
Ada
and
I
had
had
our
usual
talk
in
our
pretty
room
<EOS>
,
I
went
out
at
my
door
again
and
sought
my
guardian
among
his
books
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
he
always
read
at
that
hour
,
and
as
I
drew
near
I
saw
the
light
shining
out
into
the
passage
from

.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
come
in
,
guardian
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
little
woman
.
 
<EOS>
What
's

matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
is
the

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
would
like

take
this
quiet
time
of
saying

about

.
"
   
<EOS>
He
put
a

for

,
shut
his

,
and
put
it
by
,
and
turned
his
kind
attentive

towards

.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
observing
that
it
wore
that
curious

I
had
observed
in
it
once
before
---
on
that
night
when
he
had
said
that
he
was
in
no
trouble
which
I
could
readily

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
concerns
you
,
my

Esther
,
"
said

,
"
concerns
us
all
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
be
more
ready
to
speak
than
I
am
to

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
,
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
such
need

your

and

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
how
much
need
I
have
to
-
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
unprepared
for
my
being
so
earnest
,
and
even
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Or
how
anxious
I
have

to

,
"
said

,
"
ever
since

visitor
was
here

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
visitor
,
my

!
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
folded

and
sat

with
an

the

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Esther
,
"
said

,

,
"
our
visitor
and
you
are
the
two

on
earth
I

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
guardian
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
And
I
too
,
but
a
little

ago
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The

passed
from
his
face
,
and

became

.
<EOS>
He
crossed
to
the
door
to
see
that

was
shut
(
but
I
had
seen

)

.
   
<EOS>
"
Guardian
,
"
said

,
"
do

remensher
,

-

,
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
's
speaking

you
of
her

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of

.
 
<EOS>
Of

I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
reminding

that
she

her

had
differed
,
had

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
.
"
   
"
Why
did
they
separate
,
guardian
?
"
   
<EOS>
His
face
quite

as
he
looked
at

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
child
,
what
questions
are
these
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
knew
.
 
<EOS>
No

themselves
ever

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
Who
could

the

those

!
 
<EOS>
You
have
seen
Lady
Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
If

had
ever
seen
her
sister
,
you
would
know

to
have
been
as
resolute

she
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
guardian
,
I
have
seen
her
many
and
many

time
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Seen
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
paused
a
little
,
biting

.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Esther
,
when
you
spoke

me
long

of
Boythorn
,
and

,

,

,

---

you
know

,
and

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
guardian
,
"
I
returned
,
fearful

light
that
dimly
broke
upon

.
 
<EOS>
"
Nor
do
I
know
yet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lady
Dedlock
's
sister
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
why
,
"
I

,
"
why
,
guardian
,
pray

THEY

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

her

,
and
she

its

in

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>
Nor

<EOS>
"

"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
No

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
44
.
<EOS>
The
Letter

<EOS>
My

what

.
 
<EOS>
There

to

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
One

<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>
Ha

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Be

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
Charley

,

,
and

---
the
zig

old
-
fashioned
house
seemed

in

,
along

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
So
Charley

it
on
the

and
went
to

,
and
I
sat
looking
at
it
without

,
thinking

many
things
.
   
<EOS>
I
began
with
my
overshadowed
childhood
,
and
passed
through
those
timid
days
to
the
heavy
time
when
my
aunt
lay
dead
,
with
her
resolute

so
cold
and
set
,
and
when
I
was
more
solitary
with
Mrs
Rachael
than
if
I
had
had
no
one
in
the
world
to
speak

or

.
 
<EOS>
I
passed
to
the
altered
days
when
I
was
so
blest
as
to
find
friends
in
all
around
me
,
and
to
be
beloved
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
to
the
time
when
I
first
saw
my
dear
girl
and
was
received
into
that
sisterly
affection
which
was
the

and

of
my
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
recalled
the
first
bright

of
welcome
which
had
shone
out
of
those
very
windows
upon
our
expectant
faces
on
that
cold

,
and
which
had
never
paled
.
 
<EOS>
I
lived
my
happy
life
there
over
again
<EOS>
,
I
went
through
my
illness
and
recovery
,
I
thought
of
myself
<EOS>
so
altered
and
of
those
around
me
so
unchanged
;
and
all
this
happiness
shone
like
a
light
from
one
central
figure
,
represented
before
me
by
the
letter
on

.
   
<EOS>
I
opened
it
and
read
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
so
impressive
in
its
love
for
me
,
and
in
the
unselfish
caution
it
gave
me
,
and
the
consideration
it
showed
for
me
in
every
word
,
that
my
eyes
were
too
often
blinded
to
read
much
at
a
time
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
read
it
through
three
times
before
I
laid
it
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
thought
beforehand
that
I
knew
its
purport
,
and
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
It
asked
me
,
would
I
be
the
mistress
of
Bleak
House
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
love
letter
,
though
it
expressed
so
much
love
,
but
was
written
just
as
he
would
at
any
time
have
spoken
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
his
face
,
and
heard
his
voice
,
and
felt
the
influence
of
his
kind
protecting
manner
in
every
line
.
 
<EOS>
It
addressed
me
as
if
our
places
were
reversed
,
as
if
all
the
good
deeds
had
been
mine
and
all
the
feelings
they
had
awakened
his
.
 
<EOS>
It
dwelt
on
my
being
young
,
and
he
past
the
prime
of
life
;
on
his
having
attained
a
ripe
age
,
while
I
was
a
child
;
on
his
writing
to
me
with
a
silvered
head
,
and
knowing
all
this
so
well
as
to
set
it
in
full
before
me
for
mature
deliberation
.
 
<EOS>
It
told
me
that
I
would
gain
nothing
by
such
a
marriage
and
lose
nothing
by
rejecting
it
,
for
no
new
relation
could
enhance
the
tenderness
in
which
he
held
me
,
and
whatever
my
decision
was
,
he
was
certain
it
would
be
right
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
considered
this
step
anew
since
our
late
confidence
and
had
decided
on
taking
it
,
if
it
only
served
to
show
me
through
one
poor
instance
that
the
whole
world
would
readily
unite
to
falsify
the
stern
prediction
of
my
childhood
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
the
last
to
know
what
happiness
I
could
bestow
upon
him
,
but
of
that
he
said
no
more
,
for
I
was
always
to
remember
that
I
owed
him
nothing
and
that
he
was
my
debtor
,
and
for
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
often
thought
of
our
future
,
and
foreseeing
that
the
time
must
come
,
and
fearing
that
it
might
come
soon
,
when
Ada
(
now
very
nearly
of
age
)
would
leave
us
,
and
when
our
present
mode
of
life
must
be
broken
up
,
had
become
accustomed
to
reflect
on
this
proposal
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
he
made
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
felt
that
I
could
ever
give
him
the
best
right
he
could
have
to
be
my
protector
,
and
if
I
felt
that
I
could
happily
and
justly
become
the
dear
companion
of
his
remaining
life
,
superior
to
all
lighter
chances
and
changes
than
death
,
even
then
he
could
not
have
me
bind
myself
irrevocably
while
this
letter
was
yet
so
new
to
me
,
but
even
then
I
must
have
ample
time
for
reconsideration
.
 
<EOS>
In
that
case
,
or
in
the
opposite
case
,
let
him
be
unchanged
in
his
old
relation
,
in
his
old
manner
,
in
the
old
name
by
which
I
called
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
to
his
bright
Dame
Durden
and
little
housekeeper
,
she
would
ever
be
the
same
,
he
knew
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
substance
of
the
letter
,
written
throughout
with
a
justice
and
a
dignity
as
if
he
were
indeed
my
responsible
guardian
impartially
representing
the
proposal
of
a
friend
against
whom
in
his
integrity
he
stated
the
full
case
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
hint

me
that
when
I
had
been
better
looking
he
had
had
this
same
proceeding
in

and
had

it
.
 
<EOS>
That
when
my
old
face
was
gone
from
me
,
and
I
had
no
attractions
,
he
could
love
me
just
as
well
as
in
my
fairer

.
<EOS>
That
the
discovery

my
birth

him
no

.
 
<EOS>
That
his
generosity
rose
above
my
disfigurement
and
my

of

.
<EOS>
That
the
more
I
stood
in
need
of
such
fidelity
,
the
more
firmly
I
might
trust
in
him
to

last
.
   
<EOS>
But
I
knew
it
<EOS>
,
I
knew
it
well
now
.
 
<EOS>
It
came
upon
me
as
the
close
of
the
benignant
history
I
had
been
pursuing
,
and
I
felt
that
I
had
but
one

.
 
<EOS>
To
devote
my
life
to
his
happiness
was
to
thank
him
poorly
,
and
what
had
I
wished
for
the
other
night
but
some
new

thanking

?
   
<EOS>
Still
I
cried

,
not

in
the

my
heart

letter
,
not

prospect
---
 
for

expected

---
but
as
if
something
for

there
was
no
name

were
indefinitely

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
happy
,
<EOS>
very

,
very

;
but
I
cried
very
much
.
   
<EOS>
By
and
by
<EOS>
I
went
to
my
old
glass
.
 
<EOS>
My

were
red
and

,
and
I
said
,
"
Oh
,
Esther
,
Esther
,

!
"
 
<EOS>
I

the
face
in
the
glass

,
but
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
That

you

,
<EOS>
my
dear
,
when
you

!
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
When

House
,

.
 
<EOS>
In

;

.
"
   
<EOS>
I
went
on
with
my
hair
now
,
quite

.
 
<EOS>
I
sobbed
a

,
but
that
was
because
I
had
been

,
<EOS>
not

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
Esther
,
my
dear
,
you
are
happy

.
 
<EOS>
Happy

your
best

,
happy

,

,
and

the

the
best

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
,
all

,

my
guardian
had
married

,
how
should
I

,
and
what

!
 
<EOS>
That

have
been
a

.
 
<EOS>
It
presented
my
life
in
such
a

that
I
rang

housekeeping

and
gave

a

.
   
<EOS>
Then
I
went
on
to
think
,
as
I
dressed
my
hair
before
the
glass
<EOS>
,

,

,

---

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

,
to

,
to

!
 
<EOS>
As

(

one

House
<EOS>
,
why

?
 
<EOS>
Other

thought

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

,

plain

,
"

,
"
what
Mrs
Woodcourt

about
your

---
"
   
Perhaps
the
name

them
to

.
 
<EOS>
The
dried

of
the
flowers
.
 
<EOS>
It
would

better

keep

now
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
only

in
memory
of
something

,
but
it
would

.
   
<EOS>
They
were
in

,
and
it

next

---
<EOS>
our

-
room
,
dividing
Ada
's

.
 
<EOS>
I
took

and

.
 
<EOS>
After

,
I
saw

,
through

,
lying

,

.
   
<EOS>
It

weak

me
,
I

,
and
I

;
but
I

dear

,
and

,
and

.
<EOS>
Weaker

that
,
I
took

for

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought

Richard
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Then

at

,
and
they
were
dust
in

.
   
<EOS>
On

room

,
I

my
guardian
just

,
quite

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

(

.
 
<EOS>
I

several

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
So

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
and
he

.
   
<EOS>
At

,
Mr

?
"

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

,

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
45
.
<EOS>
In
Trust
 
<EOS>
One
morning
when
I
had
done
jingling
about

my

,

my

I

Mr
Vholes
.
 
<EOS>
Ada
had
been

might

in
the

;
and

not

's

.
   
<EOS>
Presently

,
lightly

,
as

"

!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
one

Charley
's
peculiarities
<EOS>
that
whenever

always

as

,

.
<EOS>
Therefore

"

"

Mr

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
she
had

so
often
that
she
was
out

.
   
<EOS>
I
told
Ada
I
would
make

and
inquired

Charley
as

in
whether

.
 
<EOS>
To

,
whose
grammar
<EOS>
,
I

,
never

,

,
"
Yes
,

.
 
<EOS>
Him
as

Mr
Richard
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
A
more

my

and
Mr
Vholes

I

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

the

,

I

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
Mr
Vholes
,

dear
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Not

the

urbanity
,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes

,

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Not

Richard

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Vholes
,
"

guardian
,

his
black

,
"
has

an
ugly

Rick
.
"
 
<EOS>
Laying

"
as
if

rather

connexion
with
Mr
Vholes
.
   
<EOS>
I
sat
down
between
them
;
Mr
Vholes
remained
immovable
,
except
that
he
secretly
picked
at
one
of
the
red
pimples
on
his
yellow
face
with
his
black
glove
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
as
Rick
and
you
are
happily
good
friends
<EOS>
,
I
should
like
to
know
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
"
<EOS>
what
you
think
,
my
dear
.
 
<EOS>
Would
you
be
so
good
as
to
---
as
to
speak
up
,
Mr
Vholes
?
"
   
<EOS>
Doing
anything
<EOS>
but
that
,
Mr
Vholes
observed
,
"
I
have
been
saying
that
I
have
reason
to
know
,
Miss
Summerson
,
as
Mr
C
's
professional
adviser
,
that
Mr
C
's
circumstances
are
at
the
present
moment
in
an
embarrassed
state
.
 
<EOS>
Not
so
much
in
point
of
amount
as
owing
to
the
peculiar
and
pressing
nature
of
liabilities
<EOS>
Mr
C
has
incurred
and
the
means
he
has
of
liquidating
or
meeting
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
staved
off
many
little
matters
for
Mr
C
,
but
there
is
a
limit
to
staving
off
,
and
we
have
reached
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
some
advances
out
of
pocket
to
accommodate
these
unpleasantnesses
,
but
I
necessarily
look
to
being
repaid
,
for
I
do
not
pretend
to
be
a
man
of
capital
,
and
I
have
a
father
to
support
in
the
Vale
of
Taunton
,
besides
striving
to
realize
some
little
independence
for
three
dear
girls
at

.
 
<EOS>
My
apprehension
is
,
Mr
C
's
circumstances
being
such
,
lest
it
should
end
in
his
obtaining
leave
to
part
with
his
commission
,
which
at
all
events
is
desirable
to
be
made
known
to
his
connexions
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes
,
who
had
looked
at
me
while
speaking
,
here
emerged
into
the
silence
he
could
hardly
be
said
to
have
broken
,
so
stifled
was
his
tone
,
and
looked
before
him
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Imagine
the
poor
fellow
without
even
his
present
resource
,
"
said
my
guardian
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yet
what
can
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
You
know
him
,
Esther
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
never
accept
of
help
from
me
now
.
 
<EOS>
To
offer
it
or
hint
at
it
would
be
to
drive
him
to
an
extremity
,
if
nothing
else
did
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes
hereupon
addressed
me
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
Mr
Jarndyce
remarks
,
miss
,
is
no
doubt
the
case
,
and
is
the
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
see
that
anything
is
to
be
done
,
I
do
not
say
that
anything
is
to
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
Far
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
merely
come
down
here
under
the
seal
of
confidence
and
mention
it
in
order
that
everything
may
be
openly
carried
on
and
that
it
may
not
be
said
afterwards
that
everything
was
not
openly
carried
on
.
 
<EOS>
My
wish
is
that
everything
should
be
openly
carried
on
.
 
<EOS>
I
desire
to
leave
a
good
name
behind
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
consulted
merely
my
own
interests
with
Mr
C
,
I
should
not

here
.
 
<EOS>
So
insurmountable
,
as
you
must
well
know
,
would
be
his

.
 
<EOS>
This
is
not
a
professional
attendance
.
 
<EOS>
This
can
he
charged
to
nobody
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
interest
in
it
except
as
a
member
of
society
and
a
father
---
AND
a
son
,
"
said
Mr
Vholes
,
who
had
nearly

.
   
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
us
that
Mr
Vholes
said
neither
more
nor
less
than
the
truth
in
intimating
that
he
sought
to

the

,
such

,
of

Richard
's

.
 
<EOS>
I
could
only

I
should
go
down
to
Deal
,
where
Richard
was
then
stationed
,
and
see

,
and

if

.
 
<EOS>
Without

Mr
Vholes
on
this

,
I
took
my
guardian
aside
to
propose
it
,
while
Mr
Vholes
gauntly
stalked
to
the
fire
and
warmed
his
funeral
gloves
.
   
<EOS>
The
fatigue
of
the
journey
formed
an
immediate
objection
on
my
guardian
's
part
,
but
as
I
saw
he
had
no
other
,
and
as
I
was
only
too

go
,
I
got
his

.
 
<EOS>
We
had
then
merely
to
dispose
of
Mr
Vholes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
Miss
Summerson
will
communicate
with
Mr
Carstone
,
and
you
can
only
hope
that
his
position
may
be
yet

.
 
<EOS>
You
will
allow
me
to
order

after

,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
,
Mr
Jarndyce
,
"
said
Mr
Vholes
,
putting
out

long
black

to

bell
,
"
not
any
.
 
<EOS>
I
thank
you
,
no
,
not
a

.
 
<EOS>
My
digestion
is
much
impaired
,
and
I
am
but
a
poor
knife
and
fork
at
any
time
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
was
to
partake

solid

at
this

of

,
I
do
n't

what
the

.
 
<EOS>
Everything
having
been
openly
carried
on
,
<EOS>
sir
,
I

now

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
would
that

could
take

,
and
we

all

,
Mr
Vholes
,
"
<EOS>
returned

guardian

,
"
of
a

know

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes
,
whose
black
dye
was
so
deep
from
head
to

that
it
had
quite
steamed
before
the
fire
,
diffusing
a

,
made
a
short
one

of
his
head
from
the

and
slowly
shook

.
   
<EOS>
"
We
whose

it
is
to
be

in
the

respectable
practitioners
,
sir
,
can
but

to

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
At

,
I
do

;
and
I
wish

of

professional
brethren
,
one

.
 
<EOS>
You
are

of
an

not

,
miss
,
in

Mr
C
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
said

would
be
careful
not

.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
Good

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
,
good
morning
,
sir
.
"
<EOS>
Mr
Vholes
put
his
dead
glove
,
which
scarcely
seemed
to
have
any
hand
in
it
,
on
my
fingers
,
and
then
on
my
guardian
's
fingers
,
and
took
his
long
thin
shadow
away
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
of
it
on
the
outside
of
the
coach
,
passing
over
all
the
sunny
landscape
between
us
and
London
,
chilling
the
seed
in
the
ground
as
it
glided
along
.
   
<EOS>
Of
course
it
became
necessary
to
tell
Ada
where
I
was
going
and
why
I
was
going
,
and
of
course
she
was
anxious
and
distressed
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
was
too
true
to
Richard
to
say
anything
but
words
of
pity
and
words
of
excuse
,
and
in
a
more
loving
spirit
still
---
my
dear
devoted
girl
!
<EOS>
---
she
wrote
him
a
long
letter
,
of
which
I
took
charge
.
   
<EOS>
Charley
was
to
be
my
travelling
companion
,
though
I
am
sure
I
wanted
none
and
would
willingly
have
left
her
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
We
all
went
to
London
that
afternoon
,
and
finding
two
places
in
the
mail
,
secured
them
.
 
<EOS>
At
our
usual
bed
-
time
,
Charley
and
I
were
rolling
away
seaward
with
the
Kentish
letters
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
night
's
journey
in
those
coach
times
,
but
we
had
the
mail
to
ourselves
and
did
not
find
the
night
very
tedious
.
 
<EOS>
It
passed
with
me
as
I
suppose
it
would
with
most
people
under
such
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
At
one
while
my
journey
looked
hopeful
,
and
at
another
hopeless
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
thought
I
should
do
some
good
,
and
now
I
wondered
how
I
could
ever
have
supposed
so
.
 
<EOS>
Now
it
seemed
one
of
the
most
reasonable
things
in
the
world
that
I
should
have
come
,
and
now
one
of
the
most
unreasonable
.
 
<EOS>
In
what
state
I
should
find
Richard
,
what
I
should
say
to
him
,
and
what
he
would
say
to
me
occupied
my
mind
by
turns
with
these
two
states
of
feeling
;
and
the
wheels
seemed
to
play
one
tune
(
to
which
the
burden
of
my
guardian
's
letter
set
itself
)
over
and
over
again
all
night
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
we
came
into
the
narrow
streets
of
Deal
,
and
very
gloomy
they
were
upon
a
raw
misty
morning
.
 
<EOS>
The
long
flat
beach
,
with
its
little
irregular
houses
,
wooden
and
brick
,
and
its
litter
of
capstans
,
and
great
boats
,
and
sheds
,
and
bare
upright
poles
with
tackle
and
blocks
,
and
loose
gravelly
waste
places
overgrown
with
grass
and
weeds
,
wore
as
dull
an
appearance
as
any
place
I
ever
saw
.
 
<EOS>
The
sea
was
heaving
under
a
thick
white
fog
;
and
nothing
else
was
moving
but
a
few
early
ropemakers
,
who
,
with
the
yarn
twisted
round
their
bodies
,
looked
as
if
,
tired
of
their
present
state
of
existence
,
they
were
spinning
themselves
into
cordage
.
   
<EOS>
But
when
we
got
into
a
warm
room
in
an
excellent
hotel
and
sat
down
,
comfortably
washed
and
dressed
,
to
an
early
breakfast
(
for
it
was
too
late
to
think
of
going
to
bed
)
,
Deal
began
to
look
more
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
Our
little
room
was
like
a
ship
's
cabin
,
and
that
delighted
Charley
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
fog
began
to
rise
like
a
curtain
,
and
numbers
of
ships
that
we
had
had
no
idea
were
near
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
many
sail
the
waiter
told
us
were
then
lying
in
the
downs
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
these
vessels
were
of
grand
size
---
one
was
a
large
Indiaman
<EOS>
just
come
home
;
and
when
the
sun
shone
through
the
clouds
,
maktng
silvery
pools
in
the
dark
sea
,
the
way
in
which
these
ships
brightened
,
and
shadowed
,
and
changed
,
amid
a
bustle
of
boats
pulling
off
from
the
shore
to
them
and
from
them
to
the
shore
,
and
a
general
life
and
motion
in
themselves
and
everything
around
them
,
was
most
beautiful
.
   
<EOS>
The
large
Indiaman
was
our
great
attraction
because
she
had
come
into
the
downs
in
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
surrounded
by
boats
,
and
we
said
how
glad
the
people
on
board
of
her
must
be
to
come
ashore
.
<EOS>
Charley
was
curious
,
too
,
about
the
voyage
,
and
about
the
heat
in
India
,
and
the
serpents
and
the
tigers
;
and
as
she
picked
up
such
information
much
faster
than
grammar
,
I
told
her
what
I
knew
on
those
points
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
,
too
,
how
people
in
such
voyages
were
sometimes
wrecked
and
cast
on
rocks
,
where
they
were
saved
by
the
intrepidity
and
humanity
of
one
man
.
 
<EOS>
And
Charley
asking
how
that
could
be
,
I
told
her
how
we
knew
at
home
of
such
a
case
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
thought
of
sending
Richard
a
note
saying
I
was
there
,
but
it
seemed
so
much
better
to
go
to
him
without
preparation
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
lived
in
barracks
I
was
a
little
doubtful
whether
this
was
feasible
,
but
we
went
out
to
reconnoitre
.
 
<EOS>
Peeping
in
at
the
gate
of
the
barrack
-
yard
,
we
found
everything
very
quiet
at
that
time
in
the
morning
,
and
I
asked
a
sergeant
standing
on
the
guardhouse
-
steps
where
he
lived
.
 
<EOS>
He
sent
a
man
before
to
show
me
,
who
went
up
some
bare
stairs
,
and
knocked
with
his
knuckles
at
a
door
,
and
left
us
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
then
!
"
cried
Richard
from
within
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
left
Charley
in
the
little
passage
,
and
going
on
to
the
half
-
open
door
,
<EOS>
said
,
"
Can
I
come
in
,
Richard
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
only
Dame
Durden
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
writing
at
a
table
,
with
a
great
confusion
of
clothes
,
tin
cases
,
books
,
boots
,
brushes
,
and
portmanteaus
strewn
all
about
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
only
half
dressed
---
in
plain
clothes
,
I
observed
,
not
in
uniform
---
and
his
hair
was
unbrushed
,
and
he
looked
as
wild
as
his
room
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
I
saw
after
he
had
heartily
welcomed
me
<EOS>
and
I
was
seated
near
him
,
for
he
started
upon
hearing
my
voice
and
caught
me
in
his
arms
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
Richard
!
 
<EOS>
He
was
ever
the
same
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Down
to
---
ah
,
poor
poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
---
to
the
end
,
he
never
received
me
but
with
something
of
his
old
merry
boyish
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
heaven
,
my
dear
little
woman
,
"
said
he
,
"
how
do
you
come
here
?
 
<EOS>
Who
could
have
thought
of
seeing
you
!
 
<EOS>
Nothing
the
matter
?
<EOS>
Ada
is
well
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
well
.
 
<EOS>
Lovelier
than
ever
,
Richard
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
lenning
back
in
his
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
poor
cousin
!
 
<EOS>
I
was
writing
to
you
,
Esther
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
So
worn
and
haggard
as
he
looked
,
even
in
the
fullness
of
his
handsome
youth
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
and
crushing
the
closely
written
sheet
of
paper
in
his
hand
!
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
been
at
the
trouble
of
writing
all
that
,
and
am
I
not
to
read
it
after
all
?
<EOS>
"
I
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
dear
,
"
he
returned
with
a
hopeless
gesture
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
read
it
in
the
whole
room
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
all
over
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
mildly
entreated
him
not
to
be
despondent
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
that
I
had
heard
by
chance
of
his
being
in
difficulty
and
had
come
to
consult
with
him
what
could
best
be
done
.
   
<EOS>
"
Like
you
,
Esther
,
but
useless
,
and
so
NOT
like
you
!
"
said
he
with
a
melancholy
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
away
on
leave
this
day
---
should
have
been
gone
in
another
hour
---
and
that
is
to
smooth
it
over
,
for
my
selling
out
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Let
bygones
be
bygones
.
 
<EOS>
So
this
calling
follows
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
want
to
have
been
in
the
church
to
have
made
the
round
of
all
the
professions
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Richard
,
"
I
urged
,
"
it
is
not
so
hopeless
as
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Esther
,
"
he
returned
,
"
it
is
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
just
so
near
disgrace
as
that
those
who
are
put
in
authority
over
me
(
as
the
catechism
goes
)
would
far
rather
be
without
me
than
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
And
they
are
right
.
 
<EOS>
Apart
from
debts
and
duns
and
all
such
drawbacks
,
I
am
not
fit
even
for
this
employment
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
care
,
no
mind
,
no
heart
,
no
soul
,
but
for
one
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
if
this
bubble
had
n't
broken
now
,
"
he
said
,
tearing
the
letter
he
had
written
into
fragments
and
moodily
casting
them
away
,
by
driblets
,
"
how
could
I
have
gone
abroad
?
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
been
ordered
abroad
,
but
how
could
I
have
gone
?
 
<EOS>
How
could
I
,
with
my
experience
of
that
thing
,
trust
even
Vholes
unless
I
was
at
his
back
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
suppose
he
knew
by
my
face
what
I
was
about
to
say
,
but
he
caught
the
hand
I
had
laid
upon
his
arm
and
touched
my
own
lips
with
it
to
prevent
me
from
going
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Dame
Durden
!
 
<EOS>
Two
subjects
I
forbid
---
must
forbid
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
is
John
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
The
second
,
you
know
what
.
 
<EOS>
Call
it
madness
,
and
I
tell
you
I
ca
n't
help
it
now
,
and
ca
n't
be
sane
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
no
such
thing
;
it
is
the
one
object
I
have
to
pursue
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
pity
I
ever
was
prevailed
upon
to
turn
out
of
my
road
for
any
other
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
wisdom
to
abandon
it
now
,
after
all
the
time
,
anxiety
,
and
pains
I
have
bestowed
upon
it
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
,
true
wisdom
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
very
agreeable
,
too
,
to
some
people
;
but
I
never
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
in
that
mood
in
which
I
thought
it
best
not
to
increase
his
determination
(
if
anything
could
increase
it
)
by
opposing
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
out
Ada
's
letter
and
put
it
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Am
I
to
read
it
now
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
told
him
yes
,
he
laid
it
on
the
table
,
and
resting
his
head
upon
his
hand
,
began
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
read
far
when
he
rested
his
head
upon
his
two
hands
---
to
hide
his
face
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
little
while
he
rose
as
if
the
light
were
bad
and
went
to
the
window
.
 
<EOS>
He
finished
reading
it
there
,
with
his
back
towards
me
,
and
after
he
had
finished
and
had
folded
it
up
,
stood
there
for
some
minutes
with
the
letter
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
came
back
to
his
chair
,
I
saw
tears
in
his
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
Esther
,
you
know
what
she
says
here
?
"
 
<EOS>
He
spoke
in
a
softened
voice
and
kissed
the
letter
as
he
asked
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Richard
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Offers
me
,
"
he
went
on
,
tapping
his
foot
upon
the
floor
,
"
the
little
inheritance
she
is
certain
of
so
soon
---
just
as
little
and
as
much
as
I
have
wasted
---
and
begs
and
prays
me
to
take
it
,
set
myself
right
with
it
,
and
remain
in
the
service
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
your
welfare
to
be
the
dearest
wish
of
her
heart
,
"
said
I.
"
<EOS>
And
,
oh
,
my
dear
Richard
,
Ada
's
is
a
noble
heart
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I
wish
I
was
dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
went
back
to
the
window
,
and
laying
his
arm
across
it
,
leaned
his
head
down
on
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
It
greatly
affected
me
to
see
him
so
,
but
I
hoped
he
might
become
more
yielding
,
and
I
remained
silent
.
<EOS>
My
experience
was
very
limited
;
I
was
not
at
all
prepared
for
his
rousing
himself
out
of
this
emotion
to
a
new
sense
of
injury
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
this
is
the
heart
that
the
same
John
Jarndyce
,
who
is
not
otherwise
to
be
mentioned
between
us
,
stepped
in
to
estrange
from
me
,
"
said
he
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
the
dear
girl
makes
me
this
generous
offer
from
under
the
same
John
Jarndyce
's
roof
,
and
with
the
same
John
Jarndyce
's
gracious
consent
and
connivance
,
I
dare
say
,
as
a
new
means
of
buying
me
off
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Richard
!
<EOS>
"
I
cried
out
,
rising
hastily
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
hear
you
say
such
shameful
words
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
was
very
angry
with
him
indeed
,
for
the
first
time
in
my
life
,
but
it
only
lasted
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
saw
his
worn
young
face
looking
at
me
as
if
he
were
sorry
,
I
put
my
hand
on
his
shoulder
and
said
,
"
If
you
please
,
my
dear
Richard
,
do
not
speak
in
such
a
tone
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Consider
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
blamed
himself
exceedingly
and
told
me
in
the
most
generous
manner
that
he
had
been
very
wrong
and
that
he
begged
my
pardon
a
thousand
times
.
 
<EOS>
At
that
I
laughed
,
but
trembled
a
little
too
,
for
I
was
rather
fluttered
after
being
so
fiery
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
accept
this
offer
,
my
dear
Esther
,
"
said
he
,
sitting
down
beside
me
and
resuming
our
conversation
,
"
---
once
more
,
pray
,
pray
forgive
me
;
I
am
deeply
grieved
---
to
accept
my
dearest
cousin
's
offer
is
,
I
need
not
say
,
impossible
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
have
letters
and
papers
that
I
could
show
you
which
would
convince
you
it
is
all
over
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
done
with
the
red
coat
,
believe
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
some
satisfaction
,
in
the
midst
of
my
troubles
and
perplexities
,
to
know
that
I
am
pressing
Ada
's
interests
in
pressing
my
own
.
 
<EOS>
Vholes
has
his
shoulder
to
the
wheel
,
and
he
can
not
help
urging
it
on
as
much
for
her
as
for
me
,
thank
God
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
sanguine
hopes
were
rising
within
him
and
lighting
up
his
features
,
but
they
made
his
face
more
sad
to
me
than
it
had
been
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
!
"
cried
Richard
exultingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
every
farthing
of
Ada
's
little
fortune
were
mine
,
no
part
of
it
should
be
spent
in
retaining
me
in
what
I
am
not
fit
for
,
can
take
no
interest
in
,
and
am
weary
of
.
 
<EOS>
It
should
be
devoted
to
what
promises
a
better
return
,
and
should
be
used
where
she
has
a
larger
stake
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
uneasy
for
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
shall
now
have
only
one
thing
on
my
mind
,
and
Vholes
and
I
will
work
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
not
be
without
means
.
 
<EOS>
Free
of
my
commission
,
I
shall
be
able
to
compound
with
some
small
usurers
who
will
hear
of
nothing
but
their
bond
now
---
Vholes
says
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
a
balance
in
my
favour
anyway
,
but
that
would
swell
it
.
<EOS>
Come
,
come
!
 
<EOS>
You
shall
carry
a
letter
to
Ada
from
me
,
Esther
,
and
you
must
both
of
you
be
more
hopeful
of
me
and
not
believe
that
I
am
quite
cast
away
just
yet
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
will
not
repeat
what
I
said
to
Richard
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
was
tiresome
,
and
nobody
is
to
suppose
for
a
moment
that
it
was
at
all
wise
.
 
<EOS>
It
only
came
from
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
He
heard
it
patiently
and
feelingly
,
but
I
saw
that
on
the
two
subjects
he
had
reserved
it
was
at
present
hopeless
to
make
any
representation
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
too
,
and
had
experienced
in
this
very
interview
,
the
sense
of
my
guardian
's
remark
that
it
was
even
more
mischievous
to
use
persuasion
with
him
than
to
leave
him
as
he
was
.
   
<EOS>
Therefore
I
was
driven
at
last
to
asking
Richard
if
he
would
mind
convincing
me
that
it
really
was
all
over
there
,
as
he
had
said
,
and
that
it
was
not
his
mere
impression
.
 
<EOS>
He
showed
me
without
hesitation
a
correspondence
making
it
quite
plain
that
his
retirement
was
arranged
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
,
from
what
he
told
me
,
that
Mr
Vholes
had
copies
of
these
papers
and
had
been
in
consultation
with
him
throughout
.
 
<EOS>
Beyond
ascertaining
this
,
and
having
been
the
bearer
of
Ada
's
letter
,
and
being
(
as
I
was
going
to
be
)
<EOS>
Richard
's
companion
back
to
London
<EOS>
,
I
had
done
no
good
by
coming
down
.
<EOS>
Admitting
this
to
myself
with
a
reluctant
heart
,
I
said
I
would
return
to
the
hotel
and
wait
until
he
joined
me
there
,
so
he
threw
a
cloak
over
his
shoulders
and
saw
me
to
the
gate
,
and
Charley
<EOS>
and
I
went
back
along
the
beach
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
concourse
of
people
in
one
spot
,
surrounding
some
naval
officers
who
were
landing
from
a
boat
,
and
pressing
about
them
with
unusual
interest
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
to
Charley
this
would
be
one
of
the
great
Indiaman
's
boats
now
,
and
we
stopped
to
look
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
came
slowly
up
from
the
waterside
,
speaking
good
-
humouredly
to
each
other
and
to
the
people
around
and
glancing
about
them
as
if
they
were
glad
to
be
in
England
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Charley
,
Charley
,
"
said
I
,
"
come
away
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
I
hurried
on
so
swiftly
that
my
little
maid
was
surprised
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
we
were
shut
up
in
our
cabin
-
room
<EOS>
and
I
had
had
time
to
take
breath
that
I
began
to
think
why
I
had
made
such
haste
.
 
<EOS>
In
one
of
the
sunburnt
faces
I
had
recognized
Mr
Allan
Woodcourt
,
and
I
had
been
afraid
of
his
recognizing
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
unwilling
that
he
should
see
my
altered
looks
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
taken
by
surprise
,
and
my
courage
had
quite
failed
me
.
   
<EOS>
But
I
knew
this
would
not
do
,
and
<EOS>
I
now
said
to
myself
,
"
My
dear
,
there
is
no
reason
<EOS>
---
there
is
and
there
can
be
no
reason
at
all
---
why
it
should
be
worse
for
you
now
than
it
ever
has
been
.
 
<EOS>
What
you
were
last
month
,
you
are
to
-
day
;
you
are
no
worse
,
you
are
no
better
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
not
your
resolution
;
call
it
up
,
Esther
,
call
it
up
!
"
 
<EOS>
I
was
in
a
great
tremble
---
with
running
---
and
<EOS>
at
first
was
quite
unable
to
calm
myself
;
but
I
got
better
,
and
I
was
very
glad
to
know
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
party
came
to
the
hotel
.
 
<EOS>
I
heard
them
speaking
on
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
sure
it
was
the
same
gentlemen
because
I
knew
their
voices
again
---
<EOS>
I
mean
I
knew
Mr
Woodcourt
's
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
still
have
been
a
great
relief
to
me
to
have
gone
away
without
making
myself
known
,
but
I
was
determined
not
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
,
no
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
untied
my
bonnet
and
put
my
veil
half
up
---
<EOS>
I
think
I
mean
half
down
,
but
it
matters
very
little
---
and
wrote
on
one
of
my
cards
that
I
happened
to
be
there
with
Mr
Richard
Carstone
,
and
I
sent
it
in
to
Mr
Woodcourt
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
I
was
rejoiced
to
be
by
chance
among
the
first
to
welcome
him
home
to
England
.
<EOS>
And
I
saw
that
he
was
very
sorry
for
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
in
shipwreck
and
peril
since
you
left
us
,
Mr
Woodcourt
,
"
said
I
,
"
but
we
can
hardly
call
that
a
misfortune
which
enabled
you
to
be
so
useful
and
so
brave
.
 
<EOS>
We
read
of
it
with
the
truest
interest
.
 
<EOS>
It
first
came
to
my
knowledge
through
your
old
patient
,
poor
Miss
Flite
,
when
I
was
recovering
from
my
severe
illness
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

!

<EOS>
Chapter
46
.
<EOS>
Stop
Him
!
 
<EOS>
Darkness

Tom
-
All
-

's
.
 
<EOS>
Dilating
and
dilating
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
For

,

Tom
-
all

's
,

<EOS>
Tom
-
all
-
Alone
's
---

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
The

has
eyed
Tom
with

,
as

some

of
herself
in
his

unfit

and

;
but

.
 
<EOS>
The

in

Tom
-
all
-
Alone
's
,
and
Tom

fast

.
   
<EOS>
Much

,

,
concerning
Tom
,
and
much

how

.
 
<EOS>
Whether

In

,
to

,
that
Tom
only

's

.
<EOS>
And

,
Tom

.
   
<EOS>
But
he

.
 
<EOS>
Even

are
his

,
and

in

.
 
<EOS>
There

Tom
's
corrupted
blood
but

infection
and

somewhere
.
 
<EOS>
It
shall
pollute
,
this
very
night
,
the
choice
stream
(
in

would

)
of

,

his

not

.
 
<EOS>
There

Tom
's

,

any

he

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Verily
,
what

,

,

,
Tom
has
his

.
   
<EOS>
It

whether
Tom
-
all
-
Alone
's
be
uglier

,
but

,

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
The

;

.
   
<EOS>
A

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
On

-

-

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
No

himself

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>
Beside

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

Woodcourt

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
What

"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ca

?
 
<EOS>

---

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
It
do

.
"
   
<EOS>
A

him
of
speaking

the

childishness

little

books
)
has

.
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

;

<EOS>
Tom

<EOS>
Yes

!
 
<EOS>

---
which

might

.
 
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Richard

<EOS>

.

Jo

<EOS>
Chapter
47
.
<EOS>
Jo
's
Will
 
<EOS>
As

Woodcourt
and
Jo
proceed
along

<EOS>
how

.
<EOS>
"

"

"

this

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
At

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>

suggests

to

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
Jo

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

to
Jo

,

to

,

.
   
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
I

I

amost

-

,

,
"

Jo
,
soon

,
"
<EOS>
but
I
do

nothink
---
not

.
 
<EOS>
I
do

for

wittles
nor
yet

on
'
em
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
Jo

.
   
<EOS>
Allan

.

"
<EOS>
Draw

,

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

,
"
as

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He

add
,
"
<EOS>
And

,
"
but
<EOS>

"
I
'm
a
-

,

.
"
   
<EOS>

's

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

We

<EOS>
Now

.

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
Observant

,

no

lady
in

,
with
all

.
 
<EOS>
Jo
slowly

slowly

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

.
   
<EOS>
Intending

,
zealous

Miss
Flite
,

.
 
<EOS>
But
all

changed

;

no

;

;

,

,

,
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
These

,

,

Miss

a
Mrs
Blinder
,

Bell
Yard
,
he

to
that

,
where
Miss
Flite
(
who
rises
early
that

)

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
My

,

,

!
"
 
<EOS>
She

---

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Where

lodge

?
 
<EOS>
Now
,

.
   
<EOS>
Miss

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
"
Gridley
!
<EOS>
"

Flite
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Gridley
!
 
<EOS>
To
be

!
 
<EOS>
Of

!
 
<EOS>
My

!
 
<EOS>
General
George
will
help

out
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
is

to
ask

about
General
George
,

,

Miss
Flite

akeady

.
 
<EOS>
But

in
her
disjointed
manner
on
coming
down
in
full
array
that
General
George
,
whom
she
often
calls
upon
,
knows
her
dear
Fitz
Jarndyce
and
takes
a
great
interest
in
all
connected
with
her
,
Allan
is
induced
to
think
that
they
may
be
in
the
right
way
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
tells
Jo
,
for
his
encouragement
,
that
this
walking
about
will
soon
be
over
now
;
and
they
repair
to
the
general
's
.
 
<EOS>
Fortunately
it
is
not
far
.
   
<EOS>
From
the
exterior
of
George
's
Shooting
Gallery
,
and
the
long
entry
,
and
the
bare
perspective
beyond
it
,
Allan
Woodcourt
augurs
well
.
<EOS>
He
also
descries
promise
in
the
figure
of
Mr
George
himself
,
striding
towards
them
in
his
mornmg
exercise
with
his
pipe
in
his
mouth
,
no
stock
on
,
and
his
muscular
arms
,
developed
by
broadsword
and
dumbbell
,
weightily
asserting
themselves
through
his
light
shirt
-
sleeves
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
servant
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
George
with
a
military
salute
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
humouredly
smiling
all
over
his
broad
forehead
up
into
his
crisp
hair
,
he
then
defers
to
Miss
Flite
,
as
,
with
great
stateliness
,
and
at
some
length
,
she
performs
the
courtly
ceremony
of
presentation
.
<EOS>
He
winds
it
up
with
another
"
Your
servant
,
sir
!
"
and
another
salute
.
   
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
A
sailor
,
I
believe
?
<EOS>
"
says
Mr
George
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
proud
to
find
I
have
the
air
of
one
,
"
returns
Allan
;
"
but
I
am
only
a
sea
-
going
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
thought
you
was
a
regular
blue
-
jacket
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Allan
hopes
Mr
George
will
forgive
his
intrusion
the
more
readily
on
that
account
,
and
particularly
that
he
will
not
lay
aside
his
pipe
,
which
,
in
his
politeness
,
he
has
testifled
some
intention
of
doing
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
sir
,
"
returns
the
trooper
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
I
know
by
experience
that
it
's
not
disagreeable
to
Miss
Flite
,
and
since
it
's
equally
agreeable
to
yourself
---
"
and
finishes
the
sentence
by
putting
it
between
his
lips
again
.
 
<EOS>
Allan
proceeds
to
tell
him
all
he
knows
about
Jo
,
unto
which
the
trooper
listens
with
a
grave
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
's
the
lad
<EOS>
,
sir
,
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
he
inquires
,
looking
along
the
entry
to
where
Jo
stands
staring
up
at
the
great
letters
on
the
whitewashed
front
,
which
have
no
meaning
in
his
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
he
,
"
says
Allan
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
,
Mr
George
,
I
am
in
this
difficulty
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
unwilling
to
place
him
in
a
hospital
,
even
if
I
could
procure
him
immediate
admission
,
because
I
foresee
that
he
would
not
stay
there
many
hours
if
he
could
be
so
much
as
got
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
objection
applies
to
a
workhouse
,
supposing
I
had
the
patience
to
be
evaded
and
shirked
,
and
handed
about
from
post
to
pillar
in
trying
to
get
him
into
one
,
which
is
a
system
that
I
do
n't
take
kindly
to
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
man
does
,
sir
,
"
returns
Mr
George
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
convinced
that
he
would
not
remain
in
either
place
,
because
he
is
possessed
by
an
extraordinary
terror
of
this
person
who
ordered
him
to
keep
out
of
the
way
;
in
his
ignorance
,
he
believes
this
person
to
be
everywhere
,
and
cognizant
of
everything
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
George
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
not
mentioned
that
party
's
name
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
a
secret
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
boy
makes
it
one
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
name
is
Bucket
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bucket
the
detective
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
same
man
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
man
is
known
to
me
,
sir
,
"
returns
the
trooper
after
blowing
out
a

and
squaring

,
"
and
the
boy
is
so
far
correct
that
he
undoubtedly
is
a
---
rum
customer
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
George
smokes
with
a
profound
meaning
after
this
and
surveys
Miss
Flite
in
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
wish
Mr
Jarndyce
and
Miss
Summerson
at
least
to
know
that
this
Jo
,
who
tells
so
strange

story
,
has
reappeared
,
and
to
have
it
in
their
power
to
speak

if
they
should

to
do

.
<EOS>
Therefore
I
want
to
get
him
,
for
the
present
moment
,
into
any
poor
lodging
kept
by
decent
people
where
he
would
be

.
 
<EOS>
Decent
people
and
Jo
,
Mr
George
,
"
says
Allan
,
following
the
direction
of
the
trooper
's
eyes
along

entry
,
"
have
not

much

,
as
you
see
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
the
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
happen
to
know
any
one
in
this
neighbourhood
who
would
receive
him
for
a
while
on
my
paying
for
him
beforehand
?
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
puts
the
question
,
he
becomes
aware
of
a
dirty
-
faced
little
man
standing
at
the
trooper
's
elbow
and
looking
up
,
with
an
oddly
twisted
figure
and
countenance
,
into
the
trooper
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few
more
puffs
at
his
pipe
,
the
trooper
looks
down
askant
at
the
little
man
,
and
the
little
man
winks
up
at
the
trooper
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
"
I
can
assure
you
that
I
would
willingiy
be
knocked
on
the
head
at
any
time
if
it
would
be
at
all
agreeable
to
Miss
Summerson
,
and
consequently
I
esteem
it
a
privilege
to
do
that
young
lady
any
service
,
however
small
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
naturally
in
the
vagabond
way
here
,
sir
,
both
myself
and
Phil
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
what
the
place
is
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
welcome
to
a
quiet
corner
of
it
for
the
boy
if
the
same
would
meet
your
views
.
 
<EOS>
No
charge
made
,
except
for
rations
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
not
in
a
flourishing
state
of
circumstances
here
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
liable
to
be
tumbled
out
neck
and
crop
at
a
moment
's
notice
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
sir
,
such
as
the
place
is
,
and
so
long
as
it
lasts
,
here
it
is
at
your
service
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
a
comprehensive
wave
of
his
pipe
,
Mr
George
places
the
whole
building
at
his
visitor
's
disposal
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
take
it
for

,
sir
,
"
he
adds
,
"
you
being
one
of
the
medical
staff
,
that
there
is
no
present
infection
about
this
unfortunate
subject
?
"
   
<EOS>
Allan
is
quite
sure
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
George
,
shaking
his
head

,
"
we
have
had
enough
of
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
tone
is
no
less
sorrowfully
echoed
by
his
new
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
"Still
<EOS>
I
am
bound
to
tell
you
,
"
observes
Allan
after
repeating
his
former
assurance
,
"
that
the
boy
is
deplorably
low
and
reduced
and
that
he
may
be
<EOS>
---
I
do
not
say
that
he
is
---
too
far
gone
to
recover
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
consider
him
in
present
danger
,

?
"
inquires
the
trooper
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
fear

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
sir
,
"
returns
the
trooper
in
a
decisive

,
"
it
appears
to
me
---
being
naturally
in
the
vagabond
way
myself
---
that
the
sooner
he
comes
out
of
the
street
,
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
You
,
Phil
!
 
<EOS>
Bring
him
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Squod
tacks
out
,
all
on
one
side
,
to
execute
the
word
of
command
;
and
the
trooper
,
having
smoked
his
pipe
,
lays
it
by
.
 
<EOS>
Jo
is
brought
in
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
one
of
Mrs
Pardiggle
's
Tockahoopo
Indians
;
he
is
not
one
of
Mrs
Jellyby
's
lambs
,
being
wholly
unconnected
with
Borrioboola
-
Gha
;
he
is
not
softened
by
distance
and
unfamiliarity
;
he
is
not
a
genuine
foreign
-
grown
savage
;
he
is
the
ordinary
home
-
made
article
.
 
<EOS>
Dirty
,
ugly
,
disagreeable
to
all
the
senses
,
in
body
a
common
creature
of
the
common
streets
,
only
in
soul
a
heathen
.
 
<EOS>
Homely
filth
begrimes
him
,
<EOS>
homely
parasites
devour
him
,
homely
sores
are
in
him
,
homely
rags
are
on
him
;
native
ignorance
,
the
growth
of
English
soil
and
climate
,
sinks
his
immortal
nature
lower
than
the
beasts
that
perish
.
 
<EOS>
Stand
forth
,
Jo
,
in
uncompromising
colours
!
 
<EOS>
From
the
sole
of
thy
foot
to
the
crown
of
thy
head
,
there
is
nothing
interesting
about
thee
.
   
<EOS>
He
shuffles
slowly
into
Mr
George
's
gallery
and
stands
huddled
together
in
a
bundle
,
looking
all
about
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
He
seems
to
know
that
they
have
an
inclination
to
shrink
from
him
,
partly
for
what
he
is
and
partly
for
what
he
has
caused
.
 
<EOS>
He
,
too
,
shrinks
from
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
of
the
same
order
of
things
,
not
of
the
same
place
in
creation
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
of
no
order
and
no
place
,
neither
of
the
beasts
nor
of
humanity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
Jo
!
"
says
Allan
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
Mr
George
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jo
searches
the
floor
for
some
time
longer
,
then
looks
up
for
a
moment
,
and
then
down
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
kind
friend
to
you
,
for
he
is
going
to
give
you
lodging
room
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jo
makes
a
scoop
with
one
hand
,
which
is
supposed
to
be
a
bow
.
<EOS>
After
a
little
more
consideration
and
some
backing
and
changing
of
the
foot
on
which
he
rests
,
he
mutters
that
he
is
"
wery
thankful
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
safe
here
.
 
<EOS>
All
you
have
to
do
at
present
is
to
be
obedient
and
to
get
strong
.
 
<EOS>
And
mind
you
tell
us
the
truth
here
,
whatever
you
do
,
Jo
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wishermaydie
if
I
do
n't
,
sir
,
"
says
Jo
,
reverting
to
his
favourite
declaration
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
done
nothink
yit
,
but
wot
<EOS>
you
knows
on
,
to
get
myself
into
no
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
in
no
other
trouble
at
all
,
sir
,
'
sept
not
knowin
'
nothink
and
starwation
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
believe
it
,
now
attend
to
Mr
George
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
he
is
going
to
speak
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
intention
merely
was
,
sir
,
"
observes
Mr
George
,
amazingly
broad
and
upright
,
"
to
point
out
to
him
where
he
can
lie
down
and
get
a
thorough
good
dose
of
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
look
here
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
the
trooper
speaks
,
he
conducts
them
to
the
other
end
of
the
gallery
and
opens
one
of
the
little

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
you
are
,
you
see
!
 
<EOS>
Here
is
a
mattress
,
and
here
you
may
rest
,
on
good
behaviour
,
as
long
as
Mr
,
I
ask
your
pardon
,
sir
"
---
he
refers

to
the
card
Allan
has
given
