---
"
Mr
Woodcourt
pleases
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
be
alarmed
if
you
hear
shots
;
they
'll
be
aimed
at
the
target
,
and
not
you
.
<EOS>
Now
,
there
's
another
thing
I
would
recommend
,
sir
,
"
says
the
trooper
,
turning
to
his
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Phil
,
come
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
bears
down
upon
them
according
to
his
usual
tactics
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
man
,
sir
,
who
was
found
,
when
a
baby
,
in
the
gutter
.
<EOS>
Consequently
,
it
is
to
be
expected
that
he
takes
a
natural
interest
in
this
poor
creature
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
,
do
n't
you
,
Phil
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
and
surely
I
do
,
guv'ner
,
"
is
Phil
's
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
I
was
thinking
,
sir
,
"
says
Mr
George
in
a
martial
sort
of
confidence
,
as
if
he
were
giving
his
opinion
in
a
council
of
war
at
a
drum
-
head
,
"
that
if
this
man
was
to
take
him
to
a
bath
and
was
to
lay
out
a
few
shillings
in
getting
him
one
or
two
coarse
articles
---
"
   
"
Mr
George
,
my
considerate
friend
,
"
returns
Allan
,
taking
out
his
purse
,
"
it
is
the
very
favour
I
would
have
asked
.
"
   
<EOS>
Phil
Squod
and
Jo
are
sent
out
immediately
on
this
work
of
improvement
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Flite
,
quite
enraptured
by
her
success
,
makes
the
best
of
her
way
to
court
,
having
great
fears
that
otherwise
her
friend
the
Chancellor
may
be
uneasy
about
her
or
may
give
the
judgment
she
has
so
long
expected
in
her
absence
,
and
observing
"
which
you
know
,
my
dear
physician
,
and
general
,
after
so
many
years
,
would
be
too
absurdly
unfortunate
!
"
 
<EOS>
Allan
takes
the
opportunity
of
going
out
to
procure
some
restorative
medicines
,
and
obtaining
them
near
at
hand
,
soon
returns
to
find
the
trooper
walking
up
and
down
the
gallery
,
and
to

Chapter

<EOS>
Closing
in
 
<EOS>
The
place
in
Lincolnshire
has
shut

many

,
and
the
house
in
town

.
 
<EOS>
In
Lincolnshire
the
Dedlocks
of
the
past
doze
in
their
picture
-
frames
,
and
the
low
wind
murmurs
through
the
long
drawing
-
room

they
were

.
 
<EOS>
In
town
<EOS>
the
Dedlocks
of
the
present
rattle
in
their
fire
-
eyed
carriages
through
the
darkness
of
the
night
,
and
the
Dedlock
Mercuries
,
with
ashes
(
or

-
powder
)
on

,
symptomatic
of
their
great

,
loll

.
 
<EOS>
The
fashionable
world
---
<EOS>
tremendous
orb
,
nearly
five

round
---
is
in
full

,
and
the

system
works

.
   
<EOS>
Where

,

,
where

,

Dedlock
is
.
 
<EOS>
From
the

she

,

never

.
 
<EOS>
Though

of

what
she

to

,

.
 
<EOS>

.

.

.

<EOS>

.

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
shut
?
"
   
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
She
goes
to
it
and
returns
,
and
looks
yet
more
surprised
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
about
to
place
confidence
in
you
,
child
,
for
I
know
<EOS>
I
may
trust
your
attachment
,
if
not
your
judgment
.
 
<EOS>
In
what
I
am
going
to
do
,
I
will
not
disguise
myself
to
you
at
least
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
confide
in
you
.
 
<EOS>
Say
nothing
to
any
one
of
what
passes
between
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
timid
little
beauty
promises
in
all
earnestness
to
be
trustworthy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
"
Lady
Dedlock
asks
her
,
signing
to
her
to
bring
her
chair
nearer
,
"
do
you
know
,
Rosa
,
that
I
am
different
to
you
from
what
I
am
to
any
one
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
Lady
.
 
<EOS>
Much
kinder
.
 
<EOS>
But
then
I
often
think
I
know
you
as
you
really
are
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
often
think
you
know
me
as
I
really
am
?
 
<EOS>
Poor
child
,
poor
child
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
says
it
with
a
kind
of
scorn
---
though
not
of
Rosa
---
and
sits
brooding
,
looking
dreamily
at
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
,
Rosa
,
you
are
any
relief
or
comfort
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
suppose
your
being
young
and
natural
,
and
fond
of
me
and
grateful
to
me
,
makes
it
any
pleasure
to
me
to
have
you
near
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
my
Lady
;
I
can
scarcely
hope
so
.
 
<EOS>
But
with
all
my
heart
,
I
wish
it
was
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
,
little
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
pretty
face
is
checked
in
its
flush
of
pleasure
by
the
dark
expression
on
the
handsome
face
before
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
looks
timidly
for
an
explanation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
I
were
to
say
to
-
day
,
"
Go
!
<EOS>
Leave
me
!
<EOS>
"
I
should
say
what
would
give
me
great
pain
and
disquiet
,
child
,
and
what
would
leave
me
very
solitary
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
Lady
!
 
<EOS>
Have
I
offended
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Come
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Rosa
bends
down
on
the
footstool
at
my
Lady
's
feet
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
,
with
that
motherly
touch
of
the
famous
ironmaster
night
,
lays
her
hand
upon
her
dark
hair
and
gently
keeps
it
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
,
Rosa
,
that
I
wished
you
to
be
happy
and
that
I
would
make
you
so
if
I
could
make
anybody
happy
on
this
earth
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
.
<EOS>
There
are
reasons
now
known
to
me
,
reasons
in
which
you
have
no
part
,
rendering
it
far
better
for
you
that
you
should
not
remain
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
not
remain
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
determined
that
you
shall
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
written
to
the
father
of
your
lover
,
and
he
will
be
here
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
I
have
done
for
your
sake
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
weeping
girl
covers
her
hand
with
kisses
and
says
what
shall
she
do
,
what
shall
she
do
,
when
they
are
separated
!
 
<EOS>
Her
mistress
kisses
her
on
the
cheek
and
makes
no
other
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
be
happy
,
child
,
under
better
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
Be
beloved
and
happy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
my
Lady
,
I
have
sometimes
thought
---
forgive
my
being
so
free
---
 
that
YOU
are
not
happy
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
be
more
so
when
you
have
sent
me
away
?
 
<EOS>
Pray
,
pray
,
think
again
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
stay
a
little
while
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
,
my
child
,
that
what
I
do
,
I
do
for
your
sake
,
not
my
own
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
done
.
 
<EOS>
What
I
am
towards
you
,
Rosa
,
is
what
I
am
now
---
 
not
what
I
shall
be
a
little
while
hence
.
 
<EOS>
Remember
this
,
and
keep
my
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
Do
so
much
for
my
sake
,
and
thus
all
ends
between
us
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
detaches
herself
from
her
simple
-
hearted
companion
and
leaves
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
Late
in
the
afternoon
,
when
she
next
appears
upon
the
staircase
,
she
is
in
her
haughtiest
and
coldest
state
.
 
<EOS>
As
indifferent
as
if
all
passion
,
feeling
,
and
interest
had
been
worn
out
in
the
earlier
ages
of
the
world
and
had
perished
from
its
surface
with
its
other
departed
monsters
.
   
<EOS>
Mercury
has
announced
Mr
Rouncewell
,
which
is
the
cause
of
her
appearance
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Rouncewell
is
not
in
the
library
,
but
she
repairs
to
the
library
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
is
there
,
and
she
wishes
to
speak
to
him
first
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
,
I
am
desirous
---
but
you
are
engaged
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
dear
no
!
 
<EOS>
Not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Only
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
   
<EOS>
Always
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Haunting
every
place
.
 
<EOS>
No
relief
or
security
from
him
for
a
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Lady
Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
allow
me
to
retire
?
"
   
<EOS>
With
a
look
that
plainly
says
,
"
You
know
you
have
the
power
to
remain
if
you
will
,
"
she
tells
him
it
is
not
necessary
and
moves
towards
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
brings
it
a
little
forward
for
her
with
his
clumsy
bow
and
retires
into
a
window
opposite
.
<EOS>
Interposed
between
her
and
the
fading
light
of
day
in
the
now
quiet
street
,
his
shadow
falls
upon
her
,
and
he
darkens
all
before
her
.
<EOS>
Even
so
does
he
darken
her
life
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
dull
street
under
the
best
conditions
,
where
the
two
long
rows
of
houses
stare
at
each
other
with
that
severity
that
half
-
a
-
dozen
of
its
greatest
mansions
seem
to
have
been
slowly
stared
into
stone
rather
than
originally
built
in
that
material
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
street
of
such
dismal
grandeur
,
so
determined
not
to
condescend
to
liveliness
,
that
the
doors
and
windows
hold
a
gloomy
state
of
their
own
in
black
paint
and
dust
,
and
the
echoing
mews
behind
have
a
dry
and
massive
appearance
,
as
if
they
were
reserved
to
stable
the
stone
chargers
of
noble
statues
.
 
<EOS>
Complicated
garnish
of
iron
-
work
entwines
itself
over
the
flights
of
steps
in
this
awful
street
,
and
from
these
petrified
bowers
,
extinguishers
for
obsolete
flambeaux
gasp
at
the
upstart
gas
.
 
<EOS>
Here
<EOS>
and
there
a
weak
little
iron
hoop
,
through
which
bold
boys
aspire
to
throw
their
friends
'
caps
(
its
only
present
use
)
,
retains
its
place
among
the
rusty
foliage
,
sacred
to
the
memory
of
departed
oil
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
even
oil
itself
,
yet
lingering
at
long
intervals
in
a
little
absurd
glass
pot
,
with
a
knob
in
the
bottom
like
an
oyster
,
blinks
and
sulks
at
newer
lights
every
night
,
like
its
high
and
dry
master
in
the
House
of
Lords
.
   
<EOS>
Therefore
there
is
not
much
that
Lady
Dedlock
,
seated
in
her
chair
,
could
wish
to
see
through
the
window
in
which
Mr
Tulkinghorn
stands
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
---
and
yet
---
she
sends
a
look
in
that
direction
as
if
it
were
her
heart
's
desire
to
have
that
figure
moved
out
of
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
begs
his
Lady
's

.
 
<EOS>
She
was
about
to
say
?
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only
that
Mr
Rouncewell
is
here
(
he
has
called

)
and
that

had

of
that
girl
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
tired
to
death
of

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
do
---
to
---
assist
?
<EOS>
"

Leicester
in
some

.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
us
see

here
and

.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
tell
them
to
send
him
up
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
be
so

as

ring
.
 
<EOS>
Thank

.
 
<EOS>
Request
,
"
says
Sir
Leicester
to

,

,
"

iron

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mercury
departs
in

of
the
iron

,
finds
,
and
produces

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
receives
that
ferruginous
person

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
well
,
Mr
Rouncewell
.
 
<EOS>
Be
seated
.
 
<EOS>
(
My
solicitor
,
Mr
Tulkinghorn
.
)
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
was
desirous
,
Mr
Rouncewell
,
"
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
skilfully

him
with

solemn

,
"
was
desirous
to
speak
with

.
 
<EOS>
Hem
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
very
happy
,
"
returns
the
iron
gentleman
,
"
to
give
my
best
attention
to
anything
Lady
Dedlock
does
me
the
honour
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
turns
towards
her
,
he
finds
that
the
impression
she
makes
upon
him
is
less
agreeable
than
on
the
former
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
A
distant
supercilious
air
makes
a
cold
atmosphere
about
her
,
and
there
is
nothing
in
her
bearing
,
as
there
was
before
,
to
encourage
openness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
sir
,
"
says
Lady
Dedlock
listlessly
,
"
may
I
be
allowed
to
inquire
whether
anything
has
passed
between
you
and
your
son
respecting
your
son
's
fancy
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
almost
too
troublesome
to
her
languid
eyes
to
bestow
a
look
upon
him
as
she
asks
this
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
my
memory
serves
me
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
I
said
,
when

the
pleasure
of
seeing
you
before
,
that
I
should
seriously

my
son
to
conquer
that
---
fancy
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
ironmaster
repeats
her
expression
with
a
little
emphasis
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
did
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Of
course
I
did
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
gives
a
nod
,
approving
and
confirmatory
.
 
<EOS>
Very
proper
.
 
<EOS>
The
iron
gentleman
,
having
said
that
he
would
do
it
,
was
bound
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
No
difference
in
this
respect
between
the
base
metals
and
the
precious
.
 
<EOS>
Highly
proper
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
pray
has
he
done
so
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
I
can
not
make
you
a
definite
reply
.
 
<EOS>
I
fear
not
.
 
<EOS>
Probably
not
yet
.
 
<EOS>
In
our
condition
of
life
,
we
sometimes
couple
an
intention
with
our
---
our
fancies
which
renders
them
not
altogether
easy
to
throw
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
it
is
rather
our
way
to
be
in

.
"
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
has
a
misgiving
that
there
may

a
hidden
Wat
Tylerish
meaning
in
this

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Rouncewell
is
perfectly
good
-
humoured
and
polite
,
but
within
such
limits
,
evidently
adapts
his
tone
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
proceeds

Lady
,
"
I
have
been
thinking
of
the
subject
,
which
is
tiresome
to

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very

,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
also
of
what
Sir
Leicester
said
upon

,

I
quite
concur
"
---
Sir
Leicester
flattered
---
"
and

us

this

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
Lady

.
 
<EOS>
Nothing

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
she
had
better
go
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Excuse

,
my
Lady
,
"
Sir
Leicester
considerately

,
"
but
perhaps
this
may
be
doing
an
injury
to
the
young
woman
which
she

not

.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
a
young
woman
,
"
says
Sir
Leicester
,
magnificently

the
matter
with
his

like

plate
,
"
whose
good

it
is
to
have
attracted
the
notice
and

an
eminent

and
to
live
,
under

protection
of
that

,

such

,
and

are

great
---
I
believe
unquestionably
very

,

---

a
young
woman
in
that
station
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
The
question
then
arises
,
should
that
young
woman
be
deprived
of
these
many
advantages
and
that
good
fortune
simply
because
she
has
"
---
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
,
with
an

ironmaster
,
winds

---
"
has
attracted
the
notice
of
Mr
Rouncewell
's
son
?
 
<EOS>
Now
,
has
she
deserved
this
punishment
?
 
<EOS>
Is
this
just
towards
her
?
 
<EOS>
Is
this
our
previous
understanding
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
interposes
Mr
Rouncewell
's
son
's
father
.
"
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
,
will
you
allow
me
?
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
may
shorten
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
dismiss
that
from
your
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
remember
anything
so
unimportant
---
which
is
not
to
be
expected
---
you
would
recollect
that
my
first
thought
in
the
affair
was
directly
opposed
to
her
remaining
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Dismiss
the
Dedlock
patronage
from
consideration
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
is
bound
to
believe
a
pair
of
ears
that
have
been
handed
down
to
him
through
such
a
family
,
or
he
really
might
have
mistrusted
their
report
of
the
iron
gentleman
's
observations
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
necessary
,
"
observes
my
Lady
in
her
coldest
manner
before
he
can
do
anything
but
breathe
amazedly
,
"
to
enter
into
these
matters
on
either
side
.
 
<EOS>
The
girl
is
a
very
good
girl
;
I
have
nothing
whatever

say
against
her
,
but
she
is
so
far

to
her
many

and
her

that
she
is
in
love
---
or
supposes
she
is
,
poor
little
fool
---
and
unable
to
appreciate
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
begs
to
observe
that
wholly
alters
the
case
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
have
been
sure
that
my
Lady
had
the
best
grounds
and
reasons
in
support
of
her
view
.
 
<EOS>
He
entirely
agrees
with
my
Lady
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
woman
had
better
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
Sir
Leicester
observed
,
Mr
Rouncewell
,
on
the
last

when
we
were
fatigued
by
this
business
,
"
Lady
Dedlock

,
"
we
can
not

.
 
<EOS>
Without

,
and

present

,
the

is

here

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
told

so
.
 
<EOS>
Would

,
or

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lady
Dedlock
,

---
"
   
"
By

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
---
I

the
course
which
will
the
soonest
relieve

of
the
incumbrance
and
remove
her
from
her

.
"
   
"
And
to

,
"
she

,
"
so
should
I.
 
<EOS>
Do
I
understand
that
you
will
take
her
with
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
iron
gentleman
makes
an
iron
bow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
Leicester
,
will
you
ring
?
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
steps
forward
from
his
window
and
pulls
the
bell
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
had
forgotten
you
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
"
<EOS>
He
makes
his
usual

and

.
 
<EOS>
Mercury
,
swift
-
responsive
,
appears
,
receives
instructions
whom

,
skims

,
produces

,

.
   
<EOS>
Rosa
has
been

and
is
yet

.
 
<EOS>
On

,
the
ironmaster

,

,
and

<EOS>
"
You

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

"
There
,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Sir

<EOS>
Mr

Sir

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.

Sir

.

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
If

<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
Sir

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>

"

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
But

---

one

---
<EOS>
and

,

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Sir

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

,

.

,

.

"

,

"
Yes

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

?
 
<EOS>
Spare
!
 
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
,
here
is
a
family
name
compromised
.
 
<EOS>
One
might
have
supposed
that
the
course
was
straight
on
---
over
everything
,
neither
to
the
right
nor
to
the
left
,
regardless
of
all
considerations
in
the
way
,
sparing
nothing
,
treading
everything
under
foot
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
has
been
looking
at
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
She
lifts
up
her
eyes
and
looks
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
stern
expression
on
her
face
and
a
part
of
her
lower
lip
is
compressed
under
her
teeth
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
woman
understands
me
,
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
thinks
as
she
lets
her
glance
fall
again
.
<EOS>
"
SHE
can
not
be
spared
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
she
spare
others
?
"
   
<EOS>
For
a
little
while
they
are
silent
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Dedlock
has
eaten
no
dinner
,
but
has
twice
or
thrice
poured
out
water
with
a
steady
hand
and
drunk
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
rises
from
table
,
takes
a
lounging
-
chair
,
and
reclines
in
it
,
shading
her
face
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
in
her
manner
to
express
weakness
or
excite
compassion
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
thoughtful
,
gloomy
,
concentrated
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
woman
,
"
thinks
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
standing
on
the
hearth
,
again
a
dark
object
closing
up
her
view
,
"
is
a
study
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
studies
her
at
his
leisure
,
not
speaking
for
a
time
.
 
<EOS>
She
too
studies
something
at
her
leisure
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
not
the
first
to
speak
,
appearing
indeed
so
unlikely
to
be
so
,
though
he
stood
there
until
midnight
,
that
even
he
is
driven
upon
breaking
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lady
Dedlock
,
the
most
disagreeable
part
of
this
business
interview
remains
,
but
it
is
business
.
 
<EOS>
Our
agreement
is
broken
.
 
<EOS>
A
lady
of
your
sense
and
strength
of
character
will
be
prepared
for
my
now
declaring
it
void
and
taking
my
own
course
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
prepared
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
inclines
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
all
I
have
to
trouble
you
with
,
Lady
Dedlock
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
stops
him
as
he
is
moving
out
of
the
room
by
asking
,
"
This
is
the
notice
I
was
to
receive
?
 
<EOS>
I
wish
not
to
misapprehend
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
the
notice
you
were
to
receive
,
Lady
Dedlock
,
because
the
contemplated
notice
supposed
the
agreement
to
have
been
observed
.
 
<EOS>
But
virtually
the
same
,
virtually
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
The
difference
is
merely
in
a
lawyer
's
mind
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
intend
to
give
me
no
other
notice
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
contemplate
undeceiving
Sir
Leicester
to
-
night
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
home
question
!
<EOS>
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
with
a
slight
smile
and
cautiously
shaking
his
head
at
the
shaded
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
things
considered
,
I
had
better
decline
answering
that
question
,
Lady
Dedlock
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
were
to
say
I
do
n't
know
when
,
exactly
,
you
would
not
believe
me
,
and
it
would
answer
no
purpose
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
rather
say
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
prepared
,
and
I
hold
out
no
expectations
which
circumstances
might
fail
to
justify
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
good
evening
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
removes
her
hand
,
turns
her
pale
face
towards
him
as
he
walks
silently
to
the
door
,
and
stops
him
once
again
as
he
is
about
to
open
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
intend
to
remain
in
the
house
any
time
?
 
<EOS>
I
heard
you
were
writing
in
the
library
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
going
to
return
there
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
for
my
hat
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
bows
her
eyes
rather
than
her
head
,
the
movement
is
so
slight
and
curious
,
and
he
withdraws
.
 
<EOS>
Clear
of
the
room
<EOS>
he
looks
at
his
watch
but
is
inclined
to
doubt
it
by
a
minute
or
thereabouts
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
splendid
clock
upon
the
staircase
,
famous
,
as
splendid
clocks
not
often
are
,
for
its
accuracy
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
YOU
say
,
"
Mr
Tulkinghorn
inquires
,
referring
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
If
it
said
now
,
"
Do
n't
go
home
!
"
 
<EOS>
What
a
famous
clock
,
hereafter
,
if
it
said
to
-
night
of
all
the
nights
that
it
has
counted
off
,
to
this
old
man
of
all
the
young
and
old
men
who
have
ever
stood
before
it
,
"
Do
n't
go
home
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
its
sharp
clear
bell
it
strikes
three
quarters
after
seven
and
ticks
on
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
are
worse
than
I
thought
you
,
"
says
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
muttering
reproof
to
his
watch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Two
minutes
wrong
?
 
<EOS>
At
this
rate
you
wo
n't
last
my
time
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
watch
to
return
good
for
evil
if
it
ticked
in
answer
,
"
Do
n't
go
home
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
passes
out
into
the
streets
and
walks
on
,
with
his
hands
behind
him
,
under
the
shadow
of
the
lofty
houses
,
many
of
whose
mysteries
,
difficulties
,
mortgages
,
delicate
affairs
of
all
kinds
,
are
treasured
up
within
his
old
black
satin
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
in
the
confidence
of
the
very
bricks
and
mortar
.
 
<EOS>
The
high
chimney
-
stacks
telegraph
family
secrets
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
there
is
not
a
voice
in
a
mile
of
them
to
whisper
,
"
Do
n't
go
home
!
"
   
<EOS>
Through
the
stir
and
motion
of
the
commoner
streets
;
through
the
roar
and
jar
of
many
vehicles
,
many
feet
,
many
voices
;
with
the
blazing
shop
-
lights
lighting
him
on
,
the
west
wind
blowing
him
on
,
and
the
crowd
pressing
him
on
,
he
is
pitilessly
urged
upon
his
way
,
and
nothing
meets
him
murmuring
,
"
Do
n't
go
home
!
"
 
<EOS>
Arrived
at
last
in
his
dull
room
to
light
his
candles
,
and
look
round
and
up
,
and
see
the
Roman
pointing
from
the
ceiling
,
there
is
no
new
significance
in
the
Roman
's
hand
to
-
night
or
in
the
flutter
of
the
attendant
groups
to
give
him
the
late
warning
,
"
Do
n't
come
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
moonlight
night
,
but
the
moon
,
being
past
the
full
,
is
only
now
rising
over
the
great
wilderness
of
London
.
 
<EOS>
The
stars
are
shining
as
they
shone
above
the
turret
-
leads
at
Chesney
Wold
.
 
<EOS>
This
woman
,
as
he
has
of
late
been
so
accustomed
to
call
her
,
looks
out
upon
them
.
 
<EOS>
Her
soul
is
turbulent
within
her
;
she
is
sick
at
heart
and
restless
.
 
<EOS>
The
large
rooms
are
too
cramped
and
close
.
 
<EOS>
She
can
not
endure
their
restraint
and
will
walk
alone
in
a
neighbouring
garden
.
   
<EOS>
Too
capricious
and
imperious
in
all
she
does
to
be
the
cause
of
much
surprise
in
those
about
her
as
to
anything
she
does
,
this
woman
,
loosely
muffled
,
goes
out
into
the
moonlight
.
 
<EOS>
Mercury
attends
with
the
key
.
 
<EOS>
Having
opened
the
garden
-
gate
,
he
delivers
the
key
into
his
Lady
's
hands
at
her
request
and
is
bidden
to
go
back
.
 
<EOS>
She
will
walk
there
some
time
to
ease
her
aching
head
.
 
<EOS>
She
may
be
an
hour
,
she
may
be
more
.
 
<EOS>
She
needs
no
further
escort
.
 
<EOS>
The
gate
shuts
upon
its
spring
with
a
clash
,
and
he
leaves
her
passing
on
into
the
dark
shade
of
some
trees
.
   
<EOS>
A
fine
night
,
and
a
bright
large
moon
,
and
multitudes
of
stars
.
<EOS>
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
in
repairing
to
his
cellar
and
in
opening
and
shutting
those
resounding
doors
,
has
to
cross
a
little
prison
-
like
yard
.
 
<EOS>
He
looks
up
casually
,
thinking
what
a
fine
night
,
what
a
bright
large
moon
,
what
multitudes
of
stars
!
 
<EOS>
A
quiet
night
,
too
.
   
<EOS>
A
very
quiet
night
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
moon
shines
very
brilliantly
,
a
solitude
and
stillness
seem
to
proceed
from
her
<EOS>
that
influence
even
crowded
places
full
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
Not
only
is
it
a
still
night
on
dusty
high
roads
and
on
hill
-
summits
,
whence
a
wide
expanse
of
country
may
be
seen
in
repose
,
quieter
and
quieter
as
it
spreads
away
into
a
fringe
of
trees
against
the
sky
with
the
grey
ghost
of
a
bloom
upon
them
;
not
only
<EOS>
is
it
a
still
night
in
gardens
and
in
woods
,
and
on
the
river
where
the
water
-
meadows
are
fresh
and
green
,
and
the
stream
sparkles
on
among
pleasant
islands
,
murmuring
weirs
,
and
whispering
rushes
;
not
only
does
the
stillness
attend
it
as
it
flows
where
houses
cluster
thick
,
where
many
bridges
are
reflected
in
it
,
where
wharves
and
shipping
make
it
black
and
awful
,
<EOS>
where
it
winds
from
these
disfigurements
through
marshes
whose
grim
beacons
stand
like
skeletons
washed
ashore
,
where
it
expands
through
the
bolder
region
of
rising
grounds
,
rich
in
cornfield
wind
-
mill
and
steeple
,
and
where
it
mingles
with
the
ever
-
heaving
sea
;
not
only
is
it
a
still
night
on
the
deep
,
and
on
the
shore
where
the
watcher
stands
to
see
the
ship
with
her
spread
wings
cross
the
path
of
light
that
appears
to
be
presented
to
only
him
;
but
even
on
this
stranger
's
wilderness
of
London
there
is
some
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Its
steeples
and
towers
and
its
one
great
dome
grow
more
ethereal
;
its
smoky
house
-
tops
lose
their
grossness
in
the
pale
effulgence
;
the
noises
that
arise
from
the
streets
are
fewer
and
are
softened
,
and
the
footsteps
on
the
pavements
pass
more
tranquilly
away
.
 
<EOS>
In
these
fields
of
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
inhabiting
,
where
the
shepherds
play
on
Chancery
pipes
that
have
no
stop
,
and
keep
their
sheep
in
the
fold
by
hook
and
by
crook
until
they
have
shorn
them
exceeding
close
,
every
noise
is
merged
,
this
moonlight
night
,
into
a
distant
ringing
hum
,
as
if
the
city
were
a
vast
glass
,
vibrating
.
   
<EOS>
What
's
that
?
 
<EOS>
Who
fired
a
gun
or
pistol
?
 
<EOS>
Where
was
it
?
   
<EOS>
The
few
foot
-
passengers
start
,
stop
,
and
stare
about
them
.
 
<EOS>
Some
windows
and
doors
are
opened
,
and
people
come
out
to
look
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
loud
report
and
echoed
and
rattled
heavily
.
 
<EOS>
It
shook
one
house
,
or
so
a
man
says
who
was
passing
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
aroused
all
the
dogs
in
the
neighbourhood
,
who
bark
vehemently
.
 
<EOS>
Terrified
cats
scamper
across
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
While
the
dogs
are
yet
barking
and
howling
---
there
is
one
dog
howling
like
a
demon
---
the
church
-
clocks
,
as
if
they
were
startled
too
,
begin
to
strike
.
 
<EOS>
The
hum
from
the
streets
,
likewise
,
seems
to
swell
into
a
shout
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
soon
over
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the
last
clock
begins
to
strike
ten
,
there
is
a
lull
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
has
ceased
,
the
fine
night
,
the
bright
large
moon
,
and
multitudes
of
stars
,
are
left
at
peace
again
.
   
<EOS>
Has
Mr
Tulkinghorn
been
disturbed
?
 
<EOS>
His
windows
are
dark
and
quiet
,
and
his
door
is
shut
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
be
something
unusual
indeed
to
bring
him
out
of
his
shell
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
is
heard
of
him
,
nothing
is
seen
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
What
power
of
cannon
might
it
take
to
shake
that
rusty
old
man
out
of
his
immovable
composure
?
   
<EOS>
For
many
years
the
persistent
Roman
has
been
pointing
,
with
no
particular
meaning
,
from
that
ceiling
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
likely
that
he
has
any
new
meaning
in
him
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Once
pointing
,
always
pointing
---
like
any
Roman
,
or
even
Briton
,
with
a
single
idea
.
<EOS>
There
he
is
,
no
doubt
,
in
his
impossible
attitude
,
pointing
,
unavailingly
,
all
night
long
.
 
<EOS>
Moonlight
,
darkness
,
dawn
,
sunrise
,
day
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
is
still
,
eagerly
pointing
,
and
no
one
minds
him
.
   
<EOS>
But
a
little
after
the
coming
of
the
day
come
people
to
clean
the
rooms
.
 
<EOS>
And
either
the
Roman
has
some
new
meaning
in
him
,
not
expressed
before
,
or
the
foremost
of
them
goes
wild
,
for
looking
up
at
his
outstretched
hand
and
looking
down
at
what
is
below
it
,
that
person
shrieks
and
flies
.
 
<EOS>
The
others
,
looking
in
as
the
first
one
looked
,
shriek
and
fly
too
,
and
there
is
an
alarm
in
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
What
does
it
mean
?
 
<EOS>
No
light
is
admitted
into
the
darkened
chamber
,
and
people
unaccustomed
to
it
enter
,
and
treading
softly
but
heavily
,
carry
a
weight
into
the
bedroom
and
lay
it
down
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
whispering
and
wondering
all
day
,
strict
search
of
every
corner
,
careful
tracing
of
steps
,
and
careful
noting
of
the
disposition
of
every
article
of
furniture
.
 
<EOS>
All
eyes
look
up
at
the
Roman
,
and
all
voices
murmur
,
"
If
he
could
only
tell
what
he
saw
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
is
pointing
at
a
table
with
a
bottle
(
nearly
full
of
wine
)
and
a
glass
upon
it
and
two
candles
that
were
blown
out
suddenly
soon
after
being
lighted
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
pointing
at
an
empty
chair
and
at
a
stain
upon
the
ground
before
it
that
might
be
almost
covered
with
a
hand
.
 
<EOS>
These
objects
lie
directly
within
his
range
.
 
<EOS>
An
excited
imagination
might
suppose
that
there
was
something
in
them
so
terrific
as
to
drive
the
rest
of
the
composition
,
not
only
the
attendant
big
-
legged
boys
,
but
the
clouds
and
flowers
and
pillars
too
---
in
short
,
the
very
body
and
soul
of
Allegory
,
and
all
the
brains
it
has
<EOS>
---
stark
mad
.
 
<EOS>
It
happens
surely
that
every
one
who
comes
into
the
darkened
room
and
looks
at
these
things
looks
up
at
the
Roman
and
that
he
is
invested
in
all
eyes
with
mystery
and
awe
,
as
if
he
were
a
paralysed
dumb
witness
.
   
<EOS>
So
it
shall
happen
surely
,
through
many
years
to
come
,
that
ghostly
stories
shall
be
told
of
the
stain
upon
the
floor
,
so
easy
to
be
covered
,
so
hard
to
be
got
out
,
and
that
the
Roman
,
pointing
from
the
ceiling
shall
point
,
so
long
as
dust
and
damp
and
spiders
spare
him
,
with
far
greater
significance
than
he
ever
had
in
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
time
,
and
with
a
deadly
meaning
.
 
<EOS>
For
Mr
Tulkinghorn
's
time
is
over
for
evermore
,
and
the
Roman
pointed
at
the
murderous
hand
uplifted
against
his
life
,
and
pointed
helplessly
at
him
,
from
night
to
morning
,
lying
face
downward
on
the
floor
,
shot
through
the
heart
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
49
.
<EOS>
Dutiful
Friendship
 
<EOS>
A
great
annual
occasion
has
come
round
in
the
establishment
of
Mr
Matthew
Bagnet
,
otherwise
Lignum
Vitae
,
ex
-
artilleryman
and
present
bassoon
-
player
.
 
<EOS>
An
occasion
of
feasting
and
festival
.
 
<EOS>
The
celebration
of
a
birthday
in
the
family
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
not
Mr
Bagnet
's
birthday
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bagnet
merely
distinguishes
that
epoch
in
the
musical
instrument
business
by
kissing
the
children
with
an
extra
smack
before
breakfast
,
smoking
an
additional
pipe
after
dinner
,
and
wondering
towards
evening
what
his
poor
old
mother
is
thinking
about
it
---
a
subject
of
infinite
speculation
,
and
rendered
so
by
his
mother
having
departed
this
life
twenty
years
.
 
<EOS>
Some
men
rarely
revert
to
their
father
,
but
seem
,
in
the
bank
-
books
of
their
remembrance
,
to
have
transferred
all
the
stock
of
filial
affection
into
their
mother
's
name
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bagnet
is
one
of
like
his
trade
the
better
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
kept
clear
of
his
old
girl
causes
him
usually
to
make
the
noun
-
substantive
"
goodness
"
of
the
feminine
gender
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
not
the
birthday
of
one
of
the
three
children
.
 
<EOS>
Those
occasions
are
kept
with
some
marks
of
distinction
,
but
they
rarely
overleap
the
bounds
of
happy
returns
and
a
pudding
.
 
<EOS>
On
young
Woolwich
's
last
birthday
,
Mr
Bagnet
certainly
did
,
after
observing
on
his
growth
and
general
advancement
,
proceed
,
in
a
moment
of
profound
reflection
on
the
changes
wrought
by
time
,
to
examine
him
in
the
catechism
,
accomplishing
with
extreme
accuracy
the
questions
number
one
and
two
,
"
What
is
your
name
?
"
<EOS>
and
"
Who
gave
you
that
name
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
but
there
failing
in
the
exact
precision
of
his
memory
and
substituting
for
number
three
the
question
"
<EOS>
And
how
do
you
like
that
name
?
"
<EOS>
which
he
propounded
with
a
sense
of
its
importance
,
in
itself
so
edifying
and
improving
as
to
give
it
quite
an
orthodox
air
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
was
a
speciality
on
that
particular
birthday
,
and
not
a
general
solemnity
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
the
old
girl
's
birthday
,
and
that
is
the
greatest
holiday
and
reddest
-
letter
day
in
Mr
Bagnet
's
calendar
.
 
<EOS>
The
auspicious
event
is
always
commemorated
according
to
certain
forms
settled
and
prescribed
by
Mr
Bagnet
some
years
since
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bagnet
,
being
deeply
convinced
that
to
have
a
pair
of
fowls
for
dinner
is
to
attain
the
highest
pitch
of
imperial
luxury
,
invariably
goes
forth
himself
very
early
in
the
morning
of
this
day
to
buy
a
pair
;
he
is
,
as
invariably
,
taken
in
by
the
vendor
and
installed
in
the
possession
of
the
oldest
inhabitants
of
any
coop
in
Europe
.
<EOS>
Returning
with
these
triumphs
of
toughness
tied
up
in
a
clean
blue
and
white
cotton
handkerchief
(
essential
to
the
arrangements
)
,
he
in
a
casual
manner
invites
Mrs
Bagnet
to
declare
at
breakfast
what
she
would
like
for
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bagnet
,
by
a
coincidence
never
known
to
fail
,
replying
fowls
,
Mr
Bagnet
instantly
produces
his
bundle
from
a
place
of
concealment
amidst
general
amazement
and
rejoicing
.
 
<EOS>
He
further
requires
that
the
old
girl
shall
do
nothing
all
day
long
but
sit
in
her
very
best
gown
and
be
served
by
himself
and
the
young
people
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
is
not
illustrious
for
his
cookery
,
this
may
be
supposed
to
be
a
matter
of
state
rather
than
enjoyment
on
the
old
girl
's
part
,
but
she
keeps
her
state
with
all
imaginable
cheerfulness
.
   
<EOS>
On
this
present
birthday
,
Mr
Bagnet
has
accomplished
the
usual
preliminaries
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
bought
two
specimens
of
poultry
,
which
,
if
there
be
any
truth
in
adages
,
were
certainly
not
caught
with
chaff
,
to
be
prepared
for
the
spit
;
he
has
amazed
and
rejoiced
the
family
by
their
unlooked
-
for
production
;
he
is
himself
directing
the
roasting
of
the
poultry
;
and
Mrs
Bagnet
,
with
her
wholesome
brown
fingers
itching
to
prevent
what
she
sees
going
wrong
,
sits
in
her
gown
of
ceremony
,
an
honoured
guest
.
   
<EOS>
Quebec
and
Malta
lay
the
cloth
for
dinner
,
while
Woolwich
,
serving
,
as
beseems
him
,
under
his
father
,
keeps
the
fowls
revolving
.
 
<EOS>
To
these
young
scullions
Mrs
Bagnet
occasionally
imparts
a
wink
,
or
a
shake
of
the
head
,
or
a
crooked
face
,
as
they
made
mistakes
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
half
after
one
.
"
 
<EOS>
Says
Mr
Bagnet
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
the
minute
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
be
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bagnet
,
with
anguish
,
beholds
one
of
them
at
a
standstill
before
the
fire
and
beginning
to
burn
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
a
dinner
,
old
girl
,
"
says
Mr
Bagnet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fit
for
a
queen
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bagnet
shows
her
white
teeth
cheerfully
,
but
to
the
perception
of
her
son
,
betrays
so
much
uneasiness
of
spirit
that
he
is
impelled
by
the
dictates
of
affection
to
ask
her
,
<EOS>
with
his
eyes
,
what
is
the
matter
,
thus
standing
,
with
his
eyes
wide
open
,
more
oblivious
of
the
fowls
than
before
,
and
not
affording
the
least
hope
of
a
return
to

.
 
<EOS>
Fortunately
his
elder
sister
perceives
the
cause
of
the
agitation
in
Mrs
Bagnet
's
breast
and
with
an

poke
recalls
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
stopped
fowls
going
round
again
,
Mrs
Bagnet
closes
her
eyes
in
the
intensity
of
her
relief
.
   
<EOS>
"
George
will
look
us
up
,
"
says
Mr
Bagnet
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
half
after
four
.
<EOS>
To
the
moment
.
 
<EOS>
How
many
years
,
old
girl
.
 
<EOS>
Has
George
looked
us
up
.
<EOS>
This
afternoon
?
"
   
"
Ah
,
Lignum
,
Lignum
,
as
many
as
make
an
old
woman
of
a
young
one
,
I
begin
to
think
.
 
<EOS>
Just
about
that
,
and
no

,
"
returns
Mrs
Bagnet
,
laughing
and

her

.
   
<EOS>
"
Old
girl
,
"
says
Mr
Bagnet
,
"
never
mind
.
 
<EOS>
You
'd
be
as
young
as
ever
<EOS>
you
was
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
was
n't
younger
.
 
<EOS>
Which
you
are
.
 
<EOS>
As
everybody
knows
.
"
   
<EOS>
Quebec
and
Malta
here
exclaim
,
with
clapping
of
hands
,
that
Bluffy
is
sure
to
bring
mother
something
,
and
begin
to
speculate
on
what
it
will

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
Lignum
,
"
says
Mrs
Bagnet
,
casting
a

on
the
table
-
cloth
,
and
winking
"
salt
!
"
<EOS>
at
Malta
with
her
right
eye
,
and
shaking
the
pepper
away
from
Quebec
with
her
head
,
"
I
begin
to
think
George
is
in
the
roving

again
.
   
<EOS>
"
George
,
"
returns
Mr
Bagnet
,
"
will
never

.
 
<EOS>
And
leave
his
old
comrade
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
lurch
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
afraid
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Lignum
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
say

will
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

will
.
<EOS>
But
if
he
could

this
money

of
his
,
I

he
would

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bagnet
asks
why
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
returns
his
wife
,
considering
,
"
George
seems
to
me
to
be
getting
not
a
little

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
say
<EOS>
but
what
he
's
as
free

.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
he
must
be
free
or
he
would
n't
be
George
,
but
he
smarts
and
seems
put
out
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
extra
-

,
"
says
Mr
Bagnet
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
a
lawyer
.
 
<EOS>
Who
would
put
the
devil
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
something
in
that
,
"
his
wife
assents
;
"
but
so
it
is
,
Lignum
.
"
   
<EOS>
Further
conversation
is
prevented
,
for
the
time
,
by
the
necessity
under
which
Mr
Bagnet
finds
himself
of
directing
the
whole
force
of
his
mind
to
the
dinner
,
which
is
a
little
endangered
by
the
dry
humour
of
the
fowls
in
not
yielding
any
gravy
,
and
also
by
the
made
gravy
acquiring
no
flavour
and
turning
out
of
a
flaxen
complexion
.
<EOS>
With
a
similar
perverseness
,
the
potatoes
crumble
off
forks
in
the
process
of
peeling
,
upheaving
from
their
centres
in
every
direction
,
as
if
they
were
subject
to
earthquakes
.
 
<EOS>
The
legs
of
the
fowls
,
too
,
are
longer
than
could
be
desired
,
and
extremely
scaly
.
<EOS>
Overcoming
these
disadvantages
to
the
best
of
his
ability
,
Mr
Bagnet
at
last
dishes
and
they
sit
down
at
table
,
Mrs
Bagnet
occupying
the
guest
's
place
at
his
right
hand
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
well
for
the
old
girl
that
she
has
but
one
birthday
in
a
year
,
for
two
such
indulgences
in
poultry
might
be
injurious
.
<EOS>
Every
kind
of
finer
tendon
and
ligament
that
is
in
the
nature
of
poultry
to
possess
is
developed
in
these
specimens
in
the
singular
form
of
guitar
-
strings
.
 
<EOS>
Their
limbs
appear
to
have
struck
roots
into
their
breasts
and
bodies
,
as
aged
trees
strike
roots
into
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
Their
legs
are
so
hard
as
to
encourage
the
idea
that
they
must
have
devoted
the
greater
part
of
their
long
and
arduous
lives
to
pedestrian
exercises
and
the
walking
of
matches
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Bagnet
,
unconscious
of
these
little
defects
,
sets
his
heart
on
Mrs
Bagnet
eating
a
most
severe
quantity
of
the
delicacies
before
her
;
and
as
that
good
old
girl
would
not
cause
him
a
moment
's
disappointment
on
any
day
,
least
of
all
on
such
a
day
,
for
any
consideration
,
she
imperils
her
digestion
fearfully
.
 
<EOS>
How
young
Woolwich
cleans
the
drum
-
sticks
without
being
of
ostrich
descent
,
his
anxious
mother
is
at
a
loss
to
understand
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
girl
has
another
trial
to
undergo
after
the
conclusion
of
the
repast
in
sitting
in
state
to
see
the
room
cleared
,
the
hearth
swept
,
and
the
dinner
-
service
washed
up
and
polished
in
the
backyard
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
delight
and
energy
with
which
the
two
young
ladies
apply
themselves
to
these
duties
,
turning
up
their
skirts
in
imitation
of
their
mother
and
skating
in
and
out
on
little
scaffolds
of
pattens
,
inspire
the
highest
hopes
for
the
future
,
but
some
anxiety
for
the
present
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
causes
lead
to
confusion
of
tongues
,
a
clattering
of
crockery
,
a
rattling
of
tin
mugs
,
a
whisking
of
brooms
,
and
an
expenditure
of
water
,
all
in
excess
,
while
the
saturation
of
the
young
ladies
themselves
is
almost
too
moving
a
spectacle
for
Mrs
Bagnet
to
look
upon
with
the
calmness
proper
to
her
position
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
the
various
cleansing
processes
are
triumphantly
completed
;
Quebec
and
Malta
appear
in
fresh
attire
,
smiling
and
dry
;
pipes
,
tobacco
,
and
something
to
drink
are
placed
upon
the
table
;
and
the
old
girl
enjoys
the
first
peace
of
mind
she
ever
knows
on
the
day
of
this
delightful
entertainment
.
   
<EOS>
When
Mr
Bagnet
takes
his
usual
seat
,
the
hands
of
the
clock
are
very
near
to
half
-
past
four
;
as
they
mark
it
accurately
,
Mr
Bagnet
announces
,
"
George
!
 
<EOS>
Military
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
George
,
and
he
has
hearty
congratulations
for
the
old
girl
(
whom
he
kisses
on
the
great
occasion
)
,
and
for
the
children
,
and
for
Mr
Bagnet
.
 
<EOS>
"
Happy
returns
to

,

Bucket
returns
to
his
chair
next
his
friend
Mr
George
and
pats
Mr
George
affectionately
on
the
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
your
spirits
now
,
George
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
now
,
"
returns
the
trooper
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
your
sort
!
"
says
Mr
Bucket
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
ever
have
been
otherwise
?
 
<EOS>
A
man
of
your
fine
figure
and
constitution
has
no
right
to
be
out
of
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
That
ai
n't
a
chest
to
be
out
of
spirits
,
is
it
,
ma'am
?
 
<EOS>
And
you
have
n't
got
anything
on
your
mind
,
you
know
,
George
;
what
could
you
have
on
your
mind
!
"
   
<EOS>
Somewhat
harping
on
this
phrase
,
considering
the
extent
and
variety
of
his
conversational
powers
<EOS>
,
Mr
Bucket
twice
or
thrice
repeats
it
to
the
pipe
he
lights
,
and
with
a
listening
face
that
is
particularly
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
sun
of
his
sociality
soon
recovers
from
this

and
shines
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
this
is
brother
,
is

,
my
dears
?
"
says
Mr
Bucket
,
referring
to
Quebec
and
Malta
for
information
on
the
subject
of
young
Woolwich
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
a
nice
brother
<EOS>
he
is
---
<EOS>
half
-
brother
<EOS>
I
mean
to
say
.
<EOS>
For
he
's
too
old
to
be
your
boy
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
certify
at
all
events
that
he
is
not
anybody
else
's
,
"
returns
Mrs
Bagnet
,
laughing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
you
do
surprise
me
!
 
<EOS>
Yet
he
's
like
you
<EOS>
,
there
's
no
denying
.
<EOS>
Lord
,
he
's

!
 
<EOS>
But
about
what

may
call
the
brow
,
you

,
THERE
his
father
comes
out
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
compares
the
faces
with
one
eye
shut

,
while
Mr
Bagnet
smokes
in
stolid

.
   
<EOS>
This
is
an

for
Mrs
Bagnet
to
inform

that
the
boy

George
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
George
's
godson
,
is
he
?
"
<EOS>
rejoins
Mr
Bucket
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
shake

again
with
George
's
godson
.
<EOS>
Godfather
and
godson
do
credit
to

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

?
 
<EOS>
Does

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bagnet
suddenly

,
"
Plays
the
fife
.
 
<EOS>
Beautiful
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
believe

,
governor
,
"
says
Mr
Bucket
,
struck
by
the

,
"
that

played

?
 
<EOS>
Not

,

I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord

!
 
<EOS>
"
British
Grenadiers
"
<EOS>
---
there
's
a

to

Englishman
up
!
 
<EOS>
COULD

give

"
British
Grenadiers
,
"
my
fine

?
"
   
<EOS>
Nothing

upon
young
Woolwich
,
who
immediately

and
performs

,
during
which
performance
Mr
Bucket
,
much

,
beats

and
never
falls
to
come
in

with

burden
,
"
British
Gra
-
a
-
anadeers
!
"
 
<EOS>
In

,
he
shows
so

that
Mr
Bagnet
actually
takes
his

from
his

to
express

conviction
that
he
is
a

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
receives
the

impeachment
so
modestly
,
confessing
how
that
he
did
once
chaunt
a
little
,
for
the
expression
of
the

of
his
own

,
and
with
no

of

,
that
he
is

to

.
 
<EOS>
Not

in
the
sociality
of
the
evening
,
he
complies
and
gives
them
<EOS>
"
Believe
Me
,
if
All
Those
Endearing
Young
Charms
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
ballad
,
he
informs
Mrs
Bagnet
,
he
considers
to
have
been
his
most

ally
in
moving
the

of
Mrs
Bucket
when

,

---
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
's
own
words
are
"
to
come
up
to
the
scratch
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
sparkling
stranger
is
such
a
new
and
agreeable
feature
in
the
evening
that
Mr
George
,
who
testified
no
great

of
pleasure
on
his

,
begins
,
in

,
to
be

of
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
so
friendly
,
is
a
man

,
and
so

get
on

,
that
it

something
to

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bagnet
becomes
,
after
another
pipe
,
so
sensible
of
the
value
of
his

that
he
solicits
the
honour
of
his
company
on
the
old
girl
's
next

.
 
<EOS>
If
anything
can
more
closely
cement

esteem
which
Mr
Bucket
has
formed

the

,
it
is
the
discovery
of

nature

.
 
<EOS>
He
drinks
to
Mrs
Bagnet
with
a

to

,
engages
himself
for
that
day
twelvemonth
more
than

,
makes

the

in

with

,

a

that
Mrs
Bucket

Mrs

may
before

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
As
he

himself
,
what
is
public

without
private
ties
?
 
<EOS>
He
is
in
his

way
a
public

,
but
it

in
that
sphere
that
he
finds

.
 
<EOS>
No
,
it
must

.
   
<EOS>
It

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Whatever

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
interested
in

and

as
Mr
George

.
   
<EOS>
At

George

.
 
<EOS>

Bucket
,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Respecting

,

---

?

<EOS>
"
Scores
,
"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
A

<EOS>

"

.

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
But

Bucket
,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
he

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Custody
?
 
<EOS>
What

?
"

<EOS>
"
Now
,
George
,
"

Mr
Bucket
,

,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
Therefore

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Murder
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
George
,
"

Mr
Bucket
,

in

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Where

?

<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

---

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>

?

"

,
"

,

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Last

!
 
<EOS>
Last

?
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
I

<EOS>

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Likewise
you
've

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

---
<EOS>

,
<EOS>

,

"
   
<EOS>
The

all

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,
"
my

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

's

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

;

;

any
other
man
.
 
<EOS>
On
all
of
which
accounts
,
I
should
hope
it
was
clear
to
you
that
I
must
have
you
,
and
that
I
'm
damned
if
I
do
n't
have
you
.
 
<EOS>
Am
I
to
call
in
any
assistance
,
or
is
the
trick
done
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
has
recovered
himself
and
stands
up
like
a
soldier
.
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
he
says
;
"
I
am
ready
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
George
,
"
continues
Mr
Bucket
,
"
wait
a
bit
!
"
 
<EOS>
With
his
upholsterer
manner
,
as
if
the
trooper
were
a
window
to
be
fitted
up
,
he
takes
from
his
pocket
a
pair
of

.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
serious
charge
,
George
,
and
<EOS>
such
is
my
duty
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
trooper
flushes
angrily
and
hesitates
a
moment
,
but
holds
out
his
two
hands
,
clasped
together
,
and
says
,
"
There
!
 
<EOS>
Put
them
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
adjusts
them
in
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
find
them
?
 
<EOS>
Are
they
comfortable
?
 
<EOS>
If
not
,
say
so
,
for
I
wish
to
make
things
as
pleasant
as
is
consistent
with
my
duty
,
and
I
've
got
another
pair
in
my
pocket
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
This
remark
he
offers
like
a
most
respectable
tradesman
anxious
to
execute
an
order
neatly
and
to
the
perfect
satisfaction
of
his
customer
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
'll
do
as
they
are
?
 
<EOS>
Very
well
!
<EOS>
Now
,
you
see
,
George
"
---
he
takes
a
cloak
from
a
corner
and
begins
adjusting
it
about
the
trooper
's
neck
---
<EOS>
"
I
was
mindful
of
your
feelings
when
I
come
out
,
and
brought
this
on
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
Who
's
the
wiser
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
I
,
"
returns
the
trooper
,
"
but
as
I
know
it
,
do
me
one
more
good
turn
and
pull
my
hat
over
my
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
though
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
it
?
 
<EOS>
Ai
n't
it
a
pity
?
 
<EOS>
It
looks
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
look
chance
men
in
the
face
with
these
things
on
,
"
Mr
George
hurriedly

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
,
for
God
's
sake
,
pull
my
hat
forward
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
strongly
entreated
,
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
complies
,
puts
his
own
hat
on
,
and
conducts
his
prize
into
the
streets
,
the
trooper
marching
on
as
steadily
as
usual
,
though
with
his
head
less
erect
,
and
Mr
Bucket
steering
him
with
his
elbow
over
the
crossings
and
up
the
turnings
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
50
.
<EOS>
Esther
's
Narrative
 
<EOS>
It
happened
that
when
I
came
home
from
Deal
I
found
a
note
from
Caddy
Jellyby
(
as
we
always
continued
to
call
her
)
,
informing
me
that
her
health
,
which
had
been
for
some
time
very
delicate
,
was
worse
and
that
she
would
be
more
glad
than
she
could
tell
me
if
I
would
go
to
see
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
note
of
a
few
lines
,
written
from
the
couch
on
which
she
lay
and
enclosed
to
me
in
another
from
her
husband
,
in
which
he
seconded
her
entreaty
with
much
solicitude
.
<EOS>
Caddy
was
now
the
mother
,
and
I
the
godmother
,
of
such
a
poor
little
baby
---
such
a
tiny
old
-
faced
mite
,
with
a
countenance
that
seemed
to
be
scarcely
anything
but
cap
-
border
,
and
a
little
lean
,
long
-
fingered
hand
,
always
clenched
under
its
chin
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
lie
in
this
attitude
all
day
,
with
its
bright
specks
of
eyes
open
,
wondering
(
as
I
used
to
imagine
)
how
it
came
to
be
so
small
and
weak
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
it
was
moved
it
cried
,
but
at
all
other
times
it
was
so
patient
that
the
sole
desire
of
its
life
appeared
to
be
to
lie
quiet
and
think
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
curious
little
dark
veins
in
its
face
and
curious
little
dark
marks
under
its
eyes
like
faint
remembrances
of
poor
Caddy
's
inky
days
,
and
altogether
,
to
those
who
were
not
used
to
it
,
it
was
quite
a
piteous
little
sight
.
   
<EOS>
But
it
was
enough
for
Caddy
that
SHE
was
used
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
projects
with
which
she
beguiled
her
illness
,
for
little
Esther
's
education
,
and
little
Esther
's
marriage
,
and
even
for
her
own
old
age
as
the
grandmother
of
little
Esther
's
little
Esthers
,
was
so
prettily
expressive
of
devotion
to
this
pride
of
her
life
that
I
should
be
tempted
to
recall
some
of
them
but
for
the
timely
remembrance
that
I
am
getting
on
irregularly
as
it
is
.
   
<EOS>
To
return
to
the
letter
.
 
<EOS>
Caddy
had
a
superstition
about
me
which
had
been
strengthening
in
her
mind
ever
since
that
night
long
ago
when
she
had
lain
asleep
with
her
head
in
my
lap
.
 
<EOS>
She
almost
<EOS>
---
I
think
I
must
say
quite
---
believed
that
I
did
her
good
whenever
I
was
near
her
.
 
<EOS>
Now
although
this
was
such
a
fancy
of
the
affectionate
girl
's
that
I
am
almost
ashamed
to
mention
it
,
still
it
might
have
all
the
force
of
a
fact
when
she
was
really
ill
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
set
off
to
Caddy
,
with
my
guardian
's
consent
,
post
-
haste
;
and
she
and
Prince
made
so
much
of
me
that
there
never
was
anything
like
it
.
   
<EOS>
Next
day
I
went
again
to
sit
with
her
,
and
next
day
I
went
again
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
easy
journey
,
for
I
had
only
to
rise
a
little
earlier
in
the
morning
,
and
keep
my
accounts
,
and
attend
to
housekeeping
matters
before
leaving
home
.
   
<EOS>
But
when
I
had
made
these
three
visits
,
my
guardian
said
to
me
,
on
my
return
at
night
,
"
Now
,
little
woman
,
little
woman
,
this
will
never
do
.
 
<EOS>
Constant
dropping
will
wear
away
a
stone
,
and
constant
coaching
will
wear
out
a
Dame
Durden
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
go
to
London
for
a
while
and
take
possession
of
our
old
lodgings
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
for
me
,
dear
guardian
,
"
said
I
,
"
<EOS>
for
I
never
feel
tired
,
"
which
was
strictly
true
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
only
too
happy
to
be
in
such
request
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
me
then
,
"
returned
my
guardian
,
"
or
for
Ada
,
or
for
both
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
somebody
's
birthday
to
-
morrow
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Truly
I
think
it
is
,
"
said
I
,
kissing
my
darling
,
who
would
be
twenty
-
one
to
-
morrow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
observed
my
guardian
,
half

,
half

,
"
that
's
a
great
occasion
and
will
give
my
fair
cousin
some

to
transact
in
assertion
of
her

,
and
will
make
London
a
more

for
all

.
 
<EOS>
So
to
London
we
will
go
.
 
<EOS>
That
being
settled
,
there
is
another
thing
---
how
have
you
left
Caddy
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
unwell
,
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
I
fear
it
will
be
some
time
before
she
regains

health
and
strength
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
call
some
time
,
now
?
"
asked
my
guardian
thoughtfully
.
   
<EOS>
"
Some
weeks
,
I
am
afraid
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
began
to
walk
about
the
room
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
showing
that
he
had
been
thinking
as
much
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
what
do
you
say
about
her
doctor
?
 
<EOS>
Is
he
a
good
doctor
,
my
love
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
obliged
to
confess
that
I
knew
nothing
to
the
contrary
but
that
Prince
and
I
had
agreed
only
that
evening
that
we
would
like
his
opinion
to
be
confirmed

some

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
you
know
,
"
returned

guardian

,
"
there
's
Woodcourt
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
meant
that
,
and
was
rather
taken
by
surprise
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
moment
all
that
I
had
had
in
my
mind
in

with
Mr
Woodcourt
seemed
to
come
back
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
object
to
him
,
little
woman
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Object
to
him
,

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
do
n't
think
the
patient
would
object
to
him
?
"
   
<EOS>
So
far
from
that
,
I
had
no
doubt
of
her
being
prepared
to
have
a
great
reliance
on
him
and
to
like
him
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
that
he
was
no
stranger
to
her
personally
,
for
she
had
seen
him
often
in
his
kind

on
Miss
Flite
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
said
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
here
to
-
day
,
my
dear
,
and
<EOS>
I
will
see
him
about
it
to
-
morrow
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
in
this
short
conversation
---
though
I
did
not
know
how
,
for
she
was
quiet
,
and
we
interchanged
no
look
---
that
my
dear
girl
well
remembered
how
merrily
she
had
clasped
me
round
the
waist
when
no
other
hands
than
Caddy
's
had
brought
me
the
little
parting
token
.
<EOS>
This
caused
me
to
feel
that
I
ought
to
tell
her
,
and
Caddy
too
,
that
I
was
going
to
be
the
mistress
of
Bleak
House
and
that
if
I
avoided
that
disclosure
any
longer
I
might
become
less
worthy
in
my
own
eyes
of
its
master
's
love
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
when
we
went
upstairs
and
had
waited
listening
until
the
clock
struck
twelve
in
order
that
only
I
might
be
the
first
to
wish
my
darling
all
good
wishes
on
her
birthday
and
to
take
her
to
my
heart
,
I
set
before
her
,
just
as
I
had
set
before
myself
,
the
goodness
and
honour
of
her
cousin
John
and
the
happy
life
that
was
in
store
for
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
ever
my
darling
were
fonder
of
me
at
one
time
than
another
in
all
our
intercourse
,
she
was
surely
fondest
of
me
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
was
so
rejoiced
to
know
it
<EOS>
and
so
comforted
by
the
sense
of
having
done
right
in
casting
this
last
idle
reservation
away
<EOS>
that
I
was
ten
times
happier
than
I
had
been
before
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
scarcely
thought
it
a
reservation
a
few
hours
ago
,
but
now
that
it
was
gone
I
felt
as
if
I
understood
its
nature
better
.
   
<EOS>
Next
day
we
went
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
We
found
our
old
lodging
vacant
,
and
in
half
an
hour
were
quietly
established
there
,
as
if
we
had
never
gone
away
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Woodcourt
dined
with
us
to
celebrate
my
darling
's
birthday
,
<EOS>
and
we
were
as
pleasant
as
we
could
be
with
the
great
blank
among
us
that
Richard
's
absence
naturally
made
on
such
an
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
day
I
was
for
some
weeks
---
<EOS>
eight
or
nine
as
I
remember
---
very
much
with
Caddy
,
and
thus
it
fell
out
that
I
saw
less
of
Ada
at
this
time
than
any
other
since
we
had
first
come
together
,
except
the
time
of
my
own
illness
.
 
<EOS>
She
often
came
to
Caddy
's
,
but
our
function
there
was
to
amuse
and
cheer
her
,
and
we
did
not
talk
in
our
usual
confidential
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
I
went
home
at
night
we
were
together
,
but
Caddy
's
rest
was
broken
by
pain
,
and
I
often
remained
to
nurse
her
.
   
<EOS>
With
her
husband
and
her
poor
little
mite
of
a
baby
to
love
and
their
home
to
strive
for
,
<EOS>
what
a
good
creature
<EOS>
Caddy
was
!
 
<EOS>
So
self
-
denying
,
so
uncomplaining
,
so
anxious
to
get
well
on
their
account
,
so
afraid
of
giving
trouble
,
and
so
thoughtful
of
the
unassisted
labours
of
her
husband
and
the
comforts
of
old
Mr
Turveydrop
<EOS>
;
I
had
never
known
the
best
of
her
until
now
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
seemed
so
curious
that
her
pale
face
and
helpless
figure
should
be
lying
there
day
after
day
where
dancing
was
the
business
of
life
,
where
the
kit
and
the
apprentices
began
early
every
morning
in
the
ball
-
room
,
and
where
the
untidy
little
boy
waltzed
by
himself
in
the
kitchen
all
the
afternoon
.
   
<EOS>
At
Caddy
's
request
I
took
the
supreme
direction
of
her
apartment
,
trimmed
it
up
,
and
pushed
her
,
couch
and
all
,
into
a
lighter
and
more
airy
and
more
cheerful
corner
than
she
had
yet
occupied
;
then
,
every
day
,
when
we
were
in
our
neatest
array
,
I
used
to
lay
my
small
small
namesake
in
her
arms
and
sit
down
to
chat
or
work
or
read
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
at
one
of
the
first
of
these
quiet
times
that
I
told
Caddy
about
Bleak
House
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
other
visitors
besides
Ada
.
 
<EOS>
First
of
all
we
had
Prince
,
who
in
his
hurried
intervals
of
teaching
used
to
come
softly
in
and
sit
softly
down
,
with
a
face
of
loving
anxiety
for
Caddy
and
the
very
little
child
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
Caddy
's
condition
really
was
,
she
never
failed
to
declare
to
Prince
that
she
was
all
but
well
---
<EOS>
which
I
,
heaven
forgive
me
,
never
failed
to
confirm
.
 
<EOS>
This
would
put
Prince
in
such
good
spirits
that
he
would
sometimes
take
the
kit
from
his
pocket
and
play
a
chord
or
two
to
astonish
the
baby
,
which
I
never
knew
it
to
do
in
the
least
degree
,
for
my
tiny
namesake
never
noticed
it
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
Then
there
was
Mrs
Jellyby
.
 
<EOS>
She
would
come
occasionally
,
with
her
usual
distraught
manner
,
and
sit
calmly
looking
miles
beyond
her
grandchild
as
if
her
attention
were
absorbed
by
a
young
Borrioboolan
on
its
native
shores
.
 
<EOS>
As
bright
-
eyed
as
ever
,
as
serene
,
and
as
untidy
,
she
would
say
,
"
Well
,
Caddy
,
child
,
and
how
do
you
do
to
-
day
?
"
 
<EOS>
And
then
would
sit
amiably
smiling
and
taking
no
notice
of
the
reply
or
would
sweetly
glide
off
into
a
calculation
of
the
number
of
letters
she
had
lately
received
and
answered
or
of
the
coffee
-
bearing
power
of
Borrioboola
-
Gha
.
 
<EOS>
This
she
would
always
do
with
a
serene
contempt
for
our
limited
sphere
of
action
,
not
to
be
disguised
.
   
<EOS>
Then
there
was
old
Mr
Turveydrop
,
who
was
from
morning
to
night
and
from
night
to
morning
the
subject
of
innumerable
precautions
.
<EOS>
If
the
baby
cried
,
it
was
nearly
stifled
lest
the
noise
should
make
him
uncomfortable
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
fire
wanted
stirring
in
the
night
,
it
was
surreptitiously
done
lest
his
rest
should
be
broken
.
 
<EOS>
If
Caddy
required
any
little
comfort
that
the
house
contained
,
she
first
carefully
discussed
whether
he
was
likely
to
require

too
.
 
<EOS>
In
return
for
this
consideration
he
would
come
into
the
room
once
a
day
,
all
but
blessing
it
---
showing
a

,
and
a

,
and
a
grace
of
manner
in
dispensing
the

his
high

from

I
might
have
supposed

(
if

)

Caddy
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
My
Caroline
,
"
he

,

nearest

that
he

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
that
you
are
better
to
-
day
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
much
better
,
thank

,
Mr
Turveydrop
,
"

would

.
   
<EOS>
"
Delighted
!
 
<EOS>
Enchanted
!
 
<EOS>
And
our
dear
Miss
Summerson
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
not
qulte

by
fatigue
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Here
he
would
crease

and

to
me
,
though
I
am
happy

say
he
had

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Charming
!
 
<EOS>
We
must

,
Miss
Summerson
.
<EOS>
We
must
spare
nothing
that
will

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
My

Caroline
"
---

daughter
-
in

---
"
want

,

.
<EOS>
Frame
a

,

.
 
<EOS>
Everything

,
everything

,

,

.
<EOS>
Do

,
"
he

"

,
my
Caroline
.
 
<EOS>
Your

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

to
this

(
his

's

from

)

and
her

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
my

,
"
he

;
and

Caddy
's
thin

about

as

,
I
would

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
nay
!
 
<EOS>
I
have

.
 
<EOS>
Be
dutiful

,

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

!
 
<EOS>
I

Park
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
would
take
the
air
there
presently
and
get
an

for

.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
I
do
old
Mr
Turveydrop
<EOS>
no

,
<EOS>
but
I
never

these
I
faithfully

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
,

Caddy

,
from

.
   
<EOS>
Last

our
visitors
,

Mr
Jellyby
.
 
<EOS>
Really

used

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

,
as

<EOS>
His

to
sit

,

;
and
I
could

divest

a

that
they

.
   
<EOS>
I
have
not
counted
Mr
Woodcourt
among

because

's

.
 
<EOS>
She
soon
began
to
improve

,
but
he
was
so

,

,
so

in
the

<EOS>
he

that
it

not

,
<EOS>
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
a
good
deal
of
Mr
Woodcourt
during
this

,
though
not
so
much
as
might
be
supposed
,
for
knowing
Caddy
to

in

,
I
often
slipped

at
about

he

.
 
<EOS>
We
frequently
met
,
notwithstanding
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
quite
reconciled
to
myself
now
,
but
I
still
felt

to
think
that
he
was
sorry
for
me
,
and
he
still
WAS
sorry
for
me
<EOS>
I
believed
.
 
<EOS>
He
helped
Mr
Badger
in
his
professional
engagements
,
which
were

,
and
had
as
yet
no
settled

for

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
when
Caddy
began
to
recover
that
I
began
to
notice
a
change
in
my
dear
girl
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
how
it
first
presented
itself
to
me
,
because
I
observed
it
in
many

which
were
nothing
in

and
only

when

were

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
made
it
out
,
by
putting

together
,
that
Ada
was
not
so
frankly

with
me
as

used
to

.
 
<EOS>
Her

for
me
was
as

as
ever
;
I
did
not
for

doubt
<EOS>
that
;
but
there

about
her
which
she
did
not
confide
to
me
,
and
in

I
traced
some
hidden
regret
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
I
could
not
understand
this
,
and
I
was
so
anxious
for
the
happiness
of
my
own
pet
that
it
caused
me
some
uneasiness
and
set
me
thinking
often
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
feeling
sure
that
Ada
suppressed
this
something
from
me
lest
it
should
make
me
unhappy
too
,
it

my

that
she
was
a
little

---
for
me
---
by
what
I
had
told

about
Bleak
House
.
   
<EOS>
How
I
persuaded

that
this

,

do

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no

there

any
selfish
reference
in
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
grieved
for
myself
:
<EOS>
I
was
quite
contented
and
quite
happy
.
<EOS>
Still
,
that
Ada
might
be
thinking
---
for
me
,
though
I
had
abandoned
all
such
thoughts
---
of
what
once
was
,
but
was
now
all
changed
,
seemed
so
easy

believe
that
I
believed

.
   
<EOS>
What

do
to

(
I

)
and

that
I

?
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
could
only

as

as

,
and
that
I
had
tried

.
<EOS>
However
,
as
Caddy
's

certainly

,

,

---

always

's

,
and

there

,
for

---
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
So

about

house
humming
all

I

,

and

in

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
And

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,

,
"

,
"
so
<EOS>
Woodcourt

?
"

"

,

"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
he

,
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
So

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
Would

,
little

?
"
   
<EOS>
I

,
for

,

<EOS>
As

Flite
,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
Rich

<EOS>
Rich

"
   
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
   
<EOS>
"
To

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
All

.
 
<EOS>
I

Woodcourt
,

;

.
 
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

of

.
 
<EOS>
Do

.
 
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Humph
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
I

.
"
 
As

,

for

girl
's
satisfaction
,
had
better
be

,
I

which

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

Woodcourt

?
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

;
"
and

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
little
woman
,
"
he

.
   
<EOS>
I
was

in
my

,
which
was

's

.
 
<EOS>
That
had
not

my
usual

before
the
letter
,
but

now
.
 
<EOS>
I

Ada
,

,
and

,

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
I

that

to

to
undeceive

dear
and
set
her

.
 
<EOS>
I
really
was
so
,
and
I
had
nothing
to

but
to

.
   
<EOS>
So
I
made
my
sweet
girl
lean
upon

---
<EOS>
how
little
thinking
what
was
heavy
on
her

!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
I
said
she
was
not
quite
well
,
and
put
my

,
and
took

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Ada

"
   
<EOS>
Ada

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
Enlightened
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"

A

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
They
shook
hands
upon
it
laughingly
,
but
in
deep
earnestness
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
answer
for
one
of
them
with
my
heart

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
come
as
a
godsend
,
"

,
"
for
I
have
seen
nobody
here
<EOS>
yet
<EOS>
but
Vholes
.
 
<EOS>
Woodcourt
,
there

one

I
should
like

mention
,
for

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
can

.
 
<EOS>
You

,
I

,

my

Ada
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Woodcourt

that
I
had
hinted
as
much
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

,
"
do

me
a

.
<EOS>
Do

I

.
 
<EOS>
Ada

;

ca

;

.
 
<EOS>
Do

!
"
   
<EOS>
He

Mr

<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,

"

here
<EOS>
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
Woodcourt

.
 
<EOS>
Do

"
   
<EOS>
Afterwards

so

much

's

that
in
telling
me
generally
of
his

Symond
's
Inn
he

.
 
<EOS>
It
revived
a

had

that
my
dear
girl
's

be

Mr

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
   
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
No

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
Such

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Should

's

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
No
,
Ada

.
 
<EOS>
Would

?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
Ada

.
 
<EOS>
Should

go

?
<EOS>
Yes
,

.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
could

my

,
with

<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
and

<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

any

or

.
 
<EOS>
I
fancied
my
beautiful
girl
quite
out

in
the
rugged

,
and
I
thought
there
were
more

along

than
I

before
.
   
<EOS>
We

first
to

Symond
's
Inn
.
 
<EOS>
We

Chancery

.
 
<EOS>
"
We

,

"

<EOS>
So

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Symond
's
Inn
.
   
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
"
Or

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

's

<EOS>
And

.
   
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
So

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Thus

Richard
,

.
 
<EOS>
Wherever

.
 
<EOS>
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
.
   
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

"

"

Woodcourt

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

,
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

!
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>

,

"

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

?
"

,

<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>

the

!
"
   
<EOS>
These

,

.
 
<EOS>
Her

.
   
<EOS>
"
We

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Vholes
will

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
Ask
Vholes
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
giving

no

.
 
<EOS>
Vholes
knows

and

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
rouse

that
nest

sleepers
,
mark

!
"
   
<EOS>
His

had
long

;
it
was
so

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

upon

now

his
handsome

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I
say

,
for

that

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

,
"

,
"

,

---
<EOS>
"
   
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
No
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
---

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Sometimes

,

,

---

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
"

,

"

!
"
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
It

"
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Oh

!
   
<EOS>
"
Esther
,

,
"

"
I
am

.
"
   
<EOS>
A

.
   
<EOS>
"
Never

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
Go

,

Esther
;

!
"
 
<EOS>
With

.
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
,

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
We

,

her

I

.
 
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

<EOS>
"
My

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

Richard
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Esther
,

?
 
<EOS>
Will

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

,
"
said

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
And

!
"
 
<EOS>
Why
,

!
   
<EOS>
I

darling
's

,

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

,
Esther

"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,

,
"

,
"
that
how
could

!
 
<EOS>
And

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

were
married
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

Esther
,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
How

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
Obstinacy
 
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

?
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

course
,
that
we
must
admit
,
not
only
to
ourselves
but
to
others
,
the
full
force
of
the
circumstances
against
him
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
I
knew
withal
(
I
could
not
help
saying
)
that
their
weight
would
not
induce
us
to
desert
him
in
his
need
.
   
<EOS>
"
Heaven
forbid
!
"
returned
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
stand
by
him
,
as
he
himself
stood
by
the
two
poor
creatures
who
are
gone
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
meant
Mr
Gridley
and
the
boy
,
to
both
of
whom
Mr
George
had
given
shelter
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Woodcourt
then
told
us
that
the
trooper
's
man
had
been
with
him
before
day
,
after
wandering
about
the
streets
all
night
like
a
distracted
creature
.
 
<EOS>
That
one
of
the
trooper
's
first
anxieties
was
that
we
should
not
suppose
him
guilty
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
had
charged
his
messenger
to
represent
his
perfect
innocence
with
every
solemn
assurance
be
could
send
us
.
 
<EOS>
That
Mr
Woodcourt
had
only
quieted
the
man
by
undertaking
to
come
to
our
house
very
early
in
the
morning
with
these
representations
.
 
<EOS>
He
added
that
he
was
now
upon
his
way
to
see
the
prisoner
himself
.
   
<EOS>
My
guardian
said
directly
he
would
go
too
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
besides
that
I
liked
the
retired
soldier
very
much
and
that
he
liked
me
<EOS>
,
I
had
that
secret
interest
in
what
had
happened
which
was
only
known
to
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
as
if
it
came
close
and
near
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
become
personally
important
to
myself
that
the
truth
should
be
discovered
and
that
no
innocent
people
should
be
suspected
,
for
suspicion
,
once
run
wild
,
might
run
wilder
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
I
felt
as
if
it
were
my
duty
and
obligation
to
go
with
them
.
 
<EOS>
My
guardian
did
not
seek
to
dissuade
me
,
and
I
went
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
large
prison
with
many
courts
and
passages
so
like
one
another
<EOS>
and
so
uniformly
paved
that
I
seemed
to
gain
a
new
comprehension
,
as
I
passed
along
,
of
the
fondness
that
solitary
prisoners
,
shut
up
among
the
same
staring
walls
from
year
to
year
,
have
had
---
as
I
have
read
---
for
a
weed
or
a
stray
blade
of
grass
.
 
<EOS>
In
an
arched
room
by
himself
,
like
a
cellar
upstairs
,
with
walls
so
glaringly
white
that
they
made
the
massive
iron
window
-
bars
and
iron
-
bound
door
even
more
profoundly
black
than
they
were
,
we
found
the
trooper
standing
in
a
corner
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
sitting
on
a
bench
there
and
had
risen
when
he
heard
the
locks
and
bolts
turn
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
saw
us
,
he
came
forward
a
step
with
his
usual
heavy
tread
,
and
there
stopped
and
made
a
slight
bow
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
I
still
advanced
,
putting
out
my
hand
to
him
,
he
understood
us
in
a
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
load
off
my
mind
,
I
do
assure
you
,
miss
and
gentlemen
,
"
said
he
,
saluting
us
with
great
heartiness
and
drawing
a
long
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
now
I
do
n't
so
much
care
how
it
ends
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
scarcely
seemed
to
be
the
prisoner
.
 
<EOS>
What
with
his
coolness
and
his
soldierly
bearing
,
he
looked
far
more
like
the
prison
guard
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
even
a
rougher
place
than
my
gallery
to
receive
a
lady
in
,
"
said
Mr
George
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
know
Miss
Summerson
will
make
the
best
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
handed
me
to
the
bench
on
which
he
had
been
sitting
,
I
sat
down
,
which
seemed
to
give
him
great
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
,
miss
,
"
said
he
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
George
,
"
observed
my
guardian
,
"
as
we
require
no
new
assurances
on
your
part
,
so
<EOS>
I
believe
we
need
give
you
none
on
ours
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
thank
you
with
all
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
was
not
innocent
of
this
crime
,
I
could
n't
look
at
you
and
keep
my
secret
to
myself
under
the
condescension
of
the
present
visit
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
the
present
visit
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
one
of
the
eloquent
sort
,
but
I
feel
it
,
Miss
Summerson
and
gentlemen
,
deeply
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
laid
his
hand
for
a
moment
on
his
broad
chest
and
bent
his
bead
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
Although
he
squared
himself
again
directly
,
he
expressed
a
great
amount
of
natural
emotion
by
these
simple
means
.
   
<EOS>
"
First
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
"
can
we
do
anything
for
your
personal
comfort
,
George
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
which
,
sir
?
"
he
inquired
,
clearing
his
throat
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
your
personal
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
Is
there
anything
you
want
that
would
lessen
the
hardship
of
this
confinement
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
replied
George
,
after
a
little

,
"
I
am
equally
obliged
to
you
,
but
tobacco
being
against
the
rules
,
I
ca
n't
say
that
there
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
think
of
many
little
things
perhaps
,
by
and
by
.
<EOS>
Whenever
you
do
,
George
,
let
us
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Howsoever
,
"
observed
Mr
George
with
one
of
his
sunburnt
smiles
,
"
a
man
who
has
been
knocking
about
the
world
in
a
vagabond
kind
of
a
way
as
long
as
I
have
gets
on
well
enough
in
a
place
like
the
present
,
so
far
as
that
goes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Next
,
as
to
your
case
,
"
observed
my
guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
so
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
George
,
folding
his
arms
upon
his
breast
with
perfect
self
-
possession
and
a
little

.
   
<EOS>
"
How
does
it
stand
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
it
is
under
remand
at
present
.
 
<EOS>
Bucket
gives
me
to
understand
that
he
will
probably
apply
for
a
series
of
remands
from
time
to
time
until
the
case
is
more
complete
.
 
<EOS>
How
it
is
to
be
made
more
complete
<EOS>
I
do
n't
myself
see
,
<EOS>
but
I
dare
say
Bucket
will
manage
it
somehow
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
heaven
save
us
,
man
,
"
exclaimed
my
guardian
,
surprised
into
his
old
oddity
and
vehemence
,
"
you
talk
of
yourself
as
if
you
were
somebody
else
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
offence
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
George
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sensible
of
your
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
see
how
an
innocent
man
is
to
make
up
his
mind
to
this
kind
of
thing
without
knocking
his
head
against
the
walls
unless
he
takes
it
in
that
point
of
view
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
true
enough
to
a
certain

,
"
returned
my
guardian
,
softened
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
my
good
fellow
,
even
an
innocent
man
must
take
ordinary
precautions
to
defend
himself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
have
done
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
stated
to
the
magistrates
,
"
Gentlemen
,
I
am
as
innocent
of
this
charge
as
yourselves
;
what
has

against
me
in
the
way
of
facts
is
perfectly

;
<EOS>
I
know

more
about

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
intend
to
continue

,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
What
more
can
I
do
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
the
mere
truth
wo
n't
do
,
"
rejoined

guardian
.
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
it
indeed
.
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Rather
a
bad
look
-
out
for
me
!
"
<EOS>
Mr
George
good
-
humouredly
observed
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
a
lawyer
,
"
pursued
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
engage
a
good
one
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
George
with
a
step
backward
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
equally
obliged
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
must
decidedly
beg
to
be
excused
from
anything
of
that
sort
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
have
a
lawyer
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
George
shook
his
head
in
the
most

.
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
all
the
same
,
sir
,
but
---
no
lawyer
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
take
kindly
to
the
breed
,
"
said
Mr
George
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gridley
did
n't
.
 
<EOS>
And
---
if
you
'll
excuse
my
saying
so
much
---
I
should
hardly
have
thought
you
did
yourself
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
equity
,
"
my
guardian
explained
,
a
little
at
a
loss
;
"
that
's
equity
,
George
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
,
indeed
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
returned
the
trooper
in
his
off
-
hand
manner
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
acquainted
with
those
shades
of
names
myself
,
but
in
a
general
way
I
object
to
the
breed
.
"
   
<EOS>
Unfolding
his
arms
and
changing
his
position
,
he
stood
with
one
massive
hand
upon
the
table
and
the
other
on
his
hip
,
as
complete
a
picture
of
a
man
who
was
not
to
be
moved
from
a
fixed
purpose
as
ever
I
saw
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
that
we
all
three
talked
to
him
and
endeavoured
to
persuade
him
;
he
listened
with
that
gentleness
which
went
so
well
with
his
bluff
bearing
,
but
was
evidently
no
more
shaken
by
our
representations
that
his
place
of
confinement
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
think
,
once
more
,
Mr
George
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
no
wish
in
reference
to
your
case
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
could
wish
it
to
be
tried
,
miss
,
"
he
returned
,
"
by
court
-
martial
;
but
that
is
out
of
the
question
,
as
I
am
well
aware
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
be
so
good
as
to
favour
me
with
your
attention
for
a
couple
of
minutes
,
miss
,
not
more
,
I
'll
endeavour
to
explain
myself
as
clearly
as
I
can
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
at
us
all
three
in
turn
,
shook
his
head
a
little
as
if
he
were
adjusting
it
in
the
stock
and
collar
of
a
tight
uniform
,
and
after
a
moment
's
reflection
went
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
miss
,
I
have
been
handcuffed
and
taken
into
custody
and
brought
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
marked
and
disgraced
man
,
and
here
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
My
shooting
gallery
is
rummaged
,
high
and
low
,
by
Bucket
;
such
property
as
I
have
---
'
tis
small
---
is
turned
this
way
and
that
till
it
do
n't
know
itself
;
and
(
as
aforesaid
)
<EOS>
here
I
am
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
particular
complain
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Though
I
am
in
these
present
quarters
through
no
immediately
preceding
fault
of
mine
,
I
can
very
well
understand
that
if
I
had
n't
gone
into
the
vagabond
way
in
my
youth
,
this
would
n't
have
happened
.
 
<EOS>
It
HAS
happened
.
 
<EOS>
Then
comes
the
question
how
to
meet
it
<EOS>
"
   
He
rubbed
his
swarthy
forehead
for
a
moment
with
a
good
-
humoured
look
and
said
apologetically
,
"
I
am
such
a
short
-
winded
talker
that
I
must
think
a
bit
.
"
 
<EOS>
Having
thought
a
bit
,
he
looked
up
again
and
resumed
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
to
meet
it
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
the
unfortunate
deceased
was
himself
a
lawyer
and
had
a
pretty
tight
hold
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
wish
to
rake
up
his
ashes
,
but
he
had
,
what
I
should
call
if
he
was
living
,
a
devil
of
a
tight
hold
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
his
trade
<EOS>
the
better
for
that
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
kept
clear
of
his
trade
,
I
should
have
kept
outside
this
place
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
's
not
what
I
mean
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
suppose
I
had
killed
him
.
<EOS>
Suppose
I
really
had
discharged
into
his
body
any
one
of
those
pistols
recently
fired
off
that
Bucket
has
found
at
my
place
,
and
dear
me
,
might
have
found
there
any
day
since
it
has
been
my
place
.
<EOS>
What
should
I
have
done
as
soon
as
I
was
hard
and
fast
here
?
 
<EOS>
Got
a
lawyer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
on
hearing
some
one
at
the
locks
and
bolts
and
did
not
resume
until
the
door
had
been
opened
and
was
shut
again
.
 
<EOS>
For
what
purpose
opened
,
I
will
mention
presently
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
got
a
lawyer
,
and
he
would
have
said
(
as
I
have
often
read
in
the
newspapers
)
,
"
My
client
says
nothing
,
my
client
reserves
his
defence
"
:
<EOS>
my
client
this
,
that
,
and
t'other
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
'
tis
not
the
custom
of
that
breed
to
go
straight
,
according
to
my
opinion
,
or
to
think
that
other
men
do
.
 
<EOS>
Say
I
am
innocent
<EOS>
and
I
get
a
lawyer
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
be
as
likely
to
believe
me
guilty
as
not
;
perhaps
more
.
 
<EOS>
What
would
he
do
,
whether
or
not
?
 
<EOS>
Act
as
if
I
was
---
 
shut
my
mouth
up
,
tell
me
not
to
commit
myself
,
keep
circumstances
back
,
chop
the
evidence
small
,
quibble
,
and
get
me
off
perhaps
!
<EOS>
But
,
Miss
Summerson
,
do
I
care
for
getting
off
in
that
way
;
or
would
I

hanged
in
my
own
way
---
if
you
'll
excuse

mentioning
anything
so
disagreeable
to
a

?
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
warmed
into

subject
now
,
and
was
under
no

to
wait

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather

hanged
in
my
own

.
 
<EOS>
And
I
mean
to
be
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

say
,
"
looking

and

,
"
that
I
am
more

.
 
<EOS>
What

is
,
I
must

.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,

I
hear

against
me
what

,
I
say

's
true
;
and
when
they
tell

,
"
whatever

will
be
used
,
"
I
tell

I
do
n't

;
I
mean

to
be

.
 
<EOS>
If
they
ca
n't

me
innocent

,

.
 
<EOS>
And
if

,
it
's

.
"
   
<EOS>
Taking

<EOS>
"
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
That
's

as
it

to
a
mere
trooper
with

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
done

in
life
beyond
my

as

,
and

comes

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
When

---

I

.
 
<EOS>
As

.
 
<EOS>
No

,

---

"
   
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

,
"

<EOS>
"
Of

.
 
<EOS>
For

.
 
<EOS>
That

.

Mat

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

'

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

"
cried
my
guardian
with
his
hand
in
his
pocket
,
"
how
is
she
going
?
 
<EOS>
What
money
has
she
got
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bagnet
made
another
application
to
her
skirts
and
brought
forth
a
leathern
purse
in
which
she
hastily
counted
over
a
few
shillings
and
which
she
then
shut
up
with
perfect
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
you
mind
for
me
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
soldier
's
wife
and
accustomed
to
travel
my
own
way
.
 
<EOS>
Lignum
,
old
boy
,
"
kissing
him
,
"
one
for
yourself
,
three
for
the
children
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
'm
away
into
Lincolnshire
after
George
's
mother
!
"
   
<EOS>
And
she
actually
set
off
while
we
three
stood
looking
at
one
another
lost

.
 
<EOS>
She
actually
trudged
away
in
her
grey

at
a

,
and
turned
the
corner
,
and
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Bagnet
,
"
said
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
let
her
go
in
that
way
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
help
it
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Made
her
way
home
once
from
another
quarter
of
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
With

same
grey
cloak
.
 
<EOS>
And
same

.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
the
old
girl
says
,
do
.
 
<EOS>
Do
it
!
 
<EOS>
Whenever
the
old
girl
says
,
I'LL
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
does
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
she
is
as
honest

she
looks
,
"
rejoined

,
"
and
it
is
impossible
to

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
Colour
-

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
there

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
own
to
it
before
her
.
<EOS>
Discipline
must
