.
"
    
Chapter
53
.
<EOS>
The
Track
 
Mr
Bucket
and
his
fat
forefinger
are
much
in
consultation
together
under
existing
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Bucket
has
a
matter
of
this
pressing
interest
under
his
consideration
,
the
fat
forefinger
seems
to
rise
,
to
the
dignity
of
a
familiar
demon
.
 
<EOS>
He
puts
it
to
his
ears
,
and
it
whispers
information
;
he
puts
it
to
his
lips
,
and
it
enjoins
him
to
secrecy
;
he
rubs
it
over
his
nose
,
and
it
sharpens
his
scent
;
he
shakes
it
before
a
guilty
man
,
and
it
charms
him
to
his
destruction
.
 
<EOS>
The
Augurs
of
the
Detective
Temple
invariably
predict
that
when
Mr
Bucket
and
that
finger
are
in
much
conference
,
a
terrible
avenger
will
be
heard
of
before
long
.
   
<EOS>
Otherwise
mildly
studious
in
his
observation
of
human
nature
,
on
the
whole
a
benignant
philosopher
not
disposed
to
be
severe
upon
the
follies
of
mankind
<EOS>
,
Mr
Bucket
pervades
a
vast
number
of
houses
and
strolls
about
an
infinity
of
streets
,
to
outward
appearance
rather
languishing
for
want
of
an
object
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
in
the
friendliest
condition
towards
his
species
and
will
drink
with
most
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
free
with
his
money
,
affable
in
his
manners
,
innocent
in
his
conversation
---
<EOS>
but
through
the
placid
stream
of
his
life
there
glides
an
under
-
current
of
forefinger
.
   
<EOS>
Time
and
place
can
not
bind
Mr
Bucket
.
 
<EOS>
Like
man
in
the
abstract
,
he
is
here
to
-
day
and
gone
to
-
morrow
---
but
,
very
unlike
man
indeed
,
he
is
here
again
the
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
This
evening
he
will
be
casually
looking
into
the
iron
extinguishers
at
the
door
of
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
's
house
in
town
;
and
to
-
morrow
morning
he
will
be
walking
on
the
leads
at
Chesney
Wold
,
where
erst
the
old
man
walked
whose
ghost
is
propitiated
with
a
hundred
guineas
.
 
<EOS>
Drawers
,
desks
,
pockets
,
all
things
belonging
to
him
,
Mr
Bucket
examines
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
hours
afterwards
,
he
and
the
Roman
will
be
alone
together
comparing
forefingers
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
likely
that
these
occupations
are
irreconcilable
with
home
enjoyment
,
but
it
is
certain
that
Mr
Bucket
at
present
does
not
go
home
.
 
<EOS>
Though
in
general
he
highly
appreciates
the
society
of
Mrs
Bucket
---
a
lady
of
a
natural
detective
genius
,
which
if
it
had
been
improved
by
professional
exercise
,
might
have
done
great
things
,
but
which
has
paused
at
the
level
of
a
clever
amateur
---
he
holds
himself
aloof
from
that
dear
solace
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bucket
is
dependent
on
their
lodger
(
fortunately
an
amiable
lady
in
whom
she
takes
an
interest
)
for
companionship
and
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
A
great
crowd
assembles
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
Fields
on
the
day
of
the
funeral
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
attends
the
ceremony
in
person
;
strictly
speaking
,
there
are
only
three
other

,
that
is
to

,
Lord
Doodle
,
William
Buffy
,
and
the
debilitated
cousin
(
thrown
in
as
a
make

)
,
but
the
amount
of
inconsolable
carriages
is
immense
.
 
<EOS>
The
peerage
contributes
more
four
-
wheeled
affliction
than
has
ever
been
seen
in
that
neighbourhood
.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
the

of
armorial

on

that
the
Herald
's
College
might
be
supposed
to
have
lost
its
father
and
mother
at

.
 
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Foodle
sends
a

of
dust
and
ashes
,
with

,
patent

,
all
the
last

,
and
three

worms
,
six

,
holding

,
in

of
woe
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
state

in
London
seem

into

;
and
if
that
dead
old
man
of

beyond
a
taste
in
horseflesh
(
which
appears

)
,
it
must

highly

this

.
   
<EOS>
Quiet
among

and
the

and
the

of
so
many
legs
all
steeped
in
grief
<EOS>
,
Mr
Bucket
sits
concealed

one

and
at
his

surveys
the

through

.
 
<EOS>
He

for
a

---
as

?
---

here

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
;

<EOS>
Not

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
After

.
   
<EOS>
Contrast

HIS
.
 
<EOS>
Between

!
 
<EOS>
But

;

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
sits

in
his

and

when

he

.
 
<EOS>
He
makes
for
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
's
,
which
is
at
present
a
sort

home
to

,
where

as

at
all
hours
'
,
where

,
where
he

,
and
walks
in
an

.
   
<EOS>
No

or

for
Mr
Bucket
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
caused

to
be
provided
with
a
key
and
can

at

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

,
"
Here

for

,
Mr
Bucket
,

,
"
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Another
one
,
eh
?
"

Mr
Bucket
.
   
<EOS>
If
Mercury
should

to

as
to
Mr
Bucket
's
letters
,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket

as

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"

Bucket
.
   
<EOS>
Unfortunately
Mercury
is

.
   
<EOS>
"
Could
you
fetch
me
a

from

?
"

Mr
Bucket
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Thankee
.
 
<EOS>
It
do
n't
matter
what
it
is
;
I
'm
not
particular
as
to
the

.
 
<EOS>
Thankee
!
"
   
<EOS>
Having
leisurely

himself
from
a
canister
borrowed
from
somebody
downstairs
for
the
purpose
,
and
having
made
a

show
of
tasting
it
,
first
with

of
his
nose
and
then

the
other
,
Mr
Bucket
,
with
much
deliberation
,
pronounces
it
of
the
right
sort
and
goes
on
,
letter
in
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Now
although
Mr
Bucket
walks
upstairs
to
the
little
library
within
the
larger
one
with
the
face
of
a
man
who
receives
some
scores
of
letters
every
day
,
it
happens
that
much
correspondence
is
not
incidental
to
his
life
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
no
great
scribe
,
rather
handling
his
pen
like
the
pocket
-
staff
he
carries
about
with
him
always
convenient
to
his
grasp
,
and
discourages
correspondence
with
himself
in
others
as
being
too
artless
and
direct
a
way
of
doing
delicate
business
.
 
<EOS>
Further
,
he
often
sees
damaging
letters
produced
in
evidence
and
has
occasion
to
reflect
that
it
was
a
green
thing
to
write
them
.
 
<EOS>
For
these
reasons
he
has
very
little
to
do
with
letters
,
either
as
sender
or
receiver
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
he
has
received
a
round
half
-
dozen
within
the
last
twenty
-
four
hours
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
this
,
"
says
Mr
Bucket
,
spreading
it
out
on
the
table
,
"
is
in
the
same
hand
,
and
consists
of
the
same
two
words
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
What
two
words
?
   
<EOS>
He
turns
the
key
in
the
door
,
ungirdles
his
black
pocket
-
book
(
book
of
fate
to
many
)
,
lays

by

,
and
reads
,

,
"
Lady
Dedlock
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

Mr
Bucket
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
could
have
made
the
money
without
this

information
.
"
   
<EOS>
Having
put
the
letters
in
his
book
of

and

,
he
unlocks
the

just
in

to

,
which
is

upon

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
frequently
observes
,
in

where
there
is

,
that
he
likes
a
toothful
of
your
fine
old
brown
East
Inder
sherry
better
than
anything
you
can
offer

.
 
<EOS>
Consequently
he
fills
and
empties
his
glass
with
a
smack
of
his
lips
and
is
proceeding
with
his

when
an
idea
enters
his
mind
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
softly
opens
the
door
of
communication
between
that
room
and
the
next
and
looks
in
.
 
<EOS>
The
library
is
deserted
,
and
the
fire
is

low
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
's
eye
,
after
taking
a
pigeon
-
flight
round
the
room
,
alights
upon
a
table
where
letters
are
usually
put
as

.
 
<EOS>
Several

for
Sir
Leicester
are
upon

.
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
draws
near

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
only
me
as

.
 
<EOS>
I

to
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
Baronet
,
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With

returns
to

with
a
good

,
and
after

,

-

.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
has
received
him
there
these
several
evenings
past
to
know

anything

report
.
 
<EOS>
The
debilitated
cousin
(
much

by

)

Volumnia
are

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"
Why
,

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
Springing
a
Mine
 
Refreshed

,
Mr
Bucket

.
 
<EOS>
Smartened

aid

,

,

study
<EOS>
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Having
much

and

held

,

"
just

Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
Baronet
,
that

's

I

.
"
 
<EOS>
A

that
Sir
Leicester

Mr
Bucket
in
the
library
within

,
Mr
Bucket
repairs
to

and
stands
before

fire
with
his
finger

chin
,
looking
at

.
   
<EOS>
Thoughtful
Mr
Bucket
is
,
as
a
man
may
be
with
weighty
work
to
do
,
but
composed
,
sure
,
confident
.
 
<EOS>
From

face
he
might
be
a
famous

-

for
a
large
stake
---
say
a
hundred
guineas
certain
---
with
the
game
in
his
hand
,
but
with
a
high
reputation
involved
in
his
playing
his
hand
out
to
the
last
card
in
a
masterly
way
.
 
<EOS>
Not
in
the
least

or

Mr
Bucket
when
Sir
Leicester
appears
,
but
he
eyes

aside
as

slowly

easy
-

with
that

of
yesterday
in
which
there
might
have
been
yesterday
,
but
for

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

later

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
subject
to
---
gout
"
<EOS>
---
Sir
Leicester
was

and
would

,
but
Mr
Bucket
palpably

---
"
and
recent

have

it
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
As

,
Mr
Bucket

I

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

;

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

"
Good

"
   
<EOS>
"

Leicester

,

,
"
Mr
Bucket

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

Dedlock
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

.
 
<EOS>
A
gentleman
can

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,

,
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

naturally

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,
away

---

---
<EOS>
have

;

that

;
and

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

Bucket
.
<EOS>
"
Love
him
like
a
brother
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
what
's
up
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
what
business
have
we
come
upon
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Smallweed
asks
,
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

's

in

Sir
Leicester

,

.
 
<EOS>
Come
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,
takes
a

's
counsel
with

in

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chadband
,
expressing

oil

,

,
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
You
first
!
"
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
the
client

of
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
"
pipes
Grandfather
Smallweed
then
;
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
was
useful
to

,
and
he
was
useful

.
 
<EOS>
Krook
,
dead
and
gone
,
was
my
brother
-

-

.
<EOS>
He
was
own
brother
to
a

---
leastways
Mrs
Smallweed
.
<EOS>
I
come
into
Krook
's

.
 
<EOS>
I
examined

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
There

a

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
Mr

,

<EOS>
I
'm

<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
Dear

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Oh
,

,

!

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Now

"

"

-

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
YOU

<EOS>
Do

<EOS>

.

.
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
Mr

,

.

<EOS>

.

.

<EOS>

;

,

<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

.

,

.
 
<EOS>

!

;

!

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Mrs

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"
YOU

-

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs

merely

him
he
can
"
offer
"
twenty

.
   
<EOS>
"
My

law
-
stationer
's
good

,
over

,
"
says
Mr
Bucket
,
luring
Mrs
Snagsby
forward

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
may
YOUR
game
be
,
ma'am
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Snagsby
is
at
first
prevented
,
by
tears
and
lamentations
,
from
stating
the
nature
of
her
game
,
but
by
degrees
it
confusedly
comes
to
light
that
she
is
a
woman
overwhelmed
with
injuries
and
wrongs
,
whom
Mr
Snagsby
has
habitually
deceived
,
abandoned
,
and
sought
to
keep
in
darkness
,
and
whose
chief
comfort
,
under
her
afflictions
,
has
been
the
sympathy
of
the
late
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
who
showed
so
much
commiseration
for
her
on
one
occasion
of
his
calling
in
Cook
's
Court
in
the
absence
of
her
perjured
husband
that
she
has
of
late
habitually
carried
to
him
all
her
woes
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
<EOS>
it
appears
,
the
present
company
excepted
,
has
plotted
against
Mrs
Snagsby
's
peace
.
<EOS>
There
is
Mr
Guppy
,
clerk
to
Kenge
and
Carboy
,
who
was
at
first
as
open
as
the
sun
at
noon
,
but
who
suddenly
shut
up
as
close
as
midnight
,
under
the
influence
---
no
doubt
---
of
Mr
Snagsby
's
suborning
and

.
 
<EOS>
There
is
Mr
Weevle
,
friend
of
Mr
Guppy
,
who
lived
mysteriously
up
a
court
,
owing
to
the
like
coherent
causes
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
Krook
,
deceased
;
there
was
Nimrod
,
deceased
;
and
there
was
Jo
,
deceased
;
and
they
were
"
all
in
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
what
,
Mrs
Snagsby
does
not
with
particularity
express
,
but
she
knows
that
Jo
was
Mr
Snagsby
's
son
,
"
as
well
as
if
a

had
spoken
it
,
"
and
she
followed
Mr
Snagsby
when
he
went
on
his
last
visit
to
the
boy
,
and
if
he
was
not
his
son
why
did
he
go
?
 
<EOS>
The
one
occupation
of
her
life
has
been
,
for
some
time
back
,
to
follow
Mr
Snagsby
to
and
fro
,
and
up
and
down
,
and
to
piece
suspicious
circumstances
together
---
and
every
circumstance
that
has
happened
has
been
most
suspicious
;
and
in
this
way
she
has
pursued
her
object
of
detecting
and
confounding
her
false
husband
,
night
and
day
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
did
it
come
to
pass
that
she
brought
the
Chadbands
and
Mr
Tulkinghorn
together
,
and
conferred
with
Mr
Tulkinghorn
on
the
change
in
Mr
Guppy
,
and
helped
to
turn
up
the
circumstances
in
which
the
present
company
are
interested
,
casually
,
by
the
wayside
,
being
still
and
ever
on
the
great
high
road
that
is
to
terminate
in
Mr
Snagsby
's
full
exposure
and
a
matrimonial

.
 
<EOS>
All
this
,
Mrs
Snagsby
,
as
an
injured
woman
,
and
the
friend
of
Mrs
Chadband
,
and
the
follower
of
Mr
Chadband
,
and
the
mourner
of
the
late
Mr
Tulkinghorn
,
is
here
to
certify
under
the
seal
of
confidence
,
with
every
possible
confusion
and
involvement
possible
and
impossible
,
having
no
pecuniary
motive
whatever
,
no
scheme
or
project
but
the
one
mentioned
,
and
bringing
here
,
and
taking
everywhere
,
her
own
dense
atmosphere
of
dust
,
arising
from
the
ceaseless
working
of
her
mill
of
jealousy
.
   
<EOS>
While
this
exordium
is
in
hand
---
and
it
takes
some
time
---
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
,
who
has
seen
through
the
transparency
of
Mrs
Snagsby
's
vinegar
at
a
glance
,
confers
with
his
familiar
demon
and
bestows
his
shrewd
attention
on
the
Chadbands
and
Mr
Smallweed
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
remains
immovable
,
with
the
same
icy
surface
upon
him
,
except
that
he
once
or
twice
looks
towards
Mr
Bucket
,
as

as
having
been
overheard
in
high
words
with
the
deceased
on
former
occasions
---
even
threatening
him
,
as
the
witness
made
out
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
ask
me
,
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
whether
from
the
first
I
believed
George
to
be
the
murderer
,
I
tell
you
candidly
no
,
but
he
might
be
,
notwithstanding
,
and
there
was
enough
against
him
to
make
it
my
duty
to
take
him
and
get
him
kept
under

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
observe
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Bucket
bends
forward
in
some
excitement
---
for
him
---
and
inaugurates
what
he
is
going
to
say
with
one
ghostly
beat
of
his
forefinger
in
the
air
,
Mademoiselle
Hortense
fixes
her
black
eyes
upon
him
with
a
dark
frown
and
sets
her
dry
lips
closely
and
firmly
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
went
home
,
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
Baronet
,
at
night
and
found
this
young
woman
having
supper
with
my
wife
,
Mrs
Bucket
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
made
a
mighty
show
of
being
fond
of
Mrs
Bucket
from
her
first

as
our

,
but
that
night
she
made
more
than
ever
---
in

,

.
 
<EOS>
Likewise

her
respect
,
and
all

,
for
the
lamented

of
the

Tulkinghorn
.
<EOS>
By

,

the

and
saw

with

,
that

had
done

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mademoiselle
is
hardly

in
straining

and

words
,
"
You
are

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

Bucket
,
"
had

on
the

the

?
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
to
the
theayter
.
 
<EOS>
(
She
really
was
there
,
<EOS>
I
have
since
found
,
both
before
the
deed
and
after

.
)
 
<EOS>
I
knew

had
an
artful

to

and
that
proof
would
be
very

;
and
I
laid

for

---
such

as

never

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
When

,
our

this
young
woman
's

,
I

Mrs
Bucket
's

that

.
 
<EOS>
My

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
Baronet
<EOS>
,

,

<EOS>
To

"

<EOS>

every

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

Sir

,

,
"

,
"

I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

says

Bucket
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
along
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
do
these
things
?
 
<EOS>
Then
you
can
do
as
you
please
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
but
<EOS>
the
death
,
it
is
all
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
go
,
my
angel
.
<EOS>
Adieu
,
you
old
man
,
grey
.
 
<EOS>
I
pity
you
,
and
I
despise
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
last
words
she
snaps
her
teeth
together
as
if
her
mouth
closed
with
a
spring
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
to
describe
how
Mr
Bucket
gets
her
out
,
but
he
accomplishes
that
feat
in
a
manner
so
peculiar
to
himself
,
enfolding
and

her
like

,
and
hovering
away
with
her
as
if
he
were
a
homely
Jupiter
and
she
the
object
of
his
affections
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
,
left
alone
,
remains
in
the
same
attitude
,
as
though
he
were
still
listening
and
his
attention
were
still
occupied
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
gazes
round
the
empty
room
,
and
finding
it
deserted
,
rises
unsteadily
to
his
feet
,
pushes
back
his
chair
,
and
walks
a
few
steps
,
supporting
himself
by

table
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
stops
,
and
with
more
of
those
inarticulate
sounds
,
lifts
up
his
eyes
and
seems
to
stare
at
something
.
   
<EOS>
Heaven
knows
what
he
sees
.
 
<EOS>
The
green
,
green
woods
of
Chesney
Wold
,
the
noble
house
,
the
pictures
of
his
forefathers
,
<EOS>
strangers
defacing
them
,
officers
of
police
coarsely
handling
his
most
precious
heirlooms
,
thousands
of
fingers
pointing
at
him
,
thousands
of
faces
sneering
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
such
shadows
flit
before
him
to
his
bewilderment
,
there
is
one
other
shadow
which
he
can

with
something
like
distinctness
even
yet
and
to
which
alone
he
addresses
his
tearing
of
his
white
hair
and
his
extended
arms
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
she
in
association
with
whom
,
saving
that
she
has
been
for
years
a
main
fibre
of
the
root
of
his
dignity
and
pride
,
he
has
never
had
a
selfish
thought
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
she
whom
he
has
loved
,
admired
,
honoured
,
and
set
up
for
the
world
to
respect
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
she
who
,
at
the
core
of
all
the
constrained

and
conventionalities
of
his
life
,
has
been
a

of
living
tenderness
and
love
,
susceptible
as
nothing
else
is
of
being

with
the
agony
he
feels
.
 
<EOS>
He
sees
her
,
almost
to
the
exclusion
of
himself
,
and
can
not
bear
to
look
upon
her
cast
down
from
the
high
place
she
has
graced
so
well
.
   
<EOS>
And
even
to
the

of
his

on

,

,
he
can
yet

her

with
something
like
distinctness
in
the
midst
of
those
intrusive
sounds
,
and
in
a
tone
of
mourning
and
compassion
rather
than

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
55
.
<EOS>
Flight
 
Inspector
Bucket
of
the
Detective
has
not
yet
struck
his
great
blow
,
as
just
now
chronicled
,
but
is
yet
refreshing
himself
with
sleep
preparatory
to
his
field

day
,
when
through
the
night
and
along
the
freezing
wintry
roads
a
chaise
and
pair
comes
out
of
Lincolnshire
,
making
its
way
towards
London
.
   
<EOS>
Railroads
shall
soon
traverse
all
this
country
,
and
with
a
rattle
and
a
glare
<EOS>
the
engine
and
train
shall
shoot
like

over
the
wide

,
turning
the

;
but
as
yet
such
things
are
non

in
these
parts
,
though
not
wholly

.
 
<EOS>
Preparations
are
afoot
,
measurements
are
made
,
ground
is
staked
out
.
 
<EOS>
Bridges
are
begun
,
and
their
not
yet
united
piers
desolately
look
at
one
another
over
roads
and
streams
like
brick
and
mortar
couples
with
an
obstacle
to
their
union
;
fragments
of

are

up
and

as

with

of

and

;
tripods
of

appear
on

,
where
there
are
rumours
of

;
everything
looks
chaotic
and

in
full

.
 
<EOS>
Along
the
freezing
roads
,
and
through
the
night
,
the
post
-
chaise
makes
its
way
without
a
railroad
on

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
so
many
years
housekeeper
at
Chesney
Wold
,
sits
within
the

;
and
by

Mrs
Bagnet
with

.
 
<EOS>
The
old
girl
would
prefer
the
bar
in
front
,
as
being
exposed
to
the
weather
and
a

sort
of
perch
more
in

her
usual

,
but
Mrs
Rouncewell
is
too
thoughtful
of
her
comfort
to
admit
of
her
proposing
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
lady
can
not
make
enough
of
the
old
girl
.
 
<EOS>
She
sits
,
in
her
stately
manner
,
holding
her
hand
,
and
regardless
of
its
roughness
,
puts
it
often
to
her

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
mother
,
my
dear
soul
,
"
says
she
many
times
,
"
and
you
found
out
my
George
's
mother
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
George
,
"
returns
Mrs
Bagnet
,
"
was
always
free
with
me
,

,
and
when
he
said

our

to
my
Woolwich
that

my

grey
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
my

!
"
<EOS>
returns

,

.
<EOS>
"
My

,

!
 
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
For

lion

,

my
George
,
always
from
a
baby
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
old

's

as

,
while

,
all

,
what
a

;

<EOS>
;

;

.
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
And

,

<EOS>
upright

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Bagnet
,
with

,

---

---
 
and

,
"
So
I

(

)
,
"

,
George
,

?
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

"

AM

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

"

"

,

.
<EOS>
If

wo

.
"
 
<EOS>

how

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
So

?
 
<EOS>
And

Mrs
Rouncewell
,

to

Dedlock

.
 
<EOS>
George
has

that

's

,

"
Lignum

-

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
All

Mrs

at

.
 
<EOS>
Trilling

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

Bless

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear

!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
"

,

Lady
,

!
"
<EOS>
over

.
   
<EOS>
The

wears

,
and
the

,
and

-

comes

.
 
<EOS>
It
has

of

in

,
slowly

.
 
<EOS>
London
reached
,
the

alight
,
the
old
housekeeper
in

and

,
Mrs
Bagnet
quite

---
as

,

.
   
<EOS>
But

,

old

has

,

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

,

old
china
<EOS>
she

,

heart

is

more
than
<EOS>
even

of
this
wayward

has

these

.
   
<EOS>
Approaching

cell
,

find
the
door
opening
and
a

.
 
<EOS>
The
old
girl
promptly

to

to

nothing
;
assenting
with
a
nod
,
he

to
enter
as

.
   
<EOS>
So
George
,
who
is
writing
at
his
table
,
supposing
himself
to
be
alone
,
does
not
raise

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
The
old
housekeeper
looks
at
him
,
and
those
wandering
hands
of
hers
are
quite
enough
for
Mrs
Bagnet
's
confirmation
,
even
if
she
could
see
the
mother
and
the
son
together
,
knowing
what
she
knows
,
and
doubt
their
relationship
.
   
<EOS>
Not
a
rustle
of
the
housekeeper
's
dress
,
not
a
gesture
,
not
a
word
betrays
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
stands
looking
at
him
as
he
writes
on
,
all
unconscious
,
and
only
her
fluttering
hands
give
utterance
to
her
emotions
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
are
very
eloquent
,
very
,
very
eloquent
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bagnet
understands
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
speak
of
gratitude
,
of
joy
,
of
grief
,
of
hope
;
of
inextinguishable
affection
,
cherished
with
no
return
since
this
stalwart
man
was
a
stripling
;
of
a
better
son
loved
less
,
and
this
son
loved
so
fondly
and
so
proudly
;
and
they
speak
in
such
touching
language
that
Mrs
Bagnet
's
eyes
brim
up
with
tears
<EOS>
and
they
run
glistening
down
her
sun
-
brown
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
George
Rouncewell
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
dear
child
,
turn
and
look
at
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
trooper
starts
up
,
clasps
his
mother
<EOS>
round
the
neck
,
and
falls
down
on
his
knees
before
her
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
in
a
late

,
whether

the
first
association
that
comes
back
upon
him
,
he
puts

as

it
says

,
and
raising

towards
her
breast
,
bows
down

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
George
,
my
dearest
son
!
 
<EOS>
Always
my
favourite
,
and
my
favourite
still
,
where
have
you
been
these
cruel
years
and
years
?
 
<EOS>
Grown
such
a
man
too
<EOS>
,
grown
such
a
fine
strong
man
.
 
<EOS>
Grown
<EOS>
so
like
what
I
knew
he
must
be
,
if
it
pleased
God
he
was
alive
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
can
ask
,
and
he
can

,
nothing
connected
for
a

.
 
<EOS>
All
that
time
the
old
girl
,
turned
away
,
leans
one

against
the
whitened
wall
,
leans
her
honest

upon
it
,
wipes
her

with
her
serviceable
grey
cloak
,
and
quite

herself
like
the
best
of
old
girls
as
she
is
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"
says
the
trooper
when
they
are
more
composed
,
"
forgive
me
first
of
all
,
for
I
know
my
need
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Forgive
him
!
 
<EOS>
She
does
it
with
all
her
heart
and
soul
.
 
<EOS>
She
always
has
done
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
tells
him
how
she
has
had
it
written
in
her
will
,
<EOS>
these
many
years
,
that
he
was
her
beloved
son
George
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
never
believed
any
ill
of
him
,
never
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
had
died
without
this
happiness
---
and
she
is
an
old
woman
now
and
ca
n't
look

---
she
would
have
blessed
him
with
her
last

,
if
she
had
had
her
senses
,
as
her
beloved
son
George
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
I
have
been
an
undutiful
trouble
to

,
and
I
have
my
reward
;
but
of
late
years
I
have
had
a
kind

.
 
<EOS>
When

left

I
did

,
mother
<EOS>
---
I
am
afraid
not

---
for

;
and

'

,
harum

think
that
I
cared
for
nobody
,
no
not

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

has
dried
his

and

,

there

between

<EOS>
"
So
I
wrote
a
line
home
,
mother
,
as
you
too
well

,
to
say
I
had
'
listed
under
another

,
and
I

.
 
<EOS>
Abroad
,

one
time
I
thought
I
would
write
home
next

,
when
I
might

better
off
;
and
when
that

was
out
,
I
thought
I
would
write
home
next
year
,
when
I
might
be
better
off
;
and
when
that
year
was
out
again
,
perhaps
I
did
n't

.
 
<EOS>
So

,
from

,
through
a
service
of

,
till
I
began
to

,
and
to
ask

why

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
find
any
fault
,
child
---
but
not
to
ease
my
mind
,
George
?
<EOS>
Not
a
word
to
your
loving
mother
,
who
was
growing

too
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
almost

the
trooper
afresh
,
but
he
sets

up
with
a

rough
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Heaven
forgive
me
,
mother
,
but
I
thought
there
would
be
small
consolation
then
in
hearing
anything
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
you
,
respected
and
esteemed
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
my
brother
,
as
I
read
in
chance
North
Country
papers
now
and
then
,
rising
to
be
prosperous
and
famous
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
I
a
dragoon
,
roving
,
unsettled
,
not
self
-
made
like
him
,
but
self
-
unmade
---
all
my

advantages
thrown

,
all
my
little

unlearnt
,
nothing
picked
up
but
what
unfitted
me
for
most

that
I

think

.
 
<EOS>
What
business
had
I
to
make
myself
known
?
 
<EOS>
After

all
that
time
go
by
me
,
what
good
could
come
of

?
 
<EOS>
The
worst
was
past
with
you
,
mother
.
<EOS>
I
knew
by
that

(
being
a
man
)
<EOS>
how
you
had
mourned
for
me
,
and
wept

,

;
and
the
pain
was
over
,
or
was

,
and
I
was
better

was
.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
do
n't
say
that
it
was
so
,
mother
,
but
that
I
made
it
out
to
be
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
just
now
,
what
good
could
come
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
my
dear
mother
,
some
good
might
have
come
of
it
to
myself
---
and
there
was
the
meanness
of

.
 
<EOS>
You
would
have
sought
me
out
;
you
would

purchased
my

;
you
would
have
taken
me
down

Chesney
Wold
;
you
would
have

my
brother
and

brother
's

;
you
would
all
have
considered
anxiously
how

do
something
for

set

.
 
<EOS>
But

could
any

you
feel
sure
of
me
when
I
could

as

?
 
<EOS>
How

help
regarding

to

,

?
 
<EOS>
How
could
I
look
my
brother
's

in

an

---
I
,
the
vagabond
boy
who
had

and

the

's

?
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
George
.
"
 
<EOS>
Such

my
words
,
mother
,
when
I
passed
this
in
review
before

:
"
You
have
made

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
lie
upon

.
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Rouncewell
,

,

at
the
old
girl
with

upon

,
as

to

,
"
I

!
"
 
<EOS>
The

girl
relieves

and

,

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
Mrs
Bagnet
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
To

Bagnet

two

.
   
<EOS>
And
now
the
old
lady
impresses
upon
her

George
,

own
dear
recovered
boy
,
her

,
the

,

,

,

,
that

,

self

,

,

poor

's

until

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
'
tis
little

,
"

,

;
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Bagnet
,
you

my
mother
,
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
A

from

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
If

"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
He

as

---
out

,

,

---

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"

,
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

.
 
<EOS>
Do

brother
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
know
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
In

,
mother
,
I
ca
n't

;
I
ca
n't
make
up
my
mmd
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
has
proved

so

and
has
done

've

that
I
have
n't

to

.
 
<EOS>
How

?
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
No

;

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

---

---

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

's

to

that
his
rip

brother
has
turned
up
,
I
could
wish
,
"
says

trooper
,

,
"
to

and
be

as
to
advancing

by

seems

.
"
   
<EOS>
As

evidently
has

rooted

on

,

the
depth
of
it
is
recognized
in
Mrs
Bagnet
's

,
his
mother
yields
her

to
what
he
asks
.
 
<EOS>
For
this
he
thanks
her
kindly
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
all
other
respects
,
my
dear
mother
,
I
'll
be
as

and

as
you
can

;
on
this

alone
,
I
stand

.
 
<EOS>
So
now
I
am
ready
even
for
the
lawyers
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
drawing
up
,
"
he
glances
at

the

,
"
an
exact

of
what
I
knew
of
the
deceased
and
how
I
came
to
be
involved
in
this

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
entered
,
plain
and
regular
,
like
an
orderly
-
book
;
<EOS>
not
a
word
in
it
but
what
's
wanted
for
the
facts
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
intend
to
read
it
,
straight
on
end
,
whensoever
I
was
called
upon
to
say
anything
in
my
defence
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
I
may
be
let
to
do
it
still
;
but
I
have
no

a
will
of
my
own
in
this
case
,
and
whatever
is
said
or
done
,
I
give
my
promise
not
to
have
any
.
"
   
<EOS>
Matters
being
brought
to
this
so
far
satisfactory
pass
,
and
time
being
on
the
wane
,
Mrs
Bagnet
proposes
a
departure
.
 
<EOS>
Again
and
again
the
old
lady
hangs
upon
her
son
's
neck
,
and
again
and
again
the
trooper
holds
her
to
his
broad
chest
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
to
take
my
mother
,
Mrs
Bagnet
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
the
town
house
,
my
dear
,
the
family
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
some
business
there
that
must
be
looked
to
directly
,
"
Mrs

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
to
do
with
that
,
or
what
have
you
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
understand
you
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
ladyship
,
I
come
to
put
you
on
your
guard
.
 
<EOS>
There
may
be
no
occasion
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
have
only
done
my
best
to
keep
my
promise
to
Miss
Summerson
.
 
<EOS>
I
strongly
suspect
(
from
what
Small
has
dropped
,
and
from
what
we
have
corkscrewed
out
of
him
)
that
those
letters
I
was
to
have
brought
to
your
ladyship
were
not
destroyed
when
I
supposed
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
That
if
there
was
anything
to
be
blown
upon
,
it
IS
blown
upon
.
 
<EOS>
That
the
visitors
I
have
alluded
to
have
been
here
this
morning
to
make
money
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
the
money
is
made
,
or
making
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
picks
up
his
hat
and
rises
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
ladyship
,
you
know
best
whether
there
's
anything
in
what
I
say
or
whether
there
's
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Something
or
nothing
,
I
have
acted
up
to
Miss
Summerson
's
wishes
in
letting
things
alone
and
in
undoing
what
I
had
begun
to
do
,
as
far
as
possible
;
that
's
sufficient
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
In
case
I
should
be
taking
a
liberty
in
putting
your
ladyship
on
your
guard
when
there
's
no
necessity
for
it
<EOS>
,
you
will
endeavour
,
I
should
hope
,
to
outlive
my
presumption
,
and
I
shall
endeavour
to
outlive
your
disapprobation
.
 
<EOS>
I
now
take
my
farewell
of
your
ladyship
,
and
assure
you
that
there
's
no
danger
of
your
ever
being
waited
on
by
me
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
scarcely
acknowledges
these
parting
words
by
any
look
,
but
when
he
has
been
gone
a
little
while
,
she
rings
her
bell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Sir
Leicester
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mercury
reports
that
he
is
at
present
shut
up
in
the
library
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Has
Sir
Leicester
had
any
visitors
this
morning
?
"
   
<EOS>
Several
,
on
business
.
 
<EOS>
Mercury
proceeds
to
a
description
of
them
,
which
has
been
anticipated
by
Mr
Guppy
.
 
<EOS>
Enough
;
he
may
go
.
   
<EOS>
So
!
 
<EOS>
All
is
broken
down
.
 
<EOS>
Her
name
is
in
these
many
mouths
,
her
husband
knows
his
wrongs
,
her
shame
will
be
published
---
may
be
spreading
while
she
thinks
about
it
---
and
in
addition
to
the
thunderbolt
so
long
foreseen
by
her
,
so
unforeseen
by
him
<EOS>
,
she
is
denounced
by
an
invisible
accuser
as
the
murderess
of
her
enemy
.
   
<EOS>
Her
enemy
he
was
,
and
she
has
often
,
often
,
often
wished
him
dead
.
<EOS>
Her
enemy
he
is
,
even
in
his
grave
.
 
<EOS>
This
dreadful
accusation
comes
upon
her
like
a
new
torment
at
his
lifeless
hand
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
she
recalls
how
she
was
secretly
at
his
door
that
night
,
and
how
she
may
be
represented
to
have
sent
her
favourite
girl
away
so
soon
before
merely
to
release
herself
from
observation
,
she
shudders
as
if
the
hangman
's
hands
were
at
her
neck
.
   
<EOS>
She
has
thrown
herself
upon
the
floor
and
lies
with
her
hair
all
wildly
scattered
and
her
face
buried
in
the
cushions
of
a
couch
.
<EOS>
She
rises
up
,
hurries
to
and
fro
,
flings
herself
down
again
,
and
rocks
and
moans
.
 
<EOS>
The
horror
that
is
upon
her
is
unutterable
.
 
<EOS>
If
she
really
were
the
murderess
,
it
could
hardly
be
,
for
the
moment
,
more
intense
.
   
<EOS>
For
as
her
murderous
perspective
,
before
the
doing
of
the
deed
,
however
subtle
the
precautions
for
its
commission
,
would
have
been
closed
up
by
a
gigantic
dilatation
of
the
hateful
figure
,
preventing
her
from
seeing
any
consequences
beyond
it
;
and
as
those
consequences
would
have
rushed
in
,
in
an
unimagined
flood
,
the
moment
the
figure
was
laid
low
---
which
always
happens
when
a
murder
is
done
;
so
,
now
she
sees
that
when
he
used
to
be
on
the
watch
before
her
,
and
she
used
to
think
,
"
if
some
mortal
stroke
would
but
fall
on
this
old
man
and
take
him
from
my
way
!
<EOS>
"
it
was
but
wishing
that
all
he
held
against
her
in
his
hand
might
be
flung
to
the
winds
and
chance
-
sown
in
many
places
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
too
,
with
the
wicked
relief
she
has
felt
in
his
death
.
 
<EOS>
What
was
his
death
but
the
key
-
stone
of
a
gloomy
arch
removed
,
and
now
the
arch
begins
to
fall
in
a
thousand
fragments
,
each
crushing
and
mangling
piecemeal
!
   
<EOS>
Thus
,
a
terrible
impression
steals
upon
and
overshadows
her
that
from
this
pursuer
,
living
or
dead
---
obdurate
and
imperturbable
before
her
in
his
well
-
remembered
shape
,
or
not
more
obdurate
and
imperturbable
in
his
coffin
-
bed
---
there
is
no
escape
but
in
death
.
<EOS>
Hunted
,
she
flies
.
 
<EOS>
The
complication
of
her
shame
,
her
dread
,
remorse
,
and
misery
,
overwhelms
her
at
its
height
;
and
even
her
strength
of
self
-
reliance
is
overturned
and
whirled
away
like
a
leaf
before
a
mighty
wind
.
   
<EOS>
She
hurriedly
addresses
these
lines
to
her
husband
,
seals
,
and
leaves
them
on
her
table
:
   
If
I
am
sought
for
,
or
accused
of
,
his
murder
,
believe
that
I
am
wholly
innocent
.
 
<EOS>
Believe
no
other
good
of
me
,
for
I
am
innocent
of
nothing
else
that
you
have
heard
,
or
will
hear
,
laid
to
my
charge
.
<EOS>
He
prepared
me
,
on
that
fatal
night
,
for
his
disclosure
of
my
guilt
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
After
he
had
left
me
,
I
went
out
on
pretence
of
walking
in
the
garden
where
I
sometimes
walk
,
but
really
to
follow
him
and
make
one
last
petition
that
he
would
not
protract
the
dreadful
suspense
on
which
I
have
been
racked
by
him
,
you
do
not
know
how
long
,
but
would
mercifully
strike
next
morning
.
   
<EOS>
I
found
his
house
dark
and
silent
.
 
<EOS>
I
rang
twice
at
his
door
,
but
there
was
no
reply
,
and
I
came
home
.
   
<EOS>
I
have
no
home
left
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
encumber
you
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
May
you
,
in
your
just
resentment
,
be
able
to
forget
the
unworthy
woman
on
whom
you
have
wasted
a
most
generous
devotion
---
who
avoids
you
only
with
a
deeper
shame
than
that
with
which
she
hurries
from
herself
---
and
who
writes
this
last
adieu
.
   
<EOS>
She
veils
and
dresses
quickly
,
leaves
all
her
jewels
and
her
money
,
listens
,
goes
downstairs
at
a
moment
when
the
hall
is
empty
,
opens
and
shuts
the
great
door
,
flutters
away
in
the
shrill
frosty
wind
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
56
.
<EOS>
Pursuit
 
<EOS>
Impassive
,
as
behoves
its
high
breeding
,
the
Dedlock
town
house
stares
at
the
other
houses
in
the
street
of
dismal
grandeur
and
gives
no
outward
sign
of
anything
going
wrong
within
.
 
<EOS>
Carriages
rattle
,
doors
are
battered
at
,
the
world
exchanges
calls
;
ancient
charmers
with
skeleton
throats
and
peachy
cheeks
that
have
a
rather
ghastly
bloom
upon
them
seen
by
daylight
,
when
indeed
these
fascinating
creatures
look
like
Death
and
the
Lady
fused
together
,
dazzle
the
eyes
of
men
.
 
<EOS>
Forth
from
the
frigid
mews
come
easily
swinging
carriages
guided
by
short
-
legged
coachmen
in
flaxen
wigs
,
deep
sunk
into
downy
hammercloths
,
and
up
behind
mount
luscious
Mercuries
bearing
sticks
of
state
and
wearing
cocked
hats
broadwise
,
a
spectacle
for
the
angels
.
   
<EOS>
The
Dedlock
town
house
changes
not
externally
,
and
hours
pass
before
its
exalted
dullness
is
disturbed
within
.
 
<EOS>
But
Volumnia
the
fair
,
being
subject
to
the
prevalent
complaint
of
boredom
and
finding
that
disorder
attacking
her
spirits
with
some
virulence
,
ventures
at
length
to
repair
to
the
library
for
change
of
scene
.
<EOS>
Her
gentle
tapping
at
the
door
producing
no
response
,
she
opens
it
and
peeps
in
;
seeing
no
one
there
,
takes
possession
.
   
<EOS>
The
sprightly
Dedlock
is
reputed
,
in
that
grass
-
grown
city
of
the
ancients
,
Bath
,
to
be
stimulated
by
an
urgent
curiosity
which
impels
her
on
all
convenient
and
inconvenient
occasions
to
sidle
about
with
a
golden
glass
at
her
eye
,
peering
into
objects
of
every
description
.
 
<EOS>
Certain
<EOS>
it
is
that
she
avails
herself
of
the
present
opportunity
of
hovering
over
her
kinsman
's
letters
and
papers
like
a
bird
,
taking
a
short
peck
at
this
document
and
a
blink
with
her
head
on
one
side
at
that
document
,
and
hopping
about
from
table
to
table
with
her
glass
at
her
eye
in
an
inquisitive
and
restless
manner
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
these
researches
she
stumbles
over
something
,
and
turning
her
glass
in
that
direction
,
sees
her
kinsman
lying
on
the
ground
like
a
felled
tree
.
   
<EOS>
Volumnia
's
pet
little
scream
acquires
a
considerable
augmentation
of
reality
from
this
surprise
,
and
the
house
is
quickly
in
commotion
.
 
<EOS>
Servants
tear
up
and
down
stairs
,
bells
are
violently
rung
,
doctors
are
sent
for
,
and
Lady
Dedlock
is
sought
in
all
directions
,
but
not
found
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
has
seen
or
heard
her
since
she
last
rang
her
bell
.
 
<EOS>
Her
letter
to
Sir
Leicester
is
discovered
on
her
table
,
but
it
is
doubtful
yet
whether
he
has
not
received
another
missive
from
another
world
requiring
to
be
personally
answered
,
and
all
the
living
languages
,
and
all
the
dead
,
are
as
one
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
They
lay
him
down
upon
his
bed
,
and
chafe
,
and
rub
,
and
fan
,
and
put
ice
to
his
head
,
and
try
every
means
of
restoration
.
 
<EOS>
Howbeit
,
the
day
has
ebbed
away
,
and
it
is
night
in
his
room
before
his
stertorous
breathing
lulls
or
his
fixed
eyes
show
any
consciousness
of
the
candle
that
is
occasionally
passed
before
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
this
change
begins
,
it
goes
on
;
and
by
and
by
he
nods
or
moves
his
eyes
or
even
his
hand
in
token
that
he
hears
and
comprehends
.
   
<EOS>
He
fell
down
,
this
morning
,
a
handsome
stately
gentleman
,
somewhat
infirm
,
but
of
a
fine
presence
,
and
with
a
well
-
filled
face
.
 
<EOS>
He
lies
upon
his
bed
,
an
aged
man
with
sunken
cheeks
,
the
decrepit
shadow
of
himself
.
 
<EOS>
His
voice
was
rich
and
mellow
and
he
had
so
long
been
thoroughly
persuaded
of
the
weight
and
import
to
mankind
of
any
word
he
said
that
his
words
really
had
come
to
sound
as
if
there
were
something
in
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
now
he
can
only
whisper
,
and
what
he
whispers
sounds
like
what
it
is
---
mere
jumble
and
jargon
.
   
<EOS>
His
favourite
and
faithful
housekeeper
stands
at
his
bedside
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
first
act
he
notices
,
and
he
clearly
derives
pleasure
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
After
vainly
trying
to
make
himself
understood
in
speech
,
he
makes
signs
for
a
pencil
.
 
<EOS>
So
inexpressively
that
they
can
not
at
first
understand
him
;
it
is
his
old
housekeeper
who
makes
out
what
he
wants
and
brings
in
a
slate
.
   
<EOS>
After
pausing
for
some
time
,
he
slowly
scrawls
upon
it
in
a
hand
that
is
not
his
,
"
Chesney
Wold
?
"
   
<EOS>
No
,
she
tells
him
;
he
is
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
taken
ill
in
the
library
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
Right
thankful
she
is
that
she
happened
to
come
to
London
and
is
able
to
attend
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
an
illness
of
any
serious
consequence
,
Sir
Leicester
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
much
better
to
-
morrow
,
Sir
Leicester
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
gentlemen
say
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
,
with
the
tears
coursing
down
her
fair
old
face
.
   
<EOS>
After
making
a
survey
of
the
room
and
looking
with
particular
attention
all
round
the
bed
where
the
doctors
stand
,
he
writes
,
"
<EOS>
My
Lady
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
Lady
went
out
,
Sir
Leicester
,
before
you
were
taken
ill
,
and
do
n't
know
of
your
illness
yet
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
points
again
,
in
great
agitation
,
at
the
two
words
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
try
to
quiet
him
,
but
he
points
again
with
increased
agitation
.
 
<EOS>
On
their
looking
at
one
another
,
not
knowing
what
to
say
,
he
takes
the
slate
once
more
and
writes
"
My
Lady
.
 
<EOS>
For
God
's
sake
,
where
?
"
 
<EOS>
And
makes
an
imploring
moan
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
thought
better
that
his
old
housekeeper
should
give
him
Lady
Dedlock
's
letter
,
the
contents
of
which
no
one
knows
or
can
surmise
.
 
<EOS>
She
opens
it
for
him
and
puts
it
out
for
his
perusal
.
<EOS>
Having
read
it
twice
by
a
great
effort
,
he
turns
it
down
so
that
it
shall
not
be
seen
and
lies
moaning
.
 
<EOS>
He
passes
into
a
kind
of
relapse
or
into
a
swoon
,
and
it
is
an
hour
before
he
opens
his
eyes
,
reclining
on
his
faithful
and
attached
old
servant
's
arm
.
<EOS>
The
doctors
know
that
he
is
best
with
her
,
and
when
not
actively
engaged
about
him
,
stand
aloof
.
   
<EOS>
The
slate
comes
into
requisition
again
,
but
the
word
he
wants
to
write
he
can
not
remember
.
 
<EOS>
His
anxiety
,
his
eagerness
,

<EOS>
Let
me
come
up
with
her
alone
---
a
hard
matter
---
and
I
'll
do
my
best
,
but
I
do
n't
answer
for
what
the
best
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
Time
flies
;
it
's
getting
on
for
one
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
When
one
strikes
,
there
's
another
hour
gone
,
and
it
's
worth
a
thousand
pound
now
instead
of
a
hundred
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
is
all
true
,
and
the
pressing
nature
of
the
case
can
not
be
questioned
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jarndyce
begs
him
to
remain
there
while
he
speaks
to
Miss
Summerson
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
says
he
will
,
but
acting
on
his
usual
principle
,
does
no
such
thing
,
following
upstairs
instead
and
keeping
his
man
in
sight
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
remains
,
dodging
and
lurking
about
in
the
gloom
of
the
staircase
while
they
confer
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
very
little
time
Mr
Jarndyce
comes
down
and
tells
him
that
Miss
Summerson
will
join
him
directly
and
place
herself
under
his
protection
to
accompany
him
where
he
pleases
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
,
satisfied
,
expresses
high
approval
and
awaits
her
coming
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
There
he
mounts
a
high
tower
in
his
mind
and
looks
out
far
and
wide
.
 
<EOS>
Many
solitary
figures
he
perceives
creeping
through
the
streets
;
many
solitary
figures
out
on
heaths
,
and
roads
,
and
lying
under
haystacks
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
figure
that
he
seeks
is
not
among
them
.
<EOS>
Other
solitaries
he
perceives
,
in
nooks
of
bridges
,
looking
over
;
and
in
shadowed
places
down
by
the
river
's
level
;
and
a
dark
,
dark
,
shapeless
object
drifting
with
the
tide
,
more
solitary
than
all
,
clings
with
a
drowning
hold
on
his
attention
.
   
<EOS>
Where
is
she
?
 
<EOS>
Living
or
dead
<EOS>
,
where
is
she
?
 
<EOS>
If
,
as
he
folds
the
handkerchief
and
carefully
puts
it
up
,
it
were
able
with
an
enchanted
power
to
bring
before
him
the
place
where
she
found
it
and
the
night
-
landscape
near
the
cottage
where
it
covered
the
little
child
,
would
he
descry
her
there
?
 
<EOS>
On
the
waste
where
the
brick
-
kilns
are
burning
with
a
pale
blue
flare
,
where
the
straw
-
roofs
of
the
wretched
huts
in
which
the
bricks
are
made
are
being
scattered
by
the
wind
,
where
the
clay
and
water
are
hard
frozen
and
the
mill
in
which
the
gaunt
blind
horse
goes
round
all
day
looks
like
an
instrument
of
human
torture
---
traversing
this
deserted
,
blighted
spot
<EOS>
there
is
a
lonely
figure
with
the
sad
world
to
itself
,
pelted
by
the
snow
and
driven
by
the
wind
,
and
cast
out
<EOS>
,
it
would
seem
,
from
all
companionship
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
the
figure
of
a
woman
,
too
;
but
it
is
miserably
dressed
,
and
no
such
clothes
ever
came
through
the
hall
and
out
at
the
great
door
of
the
Dedlock
mansion
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
57
.
<EOS>
Esther
's
Narrative
 
<EOS>
I
had
gone
to
bed
and
fallen
asleep
when
my
guardian
knocked
at
the
door
of
my
room
and
begged
me
to
get
up
directly
.
 
<EOS>
On
my
hurrying
to
speak
to
him
and
learn
what
had
happened
,
he
told
me
,
after
a
word
or
two
of
preparation
,
that
there
had
been
a
discovery
at
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
's
.
 
<EOS>
That
my
mother
had
fled
,
that
a
person
was
now
at
our
door
who
was
empowered
to
convey
to
her
the
fullest
assurances
of
affectionate
protection
and
forgiveness
if
he
could
possibly
find
her
,
and
that
I
was
sought
for
to
accompany
him
in
the
hope
that
my
entreaties
might
prevail
upon
her
if
his
failed
.
<EOS>
Something
to
this
general
purpose
I
made
out
,
but
I
was
thrown
into
such
a
tumult
of
alarm
,
and
hurry
and
distress
,
that
in
spite
of
every
effort
I
could
make
to
subdue
my
agitation
,
I
did
not
seem
,
to
myself
,
fully
to
recover
my
right
mind
until
hours
had
passed
.
   
<EOS>
But
I
dressed
and
wrapped
up
expeditiously
without
waking
Charley
or
any
one
and
went
down
to
Mr
Bucket
,
who
was
the
person
entrusted
with
the
secret
.
 
<EOS>
In
taking
me
to
him
my
guardian
told
me
this
,
and
also
explained
how
it
was
that
he
had
come
to
think
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
,
in
a
low
voice
,
by
the
light
of
my
guardian
's
candle
,
read
to
me
in
the
hall
a
letter
that
my
mother
had
left
upon
her
table
;
and
I
suppose
within
ten
minutes
of
my
having
been
aroused
I
was
sitting
beside
him
,
rolling
swiftly
through
the
streets
.
   
<EOS>
His
manner
was
very
keen
,
and
yet
considerate
when
he
explained
to
me
that
a
great
deal
might
depend
on
my
being
able
to
answer
,
without
confusion
,
a
few
questions
that
he
wished
to
ask
me
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
,
chiefly
,
whether
I
had
had
much
communication
with
my
mother
(
to
whom
he
only
referred
as
Lady
Dedlock
)
,
when
and
where
I
had
spoken
with
her
last
,
and
how
she
had
become
possessed
of
my
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
had
satisfied
him
on
these
points
,
he
asked
me
particularly
to
consider
---
taking
time
to
think
---
whether
within
my
knowledge
there
was
any
one
,
no
matter
where
,
in
whom
she
might
be
at
all
likely
to
confide
under
circumstances
of
the
last
necessity
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
think
of
no
one
but
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
But
by
and
by
I
mentioned
Mr
Boythorn
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
into
my
mind
as
connected
with
his
old
chivalrous
manner
of
mentioning
my
mother
's
name
and
with
what
my
guardian
had
informed
me
of
his
engagement
to
her
sister
and
his
unconscious
connexion
with
her
unhappy
story
.
   
<EOS>
My
companion
had
stopped
the
driver
while
we
held
this
conversation
,
that
we
might
the
better
hear
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
He
now
told
him
to
go
on
again
and
said
to
me
,
after
considering
within
himself
for
a
few
moments
,
that
he
had
made
up
his
mind
how
to
proceed
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
quite
willing
to
tell
me
what
his
plan
was
,
but
I
did
not
feel
clear
enough
to
understand
it
.
   
<EOS>
We
had
not
driven
very
far
from
our
lodgings
when
we
stopped
in
a
by
-
street
at
a
public
-
looking
place
lighted
up
with
gas
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
took
me
in
and
sat
me
in
an
armchair
by
a
bright
fire
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
now
past
one
,
as
I
saw
by
the
clock
against
the
wall
.
 
<EOS>
Two
police
officers
,
looking
in
their
perfectly
neat
uniform
not
at
all
like
people
who
were
up
all
night
,
were
quietly
writing
at
a
desk
;
and
the
place
seemed
very
quiet
altogether
,
except
for
some
beating
and
calling
out
at
distant
doors
underground
,
to
which
nobody
paid
any
attention
.
   
<EOS>
A
third
man
in
uniform
,
whom
Mr
Bucket
called
and
to
whom
he
whispered
his
instructions
,
went
out
;
and
then
the
two
others
advised
together
while
one
wrote
from
Mr
Bucket
's
subdued
dictation
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
description
of
my
mother
that
they
were
busy
with
,
for
Mr
Bucket
brought
it
to
me
when
it
was
done
and
read
it
in
a
whisper
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
accurate
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
The
second
officer
,
who
had
attended
to
it
closely
,
then
copied
it
out
and
called
in
another
man
in
uniform
(
there
were
several
in
an
outer
room
)
,
who
took
it
up
and
went
away
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
was
done
with
the
greatest
dispatch
and
without
the
waste
of
a
moment
;
yet
nobody
was
at
all
hurried
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
paper
was
sent
out
upon
its
travels
,
the
two
officers
resumed
their
former
quiet
work
of
writing
with
neatness
and
care
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
thoughtfully
came
and
warmed
the
soles
of
his
boots
,
first
one
and
then
the
other
,
at
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
well
wrapped
up
,
Miss
Summerson
?
<EOS>
"
he
asked
me
as
his
eyes
met
mine
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
desperate
sharp
night
for
a
young
lady
to
be
out
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
told
him
I
cared
for
no
weather
and
was
warmly
clothed
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
a
long
job
,
"
he
observed
;
"
but
so
that
it
ends
well
<EOS>
,
never
mind
,
miss
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
pray
to
heaven
it
may
end
well
!
"
said
I.
   
He
nodded
comfortingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
whatever
you
do
,
do
n't
you
go
and
fret
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
You
keep
yourself
cool
and
equal
for
anything
that
may
happen
,
and
it
'll
be
the
better
for
you
,
the
better
for
me
,
the
better
for
Lady
Dedlock
,
and
the
better
for
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
,
Baronet
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
really
very
kind
and
gentle
,
and
as
he
stood
before
the
fire
warming
his
boots
and
rubbing
his
face
with
his
forefinger
,
I
felt
a
confidence
in
his
sagacity
which
reassured
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
yet
a
quarter
to
two
when
I
heard
horses
'
feet
and
wheels
outside
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Miss
Summerson
,
"
said
he
,
"
we
are
off
,
if
you
please
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
gave
me
his
arm
,
and
the
two
officers
courteously
bowed
me
out
,
and
we
found
at
the
door
a
phaeton
or
barouche
with
a
postilion
and
post
horses
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
handed
me
in
and
took
his
own
seat
on
the
box
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
in
uniform
whom
he
had
sent
to
fetch
this
equipage
then
handed
him
up
a
dark
lantern
at
his
request
,
and
when
he
had
given
a
few
directions
to
the
driver
,
we
rattled
away
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
far
from
sure
that
I
was
not
in
a
dream
.
 
<EOS>
We
rattled
with
great
rapidity
through
such
a
labyrinth
of
streets
that
I
soon
lost
all
idea
where
we
were
,
except
that
we
had
crossed
and
re
-
crossed
the
river
,
and
still
seemed
to
be
traversing
a
low
-
lying
,
waterside
,
dense
neighbourhood
of
narrow
thoroughfares
chequered
by
docks
and
basins
,
high
piles
of
warehouses
,
swing
-
bridges
,
and
masts
of
ships
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
we
stopped
at
the
corner
of
a
little
slimy
turning
,
which
the
wind
from
the
river
,
rushing
up
it
,
did
not
purify
;
and
I
saw
my
companion
,
by
the
light
of
his
lantern
,
in
conference
with
several
men
who
looked
like
a
mixture
of
police
and
sailors
.
 
<EOS>
Against
the
mouldering
wall
by
which
they
stood
,
there
was
a
bill
,
on
which
I
could
discern
the
words
,
"
Found
Drowned
"
;
and
this
and
an
inscription
about
drags
possessed
me
with
the
awful
suspicion
shadowed
forth
in
our
visit
to
that
place
.
   
<EOS>
I
had
no
need
to
remind
myself
that
I
was
not
there
by
the
indulgence
of
any
feeling
of
mine
to
increase
the
difficulties
of
the
search
,
or
to
lessen
its
hopes
,
or
enhance
its
delays
.
 
<EOS>
I
remained
quiet
,
but
what
I
suffered
in
that
dreadful
spot
I
never
can
forget
.
 
<EOS>
And
still
it
was
like
the
horror
of
a
dream
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
yet
dark
and
muddy
,
in
long
swollen
sodden
boots
and
a
hat
like
them
,
was
called
out
of
a
boat
and
whispered
with
Mr
Bucket
,
who
went
away
with
him
down
some
slippery
steps
---
as
if
to
look
at
something
secret
that
he
had
to
show
.
 
<EOS>
They
came
back
,
wiping
their
hands
upon
their
coats
,
after
turning
over
something
wet
;
but
thank
God
it
was
not
what
I
feared
!
   
<EOS>
After
some
further
conference
,
Mr
Bucket
(
whom
everybody
seemed
to
know
and
defer
to
)
went
in
with
the
others
at
a
door
and
left
me
in
the
carriage
,
while
the
driver
walked
up
and
down
by
his
horses
to
warm
himself
.
 
<EOS>
The
tide
was
coming
in
,
as
I
judged
from
the
sound
it
made
,
and
I
could
hear
it
break
at
the
end
of
the
alley
with
a
little
rush
towards
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
never
did
so
---
<EOS>
and
I
thought
it
did
so
,
<EOS>
hundreds
of
times
,
in
what
can
have
been
at
the
most
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
and
probably
was
less
---
but
the
thought
shuddered
through
me
that
it
would
cast
my
mother
at
the
horses
'
feet
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket
came
out
again
,
exhorting
the
others
to
be
vigilant
,
darkened
his
lantern
,
and
once
more
took
his
seat
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
be
alarmed
,
Miss
Summerson
,
on
account
of
our
coming
down
here
,
"
he
said
,
turning
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
only
want
to
have
everything
in
train
and
to
know
that
it
is
in
train
by
looking
after
it
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Get
on
,
my
lad
!
"
   
<EOS>
We
appeared
to
retrace
the
way
we
had
come
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
I
had
taken
note
of
any
particular
objects
in
my
perturbed
state
of
mind
,
but
judging
from
the
general
character
of
the
streets
.
 
<EOS>
We
called
at
another
office
or
station
for
a
minute
and
crossed
the
river
again
.
<EOS>
During
the
whole
of
this
time
,
and
during
the
whole
search
,
my
companion
,
wrapped
up
on
the
box
,
never
relaxed
in
his
vigilance
a
single
moment
;
but
when
we
crossed
the
bridge
he
seemed
,
if
possible
,
to
be
more
on
the
alert
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
He
stood
up
to
look
over
the
parapet
,
he
alighted
and
went
back
after
a
shadowy
female
figure
that
flitted
past
us
,
and
he
gazed
into
the
profound
black
pit
of
water
with
a
face
that
made
my
heart
die
within
me
.
 
<EOS>
The
river
had
a
fearful
look
,
so
overcast
and
secret
,
creeping
away
so
fast
between
the
low
flat
lines
of
shore
---
so
heavy
with
indistinct
and
awful
shapes
,
both
of
substance
and
shadow
;
so
death
-
like
and
mysterious
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
it
many
times
since
then
,
by
sunlight
and
by
moonlight
,
but
never
free
from
the
impressions
of
that
journey
.
<EOS>
In
my
memory
the
lights
upon
the
bridge
are
always
burning
dim
,
the
cutting
wind
is
eddying
round
the
homeless
woman
whom
we
pass
,
the
monotonous
wheels
are
whirling
on
,
and
the
light
of
the
carriage
-
lamps
reflected
back
looks
palely
in
upon
me
---
a
face
rising
out
of
the
dreaded
water
.
   
<EOS>
Clattering
and
clattering
through
the
empty
streets
<EOS>
,
we
came
at
length
from
the
pavement
on
to
dark
smooth
roads
and
began
to
leave
the
houses
behind
us
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
while
I
recognized
the
familiar
way
to
Saint
Albans
.
 
<EOS>
At
Barnet
fresh
horses
were
ready
for
us
,
and
we
changed
and
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
cold
indeed
,
and
the
open
country
was
white
with
snow
,
though
none
was
falling
then
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
An
old

of
yours
,
this
road
,
Miss
Summerson
,
"
said
Mr
Bucket

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
I
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
gathered
any
intelligence
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
None
that
can
be
quite
depended
on
as
yet
,
"
he

,
"
but
it
's
early
times
as
yet
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
gone
into
every

where

light
<EOS>
(
they

not

the

)

<EOS>
I

,

"
   
<EOS>
With

<EOS>
and

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
Do

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"
Passed

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Traced

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Take

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
As

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

"

.
   
<EOS>
Yes

<EOS>
"
That

"

.
   
<EOS>
Seeing

,
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
I

,
I

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Puts

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Well

He

<EOS>

<EOS>
Of

.

<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
Bounds
,

?
"

<EOS>
"
Bounds
?
 
<EOS>
Now
,

Summerson
,
I

that
your

.
 
<EOS>
Whenever

,
look

,

dead

.
 
<EOS>
Whenever

"
In

I

,
"

Number

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

,

<EOS>
So

.
 
<EOS>
Fast

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
Nor

.
 
<EOS>
With

,
I

,

"
   
<EOS>
I

had

Most

.

that

might
send
a
hasty
note
to
my
guardian
,
and
then
we
hurried
back
to
where
we
had
left
the
carriage
.
 
<EOS>
The
horses
were
brought
out
as
soon
as
we
were
seen
coming
,
and
we
were
on
the
road
again
in
a
few
minutes
.
   
<EOS>
It
had
set
in
snowing
at
daybreak
,
and
it
now
snowed
hard
.
 
<EOS>
The
air
was
so
thick
with
the
darkness
of
the
day
and
the
density
of
the
fall
that
we
could
see
but
a
very
little
way
in
any
direction
.
<EOS>
Although
it
was
extremely
cold
,
the
snow
was
but
partially
frozen
,
and
it
churned
---
with
a
sound
as
if
it
were
a
beach
of
small
shells
 
---
under
the
hoofs
of
the
horses
into
mire
and
water
.
 
<EOS>
They
sometimes
slipped
and
floundered
for
a
mile
together
,
and
we
were
obliged
to
come
to
a
standstill
to
rest
them
.
 
<EOS>
One
horse
fell
three
times
in
this
first
stage
,
and
trembled
so
and
was
so
shaken
that
the
driver
had
to
dismount
from
his
saddle
and
lead
him
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
I
could
eat
nothing
and
could
not
sleep
,
and
I
grew
so
nervous
under
those
delays
and
the
slow
pace
at
which
we
travelled
that
I
had
an
unreasonable
desire
upon
me
to
get
out
and
walk
.
 
<EOS>
Yielding
to
my
companion
's
better
sense
,
however
,
I
remained
where
I
was
.
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
kept
fresh
by
a
certain
enjoyment
of
the
work
in
which
he
was
engaged
,
he
was
up
and
down
at
every
house
we
came
to
,
addressing
people
whom
he
had
never
beheld
before
as
old
acquaintances
,
running
in
to
warm
himself
at
every
fire
he
saw
,
talking
and
drinking
and
shaking
hands
at
every
bar
and
tap
,
friendly
with
every
waggoner
,
wheelwright
,
blacksmith
,
and
toll
-
taker
,
yet
never
seeming
to
lose
time
,
and
always
mounting
to
the
box
again
with
his
watchful
,
steady
face
and
his
business
-
like
"
Get
on
,
my
lad
!
"
   
<EOS>
When
we
were
changing
horses
the
next
time
,
he
came
from
the
stable
-
yard
,
with
the
wet
snow
encrusted
upon
him
and
dropping
off
him
---
plashing
and
crashing
through
it
to
his
wet
knees
as
he
had
been
doing
frequently
since
we
left
Saint
Albans
---
and
spoke
to
me
at
the
carriage
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
up
your
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
certainly
true
that
she
came
on
here
,
Miss
Summerson
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
not
a
doubt
of
the
dress
by
this
time
,
and
the
dress
has
been
seen
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Still
on
foot
?
"
said
I.
   
<EOS>
"
Still
on
foot
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
the
gentleman
you
mentioned
must
be
the
point
she
's
aiming
at
,
<EOS>
and
yet
I
do
n't
like
his
living
down
in
her
own
part
of
the
country
neither
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
so
little
,
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
There
may
be
some
one
else
nearer
here
,
of
whom
I
never
heard
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
true
.
 
<EOS>
But
whatever
you
do
,
do

you
fall
a
-
crying
,
my
dear
;
and
do
n't
you
worry
yourself
no
more
than
you
can
help
.
 
<EOS>
Get
on
,
my
lad
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
sleet
fell
all
that
day
unceasingly
,
a
thick
mist
came
on
early
,
and
it
never
rose
or
lightened
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Such
roads
<EOS>
I
had
never
seen
.
 
<EOS>
I
sometimes
feared
we
had
missed
the
way
and
got
into
the
ploughed
grounds
or
the
marshes
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
ever
thought
of
the
time
I
had
been
out
,
it
presented
itself
as
an
indefinite
period
of
great
duration
,
and
I
seemed
,
in
a
strange
way
,
never
to
have

from
the
anxiety
under
which
I
then
laboured
.
   
<EOS>
As
we
advanced
,
I
began
to
feel
misgivings
that
my
companion
lost
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
same
as
before
with
all
the
roadside
people
,
but
he
looked
graver
when
he
sat
by
himself
on
the
box
.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
his
finger
uneasily
going
across
and
across
his
mouth
during
the
whole
of
one
long
weary
stage
.
 
<EOS>
I
overheard
that
he
began
to
ask
the
drivers
of

and
other

coming
towards
us
what
passengers
they
had
seen
in
other
coaches
and
vehicles
that
were
in

.
 
<EOS>
Their

did
not
encourage
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
always
gave
me
a
reassuring
beck
of
his
finger
and
lift

his

as
he
got
upon
the
box
again
,
but
he
seemed

now
when
he

,
"
Get
on
,
my
lad
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
last
,
when
we

,
he
told

that
he
had
lost
the
track
of
the
dress
so

that
he
began
to

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nothing
,
he
said
,
to
lose
such

track
for
one

,
and
to
take

up
for
another

,
and
so

;
but
it
had
disappeared
here
in
an

,
and
we
had
not

upon

.
 
<EOS>
This
corroborated

I
had
formed
,
when
he
began
to
look
at
direction

,
and

at
cross

for
a
quarter

an
hour
at

while

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
was
not
to
be
down

,
he
told
me
,
for
it
was
as
likely
as
not
that
the
next
stage
might
set
us
right
again
.
   
<EOS>
The
next
stage
,
however
,
ended
as
that
one
ended
;
we
had
no
new
clue
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
spacious
inn
here
,
solitary
,
but
a
comfortable
substantial
building
,
and
as
we
drove
in
under
a
large
gateway
before
I
knew
it
,
where
a
landlady
and
her
pretty
daughters
came
to
the
carriage

,
entreating

to

and
refresh
myself
while
the
horses
were
making
ready
,
I
thought
it
would
be
uncharitable
to
refuse
.
 
<EOS>
They
took
me
upstairs
to
a
warm
room
and
left
me
there
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
at
the
corner
of
the
house
,
I
remember
,
looking
two
ways
.
<EOS>
On
one
side
to
a
stable
-
yard
open
to
a
by
-
road
,
where
the
ostlers
were
unharnessing
the
splashed
and
tired
horses
from
the
muddy
carriage
,
and
beyond
that
to
the
by
-
road
itself
,
across
which
the
sign
was
heavily
swinging
;
on
the
other
side
to
a
wood
of
dark
pine
-
trees
.
 
<EOS>
Their
branches
were
encumbered
with
snow
,
and
it
silently
dropped
off
in
wet
heaps
while
I
stood
at
the
window
.
<EOS>
Night
was
setting
in
,
and
its
bleakness
was
enhanced
by
the
contrast
of
the
pictured
fire
glowing
and
gleaming
in
the
window

pane
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
looked
among
the
stems
of
the
trees
and
followed
the
discoloured
marks
in
the
snow
where
the
thaw
was
sinking
into
it
and
undermining
it
,
I
thought
of
the
motherly
face
brightly
set
off
by
daughters
that
had
just
now
welcomed
me
and
of
MY
mother
lying
down
in
such
a
wood
to
die
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
frightened
when
I
found
them
all
about
me
,
but
I
remembered
that
before
I
fainted
I
tried
very
hard
not
to
do
it
;
and
that
was
some
little
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
They
cushioned
me
up
on
a
large
sofa
by
the
fire
,
and
then
the
comely
landlady
told
me
that
I
must
travel
no
further
to
-
night
,
but
must
go
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
put
me
into
such
a

lest
they
should
detain
me
there
that
she
soon
recalled
her
words
and
compromised
for
a
rest
of
half
an
hour
.
   
<EOS>
A
good
endearing
creature
she
was
.
 
<EOS>
She
and
her
three
fair
girls
,
all
so
busy
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
to
take
hot
soup
and
broiled
fowl
,
while
Mr
Bucket
dried
himself
and
dined
elsewhere
;
but
I
could
not
do
it
when
a
snug
round
table
was
presently
spread
by
the
fireside
,
though
I
was
very
unwilling
to
disappoint

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
could
take
some
toast
and
some
hot
negus
,
and
as
I
really
enjoyed
that
refreshment
,
it
made
some
recompense
.
   
<EOS>
Punctual
to
the
time
,
at
the
half
-

's
end
the
carriage
came
rumbling
under
the

,
and
they

,
warmed
,

,
comforted
by
kindness
,
and
safe
(
I
assured

)
not

.
 
<EOS>
After
I
had
got
in
and
had
taken
a

of

,
the

daughter
---
a

who

,

---
got

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
seen
her
,
from
that
hour
,
but
I
think
of
her
to
this

.
   
<EOS>
The
transparent
windows
with
the
fire
and

,

out

,
were

,
and
again

.
 
<EOS>
We
went
on
with
toil
enough
,
but
the
dismal
roads
were
not
much

than
they
had
been
,
and
the
stage

only
nine

.
 
<EOS>
My
companion
smoking
on
the
box
<EOS>
---
I
had
thought
at
the
last
inn

---
was

as

down

.
 
<EOS>
He
had

,

,

lamps

;
and
every
now
<EOS>
and

to

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

,
for

.
   
<EOS>
We

the

the

,
and
still

.
 
<EOS>
I
looked

to

,
but
I

by

.
 
<EOS>
Almost
in
an

<EOS>

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

deceive

,
my

.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
's
here
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
've
got
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
The

was
in

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
You
know

.
<EOS>
I
'm

Bucket
,
and
you

.
 
<EOS>
We
've
come
a
long

;

.
 
<EOS>
Four

out
there
for
the
next
stage
up
!
 
<EOS>
Quick
!
"
   
<EOS>
There

,
and

came

.
   
<EOS>
"
Up
,

!
 
<EOS>
Up
!
 
<EOS>
Ai

English
?
 
<EOS>
Up
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Up
?
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
To
London
!
 
<EOS>
Are

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Summerson
,
"
he

,
"
back
.
 
<EOS>
Straight

as

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
Do

.
 
<EOS>
I

the
other
,
by
G
---
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

?
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

?
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Bring

.
 
<EOS>
Wake

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

;

on

!
"
<EOS>
said

,
in

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are

,
my
dear
,
I
wo

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'll
follow
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
Look
alive
here
with

.
 
<EOS>
Send

man

in
the

,

another
for'ard

,
and
order
four
on
,
up
,
right

.
 
<EOS>
My
darling
,
do

you

afraid
!
"
   
<EOS>
These

and
the
way
in
which
he
ran

caused
a
general

that
was
scarcely
less

than
the

.
 
<EOS>
But

the

the

,
a

man
galloped
away
to
order
the
relays
,
and
our
horses
were
put
to
with
great

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Bucket
,
jumping
to
his
seat
and
looking
in
again
,
"
---
you
'll

me
if
I
'm
too
familiar
---
do

you
fret
and
worry
yourself
no
more
than
you

<EOS>
Inspector

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

<EOS>
Chapter
58
.
<EOS>
A
Wintry
Day
and
Night
 
Still

,
as
behoves

,
the
Dedlock
town
house
carries

as

towards
the
street
of

.
<EOS>
There

powdered

,

at
the
untaxed
powder

;

.
 
<EOS>
It

that
my

gone
down

,
but

.
   
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,
<EOS>
my

,
all

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
Not

'
is
to

.
 
<EOS>
One

<EOS>

<EOS>
What

?

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Sir

,

<EOS>

,

.

"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
As

the
great

one
,
so
,
empty
rooms
,

a

,

what
your
room

.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
's
state
has
a
hollow

,
thus
gloomy
and

;
and

the
inner

,
where
Mr
Bucket
last
night
made
his
secret

,
the

of
her

and
her

,

accustomed

reflect

when

,
have

.
 
<EOS>
Dark
and

as
the
wintry
day
is
,
it
is
darker
and
colder
in
these
deserted
chambers
than
in
many
a
hut
that
will
barely
exclude
the
weather
;
and
though
the
servants
heap

in
the

and
set
the
couches
and
the

within
the
warm

that
let
their

shoot
through
to
the
furthest
corners
,
there
is
a
heavy
cloud
upon
the
rooms
which
no

will

.
   
<EOS>
The
old
housekeeper
and
her
son
remain
until
the

are
complete
,
and
then
she
returns

.
 
<EOS>
Volumnia
has
taken
Mrs
Rouncewell
's
place
in
the
meantime
,
though
pearl
necklaces
and
rouge
pots
,
however
calculated
to
embellish

,
are
but
indifferent

to
the
invalid
under
present

.
<EOS>
Volumnia
,
not
being
supposed
to
know
(
and
indeed
not
knowing
)
<EOS>
what
is
the
matter
,
has
found
it
a
ticklish
task
to
offer
appropriate
observations
and
consequently
has
supplied
their
place
with
distracting
smoothings
of
the
bed
-
linen
,
elaborate
locomotion
on
tiptoe
,
vigilant
peeping
at
her
kinsman
's
eyes
,
and
one
exasperating
whisper
to
herself
of
,
<EOS>
"
He
is
asleep
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
disproof
of
which
superfluous
remark
Sir
Leicester
has
indignantly
written
on
the
slate
,
"
I
am
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
Yielding
,
therefore
,
the
chair
at
the
bedside
to
the
quaint
old
housekeeper
,
Volumnia
sits
at
a
table
a
little
removed
,
sympathetically
sighing
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
watches
the
sleet
and
snow
and
listens
for
the
returning
steps
that
he
expects
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
ears
of
his
old
servant
,
looking
as
if
she
had
stepped
out
of
an
old
picture
-
frame
to
attend
a
summoned
Dedlock
to
another
world
,
the
silence
is
fraught
with
echoes
of
her
own
words
,
"
who
will
tell
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
has
been
under
his
valet
's
hands
this
morning
to
be
made
presentable
and
is
as
well
got
up
as
the
circumstances
will
allow
.
<EOS>
He
is
propped
with
pillows
,
his
grey
hair
is
brushed
in
its
usual

,
his
linen
is
arranged
to
a

,
and
he
is
wrapped
in
a
responsible

-
gown
.
 
<EOS>
His
eye
-
glass
and
his
watch
are
ready
to
his

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
necessary
---
less
to
his
own
dignity
now
perhaps
than
for
her

---
that
he
should
be
seen
as
little

and
as
much
himself
as
may

.
 
<EOS>
Women
will
talk
,
and
Volumnia
,
though
a
Dedlock
,
is
no
exceptional
case
.
 
<EOS>
He
keeps
her
here
,
there
is
little
doubt
,
to
prevent
her
talking
somewhere
else
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
very
ill
,
but
he
makes
his
present
stand
against
distress
of
mind
and
body
most
courageously
.
   
<EOS>
The
fair
Volumnia
,
being
one
of
those
sprightly
girls
who
can
not
long
continue
silent
without
imminent
peril
of
seizure
by
the
dragon
Boredom
,
soon
indicates
the
approach
of
that

with

.
 
<EOS>
Finding
it
impossible
to

those

by
any

,
she

Mrs
Rouncewell
on
her
son
,
declaring
that
he
positively
is
one

the

she

and
as

,

,

,
her

Life
Guardsman
 
---
the

,
the
dearest
of

---
who
was

at

.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Leicester
hears

with

and

<EOS>
"
Miss

,

,

my

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
found

.
 
<EOS>
He
has
come

.
"
   
<EOS>
Sir

.
 
<EOS>
"
George
?
 
<EOS>
Your
son
George
come

,
Mrs
Rouncewell
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
old

wipes
her

.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
God
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
Sir
Leicester
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

some

,

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why

<EOS>
"

,

,

.

<EOS>
Besides
,

.
 
<EOS>

,
that

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

in

.

"

?
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
Sir

,

<EOS>
When

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

she

.
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
The

"

of
a

<EOS>
---
I

---

.

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

;

"
   
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
George

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
did

?
"
 
<EOS>
It

.
   
<EOS>
"
Truly

,

<EOS>
---

,

.
 
<EOS>

,
"

"

<EOS>
George

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
In

.
 
<EOS>
Something

,
"
making

"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

(
the

much

)

arise

.
   
<EOS>
Sir

,

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He

's

,

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

?
 
<EOS>
The

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
Nothing

<EOS>
"
Therefore
,

,

---

,

,

,

---
"
   
The
old

weeping

;
<EOS>
Volumnia
in

,
with
the

;
the

<EOS>
"
Therefore

,

---
 
beginning
,

,

---

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
That
I
have

,

.
 
<EOS>
Say

,

.
 
<EOS>
If
you

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Volumnia
tremblingly
protests
that
she
will
observe
his
injunctions
to

letter
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
Lady
is
too

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

---

,

---
<EOS>
no

I

for
her

.
"
   
<EOS>
His
formal
array
of
words
might
have
at
any

,

has

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
His

,

,
