shielding
of
her
,
his
generous
conquest
of
his
own
wrong
and
his
own
pride
for
her
sake
,
are
simply
honourable
,
manly
,
and
true
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
less
worthy
can
be
seen
through
the
lustre
of
such
qualities
in
the
commonest
mechanic
,
nothing
less
worthy
can
be
seen
in
the
best
-
born
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
In
such
a
light
both
aspire
alike
,
both
rise
alike
,
both
children
of
the
dust
shine
equally
.
   
<EOS>
Overpowered
by
his
exertions
,
he
lays
his
head
back
on
his
pillows
and
closes
his
eyes
for
not
more
than
a
minute
,
when
he
again
resumes
his
watching
of
the
weather
and
his
attention
to
the
muffled
sounds
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
rendering
of
those
little
services
,
and
in
the
manner
of
their
acceptance
,
the
trooper
has
become
installed
as
necessary
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
has
been
said
,
but
it
is
quite
understood
.
 
<EOS>
He
falls
a
step
or
two
backward
to
be
out
of
sight
and
mounts
guard
a
little
behind
his
mother
's
chair
.
   
<EOS>
The
day
is
now
beginning
to
decline
.
 
<EOS>
The
mist
and
the
sleet
into
which
the
snow
has
all
resolved
itself
are
darker
,
and
the
blaze
begins
to
tell
more
vividly
upon
the
room
walls
and
furniture
.
 
<EOS>
The
gloom
augments
;
the
bright
gas
springs
up
in
the
streets
;
and
the
pertinacious
oil
lamps
which
yet
hold
their
ground
there
,
with
their
source
of
life
half
frozen
and
half
thawed
,
twinkle
gaspingly
like
fiery
fish
out
of
water
---
as
they
are
.
 
<EOS>
The
world
,
which
has
been
rumbling
over
the
straw
and
pulling
at
the
bell
,
"
to
inquire
,
"
begins
to
go
home
,
begins
to
dress
,
to
dine
,
to
discuss
its
dear
friend
with
all
the
last
new
modes
,
as
already
mentioned
.
   
<EOS>
Now
does
Sir
Leicester
become
worse
,
restless
,
uneasy
,
and
in
great
pain
.
 
<EOS>
Volumnia
,
lighting
a
candle
(
with
a
predestined
aptitude
for
doing
something
objectionable
)
,
is
bidden
to
put
it
out
again
,
for
it
is
not
yet
dark
enough
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
it
is
very
dark
too
,
as
dark
as
it
will
be
all
night
.
 
<EOS>
By
and
by
<EOS>
she
tries
again
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
Put
it
out
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
dark
enough
yet
.
   
<EOS>
His
old
housekeeper
is
the
first
to
understand
that
he
is
striving
to
uphold
the
fiction
with
himself
that
it
is
not
growing
late
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dear
Sir
Leicester
,
my
honoured
master
,
"
she
softly
whispers
,
"
<EOS>
I
must
,
for
your
own
good
,
and
my
duty
,
take
the
freedom
of
begging
and
praying
that
you
will
not
lie
here
in
the
lone
darkness
watching
and
waiting
and
dragging
through
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
draw
the
curtains
,
and
light
the
candles
,
and
make
things
more
comfortable
about
you
.
 
<EOS>
The
church
-
clocks
will
strike
the
hours
just
the
same
,
Sir
Leicester
,
and
the
night
will
pass
away
just
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
My
Lady
will
come
back
,
just
the
same
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
but
I
am
weak
---
and
he
has
been
so
long
gone
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
so
very
long
,
Sir
Leicester
.
 
<EOS>
Not
twenty
-
four
hours
yet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
that
is
a
long
time
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
it
is
a
long
time
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
says
it
with
a
groan
that
wrings
her
heart
.
   
<EOS>
She
knows
that
this
is
not
a
period
for
bringing
the
rough
light
upon
him
;
she
thinks
his
tears
too
sacred
to
be
seen
,
even
by
her
.
<EOS>
Therefore
she
sits
in
the
darkness
for
a
while
without
a
word
,
then
gently
begins
to
move
about
,
now
stirring
the
fire
,
now
standing
at
the
dark
window
looking
out
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
he
tells
her
,
with
recovered
self
-
command
,
"
As
you
say
,
Mrs
Rouncewell
,
it
is
no
worse
for
being
confessed
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
getting
late
,
and
they
are
not
come
.
 
<EOS>
Light
the
room
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
When
it
is
lighted
and
the
weather
shut
out
,
it
is
only
left
to
him
to
listen
.
   
<EOS>
But
they
find
that
however
dejected
and
ill
<EOS>
he
is
,
he
brightens
when
a
quiet
pretence
is
made
of
looking
at
the
fires
in
her
rooms
and
being
sure
that
everything
is
ready
to
receive
her
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
pretence
as
it
is
,
these
allusions
to
her
being
expected
keep
up
hope
within
him
.
   
<EOS>
Midnight
comes
,
and
with
it
the
same
blank
.
 
<EOS>
The
carriages
in
the
streets
are
few
,
and
other
late
sounds
in
that
neighbourhood
there
are
none
,
unless
a
man
so
very
nomadically
drunk
as
to
stray
into
the
frigid
zone
goes
brawling
and
bellowing
along
the
pavement
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
wintry
night
it
is
so
still
that
listening
to
the
intense
silence
is
like
looking
at
intense
darkness
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
distant
sound
be
audible
in
this
case
,
it
departs
through
the
gloom
like
a
feeble
light
in
that
,
and
all
is
heavier
than
before
.
   
<EOS>
The
corporation
of
servants
are
dismissed
to
bed
(
not
unwilling
to
go
,
for
they
were
up
all
last
night
)
,
and
only
Mrs
Rouncewell
and
George
keep
watch
in
Sir
Leicester
's
room
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
night
lags
tardily
on
---
or
rather
when
it
seems
to
stop
altogether
,
at
between
two
and
three
o'clock
---
they
find
a
restless
craving
on
him
to
know
more
about
the
weather
,
now
he
can
not
see
it
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
George
,
patrolling
regularly
every
half
-
hour
to
the
rooms
so
carefully
looked
after
,
extends
his
march
to
the
hall
-
door
,
looks
about
him
,
and
brings
back
the
best
report
he
can
make
of
the
worst
of
nights
,
the
sleet
still
falling
and
even
the
stone
footways
lying
ankle
-
deep
in
icy
sludge
.
   
<EOS>
Volumnia
,
in
her
room
up
a
retired
landing
on
the
stair
-
case
---
the
second
turning
past
the
end
of
the
carving
and
gilding
,
a
cousinly
room
containing
a
fearful
abortion
of
a
portrait
of
Sir
Leicester
banished
for
its
crimes
,
and
commanding
in
the
day
a
solemn
yard
planted
with
dried
-
up
shrubs
like
antediluvian
specimens
of
black
tea
---
is
a
prey
to
horrors
of
many
kinds
.
 
<EOS>
Not
last
nor
least
among
them
,
possibly
,
is
a
horror
of
what
may
befall
her
little
income
in
the
event
,
as
she
expresses
it
,
"
of
anything
happening
"
to
Sir
Leicester
.
 
<EOS>
Anything
,
in
this
sense
,
meaning
one
thing
only
;
and
that
the
last
thing
that
can
happen
to
the
consciousness
of
any
baronet
in
the
known
world
.
   
<EOS>
An
effect
of
these
horrors
is
that
Volumnia
finds
she
can
not
go
to
bed
in
her
own
room
or
sit
by
the
fire
in
her
own
room
,
but
must
come
forth
with
her
fair
head
tied
up
in
a
profusion
of
shawl
,
and
her
fair
form
enrobed
in
drapery
,
and
parade
the
mansion
like
a
ghost
,
particularly
haunting
the
rooms
,
warm
and
luxurious
,
prepared
for
one
who
still
does
not
return
.
 
<EOS>
Solitude
under
such
circumstances
being
not
to
be
thought
of
<EOS>
,
Volumnia
is
attended
by
her
maid
,
who
,
impressed
from
her
own
bed
for
that
purpose
,
extremely
cold
,
very
sleepy
,
and
generally
an
injured
maid
as
condemned
by
circumstances
to
take
office
with
a
cousin
,
when
she
had
resolved
to
be
maid
to
nothing
less
than
ten
thousand
a
year
,
has
not
a
sweet
expression
of
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
The
periodical
visits
of
the
trooper
to
these
rooms
,
however
,
in
the
course
of
his
patrolling
is
an
assurance
of
protection
and
company
both
to
mistress
and
maid
,
which
renders
them
very
acceptable
in
the
small
hours
of
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
he
is
heard
advancing
,
they
both
make
some
little
decorative
preparation
to
receive
him
;
at
other
times
they
divide
their
watches
into
short
scraps
of
oblivion
and
dialogues
not
wholly
free
from
acerbity
,
as
to
whether
Miss
Dedlock
,
sitting
with
her
feet
upon
the
fender
,
was
or
was
not
falling
into
the
fire
when
rescued
(
to
her
great
displeasure
)
by
her
guardian
genius
the
maid
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
is
Sir
Leicester
now
,
Mr
George
?
"
<EOS>
inquires
Volumnia
,
adjusting
her
cowl
over
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Sir
Leicester
is
much
the
same
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
very
low
and
ill
,
and
he
even
wanders
a
little
sometimes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
he
asked
for
me
?
"
<EOS>
inquires
Volumnia
tenderly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
,
I
ca
n't
say
he
has
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
Not
within
my
hearing
,
that
is
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
truly
sad
time
,
Mr
George
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
indeed
,
miss
.
 
<EOS>
Had
n't
you
better
go
to
bed
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
a
deal
better
go
to
bed
,
Miss
Dedlock
,
"
quoth
the
maid
sharply
.
   
<EOS>
But
Volumnia
answers
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
She
may
be
asked
for
<EOS>
,
she
may
be
wanted
at
a
moment
's
notice
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
should
forgive
herself
"
if
anything
was
to
happen
"
and
she
was
not
on
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
She
declines
to
enter
on
the
question
,
mooted
by
the
maid
,
how
the
spot
comes
to
be
there
,
and
not
in
her
room
(
which
is
nearer
to
Sir
Leicester
's
)
,
but
staunchly
declares
that
on
the
spot
she
will
remain
.
 
<EOS>
Volumnia
further
makes
a
merit
of
not
having
"
closed
an
eye
"
---
as
if
she
had
twenty
or
thirty
---
though
it
is
hard
to
reconcile
this
statement
with
her
having
most
indisputably
opened
two
within
five
minutes
.
   
<EOS>
But
when
it
comes
to
four
o'clock
,
and
still
the
same
blank
,
Volumnia
's
constancy
begins
to
fail
her
,
or
rather
it
begins
to
strengthen
,
for
she
now
considers
that
it
is
her
duty
to
be
ready
for
the
morrow
,
when
much
may
be
expected
of
her
,
that
,
in
fact
,
howsoever
anxious
to
remain
upon
the
spot
,
it
may
be
required
of
her
,
as
an
act
of
self
-
devotion
,
to
desert
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
So
when
the
trooper
reappears
with
his
,
"
Had
n't
you
better
go
to
bed
,
miss
?
"
<EOS>
and
when
the
maid
protests
,
more
sharply
than
before
,
"
You
had
a
deal
better
go
to
bed
,
Miss
Dedlock
!
"
<EOS>
she
meekly
rises
and
says
,
"
Do
with
me
what
you
think
best
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
undoubtedly
thinks
it
best
to
escort
her
on
his
arm
to
the
door
of
her
cousinly
chamber
,
and
the
maid
as
undoubtedly
thinks
it
best
to
hustle
her
into
bed
with
mighty
little
ceremony
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
these
steps
are
taken
;
and
now
the
trooper
,
in
his
rounds
,
has
the
house
to
himself
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
no
improvement
in
the
weather
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
portico
,
from
the
eaves
,
from
the
parapet
,
from
every
ledge
and
post
and
pillar
,
drips
the
thawed
snow
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
crept
,
as
if
for
shelter
,
into
the
lintels
of
the
great
door
---
under
it
,
into
the
corners
of
the
windows
,
into
every
chink
and
crevice
of
retreat
,
and
there
wastes
and
dies
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
falling
still
;
upon
the
roof
,
upon
the
skylight
,
even
through
the
skylight
,
and
drip
,
drip
,
drip
,
with
the
regularity
of
the
Ghost
's
Walk
,
on
the
stone
floor
below
.
   
<EOS>
The
trooper
,
his
old
recollections
awakened
by
the
solitary
grandeur
of
a
great
house
---
no
novelty
to
him
once
at
Chesney
Wold
---
 
goes
up
the
stairs
and
through
the
chief
rooms
,
holding
up
his
light
at
arm
's
length
.
 
<EOS>
Thinking
of
his
varied
fortunes
within
the
last
few
weeks
,
and
of
his
rustic
boyhood
,
and
of
the
two
periods
of
his
life
so
strangely
brought
together
across
the
wide
intermediate
space
;
thinking
of
the
murdered
man
whose
image
is
fresh
in
his
mind
;
thinking
of
the
lady
who
has
disappeared
from
these
very
rooms
and
the
tokens
of
whose
recent
presence
are
all
here
;
thinking
of
the
master
of
the
house
upstairs
and
of
the
foreboding
,
"
Who
will
tell
him
!
"
<EOS>
he
looks
here
and
looks
there
,
and
reflects
how
he
MIGHT
see
something
now
,
which
it
would
tax
his
boldness
to
walk
up
to
,
lay
his
hand
upon
,
and
prove
to
be
a
fancy
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
all
blank
,
blank
as
the
darkness
above
and
below
,
while
he
goes
up
the
great
staircase
again
,
blank
as
the
oppressive
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
is
still
in
readiness
,
George
Rouncewell
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
orderly
and
right
,
Sir
Leicester
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
word
of
any
kind
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
trooper
shakes
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
letter
that
can
possibly
have
been
overlooked
?
"
   
<EOS>
But
he
knows
there
is
no
such
hope
as
that
and
lays
his
head
down
without
looking
for
an
answer
.
   
<EOS>
Very
familiar
to
him
,
as
he
said
himself
some
hours
ago
,
George
Rouncewell
lifts
him
into
easier
positions
through
the
long
remainder
of
the
blank
wintry
night
,
and
equally
familiar
with
his
unexpressed
wish
,
extinguishes
the
light
and
undraws
the
curtains
at
the
first
late
break
of
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
comes
like
a
phantom
.
<EOS>
Cold
,
colourless
,
and
vague
,
it
sends
a
warning
streak
before
it
of
a
deathlike
hue
,
as
if
it
cried
out
,
"
<EOS>
Look
what
I
am
bringing
you
who
watch
there
!
 
<EOS>
Who
will
tell
him
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
59
.
<EOS>
Esther
's
Narrative
 
<EOS>
It
was
three
o'clock
in
the
morning
when
the
houses
outside
London
did
at
last
begin
to
exclude
the
country
and
to
close
us
in
with
streets
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
made
our
way
along
roads
in
a
far
worse
condition
than
when
we
had
traversed
them
by
daylight
,
both
the
fall
and
the
thaw
having
lasted
ever
since
;
but
the
energy
of
my
companion
never
slackened
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
only
been
,
as
I
thought
,
of
less
assistance
than
the
horses
in
getting
us
on
,
and
it
had
often
aided
them
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
stopped
exhausted
halfway
up
hills
,
they
had
been
driven
through
streams
of
turbulent
water
,
they
had
slipped
down
and
become
entangled
with
the
harness
;
but
he
and
his
little
lantern
had
been
always
ready
,
and
when
the
mishap
was
set
right
,
I
had
never
heard
any
variation
in
his
cool
,
"
Get
on
,
my
lads
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
steadiness
and
confidence
with
which
he
had
directed
our
journey
back
<EOS>
I
could
not
account
for
.
 
<EOS>
Never
wavering
,
he
never
even
stopped
to
make
an
inquiry
until
we
were
within
a
few
miles
of
London
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
few
words
,
here
and
there
,
were
then
enough
for
him
;
and
thus
we
came
,
at
between
three
and
four
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
into
Islington
.
   
<EOS>
I
will
not
dwell
on
the
suspense
and
anxiety
with
which
I
reflected
all
this
time
that
we
were
leaving
my
mother
farther
and
farther
behind
every
minute
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
had
some
strong
hope
that
he
must
be
right
and
could
not
fail
to
have
a
satisfactory
object
in
following
this
woman
,
but
I
tormented
myself
with
questioning
it
and
discussing
it
during
the
whole
journey
.
 
<EOS>
What
was
to
ensue
when
we
found
her
and
what
could
compensate
us
for
this
loss
of
time
were
questions
also
that
I
could
not
possibly
dismiss
;
my
mind
was
quite
tortured
by
long
dwelling
on
such
reflections
when
we
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
We
stopped
in
a
high
-
street
where
there
was
a
coach
-
stand
.
 
<EOS>
My
companion
paid
our
two
drivers
,
who
were
as
completely
covered
with
splashes
as
if
they
had
been
dragged
along
the
roads
like
the
carriage
itself
,
and
giving
them
some
brief
direction
where
to
take
it
,
lifted
me
out
of
it
and
into
a
hackney
-
coach
he
had
chosen
from
the
rest
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
as
he
did
this
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
wet
you
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
not
been
conscious
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
melted
snow
had
found
its
way
into
the
carriage
,
and
I
had
got
out
two
or
three
times
when
a
fallen
horse
was
plunging
and
had
to
be
got

,
and
the
wet
had
penetrated
my
dress
.
 
<EOS>
I
assured
him
<EOS>
it
was
no
matter
,
but
the
driver
,
who
knew
him
,
would
not
be

by
me
from
running
down
the
street
to
his

,
whence
he
brought
an

clean

.
 
<EOS>
They
shook
it
out
and
strewed
it
well
about
me
,
and
I
found
it
warm
and
comfortable
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Bucket
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
're
a
-

mark
this

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
but
you
do

.
 
<EOS>
You
're
pretty

that
I
've

.
 
<EOS>
Ai

you
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
little

,
little

short

I
should

,
but
I

that
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
you
may

,

,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
tell

!
 
<EOS>
If

after

I
've
experienced
of

,

.
 
<EOS>
Lord
!
 
<EOS>
You
're
no

.
 
<EOS>
I
never

---
and

've

<EOS>
---
conduct

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
You
're
a
pattern
,
you
know
,
that
's

you

,
"
said
Mr
Bucket

;
"
you
're
a
pattern
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
told
him
I
was
very

,
as

,

,

that

.
   
<EOS>
"
My

,
"
he

,
"
when
a

as

she
's
game
,
and
as
game

's

,

's

I

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

a

,
and
that
's
about
what
you
are
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these

words
---
they
really
were

to
me
under

lonely

---
he
got
upon

box
,
and
we
once

.
 
<EOS>
Where
we
drove
I
neither
knew
then
nor
have
ever
known
since
,
but
we
appeared
to
seek
out
the
narrowest
and
worst
streets
in

.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
I
saw
him
directing
the
driver
,
I
was
prepared
for
our
descending
into
a
deeper

of
such

,
and
we
never
failed
to
do
so
.
   
<EOS>
Sometimes
we
emerged
upon
a
wider

or
came
to
a

than
the
generality
,
well

.
 
<EOS>
Then
we
stopped
at
offices
like
those
we
had
visited
when
we
began
our
journey
,
and
I
saw
him
in

with
others
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
would
get
down
by

or

light
of
his
little

.
 
<EOS>
This
would
attract
similar
lights
from
various

quarters
,
like
so
many
insects
,
and
a
fresh

would
be
held
.
 
<EOS>
By
degrees
we
appeared
to
contract
our
search
within
narrower
and
easier
limits
.
 
<EOS>
Single
police
-
officers
on
duty
could
now
tell
Mr
Bucket
what
he
wanted
to
know
and
point
to

where
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
we
stopped
for
a
rather
long
conversation
between
him
and
one
of
these
men
,
which
I
supposed
to
be
satisfactory
from
his
manner
of

from
time
to

.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
finished
he
came
to
me
looking
very
busy
and
very

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Miss
Summerson
,
he
said

me
,
"
you
wo
n't
be
alarmed
<EOS>
whatever
comes
off
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Of

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
ai
n't

,
"

,
"
but

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Although

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Are

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

And

<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

In

.
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

---

"

<EOS>

Inspector

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Richard

<EOS>

a
door

house

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
They

House
,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

---
you

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

,

.
 
<EOS>

"
   
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
His

,

!
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
C

under

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
In

C
's

,

,

,

,

he

---
I

,

,

C

,

(
that

,

)

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
HAVE

;

.
 
<EOS>
But

to

's

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

C
's

.
 
<EOS>

,

?
 
<EOS>

;

C

,

.
 
<EOS>
By

I
too
well

Mr
Vholes
's
scrupulous
way
of
saving

and
his
respectability
not
to
feel
that
our
worst

did
but

client
's

.
   
<EOS>
We
sat
down
to
dinner
,
and
I
had
an
opportunity
of
observing
Richard
,
anxiously
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
not
disturbed
by
Mr
Vholes
(
who
took
off
his
gloves
to
dine
)
,
though
he
sat
opposite

me
at
the
small

,
for
I
doubt
if
,
looking
up
at
all
,
he
once
removed
his

from
his
host
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
Richard
thin
and
languid
,
slovenly
in
his
dress
,
abstracted
in
his
manner
,
forcing
his
spirits
now
and
then
,
and
at
other
intervals
relapsing
into
a
dull
thoughtfulness
.
<EOS>
About
his
large
bright
eyes
that
used
to
be
so
merry
there
was
a
wanness
and
a
restlessness
that
changed
them
altogether
.
 
<EOS>
1
can
not
use
the
expression
that
he
looked
old
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
ruin
of
youth
which
is
not
like
age
,
and
into
such
a
ruin
Richard
's
youth
and
youthful
beauty
had
all
fallen
away
.
   
<EOS>
He
ate
little
and
seemed
indifferent
what
it
was
,
showed
himself
to
be
much
more
impatient
than
he
used
to
be
,
and
was
quick
even
with
Ada
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
at
first
that
his
old
light
-
hearted
manner
was
all
gone
,
but
it
shone
out
of
him
sometimes
as
I
had
occasionally
known
little
momentary
glimpses
of
my
own
old
face
to
look
out
upon
me
from
the
glass
.
 
<EOS>
His
laugh
had
not
quite
left
him
either
,
but
it
was
like
the
echo
of
a
joyful
sound
,
and
that
is
always
sorrowful
.
   
<EOS>
Yet
he
was
as
glad
as
ever
,
in
his
old
affectionate
way
,
to
have
me
there
,
and
we
talked
of
the
old
times
pleasantly
.
 
<EOS>
These
did
not
appear
to
be
interesting
to
Mr
Vholes
,
though
he
occasionally
made
a
gasp
which
I
believe
was
his
smile
.
 
<EOS>
He
rose
shortly
after
dinner
and
said
that
with
the
permission
of
the
ladies
he
would
retire
to
his
office
.
   
<EOS>
"
Always
devoted
to
business
,
Vholes
!
"
cried
Richard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr
C
,
"
he
returned
,
"
the
interests
of
clients
are
never
to
be
neglected
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
paramount
in
the
thoughts
of
a
professional
man
like
myself
,
who
wishes
to
preserve
a
good
name
among
his
fellow
-
practitioners
and
society
at
large
.
 
<EOS>
My
denying
myself
the
pleasure
of
the
present
agreeable
conversation
may
not
be
wholly
irrespective
of
your
own
interests
,
Mr
C.
"
   
Richard
expressed
himself
quite
sure
of
that
and
lighted
Mr
Vholes
out
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
return
he
told
us
,
more
than
once
,
that
Vholes
was
a
good
fellow
,
a
safe
fellow
,
a
man
who
did
what
he
pretended
to
do
,
a
very
good
fellow
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
defiant
about
it
that
it
struck
me
<EOS>
he
had
begun
to
doubt
Mr
Vholes
.
   
<EOS>
Then
he
threw
himself
on
the
sofa
,
tired
out
;
and
Ada
and
I
put
things
to
rights
,
for
they
had
no
other
servant
than
the
woman
who
attended
to
the
chambers
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
had
a
cottage
piano
there
and
quietly
sat
down
to
sing
some
of
Richard
's
favourites
,
the
lamp
being
first
removed
into
the
next
room
,
as
he
complained
of
its
hurting
his
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
I
sat
between
them
,
at
my
dear
girl
's
side
,
and
felt
very
melancholy
listening
to
her
sweet
voice
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
Richard
did
too
;
I
think
he
darkened
the
room
for
that
reason
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
singing
some
time
,
rising
between
whiles
to
bend
over
him
and
speak
to
him
,
when
Mr
Woodcourt
came
in
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
sat
down
by
Richard
and
half
playfully
,
half
earnestly
,
quite
naturally
and
easily
,
found
out
how
he
felt
and
where
he
had
been
all
day
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
he
proposed
to
accompany
him
in
a
short
walk
on
one
of
the
bridges
,
as
it
was
a
moonlight
airy
night
;
and
Richard
readily
consenting
,
they
went
out
together
.
   
<EOS>
They
left
my
dear
girl
still
sitting
at
the
piano
and
me
still
sitting
beside
her
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
were
gone
out
,
I
drew
my
arm
round
her
waist
.
 
<EOS>
She
put
her
left
hand
in
mine
<EOS>
(
I
was
sitting
on
that
side
)
,
but
kept
her
right
upon
the
keys
,
going
over
and
over
them
without
striking
any
note
.
   
<EOS>
"
Esther
,
my
dearest
<EOS>
,
"
she
said
,
breaking
silence
,
"
Richard
is
never
so
well
<EOS>
and
I
am
never
so
easy
about
him
as
when
he
is
with
Allan
Woodcourt
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
to
thank
you
for
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
pointed
out
to
my
darling
how
this
could
scarcely
be
,
because
Mr
Woodcourt
had
come
to
her
cousin
John
's
house
and
had
known
us
all
there
,
and
because
he
had
always
liked
Richard
,
and
Richard
had
always
liked
him
,
and
---
and
so
forth
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
true
,
"
said
Ada
,
"
but
that
he
is
such
a
devoted
friend
to
us
<EOS>
we
owe
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
thought
it
best
to
let
my
dear
girl
have
her
way
and
to
say
no
more
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
said
as
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
it
lightly
,
because
I
felt
her
trembling
.
   
<EOS>
"
Esther
,
my
dearest
,
I
want
to
be
a
good
wife
,
a
very
,
very
good
wife
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
teach
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
I
teach
!
 
<EOS>
I
said
no
more
,
for
I
noticed
the
hand
that
was
fluttering
over
the
keys
,
and
I
knew
that
it
was
not
I
who
ought
to
speak
,
that
it
was
she
who
had
something
to
say
to
me
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
married
Richard
I
was
not
insensible
to
what
was
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
been
perfectly
happy
for
a
long
time
with
you
,
and
I
had
never
known
any
trouble
or
anxiety
,
so
loved
and
cared
for
,
but
I
understood
the
danger
he
was
in
,
dear
Esther
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
I
know
,
my
darling
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
we
were
married
I
had
some
little
hope
that
I
might
be
able
to
convince
him
of
his
mistake
,
that
he
might
come
to
regard
it
in
a
new
way
as
my
husband
and
not
pursue
it
all
the
more
desperately
for
my
sake
---
as
he
does
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
I
had
not
had
that
hope
,
I
would
have
married
him
just
the
same
,
Esther
.
 
<EOS>
Just
the
same
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
In
the
momentary
firmness
of
the
hand
that
was
never
still
---
a
firmness
inspired
by
the
utterance
of
these
last
words
,
and
dying
away
with
them
---
I
saw
the
confirmation
of
her
earnest
tones
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
to
think
,
my
dearest
Esther
,
that
I
fail
to
see
what
you
see
and
fear
what
you
fear
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
can
understand
him
better
than
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
The
greatest
wisdom
that
ever
lived
in
the
world
could
scarcely
know
Richard
better
than
my
love
does
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
spoke
so
modestly
and
softly
<EOS>
and
her
trembling
hand
expressed
such
agitation
as
it
moved
to
and
fro
upon
the
silent
notes
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
,
dear
girl
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
him
at
his
worst
every
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
watch
him
in
his
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
every
change
of
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
I
married
Richard
<EOS>
I
was
quite
determined
,
Esther
,
if
heaven
would
help
me
,
never
to
show
him
that
I
grieved
for
what
he
did
and
so
to
make
him
more
unhappy
.
<EOS>
I
want
him
,
when
he
comes
home
,
to
find
no
trouble
in
my
face
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
him
,
when
he
looks
at
me
,
to
see
what
he
loved
in
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
married
him
to
do
this
,
and
this
supports
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
felt
her
trembling
more
.
 
<EOS>
I
waited
for
what
was
yet
to
come
,
and
I
now
thought
I
began
to
know
what
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
something
else
supports
me
,
Esther
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
stopped
a
minute
.
 
<EOS>
Stopped
speaking
only
;
her
hand
was
still
in
motion
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
look
forward
a
little
while
,
and
I
do
n't
know
what
great
aid
may
come
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
Richard
turns
his
eyes
upon
me
then
,
there
may
be
something
lying
on
my
breast
more
eloquent
than
I
have
been
,
with
greater
power
than
mine
to
show
him
his
true
course
and
win
him
back
.
"
   
<EOS>
Her
hand
stopped
now
.
 
<EOS>
She
clasped
me
in
her
arms
,
and
I
clasped
her
in
mine
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
that
little
creature
should
fail
too
,
Esther
,
I
still
look
forward
.
 
<EOS>
I
look
forward
a
long
while
,
through
years
and
years
,
and
think
that
then
,
when
I
am
growing
old
,
or
when
I
am
dead
perhaps
,
a
beautiful
woman
,
his
daughter
,
happily
married
,
may
be
proud
of
him
and
a
blessing
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Or
that
a
generous
brave
man
,
as
handsome
as
he
used
to
be
,
as
hopeful
,
and
far
more
happy
<EOS>
,
may
walk
in
the
sunshine
with
him
,
honouring
his
grey
head
and
saying
to
himself
,
"
I
thank
God
this
is
my
father
!
 
<EOS>
Ruined
by
a
fatal
inheritance
,
and
restored
through
me
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
sweet
girl
,
what
a
heart
was
that
which
beat
so
fast
against
me
!
   
<EOS>
"
These
hopes
uphold
me
,
my
dear
Esther
,
and
I
know
they
will
.
<EOS>
Though
sometimes
even
they
depart
from
me
before
a
dread
that
arises
when
I
look
at
Richard
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
tried
to
cheer
my
darling
,
and
asked
her
what
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Sobbing
and
weeping
,
she
replied
,
"
That
he
may
not
live
to
see
his
child
.
"
    
Chapter
61
.
<EOS>
A
Discovery
 
<EOS>
The
days
when
I
frequented
that
miserable
corner
which
my
dear
girl
brightened
can
never
fade
in
my
remembrance
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
see
it
,
and
I
never
wish
to
see
it
now
;
I
have
been
there
only
once
since
,
but
in
my
memory
there
is
a
mournful
glory
shining
on
the
place
which
will
shine
for
ever
.
   
<EOS>
Not
a
day
passed
without
my
going
there
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
I
found
Mr
Skimpole
there
,
on
two
or
three
occasions
,
idly
playing
the
piano
and
talking
in
his
usual
vivacious
strain
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
besides
my
very
much
mistrusting
the
probability
of
his
being
there
without
making
Richard
poorer
,
I
felt
as
if
there
were
something
in
his
careless
gaiety
too
inconsistent
with
what
I
knew
of
the
depths
of
Ada
's
life
.
 
<EOS>
I
clearly
perceived
,
too
,
that
Ada
shared
my
feelings
.
<EOS>
I
therefore
resolved
,
after
much
thinking
of
it
,
to
make
a
private
visit
to
Mr
Skimpole
and
try
delicately
to
explain
myself
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
was
the
great
consideration
that
made
me
bold
.
   
<EOS>
I
set
off
one
morning
,
accompanied
by
Charley
,
for
Somers
Town
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
approached
the
house
,
I
was
strongly
inclined
to
turn
back
,
for
I
felt
what
a
desperate
attempt
it
was
to
make
an
impression
on
Mr
Skimpole
and
how
extremely
likely
it
was
that
he
would
signally
defeat
me
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
I
thought
that
being
there
,
I
would
go
through
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
knocked
with
a
trembling
hand
at
Mr
Skimpole
's
door
---
 
literally
with
a
hand
,
for
the
knocker
was
gone
---
and
after
a
long
parley
gained
admission
from
an
Irishwoman
,
who
was
in
the
area
when
I
knocked
,
breaking
up
the
lid
of
a
water
-
butt
with
a
poker
to
light
the
fire
with
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
,
lying
on
the
sofa
in
his
room
,
playing
the
flute
a
little
,
was
enchanted
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
who
should
receive
me
,
he
asked
.
 
<EOS>
Who
would
I
prefer
for
mistress
of
the
ceremonies
?
 
<EOS>
Would
I
have
his
Comedy
daughter
,
his
Beauty
daughter
,
or
his
Sentiment
daughter
?
 
<EOS>
Or
would
I
have
all
the
daughters
at
once
in
a
perfect
nosegay
?
   
<EOS>
I
replied
,
half
defeated
already
,
that
I
wished
to
speak
to
himself
only
if
he
would
give
me
leave
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Miss
Summerson
,
most
joyfully
!
 
<EOS>
Of
course
,
"
he
said
,
bringing
his
chair
nearer
mine
and
breaking
into
his
fascinating
smile
,
of
course
it
's
not
business
.
 
<EOS>
Then
it
's
pleasure
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
said
it
certainly
was
not
business
that
I
came
upon
,
but
it
was
not
quite
a
pleasant
matter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
my
dear
Miss
Summerson
,
"
said
he
with
the
frankest
gaiety
,
"
do
n't
allude
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
you
allude
to
anything
that
is
NOT
a
pleasant
matter
?
 
<EOS>
I
never
do
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
are
a
much
pleasanter
creature
,
in
every
point
of
view
,
than
I.
 
You
are
perfectly
pleasant
;
I
am
imperfectly
pleasant
;
then
,
if
I
never
allude
to
an
unpleasant
matter
,
how
much
less
should
you
!
 
<EOS>
So
that
's
disposed
of
,
and
we
will
talk
of
something
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
Although
I
was
embarrassed
,
I
took
courage
to
intimate
that
I
still
wished
to
pursue
the
subject
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
it
a
mistake
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
with
his
airy
laugh
,
"
if
I
thought
Miss
Summerson
capable
of
making
one
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
said
I
,
raising
my
eyes
to
his
,
"
I
have
so
often
heard
you
say
that
you
are
unacquainted
with
the
common
affairs
of
life
---
"
   
"
Meaning
our
three
banking
-
house
friends
,
L
,
S
,
and
who
's
the
junior
partner
?
 
<EOS>
D
?
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
brightly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
an
idea
of
them
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
---
That
perhaps
,
"
I
went
on
,
"
you
will
excuse
my
boldness
on
that
account
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
you
ought
most
seriously
to
know
that
Richard
is
poorer
than
he
was
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
am
I
,
they
tell
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
in
very
embarrassed
circumstances
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Parallel
case
,
exactly
!
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
with
a
delighted
countenance
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
at
present
naturally
causes
Ada
much
secret
anxiety
,
and
as
I
think
she
is
less
anxious
when
no
claims
are
made
upon
her
by
visitors
,
and
<EOS>
as
Richard
has
one
uneasiness
always
heavy
on
his
mind
,
it
has
occurred
to
me
to
take
the
liberty
of
saying
that
---
if
you
would
---
not
---
"
   
I
was
coming
to
the
point
with
great
difficulty
when
he
took
me
by
both
hands
and
with
a
radiant
face
and
<EOS>
in
the
liveliest
way
anticipated
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
go
there
?
 
<EOS>
Certainly
not
,
my
dear
Miss
Summerson
,
most
assuredly
not
.
 
<EOS>
Why
SHOULD
I
go
there
?
 
<EOS>
When
I
go
anywhere
,
I
go
for
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
go
anywhere
for
pain
,
because
I
was
made
for
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
Pain
comes
to
ME
when
it
wants
me
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
have
had
very
little
pleasure
at
our
dear
Richard
's
lately
,
and
your
practical
sagacity
demonstrates
why
.
 
<EOS>
Our
young
friends
,
losing
the
youthful
poetry
which
was
once
so
captivating
in
them
,
begin
to
think
,
"
This
is
a
man
who
wants
pounds
.
"
 
<EOS>
So
I
am
;
I
always
want
pounds
;
not
for
myself
,
but
because
tradespeople
always
want
them
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
Next
,
our
young
friends
begin
to
think
,
becoming
mercenary
,
"
This
is
the
man
who
HAD
pounds
,
who
borrowed
them
,
"
which
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
borrow
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
So
our
young
friends
,
reduced
to
prose
(
which
is
much
to
be
regretted
)
,
degenerate
in
their
power
of
imparting
pleasure
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
I
go
to
see
them
,
therefore
?
 
<EOS>
Absurd
!
"
   
<EOS>
Through
the
beaming
smile
with
which
he
regarded
me
as
he
reasoned
thus
,
there
now
broke
forth
a
look
of
disinterested
benevolence
quite
astonishing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
"
he
said
,
pursuing
his
argument
in
his
tone
of
light
-
hearted
conviction
,
"
if
I
do
n't
go
anywhere
for
pain
---
which
would
be
a
perversion
of
the
intention
of
my
being
,
and
a
monstrous
thing
to
do
---
why
should
I
go
anywhere
to
be
the
cause
of
pain
?
 
<EOS>
If
I
went
to
see
our
young
friends
in
their
present
ill
-
regulated
state
of
mind
,
I
should
give
them
pain
.
 
<EOS>
The
associations
with
me
would
be
disagreeable
.
 
<EOS>
They
might
say
,
"
This
is
the
man
who
had
pounds
and
who
ca
n't
pay
pounds
,
"
which
I
ca
n't
,
of
course
;
nothing
could
be
more
out
of
the
question
!
 
<EOS>
Then
kindness
requires
that
I
should
n't
go
near
them
---
and
I
wo
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
finished
by
genially
kissing
my
hand
and
thanking
me
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
but
Miss
Summerson
's
fine
tact
,
he
said
,
would
have
found
this
out
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
much
disconcerted
,
but
I
reflected
that
if
the
main
point
were
gained
,
it
mattered
little
how
strangely
he
perverted
everything
leading
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
determined
to
mention
something
else
,
however
,
and
I
thought
I
was
not
to
be

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
must
take
the
liberty
of
saying
before
I
conclude

that
I
was
much

to
learn
,
on
the
best

,
some

,
that
you
knew
with
whom
that
poor

House
and
that
you

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not

to
my
guardian
,
for
I
fear

would
hurt
him

;
but
I
may

you
that
I
was
much
surprised
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
?
 
<EOS>
Really
surprised
,
my
dear
Miss
Summerson
?
<EOS>
"
he
returned
inquiringly
,
raising
his
pleasant

.
   
<EOS>
"
Greatly
surprised
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
thought
about
it
for
a
little
while
with
a
highly
agreeable
and
whimsical
expression
of
face
,
then
quite
gave

up

said
in
his
most

,
"
You
know
what
a
child
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
Why
surprised
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
reluctant
to
enter
minutely
into
that

,
but
as
he
begged
I
would
,
for
he
was
really
curious
to
know
<EOS>
,
I
gave
him
to
understand
in
the
gentlest
words
I
could
use
that
his
conduct
seemed
to
involve
a
disregard
of
several
moral

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
much
amused
and
interested
when
he
heard
this
and
said
,
"
No
,
really
?
"
<EOS>
with
ingenuous
simplicity
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
I
do
n't
intend
to
be
responsible
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
could
do
it
.
<EOS>
Responsibility
is
a
thing
that
has
always
been
above
me
---
or
below
me
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
even
know
which
;
but
as
I
understand
the
way
in
which
my
dear
Miss
Summerson
(
always
remarkable
for
her
practical

)
puts
this
case
,
I
should
imagine

was

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Then
you
see
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
shaking

,
"
I
am
hopeless
of

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
suggested
,
as
I

to

,
that
it
was
not
right
to
betray
my
guardian
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Miss
Summerson
,
"
he

with
a
candid

that
was
all

,
"
I
ca
n't
be
bribed
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not
by
Mr
Bucket
?
"
said

<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
by

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
attach
any
value
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
care
about
it
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
about
it
,
I
do
n't
want
it
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
keep
it
---
it
goes
away
from
me

.
 
<EOS>
How
can
I
be
bribed
?
"
   
<EOS>
I
showed
that
I
was
of
a
different

,
though
I
had
not
the
capacity
for
arguing

question
.
   
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
"
said
Mr
Skimpole
,
"
<EOS>
I
am
exactly
the
man
to
be
placed
in
a
superior
position
in
such
a
case
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
above
the
rest
of
mankind
in
such
a
case
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
act
with
philosophy
in
such
a
case
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
warped
by
prejudices
,
as
an
Italian
baby
is
by
bandages
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
as
free
as
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
myself
as
far
above
suspicion
as
Caesar
's
wife
.
"
   
<EOS>
Anything
to
equal
the
lightness
of
his
manner
and
the
playful

with
which
he
seemed
to
convince
himself
,
<EOS>
as
he
tossed
the
matter
about
like

ball

feathers
,
was
surely
never
seen
in
anybody
else
!
   
<EOS>
"
Observe
the
case
,
my
dear
Miss
Summerson
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
a
boy
received
into
the
house
and
put
to
bed
in
a
state
that
I
strongly
object
to
.
<EOS>
The
boy
being
in
bed
,
a
man
arrives
---
like
the
house
that
Jack
built
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
the
man
who
demands
the
boy
who
is
received
into
the
house
and
put
to
bed
in
a
state
that
I
strongly
object
to
.
<EOS>
Here
is
a
bank
-
note
produced
by
the
man
who
demands
the
boy
who
is
received
into
the
house
and
put
to
bed
in
a
state
that
I
strongly
object
to
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
the
Skimpole
who
accepts
the
bank
-
note
produced
by
the
man
who
demands
the
boy
who
is
received
into
the
house
and
put
to
bed
in
a
state
that
I
strongly
object
to
.
 
<EOS>
Those
are
the
facts
.
 
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
Should
the
Skimpole
have
refused
the
note
?
 
<EOS>
WHY
should
the
Skimpole
have
refused
the
note
?
 
<EOS>
Skimpole
protests
to
Bucket
<EOS>
,
"
What
's
this
for
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
understand
it
<EOS>
,
it
is
of
no
use
to
me
,
take
it
away
.
"
 
<EOS>
Bucket
still
entreats
Skimpole
to
accept
it
.
<EOS>
Are
there
reasons
why
Skimpole
,
not
being
warped
by
prejudices
,
should
accept
it
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Skimpole
perceives
them
.
 
<EOS>
What
are
they
?
<EOS>
Skimpole
reasons
with
himself
<EOS>
,
this
is
a
tamed
lynx
,
an
active
police
-
officer
,
an
intelligent
man
,
a
person
of
a
peculiarly
directed
energy
and
great
subtlety
both
of
conception
and
execution
,
who
discovers
our
friends
and
enemies
for
us
when
they
run
away
,
recovers
our
property
for
us
when
we
are
robbed
,
avenges
us
comfortably
when
we
are
murdered
.
 
<EOS>
This
active
police
-
officer
and
intelligent
man
has
acquired
,
in
the
exercise
of
his
art
,
a
strong
faith
in
money
;
he
finds
it
very
useful
to
him
,
and
he
makes
it
very
useful
to
society
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
shake
that
faith
in
Bucket
because
I
want
it
myself
;
shall
I
deliberately
blunt
one
of
Bucket
's

;
shall
I
positively

Bucket
in

?
 
<EOS>
And
again
.
 
<EOS>
If

is

in
Skimpole
to
take
the
note
,
it
is

in
Bucket
to
offer
the
note
---
much
more

in
Bucket
,
because
he
is
the

man
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Skimpole
wishes
to
think
well

Bucket
;
Skimpole

essential
,
in

,
to
the

,
that
he
SHOULD
think
well

Bucket
.
 
<EOS>
The

Bucket
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
does
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
's
all
he
does
!
"
   
<EOS>
I
had
nothing
to
offer
in

to
this

and

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Skimpole
,
however
,
who
was
in

,
would
not

of
my

home
attended

"
Little
Coavinses
,
"
and

.
 
<EOS>
He
entertained

on

with
a

and
assured
me
,
at

,
that

never

the
fine

with
which
I
had
found
that
out
for
him
about

young
friends
.
   
<EOS>
As

so
happened
that
I
never
saw
Mr
Skimpole
again
,
I
may
at

finish
what
I
know
of

.
 
<EOS>
A
coolness
arose
between
him
and
my
guardian
,
based
principally
on
the
foregoing
grounds
and
on
his
having
heartlessly

my
guardian
's

(
as

from
Ada
)
in

Richard
.
 
<EOS>
His
being
heavily
in
my
guardian
's
debt
had
nothing
to
do
with
their
separation
.
 
<EOS>
He
died
some
five
years
afterwards
and
left
a
diary
behind
him
,
with
letters
and
other
materials
towards
his
life
,
which
was
published
and
which
showed
him
to
have
been
the

of
a
combination
on
the
part
of
mankind
against
an
amiable
child
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
considered
very
pleasant
reading
,
but
I
never
read
more
of
it
myself
than
the
sentence
on
which
I
chanced
to
light
on
opening
the
book
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
this
:
"
Jarndyce
,
in
common
with
most
other
men
I
have
known
,
is
the
incarnation
of
selfishness
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
now
I
come
to
a
part
of
my
story
touching
myself
very
nearly
indeed
,
and
for
which
I
was
quite
unprepared
when
the
circumstance
occurred
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
little
lingerings
may
have
now
and
then
revived
in
my
mind
associated
with
my
poor
old
face
had
only
revived
as
belonging
to
a
part
of
my
life
that
was
gone
---
gone
like
my
infancy
or
my
childhood
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
suppressed
none
of
my
many
weaknesses
on
that
subject
,
but
have
written
them
as
faithfully
as
my
memory
has
recalled
them
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
hope
to
do
,
and
mean
to
do
,
the
same
down
to
the
last
words
of
these
pages
,
which
I
see
now
not
so
very
far
before
me
.
   
<EOS>
The
months
were
gliding
away
,
and
my
dear
girl
,
sustained
by
the
hopes
she
had
confided
in
me
,
was
the
same
beautiful
star
in
the
miserable
corner
.
 
<EOS>
Richard
,
more
worn
and
haggard
,
haunted
the
court
day
after
day
,
listlessly
sat
there
the
whole
day
long
when
he
knew
there
was
no
remote
chance
of
the
suit
being
mentioned
,
and
became
one
of
the
stock
sights
of
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
any
of
the
gentlemen
remembered
him
as
he
was
when
he
first
went
there
.
   
<EOS>
So
completely
was
he
absorbed
in
his
fixed
idea
that
he
used
to
avow
in
his
cheerful
moments
that
he
should
never
have
breathed
the
fresh
air
now
"
but
for
Woodcourt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
It
was
only
Mr
Woodcourt
who
could
occasionally
divert
his
attention
for
a
few
hours
at
a
time
and
rouse
him
,
even
when
he
sunk
into
a
lethargy
of
mind
and
body
that
alarmed
us
greatly
,
and
<EOS>
the
returns
of
which
became
more
frequent
as
the
months
went
on
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
was
right
in
saying
that
he
only
pursued
his
errors
the
more
desperately
for
her
sake
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
that
his
desire
to
retrieve
what
he
had
lost
was
rendered
the
more
intense
by
his
grief
for
his
young
wife
,
and
became
like
the
madness
of
a
gamester
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
there
,
as
I
have
mentioned
,
at
all
hours
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
was
there
at
night
,
I
generally
went
home
with
Charley
in
a
coach
;
sometimes
my
guardian
would
meet
me
in
the
neighbourhood
,
and
we
would
walk
home
together
.
 
<EOS>
One
evening
he
had
arranged
to
meet
me
at
eight
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
not
leave
,
as
I
usually
did
,
quite
punctually
at
the
time
,
for
I
was
working
for
my
dear
girl
and
had
a
few
stitches
more
to
do
to
finish
what
I
was
about
;
but
it
was
within
a
few
minutes
of
the
hour
when
I
bundled

little
work

,

my

my
last

for
the
night
,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Woodcourt
went
with
me
,
as
it
was

.
   
<EOS>
When

the
usual

---
it
was

,
and
Mr

had
often

---
my

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
   
<EOS>

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
His

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

had

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
How
easy
my
path
,
how
much

than

!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
62
.
<EOS>
Another
Discovery
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
the
courage
to
see
any
one
that
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
not
even
the
courage
to
see
myself
,
for
I
was
afraid
that
my
tears
might
a
little
reproach
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
went
up
to
my
room
in
the
dark
,
and
prayed
in
the
dark
,
and
lay
down
in
the
dark
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
need
of
any
light
to
read
my
guardian
's
letter
by
,
for
I
knew
it
by
heart
.
<EOS>
I
took
it
from
the
place
where
I
kept
it
,
and
repeated
its
contents
by
its
own
clear
light
of
integrity
and
love
,
and
went
to
sleep
with
it
on
my
pillow
.
   
<EOS>
I
was
up
very
early
in
the
morning
and
called
Charley
to
come
for
a
walk
.
 
<EOS>
We
bought
flowers
for
the
breakfast
-
table
,
and
came
back
and
arranged
them
,
and
were
as
busy
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
so
early
that
I
had
a
good
time
still
for
Charley
's
lesson
before
breakfast
;
Charley
(
who
was
not
in
the
least
improved
in
the
old
defective
article
of
grammar
)
came
through
it
with
great
applause
;
and
we
were
altogether
very
notable
.
 
<EOS>
When
my
guardian
appeared
he
said
,
"
Why
,
little
woman
,
you
look
fresher
than
your
flowers
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
Mrs
Woodcourt
repeated
and
translated
a
passage
from
the
Mewlinnwillinwodd
expressive
of
my
being
like
a
mountain
with

sun
upon

.
   
<EOS>
This
was
all
so
pleasant
that
I
hope
it
made
me
still
more
like
the
mountain
than
I
had
been
before
.
 
<EOS>
After

I
waited
my
opportunity
and
peeped
about
a
little
until
I
saw
my
guardian
in
his
own
room
---
the
room
of
last
night
---
by
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
made
an

to
go
in
with
my

,
shutting

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Dame
Durden
?
"
said
my
guardian
;
the
post
had
brought
him
several
letters
,
and
he
was
writing
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
want
money
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
,
I
have
plenty

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
never
was
such
a
Dame
Durden
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
"
for
making
money
last
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
laid
down
his
pen
and
leaned
back
in
his
chair

at
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
spoken
of
his
bright
face
,
but
I
thought
I
had
never
seen
it
look
so
bright
and
good
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
high
happiness
upon
it
which
made
me
think
,
"
<EOS>
He
has
been
doing
some
great

this
morning
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
never
was
,
"
said
my
guardian
,

,
"
such
a
Dame
Durden
for
making
money
last
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
never

.
 
<EOS>
I
loved

and

so

that
when

,

---
for

,

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
Dear

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Have

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Remiss

,

!

<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

"
   
<EOS>

I

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
He

"

,

.

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Little

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bucket

Steel

George

,

hands

just
knocked
off
for
dinner
-
time
and
seem
to
be
invading
the
whole
town
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
very
sinewy
and
strong
,
are
Rouncewell
's
hands
---
a
little
sooty
too
.
   
<EOS>
He
comes
to
a
gateway
in
the
brick
wall
,
looks
in
,
and
sees
a
great
perplexity
of
iron
lying
about
in
every
stage
and
in
a
vast
variety
of
shapes
---
in
bars
,
in
wedges
,
in
sheets
;
in
tanks
,
in
boilers
,
in
axles
,
in
wheels
,
in
cogs
,
in
cranks
,
in
rails
;
twisted
and
wrenched
into
eccentric
and
perverse
forms
as
separate
parts
of
machinery
;
mountains
of
it
broken
up
,
and
rusty
in
its
age
;
distant
furnaces
of
it
glowing
and
bubbling
in
its
youth
;
bright
fireworks
of
it
showering
about
under
the
blows
of
the
steam
-
hammer
;
red
-
hot
iron
,
white
-
hot
iron
,
cold
-
black
iron
;
an
iron
taste
,
an
iron
smell
,
and
a
Babel
of
iron
sounds
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
place
to
make
a
man
's
head
ache
too
!
"
says
the
trooper
,
looking
about
him
for
a
counting
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
comes
here
?
 
<EOS>
This
is
very
like
me
before
I
was
set
up
.
 
<EOS>
This
ought
to
be
my
nephew
,
if
likenesses
run
in
families
.
 
<EOS>
Your
servant
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yours
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
looking
for
any
one
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
.
 
<EOS>
Young
Mr
Rouncewell
,
I
believe
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
looking
for
your
father
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
have
a
word
with
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
man
,
telling
him
he

fortunate
in
his

of
a
time
,
for
his
father
is
there
,
leads
the
way
to
the
office
where
he
is
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
like
me
before
I
was
set
up
---
devilish
like
me
!
"
thinks
the
trooper
as
he
follows
.
 
<EOS>
They
come
to
a
building
in
the
yard
with
an
office
on

upper

.
 
<EOS>
At
sight
of
the
gentleman
in
the
office
,
Mr
George
turns
very
red
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
name
shall
I
say
to
my
father
?
"
asks

young
man
.
   
<EOS>
George
,
full
of
the
idea
of
iron
,
in

answers
"
Steel
,
"
and
is
so
presented
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
left
alone
with
the
gentleman
in
the
office
,
who
sits
at
a
table
with
account

before
him
and
some

of
paper
blotted
with
hosts
of

and

of

shapes
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
bare
office
,
with
bare
windows
,
looking
on
the
iron
view
below
.
 
<EOS>
Tumbled
together
on
the
table
are
some
pieces
of
iron
,
purposely
broken
to
be
tested
at
various
periods
of
their
service
,
in
various
capacities
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
iron
-
dust
on
everything
;
and
the
smoke
is
seen
through
the
windows
rolling
heavily
out
of
the
tall
chimneys
to
mingle
with
the

from
a
vaporous
Babylon
of
other

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
at
your
service
,
Mr
Steel
,
"
says
the
gentleman
when
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Mr
Rouncewell
,
"
George

,
leaning

with

on

and

in

,
and
very
chary
of
meeting

brother
's

,
"
I
am
not
without
my
expectations
that

I

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

in

,
and
a

that
I

was
,

I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

who

some

,

,

but

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"
returns

,
"
that
your
name

Steel
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
trooper
falters
and
looks
at

.
 
<EOS>
His

starts

,
calls

by

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

for

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
How

do
,
<EOS>
my

?
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
How

,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
They

his
"
How

do
,
my
dear
old
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
with

that

<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

anything
<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

what

<EOS>
we

,
George
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Watt
to

that

twelvemonth
he

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
George
is
so
entirely
overcome
at

by
this

that
he
resists

.
 
<EOS>
Being

,

,
by

---

his

---
he
is
taken
home
to
an
elegant
house
in
all

of
which
<EOS>
there

to

observed
a

of
the
father
and

with

.
 
<EOS>
Here
Mr
George
is
much

by
the

of
his

that
are
and

of
Rosa
,

,

of

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

aback
,

,
by
the
dutiful

of
his

and
has
a

upon
him
of

.
 
<EOS>
However
,
there
is
great

and
a
very
hearty
company
and
infinite

,
and
Mr
George
comes
bluff
and
martial
through
it
all
,
and
his
pledge
to
be
present
at
the
marriage
and
give
away
the
bride
is
received
with
universal
favour
.
<EOS>
A
whirling
head
has
Mr
George
that
night
when
he
lies
down
in
the
state
-
bed
of
his
brother
's
house
to
think
of
all
these
things
and
to
see
the
images
of
his
nieces
(
awful
all
the
evening
in
their
floating

)
waltzing
,
after
the
German
manner
,
over
his
counterpane
.
   
<EOS>
The
brothers
are
closeted
next
morning
in
the
ironmaster
's
room
,
where
the
elder
is
proceeding
,
in
his
clear
sensible
way
,
to
show
how
he

may
best
dispose
of
George
in

business
,
when

.
   
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
I
thank

a

for

more

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
But

made
.
 
<EOS>
Before

as
to

,
I

consult
you
upon
one
family
point
.
 
<EOS>
How
,
"

the
trooper
,

,
"
how

"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
George
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Scratch

out
of

will
<EOS>
,
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
"

,

,
"
I

---
TO
---
scratch

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

George
,
"
returns

,
"

that

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
!
 
<EOS>
Absolutely
!
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't

the

of
coming

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
,
who

!
<EOS>
If

,

.
 
<EOS>
Come
.
<EOS>
You

,

's

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
George
,
"

"

,
which
I

.
 
<EOS>
Look

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
No

<EOS>
You

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"
   
"

,

<EOS>
"
That

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

"

!
"
   
<EOS>
The

are

like

,

;

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
It

more

,

,

,
"
shaking

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

,

,
I

---
<EOS>

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

George
,
"

elder
,

strong
steady

upon

and

,
"
leave
that
to
me
,
and
let
me

.
"
   
<EOS>
George
shakes
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
could
do
it
,
I
have
not
a

,
if

;
but

's

.
 
<EOS>
Not
to
be
done
,
sir
!
<EOS>
Whereas

so
falls
out
,
on
the

,
that
I
am
able
to
be
of
some

use
to
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
since

---
 
brought
on
by

---
and
that

anybody
else
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
George
,
"
returns
the
other
with
a
very
slight
shade
upon
his
open
face
,
"
if
you
prefer
to
serve
in
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
's
household
brigade
---
"
   
"
There
it
is
,
brother
,
"
cries
the
trooper
,
checking
him
,
with
his
hand
upon
his
knee
again
;
"
there
it
is
!
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
take
kindly
to
that
idea
;
I
do
n't
mind
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
used
to
being
officered
;
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
about
you
is
in
perfect
order
and
discipline
;
everything
about
me
requires
to
be
kept
so
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
not
accustomed
to
carry
things
with
the
same
hand
or
to
look
at
'em
from
the
same
point
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
say
much
about
my
garrison
manners
because
I
found
myself
pretty
well
at
my
ease
last
night
,
and
they
would
n't
be
noticed
here
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
once
and
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
shall
get
on
best
at
Chesney
Wold
,
where
there
's
more
room
for
a
weed
than
there
is
here
;
and
the
dear
old
lady
will
be
made

besides
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
accept
of
Sir
Leicester
Dedlock
's
proposals
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
come
over
next
year
to
give
away

bride
,
or
<EOS>
whenever
I
come
,
I
shall

keep

in

and
not
to
manoeuvre

.
 
<EOS>
I
thank
you
heartily
again
and
am
proud
to
think
of
the
Rouncewells
as
they
'll
be
founded

you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know

,
George
,
"
says

,

,
"
and
perhaps
you
know
me
better
than
I

.
 
<EOS>
Take
your
way
.
 
<EOS>
So
that
we
do
n't
quite
lose
one
another
again
,
take
your
way
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
fear
of
that
!
<EOS>
"
returns

trooper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
before
I
turn
my
horse
's

,
brother
,
I
will
ask

---
if

---
to

.
 
<EOS>
I
brought

with
me
to
send
from
these

,
as
Chesney
Wold
might
be
a
painful
name
just
now
to

's

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not

myself
,
and
I
am
particular
respecting
this
present
letter
because
I
want

to
be
both

and

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Herewith
<EOS>
he
hands
a
letter
,
closely

in
somewhat

but
in
a
neat
round

,
to
the
ironmaster
,
who
reads
as
follows
:
   
Miss
Esther
Summerson
,
   
<EOS>
A
communication
having
been
made
to
me
by
Inspector
Bucket
of
a
letter
to
myself
being
found
among
the
papers
of
a
certain

,
I
take
the
liberty
to
make
known
to
you
that
it
was
but
a

lines
of
instruction
from
abroad
,
when
,
where
,
and
how
to
deliver
an
enclosed
letter
to
a
young
and
beautiful
lady
,
then
unmarried
,
in
England
.
 
<EOS>
I
duly
observed
the
same
.
   
<EOS>
I
further
take
the
liberty
to
make
known
to
you
that
it
was
got
from
me
as
a
proof
of
handwriting
only
and
that
otherwise
I
would
not
have
given
it
up
,
as
appearing
to
be
the
most
harmless
in
my
possession
,
without
being
previously
shot
through
the
heart
.
   
<EOS>
I
further
take
the
liberty
to
mention
that
if
I
could
have
supposed
a
certain
unfortunate
gentleman
to
have
been
in
existence
,
I
never
could
and
never
would
have
rested
until
I
had
discovered
his
retreat
and
shared
my
last
farthing
with
him
,
as
my
duty
and
my

would
have
equally

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
(
officially
)
reported
<EOS>
drowned
,
and
assuredly
went
over
the
side
of
a
transport
-
ship
at
night
in
an
Irish

within
a

of
her

from
the

,
as
I
have
myself

both
from

and

,
and
know
to
have
been
(
officially
)
confirmed
.
   
<EOS>
I
further
take
the
liberty
to
state
that
in
my
humble
quality
as
one
of
the
rank
and
file
,
I
am
,
and
shall
ever
continue
to
be
,
your
thoroughly
devoted
and

and
that
I
esteem
the
qualities
you
possess
above
all
others
far

the

of
the
present

.
   
<EOS>
I
have
the
honour
to
be
,
   
GEORGE
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
formal
,
"
observes

elder

,
refolding

with

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
nothing
that
might
not
be
sent
to
a
pattern
young
lady
?
"
asks
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
at
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
Therefore
it
is
sealed
and
deposited
for
posting
among
the
iron
correspondence
of
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
This
done
,
Mr
George
takes
a
hearty
farewell
of
the
family
party
and
prepares
to
saddle
and

.
 
<EOS>
His

,
however
,

part

so
soon
,
proposes
to
ride
with
him
in
a
light
open

to
the
place
where
he
will
bait
for
the
night
,
and
there
remain
with
him
until
morning
,
a
servant
riding
for
so
much
of
the
journey
on
the
thoroughbred
old
grey
from
Chesney
Wold
.
 
<EOS>
The
offer
,
being
gladly
accepted
,
is
followed
by
a
pleasant
ride
,
a
pleasant
dinner
,
and
a
pleasant
breakfast
,
all
in
brotherly
communion
.
 
<EOS>
Then
they
once
more
shake
hands
long
and
heartily
and
part
,
the
ironmaster
turning
his
face
to
the
smoke
and
fires
,
and
the
trooper
to
the
green
country
.
<EOS>
Early
in
the
afternoon
the
subdued
sound
of
his
heavy
military
trot
is
heard
on
the
turf
in
the
avenue
as
he
rides
on
with
imaginary
clank
and
jingle
of
accoutrements
under
the
old
elm
-
trees
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
64
.
<EOS>
Esther
's
Narrative
 
<EOS>
Soon
after
I
had
that
convertion
with
my
guardian
,
he
put
a
sealed
paper
in
my
hand
one
morning
and
said
,
"
This
is
for
next
month
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I
found
in
it
two
hundred
pounds
.
   
<EOS>
I
now
began
very
quietly
to
make
such
preparations
as
I
thought
were
necessary
.
 
<EOS>
Regulating
my
purchases
by
my
guardian
's
taste
,
which
I
knew
very
well
of
course
,
I
arranged
my
wardrobe
to
please
him
and
hoped
I
should
be
highly
successful
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
it
all
so
quietly
because
I
was
not
quite
free
from
my
old
apprehension
that
Ada
would
be
rather
sorry
and
because
my
guardian
was
so
quiet
himself
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
doubt
that
under
all
the
circumstances
we
should
be
married
in
the
most
private
and
simple
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
should
only
have
to
say
to
Ada
,
"
Would
you
like
to
come
and
see
me
married
to
-
morrow
,
my
pet
?
"
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
our
wedding
might
even
be
as
unpretending
as
her
own
,
and
I
might
not
find
it
necessary
to
say
anything
about
it
until
it
was
over
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
that
if
I
were
to
choose
,
I
would
like
this
best
.
   
<EOS>
The
only
exception
I
made
was
Mrs
Woodcourt
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
her
that
I
was
going
to
be
married
to
my
guardian
and
that
we
had
been
engaged
some
time
.
 
<EOS>
She
highly
approved
.
 
<EOS>
She
could
never
do
enough
for
me
and
was
remarkably
softened
now
in
comparison
with
what
she
had
been
when
we
first
knew
her
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
trouble
she
would
not
have
taken
to
have
been
of
use
to
me
,
but
I
need
hardly
say
that
I
only
allowed
her
to
take
as
little
as
<EOS>
gratified
her
kindness
without
tasking
it
.
   
<EOS>
Of
course
this
was
not
a
time
to
neglect
my
guardian
,
and
of
course
it
was
not
a
time
for
neglecting
my
darling
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
had
plenty
of
occupation
,
which
I
was
glad
of
;
and
as
to
Charley
,
she
was
absolutely
not
to
be
seen
for
needlework
.
 
<EOS>
To
surround
herself
with
great
heaps
of
it
---
baskets
full
and
tables
full
---
and
do
a
little
,
and
spend
a
great
deal
of
time
in
staring
with
her
round
eyes
at
what
there
was
to
do
,
and
persuade
herself
that
she
was
going
to
do
it
,
were
Charley
's
great
dignities
and
delights
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
I
must
say
,
I
could
not
agree
with
my
guardian
on
the
subject
of
the
will
,
and
I
had
some
sanguine
hopes
of
Jarndyce
and
Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>
Which
of
us
was
right
will
soon
appear
,
but
I
certainly
did
encourage
expectations
.
 
<EOS>
In
Richard
,
the
discovery
gave
occasion
for
a
burst
of
business
and
agitation
that
buoyed
him
up
for
a
little
time
,
but
he
had
lost
the
elasticity
even
of
hope
now
and
seemed
to
me
to
retain
only
its
feverish
anxieties
.
 
<EOS>
From
something
my
guardian
said
one
day
when
we
were
talking
about
this
,
I
understood
that
my
marriage
would
not
take
place
until
after
the
term
-
time
we
had
been
told
to
look
forward
to
;
and
I
thought
the
more
,
for
that
,
how
rejoiced
I
should
be
if
I
could
be
married
when
Richard
and
Ada
were
a
little
more
prosperous
.
   
<EOS>
The
term
was
very
near
indeed
when
my
guardian
was
called
out
of
town
and
went
down
into
Yorkshire
on
Mr
Woodcourt
's
business
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
told
me
beforehand
that
his
presence
there
would
be
necessary
.
<EOS>
I
had
just
come
in
one
night
from
my
dear
girl
's
and
was
sitting
in
the
midst
of
all
my
new
clothes
,
looking
at
them
all
around
me
and
thinking
,
when
a
letter
from
my
guardian
was
brought
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
asked
me
to
join
him
in
the
country
and
mentioned
by
what
stage
-
coach
my
place
was
taken
and
at
what
time
in
the
morning
I
should
have
to
leave
town
.
 
<EOS>
It
added
in
a
postscript
that
I
would
not
be
many
hours
from
Ada
.
   
<EOS>
I
expected
few
things
less
than
a
journey
at
that
tinae
,
but
I
was
ready
for
it
in
half
an
hour
and
set
off
as
appointed
early
next
morning
.
 
<EOS>
I
travelled
all
day
,
wondering
all
day
what
I
could
be
wanted
for
at
such
a
distance
;
now
I
thought
it
might
be
for
this
purpose
,
and
now
I
thought
it
might
be
for
that
purpose
,
but
I
was
never
,
never
,
never
near
the
truth
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
night
when
I
came
to
my
journey
's
end
and
found
my
guardian
waiting
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
a
great
relief
,
for
towards
evening
I
had
begun
to
fear
(
the
more
so
as
his
letter
was
a
very
short
one
)
that
he
might
be
ill
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
there
he
was
,
as
well
as
it
was
possible
to
be
;
and
<EOS>
when
I
saw
his
genial
face
again
at
its
brightest
and
best
,
I
said
to
myself
,
he
has
been
doing
some
other
great
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
Not
that
it
required
much
penetration
to
say
that
,
because
I
knew
that
his
being
there
at
all
was
an
act
of
kindness
.
   
<EOS>
Supper
was
ready
at
the
hotel
,
and
when
we
were
alone
at
table
he
said
,
"
Full
of
curiosity
,
no
doubt
,
little
woman
,
to
know
why
I
have
brought
you
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
guardian
,
"
said
I
,
"
without
thinking
myself
a
Fatima
or
you
a
Blue
Beard
,
I
am
a
little
curious
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
to
ensure
your
night
's
rest
,
my
love
,
"
he
returned
gaily
,
"
I
wo
n't
wait
until
to
-
morrow
to
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
very
much
wished
to
express
to
Woodcourt
,
somehow
,
my
sense
of
his
humanity
to
poor
unfortunate
Jo
,
his
inestimable
services
to
my
young
cousins
,
and
his
value
to
us
all
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
decided
that
he
should
settle
here
,
it
came
into
my
head
that
I
might
ask
his
acceptance
of
some
unpretending
and
suitable
little
place
to
lay
his
own
head
in
.
 
<EOS>
I
therefore
caused
such
a
place
to
be
looked
out
for
,
and
such
a
place
was
found
on
very
easy
terms
,
and
I
have
been
touching
it
up
for
him
and
making
it
habitable
.
 
<EOS>
However
,
when
I
walked
over
it
the
day
before
yesterday
and
it
was
reported
ready
,
I
found
that
I
was
not
housekeeper
enough
to
know
whether
things
were
all
as
they
ought
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
sent
off
for
the
best
little
housekeeper
that
could
possibly
be
got
to
come
and
give
me
her
advice
and
opinion
.
<EOS>
And
here
she
is
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
"
laughing
and
crying
both
together
!
"
   
<EOS>
Because
he
was
so
dear
,
so
good
,
so
admirable
.
 
<EOS>
I
tried
to
tell
him
what
I
thought
of
him
,
but
I
could
not
articulate
a
word
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
tut
!
"
said
my
guardian
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
make
too
much
of
it
,
little
woman
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
how
you
sob
,
Dame
Durden
,
how
you
sob
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
with
exquisite
pleasure
,
guardian
---
with
a
heart
full
of
thanks
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
delighted
that
you
approve
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
would
.
 
<EOS>
I
meant
it
as
a
pleasant
surprise
for
the
little
mistress
of
Bleak
House
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
kissed
him
and
dried
my
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
now
!
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
this
in
your
face
a
long
while
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
;
<EOS>
have
you
really
,
my
dear
?
"
said
he
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
Dame
Durden
it
is
to
read
a
face
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
so
quaintly
cheerful
that
I
could
not
long
be
otherwise
,
and
was
almost
ashamed
of
having
been
otherwise
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
went
to
bed
,
I
cried
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
bound
to
confess
that
I
cried
;
but
I
hope
it
was
with
pleasure
,
though
I
am
not
quite
sure
it
was
with
pleasure
.
<EOS>
I
repeated
every
word
of
the
letter
twice
over
.
   
<EOS>
A
most
beautiful
summer
morning
succeeded
,
and
after
breakfast
we
went
out
arm
in
arm
to
see
the
house
of
which
I
was
to
give
my
mighty
housekeeping
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
We
entered
a
flower
-
garden
by
a
gate
in
a
side
wall
,
of
which
he
had
the
key
,
and
the
first
thing
I
saw
was
that
the
beds
and
flowers
were
all
laid
out
according
to
the
manner
of
my
beds
and
flowers
at
home
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
my
dear
,
"
observed
my
guardian
,
standing
still
with
a
delighted
face
to
watch
my
looks
,
"
knowing
there
could
be
no
better
plan
,
I
borrowed
yours
.
"
   
<EOS>
We
went
on
by
a
pretty
little
orchard
,
where
the
cherries
were
nestling
among
the
green
leaves
and
the
shadows
of
the
apple
-
trees
were
sporting
on
the
grass
,
to
the
house
itself
---
a
cottage
,
quite
a
rustic
cottage
of
doll
's
rooms
;
but
<EOS>
such
a
lovely
place
,
so
tranquil
and
so
beautiful
,
with
such
a
rich
and
smiling
country
spread
around
it
;
with
water
sparkling
away
into
the
distance
,
here
all
overhung
with
summer
-
growth
<EOS>
,
there
turning
a
humming
mill
;
at
its
nearest
point
glancing
through
a
meadow
by
the
cheerful
town
,
where
cricket
-
players
were
assembling
in
bright
groups
and
a
flag
was
flying
from
a
white
tent
that
rippled
in
the
sweet
west
wind
.
<EOS>
And
still
,
as
we
went
through
the
pretty
rooms
,
out
at
the
little
rustic
verandah
doors
,
and
underneath
the
tiny
wooden
colonnades
garlanded
with
woodbine
,
jasmine
,
and
honey
-
suckle
,
I
saw
in
the
papering
on
the
walls
,
in
the
colours
of
the
furniture
,
in
the
arrangement
of
all
the
pretty
objects
,
MY
little
tastes
and
fancies
,
MY
little
methods
and
inventions
which
they
used
to
laugh
at
while
they
praised
them
,
my
odd
ways
everywhere
.
   
<EOS>
I
could
not
say
enough
in
admiration
of
what
was
all
so
beautiful
,
but
one
secret
doubt
arose
in
my
mind
when
I
saw
this
<EOS>
,
I
thought
,
oh
,
would
he
be
the
happier
for
it
!
 
<EOS>
Would
it
not
have
been
better
for
his
peace
that
I
should
not
have
been
so
brought
before
him
?
<EOS>
Because
although
I
was
not
what
he
thought
me
,
still
he
loved
me
very
dearly
,
and
it
might
remind
him
mournfully
of
what
be
believed
he
had
lost
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
wish
him
to
forget
me
<EOS>
---
perhaps
he
might
not
have
done
so
,
without
these
aids
to
his
memory
---
but
my
way
was
easier
than
his
,
and
I
could
have
reconciled
myself
even
to
that
so
that
he
had
been
the
happier
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
little
woman
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
whom
I
had
never
seen
so
proud

as
in
showing

and

of

,
"
now
,
last

all
,
for
the

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
called
,
dear
guardian
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
child
,
"
said
he
,
"
come
and
see
,
"
   
He
took
me
to
the
porch
,
which
he
had

,
and
said
,

,
"
My

,
do

you

the

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
<EOS>
I.
   
We
went
out
of
the
porch
and
he
showed
me
written
over
it
,
Bleak
House
.
   
<EOS>
He
led
me
to
a
seat
among
the
leaves
close
by
,
and
sitting
down

me
and
taking

in

,
spoke

thus
,
"
My
darling
girl
,
in
what
there
has
been
between
us
,
I
have
,
I
hope
,
been
really
solicitous
for
your
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
wrote
you
the
letter
to
which
you
brought
the
answer
,
"
smiling
as
he
referred
to
it
,
"
I
had
my
own
too
much
in
view
;
but
I
had
yours
too
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
,
under
different

,
I
might
ever
have
renewed
the
old
dream
I
sometimes
dreamed
when
you
were
very
young
,
of
making
you
my
wife
one
day
,
I
need
not
ask
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
renew
it
,
and
I
wrote
my
letter
,
and
you
brought
your
answer
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
following
what
I
say
,
my
child
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
was
cold
,
and
I
trembled
violently
,
but
not
a
word
he
uttered
was
lost
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
sat
looking
fixedly
at
him
and
the
sun
's
rays
descended
,
softly
shining
through
the
leaves
upon
his
bare
head
<EOS>
,
I
felt
as
if
the
brightness
on
him
must
be
like
the
brightness
of
the
angels
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
my
love
,
but
do
not
speak
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
for
me
to
speak
now
.
<EOS>
When
it
was
that
I
began
to
doubt
whether
what
I
had
done
would
really
make
you
happy
<EOS>
is
no
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Woodcourt
came
home
,
and
I
soon
had
no

at
all
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
I
clasped
him
round

neck
and
hung
my

upon

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lie
lightly
,
confidently
here
,
my
child
,
"
said
he
,
pressing
me
gently
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
your
guardian
and
your
father
now
.
 
<EOS>
Rest
confidently
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Soothingly
,
like
the
gentle

of
the

;
and
genially
,
like

ripening

;
and
radiantly

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Understand
me
,
my
dear
girl
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
doubt
of
your
being
contented
and
happy
with
me
,
being
so
dutiful
and
so
devoted
;
but
I
saw
with
whom
you
would
be
happier
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
penetrated
his
secret
when
Dame
Durden
was
blind
to
it
<EOS>
is
no
wonder
,
for
I
knew
the
good
that
could
never
change
in
her
better
far
than
she
did
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
have
long
been
in
Allan
Woodcourt
's

,
although
he
was
not
,
until
yesterday
,
a

here
,
in
mine
.
<EOS>
But
I
would
not

my
Esther
's

;
I

of

's

;

Morgan
ap
-
Kerrig
,
no
,
not
for
the
weight
in

of

in
Wales
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
to

on

,
and
I
sobbed
and

.
 
<EOS>
For
I
felt
as
if
I
could
not
bear
the
painful

of
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
,
little
woman
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
cry
;
this
is
to
be
a
day
of
joy
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
looked
forward
to
it
,
"
he
said

,
"
for
months
on
months
!
 
<EOS>
A
few
words
more
,
Dame
Trot
,
and
<EOS>
I
have
said
my
say
.
<EOS>
Determined
not
to
throw
away
one
atom
of
my
Esther
's
worth
,
I
took
Mrs
Woodcourt
into

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
madam
,
"
said
I
,
"
I
clearly
perceive
---
and
indeed
I
know
,
to
boot
---
that
your
son
loves
my
ward
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
further
very
sure
that
my
ward
loves
your
son
,
but
will
sacrifice
her
love
to
a
sense
of
duty
and
affection
,
and
will

so

,

,
so

,
that
you
should
never
suspect

though

her
night

.
<EOS>
"
Then
I
told

all
our
story
---
ours
---
yours
and
mine
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
madam
,
"
said
I
,
"
come
you
,
knowing
this
,
and
live

.
 
<EOS>
Come
you
,
and
see
my
child
from
hour

;
set

see
against
her

,
which

this
,
and
this
"
---
for
I

---
"
and

true

when
you
shall

.
"
 
<EOS>
Why
,
honour

her
old
Welsh
blood
,
my
dear
,
"
cried

,
"
<EOS>
I
believe
the

it

no
less

,
no

,
no

,

Dame
Durden
than
my
own
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
tenderly

my
head
,
and
as

clung

,

in
his
old
fatherly

again
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
light
,
now
,
on

I

!
   
<EOS>
"
One
more
last

.
 
<EOS>
When
Allan
Woodcourt
spoke
to
you
,
my
dear
,
he
spoke
with
my
knowledge

---
but
I
gave

no

,
not
I
,
for
these

<EOS>
were
my
great
reward
,
and
I
was
too
miserly
to
part
with

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
to
come
and
tell
me
all
that
passed
,
and
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
more
to

.
 
<EOS>
My
dearest
,
Allan
Woodcourt
stood
beside
your
father
when
he
lay
dead
 
---
stood
beside
your
mother
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
Bleak
House
.
 
<EOS>
This
day
I
give
this
house
its
little
mistress
;
and
before
God
,
it
is
the
brightest
day
in
all
my
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
rose
and
raised
me
with

.
 
<EOS>
We
were
no
longer
alone
.
 
<EOS>
My
husband
---
I
have
called
him
by
that
name
full
seven
happy
years
now
 
---
stood
at
my
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
Allan
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
"
take
from
me
a
willing

,
the
best
wife
that
ever
man

.
 
<EOS>
What
more

I
say

you
than
that
<EOS>
I
know

!
 
<EOS>
Take
with

the
little
home
<EOS>
she

.
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
she
will
make

,
Allan
;
you

she
has

.
 
<EOS>
Let
me

its
felicity
sometimes
,
and
what
do

?
 
<EOS>
Nothing
,
nothing
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
kissed
me
once
again
,
and
now
the
tears
were
in
his
eyes
as
he
said
more

,
"
<EOS>
Esther
,
my
dearest
,
after
so

,
there
is
a
kind

in

.
 
<EOS>
I
know
that
my

.
 
<EOS>
Forgive
your
old
guardian
,
in

old

your

;
and
blot

of

.
 
<EOS>
Allan
,
take

dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
moved
away
from
under
the
green
roof
of
leaves
,
and
stopping
in
the
sunlight
outside
and
turning

,

,
"
I
shall
be
found
about
here
somewhere
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
west
wind
,
little
woman
,
due
west
!
 
<EOS>
Let
no
one
thank
me
any
more
,
for
I
am
going
to
revert
to
my
bachelor
habits
,
and
if
anybody
disregards
this
warning
,
I
'll
run
away
and
never
come
back
!
"
   
<EOS>
What
happiness
was
ours
that
day
,
what
joy
,
what
rest
,
what
hope
,
what
gratitude
,
<EOS>
what
bliss
!
 
<EOS>
We
were
to
be
married
before
the
month
was
out
,
but
when
we
were
to
come
and
take
possession
of
our
own
house
was
to
depend
on
Richard
and
Ada
.
   
<EOS>
We
all
three
went
home
together
next
day
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
we
arrived
in
town
,
Allan
went
straight
to
see
Richard
and
to
carry
our
joyful
news
to
him
and
my
darling
.
 
<EOS>
Late
as
it
was
,
I
meant
to
go
to
her
for
a
few
minutes
before
lying
down
to
sleep
,
but
I
went
home
with
my
guardian
first
to
make
his
tea
for
him
and
to
occupy
the
old
chair
by
his
side
,
for
I
did
not
like
to
think
of
its
being
empty
so
soon
.
   
<EOS>
When
we
came
home
we
found
that
a
young
man
had
called
three
times
in
the
course
of
that
one
day
to
see
me
and
that
having
been
told
on
the
occasion
of
his
third
call
that
I
was
not
expected
to
return
before
ten
o'clock
at
night
,
he
had
left
word
that
he
would
call
about
then
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
left
his
card
three
times
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Guppy
.
   
<EOS>
As
I
naturally
speculated
on
the
object
of
these
visits
,
and
as
I
always
associated
something
ludicrous
with
the
visitor
,
it
fell
out
that
in
laughing
about
Mr
Guppy
<EOS>
I
told
my
guardian
of
his
old
proposal
and
his
subsequent
retraction
.
 
<EOS>
"
After
that
,
"
said
my
guardian
,
"
we
will
certainly
receive
this
hero
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
instructions
were
given
that
Mr
Guppy
should
be
shown
in
when
he
came
again
,
and
they
were
scarcely
given
when
he
did
come
again
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
embarrassed
when
he
found
my
guardian
with
me
,
but
recovered
himself
and
said
,
"
How

"

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
65
.
<EOS>
Beginning
the
World
 
<EOS>
The
term
had
commenced
,
and
my
guardian
found
an
intimation
from
Mr
Kenge
that
the
cause
would
come
on
in

.
 
<EOS>
As
I
had
sufficient
hopes
of
the
will
to
be

flutter
about
it
,
Allan
and
I
agreed
to

down

.
 
<EOS>
Richard
was
extremely

and
was
so
weak
and
low
,
though

illness
was
still
of
the
mind
,
that
my
dear
girl
indeed
had
sore

be

.
 
<EOS>
But
she
looked
forward
---
a
very
little

---
to
the
help
that
was
to
come
to
her
,
and
never

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
at
Westminster
that
the
cause
was
to
come
on
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
come
on
there
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
a
hundred
times
before
,
but
I
could

of
an

that
it
MIGHT

some

now
.
 
<EOS>
We
left
home
directly
after

to
be
at
Westminster
Hall
in
good
time
and
walked
down
there
through
the
lively
streets
---
so
happily
and
strangely
it
seemed
!
<EOS>
---
together
.
   
<EOS>
As
we
were
going
along
,

what
we
should
do
for
Richard
and
Ada
,
I
heard

"
Esther
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Esther
!
 
<EOS>
Esther
!
"
<EOS>
And
there
was
Caddy
Jellyby
,
with
her
head
out
of
the
window
of
a
little

which
she

now
to
go
about
in
to
her
pupils
<EOS>
(
she
had
so
many
)
,
as
if

wanted
to

at
a

'

.
 
<EOS>
I
had

of
all
that
my
guardian
had
done
,
but
had

to
go
and
see

.
<EOS>
Of
course
we
turned
back
,
and
the
affectionate
girl
was
in
that
state
of
rapture
,
and
was
so
overjoyed
to
talk
about
the
night
when
she
brought
me
the
flowers
,
and
was
so
determined
to
squeeze
my
face
(
bonnet
and
all
)
between
her
hands
,
and
go
on
in
a
wild
manner
altogether
,
calling
me
all
kinds
of
precious

,
and
telling
Allan
I
had
done
I
do
n't
know
what
for
her
,
that
I
was
just
obliged
to
get
into
the
little

and
caln
her
down
by
letting
her
say
and
do
exactly
what
she
liked
.
 
<EOS>
Allan
,
standing
at
the
window
,
was
as
pleased
as
Caddy
;
and
I
was
as
pleased
as
either
of

;
and
I
wonder
that
I
got
away
as
I
did
,
rather
than
that
I
came
off
laughing
,
and
red
,
and
anything
but

,
and
looking
after
Caddy
,
who
looked
after
us
out
of
the
coach
-
window
as
long
as
she
could
see
us
.
   
<EOS>
This
made
us
some
quarter
of
an
hour
late
,
and
when
we
came
to
Westminster
Hall
we
found
that
the
day
's
business
was
begun
.
 
<EOS>
Worse
than
that
,
we
found
such
an
unusual
crowd
in
the
Court
of
Chancery
that
it
was
full
to
the
door
,
and
we
could
neither
see
nor
hear
what
was
passing
within
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
be
something
droll
,
for
occasionally
there
was
a
laugh
and
a
cry
of
"
Silence
!
"
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
be
something
interesting
,
for
every
one
was
pushing
and
striving
to
get
nearer
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
be
something
that
made
the
professional
gentlemen
very
merry
,
for
there
were
several
young
counsellors
in
wigs
and
whiskers
on
the
outside
of

crowd
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
We

cause

.
 
<EOS>
He

Jarndyce

Jarndyce
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Over

!
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

;

"

I

<EOS>
Down

There

,

upon

.
 
<EOS>
The

that
Sir
Leicester
paid
some
who
could
have
spoken

to

;
but
it
is
a

,

,
and
any

it

.
 
<EOS>
It

known

that
the

Dedlock
lies
in
the

,
where

,

;
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
Some

,

,
did
once

,

---
like

to

,
after

---
<EOS>
did
once

,
when

world

,
that

wondered
the
ashes
of
the
Dedlocks
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

-
and
-

take

.
   
<EOS>
Up

.
 
<EOS>
Then
may

<EOS>
Sir

---

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
War

,

,

<EOS>

Volumnia

Long

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

---

<EOS>

<EOS>

by
her
condescension
,
by
her
girlish
vivacity
,
and
by
her
skipping
about
as
in
the
days
when
the
hideous
old
general
with
the
mouth
too
full
of
teeth
had
not
cut
one
of
them
at
two
guineas
each
.
 
<EOS>
Then
does
she
twirl
and
twine
,
a
pastoral
nymph
of
good
family
,
through
the
mazes
of
the
dance
.
<EOS>
Then
do
the
swains
appear
with
tea
,
with
lemonade
,
with
sandwiches
,
with
homage
.
 
<EOS>
Then
is
she
kind
and
cruel
,
stately
and
unassuming
,
various
,
beautifully
wilful
.
 
<EOS>
Then
is
there
a
singular
kind
of
parallel
between
her
and
the
little
glass
chandeliers
of
another
age
embellishing
that
assembly
-
room
,
which
,
with
their
meagre
stems
,
their
spare
little
drops
,
their
disappointing
knobs
where
no
drops
are
,
their
bare
little
stalks
from
which
knobs
and
drops
have
both
departed
,
and
their
little
feeble
prismatic
twinkling
,
all
seem
Volumnias
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
rest
,
Lincolnshire
life
to
Volumnia
is
a
vast
blank
of
overgrown
house
looking
out
upon
trees
,
sighing
,
wringing
their
hands
,
bowing
their
heads
,
and
casting
their
tears
upon
the
window
-
panes
in
monotonous
depressions
.
 
<EOS>
A
labyrinth
of
grandeur
,
less
the
property
of
an
old
family
of
human
beings
and
their
ghostly
likenesses
than
of
an
old
family
of
echoings
and
thunderings
which
start
out
of
their
hundred
graves
at
every
sound
and
go
resounding
through
the
building
.
 
<EOS>
A
waste
of
unused
passages
and
staircases
in
which
to
drop
a
comb
upon
a
bedroom
floor
at
night
is
to
send
a
stealthy
footfall
on
an
errand
through
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
A
place
where
few
people
care
to
go
about
alone
,
where
a
maid
screams
<EOS>
if
an
ash
drops
from
the
fire
,
takes
to
crying
at
all
times
and
seasons
,
becomes
the
victim
of
a
low
disorder
of
the
spirits
,
and
gives
warning
and
departs
.
   
<EOS>
Thus
Chesney
Wold
.
 
<EOS>
With
so
much
of
itself
abandoned
to
darkness
and
vacancy
;
with
so
little
change
under
the
summer
shining
or
the
wintry
lowering
;
so
sombre
and
motionless
always
---
no
flag
flying
now
by
day
,
no
rows
of
lights
sparkling
by
night
;
with
no
family
to
come
and
go
,
no
visitors
to
be
the
souls
of
pale
cold
shapes
of
rooms
,
no
stir
of
life
about
it
---
passion
and
pride
,
even
to
the
stranger
's
eye
,
have
died
away
from
the
place
in
Lincolnshire
and
yielded
it
to
dull
repose
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
67
.
<EOS>
The
Close
of
Esther
's
Narrative
 
<EOS>
Full
seven
happy
years
<EOS>
I
have
been
the
mistress
of
Bleak
House
.
<EOS>
The
few
words
that
I
have
to
add
to
what
I
have
written
are
soon
penned
;
then
<EOS>
I
and
the
unknown
friend
to
whom
I
write
will
part
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
Not
without
much
dear
remembrance
on
my
side
.
 
<EOS>
Not
without
some
,
I
hope
,
on
his
or
hers
.
   
<EOS>
They
gave
my
darling
into
my
arms
,
and
through
many
weeks
I
never
left
her
.
 
<EOS>
The
little
child
who
was
to
have
done
so
much
was
born
before
the
turf
was
planted
on
its
father
's
grave
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
boy
;
and
<EOS>
I
,
my
husband
,
and
my
guardian
gave
him
his
father
's
name
.
   
<EOS>
The
help
that
my
dear
counted
on
did
come
to
her
,
though
it
came
,
in
the
eternal
wisdom
,
for
another
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Though
to
bless
and
restore
his
mother
,
not
his
father
,
was
the
errand
of
this
baby
,
its
power
was
mighty
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
saw
the
strength
of
the
weak
little
hand
and
how
its
touch
could
heal
my
darling
's
heart
and
raised
hope
within
her
,
I
felt
a
new
sense
of
the
goodness
and
the
tenderness
of
God
.
   
<EOS>
They
throve
,
and
by
degrees
<EOS>
I
saw
my
dear
girl
pass
into
my
country
garden
and
walk
there
with
her
infant
in
her
arms
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
married
then
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
the
happiest
of
the
happy
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
at
this
time
that
my
guardian
joined
us
and
asked
Ada
when
she
would
come
home
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Both
houses
are
your
home
,
my
dear
,
"
said

,
"
but

older

House

.
 
<EOS>
When
you
and

boy
are
strong

do

,
come

your
