.
"
   
<EOS>
Ada
called
him
"
her
dearest
cousin
,
John
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
he
said
,
no
,
it
must
be
guardian
now
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
her
guardian
henceforth
,
and
the
boy
's
;
and
he
had
an
old
association
with
the
name
.
 
<EOS>
So
she
called
him
guardian
,
and
has
called
him
guardian
ever
since
.
 
<EOS>
The
children
know
him
by
no
other
name
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
the
children
;
I
have
two
little
daughters
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
difficult
to
believe
that
Charley
(
round
-
eyed
still
,
and
not
at
all
grammatical
)
is
married
to
a
miller
in
our

;
yet
so
it

;
and
even
now
,
looking

write
early
in
the
morning
at
my
summer
window
<EOS>
,
I
see
the
very
mill
beginning
to
go
round
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
the
miller
will
not
spoil
Charley
;
but
he
is
very
fond
of
her
,
and
Charley
is
rather

of
such

match
,
for
he
is
well
to
do
and
was
in

.
 
<EOS>
So

my
small
maid
is

,
I

to
have
stood
for
seven
years
as
still
as

did
half

,
since
little
Emma
,

's

,
is

.
 
<EOS>
As

Tom
,
Charley
's

,
I
am
really

to
say
what
he
did
at
school
in
ciphering
,
but
I
think
it
was
decimals
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
apprenticed
to
the
miller
,
whatever
it
was
,
and
is
a
good
bashful
fellow
,
always
falling
in
love
with
somebody
and
being
ashamed
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
Caddy
Jellyby
passed
her
very
last
holidays
with
us
and
was
a
dearer
creature
than
ever
,
perpetually
dancing
in
and
out
of
the
house
with
the
children
as
if
she
had
never

-

.
 
<EOS>
Caddy
keeps
her
own
little

now
instead
of
hiring
one
,
and
lives
full
two
miles
further
westward
than
Newman
Street
.
 
<EOS>
She
works
very
hard
,
her
husband
(
an
excellent
one
)
being
lame
and
able
to
do
very
little
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
she
is
more
than
contented
and
does
all
she
has
to
do
with
all
her
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jellyby
spends
his
evenings
at
her
new
house
with
his
head
against
the
wall
as
he
used
to
do
in
her
old
one
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
heard
that
Mrs
Jellyby
was
understood
to
suffer
great
mortification
from
her
daughter
's
ignoble
marriage
and
pursuits
,
but
I
hope
she
got
over
it
in
time
.
<EOS>
She
has
been
disappointed
in
Borrioboola
-
Gha
,
which
turned
out
a
failure
in
consequence
of
the
king
of
Boorioboola
wanting
to
sell
everybody
---
who
survived
the
climate
---
for
rum
,
but
she

rights

women
to
sit
in

,
and
Caddy
tells
me
it
is
a
mission
involving
more
correspondence
than
the
old

.
 
<EOS>
I
had
almost
forgotten
Caddy
's
poor
little
girl
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
not
such
a
mite
now
,
but
she
is
deaf
and
dumb
.
 
<EOS>
I
believe
there
never
was
a
better
mother
than
Caddy
,
who
learns
,
in

of
leisure
,
innumerable
deaf
and
dumb
arts
to
soften

of
her

.
   
<EOS>
As
if
I
were
never
to
have
done
with
Caddy
,
I
am
reminded
here
of
Peepy
and
old
Mr
Turveydrop
.
 
<EOS>
Peepy
is
in
the
Custom
House
,
and
doing
extremely
well
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Mr
Turveydrop
,
very
apoplectic
,
still
exhibits
his
deportment
about
town
,
still
enjoys
himself
in
the
old

,
is
still

in
in
the
old

.
 
<EOS>
He
is
constant
in
his

of
Peepy
and
is
understood
to
have
bequeathed
him
a
favourite
French
clock
in
his
dressing
-
room
---
which
is
not
his
property
.
   
<EOS>
With
the
first
money
we
saved
at
home
,
we
added
to
our
pretty
house
by
throwing
out
a
little

expressly
for
my
guardian
,
which
we
inaugurated
with
great

the
next

came

to

.
 
<EOS>
I
try
to
write
all
this
lightly
,
because
my
heart
is
full
in
drawing
to
an
end
,
but
when
I
write
of
him
,
my
tears
will
have
their
way
.
   
<EOS>
I
never
look
at
him
<EOS>
but
I
hear
our
poor
dear
Richard
calling
him
a
good
man
.
 
<EOS>
To
Ada
and
her
pretty
boy
,
he
is
the
fondest
father
;
to
me
he
is
what
he
has
ever

,
and
what

to

?
<EOS>
He
is
my

's
best
and

friend
,
he

our
children
's
darling
,
he
is

and

.
 
<EOS>
Yet
while
I
feel

him
as
if

,
I
am
so

with

and
so

that
I
almost

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
lost
my
old
names
,
nor
has
he
lost

;
nor
do

ever
,

,

,
Dame
Trot

,
Little
Woman
---
all

;
and

,
"
Yes
,
dear

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
just

.
   
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

,
no
,

.
   
<EOS>
I

girl

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>

Richard

<EOS>
I

!
 
<EOS>
But

.
   
<EOS>
We

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

degree
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I
never

night

but

he
has

fellow
-

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
thanks

,

,
in

,

.
 
<EOS>
Is

rich
?
   
<EOS>
The

doctor
's
wife
.
 
<EOS>
The

even

me
as
I

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
I
owe

to
him
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
They
like
me
for
his

,
as
I
do

I
do

for
his

.
   
<EOS>
A

,

and

Richard
,

-
morrow
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
So

,
"
My

,

?
"
 
<EOS>
And

,
"
The

,
Allan
,

,
that
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
How

are
!
"
said
I.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
almost

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
thinking

my
old
looks
---
such
as
they
were
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

have

been

about
THEM
,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have

thinking
that
I

was

that
you
COULD
have
loved

any

,

.
"
   
"
<EOS>
"
Such
as

were
"
?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Such

were
,

.
"
   
"
My
dear
Dame
Durden
,
"
said
Allan
,
drawing
my
arm
through
his
,
"
do
you
ever
look
in
the
glass
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know

do
;
you
see

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
do
n't

know
that
you
are
prettier
than

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
know
that
;
I
am
not
certain
that
I
know

now
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
know
that
my
dearest
little
pets
are
very
pretty
,
and
that
my
darling
is
very
beautiful
,
and
that
my
husband
is
very
handsome
,
and
that
my
guardian
has
the
brightest
and
most
benevolent
face
that
ever
was
seen
,
and
that
they
can
very
well
do
without
much
beauty
in
me
---
even
supposing
---
.
     
<EOS>
